title: Excerpts From Statement and Speeches at Communist Meeting in East Berlin
description: Conference Document

title: French Jet's Hijackers Free 47 in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 30 Hijackers of a French jetliner freed 47 hostages today, including an American woman and her 6yearold son, but continued to hold about 210 others, including more than 70 Israelis, under threat of death. Those freedmothers, children, ailing and elderly peoplewere put on a special flight to Paris.

title: Velasquez Takes Title on Foul Blow
description: MADRID. June 30 (AP)Miguel Velasquez of Spain won the World Boxing Council's junior welterweight title tonight from Saaensak Muangsuring of Thailand on a disqualification in the fourth round of their scheduled 15round fight.

title: Sudden Death, an Unreal
description: Three weeks ago Sus McCready bought a stack of guidebooks to national parks, planning a crosscountry trip she and her husband were to begin today. Two days later, she bought a cuifin.

title: WEST PON GIVEN CODE ASSURANCE
description: WASHINGTON. June 30Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of a Senate subcommittee investigating military academy honor codes, assured West Point Officials today that no new honor code will be legislated from I.Vashington.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Tuesday stated incorrectly that the Community Savings Bank in Rochester would cease to pay the maximum interest rate of 73/4 percent on savings certificates, starting July I. The hank will continue to pay the maximum rate.

title: Carter Talks With Meany and Two From Jersey
description: WASHINGTON. June 30I.Iimmy Carter, meeting today with George Meant', president lof the A.F.L.C.I.O.. to solicit the labor leader's advice on his !choice of a Vice Presidential running mate, found Mr. !NIeany's organization still unwilling to endorse him for the Presidency.

title: Evehts Today
description: Theater

title: Student Figures Revised
description: The State Education Department said yesterday it had made public incorrect figures on the number of parttime students expected to attend private colleges In the state by 1984. The correct figure is 144,000, the department said.

title: EUROPEAN REDS BACK AUTONOMY FOR EACH PARTY
description: EAST BERLIN, June 30A twoday conference of European Communist leaders, marked by deep divisions over tactics and ideology, ended today with the issuing of a document endorsing the independence of each party to find its own path to Socialism.

title: KEY CANADIAN AIDE QUITS OVER AIR PACT
description: OTTAWA, June 30 (UN)Environment Minister Jean Marchand, a key aide to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's since the days they entered federal politics, today resigned his cabinet post in disagreement with the way Canada's recent air strike was ended.

title: U.S. Judge Stays End of Aid to DayCare Centers
description: U.S. Judge Stays End of Aid to DayCare Centers

title: MILTON J. MEYER
description: Dr. Milton Joseph Meyer, who practiced family medicine in Brooklyn for 34 years, died, on Tuesday at his home. He was 61 years old and lived at 135 Willow Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section. Dr. Meyer was a staff associate at the Beekman Downtown Hospital in Manhattan. He is survived by his wife, Teresa; his mother, Gertrude Meyer, and two brothers, Mervin and Leonard.

title: Ford Endorsed Formally by Goldwater
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Senator Barry Goldwater urged the Republican Party today to nominate President Ford for a full term in the White House to continue turning this country back in the right direction.

title: Kapp's Bid for New Trial Denied
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (UPI)A Federal judge denied a motion today by Joe Kapp for a new trial in his damage suit against the National Football League. The former pro quarterback lost a suit in a jury trial earlier this year and his lawyers argued before United States District Judge William T. Sweigert for a new trial and also for a judgment notwithstanding the jury verdict. The judge denied both motions. Kapp had charged that was not allowed to play professional football and was illeeallv denrived of his livina.

title: Workers Strike Airport
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., June 30 (AP)About 10 workers at the WilkesBarreScranton Airport walked off the job today, forcing Allegheny and Eastern Airlines to cancel some flights.

title: Britain May Ease Its Price Controls
description: LONDON, June 30The British Government published proposals today designed to ease its price controls slightly and allow Britsih business to become more profitable.

title: Notes on People
description: The Federal Communications Commission's equal time rule for political candidates apparently takes precedence even over the Bicentennial. For almost two years now, CBSTV has been showing nightly Bicentennial Minutes, and quite logically, the network had planned to devote its grandest 60 seconds on the Fourth of July to a message from the President. But he is in a political race, and if he appearec it would mean other candidates for the Presidency would have to receive equal time. So Paul Waigner, producer of the series, settled on having Betty Ford, the President's wife, deliver THE Bicentennial minute. Mrs. Ford is perfect, he said. She is one of the most important people in our country.

title: Knock Knock
description: Knock Knock, the Jules Feiffer comedy, will end its run at the Biltmore Theater on Saturday after 152 performances. Terry Allen Kramer and Harry Rigby, by arrangement with the Circle Repertory Company, were the sponsors of the Broadway presentation, which was directed by Jose Quintero. Lynn Redgrave, Charles Durning, John Heffernan and Leonard Frey made up the cast.

title: U.S. Tells Why It Denied Asylum to 2
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Ford Administration officials said today that they had refused political asylum last week to two Lithuanians who in 1970 hijacked a Soviet airliner to Turkey because the United States could not appear to slacken in its opposition to international piracy.

title: BEIRUT RIGHTISTS SAID TO CAPTURE PALESTINIAN SITE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30One of two besieged Palestinian camps here reportedly fell to rightwing Christian forces last night after eight days of fighting.

title: Shad Polier, Lawyer, Dead; Active in Civil Rights Cases
description: Shad Polier, the civil rights lawyer who won early prominence as part of the defense team in the landmark Scottsboro case 45 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 175 East 64th Street. He was 70 years old.

title: PENTAGON WARNS LITTON ON SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) A top Pentagon official said today that we will take steps to assure that Litton Industries continues construction of four new helicopter assault shins.

title: Interim Agreement Erases Threat of Municipal Strike
description: After a daylong series of snags, delays and false starts, New York City and its labor unions agreed yesterday on a memorandum of interim understanding, lifting the threat of a strike and clearing the way for Federal loans that would avert default.

title: Jersey Schools Closed by Court Order
description: TRENTON, Tnursaay, July 1 An order by the New Jersey Supreme Court closing the state's 6,000 public schools unless they were constitutionally financed took effect at 12:01 this morning while the Legislature remained deadlocked past the midnight deadline over a method of raising the $378 million necessary to keep summer school programs nnerating.

title: Hubbard in Fine Form in Two Shows
description: Tuesday evening at the Newport Jazz Festival belonged to Freddie Hubbard. The trumpeter was in fine form early in the evening at the Herbie Hancock Retrospect, and then he made a late appearance with Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Blakey, who had featured Mr. Hubbard in his Messengers in the 1960's, kicked up a rhythmic firestorm behind the trumpeter, and the result was another superb performance

title: POLICE STANDARDS TERMED SEX BIAS
description: ATLANTA, June 30A three judge Federal panel in Alabama has ruled that the state's minimum height and weight requirements for police personnel illegally discriminate against women.

title: Jazz Events
description: Following is a schedule of today's Newport Jazz FestivalNew York events:

title: 2 DIED, 75 WERE HURT IN RIOTING IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, June 30 (UPI)Two demonstrators were killed and 75 policemen were injured last week in rioting that forced the Polish Government to cancel foodprice increases, Polish television said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 1, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful

title: National Communism
description: Symbolically, the East Berlin meeting of 29 European Communist Parties was a triumph for national Communism.

title: FORD SCHEDULES HOLIDAY SPEECHES
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) President Ford will visit. Val. ley Forge, Pa., Philadelphia, New York and Charlottesville, Va., on the long Fourth of July weekend marking the country's Bicentennial.

title: HIGH COURT BARS SCHOOLS'
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review a lower court's decision declining to order further steps to desegregate Chattanooga, Tenn., public schools despite the existence of nearly allblack high schools.

title: ISRAEL ANNULS EDICT ON PRAYER BY ARABS
description: TEL AVIV, June 30The District Court in Jerusalem today set aside a cantroversial magistrate court's ruling on prayer Tights that had led to Arab rioting earlier this year.

title: Brzezinski Visiting Israel
description: TEL AVIV, June 30 (Reuters) Prof. Zbigniew Brzezinski, chief foreign policy adviser to Jimmy Carter, arrived here today for a threeday stay during which he will meet Israel's tong leaders.

title: Long Bicentennial Row
description: AVALON, June 30Their skin a deep red from the sun and wind and their joints aching from nearly two months of rowing, two former lifeguards have begun the final phase of a 1,400mile journey from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to the Statue of Liberty.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission proposed that Jersey Central Power and Light Company be fined $8,000 for alleged infractions of security rules at its Oyster Creek nuclear power plant near Toms River. The commission's office of inspection and enforcement launched an investigation at the plant April 26 after a newsman told the commission he had walked through an open gate at the plant without being stopped by guards. The investigators from the agency's Philadelphia regional office verified the entry and alleged that Jersey Power officials had failed to notify the police promptly.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Kingman Is All Hit, No Talk
description: Dave Kingman probably would rather talk about the effect of gamma rays on maninthemoon marigolds than homerun records. Kingman wants nothing to do with discussions of homerun records. The records hell take. But the discussions, leave out.

title: AWARD ESTABLISHED IN SCRIPPS MEMORY
description: The ScrippsHoward Foundation yesterday announced the establishment of an annual jourInalism award for outstanding public service in the cause of the First Amendment guarantee of a free press.

title: Todd Is a Student of Sorts At Namath's Football Camp
description: DUDLEY, Mass.The present and future quarterbacks of the New York Jets, Joe Namath and Richard Todd, stood naked in the women's locker room at Nichols Collene.

title: A Restored Custom House Glows for Bicentennial
description: The United States Custom House on Bowling Green, an opulent monument to New York's role in sea trade, has been scrubbed and restored until it glows like a pearl.

title: DRILLING OPPOSED BY NEW YORK SUIT
description: State and Private Group Are Fighting U.S. Leasing Plan

title: Lightning Kills Man In Jersey as Storm Hits a 3State Area
description: Severe thunderstorms swept areas of New Jersey, southern New York and eastern Connecticut yesterday with heavy winds that knocked down power lines and lightning that struck and killed one young man and injured a second.

title: People in Sports
description: Nick Foam, a 24yearold Staten Islander, has become the first native New Yorker to sign with the New York Rangers. The signing of the 6foot2inch, 200pound enforcer to a twoyear pact was announced yesterday by the Rangers general managercoach, John Ferguson, who apparently is continuing his quest to add muscle to the club.

title: OneYear Increase In Stabilized Rents Narrowed by Board
description: Tenants renewing leases in many of New York City's 700,000 rentstabilized apartments in the year starting today will face maximum rent increases of 6.5 percent for a oneyear renewal lease, 8 percent for twoyear renewal, and 11 percent for a threeyear renewal, the city's Rent Guidelines Board announced yesterday.

title: U,S, RETAIL SALES MAKE JUNE GAINS
description: Reversal of April and May Buying Lag Indicated, but Price Cuts Trim Profits

title: BEIRUT RIGHTISTS SAID TO CAPTURE PALESTINIAN SITE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30One of two besieged Palestinian camps here reportedly fell to rightwing Christian forces last night after eight days of fighting.

title: GEICO PROPOSES SALE OF STOCKS
description: Directors Planning to Offer Preferred Shares if Bid to Sell Convertibles Fails

title: Chess:
description: A rook and two pawns are equivalent to two minor pieces, and yet games in which the opposing sides are thus arrayed do not usually end in draws. When this material is all there is left on the board, the side with the rook has the only winning chances and, if the pawns are connected, that side Invariably wins.

title: Oil Curbs to Lapse
description: Democrats in Congress failed to block an Administration plan to suspend mandatory price and allocation controls for heating oil, diesel fuel and kerosene, raising the possibility of autumn and winter price rises. Page 39.

title: Advertising
description: Burger King is having it its way. It is splitting with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn effective Sept. 30. The account billed over $15.7 million in measured media last year.

title: Banished Priest Reportedly Had a Real Estate License
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Rev. Guido John Carcich, the Pallottine priest banished from the Baltimore area amid complaints about the order's use of its funds, was also licensed to sell real estate in Maryland and Florida, according to The Washington Post.

title: Pentagon Papers Ruling Issued Five Years Ago
description: WASHINGTON, June 30It was five years ago todaythat the Supreme Court handed down what is regarded as one of its most important decisions concerning prior restraint, ruling that the Government could not prevent publication of the Pentagon papers.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes of stock ownership by large shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Jersey Schools Closed by Court Order
description: TRENTON, Thursday, July 1 An order by the New Jersey Supreme Court closing the state's 6,000 public schools unless they were constitutionally financed took effect at 12:01 this morning while the Legislature remained deadlocked past the midnight deadline over a method of raising the $378 million necessary to keep summer school programs operating.

title: Cosmos Defeat Lancers On Goals by Field, 2 to
description: With a new coach, a new goalkeeper and a new emphasis on attack the New York Cosmos got two goals from Tony Field and defeated the Rochester Lancers, 20, at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Du Pont Sees 20% Rise In Sales, 15% Unit Gain

title: Burglaries by F.B.I. As Late as 197273 Conceded by Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who previously insisted in Congressional testimony and elsewhere that burglaries by bureau agents were halted in 1966, confirmed today that the bureau carried out in 1972 and 1973 a limited number of breakins directed at radical domestic and terrorist groups.

title: Troy Says He Will Admit Guilt in a Tax Fraud Case
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., finance chairman of the City Council, said yesterday that he intended to plead guilty in Federal Court today to a charge of filing a fraudulent Federal income tax return for 1972.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Approximately 60,000 Long Island Rail Road commuters were delayed last evening by a derailment in Pennsylvania Station that blocked two of four tunnels leading into and out of the station, according to the railroad. A Long Island spokesman said some commuters had been delayed more than an hour by the incident which he said occurred shortly before 5 o'clock when the engine of an empty Conrail train derailed as it was coming into the station from Queens. The train was removed about 6:15 P.M., but another hour elapsed before operations began returning to normal, the spokesman said.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD JURY TRIAL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Supreme Court ruled today, to 4, that a state may deny a defendant a jury in his initial trial on a criminal charge if it allows the defendant, through an appeal, to get a second trial in which there is a jury.

title: Red Sox Complete Sweep of Orioles
description: The Boston Red Sox, nine games behind the firstplace New York Yankees in the American League's Eastern Division, revived memories of 1975 at Fenway Park yesterday as the defending league champions defeated Baltimore, 64, to complete threegame series sweep. And they did it against the league's last undefeated pitcher.

title: Faith Hackl Is Wed To James Stewart
description: The marriage of Faith Severance Hackl of Princeton, N.J., widow of George F. Hackl Jr., to James P. Stewart, also of Princeton, took place there yesterday afternoon. Dean Ernest Gordon performed the Protestant ceremony in the Princeton University Chanel.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 30In seeming change of tactics, the New Jersey Education Association has maintained a low profile for more than a month in the school crisis.

title: A Communist Milestone
description: EAST BERLIN, June 30The European Communist leaders who concluded their twoday conference here today had a variety of views on the importance of their meeting and the document it issued. That variety itself, a fundamental break with the tradition of official conformity, was probably the most important aspect of their session.

title: Open Wound in Upstate Hills Now Resounds to the Call of Birds
description: GARRISON, N. Y.More than a century ago, these Hudson Valley Highlands echoed to the groans and creaks of heavy equipment, the shouts of sinewy laborers who cut into the hills to find thousands of tons of granite. needed for construction projects in New York City. then rapidly growing 50 miles to the south.

title: Aussie Wins Again in Yachting Series
description: HANKOE, Norway. June 30 (AP)Frank Tolhurst of Australia won his third race in the 5.5meter world championship yachting series today, then announced he had sold his yacht. Arunga, to LarsGoeran Johnsson of Sweden.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Enigmatic Side of Carter
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 With his nomination assured, Jimmy Carter still occasionally fences with the reporters traveling with him who, use these occasions to try to plumb his character. But the encounters often leave the reporters just as puzzled about his personality as beforehand.

title: ... Dangerous Outbursts
description: In the wake of last week's dramatic confrontation between Poland's workers and Poland's Government, the latter has been working hard to repair its image. Illadvised and large food price increases had precipitated violent worker reactions and strikes in many places, inducing panic and immediate surrender on the issue in Warsaw.

title: New Financial Support Gained Rv Ontimistic Saturday Review
description: Saturday Review, which has been struggling back from its 1973 bankruptcy, gained new financial support yesterday.

title: Third Turtle, a Trimaran, Tons Class in Atlantic Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 30Into this city's spacious harbor, jammed with the world's largest sailing ships and hundreds of others not so large, came an innocuous vessel before dawn today, tacking amon2 the Eiants.

title: PRICE OF COPPER INCREASED AGAIN
description: Kennecott and Phelps Dodge Announce Rises of 4 Cents a Pound to 74 Cents

title: Market Place
description: Many stock market observers are baffled because the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 leading stocks, the I most widely watched indicator of stock market health, has not been able to stay above 1,000.

title: TV: Mary Hartman Is Ill Till Fall
description: With all the hoopla this week about Bicentennial celebrations, a few dazed souls may be in danger of overlooking the fact that Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman will be concluding its first run of 26 episodes tomorrow evening. Those who have detected a remarkable reflection of contemporary America in the series should be delighted to learn that we leave Mary, only temporarily, as the victim of a complete and total nervous breakdown.

title: HOSPITAL STRIKE HELD PROBABLE
description: After meeting yesterday with state officials who control most of the income hospitals now receive, Federal mediators and representatives of the hospitals and the union involved saw litthe hope of avoiding a strikes at most of the city's voluntary hospitals next Wednesday.

title: 2 Brothers Reunited by Adoption
description: William Logan, who spent two years ling at Bellevue Hospital because nobody wanted him until he was adopted by Florence Logan last December, ran to the front door of his apartment yesterday and threw his arms around another little boy. Willie, 11 years old, was wel1 comiag home his brother, Ricky, 9, who is also being adopted by Mrs. Logan after a ,search was made to find the boy who was, as far as Willie was concerned, lost somewhere within the vast fostercare system.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Legislature Closes
description: The New York Legislature ended its 1976 regular session in Albany yesterday morning after a 19hour marathon that included enactment of a reduced pension system for future public employees and failure to agree on court reorganization amendments. Page 26.

title: Rainout Halts Yanks Brief Slump
description: DETROIT, June 30Rain brought a halt to a brief slump of the New York Yankees and the sudden exhilaration of the Detroit Tigers tonight as the scheduled finale of their threegame series was washed out by a steady downpour. No date for a makeup game was announced.

title: Technology Shares Lead RallyDow Gains 2.13 Points
description: Stock prices pushed ahead yesterday on steppedup volume as the broad market outperformed the bluechip Dow Jones industrials.

title: `Retrospective
description: The Idea of mounting a retrospective for a 36yearold jazz musician might seem just a touch premature. But Herbie Hancock, the recipient of such a tribute Tuesday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, courtesy of the Newport Jazz Festival, is not only a flashy keyboard player but also the producer of a record, Headhunters, that sold a million conies in 1974.

title: Frazzled Legislators Cast Decorum Aside
description: ALBANY, June 30Morning sunlight brought a muted glow to the leaded stainedglass windows in the Assembly chamber today as lawmakers and their aides churned through the 19th straight hour of business, watching as their bizarre political slumber party deteriorated into a legislative version of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

title: Heating Oil Controls to Lapse, Opening Way for Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Democrats failed tonight in separate attempts in the House and Senate to prevent the Ford Administration from suspending mandatory price and allocation controls for heating oil, diesel fuel and kerosene.

title: Jazz Minister's Flock To Honor Him Tonight
description: He does not sing. He does not play an instrument. He does not write or arrange music. Yet tonight men and women who do all of those things will turn out at Radio City Music Hall to honor himthe Rev. John Garcia Gensel, minister to the iazz community.

title: May Inventory Rise Big; Orders Show Strong Gain
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Manufacturers inventories rose by $1 billion in May. the largest monthly increase since the economic recovery began, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: The Korshak Series
description: Sidney R. Korshak, an attorney with important connections to legitimate businesses, labor unions and organized crime, has never been indicted. Yet, as is clearly demonstrated by the series of articles in The Times on Mr Korshak, concluded yesterday. there is a great deal of evidencemuch of it already in the hands of Federal agenciesthat might have warranted indictment on charges of having committed many illegalities, including bribery, kickbacks, extortion, fraud and labor racketeering.

title: Farmers Slaughter Herds as Drought Afflicts Europe
description: LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) After weeks of scorching sunshine, Western Europe is suffering the effects of serious drought. Farmers desperately need rain for their parched land and livestock.

title: Keenan Sworn In to Succeed Nadjari
description: John F. Keenan was sworn in as special New York State prosecutor yesterday and pledged that his untiring efforts will be directed towards the discovery and eradication of corruption in the criminaljustice system wherever it exists.

title: Wilmington Coach Named
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, June 30 (AP)John Ferguson was named today head basketball coach at Wilmington College, which won 3 of 27 games last season.

title: IVAN F. BAKER DIES; BUSINESS EXECUTIVE
description: Ivan Franklin Baker, a former senior vice president and treasurer of the Westinghouse Company died Tuesday at Muhlenberg Hcspital near his home in Westfield, N.J.. He was 89.

title: Special Security Is Planned for 2 Operation Sail Ships
description: Two Operation Sail squareriggers will get special security attention during the Fourth of July celebration herethe Chilean training schooner Esmeralda target for political protests,I and the Colombian bark Gloria, on which cocaine was reportedly found a fortnight ago.

title: Korshak Leaves Hospital After Intestinal Illness
description: Sidney R. Korshak was released yesterday from Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago after treatment for a gastrointestinal disorder, a hospital official said.

description: MILTON J. MEYER

title: President Appoints Panel To Study Cities
description: MILWAUKEE, June 30President Ford has appointed a 13member committee that includes eight Cabinet members to study the problems of the cities.

title: Ford Signs Measure To Extend Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)Only five hours before a midnight deadline, President Ford signed a bill today that will protect the paychecks of American workers from increased income tax withholding for two more months.

title: Basenji, Purchased as a Pet, Turns Out as Champion for His Owner
description: Not every dog is a show dog.

title: Dance Spell Defeats Zen at Aqueduct
description: Both Zen and the crowd may have been a little short yesterday as Aqueduct opened a 28day meeting with the 69th running of the Saranac Stakes.

title: Sahara Rebels Name Chief
description: ALGIERS, June 30 (AP)Mahmoud Larussi, the deputy leader of the Polisario Front the Algerianbacked Saharan independence movement, has been named interim leader, it was announced here. He replaces Mustapha Sayed el Vali, who, the announcement said, had fallen in the field of honor.

description: Soybeans Aided by Rumor of Soviet Buying Plan

title: Ford's Delegate Lead Is Put at Only 34
description: WASHINGTON. June 30An incumbent President 44 votes short of nomination, his challenger 48 votes short, and 91 uncommitted delegates holding the balance.

title: A.M.A. GETS PLAN TO CURB DOCTORS
description: DALLAS, June 30  The American Medical Association took its first step today toward establishing a national policy on the disciplining of physicians.

title: After 200 Long Summers, Philadelphia Still Enjoys A Party for Any Occasion
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 30Two centuries ago, after finishing a preliminary draft of the unanimous Declaration of the thirteen united States of America, young Thomas Jefferson returned to his desk in a stifling little apartment here, picked up a fresh quill and wrote a letter home to Virginia.

title: Stage: Historical Farce
description: If Gen. William Howe hadn't stopped to dine at Mrs. Murray's farm, the story goes, 5,000 American soldiers would have been trapped in Lower Manhattan and the War of Independence might have ended there and then.

description: It was a case of tit for tat. On Monday, when the Mostly Mozart Festival opened at Alice Tully Hall, the instrumental ensemble called Tashi supplied the concerto soloists for the orchestra program, which Alexander Schneider conducted.

title: Gag Order Ruling Hailed By Newsmen and Lawyers
description: I When word first came yesterday that the Supreme Court had unanimously struck down a gag order imposed on the press in a murder trial in Nebraska, jubilation spread among hundreds of newspapermen and lawyers who had anxiously been awaiting the outcome. Many of them immediately viewed the Court's 9to0 decision as a spectacular victory.

title: Carswell Indicted On Florida Charge Of Sexual Advance
description: TALLAHASSEE, FIG., June 30 (UPI)  Former Federal Judge G. Harrold Carswell, a nominee to the Supreme Court in 1970, was indicted today on charges of making a homosexual approach to a vice squad policeman.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ACCENT ON YOUTH The Bicentennial Salute to Broadway in midtown today at noon will be rendered not by show business specialists but by nonprofessional young people, ranging in age from 8 to 20. Some 125 colorfully costumed members of the Performing Arts Group of the Police Athletic League will perform at the W. R. Grace Plaza, Avenue of the Americas and 43d Street, in the nostaglie songanddance salute to American show busi

description: The United buttes custom House on Bowling Green, an opulent monument to New York's role in sea trade has been scrubbed and restored until it elows like a pearl.

title: OUTPUT OF GASOLINE SETS A RECORD AGAIN
description: Gasoline production in the nation rose to a record level for the fourth consecutive week, moving stocks of motor fuel higher, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: U.S. Court Acts to Bar State's Violation of Own Law
description: TRENTON, June 30The 11member Federal Court refused today to enjoin the order of the State Supreme Court to close the state school system at midnight unless it was fully financed because, the panel said, it did not want to force New Jersey to perpetuate a violation of its own constitution.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Wednesday, June 30, 1976

title: SCHORR WON'T BE AT CONVENTIONS
description: Daniel Schorr, who participated in the CBS News coverage of most of the recent political conventions, will be lecturing, writing and vacationing in Aspen. Colo., when the Democrats hold their national convention in Manhattan the week of July 12. He will be involved in other personal travel in August when the Republicans convene in Kansas City.

title: New U.S. Debt Limit Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to President Ford today a bill extending the limit on the Federal debt to $700 billion. WithJut the bill, the current limit of $527 billion would have expired at midnight, theoretically depriving the Government of authority to pay its bills.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: An article in The Times on Tuesday stated incorrectly that the Community Savings Bank in Rochester would cease to pay the maximum interest rate of 73A percent on savings certificates, starting July 1. The bank will continue to pay the maximum rate.

title: Polo Tourney Postponed
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 30The opening of the Northeastern Circuit 12goal polo tournament was postponed today because of wet grounds at Hickox Field. A doubleheader is scheduled for Friday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Tall Ships Sail Into Newport Social Seas
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 30There is a strong belief in some circles that an earthquake might pass unnoticed in social Newport's sea of serenity unless, of course, the tea cups rattled. That would be cause for irritation. Nothing much excites the Old Guard, or the. New Guard who are trying to become Old Guard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Finance: Medical History
description: Applications for life insurance generally require listing of illnesses and diseases arising or existing during the last five years. Although many persons may be hesitant to do so, it is wise to provide full and accurate information on the form.

title: `Blazing Ubiquities
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Our country, right or wrong! cried naval officer Stephen Decatur, in a toast that is now uncomfortably regarded as the apogee of patriotic fervor. In this century G. K. Chesterton undermined the enthusiasm for Decatur's devotion with a quiet toast of his own: My mother, drunk or sober.

title: 2 Fraehauf Officials Given Jail Terms For Evading Taxes
description: DETROIT, June 30 (AP)Two top executives of a leading truck  trailer manufacturer were sentenced to prison terms today on charges of conspiring to evade paying more than $12.3 million in Federal excise taxes owed by the corporation.

title: Suspect Seizes Gun At a Police Station, EscapesinMidtownj
description: A robbery suspect being fingerprinted at the Midtown Precinct North police station yesterday afternoon suddenly grabbed the gun of the officer who had arrested him and escaped into the midday crowds on Ninth Avenue at 54th Street.

title: Amalrik, in Dispute, Delays His Soviet Departure
description: AMSTERDAM. June 30Andrei Amalrik, the Russian dissident author, tonight put off his scheduled departure fr)m the Soviet Union when new obstacles were put in his way by Soviet authorities.

title: Italian Fencers Hurt
description: RAVENNA, Italy, June 30 (UPI)Two members of Italy's Olympic epee fencing team, Stefano Bellone and Stefano Romanelli, were injured in a car crash today. Bellone suffered head injuries and will miss the Olympics.

title: By The Associated Press
description: Lawrence, Mass.  Tommy Rose, 130 pounds, Shearborn, Mass., knocked out Bobby Castaneda, 125 Brockton, Mass., 7 rounds.

title: WILLIAM CALDWELL, RETIRED PROFESSOR
description: Dr. William T. Caldwell, retired chemistry professor and former dean at Temple University, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J. He was 81 years old and a resident of Red Bank.

title: Books of The Times
description: James Michener has left no blade of grass unturned in his exhaustive and sometimes exhausting Sports in America. He is a bit like the great Jim Brown the way he plunges ahead through dense masses of material. Somewhere in these pages, Mr. Michener says that, when he is about to begin a book, he gets into training much as an athlete would, and one can easily believe him. His energy in researching his subject is prodigious and it is only his monolithic clearheadedness and confident sense of purpose that keep Sports in America from degenerating into an anarchy of information or an embarrassment of riches.

title: Postal Rate Increase by Spring Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Postal Rate Commission announced today approval of the present 13cent stamp, clearing the way for the Postal Service to set higher temporary postage rates as early as next wring.

title: Interim Agreement Erases Threat of Municipal Strike
description: After a daylong series of snags, delays and false starts, New York City and its labor unions agreed yesterday on a memorandum of interim understanding, lifting the threat of a strike and clearing the way for Federal loans that would avert default.

title: Burglaries by F.B.I. As Late as 197273 Conceded by Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, June 3u Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who previously insisted in Congressional testimony and elsewhere that burglaries by bureau agents were halted in 1966, confirmed today that the bureau carried out in 1972 and 1973 a limited number of breakins directed at radical domestic and terrorist groups.

title: For Olivia de Havilland, a RealLife Mother Role
description: What is Olivia de Havilland doing these days? To listen to her tell it, she is playing a supporting role to a girl she describes as a ravishing 19yearold. She and Gisele Galante, her daughter by her second husband, Pierre Galante, live in Paris and she describes her main function as answering the telephone and taking messages when her daughter's many beaux call.

title: Panel Reprimands A Brooklyn Judge For Primary Role
description: A State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn has been reprimanded for carelessness and injudiciousness for his role in a closely contested Democratic Congressional primary in 1972.

Black, a Canadian business consultant and company director who helped set up the Commonwealth Air Training Plan under which thousands of airmen from all parts of the British Commonwealth were trained in Canada in World War II, died yesterday. He was 65 years old.

Lord Hugh Russell, chairman of the British team selectors, said that if all went well, the Princess and her husband would be among the Olympic competitors.

title: The Tall Ships Give Newport a Sparkle That Even Garbage and Fog Cannot Quite Diminish
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 30The sea breeze is smelling a bit less salty lately, especially on the windward side of the tall ships in Newport harbor. Sometimes it's just smelling. Garbage collection is one of the least glamorous and most obvious problems of Operation Sail. The tall ships berthed by the pier are getting daily collections by a private concern contracted by the State of Rhode Island.

title: Rules and Ruin
description: In spite of overwhelming sentiment in favor of saving North Carolina's New River from disaster, that remarkable stream is now in greater danger than ever. Both houses of the state's General Assembly, its governor, virtually all of its press and its entire delegation in Congress have been attempting to prevent a subsidiary of the American Electric Power Company from ruining the river, noted for its archeological riches as well as its beauty, in order to accommodate a hydroelectric storage project.

title: Newport Jazz Festival
description: The question of why contemporary jazz bands have difficulty recreating the music of bands of the 20's and 30's was brought into focus at the second of the Newport Jazz Festival's four concerts on Duke Ellington's music, presented on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall by the New York Jazz Repertory Company.

title: NASSAU ASSESSES TAXRISE EFFECT
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 30The new onecent increase in Nassau County's sales tax will reduce competitive advantages the county's businesses now have over New York City merchants, but shoppers and businessmen interviewed today said they did not anticipate any major changes in consumer habits as a result.

title: EUROPEAN REDS BACK AUTONOMY FOR EACH PARTY
description: EAST BERLIN, June 30A twoday conference of European Communist leaders, marked by deep divisions over tactics and Ideology, ended today with the Issuing of a document endorsing the independence of each party to find its own path to Socialism.

title: 'Silent Movie' With Golden Subtitles
description: You might suspect that Mel Brooks's decision to make a contemporary silent movie titled "Silent Movie," starring himself as a director trying to make a silent movie today, was not the wisest thing he'd ever done, and you'd be right. But having recognized that fact immediately, you can relax and enjoy "Silent Movie" as a virtually uninterrupted series of smiles.The film, which opened yesterday at the Cinema 1 and 2, doesn't contain a single moment that ever seriously threatens to split the sides, which, I suppose, will strike fanatical Brooks watchers-and-weighers as a statement of dismissal. To the rest of us it's to admit that Mr. Brooks, having given us the lunatic highs of "Blazing Saddles" and "Young Frankenstein," should be allowed to fool around as he sees fit, possibly to extend his talent while discovering its limitations.Actually "Silent Movie" is not silent at all. It has a very busy soundtrack, full of music and of exaggerated noises that accompany such sights as those of a foot crushed in a door, a head bashed against a wall or the collapsing of a Murphy bed.The only element missing is spoken dialogue, and the written titles, which often adopt a genteel tone as if to spare us the crude reality of the true dialogue, are among the funniest things in the film. I particularly like: "That poor woman is incredibly pregnant. Let's give her a lift." Also the title that appears when a man 15 feet tall rings a stranger's doorbell. "Hi," he says. "I have a glandular condition. May I use your phone?"Politeness is, ultimately, one of the film's problems, especially in the personality of Mel Funn (Mr. Brooks), the reformed boozer who dreams of making his Hollywood comeback by directing a silent film in 1976. Mel Funn is polite, sweet and vulnerable, qualities one associates with some of the old silent film comedians and that fit Mr. Brooks less well than a nun's habit.The lack of spoken dialogue doesn't disable the character. It's the concept. When you have a Mel Brooks who doesn't allow himself to be rude, testy and master of the low leer, you don't have a funny man. You have an affable floorwalker. He's a suprise and sort of pleasant but not what you were expecting. By being thus prepared, you should be able to appreciate the good things that Mr. Brooks has brought off.These are the sight gags involving Mel Funn and his two staunch associates, Marty Eggs (Marty Feldman) and Dom Bell (Dom DeLuise), as they tootle around Hollywood (identified as "the film capital of Greater Los Angeles") stuffed into a minuscule sports car, signing up real life stars (James Caan, Anne Bancroft, Paul Newman, Burt Reynolds) for the film within the film.Between the set routines with these stars, who are very funny (particularly Mr. Reynolds and Miss Bancroft), the three indomitable heroes must buck up the failing health of their harried studio chief, played with surprisingly humorless intensity by Sid Caesar. They also have to outwit the corporate and criminal machinations of the New York-based conglomerate. Engulf and Devour ("our fingers are in everything"), which wants to take over the studio.To this end, Engulf and Devour hires Vilma Kaplan (Bernadette Peters), a nightclub performer billed as "a bundle of lust," to lure poor Mel Funn back to his dependency on the bottle.Everything turns out gloriously, and in something less than 90 minutes, so there's not much time to become impatient with a gag that doesn't build to a boff. As in any good slapstick comedy, some of the most inspired moments are those that have no point whatsoever, such as the "rushes" we are shown of a low-budget picture the studio is then shooting in India."Silent Movie" is not the greatest movie Mr. Brooks has made, but if you adjust your expectations, it could be one of the nicest things you'll see all summer.The film, which has been rated PG, contains some visual vulgarisms of the sort that small children find price-lessly funnysuch as the sight of a wooden merry-go-round horse doing what live horses do naturally.

title: Henley Regatta to Open With Bicentennial Flair
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES, England, June 30The Henley Royal Regatta opens tomorrow, with 15 American colleges, prep schools and clubs making up more than half the foreign entry. In 1839 the first regatta was staged on the stretch of the Thames that flows through this idyllic town, and ever since, oarsmen have been making an annual pilgrimage here.

title: Connecticut Raises Tolls
description: HARTFORD, July 1 (AP)Tolls on two Connecticut parkways increased to 25 cents each today, the start of the new state fiscal year. The rates increased from 20 cents to a quarter at Greenwich and Milford on the Merritt Parkway and from 15 cents to 25 cents at Wallingford on the Wilbur Cross Parkway. The annual fee for parkway toll plates also rose by $10, to $20 for a single toll station, $25 for two stations and $30 for all three.

title: Troy's Seat Held Safe Despite Tax Case
description: As City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. was formally charged yesterday with filing false income tax returns, the city's Corporation Counsel ruled that he would not automatically lose his City Council seat.

title: Declaration Was Voted on July 4
description: The Continental Congress voted for independence on July 2. 1776, and from then till July 4 discussed an amended text of Thomas Jefferson's Declaration of Independence. On July 4, 12 colonies voted for the Declaration, New York abstaining because its provin cial Congress had not authorized a vote either way. Jefferson, John Adams and Benjamin Franklin later suggested that all delegates had signed on July 4, but historians now agree that probably only John Hancock, as President of Congress and Charles Thomson, as Secretary, signed the muchamended draft that day. parchment copy was ready by Aug. 2. when most the other members signed. The 56th and final signature was not fixed until at least November 1776.

title: Canada Bans Taiwan Team
description: LAUSANNE. Switzerland, July 1 (AP)With the opening of the Montreal Games nearly two weeks away, a sharp dispute surfaced today between Canada and the International Olympic Committee over the admission of a team from Nationalist China.

title: Newport Filled on Land and Sea As Tall Ships Sail for NewYork
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 1The tall ships are on their way to New York City.

title: Sample Is Cleared
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP)  Johnny Sample, former defensive back for the New York Jets, was cleared of a rape charge today.

title: And a Salute to Ethnic Diversity
description: On Sunday, the city's huge ethnic Fourth of July Festival will be in Lower Manhattan, but tomorrow, in a sort of preview, there will he a daylong New York Bicentennial Heritage Festival in Rockefeller Center.

title: Soviet Freighter Rescues U.S. Balloonist
description: The balloonist Karl Thomas was plucked from a life raft in the Atlantic Ocean late Wednesday night, three days after aborting his solo flight across the Atlantic and abandoning his Spirit of 76 balloon during a heavy thunderstorm.

description: TRENTON, July 1The legislative deadlock on taxes and Ithe courtordered closing of iNew Jersey's public schools were magnified by the same !political considerations that have Coloree Just about ever, other showdown involving the Governor, the Legislature and the state and Federal courts.

title: Lawsuit Charges Occidental Petroleum With Bribery
description: SAN FRANCISCO. July 1An Occidental Petroleum Corporation shareholder today sued the company, its chairman, Dr. Armand Hammer, its other principal officers and outside directors. They were accused of violating Federal securities laws in connection with Dccidental's illegal $54,000 contribution to the 1972 Presidential reelection campaign of Richard M. Nixon and of alleged bribes, payoffs and kickbacks to foreign government officials.

description: It must be nearly 10 years since Martine van Hamel first danced OdetteOdile it Erik Bruhn's version of Swan Lake for the National Ballet of Canada. She wa5 then greatly promising. She has become promisingl) great.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY OFF $t6 BILLION TO A 2MONTH LOW
description: The nation's basic money supply plunged $1.6 billion in the latest reporting week and reached its lowest level in two months, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, July 1The domestic auto industry, beginning to gear down its production for model changeover, is scheduled to build 175,156 cars this week, of! 10.9 percent from 196,576 last week, according to Automotive News. But the trade paper said this week's output would still be 52.7 percent ahead of the 114,670 cars built in the corre, sponding week a Year ago

title: French Learn to Their Sorrow That Inflation Doesn't Take Holiday
description: PARIS, July 1The slobs! said a welleducated Frenchwoman, referring to the Govenunent. They wait for the first wave of vacations to bekin then they raise prices.

title: The City Throws an AllDay Party
description: Metropolitan New Yorkers and their guests will this Sunday pray for their country, fire off rounds of grapeshot, join in historical recreations of their 200yearold revolution, see a vast armada, view tableaux of the city's immigration waves, cat everything from egg rolls to Brunswick Stew and otherwise celebrate their country's Bicentennial with the largest public festival this city has ever seen.

title: ... and Accomplishments
description: Given the systemand New York's is among the better legislatures of the countrythe now recessed session deserves moderately high marks. Under unusually severe pressures for financial retrenchment and slowdown in social advance, the Legislature has at least held the line. Among its achievements, besides a balanced budget, must he counted monitoring legislation keep the state's public authorities from jeopardizing the credit of the state, a serious if not altogether successful attempt lo deal with the thorny question of employees pensions (see below), and enough improvement in the primary election ballot to allow voters to know the Presidential preference of the convention delegates.

title: HIGH COURT BARS GIVING A HUSBAND VETO ON ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that states may not re. quire women to get the consent of the husband before they, have an abortion.

title: Burglaries, Lies ...
description: Just as the impact of the revelations of intelligence abuses had begun to fade, Americans have been provided with two jolting reminders that the issues are far from resolved. A subcommittee of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities has reported that the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been derelict in meeting their responsibilities to the Warren Commission. Almost simultaneously, was reported that the Department of Justice had begun a major investigation into burglaries undertaken by the F.B.I. since 1971, when, say Director Clarence M. Kelley and other officials, they thought such activities had ceased.

title: An Occasion for Satire
description: EVERY solemn and celebratory event is a natural subject for satire. The Bicentennial, being one of the biggest such events in our time, could scarcely be expected to escape such satirical treatment. The only question was: Would any serious artists address themselves to the task, or would be it left to the facile talents of hitandrun journeyman gagsters to lay a few eggs on their busy rounds.

Rodman, trustee of the estate of Grant, said yes!terday. W. T. Grant terminated As business operations earlier this year.

title: Peru Troops Halt Economic Protest; Lima Curfew Is Set

title: In Marble's White Glare, a Debut for Albany Plaza
description: ALBANY, July 1 Two dozen fountains sprayed huge sheets of misty water across the vast reaches of the Albany Mall today as Governor Carey and a retinue of top state officials dedicated the Cultural Education Center and pronounced the plaza itself completed after 14 years of planning and construction.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TODAY, JULY 2

title: JERSEY RESUMES DRIVE TO REOPEN SCHOOLS IN STATE
description: TRENTON, Friday, July 2The New Jersey Legislature wearily engaged in its second consecutive marathon session this morning as it sodght to find the $378 million necessary to balance the state school budget and get summer school programs back in operation,

title: Yankees Lose to Indians
description: CLEVELAND, July 1The Yankees may be challenged for the top spot in the American League's Eastern Division after all. After holding a ninegame lead on Monday, the New Yorkers lost their third straight game tonight and their lead over the Indians dropped to six games as the Tribe posted a 32 victory before a delighted crowd of 23,437.

title: Jury Awards Connie Francis $2.5 Million in Westbury Rape
description: A jury of six men awarded the singer Connie Francis $2.5 million yesterday as compensation for her rape in a Howard Johnson Motel in Westbury, L. 1., on Nov. 8, 1974. Local court experts described it as one of the largest awards ever made in a rape case.

title: Associated
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 1 (AP)ProPalestinian guerrillas; who hijacked a French airliner over Greece Sunday freed 101 more hostages here today, but kept 110 prisoner.

title: Robert A. Murphy, 65, Marine Insurance Executive
description: Robert A. Murphy, a retired marine insurance industry executive, died Wednesday at his Manhasset, L.I., home. He was 65 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court has reinstated a negligence suit brought by a woman who asserted that her 23yearold son had been shot to death by three Paterson policemen. The Appellate Division of Superior Court ordered Paterson city police and fire officials to stand trial on the civil charges.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON. July 1The Association of American Railroads estimated today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week ended June 26 totaled 16.1 billion donmiles, 9.6 percent above the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 485,975, up 4.1 percent from last year. The American trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 9.5 percent from last year.

title: Arol Bows to Court On Ceding Records Of MarketinBronx
description: The Arol Development Corporation bowed yesterday to a court ruling and ended its sixmonth fight to keep records of the Bronx Terminal Market from official investigators.

title: Many Arrests Reported in South Africa Since Rioting
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 1The wave of arrests that began with the recent outbreak of rioting has continued since the rioting was suppressed, with the Government reportedly making widespread use of laws that permit indefinite detention without trial.

title: Olympics Office Occupied
description: GENEVA, July 1About 30 youths occupied the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee in Lausanne today in a demonstration of support for Frenchspeaking nationalists of Canada's Quebec Province.

title: Associated Press Governor Carey discusses the legislative session that ended Wednesday morning, at Albany news session.
description: ALBANY, July 1Governor Carey, with the Capitol to himself and the luxury of the last word, surveyed the freshly departed Legislature today and pronounced himself pleased and gratified by its performance.

title: Art People
description: THE Bronx Museum of the Arts, the fledgling, fiscally troubled institution that inhabits the rotunda of the Bronx County Courthouse, has just appointed a new director, the fourth since the museum opened in 1971. He is Edward M. Dweck, an architect and former deputy administrator of the old New York City Department of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Atfairs.

title: Gala in the StarSpangled Night
description: Six weeks and 28 concerts ago, the New York Philharmonic and Leonard Bernstein set out on a tour of Europe and this country that was unlike any tour any major American orchestra had undertaken previously. Its distinction lay in the fact that, from Vienna, Paris and Londen to Chicago, St. Louis and Des Moines, every note of music played was composed in the United States.

title: New York City Repays Last of Federal Loans
description: The City of New York delivered a check for $102.29 million at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York Wednesday in its last installment to repay $1.26 million in Federal loans to keep the city solvent.

title: FLORENCE C. POWERS
description: Florence Colebrook Powers. a dancer, died June 24 at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home. She was 90 years old and a resident of the Irving Hotel, 26 Gramercy Park South.

title: Saudi City of Riyadh Modernizes in Haste
description: RIYADH. Saudi Arabia, There are seats, says the man at the entrance to the stadium, apologetically. but. there are no more tickets.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: A Bicentennial celebration of the American Revolution converges this weekend with the socalled telecommunications revolution and the event is shaping up as a globalvillage event with the emphasis almost exclusively on patriotism, pure and unapologetic. The electronic preparations for the Bicentennial in some quarters are unprecedented.

title: As the Long Night Wore On in Legislature ...
description: TRENTON, July 1  New Jerseyans awoke today the confused owners of what appeared to be the only nonfunctioning public school system in the United States and wondered if this was to be their hallmak as they prepared to celebrate the Fourth of July in this Bicentennial year.

title: Electronic Exchange Is Found In the Best Interest of Investors
description: The New York Stock ExChange said yesterday that a fully electronic system linking all stock markets might, in the long run, be in the interest of investors but maintained that it could cost as much as $20 million to build, take four to six years to complete and possi, bly lead to the demise of the exchange itself.

title: A Rumanian, on the Italian Reds
description: BUCHAREST, RumaniaThe world has come a long way since the Communist Manifesto: A Communist Party has won enough votes to qualify for a role in the Italian Government and yet is not pressing for places in the Cabinet. Something unusual must have occurred that neither Marx nor Lenin had ever anticipated. For a contemporary Marxist, it is a fascinating venture to try to find the explanation of this new political phenomenon.

title: New QuarterHorse Track Is State's First Out of Gate
description: NICHOLS, N. Y., July 1This is the greatest thing to happen to this town since the railroads.

description: DALLAS, July 1 (AP)The American Medical Assocladen's house of delegates ended its 125th convention today by adopting several resolutions warning the Federal Government to stay out of the medical practice.

title: 28 Rare Falcons Will Be Released In Wildernesses
description: WASHINGTON, July 1In a project sponsored jointly by the Interior Department, Cornell University and the states involved, 28 peregrine falcons will be released this summer into wilderness areas of six states, including New York and New Jersey, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced today.

title: Spanish Premier Resigns, Apparently at King's Wish
description: MADRID, July 1The resignation of Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro and the Spanish Cabinet was unexpectedly announced today. The development, apparently result of a decision by King Juan Carlos I, threw the program for democratic change into a state of confusion.

title: Toots and the Maytals Exhilarating in Reggae
description: Island Records continues to work busily, trying to establish its stable of reggae artists in the American market. A massive promotional blitz has apparently gotten Bob Marley and the Wailers on their way to transcult acceptance here (an effort that makes Columbia's muchlamented hype of Bruce Springsteen look like pretty small beer, at least in terms of print advertising).

title: Lou Myers

title: Ali Hospitalized
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 1 (AP) Muhammad Ali was admitted to St. John's Hospital today with clots in his legs, a hospital spokesman said. The 34yearold champion first felt twinges of pain in his legs after his world martial arts match last week against Antonio Inoki of Japan. He will be hospitalized three days.

title: Hansen Denies Deal With Ford on a. Bill For Delegate Votes
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Senator Clifford P. Hansen, Republican of Wyoming, said tonight that he told President Ford last week that Mr. Ford might pick up some of Wyoming's uncommitted convention delegates by signing a bill opposed by the Administration.

title: New Federal Loan For New York City Comes With Praise
description: The Federal Government renewed New York City's option to stay in business yesterday, extending the first of $2.3 billion worth of loans needed for solvency in the new fiscal year and including a bonus of some praise from Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 1The tall ships are on their way to New York City.

title: Associated Bjorn Borg of Sweden In action during men's singles semifinals with Roscoe Tanner, U.S., at Wimbledon yesterday
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1For the first time in three years no American man is in the final of the AllEngland championships, as Roscoe Tanner was snuffed out today by 20yearold Bjorn Borg, 64, 98, 64, in a crash of heavy artillery that saw only two service breaks over 110 minutes.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: Wind howled as the rain pelted the windowpanes of my darkened childhood bedroom. I snuggled beneath the bedclothes, terrorized in the warm and vaguely comfortable fashion of a youngster who had just managed to listen secretly to a full three hours of radio drama beginning with Gangbusters and ending with The Shadow.

title: Cadet Sues West Point for CourtMartial
description: NEWARK, July 1A West Point cadet who was acquitted of cheating in March but accused again a month ago demanded today that be be granted a courtmartial.

title: HERMAN L. MERRITT
description: Herman L. Merritt, a former manufacturer of tubular plumbing products, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 74 years old and a resident of Brooklyn.

title: Some U.S. Blacks Visit South Africa on Business
description: A number of influential black persons affiliated with American companies in South Africa have been traveling to that country. Their purpose, they say, is to gather information that might influence developments in the whiteruled country, where blacks outnumber whites 5 to 1.

title: N.F.L. Held in Labor Code Violation
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) A National Labor Relations Board administrative law judge has found the National Football League guilty of unfair labor practices in dealings with the N.F.L. Players Association during the 1974 contract negotiations and players strike.

title: Uruguay's 1984
description: It is not surprising that the people of Uruguay paid little attention to the recent ouster of President Juan M. Bordaberry. For three years at least, the President had beer a puppet providing a thin veneer of legitimacy for Uruguay's real rulers, the military. Their removal of Mr. Bordaberry devalues their declarations about a return to democratic rule by 1984.

title: NEW YORK FACING NEW U.S. AID CUTS
description: Federal estimates of shrinking population in New York State have led to another $3 million cut in Federal grants for social services in the state, following a similar S3 million reduction during the program year that started last Oct. 1.

title: King Olav Wins Yacht Race
description: HANKOE. Norway, July 1 (AP)King Olav of Norway, who will be 73 years old tomorrow, won the fifth race the yachting world championship today by 2 minutes seconds. After five races in the sevenrace series, Frank Tolhurst of Australia was first in Arunga with 22 points, while Bingo, skippered by King Olav, was second with 30.7. Completing the first five were Alphee, Claude Bigar Switzerland, 41.7; Sundance, Ted Turner of Atlanta, Ga., and Artemis, Willie Pieper of Switzerland.

title: Adams Saw Celebrations Marking Memorable Epoch in America on July
description: John Adams was an extraordinary correspondent. But on July 3. 1776just one day after Congress voted independence from Englandhe was extraordinary to a fault. This made it a perfect setting for the rundown team that called the park home. The press box was a fencedoff section of the upper deck directly behind the plate, rather narrow and perhaps a dozen tiers deep. Stan Baumgartner had been a lefthanded pitcher with the Phillies, and it tells something about the team

description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The National Science Foundation is making grants totaling $946,171 for projects aimed at bringing more wornen into scientific careers, the foundation announced today.

description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) The House Ethics Committees voted today to open to the public its hearing into how a secret C.I.A. report was leaked to Daniel Schorr, a CBS News correspondent. Mr. Schorr admitted passing the report to the Village Voice.

title: Guns at the Tunnel
description: The brief, illegal strike of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority's toll collectors may well have been the oddest job action in the history of organized labor. It is difficult to imagine a more unlikely strike slogan than No Guns, No Work; yet it was the authority's entirely rational refusal to let the collectors arm themselves that caused the walkout. Indeed, even as they ended the strike, the officers threatened to press the issue again at the next contract talks.

title: Court Upholds a Paper's Merger Rights
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UN) A threejudge Federal Court ruled 2 to I today that newspapers do not violate the law solely because they merge without prior approval from Ithe Justice Department.

title: Ford Signs Two Aid Bills Giving Assistance to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters) President Ford today signed two foreign aid bills that include arms and economic assistance to Israel.

title: Weather Report Is Partly Sunny
description: Weather Report has been the Rolls Royce of jazz/rock groups since its formation in 1972, purveying fleet, elegant, substantial music that was a far cry from the calculated flash of most of the competition. Cofounders Josef Zawinul, a keyboard player, and Wayne Shorter, a saxophonist, have always kept an eye on the demands of their audience, but they have rarely, if ever, played down to them, as so many jazz/rockers seem to be doing these days.

title: Boston Now Buys That Tea
description: LONDON, July 1Monkhouse Davison and Abraham Newman were prominent London tea merchants a couple of centuries ago. Much of the tea that was jettisoned in Boston Harbor, igniting the American Revolution, was theirs.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: IF THE neighborhood around Independence Hall in Philadelphia or that around Old North Church in Boston were as jammed with crowds as Lower Manhattan is likely to be this weekend, there wouldn't be much visible. But in New York you can always look up indeed, as you wander around Lower Manhattan, you can see some of the city's best skyscrapers as well as some of its most significant historical sites. This is neighborhood in which past and present come together, not so much in the gentle partnership of the ideal city as in the dramatic clash of a city desperate to make itself new at the expense of the old.
