title: ISRAEL, YIELDING, TELLS HIJACKERS IT WILL NEGOTIATE
description: JERUSALEM, July 1Breaking a longstanding policy, Israel today announced its willingness to negotiate the release of an unspecified number of convicted Arab prisoners in exchange for hostages being held by airplane hijackers in Uganda.

title: Adams Saw Celebrations Marking Memorable Epoch in Americaon July
description: John Adams was an extraordinary correspondent. But on July 3, 1776just one day after Congress voted independence from Englandhe was extraordinary to a fault. The events of the previous day had been so momentous that one letter to his wife could not contain his emotionsso he wrote her two. One of them declared:

title: Lebanon Accuses Libyans
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 1The Government of President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon has said that the 500 Libyan soldiers in Lebanon are not neutral and therefore cannot serve in an Arab peacekeeping force.

title: Soviet Freighter Rescues U.S. Balloonist
description: The balloonist Karl Thomas was plucked from a life raft in the Atlantic Ocean late Wednesday night, three days after aborting his solo flight across the Atlantic and abandoning his Spirit of 76 balloon during a heavy thunderstorm.

title: Louisville Police Slowdown
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., July 1 (AP)Louisville police began a work slowdown today over a salary dispute. The city has offered a 3 percent salary increase, plus a onetime $100 payment, for the year beginning in September, and another 3 percent the year after that. The police want salary increases of from 71;; to 101/2 percent and paid hospitalization for dependents, and cost of living protection.

title: 2 TeenAged Boyi. Are Victims In Two Killings Linked to Gangs
description: A 15yearold youth was stabbed to death by a gang of knifewielding teenagers in a Bronx school playground early yesterday, and a 14yearold boy was shot and killed in Brooklyn Wednesday night as he and other members of gang allegedly tried to attack a man with sticks, pipes, bricks and bottles.

title: Beirut Rightists Intensify Palestinian Camp Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. July 1Lebanese rightwine Christian militiamen today intensified their efforts to capture a besieged Palestinian camp here as a special Arab League envoy met with Christian leaders in a new attempt to end the fighting.

title: 28 Rare Falcons Will Be Released. In Wildernesses
description: WASHINGTON, July 1In a project sponsored jointly by the Interior Department, Cornell University and the states involved, 28 peregrine falcons will be released this summer into wilderness areas of six states, including New York and New Jersey. the United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced today.

title: Sky Will Dance With Silver and Gold
description: If you want to get the most out of watching Sunday's mammoth Bicentennial fireworks show, bring a radio. The skylighting display, which will range from orthodox pyrotechnics to mortars, will have a broadcast accompaniment of music and cornmentary.

title: ZARA LEVINA
description: MOSCOW, July 1 (Reuters)1 Zara Levirfa. a Soviet composer, I has died after illness, the Tass (press agency reported. She was 70. Most of her works were written for children but she also composed other songs and chamber works.

title: Ford Orders Review of All U.S. Laws To Find and Halt Unjustified Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON. July 1President Ford today ordered a review of all Federal laws in an effort to identify and eliminate those that unwisely or unjustifiably discriminate on the basis of sex.

title: A Guide to Mulches
description: Cocoa bean hulls. Usually available bagged at garden centers, cocoa bean hulls are one of the best mulches for dry areas, They will hold more than two times their weight in water.

title: Congressional budgetcontrol procedures are subject news conference conducted by Senator Edmund Muskie, center, chairman of the Senate Budget Com
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Senate and House chairmen of the new Congressional budget committees announced today that Congress, in the fiscal year just ended, had stayed within the $374.9 billion ceiling it set for itself under the new budgetcontrol procedures in effect for the first time.

title: 4 Novellas in a Hollywood Mood
description: Crowned Heads is a collection of four novellas interrelated by a common Hollywood atmosphere and recurring characters who star in one story and do bit parts in the others. As Mr. Tryon's epigraph from Shakespeare suggests, uneasy lie the heads of the Hollywood royalty who wear their respective crowns: Fedora, the remote, ageless beauty whose career has spanned four Hollywood decades; Robin, the grownup movie moppet; Lorna, the shopworn sex symbol, and Willie, a charming relic from the golden era of polo at the Zanucks'.

title: Wilkins Assails Directors of N.A.A.C.P.
description: MEMPHIS, July 1Roy Wilkins, the retiring executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today accused members of the organization's board of directors of mounting a campaign of vilification against him.

title: MANOUTCHEHR PARTOW
description: Dr. Manoutchehr Partow, Hicksville, L. I., general practitioner, died Monday at his Dix Hills, L. I. home. He was 57 years old. Dr. Partow, graduate of the University of Teheran Medical School, leaves his wife, Marzieh, two sons, David and Bahram; three daughters, Linda, Cynthia and Pamela, and three grandchildren and a brother.

title: Soybean and Wheat Prices Soar on U.S.Soviet Talks
description: Rumors of Soviet buying of soybeans and wheat began to gain credence yesterday, and prices soared on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: HOUSE COMPLETES REFORM PACKAGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The House Democratic leadership overcame stubborn opposition today from conservatives in its own party plus that of most Republicans and passed the remaining pieces of a reform package aimed at preventing payroll padding and expense account abuses.

title: Layoffs in Erie, Pa.
description: ERIE, Pa., July 1 (AP)More than 160 employees of the Erie School District have been laid off. The school board voted yesterday not to raise school taxes, and the assistant superintendent, Andrew Paykos, said that the board's decision would require a $2 million cut in the proposed budget..

title: Associated The Cultural Education Center, in Albany's Empire State Plaza, being dedicated yesterday
description: ALBANY  There is a strong temptation to view the Albany Mall as a grandiose, utter folly, and while it is not merely that, there is a lot of that aspect to it.

title: Ford Bids Nation Keep Reaching Into the Unknown
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 President Ford, in the first of a series of speeches to corn: memorate the Bicentennial of American independence, said today that the nation must: keep reaching into the un known.

title: 160 Safe in Jet Mishap
description: BLYTHE, Calif., July 1 (AP) A National Airlines DC10 jumbo jet with 160 persons aboard made a safe emergency landing today in this small Mojave Desert town after an engine caught fire, the authorities said. A sheriff's spokesman said no one was injured as the plane, bound from Los Angeles to New Orleans, touched down at Riverside County Airport.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)  DeBeers Industrial Diamond Division Ltd. of Ireland agreed today to a proposed consent judgment prohibiting it from fixing prices of diamond grit or allocating customers and territories, the Justice Department said. DeBeers Ireland is the marketing organization for all DeBeers synthetic and natural diamond grit, which among other uses serves as an abrasive in grinding wheels, masonry saws and drill bits.

title: People and Business
description: The supersonic Concorde has not so far given Air France a financial lift, according to Gilbert Perol, director general of the staterun French airline. In Paris yesterday Mr. Pero! said that the Concorde would have an operating loss of about $42 million this year if flights to New York and Tokyo were not approved. Concorde flights have been barred by the New York Pert Authority and are awaiting decision in Tokyo.

title: CORRECTION
description: On June 18, 1976, the Notes on People column said incorrectly that Bernard Cornfeld had been imprisoned in Switzerland for fraud. Mr. Cornfeld was held in prison during an investigation by the Swiss authorities into allegations of fraud.

title: Major Actions Taken by New York Legislature in 76 Session
description: ALBANY, July 1Following, are some of the major actions taken by the Legislature during the 1976 session:

title: Bill Directs President To Pick Route for Gas
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Senate approved today and sent to the House a bill that directs the President to choose by July 1, 1977, a route for delivery of natural gas from the North Slope of Alaska.

title: Golf Hall to Induct Sanders, Casper
description: The late Gary Sanders, a former University of Southern California star who died last August at the age of 25, and Billy Casper, 45, who is in his 22d year on the Professional Golfer's Association tour, will be inducted into the AllAmerican Collegiate Golf Hall of Fame.

title: Tiger Tale: Losing A Thing of the Past
description: Last season the Detroit Tigers came close to a major league record for consecutive defeats. They cropped 19 straight games, four short of the record 23 set by the Philadelphia Phillies in 1961.

title: Albany Chaos ...
description: By recessing this week instead of adjourning, the State Legislature was telling Governor Carey what he already suspected from the rare experience of having had a major bill passed over his veto: the Bicentennial seems to have infected the lawmakers with a taste for independence. On the off chance that the Governor might now reject their legislative efforts too freely, they are a position to return in 30 days to attempt to override him.

title: Venezuela Increasing Oil Prices;
description: Venezuela. the largest supplier of potoleum to the United states, announced yesterday', moderate price increases on certain types of crude oil and products.

title: An etching made in 1787 shows Christ Church in Philadelphia. A page from the church's Prayer Book shows a change made on July 4, 1776
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1On the day independence was proclaimed, a large contingent from the Continental Congress gathered in Christ Church to pray for succor and to inspire the church's vestry to declare its solidarity.

title: U. S. AIDE DOUBTS A HEAVY FLU TOLL
description: An official of the Government agency that four months ago raised the possibility that the nation might face a return of the devastating 19181919 pandemic of swine flu said yesterday that there was no reason to believe that the new swine flu virus would be any more deadly than other strains of influenza in recent years.

title: Selloff in Chemicals Cuts Dow by 7.94 to 994.84
description: A selling wave in chemical issuestouched off by disap3ointing news about Du Pont, the industry leaderengulfed the stock market yesterday.

title: T.W.A. Says Court Bars Flight Attendant Strike
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday it had obtained a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court in New York to bar a strike by flight attendants set for 4 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Strike Ineffective
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) Union leaders called a strike of city workers today, but most employees reported for work and the dispute seemed to have little effect on city services.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 1The state budget for the fiscal year 1977 that was due to go into effect at 12:01 this morning was held up by more than eight hours. Governor Byrne waited to sign it to see what the Legislature might do about taxes and to make some lastminute adjustments in it.

title: Business in Africa
description: Headlines tell a story of Africa's torment.

description: WASHINGTON, July 1In the last few weeks, the two socalled superpowers of the worldthe United States and the Soviet Unionhave been compelled to recognize just how seriously their political influence has declined since the beginning of the nuclear era.

title: Newport: Tribute to Ellington
description: UNTIL Wednesday evening, Duke Ellington's Black, Brown and Beige, one of his earliest extended compositions, had not been performed in its entirety since the Duke introduced it at Carnegie Hall in January 1943. However, portions of it have been available on recordings for many years, so that when the New York Jazz Repertory Company gave the work its first complete performance in 33 years on Wedensday, again at Carnegie Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival, most of the individual selections were more or less familiar to Ellington followers. In particular, Come Sunday has long been established as one of Mr. Ellington's richest and most moving creations.

description: New York is a music festival. Members of Mormon Tabernacle Choir sang on the steps of Federal Hall museum at Wall and Nassau Streets.

title: Bombing in San Francisco Tied to South African Deaths
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (Reuters)A powerful bomb exploded on the doorstep of the South African Consul's home here early today, causing an estimated $20,000 in damage and blowing out windows in nearby houses.

title: 350 Die in Quake In Indonesia Part Of New Guinea
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 1 (Reuters)At least 350 Papuans were killed in an earthquake in western New Guinea last Saturday, the daily newspaper Sinar Harapan reported today.

description: CHICAGO, July 1The Supreme Court's ruling on abortion will have a major impact in Missouri because it has clarified the disturbing question of whether an abortion may be performed on a minor without her parents consent, directors of Missouri proabortion grous said today.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 30 (Reuters)  Decorative lights and neon signs will go out in Teheran between G and 9.P.M. daily because of an acute power shortage, the Government has announced.

description: A vast armada is en route to New York today bound for a spectacular Bicentennial waterborne celebration that will fill the great natural harbor with sailing ships and naval craft. The massing of the ships will reach a climax on Sunday with a parade and a review that is expected to draw huge throngs to the waterfront.

title: Longet Hearing Recessed
description: ASPEN, Colo., July 1 (UPI)The Claudine Longet manslaughter hearing was recessed today until tomorrow because a magistrate refused to answer questions about the legality of a warrant issued for the search of the home Miss Longet, a singer, shared with Vladimir Sabich, a skier. Legality of the warrant is at issue.

title: BICENTENNIAL WEEKEND CALENDAR
description: The biggest Glorious Fourth in 100 years is evoking a joyous stir and noise throughout the region. Although the big, spectacular observances will center on New York City, other metropolitan area residents will be celebrating in traditional fashionthe picnic, the ball game, the kids throwing firecrackers and after dark the Roman candles and skyrockets shooting into the air leaving patterns sparkling in the firmament as tribute to the Bicentennial. This year. the celebrations in the small towns and cities will be more ambitious than, others. There will be twoday celebrations and threeday celebrations. There will be parades and music and readings of the Declaration of Independence and emphasis on how the locality relates to the nation and its birth. It promises to be a birthday party that will not be matched for another 100 years.

description: The Newport Jazz Festival, which has been blowing around New York City, Long Island and through the hills of New Jersey since last Friday, will wind up its 11day run this weekend with a truly festive displaythree free big band concerts and a free street fair on 52d Street as well as jazz on the Hudson among the tall ships, a children's concert with Tubby the Tuba, a Festival Farewell Dance at Roseland Ballroom and six concerts at Carnegie Hall.

description: CANNIZZAROGary. His life was gentle; and the elements so mixid in him that Nature might stand up and say to ail the world, This was a man.

description: MOSCOW, July 1 (AP) Pavel N. Kumykin, former Minister of Foreign Trade, died today after a long illness, the official Tass press agency reported. He was 75.

title: Detroit Cuts School Sports
description: DETROIT, July 1 (AP)In a drastic economy measure, the Detroit Board of Education voted today to eliminate high school sports and cut the number of hours most students spend in class. The board said it was required by law to adopt a balanced budget but hopes for a miracle that will give the school system enough morrey before September to  prEvent the cuts from going into,effect.

title: Portugal Increases Taxes, Cuts Energy Consumption
description: LISBON, July 1Portugal announced today a broad array of austerity measures ranging from increased taxes and energy curbs to a crackdown on pornography.

title: U.S. RAID FOR P.O.W.'S IN 1970 DESCRIBED
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) United States commandos raided a North Vietnam prisoner of war camp in 1970 despite reports that it was empty and killed 100 to 200 Soviet or Chinese soldiers in a battle that broke out when many raiders attacked the wrong target, according to the author of a new book

title: Big Defense Bill Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON July 1 (AP)Congress gave final approval today to a bill authorizing $32.5 billion for military weapons, including a start on production of the B1 bomber and construction of 17 new warships.

description: TRENTON, Friday, July 2The New Jersey Legislature wearily engaged in its second consecutive marathon session this morning as it sought to find the $378 million necessary to balance the state school budget and get summer school programs back in operation.

title: Guild Parley Averts Washington Post Showdown
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Delegates to the annual convention of the Newspaper Guild averted a constitutional crisis tonight over the status of the union's rebellious membership at The Washington Post. However, they left unhealed ideological wounds in the national newspaper union and in the WashingtonBaltimore Local, the, guild's second largest.

title: Knits That Are Forever
description: Besides the leather, tweed and canvas clothes she designs for Sills & Co., Bonnie Cashin has always turned out sweaters and sweaterdresses to wear with them. For the last couple of years she's been producing them through her own company, called the Knitters.

title: The Pop Life
description: HILLY KRISTAL, the paterfamilias down at CBGB's on the Bowery, is trying to interest record companies in a record he has produced, containing 10 songs by seven New York area bands.

title: Restaurants
description: IN VIEW of estimates, prophecies and warnings of what the scene is going to be like on the tip of Manhattan this Fourth of July, wouldn't you think that the wise thing to do would be to batten down the hatches, man the ramparts, and check on your supply of distress flares if you owned a business down there? At Fraunces Tavern, the combined museum landmark and restaurant at the corner of Broad and Pearl Streets, they are doing just the opposite, not only staying open on the Fourth but extending their hours on that day and the days before and after from noon to midnight. When its bar and all its dining rooms are open at one time, Fraunces Tavern can seat about 400 people. By my amateur calculations, that could mean 1,600 meals a day even if you allow each diner a full three hours to get in, get fed, and get out.

title: Dr. Martin R. Post Weds Amy Teplin
description: Amy Susan Tenlin and Dr. Martin Roger Post were married last night in the garden of the Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Congregation Emanuel, in Rye, N.Y.

description: Barry Tuckwell, the Frenchhorn virtuoso, will appear at Caramoor tomorrow evening in a program of Britten's Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings and Mozart's Concerto No. 2.

description: The Federal Government renewed New York City's option to stay in business yesterday, extending the first of $2.3 billion worth of loans needed for solvency in the new fiscal year and including a bonus of some praise from Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) The Hearst Corporation has agreed to pay the Synanon drugaddict rehabilitation program $600,000 as settlement of a $32 million libel action brought against The San Francisca Examiner four years ago, it was announced late today.

description: NEWPORT. R.I., July 2 (AP)Main Colas of France. the 1972 winner of the singlehanded transAtlantic race, has been dropped from second to third in this year's standing for violating rules of the Royal Western Yacht Club.

title: World Trend Is Toward Ending Executions for Crime.
description: TOKYO, July 2The death penalty, the ultimate punishment assessed by societies from the beginning of recorded history, is dying a slow lingering death itself, a victim of changing times, altered priorities and terminal disuse.

title: INFORMER ON MAFIA WINS U.S. TAX CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July  2 (UPI)Gerald Zelmanowitz, a Mafia informer, came out of hiding to sue the Federal Government over his tax problems, and yesterday he won at least a partial victory.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Partly sunny skies and warm temperatures are forecast for the New York Metropolitan area today, while scattered showers and thundershowers are expected in upper New York and northern New England. Scattered showers and thundershowers will also be found in the South Atlantic States and extend from the Ohio Valley through the middle and lower Mississippi Valley and into the Central and Southern Plains States. A few scattered showers and thundershowers will occur in the northern and central Rockies and showers will fall in the Pacific Northwest. It will be mostly cloudy with mild temperatures in areas of precipitation and partly cloudy to sunny with warm temperatures elsewhere in the nation.

description: WASHINGTON. July 2William P. Clements Jr., the Millionaire Texas oil driller who became Deputy Secretary of Defense, had a showdown this week across a Pentagon coffee table with Hyman G. Rickover, the outspoken politically powerful admiral. Mr. Clements apparently won.

description: OSLO, Norway, July 2 (UPI)Frank H. Tolhurst of Australia secured a wide overall lead in the world 5.5Meter Class yachting championships today by winning the sixth race and appeared set to take the title after tomorrow's final event.

description: Blood clots around the knees of Muhammad All were found yesterday to be superficial. However, the world heavyweight boxing champion will remain hospitaliied in Santa Monica, Calif., for a few more days. His physician cited muscle damage from kicks in a match with a Orestler. Page 11,.

title: Chris Evert Takes 2d Wimbledon Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2Chris Evert has won the AllEngland tennis title for the second time. In a nailbiting final that raged over 2 hours on center court, the 20yearold No. 1 seeded player rallied to take three games running and the match from archrival Evonne Goolagong, S3, 46, 86, for the first American title at this sunniest of Wimbledons.

title: Tradition, Marks Fall At Henley
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES, July 2Records fell as temperatures rose on the second day of the Henley Royal Regatta. For the first time in the 140year history of Henley, gentlemen were allowed to remove their coats, but not their ties, in the stewards enclosure, where the temperature hit 96 degees after the luncheon interval.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, July 2 (UPI)The United States women's basketball team put on a torrid shooting exhibition in the first half today and defeated a strong Cuban squad, 8973, in the finals of the Olympic qualifying tournament. The victory all but mathematically qualified the Americans for the Montreal Games. A victory in their second and last game tomorrow against Bulgaria would clinch the spot as would a combination of victories and losses among the other three teams in the finals.

title: At Arlington...
description: The S100,000 added American Derby will headline the first thoroughbred Sunday racing program ever held at Arlington Park.

title: 2 Parts of Vietnam OfficiallyReanited; Leadership Chosen
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 2North and South Vietnam were officially reunited today after more than 20 years of war, and Hanoi was declared the capital. The Hanoi radio said that leaders of the new Socialist Republic of Vietnam had been elected in the National Assembly by secret ballot.

title: Harris Trial Begins Recess, Still With No Jury Chosen
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (UPI) The trial of William and Emily Harris began a fourday holiday recess today, still without a jury after two weeks. A prospective juror was dismissed yesterday when she argued she was too tenderhearted to render judgment on anyone.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER GAIN
description: Stock prices moved up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market. The Amex marketvalue index closed at 105.17, up 0.39, and the NASDAQ industrial index ended at 96.92, up 0.84.

description: A New Jersey judge refused to remove a court gag order that forbids defense and prosecution lawyers from commenting on the pending triplemurder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis. The defense motion to rescind the order will be reviewed by an appellate court on July 19. Meanwhile, the fourth day of a closed hearing to increase Mr. Carter's $20,000 bail was held in Paterson and is expected to resume Tuesday.

description: MEXICO CITY, July 2Every day the streets of this bustling city are crowded with downattheheel men and women cleaning cars, shining, shoes, playing solitary trumpets, dancing in Indian costumes and selling everything from tropical fruit to contraband watches.

description: Terfnis moves slowly. Its politicians always appear to be waiting patiently for tea to be served at a lawn party. Think of all the years that the tennis politicians resisted the concept of open tournaments with prize money. Touring pros are too commercial, they protested. Preserve the amateur atmosphere, they demanded. But finally in 1968 they approved open tournaments. Tennis boomed. Its politicians hadn't realized they had such a popdlar game, mostly because they had preferred a lawn party to a block

title: Dividends
description: DIVIDENDS DECLARED FRIDAY

title: MARKET STAGES A SEDATE RALLY
description: The stock market staged a sedate rally on Wall Street yesterday on modest volume as brokers and investors headed for a threeday weekend. Stock exchanges will be closed Alpday in observance of Independence Day.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 715% FOR JUNE FROM MAY'S 7.3%
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The number of Americans with jobs fell in June and the national unemployment rate rose to 7.5 percent from 7.3 percent in May, the Labor Department reported today.

description: Empire State Building Suite of Diamond Company Invaded by 5 Robbers Who Bind 8 With Rope and Handcuffs

description: LONDON, July 3  A 14thcentury crucifixion by the Jtalian painter Duccio di Buoninsegna was sold at Christie's today for a record $1.8 million to an anonymous private collector who was not present at the sale.

title: Former Times Editor To Conference Board
description: Lewis Bergman, former editor of The New York Times Magazine, is joining the Conference Board next month as editorinchief of its monthly general business magazine, the Conference Board Record.

title: SIKES FACES LOSS OF KEY ROUSE JOB
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Representative Robert L. F. Sikes is likely to lose the Chairmanship of his Military Appropriations Subcommittee as a result of findings by the House ethics committee that he was guilty of misconduct, one source in the Democratic leadership said today.

title: Flooding in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, July 2 (Reuters)Five rivers in southern and northeastern Bangladesh are close to overflowing their banks following monsoon rains during the past few days, officials said. About 100,000 people in the northeastern district of Sylhet have been forced by floodwaters to move into relief camps for the second time in a month.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY DEFERS TAX ISSUE
description: TRENTON, July 2The New Jersey Legislature adjourned for the weekend at 1 P.M. today after a second consecutive allnight session in the Assembly produced high drama and jagged nerves, but no new tax measure to finance fully the state's public schools, which have been closed since Wednesday by order of the State Supreme Court.

title: NO GAIN REPORTED IN HOSPITAL TALKS
description: Federal mediators met yesterday with union and hospital officials in the continuing attempt to avoid a strike by 40,000 workers in New York City's voluntary hospitals next Wednesday.

title: HARRY ROTH
description: Harry Roth, a book illustrator and muralist, died Wednesday in Benedictine Hospital, Kirigston, N. Y., after suffering a heart attack in his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Giving the Bicentennial Cookout An International Flavor
description: While the United States may be accredited home of the supercookout, barbecuing is one of the more popular methods of cooking throughout the world. The name itself is said to have originated with French corsairs who sailed the Spanish Main, and who built gigantic spits over which they roasted animals whole, from beard to tailde barbe a queue. Whether or not that is true, it is a fact that in the next eight or 10 weeks, Americans will he indulging in one of their favorite outdoor sports, cooking overt charcoal in backyards and on beaches, at public picnic grounds and on city terraces and rooftops. It hardly seems necessary to repeat instructions for grilling such allAmerican classics as hot dogs, hamburgers and corn; instead, a few unusual foreign barbecue specialties are described below. Although it is cricket to use electric starters for fires, it is best to avoid liquid starters or treated charcoal that invariably add their most unwelcome flavors to the final results. And since some of these preparations take a good deal of time, a wise firstaid precaution would be to have several packages of hot dogs on hand, to be broiled and nibbled on for sustenance while the more exotic fare sizzles to a finish.

title: Blue's Return to the Mound Spoiled as Royals Beat A's
description: Vida Blue or Oakland, who had not pitched in a game since June 11, paid the price for his extended inactivity last night in Royals Stadium when Kansas City beat the A's, 85.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 2 (AP)Judy Rankin fell behind today as four players were tied with threeunderpar 68's in the first round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Bloomington Bicentennial Classic.

description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Justice Department announced today that its civil rights division would conduct xvidespread search to ferret out statutes and regulations that may result in sex discrimination against Government employees.

description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that it had filed with the Public Service Commission revised electric rates to recover about $21.3 million of increased annual operating costs resulting from higher New York City realestate taxes that went into effect Thursday.

title: Inmates'
description: About half the approximately 600 inmates now on Death Row could face execution as a result of the Supreme Court's death penalty decisions, lawyers who argued on behalf of those inmates said yesterday.

description: KAOHSIUNG, TaiwanA kluge, new shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corporation here is being hailed as symbol of Taiwan's economic modernization.

title: Explosion in New Hampshire
description: BOSTON, July 7 (UPI)An explosion blasted windows out of the Seabrook, N.H., Post office tonight, causing no injuries and minor damage. There was no immediate determination of the cause of the blast. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was investigating.

title: Stan Kenton Playing It Soft and Smooth at Festival
description: Stan Kenton has apparently conceded the loudness title among big bands to Maynard Ferguson. When the bands of both Mr. Kenton and Mr. Ferguson played Thursday evening for the Newport Jazz Festival at City Center, Mr. Kenton was content to offer a relatively calm, retrospective program, _dotted with olden, golden favorites from deep in his extensive repertory, while Mr. Ferguson's band came on at a high. nervously energetic pitch and stayed there through most of its half of the evening.

title: Gulf and Indiana Standard Seek a Delay on Oil Shale
description: DENVER, July 2 (Reuters)The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said today they requested a 24month suspension of operations on Federal oil shale prototype Tract CA in Rio Blanco County, Colo.

title: Elk Hills Reserve Oil Will Flow Again
description: TAFT. Calif., July 2After more than 50 years of controversy and intrigue, Congressional bickering and an epimode cf chicanery in high places, commercial production of the Gcvernment's longhusbanded oil in the Elk Hills naval petroleum reserves will begin tomorrow.

title: Injuries to Ali's Legs Called Superficial in Hospital Tests
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 2 (AP)Blood clots around the knees of Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion, were found to be superficial today, but he still must remain hospitalized.

description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 2For the last week 275 publicschool teachers and administrators from around the country have been stretching and bending and leaping energetically, if sometimes awkwardly, around the fringes of the American Dance Festival here.

description: Back in the 1960's, the vicar of an Episcopal parish in a small North Carolina town decided to come to New York City for graduate training in pastoral work.

description: LONDON, July 2 (AP)The British Government asked the House of Commons today for emergency powers to control the use of water amid a drought.

title: Soybeans Sold to Soviet, 800,000 Tons From U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, lulu 2 (UPI) A private American grain trading company, operating through a foreign subsidiary, has sold a million tons of soybeans worth $250 million to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: A BOB KILLS 18 IN BUENOS AIRES
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 2A bomb exploded today in crowded dining room at the intelligence department of the Argentine Federal Police, killing at least 18 persons, mostly police officials. About 40 persons were injured.

title: Tubby the Tuba Pleases the Youngsters
description: Tubby the Tuba brought the Newport Jazz Festival to the youngest generation and vice versaat New York University's Loeb Center yesterday afternoon. Tubby, in the person of Major Holley, a jazz bassist and tuba player, and a coterie of his jazzplaying associates gave a concert to an audience of toddlers, teenagers and parents that stressed the light side of jazz, including the first live performance of a sequel to the original Tubby the Tuba, Tubby Meets a Dixieland Band.

description: CAIRO, July 2 (Reuters)Iraq has decided to participate in the Arab League peacekeeping force in Lebanon, the Itaqi press agency reported.

description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) President Ford conferred today with the West German Defense Minister, Georg Leber in a discussion of European security issues. There was no immediate report on their talks.

description: MILLVILLE, N.J., July 2 (UPI) Virgil S. Johnson, 90 years old, the oldest active journalist in New Jersey, died yesterday. He had been a newspaper reporter for 60 years.

title: Survey Finds Many LaidOff Workers Are Back on New York City's Payroll
description: Threequarters of the bluecollar and clerical Civil Service workers laid off in New York City's 1975 fiscal crisis found their way back onto the municipal payroll by the beginning of this year, according to the first detailed survey of the effects of the city's largescale dismissals that began a year ago.

title: J. Geils Band: Purist's Rock
description: The J. Geils Band, which appeared at the Schaefer Festivaryesterday, is one of a very few contemporary rock bands taking what might be termed a purist's approach to the music. Throughout a decade when most popular rock groups nave gone arty, become involved in theater, embraced disco, or steered a course down the middle of the road, the Geils group has remained true to its original inspirations, the Chicago blues of the 1950's and the fusion of several decades of black American styles that was effected during the 1960's by the Rolling Stones.

title: Frances Howard Goldwyn Dies; Actress and Husband's Partner
description: Frances Howard Goldwyn, the widow of Samuel Goldwyn, who was one of the last of the pioneer Hollywood producers at hit death two years ago at 91, died yesterday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She yeas 173 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 2A Bicentennial raid by a foursome of British Redcoats was heavily repulsed in action here this morning. After preliminary sniping last night left the result of the battle in doubt, the New England troops belied history by showing themselves better trained and disciplined than their adversaries.

title: Mine Union Backs Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The United Mine Workers union announced yesterday its endorsement of Jimmy Carter for President, and promised that the 270,000member union would work enthusiastically to elect him in November.

title: N. A. A. C. P. Postpones Action On Wilkins Bid to Stay in Office
description: MEMPHIS, July 2The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today put off consideration of the request by Roy Wilkins, its executive director, to delay his retirement, now scheduled for the end of this year.

title: Amalrik Gets an Extension Of Exit Visa From Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 2 (UPI)Soviet authorities have extended the exit visa of Andrei A. Amalrik, a dissident writer, who is involved in a dispute over customs duties for art works, friends said today.

title: Six at Queens College Quit Over Budget Cuts
description: The provost and all five academic deans of Queens College turned in their resignations to the college president yesterday rather than cut next year's programs in line with a 15 percent spending reduction ordered for the college by the chancellor of the City University. Robert J. Kibbee.

title: LIBET SUIT COSTS HEARST $600,000
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2The San Francisco Examiner said today that it had agreed to pay a $600,000 libel settlement to the Synanon Foundation Inc., the rehabilitation community, and to its founder and chairman, Chuck Dederich.

description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 2For the last week 275 publicschool teachers and administrators from around the country have been stretching and bending and leaping energetically, if sometimes awkwardly, around the fringes of the American Dance Festival here.

description: A caption accompanying an article in The Times yesteday about first graders expressing their views of the Bicentennial incorrectly identified the school as Public School 84. The pupils are from P.S. 9 on West 84th Street.

title: India Says Mizo Guerrillas Agree to End Their Uprising
description: NEW DELHI, July 2 (Reuters) Leaders of the Mizo nationalist guerrilla movement, which has been fighting Indian security forces for 10 years, have agreed to collect all their men and hand over their arms and ammunition, a Government statement said today.

title: FIVE PROTESTERS DIE IN LIMA DISORDERS
description: LIMA, Peru, July 2 (Reuters) Five people, including four convicts, were killed in riots touched off by the Peruvian Government's new economic policies, authorities said here today.

title: South Africa Reports Settling Of Dispute That Started Riots
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 2The Government said today that it had reached complete agreement with black leaders on the languge dispute that touched off the recent rioting, but details were withheld pending a formal announcement next week.

title: The Abortion Decision
description: The Supreme Court's landmark 1973 abortion decision indicated that termination of a pregnancy was basically a decision for the woman to make for herself. It thereby limited the extent to which the state could participate in that decision. In the abortion cases decided this week, the denial of a requirement for a husband's consent to his wife's abortion and the limitation of parental participation in decisions where minors are involved are but logical extensions of the original opinion.

title: U.S. Threatens to Quit Olympics Over Taiwan
description: The United States threatened yesterday to pull its athletes out of the Montreal Olympics if the International Olympic Committee withdraws sanction from the July 17throughAug. 1 competition.

description: TEL AVIV, July 2 (Reuters) Air France's office hcre announced today that all its flights between Israel and France would be nonstop in the future.

description: TIME OUT. New Yorkers who happen to be in the midtown area tomorrow might might want a quiet entertainment breather somewhere between the incoming flotilla and the fireworks. One way would be to look in at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, which is installing a young pianist in its Rose Room for the holiday  the first entertainment at the hotel in 40 years.

title: Ship Sinks Despite Dumping Of Cargo of Frozen Chickens
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 2 (UPI) An American cargo vessel sank west of Puerto Rico last night after dumping 120,000 pounds of frozen chicken into the Caribbean Sea in a fruitless effort to control a leak in its hull, the Coast Guard reported today.

description: MADRID. July 2The Council of the Realm, Spain's high, lest consultative body, tried without success today to draw up a list of three candidates from which King Juan Carlos might choose a successor to; the Prime Minister he dismissed; yesterday.

title: ARCO PLANS 10 BUY REST OF ANACONDA

title: RALPH CONCANNOPI, LAW FIRM PARTNER
description: Ralph L. Concannon, a partner in the law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, died of a heart attack Thursday at his office, 25 Broadway. Mr. Concannon, who lived in Locust Valley, L.I., was 53 years old.

title: Detroit Police Torn by Layoff Decisions
description: DETROIT, July 2 Rosa Gomez, on the police force in Detroit for a year and half, sat at her working desk today with a Federal guarantee that she could not be dismissed from her job as a public information officer.

title: Now Let Us Address The Main Question: Bicentennial Of What?
description: IT IS a common numan p ctI answer questions without truly asking them and the American Bicentennial is merely the latest instance. title: Film: Drawn-Out Disney:'No Deposit, No Return' Is No 'Dumbo'
description: "No Deposit, No Return," a new Walt Disney live-action comedy, runs just eight minutes short of two hours, which is lunacy, considering that the members of the audience for whom it is intended can't even concentrate on Donald Duck that long. The film is about two children who blackmail a couple of innocent safecrackers into giving them shelter and attempt to extort $100,000 from their rich grandfather.According to the brainless plot, the children, played by Kim Richards and Brad Savage, are motivated by loneliness for their widowed mother, who's in Hong Kong and too busy with her career as a roving magazine editor to pay them any attention. A closer reading of their characters suggests that they're plain spoiled.That the movie goes on so long is no indication that it is especially full of incident, but rather that the director, Norman Tokar, doesn't know when to say cut. Every scene and every gag is allowed too much time, which is too bad, because a couple of routines show promise, especially one in which a small boy attempts to retrieve his pet skunk from the girders of a high-rise building under construction. It's not exactly Harold Lloyd, but it's better than looking at a flying Volkswagen.As usual, the Disney organization has lined up a group of actors who are generally much better than the material. They include David Niven (the grandfather), Darren McGarvin and Don Knotts (the safecrackers), Barbara Feldon (the mother). Herschel Bernardi (a police sergeant) and Charlie Martin Smith, who looks startlingly like David Eisenhower, as Mr. Bernardi's over-educated assistant."No Deposit, No Return" opened yesterday at the Festival and other theaters on a double bill with the Disney cartoon classic, "Dumbo," which is only 63 minutes long.

His group was in fact in the minority. but it was prophetically more determined, more closely knit and more disciplined.

Syrian soldiers, the new colonizers of the Bekaa Valley, lounge around; Syrian tank carrier passes through; the only Lebanese doing ft anything plies an ancient Phoenician trade, moneychanging, waving a wad of Syrian pounds.

title: Aiorica in the World

Caesar Augustus was named Father of the Roman Nation here; Caligula and Nero were born here; Tiberias, Cicero, Hadrian, Cassius, Lucullus, Maecenas, Gabriele DAnnunzio and Eleonora Dusethe elegant rich of a hundred generations have summered languidly here by the Tyrrhenian Sea; and on a wretched January morning in 1944, an amphibious assault force of 50,000 American and British troops landed here on beach it took four months of hell to fight out of.

title: PRIME MINISTER NAMED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID. July 3Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez, a 43yearold Cabinet Minister and a personal friend of King Juan Carlos I, was named Prime Minister today in place of Carlos Arias Navarro, who was dismissed on Friday.

title: Beata Gottschalk Bride of Lawyer
description: Beata Dabrowska Gottschalk, daughter of Mrs. E. Robert Thomas of Haverford, Pa., and the late Stefan Dabrowski of Warsaw, and adopted daughter of Mr. Thomas, was married yesterday afternoon to Prof. Henry P. devries.

title: Advertisement AdVertisement
description: In 1966 in Manhattan, a man died believing he'd secured his widow's welfare by leaving his modest Estate in Trust for her in his Will. But lawyers hired for the Estate obstructed the Will's fulfillment (for personal, not legal, reasons). The Manhattan Surrogate's Court legalized their efforts. So, to this day, the widow is denied her $250 monthly allowance, and the small Estate is not yet administered (at a loss of over 60% of its original value, with litigation costs alone exceedinz 25% to date). Even the Estate taxes are not paid.

title: PEOPLE
description: Alger Hiss got the benefitparty social scene in the Hamptons off to a rousing start last weekend by warning more than 100 smartly clad cocktail sippers who had donated $15 each to the National Emergency Civil Liberties Foundation Inc. that if President Ford were reelected, the Freedom of Information Act would be strongly amended and clipped. Not that Jimmy Carter would be more alert to the act, which opened to the public his own F.B.I. dossier as well as other Government files, Mr. Hiss said. But he went on to tell his celebritystudded audience gathered on the lawn of Robert Gwathmey's prizewinning Amagansett home that with Mr. Ford, we know where he stands and that things haven't been vigorous in his support of the act.

title: ART
description: NEW BRUNSWICK

title: PEOPLE
description: The Royal Society of London, Britain's preeminent scientific academy, has named George B. Mackaness, president of the E. R. Squibb Institute for Medical Research in Princeton, a Fellow. Dr. Mackaness, who is a physician and holds a doctorate in philosophy, is one of the few Americans admitted to the society, whose full name is the Royal Society of London for the Improvement of Natural Knowledge. It was founded in 1622 by charter from king Charles 11.

title: Medical Unit Designed to Aid Athletes
description: CHICAGO, July 3 (AP)The Illinois Masonic Medical Center announced this week :the creation of a center for sports medicine designed to help reduce the number of sportsrelated injuries in the United States.

title: Red Smith
description: The New York Jets were a toddling team in the American Football League struggling to change the tradition of pacifism and penury bequeathed to them by the Titans when Walt Michaels, their defensive coach, went down to Mississippi to acquire Ben McGee, a defensive tackle at Jackson State College. McGee was on the point of signing a contract when a representative the Pittsburgh Steelers strode into the Steelof room. He regarded Michaels briefly with the lofty disdain members of the National League reserved then for all employees of that Mickey Mouse league, plucked the pen from McGee's fingers and escorted the young man from the premises. The next time Michaels saw McGee he was pitching blockers out of his way and clawing at the bail carrier, a service he performed for Pittsburgh from 1964 through 1972.

title: ART VIEW
description: From the approximately 3,000 photographs acquired by the Department of Photography at the Museum of Modern Art in the last two years, some 80 works have been selected by Dennis Longwell, assistant curator of photography the museum, for the current exhibition (through July 13) of Recent Acquisitions, 19741976. title: They Make Their Clothes Fit for Their Queen
description: LONDON, July 3  When Elizabeth II steps off the yacht Britannia for the start of her state visit to the United States Tuesday, two elegant Englishmen will be particularly anxious to see what she is wearing.

title: Apple Pie: Variations On a Theme
description: AS John Hancock is to signers, the apple is to pie. Americans began eating that most popular of pies in the 17th century and are still loyal to it. We are warmed and comforted by juicy tartsweet wedges of pale apple, flecked with cinnamon and nutmeg and enclosed in meltingly rich flaky pastry.

title: Pact in Chemical Strike
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service announced a tentative settlement last night in the threemonth strike by 2,700 members of the International Chemical Workers Union against Lever Brothers, The service's national director, James S. Scearce, said details would not be disclosed until the pact was ratified by union members,

FORRESTAL, July 3  Mayor Beame was presented with big white and blue cake, decorated with a big red apple, by the crew of this aircraft carrier today and was asked to make the first slice by Vice Admiral John J. Shanahan, commanding officer of the Second Fleet and Tactical Commander of the International Naval Review.

title: Ali Listed as Much Improved
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 3Muhammad Ali was reported making substantial progress today with a variety of leg ailments suffered in his martialarts exhibition match in Tokyo. The ailments apparently included minor blood clots in both knees.

title: More Purses, More Races, More Injured Horses
description: They don't shoot horses anymore, but they do enter them in 65,000 races in this country each year. And many people who own, train, ride, watch and bet on the thoroughbreds are getting worried these days that we are working our best racers to death chasing a quarter of a billion dollars in prize money.

description: ATLANTA, July 3 (AP)Roger Banks, a 32yearold assistant basketball coach at Austin Peay State University, has been named to a similar position at Georgia Tech, it was announced today. He is native of Asheville, N.C.

title: Meadow Bright, in Foal, Is Trot Winner
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 3Savoir has the corner stall in the breezeway in Billy Haughton's barn CC at Roosevelt Raceway. There are 19 other trotters and pacers stabled there, but none got the attention given today to Savoir. In an atmosphere of concern, Savoir underwent blood tests at 11 A.M. to determine why the 8yearold brown gelding was beaten again last night.

title: New Orleans Enjoying Spirits of 76
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 3They know not what course others may take, but as for the Bicentennial celebrators of New Orleans, give them food or give them drink.

title: NEWS UNION FACES A TEST IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 Delegates to the 43d annual convention of the Newspaper Guild ended a weeklong session here yesterday with many of them unsure of the future of their union.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IN the days before airconditioning was as popular a home convenience as it is now, the most effective way of insuring a comfortable night's sleep during the summer was by the installation of a large attic or window exhaust fan. Now that electric bills have cimbed to almost astronomical heights for many airconditioned Long Island homes, there is renewed interest in using exhaust fans to help lower the cost of keeping cool during the summer.

title: Mexicans Will Elect a President Today
description: MEXICO CITY, July 3Mexicans will vote tomorrow to endorse the longruling Institutional Revolutionary Party's Choice of Jose Lopez Portillo to succeed President Luis Echeverria Alvarez as the country's Ldoez Portillo. But while Mr. Lopez Portillo has no registered opponent in the elections, party officials are worried that high abstentionism or a strong writein vote for the unofficial Communist Party candidate could signal erosion of the Government's popular base.

title: Celebrating Agnes de Mille's HomeGrown Choreography
description: Agnes de Mille leaned forward in her chair. You know, she began, I'm really like a playwright. That is my real value as a choreographer. I tell a story, and I tell it well. My big strength is not in the lyrical development of movement, but in the telling dramatic gesture and the funny one. That's what comes easily for me, and I hit it like a bull'seye.

title: On Falling From an Academic Height
description: THIS Is one Fourth of July probably won't spend at the beach. The beach was my reason for living on the Island. Not just a few square miles of sand, but what it symbolized to me: a more tranquil rhythm of living without some of the stresses of noise, pollution and overpopulation that made each day in New York the nervejangling, eardeafening experience it was for me. When city friends asked incredulously how could possibly live in a place called Hicksville. I had an answer.

title: TV Notes: Cassie Mackin Is a Newscaster to Watch
description: At an NBC affiliates meeting here in New York City last week, a station manager rose to say that he hoped the network was considering Catherine Mackin for Barbara Walters's former spot on the Today show. The suggestion touched off applause and murmurs of approval from many of NBC's 217 television affiliates.

title: Lotteries Bring in $100 Million
description: General Washington's troops had just been routed at New York, the British were marching on Newport, and in Philadelphia delegates to the Continental Congress faced a tough decision: whether to establish the nation's first lottery. (They did, but it never got off the ground.)

title: Lawyer to Marry Ellen Humphreville
description: The engagement of Ellen Holton Humphreville to James Connolly McGuire has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Neil Evans Humphreville of New London, Conn. Mr. McGuire is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis F. McGuire, also of New London, where his father is a lawyer.

description: WASHINGTON, July (UPI)The Senate has voted to restore posthumously the full rights of citizenship to Eugene V. Debs, the fivetime Socialist Presidential candidate who lost his citizenship in 1918 for opposing World War I.

description: Jay Evans, manager of the 1972 Olympic canoe and kayak team, contributed a thoughtful article and plea for declaring the Olympic Games open to all athletes, casting aside tha eligibility rules observed by 132 national Olympic committees (The New York Times, May 10.

title: The Black Experience; A Slow Walk of Trees (as Grandmother Would Say) Hopeless (as Grandfather Would Say)
description: His name was John Solomon Willis, and when at age 5 he heard from the old folks that the Emancipation Proclamation was coming, he crawled under the bed. It was his earliest recollection of what was to be his habitual response to the promises of white people: horror and an instinctive yearning for safety. He was my grandfather, a musician who managed to hold on to his violin but not his land. He lost all 88 acres of his Indian mother's inheritance to legal predators who built their fortunes on the likes of him. He was an unreconstructed black pessimist who, in spite of or because of emancipation, was convinced for 85 years that there was no hope whatever for black people in this country. His rancor was legitimate, for be, John Solomon, was not only an artist but a firstrate carpenter and farmer, reduced to sending home to his family money he made playing the violin because he was not able to find work. And this during the years when almost half the black male population were skilled craftsmen who lost their jobs to white exconvicts and immifarmers.

title: U.S. Bids Angola Spare Gearhart
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The State Department has sent a formal plea to the Government of Angola to spare the life of a Kensington, Md., mercenary on humanitarian grounds.

description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Administration has warned airports and airlines this holiday weekend to guard against bombings like the one that destroyed an Eastern Air Lines plane in Boston yesterday.

description: DETROIT, July 3How safe are small cars? Many car buyers have asked the question as they switched from big cars to smaller ones that are less expensive to buy and to operate.

description: The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act, enacted in 1974 after four years of controversy, took on a new face last week when Department of Housing and Urban Development regulations implementing new amendments went into effect.

description: FIVE New Jerseyans were among the 56 Americans Revolutionaries who approved the Declaration Independence on a hot and stormy afternoon Philadelphia 200 years ago today. They were mixed bag. those five men who became members of the country's Founding Fathers.

title: The American Voice It Begins on a Note of Wonder
description: With America, a new idea comes into the world; with American literature, a new voice. As a dream or fantasy of overburdened Europeans, the idea can be heard even before the Atlantic settlements. It flourishes a while later in the colonies themselves, among Puritan divines, through the letters of the farmer Crevecoeur, amid the reflections of Thomas Jefferson. It speaks of a second Israel through God's provision, or in secular language, of a social compact forged by sturdy freeholders. And it depends on a common yielding to the myth of a new start for humanity on unsullied ground.

description: Edward F. Moore, manager of business administration for CBS Television Network Sales, died Friday of a heart ailment at his home in Neponsit, Queens. He was 47 years old.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 3 (AP)  Vietnam's National Assembly named former Hanoi leaders to most of the top ministerial posts in the Government of the newly reunified nation, the Hanoi radio announced today.

July 3In Golden Gate Park last Sunday, 6,000 residents and visitors celebrated the 200th anniversay of the arrival of Spanish settlers in Yerba Buena (as they were to name this town) with dancing, presentations and two reenactments of the settlers arrival by two groups of horsemen.

title: Weis Gives Redman's Car Good Start
description: There's a little bit of Franz Weis in every one of Brian Redman's Formula 5000 race victories, and next Sunday at Watkins Glen, the mechanic and the driver will be trying to work their About magic for the umpteenth time. Motor If everything Sports goes according to plan, Weis and Redman will huddle for a few minutes before the first practice session. Then Redman will get in the Boraxo Chaparral Lola, turn a few laps and come back into the pits. They will make a few minor adjustments on the car and Redman will go back out.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAIRO, July 3 (AP)Presi. dent Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan declared today that he had crushed a rebellion against his proWestern regime that had claimed at least 100 lives, It was the third unsuccessful coup in five years against his rule.

title: Pace U. Professor Wins $75.000 for Tenure Bias
description: An assistant professor who complained that she had been denied promotion and tenure because she was a woman has won an award of $75,000 from Pace University along with promntion to associate professor at $19,500 a year with full tenure.

title: Book Ends
description: Library Reading. Best seller lists reflect what people are buying in the bookstores, but do they also reflect the reading tastes of library patrons? Fortunately, we need not speculate about this question, because the American Library Association since October 1975 has been compiling lists of the 10 most requested fiction and nonfiction titles in 150 libraries. According to Carol Felsenthal, who is director of the list, the polled libraries were selected to be representative both geographically and by population. The libraries send in cards each weeK listing their 20 titles most in demand and these are totaled up. The list is syndicated, along with a book review column, About Books, and appears in 300 to 400 papers, mostly small town and small city papers that probably would not normally carry book reviews.

title: First at the checkered Flag
description: One has but to mention automobiles, racing, and style to bring to mind immediately an image of a beautiful red Italian car arriving first at the checkered flag of victory ahead of the best that international competition has to offer.

description: Some investors who put their money into worms are squirming these days.

description: BUENOS AIRES, JULY 3The bodies of 13 men and two women with multiple bullet wounds were found today as the Argentine federal police buried 18 of its men who had been killed by a bomb.

title: ARCHITECTURAL VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, D. C. It's a bird, it's a plane, it's Supermuseum! It's the Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian Institution, dedicated this week for the Bicentennial, and it stretches 685 glass and marble feet, or more than three city blocks, along the Mall. Air and Space is the latest of that crushing group of megaliths that house the Smithsonian's remarkable collections of American art, history, science and culture.

description: OMAHA, Neb., July 3 (AP) Dragset, a 221 shot. came from last place to win the $100,000 added Cornhusker Handicap at AkSarBen today.

Whatever the reservationsand there are many, some of them quite seriousabout the presence of corporate funding in the publictelevision schedule, the money has been a key factor the raising of programing quality, in terms both acquisitions and, more importantly, original productions.

title: A Petition to Parliament
description: On Jan. 23, 1775, the merchants of London, noting their business interests, petitioned Parliament to make peace with the colonies.

title: ALTRUISM (n.) regard for or devotion to the interests of others. Encoded in human genes according to sociobiologists theory. Could be the salvation of Homo sapiens, a social species.
description: One of the most astonishing things about human society, from a Nolo. gist's point of view, is that it is made up of individual, distinguishable, specifically marked selves, all apparently out on their own. Here we are, now four billion of us, each one labeled as an absolute entity, fundamentally different from all the rest. The labels are not just the visible, behavioral marksthe way a head is turned, the special manner of a smile, the pitch of a voice these are obvious distinctions; despite superficial resemblances and reminders, no one is precisely duplicate of anyone else except the occasional pairs of identical twins. Then there are the biochemical marks of self, even more specific and rigid than our behavior, setting us apart. The surfaces of our cells are sufficiently different that immunologists can detect the biochemical difference among all four billion. We probably have different smells as well; a tracking hound can sense the uniqueness of every man's footprint, except for those of twins.

title: Economic Conditions In Greece
description: The Greek economy, as any other western economy, was seriously affected by the sudden increase of oil prices, which ushered in a period of international inflation. The readjustment of the internal price level in 1973 was without precedence in Creek postwar experience. The abrupt change in prices was to a large extent caused by the sudden lifting of the strict price control, which was followed inflexibly by the military regime, in order to keep the cost of living down, but which proved ineffective when the inflationary pressures became persistent.

title: Few Holiday Tourists Visit Philadelphia, Washington and Boston
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3Just before noon today, a high school band from Portersville, Calif., struck up a sprightly tune on the broad promenade here in front of Independence Hall.

title: Battlefields for The Bicentennial
description: Battlefields can be fun  200 years after the carnage. You can fly a kite where Washington rallied his troops at Princeton, N. J., picnic where American bayonets hemmed in the British garrison on Stony Point, N. Y., and shop for farmfresh fruit where redcoats and rebels traded bloody blows near Jersey's Monmouth Courthouse in the longest battle of the Revolution.

title: Cry of the Pine Barrens
description: I once met a man from the New Jersey state geologist's office, in Trenton, who has made hundreds of trips through the Pine Barrens. He told me that one of the most remarkable things about the region is that the great silence there is not broken by so much as a birdcall, since the pines are so barren that there is nothing for birds to eat.

title: Potomac Four Gains Final at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES,July 3The sweltering fans at the Henley Royal Regatta have been treated to recordbreaking performances all week, and today the Potomac Boat Club of Washington, gave them another. The Americans set a course record of 6 minutes 54 seconds in its morning quarterfinal heat. The Potomac four without coxswain, enters tomorrow's final the heavy favorite for the Wyfold Challenge Cup.

description: Whatever Mary Hartman's been doing recently, she sure isn't sweeping the floor, and neither are lots of others, it seems.

title: A scissorsandpaste job of genius
description: One of the clandestine classics of our century is a picturebook by Max Ernst called Une Semaine de Bonte (A Week of Kindness). Projected in 1934 as a sevenpart serial, to be sold by subscription, it had a nominal firstedition run of 828 copies. But the series did not go well, and without the help of Ernst's English friend and admirer Roland Penrose it would have had to be abandoned. Five parts in all got printed; they came in a soft openended cardboard box;. and the current rate for the setif you can find one is around $750.

title: Residing With Prefinished Hardboard
description: When most homeowners think of putting up new siding around the outside of their house, they almost always think of only the two most widely sold forms of residing materialvinyl or aluminum. Yet there is another material available for residing older houses, as well as for use on new houses or additions, that is becoming increasingly popular in many areas  prefinished hardboard. Made by the Masonite Corporation, and called Colorlok, this is a clapboardtype horizontal siding material that is just under I,2 inch in thickness and comes with a bakedon finish which will not need painting for many years (it is guaranteed for 15 years against cracking, blistering and peeling).

title: Palestinians See an Arab Plot

It was a skillful and provocative recording on which Joe Williams sang the title role with great feeling and authority and Randy Crawford made a most impressive recording ?? opposite him.

title: Muttontown Wins Polo Opener. 76
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 3 Aided by a twogoal handicap, Muttontown defeated Fairfield (Conn.), 76, .today at Hickox Field in the opening round of the Northeastern ]2goal polo tournament.

description: For All

title: What's the Big Idea, Ben Franklin?
description: What we have here in this book about Benjamin Franklin is a clear triumph for the simpte declarative sentence. something not very easily come by. What's the Big Idea, Ben Franklin? is neither cute nor is it simpering. Neither does it condescend nor shirk facts, nor does it romanticize nor pull out all the stops. It does not display any of the useless pedantry that may satisfy adults but only serves to confuse, bore or antagonize children.

title: Out of the Presidential Past
description: When Queen Elizabeth II makes a royal progress through six of her lost colonies this week, she will visit the Jumel mansion on the heights above Harlem. She will stand on the site of Federal Hall downtown. She will lunch at the WaldorfAstoria.

title: U.S. Courts in ThreeState Area Set 250Day Deadline for Trials
description: Speedy trial plans that require criminal cases to go to trial within 250 days of the defendant's arrest have been adopted for the United States courts of New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: World Record Set For Aged Pacers

title: JEROME VINOGRAD, A DNA RESEARCHER
description: PASADENA, Calif., July (UPI)Dr. Jerome Rubin Vinograd, one of the world's foremost researchers Into the structure and function of DNA, life's basic genetic material, died of a heart ailment today at Huntington Memorial Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Survey Finds Companies Hindered in Energy Plans
description: More than 140 American corIporations are working to develop practical new ways of tapping the energy of the sun, fossil and nuclear fuels, the earth's heat and trash and industrial wastes, but are hindered by several obstacles, a threeyear study of the energy, industry has disclosed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx announced that 159 persons were arrested by his office in the first six months of 1976 for the alleged theft of more than $1 million in welfare funds. He said that 36 of those arrested were governmental employees who could have been caught almost immediately after they began taking money fraudulently if the agencies employing them had made a routine, inexpensive check with the Welfare Department computer of their Social Security numbers. the 36, half were employed by the Board of Education, three by the Police Department and three by the Department of Social Services itself, Mr. Merola said.

title: The Pursuit of Pleasure
description: The couple, in their early CO's, have a common but distressing problem: He is impotent (because of diabetes) and for six years their sex life has been suspended. Until very recently, they would have simply adjusted to the situation, coping with anxieties it produced however they could. But today they have decided to consult a psychotherapist.

title: License Plates Are Their Dish
description: For more than 60 years, every state in the country has required automobiles to carry license plates for identification. Over this period, many people did not throw their old plates away each time a new one was issued. Nowadays, these old license plates have become a popular collectible for many hobbyists.

title: Meg Chapin Bride of Robert E. Carlson
description: Margaret Louise Chapin and Robert Eugene Carlson were married yesterday afternoon at the First Methodist Church in Westfield, N.J., by the Rev. Philip R. Dietterich.

title: Buddy Rich vs. KonitzMarsh Quartet
description: It would be difficult to find two jazz styles at more opposite extremes than the long, springy, boneless lines that Lennie Tristano's groups specialized in at the end of the 1940's and the emphatic, swinging drive of Buddy Rich's big band, which is now called the Killer Force. Yet there were the two, sharing an evening at Carnegie Hall for the Newport Jazz Festiv,a1 on Fridaythe Tristano manner represented by Lee Konitz and Warne Marsh, who were the saxophonists in the Tristano sextet in 1949, and Mr. Rich by the young and feisty band he leads.

title: Pamela Aall Married to Economist
description: Pamela Ruth Aall and Charles Phillip McPherson were married last night in the United Methodist Church in Blue Mountain Lake, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur Wyman performed the ceremony.

title: Bicentennial Track Meet Invites Stars
description: PHILADELPHIA, Pa., July 2The Bicentennial Meet Champions has invited world recordholders Dwight Stones (high jump), Dave Roberts (pole vault) and a coworld recordholder, Houston McTear (100 yards), to compete the August 4 track and field meet at Franklin Field.

description: Fiction

title: FORD'S POPULARITY DIPS IN GALLUP POLL
description: President Ford's popularity rating, which has been on a down curve since March, has slipped 2 more percentage points, according to the latest Gallup poll, which found that 45 percent of the public now approves of his performance in office.

title: Maria L. Shrady Is Engaged To Peter L. Smith, a Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Shrady of Monroe, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Louise Shrady, to Peter Lawrence Smith of New York and Sagaponack. L. I., son of Mrs. William E. Smith of Port Washington, L. I., and the late Mr. Smith.

title: Op Sail in a Blimp's Eye
description: Hovering not too far overhead in New York harbor today as the tall ships pass in review will be one half of the world's most unusual corporate air fleet  the blimps of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

title: Flickers of Days Gone By
description: SUMMONING up the remembrance of things past on the Island is like cranking out an old home movie  blurred, flickering, unbelievably antique and with many gaps. The earliest reel begins with the Fourth of July parade 67 years ago at Rockaway Beach, where my family used to spend the summers. That's me, the bewildered 3yearold Uncle Sam on the new motor fire engine ablaze with red, white and blue bunting. The distinguishedlooking marshal in G.A.R. blues marching under the 46star flag is Colonel Myers. whose cottage my folks always rented for the season.

title: A Mercenary Who Wanted to Be Somebody
description: KENSINGTON, Md., July 3Danny Gearhart never used to tell war stories, but he was so solemn when Vietnam was mentioned that his friends and acquaintances usually gained the impression that he had plenty to tell. Some even had the idea that he was a Special Forces veteran.

title: The Nation
description: The United States Supreme Court, following its custom in recent years, has saved most of its more important and difficult decisions for last. As the end of its term approached, the Court last week issued decisions upholding .the death penalty, reinforcing freedom of the press, strengthening the right to an abortion and limiting the judiciary's power to enforce school desegregation.

title: What the Summit Produced
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.It Is quite natural, after the conclusion of highlyheralded international meetings such as last week's Western economic summit sessions near here, to wonder whether it was all worthwhile and whether such limited discussions can really accomplish very much in any circwnstances.

title: The Tall Ships
description: The parade of tall ships across New York harbor and up the Hudson River today promises a pageant worthy of this nation's 200th birthdaya glorious resurrection of the days of sail against the backdrop of the world's most spectacular modern metropolis.

title: U.S. Stars Abound Despite Absence Of Ailing Trevino From British Open
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 3There are enough Yankees here this weekend to win the War of Independence all over again.

title: Hunt Is on Pole for French Prix Today
description: LE CASTELLET, France, July 3 (UPI)James Hunt earned the pole position for tomorrow's French Grand Prix auto race as his time of 1 minute 47.89 seconds on the 3.61mile Paul Ricard course stood up through the second day of qualifying today. Hunt posted his time in yesterday's trials.

title: Mark in ShotPut
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 3 (Reuters)  Ivanka Hristova of Bulgaria broke the women's shotput world record with a distance of 71 feet 9 inches at a meet here today. The previous record was 711.

description: LONDON, Sunday, July 4 (AP)Two London newspapers, citing statements from released passengers, made new allegations that President Idi Amin of Uganda had helped the hijackers who were holding 105 hostages from a jetliner in Uganda.

title: Down to the Sea In Galoshes
description: OF what? From where? For how long? These are among the questions that have been asked recently by Federal, state, Nassau and Suffolk counties, Babylon, Islip, Brookhaven and Hempstead Town officials, as well as merchants, residents and bathers on South Shore beaches. They were prompted by the sudden and mysterious contamination of 70 miles of ocean beach from the QueensNassau border to Smith Point County Park on the eastern end of Fire Island, including Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Parks, the Fire Island National Seashore, Long Beach and Atlantic Beach and town and county beaches.

title: Pension Law Said to Add Costs for New York City
description: The pension revision law enacted last week in a round of legislative compromise and promises of savings actually will increase New York City's budget expenses and cut into Ithe hopes of attrition in jobs Ithat underlie its austerity plan, the City Actuary cautioned yesterday.

The National Football League's 27 other teamsthe Seattle Seahawks and Tampa Bay Buccaneers are new this year will be assembling players at their camps beginning tomorrow as the league's 57th season begins to take shape. title: Public Service Agency Permits Use of ExtraHigh Voltage Lines
description: ALBANY, July 2The Public Service Commission has issued a permit for the State Power Authority to build 122 miles of a 765,000volt electric line in upstate New York, thus adding to a growing environmental controversy about the safety of extrahigh voltage transmission lines.

description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) State Representative Michael Myers has been chosen the Democratic nominee for the First District Congressional seat vacated last April by the death of Representative William Barrett, 79 years old. District ward leaders selected Mr. Myers.

description: In recent years the owners have sought to reduce the size of the major league roster from 25 players to 24 or 23. They never have_persuaded the Players Association About to agree to the Baseball smaller roster, but the Mets have gone ahead and reduced theirs anyway or so it seems.
