title: Ideas &
description: Israeli archeologists have discovered that a fortress at Kuntillet Airud, deep in the Sinai Peninsula and formerly thought to have been a Roman site was in fact a castle belonging to King .tehoshaphat of Judah about 800 B.C. The discovery suggests that the Judean kingdom may have been even more extensive and influential at that time than had been supposed, even though the Bible says of Jchoshaphat that he waxed great exceedingly: and he built in Judah castles, and cities of store.

title: New Truce Bid Fails and the Lebanese Fight On
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3Another attempt to attain a ceasefire failed today and fierce fighting continued between rival factions in various Darts of Lebanon. An Arab League delegation under Secretary General Mahmoud Riad held talks here with Palestinian and leftist leaders in an effort to salvage the truce agreement, which Mr. Riad himself negotiated yesterday with the Christian bloc under President Suleiman Franjieh.

description: Back in 1975, books and special projects concerning the Loyalists were doing so well that one wag remarked: The Tories may have lost the Revolution, but they are winning the Bicentennial.

title: Can We Afford The Welfare System?
description: IN their State of the County messages, both Nassau's Ralph G. Caso and Suffolk's John V. N. Klein indicated that welfare was now absorbing close to or more than half their annual county budgets. This is not surprising in light of the fact that New York State welfare costs have climbed 968 percent in fifteen years (19601975); the question now is, when will it all end?

title: Second Century
description: If some of the quality of American life seems to have declined since the first year of Independence, it may be comforting to realize that a celebrant of its Centennial in 1876 had reason to feel lower in mind about the state of his country than Americans do today.

title: Education

Things are immeasurably different today for Miss Revonna and for other elementary and secondary school teachers across the country.

description: I AM one of those who voted for Carter in the preferential poll but who voted for nonCarter delegates. I did it on purpose. Thinking I was expressing an opinion politicians would be able to interpret, now find analysts saying I just could not find my way around the ballot. Since many people I !atom similarly split their votes, other possible explanations ought to be considered. Remember, Humphrei, Brown and Udall were, not on the nreferential ballot.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 3  A black man denied a custodial job by Los Angeles County because he was convicted of auto theft as a youth has filed suit in Federal District Court here seeking to eliminate the use of juvenile records as criteria for hiring county employees.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNEMPLOYMENT IN JUNE rose to 7.5 percent of the work force, up from 7.3 percent in May the Labor Department said . . . The composite of leading economic indicators rose 1.4 percent in May to 109.2 [1967=100] compared with a rise of 0.7, percent in April. . . The National Association of Purchasing Management reported the second quarter ended on a healthy note with new orders,, production, inventories and employment in good shape. . . Manufacturers inventories in May rose $1 billion, the largest increase since last September, to total of $149.17 billion, the Commerce Department said.

Dolan of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Patricia Dolan, to Peter Hadley Vogel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vogel of White Plains. title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: EA. Hegg, whose pictures are now on view at the International Center of Photography, was turnofthecentury studio photographer (weddings, portraits, christenings) who went Alaska in 1897 to photograph the Klondike gold rush. He was one of those slightly mad, selfwilled fanatics like Eugene Atget or Mathew Brady who neglected a safe commercial practice to undertake, on his own hook and with no assurance that anyone else would care, a photographic record of monumental proportions. As with Brady and Atget, it is not easy to fit his work into any of the traditional categories of art.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: To Dr. Howard B. Levy, a dermatologist from Brooklyn, the Vietnam war was a diabolical evil. As an Army captain during the war, he chafed at Army life, waving amicably at enlisted men instead of returning their polished salutes and declining to join the officers club on the ground that he did not like golf, tennis, swimming, or officers.

description: CHARLOTETOWN, Prince Edward IslandOnce a year, this compact capital of Canada's smallest province becomes the center stage of the allCanadian professional theater, presenting attractions conceived, produced and performed entirely by indigenous talent in the nineweek Charlottetown Festival.

description: Free speech (First Amendment) and fair trial (Sixth Amendment) are two of the most cherished policies of our civilization and it would be a trying taste to choose between them.

title: Doctors End Slowdown:.
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 3 (UPI) Doctors who had started. a work slowdown at Louisiana's two largest public hospitald'resumed their normal schedules today, pleased with new state malpractice legislation. Gov. Edwin W. Edwards signed the malpractice bill late yesterdajr, hours after it was approved by the House on a 72to13 vote. The law makes the state liable for any malpractice judgments against doctors employed at stateoperated hospitals.

Aftei Tom Seaver had allowed the hapless Cubs to tie the _game in the ninth on Jerry Morales's leadoff homer, the Mets strung together some nervous pitching and unlikely hitting in snatching the game back in the 10th.

description: According to figures released by the league president. Larry King, World Team Tennis drew 354,876 fans for 103 playing days in its first half this year, an average of 3,445 and a rise of 78 percent over the first half of last year. the same period prior to the Wimbledon break last year. the league had attracted 198,968 fans for an average 2,426. title: Ethel Myers Is Betrothed
description: Ethel Rita Myers, a graduate of the University of Denver, and Alexander Britton Browne 3d, an alumnus of the university's College of Business Administration, will be married on Aug. 21 in Chicago.

title: Notes: Room at The Inn, After All
description: The beat of the 200th birthday drum  is echoing in empty hotel rooms in the major Bicentennial cities of Philadelphia, Boston, New York and Washington. Hotel officials in all four report that the anticipated rush of bookings by overnight tourists has not materializes1 as of the beginning of July and that there are plenty of rooms available for the rest of the summer. They say fears of hotel overcrowding and no vacancy signs have created a backlash: People are staying away.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The ultimate in caution is a tomb squad circling a ticking package, or perhaps a musical historian gingerly examining a piece dubiously attributed to a great composer. The slightest premature movement, both groups of experts realize, may set off blasts that could wreck whole careers. The musicologists, at any rate, sometimes seem to be performing an exquisite slowmotion dance around a problem, caught in a trance from which only final authentication can release them.

title: 8 Die in HeadOn Crash
description: LA CYGNE, Kan., July 3 (UPI) A headon collision killed eight persons today and injured another. The Miami County sheriff's department said a pickup with a camper, carrying a family of seven from Kansas City, Mo.. was headed southbound when a small foreign car with two persons in it apparently crossed the center line and struck the pickup.

title: The life explains the art, the art explains the life
description: For most of his lifeand for the publicatlarge  Picasso was the modern artist, a vivid, controversial, public figure, until his death, on the French Riviera, in 1973, at the age of 91. Even after his quiet, private burial in the garden of his chateau at Vauvenarguesone of his several abandoned residenceshe continued to be headline news. His absolute refusal to make a will, the result of lifelong superstition about the mere mention of death or its practical consequences, resulted in a much publicized legal squabble, involving his wife, his son by a prior marriage, the children of former mistresses. His estate, recently estimated at $750 million, included a series of villas, chateaus, Parisian apartments, cluttered with the accumulations of a lifetime, a horde

title: This Time Harder Than Ever, With the Communists
description: ROMEThe formation of an Italian government often resembles a long, wordy and complex drama, where the audience falls asleep, wakes up at the loud voices, dozes off again, but remains aware somehow that the conclusion may be important.

title: The Region
description: As expected, New York City and its major municipal unions have reached agreement on a twoyear contract in which the gains are to be made by the city, not by its employees. The specific ways in which this manbitesdog arrangement will work are still to be decided and disputes are still possible. But the agreement, termed a memorandum of interim understanding, appears to reflect the clear understanding of both sides that the city must have demonstrable savings.

title: Minnie G. Vare, 71, Dies; Long in Medical Practice
description: Minnie Gallay Vare, one of the first women to be graduated from a medical school in Canada, died Friday of cancer at her home, 235 East 22d Street. She was 71 years old.

title: BIAS ON PENSIONS LAID TO COLUMBIA
description: One hundred and one women professors, administrators and researchers have filed complaints against Columbia University, charging that they are being denied equal pensions because women as a class live loneer than men.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: We have wide oak flooring in our homethat was given a double coat of walnut stain when it was built in 1960. Now there are small areas of the floor which have begun to fade perceptibly. How do I go about restaining these areas?  P.W., Durham, N. C.

title: The Dark Secret of Doctors Most Things Get Better by Themselves
description: Sometimes it seems to the people who cluster around Dr. Lewis Thomas, president of the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in New York and one of America's leading figures in medicine, that he must be leading a double life or at least a multipartite single life. A few months ago, he was the focus of attention at the poetry center of the 92d Street Y.M.H.A., where he read an essay at the monthly meeting of poetry lovers; weeks later he surfaced at the 75th anniversary of Rockefeller University in midManhattan. where he also read an essayon the future of biomedicine. to an audience that included Nobel Prize winners and a mix of multimillionaire industrialists and bankers. At the end of the month, he was in Washington, D.C., guiding a Presidential panel devoted to defending basic medical research in cancer. In between, you could have found him, whitecoated and absorbed, in a small laboratory in the Howard Building at Memorial SloanKettering, tinkering with horseshoe crabs. These crabs, Thomas says with awe in his voice, hardly look it, but they're one of nature's most successful creatures. They've lived on earth for million.; of years and have never had to change

title: Archibald Has a Request: Let Me Play in New York
description: Nate (Tiny) Archibald, of the Kansas City Kings, will be playing about 30 professional games in the Metropolitan area this summer. It is something he would like to do all year in his chosen profession as one of the best guards in the National Basketball Association.

It'll be different on Sunday, with the closing off of stretches of the Belt and the West Side Highway, said Deputy Police Chief William R. Bracey, coordinator of the municipal effort to cope with the holiday crowds. But so far, he said, all of our assessments have been correct.

title: THE EVOLUTION OF GREEK MERCHANT SHIPPING
description: Greek merchant shipping, since very early times, has been one of the major factors of the civilization, economic life, and glory of Greece. The geographic position of the country, as much in the ancient as in the modern world, outlined the remarkable role which was to be played by Greek Shipping throughout centuries.

title: Wood, Field &

title: Winning Isn't Everything It's Cracked Up to Be
description: The idea (attributed to Vince Lombardi) that winning isn't everything, that it's the only thing, is the shibboleth of sports. It makes sports nothing more than a continuing struggle to maintain a pecking order. It means nothing if the game is done just for itself, for the fun or the pride of doing it well; the only satisfaction is of prevailing over someone else, and the only motivation for playing is to be No. 1.

title: Turism and Environment
description: The development of international tourism is continuing, and indeed, at a rapid pace. For the decade 19751985, 0.E.C.D. foresees a growth rate of at least 57% over 1973. Greece's tourism in particular. anticipates much more, approaching at least 150%. This development is organic, as it is connected in the industrialised countries of origin of tourism with the increase of real incomes, with the development of education and with the expansion of urbanization. New roads, airports and harbours transform natural surroundings differently. Noise and pollution destroy the atmosphere. Beaches may become infected and the abundant animal and plant life of a certain region may be

title: DIPLOMACY THAT CONFORMS WITH PEOPLE'S ASPIRATIONS
description: Any country's foreign policy is reflection of its internal situation. This rarely disputed fact applies perfectly to the Moroccan diplomacy conducted scrupulously and assiduously by Their Majesties King Mohammed V and King Hassan 11, in full conformity with Morocco's national interest and the aspirations of its people.

description: ROME, July 3The Communist Party won a victory today when the leaders of major parties agreed to give it the job of President, or Speaker, of the Chamber of Deputies.

She was involved so ,intimately with the development of the Jose Limn company that her own personal development tended to be ,overlooked. With the estabJishment of the Pauline :Koner Dance Consort, making its official debut at the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College, she has allowed us to see her in a clear setting.

description: WASHINGTON, July 3President Ford, celebrating the birth of American independence in a series of weekend speeches, says that the American adventure remains an example to the world, but warns that the blessings of liberty must still be defended.

Schwartz, a chiropractor in Maspeth and Elmhurst, Queens, for 22 years and a founder in 1950 of the National Chiropractical Association Council on Psychotherapy, died Thursday at the Manhasset Medical Center Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L.I. He leaves his wife, the former Cecilia Langman; a son. Dr. Edward M. Schwartz, and two grandchildren.

They were the Four Musketeers of France, and now they are returning to the United States, where they achieved some of their most memorable victories when international matches rated frontpage headlines.

The jumping team, which lost the gold medal by onequarter of a fault in the 1972 Games, will compete at the Lake Placid show tomorrow against some of tomorrow against some of the leading amateur and professional jumpers in the country.

Gathered in book form, the work of the children is mixed with excerpts from the Founding Fathers, and from various resonant declarers of the American Dream in a range that includes Ralph Waldo Emerson and John Wayne.

title: Headliners
description: Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has said he was wrong in maintaining that the bureau stopped using breakins in domestic intelligence gathering in 1966. Breakins were standard practice in 3. Edgar Hoover's F.B.I.; though halted by Mr. Hoover in 1966, some bureau officials apparently reinstituted the practice after his death in 1972. Presumably Mr. Kelley was not informed of the burglaries by those who knew about them because they thought he would forbid them. How long the practice continued is not known.

title: Mobile Home Parks Still Meeting Resistance
description: Prospective buyers of mobile homes can put a compass point in New York City and draw a circle 50 miles from the center. Almost all mobile home parks of any distinction are located outside that circlenorth from Columbia County and east of Amityville, L. I., in New York State; south of the New Brunswick area in New Jersey.

title: Whether or Not a Loch Ness Monster Exists, Belief in Such Creatures Is Thought to Fill Human Need
description: The expedition that is searching the murky depths of Loch Ness may not find the longnecked monster that has been said to surface into the Scottish mist now and again. But whether Nessie, as the monster is popularly called, is discovered or not, people will continue to believe in such creatures, as they have throughout recorded history.

title: In Our Time
description: Eric Hoffer is always capable of making the kind of selfcongratulatory generalization about America that an American sage needs to make to be welcomed as sage, welcomed as a lowbrow's highbrowfor example, that basically America is the world's best place, that the best petiole in it want to be fullblown Americans, that the masses are to be trusted, and that the intellectuals are not. In other words he can be a comforting affirmer of democratic common sense and the capitalist status quo. He can even find money harmless, and find nice things to say about the trivial, meansouled middle class, whose weaknesses he always acknowledges but balances against what he regards as larger evils elsewhere. Perhaps it is this capacity in him that attracted Eisenhower, who liked Hoffer's first book The True Believer (though Hoffer did not like Ike in return), and then attracted Lyndon Johnson. In 1967 Hoffer said of Johnson in a TV interview with Eric Sevareidthat history would look on him as the foremost President of the 20th century, a statement that produced quick invitation to the White House and soon made Hoffer a member of a Presidential com

title: Europeans Plan Many Events To Celebrate U.S. Bicentennial
description: LONDON, Iuly 3 (UPI)In a gesture of good will toward the United States, some Europeans are celebrating the American Bicentennial almost as if the anniversary was their own.

title: Leadbelly Speaks For Every Black Who's Catching Hell
description: The dramatic climax of the movie Leadbelly shows shirtless Huddie Ledbetter, feet in chains, whitehaired but still strong at 59, defiantly raising a sledge hammer, pounding it into a pile of rocks on a hot, dusty Louisiana roadbed, and proclaiming: Six more months. Just six more months. You ain't broke my mind. You ain't broke my body. And you ain't broke my spirit.

Hand is now director of information for the American Conference of the National Football League:

title: An unpredictable maverick of baffling predilections
description: Philip Guston has had one of the most interesting and complex careers of any living American artist. A contemporary of the great first generation of Abstract Expressionists and a significant, if somewhat distant contributor to their triumphs, he has earned a reputation as a maverick of often baffling predilections. Socially committed muralist in the 1930's, eccentric realist in the 40's, master of a feathery abstract impressionism in the early 50's, maker of dark existentialist abstractions around 1960, Guston confounded absolutely everybody several years ago when he took to painting

title: Ernie Pyle Honored
description: DANA. Ind., July 3 (UPI)Ernie Pyle, the war correspondent who was killed in World War II, was honored today in dedication of his birthplace home as an Indiana state memorial. Ernie Pyle was a journalist of world renown and a patriot of monumental stature, Gov. Otis R. Bowen said in remarks prepared for the ceremony.

Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, apparently concerned by criticism of the many specialinterest provisions contained in the pending tax bill, has decided to take the extraordinary step of giving the committee a chance to reconsider its arlier decisions on the bill.

description: The controversy over Taiwan's participation in the Summer Olympics in Montreal continued yesterday, but threats by the International Olympic Committee to withdraw sponsorship and by the United States to withdraw its team were apparently dead, The Associated Press reported.

But the currents favored the state, saving its Atlantic shoreline for the million or so bathers who sought to escape the heat on this, the first big holiday weekend of the summer.

Remarkably, it has also been claimed that tactics comprise 99 percent of the game, leading one to wonder how the champions got so much mileage out of the remaining one percent.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Behind his hospital curtain, Muhammad Ali is being treated for a damaged left leg that will hinder his training for Ken Norton, if not his performance. Behind the same curtain, the world heavyweight champion also is hiding a damaged ego from financial problems surfacing now after the Travesty in Tokyo. He allegedly was guaranteed $6 million for the bore Sports with Antonio Inoki, the of Japanese wrestler. But The Times all he can be sure of is $1.8 million. The other $4.2 million is clouded. In the ripoff. Muhammad Ali's role suddenly has changed from ripper to rippee.

description: DETROIT. July 3 (AP) Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, the rookie, pitched a fourhitter for his first shutout and Rusty Staub slammed a threerun home run to send the Detroit Tigers to a 40 victory tonight over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Robert Altman is not 19 or 26 or even 40. He's 51, on the far side of that great halfcentury divide, but in talent, energy and output he's younger, more independent and more consistently innovative than any other director at work within the commercial film industry today. He's also the most cantankerously critical observer of the current American scene with access to actors, cameras, sound equipment and money.

title: Thomas Jefferson and His Shepherds
description: The author of the Declaration of Independence, Thomas Jefferson, was a longtime dog fancier, and carried on an extensive correspondence on the Ambient. both here and abroad. James A. News Bear, resident diet rector and curator of Monticello, Degs Jefferson's home .n Charlottesville, Va., has compiled a list of references from manuscripts at the historic estate.

description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., July 3 (UPI)Mark Landsberger, a 6foot8inch forward from Arizona State, was cut from the United States Olympic basketball team today, reducing the squad to its limit of 12 players.

His vision turns out to have been about as misty as most of today's visions about how America earned its living 200 years ago.

title: Art Versus Arts Advocacy In the NonCommercial Theater

By the time the conference was over, identifying the precise nature of these problems and concerns had become a source of considerable disagreement.

title: Roger Waldman Becomes Fiance Of Miss Heyman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Heyman of New York and East Hampton, L.L. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Louise Heyman, to Roger L. Waldman, son of Col. Irvin Waldman, U.S.A.F. retired, and Mrs. Waldman of New York.

description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Bradford of Pepper Pike, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara R. Bradford, to Warren Neil Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Davis of Denver.

title: Words and Women
description: Since the advent of coeducation, Frederic Fox, class of 39, notes in the letter columns of a recent issue of the Princeton Alumni Weekly, there have been many suggestions to modernize the words of Old Nassau,' some better than others. Nevertheless, Fox adds, I would stick to the original. When we amended the U. S. Constitution in 1921 to provide full citizenship for women, we did not modernize the words of The Star Spangled Banner. (. . . and thus be it ever when free men shall stand . . .) Or change America to land where my parents died. In like manner I hope we can continue to sing the manly words of Old Nassau in the generic sense, as our Declaration of Independence still says, All men [and women, ergo mankind] are created equal, it is dangerous to monkey with masterpiece.

title: Patriotism
description: They still tell in our family how the 14yearold, my father, came off the boat with a rope around his waist to hold up his pants. When he bent to kiss the ground, the rope loosened and his pants fell down. America! he cried.

title: For both the making of buildings was a noble act
description: There are striking, even disconcerting, parallels in the lives of Antonio Gaudi and Louis Kahn. Both were among the greatest architects the modern age has produced, yet each worked away from the mainstream in an intensely personal style with almost mystical overtones. And both died under similar and tragic circumstances: Gaudi was struck by a street car in Barcelona in 1926 and lay unrecognized on the street before being taken to a hospital; Kahn had a heart attack in Penn Station in New York in 1974 and lay deack, in the city morgue for almost two days before officials rea

title: Sunday Observer
description: Aged 20 years in 1776, he decided to sit out the revolution. It was too radical. Hotheads on the left trying to overthrow the government. Hangmen on the right burning with dutytoKing talk. It wasn't his kind of politics. He was a middleoftheroad man, a moderate. The middle of the road, that's where the future lies, he always said, and when a polltaker asked him whether he favored King George or George Washington, he said he undecided.

title: Chantal Defay Bride Of Richard L. White
description: Chantal Defay, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Defay of Clervaux, Luxembourg, and Biarritz, France, was married in Luxembourg City yesterday to Richard L. White, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Lupton White of Chatham, N.J.

title: Mexican Crew Tops Qualifiers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Pa., July 3An eightoared crew from Mexico scored the best time 7 minutes 17.8 secondsin winning its qualifying heat for 2,000 meters In the Independence Day regatta today on the Schuylkill.

title: Renewal
description: The Bicentennial is being celebrated by the people of the United States today not quite as their political leaders had at first planned.

title: STAMPS
description: In a most fitting issue for this July 4, a new nation, the Seychelles Islands, which became independent a week ago, combined the celebration of the severing of its colonial bonds to Britain with a tribute to the nation that won its independence from Britain 200 years ago.

title: The World
description: The Communist Parties of Eastern and Western Europe have publicly and explicitly buried the myth of a monolithic Communist movement directed by Moscow and in its place have articulated reality: each national party is free to find its own path to Socialism.

title: John Dickinson: Against Independence
description: On July 1, 1776, John Dickinson of Pennsylvania stood before the Second Continental Congress and made his last protest against a declaration of independence. The excerpts that follow are a reconstruction from the text that was printed by Hezekiah Niles in his Principles and Acts of the Revolution in America. affirm that prudent men do not abandon objects which are certain to go in pursuit of those which offer only uncertainty. Now, it is an established fact that America can be well and happily governed by the English laws, under the same king and the same Parliament. Two hundred years of happiness furnish the proof of it; and we find it also in the present prosperity, which is the result of these venerable laws and of this ancient union. It is not as independent, but as subjects; not as republic, but as monarchy, that we have arrived at this degree of power and of greatness. What then is the object of these chimeras, hatched in the days of discord and war? Shall the transports of fury have more power over us than the experience of ages? Shall we destroy, in a moment of anger, the work cemented and tested by time?

title: Another Meeting Between Kissinger and Vorster is Planned in Search for a Solution in Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Another meeting, possibly next month, is projected between Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa to accelerate their search for, a political solution in Rhodesia.

title: Audrey Coggeshall, a Designer, Is Betrothed to Anthony Kelly

title: Oslo Crew Arrives, Bound for Manhood And Tall Adventure
description: ABOARD THE CHRISTIAN RADICH, July 3This Norwegian fullrigged ship dropped anchor off Sandy Hook, N.J., at 11:30 A.M. today, ending a sixmonth, 5,000mile voyage from Oslo with a crew of boys who have sailed halfway to manhood.

title: City Like a Small Town During Holiday Festival
description: New York was like an oldfashioned small town yesterday, presenting an image of straw hats, little girls in summer prints, unusually orderly boys in proper knee socks and air so clean and fresh you could breathe it without seeing it. The tall ships of Operation Sail and the gray ships of the International Naval Review glided into a bright harbor where crowds were not overwhelming and where the spirit of the past somehow seemed more real than the present.

title: Human Achievement, Human Destructiveness
description: PASADENA, Calif.A spacecraft orbits Mars. An instrument of man on a mission of exploration, looks with cameras, reports to Earth by radio and waits to land and to discover. It hopes to discover if there is some form of life, however rudimentary, on another world. But whatever it learns about Mars, whatever it can learn, Viking I proves that there robust life on Earth.

Barnum, Deputy Secretary of Transportation; Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and Richard van Dusen of Birmingham, Mich.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market failed to produce any spectacular fireworks last week or a Bicentennial rally. But a number of Wall Street's more astute analysts, taking note of the market's veluctance to give up any appreciable ground, believe that the standfast pattern showing up on stock charts point to higher prices ahead.

title: NUMISMATICS

Uptodate sales figures have not been announced, but the actual train itself has been visited by more than 5,000,000 people during the first three  quarters of its 21month crosscountry odyssey and the medal is clearly designed to be a wellnigh perfect souvenir of a visit to that train.

The successful development of the machine tool industry can be easily demonstrated by the remarkable increase in output: from 24,000 tons and a value of 30.6 billion lire on 1952 to 160,000 tons and 360 billion lire in 1973. Further advances were achieved in 1974, when production reached 185,000 tons, valued at more than 500 billion lire.

title: The Economy
description: We have a splitlevel societyone of equal rights but unequal incomes. Our laws bestow upon us the rights to obtain equal justice, to exercise freedom of speech and religion, to vote, to take a spouse and procreate, to be free in our persons in the sense of immunity from enslavement, to leave America if we want, to benefit from public services such as the police and sanitation departments and the schools. These rights are distributed equally and free of charge, not on the basis of one's ability, education, income or looks. They may not even be bought or sold for money. They confer on Americans membership in a social and political club in which no one is more equal than else.

title: The Voice
description: Ellen Frankfort's book is not written on a grand scale. Bracketing off the bohemian origins and the sixties radicalism of The Village Voice (est. 1955), she tears into the seventies to analyze the breakup of the paper's one big ubhappy family. But even her chronicle of the 197074 period, marking the Voice's sale to City Councilman Carter Burden acid its resale to New York editor Clay Felker, narrows down to the sad fates of five former Voice women, including Frankfort herself. This isn't history, but herstory of such unsheathed vengeance that much of Frankfort's is suspect.

It takes Miss Vaughan time to get completely warmed up, to simmer down to a level at which she is cooking at her richest. The length of these two programs gave her an unaccustomed opportunity to develop that simmer to its fullest.

title: Books of The Times
description: Raymond Chandler was a detectivestory writer who thought he exceeded the genre. Like Dashiell Hammett, his acknowledged equal, he was a serious craftsman who took the form and infused it with wider accomplishments as well as an unusual American voice. He had a spiky integrity, as well as a touchy attitude of I'd rather have it bad, but mine own, than successful that did not fit him in well with the Hollywood committee system of art and left scratches on the publishers and literary agents who  handled him.

description: Espanola, N.M., July 4 (UPI)  A 12yearold boy from Heraandez, N.M., has been hospitalized with the plague, health officials said today. Officials said the youth apparently contracted the disease from fleas carried by domestic animals. It was the fifth case of plague reported in New Mexico this year.

title: Harvard Triumphs At Henley
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES, England, July 4The band of Her Majesty's Royal Marines opened the finals of the 140th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta with John Philip Sousa's Semper Fidelis, and closed today's racing with The Stars and Stripes Forever. In between, three American crews captured trophies and two others lost in one of the best Yankee showings of recent Henley regattas.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COUNTDOWN New Yorkers who may have missed the local concerts of the current Newport Jazz Festival can attend the final event tonight at 9 o'clock, when Count Basie heads a bill with his orchestra and stars of the forthcoming Grande Parade du Jazz Festival on the French Riviera. Tonight's event is scheduled for the ballroom of Roseland Dance City, 239 West 52d Street. Among the jazz contingent bound for Nice axe Milt Buckner, Vic Dickensoh, George Duvivier, Sweets Edison, Illinois Jacquet and Zoot Sims. Tickets tonight are $9, available at Roseland or at the New York Sheraton Hotel.

description: JERUSALEM, July 4When the hijacked Air France airliner landed at Entebbe Airport in Uganda last Monday, most people. Israelis among them, concluded that the sheer distance from Israel precluded the kind of military operation that had been employed against terrorists in the past.

description: MEXICO CITY, July 4Jose Lopez Portillo, a lawyer. intellectual and former Finance Minister, was elected today to serve a sixyear term as President of Mexico beginning Dec. 1.

title: Princess Anne Gets An Olympic Berth

July 4 With its famous bells ringing, bands blaring, choirs singing and fireworks exploding, this city today staged a joyous. cacophonous commemoration of that day two centuries ago when the representatives of the 13 English colonies met here to renounce their allegiance to the British Crown.

title: Boy, 11, Is Killed by Train
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 4 (UPI)One of three boys who were struck yesterday by a Conrail train on a trestle here, died of his injuries today, officials reported. A spokesman at Mount Vernon Hospital said the boy, 11yearold Lemon Jackson of Mount Vernon, had died at 1:15 A.M. His companions, Brian and Craig Hines of Plymouth, N.C., remained in critical condition. The police said the boys had been using the trestle as a shortcut.

Stanley Ketchel, the Michigan Assassin, was middleweight champion of the world and when Wilson Mizner, writer, wit and con man, heard that he had been shot dead he said: Start counting 10 over him. He'll get up.Not so many years ago, the statement, Sports was wit Ketchel. was the proudest boast in the fight. mobs. There aren't. many left. of make that boast today, and the quiet beauty The Times of La Jolla. Calif., seems an unlikely place to encounter one who can Nevertheless. Mrs. John B. Sebree, who lives there beside the sea, was wit Ketchel briefly, as she tells us in this small memoir:

title: ...Too Rapid Growth?
description: How much immediate danger is there of excessively rapid growth? Even the cautious Dr. Burns told Congress that he does not believe the economy is moving too fast now. But he thought a warning that we might be at that stage six, nine or twelve months down the road is very salutary. Other economists think that the chances are slim that the economy will be growing too fast for a longer stretch ahead, given the high degree unused capacity and manpower.

title: Peter Duchin Has the Beat From 2Step to the Hustle And Band Bookings to 82
description: Peter Duchin was enjoying himself, or at least he seemed to be, because he was smiling. He was also watching dancers feet, which he does often, and from time to time he spoke. Carmen Miranda strikes again. he said, while the boys in the band shook their maracas, and from somewhere off the dance floor on Long Islana a woman sidled up and whispered in his ear. It looked as if she were making an indecent proposal; actually, she only wanted to hear Stardust.

title: Ellington Concert Lacks Duke's Touch
description: The last of the Newport Jazz Festival's four concerts on Duke Ellington's music, this one covering the early 1940's and held at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening, served to underline a circumstance that has been emerging all through the series. No matter how well the various groups of musicians who played these concerts read the transcriptions of the Duke's arrangements  and for oneshot performances, the level was consistently high  and no matter how evocative the soloists were of the styles of the original performers, there was still something missing.

title: Mexican is Elected By a Wide Margin As Next President
description: MEXICO CITY, July 5Mexico's longruling Institutional Revolutionary Party estimated today that its victorious candidate in the presidential election yesterday, Jos Lpez Portillo, won 17.5 million of the 18.5 million votes cast.

title: Crumbling Trust
description: The first bitter fruits of Washington's shortsighted enthusiasm for splitting off the Northern Mariana islands from the rest of the farflung Pacific Trust Territory are now showing up in the corridors of the United Nations Trusteeship Council. A delegation from the Marshall Islands and Palau has arrived to ask for eventual independence from the United States but immediate administrative separation of the relatively prosperous Marshalls and Palau from their poorer island neighbors.
