title: Queen Gets Rousing Welcome as Visit Begins in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA. July 6 Queen Elizabeth II, the greatgreatgreatgreat granddaughter of George III, stepped ashore here today to start a brief East Coast tour celebrating 200 years of independence for this former British colony.

title: Auto Sales Up 20. 9% in Final Third of June
description: DETROIT, July 6Domestic new car sales climbed 20.9 percent in the final third of June from the yearearlier level, according to reports by the manufacturers today.

title: Two Struck Rubber Concerns To Deal With Union Locals

description: MIAMI, July 6 (UPI)Immigration officials have granted sanctuary to three Cuban men who rowed an eightfoot dinghy for 58 hours across the sharkinfested Florida straits because, they said, they feared they would be sent to fight in Africa.

description: WASHINGTON, July 6Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the coming election should be a time to build a new foreignpolicy consensus in this country and that any debate should be conducted in the spirit of partnership.

description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI)  The Treasury Department has prepared letters to major foreign car manufacturers instructing them to bring their United States auto prices in line with Government antidumping regulations.

title: Weak Automobile Stocks Lead Market Downward
description: Weakness in automobile issues helped send the stock market lower yesterday in moderate trading.

title: STATE FARM DROPS OFFER TO AID GEICO
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)The State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company has withdrawn its offer to help bail out the financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company, a spokesman C2 la today.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS CARTER AS VAGUE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6Ronald Reagan, far from assured of the Republican Presidential nomination looked beyond his challenge to President Ford today and aimed his rhetorical guns at Jimmy Carter, the apparent Democratic nominee, pausing to take only a little potshot at his fellow Republican.

description: WASHINGTON, July 6Jimmy Carter says that he expects foreign policy to be a major issue in the Presidential campaign and he seems ready to run with a program that decidedly places him in the liberal wing of the Democratic Party.

title: Proxmire to Run Again
description: MILWAUKEE, July 6 (UPI)Senator William Proxmire, a Democrat, one of the top votegetters in Wisconsin political history, said today he would run for reelection. Mr. Proxmire, who is 60 years old won his Senate seat in a special election in 1957 and was reelected in 1958, 1964 and 1970.

title: 2 YOUTHS GUILTY OF KILLING MAN, 71

title: City U. In Turmoil Over Faculty Cuts
description: The colleges of the City University were in a state of administrative turmoil yesterday as officials met to map faculty layoffsmore than a fifth of some staffs  and discussed other ways to cope with budget slashes under a new formula of allocating funds to the various institutions.

description: New York City, whose chronic complaint to Washington has been that it loses out to rural areas in the annual competition for Federal funds, got an appropriation from an unlikely Congressional committee: Agriculture.

description: WASHINGTON, July 6. The Supreme Court took the following actions today.

title: Teamsters Staff on Strike

Some 150 members of Local 10 of the Office and Professional Employes International Union, A. F. L. C. L. O. walked off their jobs Friday in a contract dispute with the international Brotherhood of Teamsters. Robert Holmes, an international vice president. and several other teamster orficials were met by pickets when they went to work today and walked through the lints.

title: HOSPITALS GIRDING FOR STRIKE TODAY
description: Hospital, union and government officials prepared last night for a strike at 6 A. M. today as negotiations remained at a standstill between most of the city's voluntary hospitals and 40,000 members of District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees.

description: The special anticorruption prosecutor's office lost two attempts yesterday to reopen key cases that it lost last month.

description: WASHINGTON, July 6 1 President Ford vetoed today a S3. 95 billion public works jobs bill that he said epitomized the empty promises and giveaway programs of the Democratic majority in Conaress.

description: The New York Yankees baseball team announced yesterday that it would spend $35,000 to upgrade sports facilities in a city park near Yankee Stadium.

title: SUIT IS WELCOMED BY SOVIET WEEKLY
description: MOSCOW, July 6 (Reuters)The editors of a Soviet weekly newspaper said today that they were quite nappy that an American correspondent here had filed a libel suit over its allegation that he worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

description: MOSCOW, July 6The Soviet Union today launched a manned Soyuz spacecraft apparently destined for a rendezvous with a research station put into orbit two weeks ago.

Not only will there be new trees, plants and flowers sprouting between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, 46th to 47th Streets, but the occasion will have pink lemonade poured free (while it lasts) from cut crystal punch bowls. Add, for a final party touch, piano music by Cy Coleman, the wellknown exponent of theater music.

title: SummerSchool Closings Jeopardize Handicapped
description: TRENTON, July 6  Joshua Edelson of Ridgewood, 9 years old, has not been able to go to his special education class since last Thursday because of the courtordered shutdown of the public school system. His parents fear the progress hei has made is in jeopardy.

Rodino Jr. of New Jersey may also be asked to undergo such an examination by Mr. Carter.

description: The broad list of stocks moved ahead yesterday to outperform the bluechip roster making up the Dow Jones industrial average. Moreover, the stock market produced a rally in the final hour of trading after showing lower prices earlier in the session.

description: James Scott Baker, a retired banker, died yesterday at his home on Main Street in Yarmouthport, Mass. He was 78 years old.

title: United Press, International In Paris, Frenchmen and foreign tourists sun themselves near the Eiffel Tower as heat wave goes on unabated.

title: Indonesia Reports 6,000 Papuans Lost After Earthquake

description: NEWARK, July 7 (AP)Affidavits filed in Fetlral District Court here today alleged that West Point cadets sold stolen military equipment, cheated on exams and impersonated Government officials, but were never punished for honorcode violations.

Mr. Mosco was arrested Tuesday for allegedly extorting money from an undercover police officer posing as a peddler near the South Street Seaport Museum.

In its first major pronounce, ment since last month's presidential election, the Communist Party's Central Committee acknowledged its relative defeat in the election.

title: Of Northern Fears, Southern Realities and Jimmy Carter
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y.Why the lingering antipathy toward him here in the East? is it the fear that he equivocates on the big issuesthat there is little difference between him and Ford or Reagan, as some liberals have actually suggested? Or that they will be singing Bringing in the Sheaves in the Northern parochial schools and that Jewish boys henceforth will be baptized by full immersion of the head at bar mitzvahs? Or that America will become ethnically pure again? Or that a twiceborn Christian will deny the state of Israel's sovereignty? Or is there something a little more complicated at work here?

title: Mr. Vorster's Gamble

Pupils in schools for blacks will no longer face the legal requirement that they be taught in Afrikaans, the language of the Afrikaners who form the majority of South Africa's white population.

description: WASHINGTON. July 7 (AP)The Food And Drug Administration today recalled because of contamination with a mold, more than 19,000 jars of peanut butter distributed on the East Coast.

description: United States District Judge Orrin G. Judd, who ordered the cleanup of the Willowbook State School for the Mentally Retarded, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Aspen, Colo., where he was attending a judicial seminar. He was 69 years old.

When he can, the 26yearold former Ethiopian university student engages American tourists in conversation. if he is lucky, the tourists buy him a meal.

title: Housen Takes Ike Golf By 2 Strokes at Wykagyl
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 7  Bob Housen, who was 38 years old yesterday, won the 24th annual Ike amateur golf tournament today and then received an unexpected gift exemption from qualifying for the Metropolitan amateur championship.

title: EXNIXONAIDENAMED AS FORD STRATEGIST

title: Polish Party Paper Calls Farm System Backward
description: WARSAW, July 7 (Reuters) Poles have been warned that their largely private smallplot farming structure has fallen as much as 15 years behind other Communist countries and 20 years behind those of Western nations.

title: A. & P. Registers 2d Quarterly Profit in Succession
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which is revamping its operations under new management, has turned a profit on its massive supermarket business for the second successive quarter. Its report yesterday for the fiscal first quarter ended May 29 showed net income at $6.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in contrast to a yearearlier deficit of $4.7 million.

description: While Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan is not exactly off and running for Mayor in 1977, he and a number of people who think he should make the race are making sounds that suggest that Mr. Sutton is at least ready and waiting to seek the post.

description: The block of East 11 th Street that runs between Avenue A and B used to he hubcap clipping  country. There was a fire almost every week.

He will succeed George Smith, who held the position two years while attending graduate school at Columbia. Rohan will retain his department chairmanship.

title: ROBERT PURVES, LED HAMPTON INSTITUTE

title: Personal Finance: Keogh Plan Requires New Data
description: If you had a Keogh plan last year and thought that you had finished filing with the Internal Revenue Service for 1975, think again. Another form is due by Oct. 15 in which further information must be provided. Keogh plans permit proprietors, partners, small business owners and their fulltime employees to defer certain taxes until retirement.

title: Gov. Grasso Stirs Internal Fight With Move to Oust Party Chief
description: HARTFORD. July 7After little more than a year, Gov. Ella Grasso of Connecticut is quietly working to drop her onetime campaign manager, William A. O'Neill, as head of the Democratic Party's state organization.

title: SOVIET DIMS BEAM AT U.S. EMBASSY

description: MONTGOMERY. Ala.. July 7 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace will address the Democratic National Convention Tuesday night on Government Reform and Business Accountability, Wallace aides said today.

description: Wednesday, July 7. Seventh day. Weather showery, track fast for six races, sloppy thereafter.

title: T.W.A. Flight Attendants Withdraw Threat of Strike

description: WEST BERLIN, July 7 (AP)1 Four women convicted or accused of terrorism escaped from a West Berlin prison early today by overpowering two guards, climbing onto a roof and hanging by window bars to reach the top of the outside wall, city officials said.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Mayor Thomas Whelan of Jersey City and Thomas Flaherty, former City Council President, who are serving 15year Federal prison terms for extortion and bribery while in office, have been denied paroles. Mr. Whelan, 54 years old, and Mr. Flaherty, 48, are in the United States penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa. Both were sentenced to 15year terms in Federal District Court on Aug. 10, 1971. on Feb. 17, 1972, each was sentenced to five years more to be served concurrently with the first terms. They were convicted of bribery and extortion in a conspiracy to obtain kickbacks from contractors, engineers and other suppliers doing business with Jersey City.

title: Unwise Veto
description: Though urged by Republican mayors around the country to sign it, President Ford has vetoed the $3.95 billion public works employment bill and denounced it as an effort by the Democratic majority in Congress to enact empty promises and giveaway programs. The bill would lead, Mr. Ford asserts, to larger deficits, higher taxes, higher inflation and, ultimately, higher unemployment.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Newark Human Rights Commission said in a longawaited report that there were serious shortcomings in the treatment of the city's Spanishspeaking population, most of it Puerto Rican, and proposed 24 recommendations for correcting them.

title: TAXAGENT GIFTS BY GULF ALLEGED
description: PITTSBURGH. July 7The Internal Revenue Service is investigating allegations that its employees who reviewed tax matters of the Gulf Oil Corporation regularly accepted gratuities from representatives of the company.

title: Lab Dropping Plans For a Queens Plant; Blame Put on Albany
description: A New Jerseybased medical laboratory that had planned to open a plant in Queens that it said would ultimately provide 1,000 new jobs now intends to abandon the project.

title: WORKERS STRIKE AT 33 HOSPITALS; All REMAIN OPEN
description: Thirty thousand workers at 33 private, nonprofit hospitals went on strike yesterday after union and management negotiators failed to reach an agreement on wages.

title: 3 Tie for Lead In British Open
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 7The first round of the British Open developed into an ecumenical congress today as a Japanese a Spaniard and an Irishman shared the lead at 69, three under par for the/baked and dusty links of the Royal Birkdale Golf Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If you wish to pontificate about South Africa during a time of stress and anguish, may one at least expect a basis of fairness and objectivity? This, unfortunately, your June 20 editorial Somber Warning lacks.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY, ENDING DEADLOCK, VOTES INCOME TAX
description: TRENTON, July 7The Democratic majority in the New Jersey Assembly put together the right combination of bills tonight to obtain passage of an income tax measure. The vote was 41 to 36, the minimum total needed.

title: Remembering Mr. Rusk
description: ATLANTA, July 7Does Dean Rusk have a younger brother?

title: TAPE IS DISPUTED AT HARRIS TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7Lawyers for Emily. Harris began their fight today to prevent the admission into evidence of a crucial tape recording in which Mrs. Harris's husband, William, is quoted as saying that we were forced to fight our way out of a sporting goods store where the couple had been detained as shoplifting suspects.

title: AUDUBON BUILDING TO USE SOLAR HEAT
description: FALMOUTH, Me., July 7Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, described the Maine Audubon Society's new headquarters building here today as an effort of real significance for the energy future of the United States.

title: Bank Ending Fees And Balance Rules For Free Checking
description: The National Bank of North America announced yesterday that it was eliminating all charges for checking accounts and would require no minimum balances in savings or checking accounts for its customers to obtain free checking.

title: Henry Loves Jimmy
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Henry Kissinger has apparently decided that Jimmy Carter will be the next President of the United States, and his reached our to embrace him.

title: The Best Ballplayer in the League
description: From the loudspeaker in center field, rock music thumped through Yankee Stadium as George Brett threw lefthanded off the mound. George Brett ordinarily throws righthanded, as all third basemen do. But in this moment before the Kansas City Royals were about to take infield practice, George Brett, his blond hair spread out below his tippedback cap, was throwing lefthanded off the mound for the fun of it. George Brett also was smiling, as all 350 hitters do. He's the best ballplayer in the league, his manager, Whitey Herzog, was saying in the dugout. He can hit, he can play third base, he hustles all the time. He's just a good kid, just great. You don't have to manage him, just let him play. And let him hit. Only 23 years old, George Brett is threatening to dethrone Rod Carew as the American League batting champion. He was elected by the fans to start at third in the AllStar Game on Tuesday.

title: AutoPart Prices Go Up: Ford 1.5%, Chrysler 4.8%
description: DETROIT, July 7The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said today they had raised the prices of replacement parts for their cars and trucks. The American Motors Corporation said it was going to raise prices of parts later this summer, but the General Motors Corporation said it planned no increase.

title: Utah Spring Water Suspected In the Death of 38 Wild Horses
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 7Thirty eight wild horses have now been found dead in the Orr Springs sector of the Dugway Proving Grounds. Army and Bureau of Land Management officials said today. Animal experts are unable to identify what felled the horses, but, indicated that the Orr Springsi waters seems directly implicated.

title: Met's Ballet Troupe Bows Tomorrow in New London
description: The Metropolitan Opera Ballet Ensemble, a 14dancer troupe from within the 29member ballet company at the Met, will make its debut as an independent performing unit tomorrow and Saturday at the American Dance Festival in New London, Conn.

title: Martin and Amaya Advance in Tennis
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 7 (AP)Billy Martin and Vic Amaya of the United States won secondround matches in the $100,000 Swedish open tennis championships today. Per Hegna, a Norwegian parttime player upset Juan Gilbert of Spain. 62, 63.

title: Housing Aide Quits
description: Lee Goodwin, New York State's Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, resigned yesterday because of her dissatisfaction with the compromise planagreed to recently by Governor Careyto end the bitter maintenancecharge dispute between the state and residents of Coop City. Page 63.

title: Astronauts Wanted; Women, Minorities Are Urged to Apply
description: HOUSTON, July 7 (UPI)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that applications for new astronauts to work on the upcoming space shuttle program would be accepted until June 30, 1977, and women and members of minority groups were more than welcome to apply.

title: Parents Seek Action on Closed Schools
description: TRENTON, July 7The first sign of public unrest over the courtordered school shutdown appeared at the State House today when parents and students from Ridgewooi showed up to lobby for a solution to the school financing problem.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CHICAGO (AL)Signed Steve Trout, lofthanded Ocher, firstround choice in tree. agent draft. Trout was assigned to Sarasota, Fla., of the Gulf Coast League.

title: To the Quick Wins Juvenile by Head
description: The Juvenile, which has been won by such notable thoroughbreds as Equipoise, Nashua and Bold Ruler, had its 100th running at Aqueduct yesterday. But despite its glamorous past, the 5 12furlong fixture attracted only five starters and four betting interests.

title: U.S. Decides to Continue Davis Cup Competition
description: MONTE CARLO, July 7The United States Tennis Association did an aboutface today when it decided against withdrawing from the Davis Cup international tennis competition.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITIES

title: PRESIDENT SAVES A FAMILY CUSTOM
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)The Ford Administration suspended today a ruling that fatherson or motherdaughter school events violate civil rights laws on sex discrimination.

title: NEWARK IS FOUND TO SLIGHT LATINS
description: NEWARK, July 7The Newark Human Rights Commission said today in a longawaited report that there were serious shortcomings in the treatment of the city's Spanishspeaking population, most of it Puerto Rican, and proposed 24 recommendations for correcting them.

title: David Eisenhower Writing Book About Grandfather's Character
description: David Eisenhower is writing an intimate character study of his grandfather entitled, Going Home to Glory: Dwight D. Eisenhower. Random House has acquired the rights to the book, which a spokesman for the publisher says will examine not so much how but why power flowed to the general so suddenly and in such quantity.

title: F.C.C. ACTS TO EASE PLUGIN PHONE USE
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission adopted standard plugs and sockets nationwide for telephones today to ease purchase and installation of telephone equipment by consumers.

title: Fisherman Feared Drowned
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 7 (AP)  A fisherman apparently drowned when he was pulled from his fishing boat by a large tuna, the Coast Guard reported today. William Rich, 31 years old became entangled in MS fishing line yesterday after hooking the tuna about 15 miles southeast of Gloucester aboard his vessel, the Seven Thirty. He was being sought today.

title: Atlanta Vanguard Opens Beachhead in Americana
description: The redandwhite quilt was neatly folded yesterday on the fourposter bed where Jimmy Carter will sleep during the Democratic convention. Twentyfive Olympia typewriters were stacked next to Isabel Hyde in the press office. Steve Elkin berated a sluggish trucking company into unearthing two big blow  ups of the candidate's picture that had been mislaid.

title: Tornado Causes Damage Near Bayonne
description: A tornado staged another rare spectacle in New York Harbor just before noon yesterday. The black, twisting code touched down in an industrial area near the waterfronts of Bayonne and Jersey City, whipping walls and roof from four buildings, tipping over trailers and cars and downing utility lines. Three persons were reportedly elightly injured.

title: TruckSnarled Garment Area Resisting Efforts to Untangle It
description: On West 39th Street, nearly a year after New York City started its program to speed the movement of goods in the truckclogged garment district, there was a familiar workaday scene the other afternoon.

title: Zoning Adult Movies
description: In a recent decision upholding Detroit's attempt to zone adult movies, the Supreme Court ruled that a city has the right to try to preserve the quality of urban life. and in doing so must be allowed a reasonable opportunity to experiment with solutions.

title: Nixon Scheduled to Speak At Fund Event for Wiggins
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to return to his birthplace next Monday for his first political appear. ance since he resigned the Presidency, the Secret Service confirmed today.

title: Mcadowbrook Polo Victor
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 7Russell Corey scored six goals and Alan Corey added three as the Meadowbrook polo team defeated Muttontown, 116, today in the Northeastern Circuit 12goal tournament at Hickox Field.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
Ohio and VW Reopen Talks on Plant Site
description: PITTSBURGH, July 7Ohio industrial development officials reopened their meetings with Volkswagen representatives today in hopes the West German automaker might change its tentative decision to open its first North American assembly plant in New Stanton. Pa.

title: Wealthy Rancher Questioned in Bomb Slaying of Phoenix Reporter,
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 6A multimillionaire rancher, businessman and political contributor has been questioned here in connection with the investigation of the slaying of Don Bolles, a reporter for The Ari zona Republic.

title: British. Liberals Choose Steel To Succeed Thorpe as Leader
description: LONDON. July 7  British Liberals have entrusted their hopes for more political influence to David Steel, a 38yearold Member of Parliament who campaigned for the job on the idea that such influence would not easily be achieved.

title: Too Hot to Work, Staff Closes Library Branch
description: A West Side branch of the New York Public Library was shut down yesterday by its employees who, citing contract provision, said it was too hot and humid to work. The move surprised, community residents, many whom had recently fought to keep the library open and had saved the jobs of those who work there.

title: Mets Rap 20 Hits, Win, 124
description: HOUSTON, July 7Staked to 12 runs on a 20hit attack. Jerry Koosman easily halted the brief threegame slide of the New York Mets tonight by turning back the Houston Astros, 124. The Met lefthander picked up his ninth victory against six losses in eight innings of work. Ken Sanders mooned up.

title: A Tornado Damages Port Area
description: A tornado staged another rare spectacle in New York Harbor just before noon yesterday. The black twisting cone touched down in an industrial area near the waterfronts of Eayonne and Jersey City, whipping walls and roof from four buildings, tipping over trailers and cars and downing utility lines. Three persons were reportedly slightly injured.

title: British Open Scores
description: Gene Sarazon, United Stales Withdrew

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Travis Price, at left, and Michael Freedberg, right

title: Books of The Times
description: Do you find it hard to believe that we may some day soon be able to travel from New York to Los Angeles by subway in 21 minutes? Or that some time before the year 2000 we could be getting edible protein from cow manure, garbage, sewage sludge and old rubber tires? Or that the ability to speak a new language may eventually be acquired by means of a chemical injection? Well, I certainly found such predictions incredible when I read them in Stephen Rosen's Future Facts: A Forecast of the World as We Will Know it Before the End of the Century. But among the more than 300 predictions that Mr. Rosen made when he completed Future Facts in 1975, enough have already come true to make even the wildly implausible seem possible. (For instance, many newspapers are already using video typewriters and computerized phototypesetting, and we know that the conversion of sunlight to electricity and heat is technically feasible if not yet economically practical.) So assuming that all goes well and there is a future, we may well soon be discussing the children in Urdu as we sit down to our rubbertire fortified dinners.

title: CUBICULO OFFERS DANCE EVOLUTION
description: In its short history, modem dance has encompassed expressionist pieces at the turn of the century, heroic drama thereafter, and determined nonmovement in the present generation. The six choreographers represented on Program 1 of the Cubiculo Dance Retrospective Tuesday evening touched most of the stages, starting at the beginning.

title: 2 WOMEN REBUT HOWE IN SEX CASE
description: SALT LAKE CITY. July 7 (UPI)Two police decoys testified today that Representative Allan T. Howe, Democrat of Utah, brought up the subject of sex after pulling up next to their parked car in Salt Lake City's redlight district last month.

title: U.S. CUTS ESTIMATE OF BUDGET DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)The Federal budget deficit for 1976 could be $9 billion less than was estimated a few months ago, largely because the Ford Administration significantly overestimated expenditures, Government officials said today.

title: Viking's Mars Landing Delayed Again
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 7 (UPI)Scientists postponed tonight for the secoond time the Mars landing of the Viking 1 space mission because the alternate site was found to be rougher than had been exfleeted.

title: Jersey Man Shot to Death
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 7 (AP)  Mark Arnold, 24 years old, was shot and killed in his apartment here yesterday by two men whom he apparently knew, the police said. Mr. Arnold's wife, Jacqueline, said she was in the bedroom when she heard a knock on their door. She said her husband let someone in and an argument ensued, during which, she told the police, she heard her husband say, I don't have any money. She then heard a gunshot, she said. The assailants fled.

title: Strike Against the Sick
description: The strike of 30,000 employees against 33 voluntary hospitals here represents an unconscionable betrayal of their responsibilities to the sick both by the union and by hospital managers, who alike refuse to face fiscal realities.

title: Indonesian Satellite to Be Launched
description: The first communications satellite to be owned by a developing nation, a $12 million Indonesian craft called Palapa, is scheduled to be launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., tonight by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Dance: Shadowplay
description: There are many layers of meaning in Antony Tudor's ballet Shadowplay, which had its first performances of the season Tuesday night and yesterday afternoon with American Ballet Theater at the State Theater.

title: Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES?? Angeles at Sacramento.

title: DONALD (LUKE) QUAY
description: Donald (Luke) Quay, 56yearold executive sports editor of The McKeesport Daily News for 18 years, died yesterday in McKeesport (Pa.) Hospital, where he was taken last Friday night after he suffered a heart attack, While covering the Pittsburgh Pirates baseball team, Mr. Quay frequently acted as the official scorer at. Three Rivers Stadium. His most controversial decision was on Sept. 29, 1972. when he called what appeared to he the late Roberto Clemente's 3,000th hit an error by the second baseman. Mr. Clemente got his 3.000th hit the next clay and it turned out to he his last hecause the Pirate outfielder was killed three months later in plane crash.

title: A GreasedPig Contest Stirs Squeals of Protest
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., July 7 (AP)A Humane Society official filed a complaint with the police yesterday against 25 members of the local Bicentennial commission, charging they held a greased pig contest Monday.

title: DANIEL KANPFER
description: Daniel Kanpfer, founder and president of Dan's Supreme Supermarkets, a chain of New York City food stores, died yesterda at his home, 11403 Queen.; Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 74 years old.

title: Body Found in Club Pool
description: MULLICA HILL, N. J., July 7 (AP)  The body of a missing youth, Timothy Jackson, 16 years old, of Mullica Hill, was found on the bottom of a swimming pool at the Raccoon. Valley Swim Club here yesterday, the Harrison Township police said. Police Chief Clarence Wingate said an autopsy would be performed.

title: 2 More Bodies Found After Gunfight in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July (AP)The bodies of two more possible victims of an Amazon jungle gunfight were discovered today.

title: BONDYIELD CUTS FIND ACCEPTANCE
description: Investment bankers tested the water yesterday with lower Merest rates for corporate and taxexempt bonds, and money managers accepted the lower yields. Highgrade utility bonds were priced to yield 6.75 percent, a quarter  point below similar securities marketed two weeks ago, and the issue sold out corn oletely.

title: Voluntary Hospitals Affected by the Strike
description: There are three general categories of hospitals public, proprietary and voluntary. Local public hospitals include such facilities as the municipal and Veterans Administration hospitals. Proprietary hospitals are private, profit  making institutions. Voluntary hospitals are private, nonprofit institutions, which tend to have strong lines to religious or educational institutions. Most of the inpatient care in the city is provided by voluntary hospitals.

title: Sudanese Move to Round Up Supporters of Attempted Coup
description: CAIRO, July 7The Sudanese Government, jolted by last week's coup attempt, has been carrying out a sweeping police action against suspected plotters and dissidents, according to reports reaching Cairo.

title: Texan Enters Guilty Plea To Role in Stock Fraud
description: Selwyn Weber of Odessa, Tex., pleaded guilty yesterday in New York to a charge of taking part in a $16 million fraud involving the sale and distribution of stock in Select Enterprises, a virtually worthless shell corporation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A State Department spokesman said in Washington that in recent months the Soviet Union had sharply reduced the level of microwave radiation beamed at the American Embassy in Moscow. He nonetheless rebuked the Russians for continuing the waves even at the current insignificant level and said that they thus showed a lack of concern for the living and working conditions of Americans. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Lack of Money Spurs Both Sides in Strike
description: Edith Jinwright Brown had her first baby in Mount Sinai Hospital. I liked the way they cared. she said, the staff, all the people I met. All the services have a slogan, We care. They do care.

title: Elaborate Funeral Planned in China To Honor Chu Teh
description: PEKING, July 7 (Reuters)China prepared elaborate funeral ceremonies today to honor Chu Tell, Its most famous soldier and elder statesman.

title: 54 Indians Are Arrested At Indian Bureau Building
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  Fiftyfour Indians who said they were trying to tour the Bureau of Indian Affairs building were arrested today on charges of disorderly conduct, bureau and police spokesmen said.

title: Welding Dispute Imperils Alaska Pipeline Opening
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The likelihood of a delay in the scheduled July 1977 opening of the Alaska oil pipeline has increased in recent weeks because of problems with the pipeline company's records of qualitycontrol radiographs of welds in the 800mile line, authoritative Government sources said today.

title: Justice Upholds Four Counts In Indictment of Hochberg
description: Justice William Crangle of the State Supreme Court in Albany has upheld four of the five counts of the indictment of Assemblyman Alan Hochberg, it was announced yesterday by Charles J. Hynes, the special prosecutor investigating nursling homes.

title: F.B.I. Chief Admits Alert on Indians Lacked Proof
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 7 Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged in court today that the bureau issued a nationwide alert about possible violence by American Indians over the July 4 holiday without proof that such events would occur.

title: In Memoriam
description: ERNSTOFFBessle. July 8, 1973. To my dearest sweetheart, I love and miss you very much Your Daughter, RUTH. FRANKNed David. on this third anniversary of the sad passing of beloved Ned our organization is dedicated to continue its philanthropic endeavors in order to Perpetuate his love for humanity.

title: GM Recalls 938 Cars
description: DETROIT, July 7 (AP)General Motors said today that it is recalling 938 currentmodel Chevrolet Monte Carlos to replace a possibly defective deluxe wheel that could fall off the car. The company's ChevroInt Division said that only those vehicle equipped with the optional PE2 style wheel are involved.

title: Absentee Voting Provided
description: HARTFORD, July 7 (AP)Former Connecticut residents now living in another country are eligible to vote in state elections by absentee ballots. Secretary of the State Gloria Schaffer said yesterday. She said new Federal and state liws enabled a person in another country whose last bona fide residence was in Connecticut tp register to vote by getting in touch with the clerk of the city or town where they once lived.

title: A Bicentennial Windfall for Ford
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  It would be hard to imagine a greater political windfall for a beleaguered President than the exuberant celebration of the American Bicentennial this week, which gave Gerald R. Ford a priceless opportunity to play the role of national leader rather than that of a candidate scrambling to avoid repudiation by his own party.

title: Music: Student Concert
description: In the six years that Lynn Geddes has been operating his Universal Academy for Music, which has its headquarters in Princeton, N. J., it has become a big business. This summer, more than 900 high school students from across the country are enrolled in the two choruses, two bands and orchestra that went off to Europe this week after rehearsing for a few days and giving a pair of concerts at Carnegie Hall.

title: U.S. Discourages Saudis From Buying New Jets
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Defense Department is discouraging Saudi Arabia from purchasing advanced fighter planes such as the F14 or F15 on the ground that they are too sophisticated for the Saudi Air Force to handle.

title: Rare Visitor to Tibet Finds a New Lhasa
description: LHASAAt the points where the old foot tracks that wended through the wastes of Asia to Lhasa brought the traveler to first sight of the holy city of Tibet, cairns stood, raised by the pebbles placed in thanksgiving by pilgrims through the ages. Now the car coming from the airport stops for that first sight only if the traveler has thought to ask, but this first glimpse of a city no longer holy holds still something of its old power.

title: FOREMOSTM'KESSON ENJOINED ON GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)A Federal judge issued an order today barring future violations of securities laws by ForemostMcKesson Inc. and requiring the company to conduct a full investigation of more than $6 million in questionable payments, including the largest domestic payments case yet involving sales promotion.

title: Fire Agency Fund Bill Vetoed by President
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) President Ford vetoed today an appropriations bill for the National Fire Prevention and Control Administration, saying that it contained provision that would enhance the power of Congress at the expense of the President.

title: Democratic Women to Discuss Party Role With Carter in an Attempt to Avoid a Convention Fight
description: WASHINGTON. July 7 Jimmy Carter and a group of leading women Democrats will meet in New York City this weekend in an effort to compromise an issue that threatens the harmony of the forthcoming Democratic National Conventionthe future role of women in the Democratic Party.

title: Snags Stall Merger in Basketball
description: The consolidation of the American Basketball Association into the National Basketball Association has hit several serious snags.

title: U.S. Wants U.N. to Debate Hijacking as, Well as Israeli Raid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 7The United States made it clear today that it wanted a broad debate of hijacking and terrorism when the Security Council takes up African charges that Israel committed wanton aggression ny its air rescue of hostages from EnItebbe Airoort in Uganda.

title: Simon & Schuster Takes New Lease on New York
description: Simon & Schuster, one of the country's biggest book publishing companies, signed a lease yesterday for 115,000 square feet of space in Rockefeller Center that will permit it to bring together its scattered New York City workforce and continue the expansion that has added 100 employees in the last year.

description: LHASAAt the points where the old foot tracks that wended through the wastes of Asia to Lhasa brought the traveler to first sight of the holy city of Tibet, cairns stood, raised by the pebbles placed in thanksgiving by pilgrims through the ages. Now the car coming from the airport stops for that first sight only if the traveler has thought to ask, but this first glimpse of a city no longer holy holds still something of its old power.

title: Soybean Futures Lase Early Gains In Profit Taking
description: After jumping the new daily limit of 30 cents a bushel yesterday early in the session in most months, soybean futures contracts dropped sharply amid a wave of profit taking. The July contract, which rose as high as $7.57 a bushel during the day, closed at $7.07 off from 57.27.

title: MARGOT M'CONNELL, EDITOR, FOOD WRITER
description: Margot. Murphy McConnell, who originated the food column in The New York Times in 1941 under the pen name Jane Holt. died Tuesday of a heart ailment in a hospital in London, where she was on vacation. She was 70 years old and lived at 64 East 94th Street.

title: Wine Barrels Come Into Their Own
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I.Mister, you're about 100 years too late for a job in your trade. That is what one unemployment officer told Edward White, a master cooper, in 1962.

title: T roy's Role in the Council Discussed by Colleagues
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr. who last week pleaded guilty to a Federal charge of incometax evasion, was applauded by some of his colleagues in the New York City Council as he took his seat yesterday at the head of the Council's Finance Committee.

title: Bank Robbery Suspect Mars Queen's Arrival
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (Reuters)  Policeman fired shots at a suspected hank robbery who fled into nearby Andrews Air Force Base today as Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip arrived for their twodav visit.

title: Notes on People
description: Who were the Americans that, as a Bicentennial gesture, put up $360,000 to help save the Battle of Hastings site for the British? The twoweek mystery was solved yesterday when a Princeton University professor, Julian P. Boyd, and a microfilming pioneer, Eugene B. Power of Ann Arbor, Mich., were identified in simultaneous London and Washington announcements. The American pledges they raised were part of the $1.2 million paid at a June 24 auction for the 100acre 12attlefield and surrounding estate by the British Department of the Environment. Although the department was short of money, it expects to preserve the historic site where William the Conqueror, leader of the Normans, won his title by defeating the Saxons in 1066.

title: CHARLES KELLOGG, L.I. MINISTER, 60
description: The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Kellogg, minister of the Old South Haven Presbyterian Church of Brookhaven, L.I. died June 28. He was 50 years old.

description: Shipping

title: Gustav Heinemann Dead; Bonn's Former President
description: ESSEN, West Germany, July 7 (AP)Gustav Heinemann. former President of West Germany, died today, six days after being admitted to a hospital with a circulatory ailment a hospital spokesman announced. He was 76.

description: If there were a Richter scale of shocks at the bridge table, the opening bid by South on the diagramed deal would have struck West with a force right at the top of the scale.

description: TRENTON, July 7The legislative standoff on the income tax in the State Assembly this week was an almost classic example of the growing problem in nearly every legislature in the nation  a fight between the cities and the suburbs.

title: Hidden Ford Supporters Found in New York Slates
description: In a contest in which even a halfdozen delegates could be crucial, President Ford appears to have a dozen or more hidden supporters among nominally uncommitted New York state delegates of the RepubliNational. Convention.

title: TRADING IN PUTS DELAYED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON. July 7Dashing the hopes of four stock exchanges that had hoped finally to begin trading in put options next month, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it would delay any decision on such transactions until January 1977. Put options give holders the right to sell stock under specified conditions.

title: I.O.C. Split Likely
description: MONTREAL, July 7 (AP) The International Olympic Committee is likely to be divided over the issue of putting on the Montreal Games, in view of the Taiwan dispute.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Defense Department notified Congress yesterday that it planned to sell 12 F5 fighter planes, made by the Northrop Corporation, to Kenya. Congress has 20 days to bar the sale if it chooses.

title: Tibet at a Glance
description: VITAL STATISTICSTibet, the socalled forbidden land beyond the Himalayas, has long been a mystery to most of the outside world. Invaded by Chinese Communist troops in 1950, it is now an autonomous region of China, equivalent to a province. it has an area of 470,000 square miles with a population of 1.3 million people. The capital is Lhasa, whose population is about 175,000. The religion is Lamaism, a late form of Buddhism modified by animism and primitive magic. Three years ago there were said to be2,000 primary schools and 10 middle schools with a total of 124,000 pupils.

title: Cambridge Council Bids Harvard Delay Its Gene Research

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The United States International Trade Commission announced today its first investigation of injury to a domestic industry under the revised countervailing duty provision of the 1974 trade law. Until the 1974 law the United States Treasury had the sole decision on whether imports were being subsidized by a foreign government and, therefore, must be subject to special countervailing duties. There was no need for a determination of whether a domestic industry was being injured by the subsidized imports.

title: CHRISTIANS REPEL LEBANON LEFTISTS
description: DEIRLIT, Lebanon. July 7 (Reuters)  Palestinian and Lebanese leftist forces yielded ground today in heavy fighting in northern Lebanon.

title: Bids Due on 1195 Stretch

The roadway will eventually link Trenton with the central Jersey shore. Bids will be opened Aug. 5 on a 4.3mile stretch from the present terminus in Jackson Township to Howell Township. The department will advertise for bids on the remaining portion in October.

title: U.S. Calls E.E. C. Tariff Plan Inadequate

title: Boston Police and Firemen To Fight Residency Law
description: BOSTON, July 7 (AP)Boston police and firefighter unions say they will challenge a law that requires any city employees hired or promoted after July 1, 1976, to be a Boston resident.

title: MANDA HOSTAGE, AILING, IS MISSING

Jimmy Carter awoke in Mary King's Capitol Hill townhouse, and at 8 A.M. bounded down the celadon green carpeted stairs for his usual cup of coffee and piece of toast. The former Governor of Georgia sat across the kitchen counter from Miss King, his collar open, sleeves rolled up, redpenciling the seventh draft of a major policy speech on health.

Midonick last December, has filed a motion in Surrogate's Court for relief from the judgment, charging the artist's daughter, Kate Rothko Prizel, with misrepresentation and misconduct.

Before each set of race results, a tape of First Call was played over the loudspeakers at 86 of the Offtrack Betting Corporation's 153 shops. The recording is part of a new broadcast system introduced yesterday to provide offtrack horse players with more uptodate information.

description: MILWAUKEE.  A desegregation plan for Milwaukee's public schools was approved today by a Federal judge and is to go into effect in September.

City, the league's leading hitter, and Fred Lynn, Boston outfielder and the league's most valuable player and rookie of the year last year, were among the eight starters named yesterday to the American League team for the AllStar Game, to be played next Tuesday night in Philadelphia.

description: Albert I. Siff, a retired insurance broker and an active Columbia University alumnus, died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday. He was 86 years old.

description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and its president, Frank R. Fitzsimmons, have been charged with attempting to control, dominate and monopolize interstate motor transportation in the United States in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Screen: 'Le Magnifique'
description: The talent of Philippe De Broca, the French director of "The Love Game," "The Five-Day Lover" and "That Man From Rio," began to melt in the mid-1960's. His last respectable comedy was "King of Hearts" (1967), and that was pretty soft. Mr. De Broca's "Le Magnifique," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts, is so soft it just sort of sloshes around the ankles like a lukewarm footbath. It's not unpleasant, but it's not much of anything.The movie is a dual comedy about an impoverished, alimony-ridden writer who turns out pulp novels, and about a glamorous James Bond-type of hero created by the writer. Jean-Paul Belmondo plays both roles with as much verve and style as Mr. De Broca's inspirations allow. Jaqueline Bisset is cast as the spy's sultry assistant as well as the writer's upstairs neighbor, a scholarly young sociology major, while Vittorio Capriolo plays both the writer's stingy publisher and the spy's archenemy.There is a lot of not very witty cross-cutting between the writer's drab problems in rainy Paris and the spy's extraordinary adventures in sun-drenched Acapulco, and because the scenery is very pretty, the Acapulco footage is more fun. At this point, though, it's impossible to parody the work of Ian Fleming with real enthusiasm, as Mr. De Broca here demonstrates. The good humor that one takes away from "Le Magnifique" will depend entirely on the good humor one takes to it.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY, ENDING DEADLOCK, VOTES INCOME TAX
description: TRENTON, Thursday, July 8The Democratic majority in the New Jersey Assembly put together the right combination of bills last night to obtain passage of an income tax measure. The vote was 41 to 36, the minimum total needed.

Two groups are performing each evening through Saturday, with two saxophonists, Marion Brown and Charles Tyler appearing tonight. Jazz at Itivbea is more experimental than most of the music heard at tha New port Jazz Festival, but the groups are carefully chosen and the lew el of musicianship is consistently very high.

PAUL, July 7A Federal district judge ordered the Reserve Mining Company today to halt its discharge of ore wastes into Lake Superior at midnight July 7, 1977an action that could, if upheld on appeal, force the company to shut down its extensive mining operations in northeastern Minnesota.

Here are some that this department has found dependable. Prices are moderate unless otherwise notedmoderate by New York standards, meaning you can get out for under $10 a person, drinks and wine not included.

New York, a city that the soldiers of her ancestor once occupied, extends to the Queen and to her husband, Prince Philip, an especially warm greeting on their arrival here today for a tantalizingly brief visit.

The ground was muddy underfoot, the result of welcome rains the night before, but nobody seemed to mind and the food vendors were doing capacity business.

title: Many Splendors Await Visitors to Outer Areas
description: One of the first things delegates to the Democratic National Convention and their families should understand about New York City is that of its more than 7. 7 million residents, nearly 6. 2 million live in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. of the remaining 1.4 million only a very small percentage lives in Times Square or along Fifth Avenue, or other areas most frequented by tourists.

title: Art: Feast for the Eyes at Museums
description: NEW YORK is unquestionably the art capital of the nation and, so far as contemporary art is concerned, probably of the world. But it does not fully function as such at the height of the summer season, which marks something of a lull in the affairs of the New York art world. The museums are open, or course, and crowded with great thinrs to see and a great many people seeing them. But by the second week of July, the art galleries, which bring us the bulk of the new art each season, are preparing to close down. and by the third week of July many will have locked their doors until after Labor Day.

title: VALIUM HELD LEADER IN DRUG ABUSE CASES
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) A new Government report relased today shows that the tranquilizer valium is associated with drug abuse crises more often than heroin or any other drug.

The ripples of Whither Thou Goest. By Eleanor Diens tug. 187 pages. New York: E. P. Dutton & Co. $7. 95. anxieties this has sent out through the society may account for the popularity of books such as The Total Woman, which offer a sort of escapefromfreedom prescription calling on the wife simply to submit to the husband.

title: Case of the Pregnant Mare
description: Joe Palmer, and perhaps others, wrote of a mare named Annie G. who raced on the bush tracks of the West when the ordinary purse was $300. The closing feature of the meeting was a $5,000 handicap at a mile and quarter, and although Annie G. didn't want to go that far, her owner needed money. Nursing a grudge against the owner, the racing secretary slapped 160 pounds on the mare and because the only rider available was a 100pound apprentice, she went to the post with 60 pounds of lead in her saddle pockets. She had post position No. 16 in a field of 17. She was a little thing who couldn't stand jostling, but at the start the outside horse came over and slammed her into the horse inside. in spite of that, she caught the leader on the clubhouse turn and was drawing away in the backstretch when her rider felt the saddle slip. Scared of the big field behind him, he pulled her to the outside fence.
