description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, July 9 (AP) A large Lebanese Christian military force, battling to clear a northern province of Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese leftists, attacked a coastal town in the area for the second day.

title: AGNES A. GILCHRIST, ART HISTORIAN, DIES
description: Agnes Addison Gilchrist, an architectural historian, died last Saturday at her Woods Hole, Mass., home. She was 68.

title: The American Farmer In the Dell
description: PARISDespite an even higher than normal budget of disasters this summerincluding the Lebanese holocaust, fighting in southern Africa, paralysis in Italy and continued mess in Ulster and the Aegeanthere has been one dominant subject of concern in Europe: the weather. And, as I believe Mark Twain said, everybody talks about it but no one does anythingwhich is surprising these days when the moon's backside has become more familiar than terrestrial meteorology.

title: CB Interference Brings F.C.C. Horror Stories
description: The explosive growth in citizens band radio in the last 18 months, with new enthusiasts emerging at the rate of 500,000 a month, has been accompanied by a voluminous catalogue of complaints to the Federal Communications Commission about interference with other electronic devices, ranging from church organs to automobile ignition systems.

title: 6, Strikers Arrested in Clash at Hospital
description: Six striking hospital workers were arrested yesterday and at least a dozen others sustained injuries allegedly inflicted by police officers in a brief exchange at the Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Sluggish Ethics
description: Thanks to that very worthwhile peoples lobby, Common Cause, the ethics committee of the House of Representatives has for the first time in its nineyear history formally investigated a member of the House.

title: Open Teamster Aide
description: CHICAGO, July 9A week ago yesterday, Daniel J. Shannon, executive director of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters principal pension fund, walked into a trustees meeting in Washington with seven resignations in his pocket. He told the 16 trustees that unless they agreed to his conditions, he and his six top aides were outing.

title: About New York
description: Down at the A. L. Bazzini Company Inc.Peanuts Our Specialty  everybody is walking a little taller these days.

title: Aides See Kissinger in Job if Ford Wins
description: WASHINGTON. July 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's associates now say privately that if President Ford wins the November election, Mr. Kissinger is virtually certain to remain in office for an extended period.

title: No Hiding Place
description: Enactment of a personal income tax in New Jersey eliminates one of the last holdouts in the nation against this broadbased, productive and generally equitable means of raising funds for the processes and operations of government.

title: Tax Logjam Broken by a Bill Filed in 1974
description: TRENTON, July 9Of the numerous state income tax plans proposed and rejected in New Jersey for a decade, the one that finally broke through the Legislature last night was first proposed in the Assembly in 1974.

title: Wright Enters Race For Chisholm Seat
description: The long political feud between Representative Shirley Chisholm and Councilman Samuel D. Wright came to a head yesterday when Mr. Wright announced his candidacy for her seat in Congress from Brooklyn's 12th District.

title: Harrises Lose Bid to Get Mistrial and Void Charges
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9William and Emily Harris, accusing the prosecutor of systematically excluding third world people from the jury, sought unsuccessfully today to obtain a mistrial or dismissal of the charges against them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL Al ice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: OTTAWA. July 9Simon Schuster Inc., the New York publishing company. has sold its Canadian subsidiary to the General Publishing Company of Toronto, ending a conflict with the Foreign Investment Review Agency here.

title: CAREY DEMANDS. HOSPITAL TALKS
description: As the strike by 30,000 employees against 33 private nonprofit New York City hospitals rounded out its third day, an angry Governor Carey last night denounced what he called an intolerable situation and demanded nonstop talks CO find a settlement.

title: Volunteers Pitch In As Patients Transfer
description: Rosalia Gunsberger sat in her wheelchair in the hot sun on the sidewalk in front of the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged on the Upper West Side yesterday morning and refused to let go of Beverly Willis's hand.

title: JERSEY'S SCHOOLS ALLOWED TO OPEN
description: TRENTON, July 9The shutdown of the state's 2,500 public schools ended today when the New Jersey Supreme Court dissolved its injunction halting the expenditure of state and local money for education.

title: 2 Wars in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 9There are two wars being fought in Lebanon. One is between the Syrians and the Pal, estinians. The other is between Lebanese rightwing Christians and an alliance of Lebanese Moslems and leftists.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Association of American Railroads reported today teat freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended July 3 totaled an estimated 14.4 billion tonmiles, 26.9 percent above the corresponding week a year ago, which included the Independence Day holiday. Carloadings in the same period totaled 1439,939 cars, 23.5 percent abovs last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 34.7 percent above last years.

title: Racial Bias Is Laid To Justice Systems In Crime Prevention
description: A group of black criminologists charged yesterday that predominantly white interest groups in criminaljustice systems throughout the country had deliberately kept blacks out of crimeprevention programs.

title: Mercantile Exchange Sends Potato Issue to Commission
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange's proposed changes in its highly criticized potato futures trading contract were formally submitted Thursday to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Opera: Brogue Troupe in Double Bill
description: New York's newest troupe of musical dramatists calls itself the Brogue Opera Company a waggish title that could apply to most other opera companies, large or small. But the little group, which gave its premiere performance on Thursday night, proved to be artistically solvent, at least, whatever its other problems. A double bill of two 18thcentury comic operas, imaginatively produced and capably performed by attractive young casts, provided more pleasure than many a more pretentious Cav and Pag that one has sat through.

title: The Game Everyone Is Playing
description: In Washington offices, in Manhattan watering spots and even on a Metroliner carrying a group of Democrats from one city to the other yesterday, they were playing the current political parlor game. Who's he going to pick for Vice President, they call it, and its vogue will last for about four more days, until Jimmy Carter spoils it by supplying the answer.

title: InterAmerican Bank Adds New Members and Funds
description: WASHINGTON. July 9Seven European countries and Israel and Japan joined the InterAmerican Development Bank today and, together with four other European nations soon to join, will put up more than $800 million to aid the economic development of Latin; America.

title: Arnold Gingrich, 72, Dead; Was a Founder of Esquire
description: Arnold Gingrich, one of the founders of Esquire magazine in 1933 and its principal guiding light in most of the years since then, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. Mr. Gingrich, who was given the title of founding editor earlier this year was 72 years old.

title: Nureyev and Fracci Aid Art Hit by Quake in Italy
description: Carla Fracci and Rudolf Nureyev will dance together for the first time in the United States here on July 23 with all proceeds from the performance to go for the restoration of art treasures damaged by the recent earthouake in northern Italy.

title: Huge NATO Maneuvers Set
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, July 9 (Rputers)  NATO's European Commander, Gen. Alexander Haig, today announced a huge program of maneuvers involving troops of every alliance nation committed to the defense of Western Europe. Ai statement from General Haig's headquarters here said the maneuvers, codenamed Autumn Forge 76, would begin in ???gust and end in late October.

title: FORD NOW FINDS REAGAN QUALIFIED TO BE PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 President Ford said today that Ronald Reagan was qualified to serve in the White. House aid he appealed to his challenger Ito keep ah open mind about the Republican nomination for Vice President.

title: Ah well. Half a vote is better than none.
description: Two weeks ago, Fate, along with the higher mathematics of a preconvention credentials challenge, mandated my selection, along with fifteen others (mostly women under 30) to share a convention vote with a willing member of the New York State atlarge delegation to the Democratic National Convention. Thus, suddenly and unexpectedly. I became a political and physical anomalya half delegate.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced an extension through Jan. 2, 1977, of its Sunday halffare program. The halffare plan is in effect from 6 P.M. Saturdays to I A.M. Mondays on subways and buses, and until 4 A.M. Mondays on its commuter rail lines. The M.T.A. also extended for six months two other bargainfare plans, the midManhattan shoppers bus ticket and the nightcoach plan formerly known as Night on the Town. The Sunday halffare program on publicly owned buses in Nassau County will be discontinued next week.

title: Irish Minister Sees Rumsfeld
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (Reuters)The Irish Defense Minister, Patrick Donagan, paid 15minute courtesy call today on Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld at the Pentagon, a spokesman announced. Mr. Donagan is visiting the Untied States in connection with the Bicentennial celebrations.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Los AngelesGerardo Aceves, Mexico City, knocked out, Domi Cauz, Manila, 1 round; weights unavailable.

title: Youthful Creators Of Dance Get Day
description: One chance to see what the younger generation of choreographers is up to will be afforded visitors this weekend at the Clark Center for the Performing Arts at the City University Graduate Center Mall on 42d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenue, where nine artists will participate in the 18thannual New Choreographers Concert.

title: West Irian Appeals For Help in Quake; Rescue Hampered
description: JAKARTA. Indonesia, July 9 (Reuters)  The Governor of earthquake  shattered West Irian arrived tonight with an appeal for aid in a disaster that may have killed 9.000 neonle.

title: 3 STORES OFFER TO SETTLE SUITS
description: Three of the New York area's bestknown fashion stores, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Bonwit Teller, have offered about $5.2 million to settle seven classaction suits brought on pricefixing allegations by their credit customers.

title: Hong Kong Is Agog Over Beauty Pageant
description: HONG KONG, July 9This British colony is in the midst of its biggest event since the riots that broke out here during the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's, or possibly, in the view of some, since the Japanese attacked Hong Kong in 1941. It's the Miss Universe beauty pageant.

title: Workers Groups Change Life of Tibetans
description: LHASA, TibetIf the line of the Internationale, Arise ye workers of the world, is the most famous call to revolution, Chairman Mao Tsetung's prosaic injunction, Get organized, appears to have had more historical impact.

title: Red and Tan Lines Is Seeking to Avert A Walkout Today
description: BERGENFIELD, July 9Negotiations continued today in an effort to avert a strike against Red and Tan Bus Lines Inc. at 12:01 tomorrow morning by 350 drivers, mechanics, garage workers and other members of Local 1558 of the United Transportation Union.

title: Pentagon Permits a Glimpse Of UltraSecret War Room
description: WASHINGTON, July 9A few weeks ago the Secretary of Defense, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and sundry flag officers and civilian officials assembled in a topsecret room at the Pentagon to supervise the evacuation of 116 Americans in Beirut.

title: The Times Names John M. Lee as Financial Editor
description: The appointment of John M. Lee as business and financial news editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor.

title: FELIX R. TYROLER
description: Felix R. Tyroler, a retired trade association executive, died Wednesday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He has 75 years old.

title: Screen:'Small Town in Texas' Opens at Cinerama 2
description: "A Small Town in Texas," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, is another foolish melodrama about rural life in a fictional state called Texas, where all the county sheriffs are crooked, all the sheriffs' deputies are named either Lenny or Leroy and are slow-witted, and decent young men go wrong because there's nothing else to do.This one was directed by Jack Starrett. It stars Timothy Bottoms as a fellow who comes home after several years in the slammer (apparently for smoking pot, which is an excessive sentence even in Texas) to pick up his girl, played by Susan George, who is the mother of his illegitimate son. Before they can get out of town there is one political assassination (never explained) and two extended chases in which a lot of police cars are wrecked. Bo Hopkins, who can be a good actor, plays the nasty sheriff.The film has been rated PG, which is a very lenient rating for a film containing so much violence, but perhaps the violence appears to be excessive because none of it seems to be motivated by anything more reasonable than the producers' greed.

title: Indian Trial Defense Ends After Testimony by Church
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 9 (UPI)The defense rested its case in the murder trial of two American Indians today after subpoenaed testimony by Senator Frank Church on activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation against targeted domestic organizations the bureau considered subversive.

title: Sponsor Will Kill NursingHome Bill Passed in Albany
description: ALBANY, July 9The sponsor of a nursinghome licensing measure by the Legislature in its closing hours last week said today that the bill would be killed because of a previously unnoticed provision that actually would weaken the state's control over possible nursinghome abuse.

title: New Jersey's Income Tax
description: The New York Times/July 10, 1976

title: Giants' Jacobson Quits Pro Football
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 9 (AP)Larry Jacobson, a defensive tackle and the New York Giants No. 1 draft pick in 1972 but who has been hampered by injuries the last three seasons, retired today, the club announced.

title: Strike Gives Hospital Officers A Chance to Try Out Old Skills
description: Jetty Sloven was glowing like an athlete at the peak of his game as he rushed to assist on a pacemaker operation.

title: New Chemical Reported To Aid Chicken Output
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Dr. Raymond M. G. Boucher, president of Wave Energy Systems Inc. of New York, was granted two patents this soiution can be used to disinfect and sanitize hatchery plants and to increase the weight yield of broiler chickens by dipping the eggs into it for a few seconds.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ASTERSala, beloved mother of Edward Rocket and Ruth Fredman, loving daughter of Harming Blau, devoted grandmother of Steven, Carey, Laurie, Rena and Joanne, dear sister of Sol, Herman and Leo Blau, cherished motherInlaw of Aaron Fredman and Peggy Ruckel and cherished sisterinlaw of Gerda Blau and Ruth Blau. Services Sunday, July 11, 10:30 A.M., The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Threat to Cancel Olympics Made Over Taiwan Dispute
description: OTTAWA. July 9Olympic officials declared today, in a formal statement, that the International Olympic Committee would have no alternative but to cancel the 1976 Games, scheduled to open in Montreal on July 17, unless Canada relented in its decision to prevent Taiwanese athletes participating as representatives of the. Republic of China.

title: Evidence of Poison Lacking In Deaths of Wild Horses
description: DUGWAY, Utah, July 9 (UPI) Bureau of Land Management scientists said today that preliminary tests had found no evidence of chemical poisoning or disease in 38 wild horses that died mysteriously on the Army's Dugway Proving Grounds.

title: Angola Leader Confirms Death for 4 Mercenaries
description: LUANDA. Angola, July 9 (Reuters)President Agostinho Neto today confirmed that death sentences would be carried out on four white mercenaries who were tried for their role in Angola's civil war, the Angolan News Agency reported.

title: Carter Mystery Pieced Together
description: Jimmy Carter is serving 10,000 pieces or fried chicken at his big Sunday night party for delegates to the Democratic National Convention, and already there are cries of fowl play.

title: Ford to Continue Flu Immunization Despite Problems
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) President Ford has decided to continue the mass swine influenza immunization campaign this fall despite insurance difficulties and scientific questions, Government health officials said today.

title: PRESIDENT GAINS 3 COLORADO VOTES
description: FORT COLLINS, Cola, July 9President Ford's nomination campaign was saved to. night from a threatened shutout in Colorado.

title: ALCOA AND ARMCO REPORT PAYMENTS
description: Two more companies, the Aluminum Company of America and the Armco Steel Corporation, that separately reported yesterday internal investigations had turned up questionable foreign payments and transactions.

title: ITALIAN CLEARS WAY FOR A NEW CABINET
description: ROME, July 9Prime Minister Aldo Moro confirmed his Government's resignation to President Giovanni Leone today in the first of a series of formalities aimed at giving Italy a new government after national elections three weeks ago.

title: CB Interference Brings F.C.C. Horror Stories
description: The explosive growth in citizens band radio in the last 18 months, with new enthusiasts emerging at the rate of 500,000 a month, has been accompanied by a voluminous catalogue of complaints to the Federal Communications Commission about interference with other electronic devices, ranging from church organs to automobile ignition systems.

title: Seven and Director Of a Bank Indicted On Silver Charges
description: DALLAS, July 9 (UPI)Eight men including the director of the Castle Bank & Trust Corn pang of the Bahamas, have been indicted on 16 counts of fraud in an alleged scheme to bilk investors in the silver market.

title: Torn Yawkev Dies
description: Torn Yawkev Dies

title: Soviet Bloc Drafts Joint Goals In Economy for 10 to 15 Years
description: EAST BERLIN, July 9Faced with energy problems and widespread difficulties in food supplies, leaders of the Sovietbloc countries pledged here today to work out common economic programs in key sectors, but they failed to reach final agreement on a plan for sharing of electric power.

title: PAPER IN MEXICO ENDSLIBERAL TONE
description: MEXICO CITY, July 9Excelsior, the independent newspaper that was seized yesterday by its conservative employees, appeared today with its traditionally Liberal view of Mexican affairs replaced by a conservative outlook.

title: Style Marks British Sales Pitch on Yacht
description: It was hardly an ordinary shipboard conversation. How many boards are you on? one guest asked another, as they strolled, gin and tonic in hand. on the top deck of the royal yacht Britannia.

title: Amin Cuts a Broad but Erratic Swath, and People Love Him or Hate Him
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 9Since seizing power in Uganda, in January 1971, Idi Amin, once a close friend of the raelis, has reveled in the spotlight of controversy. He broke with Israel and announced that Hitler was right about the Jews. Though he calls himself gentle giant and a man of peace, he has been accused by Uganda exiles of killing as many as 80,000 people.

title: Amor Res Publica Vincit
description: This is a busy weekend for liberal Democrats in Manhattan.

title: Jersey Chemical Landfill Told to Close in 10 Days
description: TRENTON, July 9 (AP)The state has ordered New Jersey's only chemical landfill to close within 10 days on charges of continued violations of environmental standards.

title: McCarthy Seeking to Rouse the Disaffected
description: WASHINGTON, July 9If a political proposition involves Eugene J. McCarthy, it is likely to be paradoxical. And the proposition that the former Minnesota Senator has been refining in the last year, in one of the loneliest races anyone has recently made for the Presidency, is his most paradoxical vet.

title: Huge NATO Maneuvers Set
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, July 9 (Reuters)  NATO's European Commander, Gen. Alexander Haig, today announced a huge program of maneuvers involving troops of every alliance nation committed to the defense of Western Europe. A statement from General Haig's headquarters here said the maneuvers, codenamed Autumn Forge 76. would begin in August and end in late October.

title: Yonkers Minorities Angered by Rumor Of Selective Use of New School Funds
description: YONKERS, July 9Leaders of this city's minority community reacted bitterly last night to reports, later denied, that the Board of Education intended to favor all  white schools in reassessing a drastic closure policy.

title: American Writer Protests Refusal Of Visa by Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Suzanne Massie, an expert on Russian affairs, complained to the State Department today that Soviet authorities at the last minute had refused her a visa to travel to Leningrad to work on a book.

title: CarTruck Crash Kills Five
description: LUDLOW, Mass., July 7 (AP) Five persons in an automobile were killed and three injured early today in a cartruck collision on the Massachusetts Turnpike. Those killed were identified as Lucinda Botalno, Natalie Moniz, Miguel Botalno, Paul Moniz and a girl identified as Anna. The State Police said that the victims were natives of Portugal traveling from Canada to New Bedford, Mass.

title: Judge Loses Job Over Reaction to Terrible Coffee
description: A Suffolk Couny District Court judge who last year had a coffee vendor brought to his chambers in handcuffs because he did rot like the coffee and then had reportedly lied about the incident was dismissed from the bench yesterday.

title: 3 Golfers Share Lead At Moline
description: MOLINE, Ill., July 9 (AP)A threeway tie for the lead at 134 developed in the $100,000 Quad Cities open today as Fuzzy Zoeller, the firstround leader, got off to a shaky start and Mike Morley and Rex Caldwell shot subpar rounds on a windswept course.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dualpurpose Investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices or best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount or, premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the Capital shares.

title: 51,041 and Fidrych Shut Out by Royals
description: For the third straight time. Mark Fidrych attracted a sellout crowd to Tiger Stadium in Detroit. But The Bird made the mistake of giving up a run, and the 51,041 fans who turned out to cheer the bizarre moves of the 21yearold rookie righthander had to accept a 10 defeat from the Kansas City Royals.

title: UGANDA BIDS U.N. CONDEMN ISRAEL FOR AIRPORT RAID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 9Uganda demanded in the Security Council tonight that Israel be condemned in the strongest terms for its raid on Entebbe airport last Saturday night to rescue hostages held by proPalestinian hijackers. Israel replied by charging Uganda President Idi Amin with conniving with terrorists.

title: Berg Succeeds Getty As Oil Company Chief
description: The election of Harold E. Berg as president of the Getty Oil Company was announced yesterday.

title: A Spot of Hectic Browsing for the Queen
description: Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip, trailed by a retinue of regal pinstripesuited attendants, strolled through a crowd of clamoring spectators yesterday at Bloomingdale's department store, the place where the trendy cornmon folk of New York are clothed shoed and coiffured.

title: JERSEY'S SCHOOLS MOWED TO OPEN
description: TRENTON, July 9The shutdown of the state's 2,500 public schools ended today when the New Jersey Supreme Court dissolved its injunction halting the expenditure of state and local, money for education.

title: It's Washable, ifs Wearable, It's Super Antelope
description: Gunter Riiecker first attracted attention with his Courregeslike clothes and his leather styles. That was back in the 1960's, however, and Gunteras he is known by his first namehas moved on. His present preoccupation is with one of those washable leatherlook fabrics. Like the prototypical Liltrasuede, it's made in Japan. This happens to be convenient, since the clothes are made in Hong Kong.

title: NoHitter for Dierker
description: Larry Dierker of the Houston Astros pitched the season's first nohitter last night, beating the Montreal Expos, 60, in the Astrodome. Details on Page 17.

title: BlumenfeldSteiner Duo Scores 2 Upsets in Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 9Jay Blumenfeld and Ned Steiner, a pair of University of Miami graduates playing out of New Jersey's Pleasant Valley, scored the major victories today in advancing to the quarterfinal round of the Anderson Memorial team golf tournament.

title: Dave Anderson
description: High above midtown the offices of the American Basketball Association have emerged as a shrine for collectors.

title: Yankees Win, 21, For Ellis
description: It comes as no surprise to the Chicago White Sox that the Yankees will have the most players on the American League AllStar team next Tuesday in Philadelphia.

title: Ballesteros Leads British Open by 2 Shots
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 9That 19yearold kid from Spain, Severiano Ballesteros, hung in there today and for the third straight round he led the 105th British Open.

title: A 30Second Spot of Your Very Own
description: A moving, lifesized three dimensional image of The Rolling Stones on a billboard? Singer Mamie Van Doren dancing onstage beside a fullsized, animated version of herself? Or, for proud parents, bow about a 3D wall portrait of their two year old, who blows a kiss each time they pass?

title: Marie F. Wemyss Affianced To William Larimer Richards
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Wemyss of Lloyd Harbor in Huntington, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Frances Wemyss, to William Larimer Richards, son of Mrs. George Harrison of Palm Beach, Fla., and Ralph S. Richards Jr. of Sewickley, Pa.

title: French Country Sales
description: The larger towns and provincial capitals have hotel des verges of their own, with a commissairepriseur presiding over each. In the absence of such an official, the sale is handled by the local notary (a powerful figure in. France, since all transfers of property pass through his hands) or by a huissier, combination processserver and bailiff.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Popular taste. In the world of massmarket paperbacks, July traditionally is a bonanza month, a time millions of vacationers carry good reads with them to the shore. Last year, aided by the phenomenally popular movie, Bantam's edition of Jaws made booksellers cash registers ring several million times.

title: Predicted Order of Finish in Olympic Track Events
description: Men

title: Miss Holton Married to T.A. Lombardo
description: Linda Lee Holton, daughter of Mrs. Harold Yudain of Stamford, Conn., and the late Curtis R. Holton, was married yesterday morning in the First Congregational Church of Stamford to Thomas Albert Lombardo. He is the son of Lieut. Albert M. Lombardo of the Stamford Police Department and the late Dorothy Burns Lombardo.

title: Beverly A. Lake Will Be Bride Of L. R. Wilkes
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Lake of Dedham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beverly Ann Lake, to Lawrence R. Wilkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Wilkes of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of West Hartford. Conn. The wedding is planned for September in New York. Miss Lake's mother, a lawyer in Dedham, was formerly president of the Massachusetts Association of Women Lawyers. Dr. Lake is a physician in Boston. The prospective bride is an estate planner with the United States Trust Company of New York.

title: Old Ironsides Joins Fleet for Operation Sail
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. CONSTITUTION, off Boston, July 10 (UPI)Old Ironsides, the ship that turned a young United States into a seapower in the days of sail, proudly joined sister windjammers and squareriggers from around the world today in Operation Sail.

title: SPEARING PERSONALLY
description: BY 1968 it had become apparent that population growth had pushed the world's capacity to feed itself close to the limit. My fellow economists at Drew University and elsewhere in the academic world were pointing out mat a crop failure anywhere in the world would mean hunger and, indeed starvation for many. One could wring one's hands in despair over the Malthusian implications of population growth. One could bury one's head in the sands of theological dogma. Or one could act.

title: The Dictator's Heirs Are Ready to Accept Reform
description: MADRIDIn Franco's house there were many mansions. They were peopled by ideological families that were not always friends and were even bitter rivals on occasion. But they were linked by loyalty to Franco, the man and a desire to stay together to keep the enemythe left in general and the Communists in particularfrom the door.

title: India Presses U.S. on Uranium Supply
description: BOMBAY, India, July 5Indian atomicenergy officials, worried over the uncertainty of a regular supply of enriched uranium from the United States for the Americanbuilt power plant at Tarapur, near here are considering alternative sources.

title: Julia Whayne Caldwell Is Married
description: The marriage of Julia Whayne Caldwell to John Albert Morris Jr. took place in Louisville, Ky., yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Richard H. Humke, assisted by the Rev. Patrick Caster, performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: Notes: Alpine Sliding
description: A new form of outdoor recreation called Alpine sliding has spread to the United States from Europe, and if it catches on here as it has on the Continent, America's ski slopes will be as crowded in July as they are in February.

title: The Contradictions in Carter's Budget Policy
description: This is the most relevant question about his philosophy on economic matters. The prospective candidate of this week's Democratic convention has spoken in some detail on such questions as sweeping tax simplification and reform, standby powers to control or delay major price and wage increases, and devices to induce private employers to hire more workers or to retain them during recessions. All of these are important as parts of economic policy.

title: 6 Naples Aides Convicted For Negligence on Cholera
description: NAPLES, July 10 (AP)Fivec public health officials and a former head of the Naples port authority have been convicted in connection with the 1973 cholera epidemic that killed 22 persons in the Naples area. All received suspended sentences.

title: Two Wheels and a PuttPutt
description: The moped, that cross between bicycle and motorcycle (more than the former but decidedly less than the latter) is beginning to puttputt its way across the American landscape.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The New York Times/Robert Walker

title: Tax Sin A Minority View
description: TO those accustomed to observing the New Jersey Legislature, the turmoil the tax debate has stirred in the Assembly and Senate chambers in Trenton over the last few weeks is not surprising. Even so drastic a development as the July 1 closing of the state's system of public schools has not produced the arched eyebrows one might anticipate.

title: Welcome Visitors
description: To the Democrats gathered here to nominate a President, New Yorkers offer not only the hospitality of A host but thanks for a vote of confidence in their city. No one who felt the warmth of New York during the Operation Sail weekend will question either its capacity for making visitors welcome or its almost smalltown pleasure in celebrating an occasion.

title: Navy Lifts F14 Flight Ban After Inquiry Into Crashes
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) The Navy's 200 sophisticated K14 jet planes have been returned to full flight status after being grounded because of two crashes.

title: Note to Readers
description: The alphabetical listing of stocks in both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange tables has been changed in two respects.

title: The Master
description: In a story called Under the Trees, Sue Kaufman tells of a schoolteacher who disconcerts his students until they manage to place him, to fit him into a recognizable slot. The teacher is a homely, slopeshouldered, taciturn man, given to alternate fits of elation and depression. His students regard him with blankfaced astonishment until the day he reads James Joyce to them with a brogue, an act that transforms him into Mister Morrgan. Their Volatile Celt. Their Irish Bard, Although they understand him no better than before, they can accept him now because they have a handle to grasp him by. What mattered was the somehow pleasing rightness of the sounds that poured from his lips, what mattered was the shining beauty of the day and being fifteen in a spring without war.

title: Fireworks Deaths Set at 4 During July 4th Weekend
description: BOSTON, July 10 (UPI)The National Fire Protection Association said four persons were killed and 15 others seriously injured across the nation in accidents involving fireworks during the Fourth of July weekend.

title: BRIDGE
description: If bridge players could be scored errors like baseball players, the results would be exceedingly interesting; although some of the experts would not care to read them. Unfortunately few errors are clear cut, and the borderline cases would generate endless objections from players who, in their own view, never make a mistake.

title: Consumer Spending: Is the Upsurge Solid?
description: Consumer spending, the bellweather of the nation's current economic recovery, has perked up again.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Lincoln Center already has at least a dozen directors and associate directors (including one entrusted with Media Development and another with just plain Development), but it ought to consider adding one more: a Director of Auffiihrungspraxis. That lovely German word means the study of how music of the past was perfcrrned during its own time, a fascinating subject about which there exist great piles of documents, pictorial and anecdotal evidence and convincing firsthand testimony. The Center's cur rent Mostly Mozart festival, which finds itself in a suitably small hall for the first time in its 10year history, could have used a dose of Auffiihrungspraxis this summer. Unfortunately, the chance was allowed to slip by. The schedule at Alice Tully Hall is not weighty with performers who have displayed great interest in historically correct performance practice.

title: The Abyss
description: Published in France nearly a decade ago, under the promising and allusive title L'Oeuvre au noir (that black phase to which alchemists refer when pursuing the separation and reduction of metals), The Abyss is an elaborate metaphor for the emptiness of history, the vanity of power, and the grandeur and misery of men, exemplary of whom is Marguerite Yourcenar's weary hero, Zeno of Bruges, the last in an alphabetic lineage which begins with Adam, the first man.

title: Susan J. Tahmoush to Be Bride Sept. 25
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Tahmoush of Elmsford, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan J. Tahmoush, to Douglas B. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Brown of White Plains. The wedding is planned for Sept. 25.

title: 76 Plus: Calendar of Events
description: There's a lot more to come. After all, the adoption of the Declaration of Independence 200 years ago last Sunday wasn't the end, or even the beginning of the endrather more like the end of the beginning. In fact, the

title: S. Palmer Leads by 2 Strokes
description: SPRINGFIELD, Pa., July 10  Sandra Palmer took the thirdround lead in the 31st United States Women's Open golf championship today putting herself just where she was after 54 holes last year when she won the title.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I am writing with regard to the article entitled Fishermen Compete in Shark Hunt (June 21).

title: Hugh Scott in Peking
description: PEKING, July 10 (Agence TrancePresse)  Sen. Hugh Scott, the Republican minority leader, arrived here today for a twoweek visit.

title: TAX SHORTFALLS WORRY GOLDMARK
description: ALBANY, July 10 The state is informing major banks and other holders of its bonds and notes that, as a result of unanticipated cost overruns and a shortfall in sales tax revenues last month, it is now less certain that the state's $10.9 billion budget will be in balance at the end of the fiscal year.

title: You Can't Keep Them in Peoria After Persepolis
description: The Middle East troubles aren't frightening off tourists, at least not from Israel and Egypt. Even the Israeli strike at Uganda, as a blow to terrorism. could be a plus.

title: Excerpts from a Discussion of Suffolk's Sewer Project
description: Following are excerpts from a discussion of Suffolk County's Southwest Sewer District protect held recently at The New York Times:

title: Hijacking in Reverse
description: The international repercussions are still growing as a result of Israel's extraordinary surgical invasion of a Uganda airport to rescue 103 Israeli citizens from proPalestinian terrorists who were holding them hostage. The aftermath has magnified differences among several African nations and the raid Is now the subject of what may be rancorous debate in the United Nations.

title: CHESS
description: A suggestion for cutting down the number of draws in tournament play would be to speed up the time limit for a game, since this would favor a more impulsive, less analytically cautious approach.

title: Kissinger Says Position Of Carter Is Compatible
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the foreign policy outlined so far by Jimmy Carter, the likely Democratic Presidential nominee, was fairly consistent with the policy of the Ford Administration.

title: Postal Strike Settled in Spain After Change in Official Policy
description: MADRID, July 10 Thousands of striking postal workers who had tied up the mails through most of Spain this week returned to work today after a major cnange in Government labor policy led to an agreement.

title: How Bill Swiacki Caught Em
description: From the Navy game in November of 1943 to the Columbia game on October 26, 1947, the West Point football team went 32 games without defeat. Then with Gene Rossides completing 20 of his 30 passes, eight of them caught by a gyrating genius named Bill Swiacki, Columbia upset Army, 2120. The next week Army traveled to Notre Dame for the last game before that historic series was broken off. Bill Heinz, out to cover the game for the New York Sun, was dragooned to address a pep rally of the St. Joseph Valley Notre Dame Club. Notre Dame was undefeated and, Bill told his audience, Army might just as well be, too.

title: Olympic Body, Canada Meet on Taiwan Dispute
description: MONTREAL, July 10After a daylong series of meetings with the International Olympic Committee, Canada's assistant secretary of state said tonight his government had raised several very interesting ideas in an effort to solve the political dispute over Taiwan's participation in the Olympic Games.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTONThose in Congress who believe the legislature should have more say in how the Federal Reserve conducts the nation's monetary policy have found at least half a champion in Representative Stephen L. Neal. a firstterm Democrat from WinstonSalem, North Carolina.

title: Michael Longyear Weds Miss Wendel
description: Christine Wendel and Michael James Longyear were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Charles Geisler, a Presbyterian minister, in Lewiston, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Wendel. The bridegroom is a son of Mary E. Longyear of Port Byron, N.Y. and the late Leslie W. Longyear.

title: Jody Walton Is a Bride
description: Jody Miller Walton, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Humphries Miller Walton of Pittsburgh, was married there last evening to Mark Callison Bundy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Bundy Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. Dr. James Blackwood performed the ceremony in the Shadyside Presbyterian Church.

title: For home, apple pie and security from future wars
description: Essentially Americans fought in World War II for negative reasons, seeking to regain the world order that existed before the rise of totalitarianism, and to retain the prosperity at home that the war had brought. So John Morton Blum powerfully argues in V Was for Victory, a brilliant analysis of the limiting force of American culture upon politics during the war.

title: Bologna's Cuisine:
description: I became aware of the subtleties of Italian cooking comparatively late In life. Italian food had always seemed a matter of cheese and tomatoes. Even touring Italy, I found spaghetti with tomato sauce and pizzas everywhere from Milan and Venice in the north to Rome and Naples in the south. Tourists expect such food, and so it is served to them. It was during a chance detour to the gracious northeasterly city of Bologna that I discovered the finesse and rich regional variety of la cucina italiana.

title: 2 NURSING HOMES SPEND ON LUXURY
description: ALBANY, July 10 (AP)Detailed audits of two upper New York State nursing homes indicate an effort to charge unusual luxury items to the taxpayers, including a $175 dinner for six persons and $958 for a countryclub membership and golfcart rentals.

title: H. L. Alverson Jr. Weds Miss Groves
description: In the Union Chapel in Hyannis Port, Mass., at noon yesterday, Katherine Groves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Freeman Groves of Scotch Plains. N.J., became the bride of Harry Lynwood Alverson Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Paul Gibbert of Virginia Beach and Mr. Alverson of Surf City, N.J.

title: Delegates to Convention Vie for the Guest Tickets
description: The day before the opening of the Democratic National Convention, a major concern among many delegates is not Jimmy Carter's VicePresidential choice, but where they can New York get guest tickets Political for their relatives, friends and Notes sponsors. It's a good question. The allocation of tickets to the four sessions of the convention is as closely guarded a secret as Mr. Carter's VicePresidential choice. Up to 7,000 seats will be available each day at Madison Square Garden for guests, with 5,800 for delegates and alternates and 3,200 for news organizations.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I am extremely allergic to oil paint and want to know whether it is possible to use a latex paint in the kitchen. My professional painter says that a latex will not last or wear. If we can use latex, what kind should we use? Mrs. T. L., Clayton, Mo.

title: Neal Grenley Weds Frances Wise
description: Frances Thayer Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Wise of West Hartford, Conn., and Menauhant, Mass., was married in Menauhant yesterday afternoon to Neal Forrest Grenley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Grenley of Tacoma, Wash.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: With the greater part of the Bicentennial's binge of ceremonies and euphoria now past, the nation's economic ship is headed into the second half of the year and along the way toward the tercentenary under a fairly good head of steam, despite some recent sputters.

title: Berlin Notes Bicentennial
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI) West Berlin gave its sister city, Los Angeles, a fivefoot bronze statue of a bear to help commemorate the American Bicentennial. The Berlin bear. the German city's traditional symbol, was presented yesterday in a ceremony at city hall.

title: Struck Home Still Provides Essentials
description: The daily bingo games and singalongs at Braker Memorial Home were canceled yesterday and patients were unable to get fresh linen or have their hair washed after 40 members of Local 1199 walked out at 6 A.M. as the hospital strike spread to some nursing homes and municipal hospitals.

title: Connecticut
description: The Connecticut General Assembly, according its critics, was good on detail this year but failed take much notice of the big picture.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Nothing in American museum life is quite like the exhibitions at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. They are about people, as the name of the Gallery would indicate, and necessarily they have a lot of portraits in them. But the people in question are not brought alive by portraits only. They are brought alive by paintings, photographs, objects and letters which document what they said, what they did, and what they saw. They are also brought alive by what other people thought of them. What we experience at the N.P.G. is resuscitation in depth. And as it never goes on too long, it follows that we come away stirred but not sated, instructed but not dazed, entertained but not halfdead on our feet.

title: Car Burnings and Assaults on Radicals Linked to F.B.I. Agents in Last 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation committed widespread acts of unauthorized lawlessness, including the burning of automobiles, assaults and illegal wiretapping, while conducting internal security investigations in the last five years, law enforcement sources said today.

title: F.T.C. CHIEF STAYS OUT OF HEADLINES
description: WASHINGTON. July 10A young lawyer of some note among Government officials but anonymous by national standards has quietly taken over the chairmanship of the Federal Trade Commission, an agency with the power to affect virtually every business and consumer in the country.

title: Point of View
description: Over the first six years of the Federally aided Community Development Program, New York City is slated to receive $825 million. This huge sum could make a very substantial contribution to the upgrading of many of the city's deteriorating and deteriorated neighborhoods, but only if the city will approach community development planning, not on a piecemeal, yearbyyear basis, but as a single program intended to be staged over a sixyear period.

title: Claire McMahon, Teacher, Is Bride
description: Claire Ellen McMahon, daughter of Edward W. McMahon of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Margretta McGaray McMahon, was married yesterday afternoon to James E. Clair Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clair of Weston, Mass., and Sebago, Me.

title: Take Two Crossed Sticks, Some Yarn, and
description: An ancient and comparatively little known craft that is presently undergoing a revival in this country is the making of ojos de dios (God's Eye) hangings and talismans. Long popular in Mexico and among the Indians of our Southwestern states, ojos (pronounced ohos) are actually decorative symbols of good fortune which are made by weaving colorful yarns around two or more crossed sticks to form multicolored geometric patterns.

title: New Jersey
description: TRENTONThe 1976 New Jersey Legislature convened in midJanuary, and almost before the welcoming speeches had stopped resounding, the legislators found a list of priority jobs to do:

title: Portuguese Entering a Democratic Era
description: LISBON, July 9After two years of revolutionary instability. Portugal is now endowed with new democratic institutions. The question is, will they work?

title: Ellen W Bates Becomes Bride
description: Ellen Walker Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Page Bates of Warren, Conn., was married in the Congregational Church there yesterday afternoon to Burton Loyal Stevens. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton I. Stevens of Middlebury, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: How to Enjoy the Games on TV
description: It is the Olympic men's 400meter dash final. Maxie Parks of the United States and Alberto Juantorena of Cuba are battling for the lead on your television screen when another American, Fred Newhouse, suddenly emerges from nowhere in the last straightaway.

title: 4 More Boats Finish Atlantic Race
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 10 (UPI)Four more competitors have finished the singlehanded transatlantic sailing race from Plymouth, England, to Newport, race officials said today. The arrivals brought to 32 the number to cross the finish line in the 3,000 mile Royal WesternLondon Observer race. A race official said that 54 boats remained at sea, including 12 unreported or unsighted since the start of the race June 5.

title: Show Boat Rounds the Bend Again
description: JONES BEACH HE more things change, the more they stay the same. At least that's what Guy Lombardo and his colleagues at the Jones Beach Marine Theater are banking on. Be cause 20 years ago, when they first produced Show Boat at their 8,200  seat, open  air theater, the classic Jerome Kern  Oscar Hammerstein musical set audience records that have never been equaled in the succeeding two decades.

title: The Corn Dance: Complex, Hypnotic
description: Santo Domingo Pueblo is a community of about 2,000 Indians in northern New Mexico, halfway between Albuquerque and Santa Fe off Interstate 25. It is a land of enormous space: empty pirion mesas sweep away to distant mountains; the sky is so vast that sometimes it rains, hails, snows and suns at the same time. It is the kind of country travelers drive through at 70 miles an hour, their eyes fixed on the highway, and on the green and white Interstate signs that mark their anonymous passing.

title: WILLIAM G. MORRIS, SPORTS DIRECTOR, 85
description: William G. (Country) Morr;s, former athletic director of the Albany Academy and a leading sports figure in the Albany area for more than five ?? ades, died yesterday in Glens Falls, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: It's Convention Time
description: NEW JERSEY'S delegates to the Democratic National Convention, most of whom opposed Jimmy Carter in the state's primary election last month, began arriving in Manhattan today, resigned to his Presidential nomination.

title: French Auctions: Lively, Eccentric
description: The auctioneer combines the dapper dress of an Adolphe Menjou with the patter of a W. C. Fields: Here is a porcelain fireplace mantel decoration, a king and a queen. The king's head is broken off, but we have it here for you. Actually it was knocked off at the storming of the Bastille. Someone in the back of the room runs his fingers along the keys of an old Pleyel piano. Eh, we're not at the Opera here, the auctioneer says. When a woman bids after he has rapped his gavel, he announces, You are late, Madamelike the Italian infantry.

title: The Changing American Voter
description: It would be tempting but probably futile to suggest to visiting conventioneers this week that between their deliberations at Madison Square Garden they forgo trips to museums, concert halls, libraries and other cultural centers and read these books instead. But it would not be amiss to say that those who advise parties and candidates would do a great service to their clients by mastering the material they contain.

title: Voice of Liberation
description: QUITE recently, and most surprisingly, my consciousness has been raised. One incident, trivial on the surface, but deep in its implications, has suddenly illuminated for me the feminist philosophy. I enrolled in a course in a local community school, an adult school that offers a variety of instruction in skills, leisuretime activities and business and cultural interests.

title: Quiet Little Table Wins at Aqueduct
description: Meadowhill's Quiet Little Table, a wellmannered gray gelding who never had been worse than third in eight races, reached the height of his career yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mel Patrick Lynch, the Bronfman kidnapping suspect who injured his foot during an attempt to escape custody, may have to have it amputated, hospital authorities Albany said.

title: Algiers Holding a Suspect In Fatal Stabbing of Bishop
description: ALGIERS, July 10 (AP)A young man with a history of mental illness has been arrested in the fatal stabbing of the Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Algiers, the police reported today.

title: Reporter in Manson Case Is Again Ordered to Jail
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (AP) A Los Angeles Times reporter. William T. Farr. has been ordered to serve another jail term for his refusal to reveal the source of a story about the Charles Manson trial.

title: Councilman Opposes Free Modern Statue for Dallas
description: DALLAS, July 10 (UPI) The city has been offered a free commission of a statue by Henry Moore, the sculptor, but one Councilman is afraid it might be too avant garde for Texans.

title: WOHAN ACQUITTED IN CAROLINA DEATH
description: HENDERSON, N. C., July 10 (AP)Sandra Dupree, a white Free Will Baptist minister's wife charged with murdering a black man, was acquitted today by a jury that deliberated three hours.

title: FISHING
description: THE cold water that has held the bluefish off Atlantic City for the last couple of weeks finally seems to be giving way to warmer temperatures. Blues are expected to provide good action for New Jersey fishermen this week as far north as the Farms and the Klondike Banks.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A triplefeature medallic attraction awaits numismatically. minded visitors to Third Century America, a Bicentennial Exposition on Science and Technology, at the Kennedy Space Center near Cocoa Beach, Fla. The U. S. Mint has set up an exhibit, the focal poiht of which is a special automated coming press. Visitors can buy a blank bronze planchet, place it in the press and activate the striking mechanism; an example of the handsome doityourself result is illustrated in the insets in the photograph at right. The buyer also receives, at a total cost of $1, a special red, white and blue package. Thus the triple attraction of this medal is that it is not only a souvenir of the Kennedy Space Center exposition, it is also an excellent 17761976 commemorative and, of course, a uniquely personal medallic memento.

title: Sister Attends Mary B. Adams At Her Nuptials
description: In the First Baptist Church of South Londonderry, Vt., yesterday afternoon, Mary Backus Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Worthington Miner Adams of Farmington, Conn., and South Londonderry, was married to Stephen Van Rensselaer Lines 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lines 3d of Pittsford, N. Y. The Rev. Robert N. Abarno performed the ceremony.

title: Miller's 66 for a 279 Captures British Open
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 10Johnny Miller made up a threestroke deficit today and, with a finalround 66, blitzed his way into the British Open championship, winning by six strokes. His 72hole aggre gate was 279, nine under par for the Royal Birkdale Golf Club, a seaside links course that suggests a moonscape.

title: Diane Weiner Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ernest M. Weiner of West Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Ellen Weiner, to Gary D. Hirsch, son of Rose Hirsch of New York and the late Benjamin Hirsch. Mr. Hirsch, a certified public accountant, is a manager of the New York office of Price Waterhouse & Company.

title: RABBI HENRY LANDES
description: Rabbi Henry Azer Landes died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 81 years old. Rabbi Landes was born in the Soviet Union but he had lived in the Revere community for 55 years.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees close their home stand today with a game at 2 P.M. against the Chicago White Sox at the Stadium. After the threeday break for the AllStar Game Tuesday night in Philadelphia, the Houston Astros come to Shea Stadium on Thursday for the first of a threegame series against the Mets at 8:05. There is another night game Friday and one at 4:05 P.M. Saturday.

title: Answers/Questions
description: MORE ON ROSE PETAL JAM (June 27)

title: Among the Guests Were 108 Dogs And a Monkey
description: Los ANGELES It was 5:59 P.M., and there were 10 security guards and $1,000 worth of caviar at the Dee Luxe Car Wash. For the last halfhour, a truck carrying four builtin portable toilets had been circling the midtown Los Angeles block. At 6:01 P.M.one minute after rush hour parking restrictions endedthe truck pulled into a parking space designated weeks earlier on a Universal Studios blueprint. Universal's 350 guests for the evening would be able to go to the bathroom.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Queen Elizabeth II paid a visit to Wall Street on Friday  a day when the stock market produced its best gain in more than three weeks.

title: Rev. Kenneth Mackenzie Larchmont Church Rector
description: The Rev. Kenneth E. Mackenzie died yesterday at his home at 41 Beach Avenue in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 57 years old.

title: Porsche Winner At Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 10 (AP)  A turbocharged Porsche 935, piloted by Rolf Stommelen and Manfred Schurti of West Germany, held on to win the sixhour World Championship of Makes endurance race today despite brake problems in the final half of the race.

title: Replacing Broken Sash Cords
description: Older houses with double hung windows (windows that slide up and down) usually have sash cords with concealed weights inside the window frame that counterbalance the movable sash so they will stay in place when the window is opened. When one of the sash cords break the window becomes difficult, or impossible, to open and close, and the sash has to be propped up with a stick to keep it from crashing down.

title: Brown Names Press Chief
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 10 (AP)Elisabeth Coleman, a 31yearold newswoman, will be Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s next press secretary. Miss Coleman, a freelance writer of Los Angeles, will succeed David Jensen, who will join the staff of The Sacramento Bee.

title: T.V. Vixen Scores In Arlinzton Stakes
description: CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)T. V. Vixen scored her 10th victory in 11 starts this season today in the $46,400 Patricia A. Stakes before 22,437 at Arlington Park. The victor earned $30,400, raising her career total to $220,379.

title: Civil Service, or Servitude?
description: LOCAL politicians trying to capitalize on negative publicity generated by the excesses of New York City unions are attempting to blame the salaries and benefits paid to Nassau and Suffolk civil servants for the rising costs and taxes on Long Island.

title: 13 Kilowatts of Electricity Produced From Sun's Rays
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 10Scientists at Sandia Leboratories here have generated the first significant amount of electricity from the sun's rays by producing 13 kilowatts at the laboratory's solar energy test facility.

title: How Youngsters Are Recruited For the Future
description: MOSCOW  They wriggled on the gymnastics apparatus like wormsskinny, silkenhaired little boys who had come Saturday morning to the Central Army Sports Club in Moscow. Exhibiting remarkable strength, they pushed themselves into handstands on the rings and took stationary pike positions on the parallel bars, moves ordinarily reserved for older gymnasts, not boys of 9 and 10.

title: Siderowf's Duo Gains FourBall Golf Final
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 10The 40th Anderson Memorial fourball golf tournament for leading amateurs along the Eastern seaboard produced its finalists after, today's play.

title: The Letters Of Charles And Mary Anne Lamb
description: Charles Lamb is remembered as the transparently pseudonymous essayist Elia. a connoisseur of nostalgia and whimsy, old china and roast pig. Nothing about Lamb was big or bold. With wry selfdepreciation he wrote to William Godwin, who thought in theories, I can vehemently applaud, or perversely stickle at parts: but I cannot grasp at a whole.

title: A Simple Method To Propagate Shrubbery
description: Rooting a stem cutting taken from the tip of a favorite rhododendron is not always easy. But there is almost sure success in bending a low branch to the ground and rooting the tip. This technique is called layering.

title: Fashion
description: The coolest fabric for sleepwear is good oldfashioned cotton. And the fresh crop of sleepwear is as classic as the fabricstyles range from tailored pajamas to lace  trimmed Edwardian nightdresses.

title: Israel's Hard Line Is in the Minority
description: JERUSALEMIt is always an agonizing choice: the lives of the hostages versus the demands of the hijackers. If a government gives in to save lives, will the action not ultimately cost lives? Do justice and morality have anything to do with it? In fact, does a government have the right to decide? For Israel, which has coped with more than its share of hijackings, these are questions of urgent concern.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JULY 11, 1976

title: ART
description: SOUTHAMPTON THE art of Antonio Ciccone is spindrift. Like the windblown sea spray, it is elusive, poetic and wispy, resisting convenient descriptions. Just when the observer thinks he has seized its essence and summoned the vocabulary to articulate his perception, it moves mercurially off in another direction, doing unpredictable things the observer had not anticipated. But spindrift can also be light, without significant substance and impact, and so can Mr. Ciccone's art.

title: Letters
description: The question has sadly become almost rhetorical when many women still ask, Why isn't there a pill for men? (The pill turns twenty by Paul Vaughan, June 13). Is it possible, granting even the complications that exist, that male scientists are a little more careful about tampering with the male body and psyche than with the female's?

title: Carter Sees No Conflict With Jackson on Defense
description: Jimmy Carter said last night that he found no disagreement between his own view that defense spending could be cut by $5 billion to $7 billion and the opinions of Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, and advocate of a strong defense.

title: Memo to the Delegates
description: Delegates: This is a Democrat speakin. We wanted you back; 52 years is quite a wait. Welcome Kansas to the Hotel Americana, Michigan to the Hilton, Idaho to the Lexington, Missouri and Tennessee to the Drake, Vermont to the Taft.

title: Ann Frances Levy Is Married To James B. Paull, an Engineer
description: Ann Frances Levy, daugher of Mr. and Mrs. William Levy 3d of Plattsburgh, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to James Bartlett Paull, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Paull of Weston, Conn.

title: The Region
description: Nobody likes taxes, and nobody cares overmuch for the person who voted for them. But legislators have usually bowed to realitypublic services must be paid for by public moneyand passed, tax measures, however unpopular and however much not conducive to political survival.

title: 50 Million Eggs Against Swine Flu
description: While some may call the egg a killer because of the cholesterol, there's no doubt it's also a life saver. Viruses used for vaccines may be grown within an egg. Fifty million or so eggs were to be used to produce the vaccine for the swinetype influenza that was called a national threat just a few months ago.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayTwin Brooks K.C. allbreed, The Mall. Route 24 and J. F. Kennedy Parkway, Short Hills, N.J.; 1,182 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Robert C. Seamans Jr., head of the United States Energy and Research Office, says windmills will never account for more than 1 percent of our total energy supply (NASA Has Troubles With Its Big Windmill June 27).

title: Letters: What Does O.T.C. Really Cost?
description: The June 13 article by Mike Kalina on The $359 Waikiki Package (Travel Section, June 13) missed one very significant point. It failed to mention how much the onestop tour charter cost when all was said and done. The author paid an extra $100 for a better hotel; how much more was spent on meals, drinks, excursions, cabs and so on? How much should a couple budget for meals, sightseeing, perhaps a show or two? Would they actually be better off taking an allinclusive package (in which everything is prearranged at wholesale rates) for a few hundred more than the advertised price of barebones O.T.C.?

title: Mailbox: Olympic Picks
description: The selection process of the United States Olympic team has recently come under controversy. Injuries suffered by track stars Steve Williams and Marty Liguori prevented them from qualifying. Other potential medal winners did not perform up to their usual standards in Oregon.

title: Marion Weber Miller Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Miller of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Marion Weber Miller, to Douglass Morson Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Barnes of Chatham. Mass.

title: Gifts in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, July 10 (AP)Fifty thousand people lined the docks, streets and airport here this morning to watch Queen Elizabeth pay a 40minute visit.

title: Weddings
description: AlumsSchapiro

title: Crew in crisis
description: A lot has changed since this reporter, fresh to the sport of rowing, watched the premier American crew win the world championship at Lucerne in 1974. My view came, alas, not live, but on film, projected 11 months after the fact on the wall of a darkened dormitory room at Brock University in St. Catharines, Ontario. But the loss of immediacy was made up for by the company. Running the projector was Alan Shealy (6'4, 185 lbs., Harvard 75), the man who had stroked the boat. The others in the room had also contributed to the winning effort, including, to no small degree, the crew's controversial coach, Allen Rosenberg, a bundle of neuroses, contradictions and rowing wisdom packed into a diminutive fivefoot oneinch frame.

title: Weicker Confident of a Victory; Democratic Contest Is Spirited
description: HARTFORD. July 9This is a Democratic statethe numbers obviously present a problem. Senator Lowell Weicker said today while enjoying a brief respite from the Senate and the campaign. He is the Republican incumbent and is seeking a second sixyear term. He is also widely believed to be the frontrunner and despite the numbers he seems confident.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WHEN Bill Johnson wants to go for a Sunday drive with his wife, Jean, and their 3yearold daughter, Heather, he stays away from the shorebound Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: DINING OUT
description: THIS gem, every facet polished, is set back from Westhampton's Main Street in an attractive white frame house. We found the charming atmosphere extraordinary. It is a place to savor during dinner like a fine sauce, the memory of it lingering long afterward. Patricia and Peter Lenz, who have conceived and realized A Moveable Feast, are people of consummate taste. It shows in the furnishings of the dining roomspleasant green and white, antique chests and sideboards, lovely bricabrac and porcelainsand in the beautiful table appointments that no restaurant supply house would carry.

title: $185 Million Marked For New Roads
description: OUTLAYS of $185 million are planned for major highway projects in the state in the next 12 months. The program, which embraces 10 counties stretching from Passaic and Bergen to Monmouth and Ocean, includes continued construction of Interstate I95 and I280, major planning on controversial extensions of I95 and I287 and important urban highways in New Brunswick, Bayonne and Jersey City.

title: World News Briefs
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 10 (AP)Officials called today for a major effort to evacuate about 50,000 surv ivors of the West Irian earthquake and landsliu es that is estimated to have left 9,000 persons dead.

title: The Family Arsenal
description: When The Family Arsenal appeared in England last March, it was widely praised as one of the most evocative, intelligently crafted suspense novels in yearslike the early fiction of Graham Greene: an entertainment to please the wiser sort. One can easily see why. The sensational plot turns on terrorist bombings, art theft, gunrunning and guilt about Vietnam; the cast of freaky, foulmouthed conspirators crosses a spectrum from radical squalor to radical chic; and the sense of urban rot edging toward ruin is palpable on every page.

title: Unnecessary Barriers for the Disabled
description: THE car pulls up at the curb and stops. The driver, Mary Ann Sciacca of Commack, pulls her front seat forward, reaches to the back of the car, and slides her wheelchair out ?? she unfolds the chair and locks it in place. Sliding across the front seat, she carefully lifts herself into the chair. She hooks the leg rests onto the chair, then places her legs into position on the rests. She reaches into the car for her purse, closes and locks the door and maneuvers toward the supermarket. Only then does she notice the poles in front of the store that keep the carts in and the wheelchairs out.

title: UNION BROADENS HOSPITAL STRIKE; TALKS AT IMP ASSE
description: The fourday strike of nonmedical workers at 33 private, nonprofit hospitals in the metropolitan area spread yesterday to 14 nursing homes and 10 municipal hospitals, but the impact of the widened walkout appeared to be slight Negotiations remained at a standstill.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: You may have seen him standing, poised, unwrinkled and confident, on the platform of your railroad station.

title: Peru Puts Down A Brief Rebellion By Rightist General
description: LIMA, Peru, July 10 (AP)Peru's leftist military Government has put down its first revolt since taking power almost a year ago.

title: Headliners
description: Former President Richard Nixon has been disbarred by a New York Court. The Watergate  connected charges were brought by the New York Bar Association, and resemble those contained in the articles of impeachment drafted by the House Judiciary Committee in 1974. The court ruled that Mr. Nixon had obstructed the due administration of justice and thus violated the Code of Professional Responsibility that all lawyers must observe. Mr. Nixon has on several occasions attempted to resign from the New York Bar, but has been rebuffed because he refused to meet a legal requirement that he admit inability to defend himself against the charges brought against him.

title: Montreal Is Near by Air, Rail and Bus
description: Travelers who prefer to leave the driving to someone else will have no problem getting from New York to Montreal for the Olympics.

title: Crowned Heads
description: Thomas Tryon seems to have been born with a silver story in his mouth. He spins bestselling novels: The Other, Harvest Home, Lady. He probably has written another best seller in Crowned Headsa tale with the impact of The National Enquirer crossed with The Day of the Locust.

title: Olympics on TV
description: Channel 7 (Eastern Daylight Time)

title: Ford Gives Olympic Athletes a SendOff
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., July 10With the fate of the 1976 Olympics hanging in the balance over the admission of the athletes from Taiwan to Canada, President Ford journeyed today to this college town near the Canadian border to give an elaborate sendoff to the first of 425 American athletes going to Montreal for the games.

title: Card of Thanks
description: CHIGEIvan Chio. Our sincere ?? to an the lovely morale who cared end shared In our hour of sorrow.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONIt was a stunning finale, a sharp contrast to the boredom of the year before. Each morning for eight workdays running, the Justices of the United States Supreme Court entered their marbled courtroom and took their seats before a crowd of tourists in town for the Bicentennial. Then, grimfaced, they announced their rulingsat least one landmark a day, often two, sometimes three. The death penalty upheld. Gag orders banned. Racial discrimination in private schools forbidden. The power of Federal judges sharply curtailed.

title: LIME GIFTS AID FRESH AIR FUND
description: I would like to give 50 cents because that's all I can afford since I'm only 11, Richy Leffler wrote. Good luck with the charity.

title: U.S. Enters Electric Talks
description: PITTSBURGH. July 10 (AP)Federal mediators entered contract talks today between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and its four major unions, in the face of a possible nationwide strike Monday by more than 55,000 workers. The unions involved are the International Union of Electric Workers, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, the United Electrical Workers and the whitecollar Federation of Westinghouse Salaried Unions.

title: Unlikely Duel: Broker vs. Banker
description: The problem, it seems, is that the bankers are moving into the traditional turf of the Wall Streeters. And the competition for the most part is coming from major moneycenter banks, such as Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation in New York, the Continental Illinois Corporation in Chicago, and the Crocker National Corporation in San Francisco.

title: Hoffa Son Accepts Trial
description: MIAMI, July 10 (UPI)Charles L. O'Brien, foster son of James R. Haifa, the missing formr teamsters, unton president, volunteered yesterday to return to Detroit for trial on charges of illegally accepting gifts. Mr. O'Brien, proclaiming his innocence, waived extradiction on the charge that he had accepted a $3,000 automobile and $147 in repairs from a Detroit automobile dealership he was trying to organize.

title: Gerald Clark Weds Miss Westermann
description: Cynthia Jeanne Creore Westermann and Gerald Bruce Clark were married yesterday afternoon in the Park Avenue Methodist Church by the Rev. Philip A. C. Clarke. Their parents are Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Westermann of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Marion E. Clark of Kennewick, Wash.

title: New Orleans, Italian style
description: Although the French connection in Louisiana cooking is well known, observant food buffs visiting New Orleans soon become aware of the strong influence of the fine Italian hand in the local cuisine. This less publicized but no less important influence is a result of several waves of Italian immigration, which began in the 19th century and which brought, for the most part, natives of Sicily to Louisiana. Through the years, these newcomers developed a very special strain of New OrleansItalian dishes.

title: In Auto Racing, Accidents Are NoFault Collisions Sometimes
description: I brought the Eagle out of Turn Six, a 180degree right hand turn, and accelerated down the undulating straight toward Turn Seven, which was a fairly slow lefthander. The approach to Turn Seven was sharply uphill, and from the car the turn itself was invisible behind the hill.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The Hidden Health Bomb by Dr. George Jacobs [Opinion Page, May 16], calls for immediate action to protect Suffolk County residents from diseases transmitted by ticks.

title: CarterKissinger Debate
description: During most of his energetic pursuit of the Democratic nomination, Jimmy Carter has focused on domestic issues and the need for change in the Washington Establishment. His recent comments on international issues and national security affairs suggest that he expectsand is ready to precipitatea major debate on foreign pcilicy in the Presidential campaign no matter who is the Republican candidate.

title: Linda J. Moore, Buyer, Is Bride Of D. R. Holmes
description: Linda Jane Moore, daughter of Mrs. William Gilbert Moore of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Mr. Moore, was married yesterday afternoon to David Reesor Holmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Holmes of Old Brookville, L.I., and Sharbot Lake, Ontario.

title: Moses's barbecued shrimp
description: Cooked and served in the shell, these sublimely fragrant shrimp require fingers if one wants them peeled. Aficionados know that shrimp have far less flavor when peeled, and so they usually pull off only the legs and eat the shrimp, shells and all; slow cooking in oil and wine tends to soften the shell anyway. The less adventurous can peel the shrimp, but they should then be dipped in an oilrosemary sauce before being eaten. It is not a good idea to shell them before cooking, as the delicate meat tends to harden in the oil. Marinating the shrimp in the oil mixture before cooking is my own addition, but one that seems to earn enormous dividends in flavor.

title: South Africa Rejects Plea To Free Black Juveniles
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10Police officials here have rejected demands for the release of several dozen black juveniles arrested during the rioting in the Johannesburg area three weeks ago.

title: A letter to the Queen
description: As you may know, I am the fellow from New Jersey who has been trying very hard to gain an audience with you to discuss something important, in private, during your visit. Unfortunately, a member of the royal entourage has informed me that your schedule is so tight that you couldn't spare me even a Bicentennial minute. I am forced, therefore, to seek expression in this public forum, hoping that I may win your attention as you wind up your visit to America and head for the Olympic Games

title: Will Rogers Says: Letters to the Delegates
description: Will Rogers, the cowboy humorist, began covering political conventions for this and other newspapers in 1920 and continued through 1932. The letter below is an amalgam of some of his choicer remarks, altered slightly for context and updated. The material is taken from a new book, Convention Articles of Will Rogers, published by Oklahoma State University Press, Stillwater, Okla., 7.95.

title: Keith O'Hara Weds Monique Merriam
description: Monique Merriam and Keith William O'Hara, graduates of McGill University in Montreal, were, married yesterday afternoon in the Thorndike Hilton Chapel of the University of Chicago. The Rev. Robert White, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.
