title: Deborah Jones Becomes Bride Of Karl Karlson
description: Deborah Ann Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L Jones 2d of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday evening in the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church to Karl Jon Karlson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Karl Eugene Karlson of Providence. R I.

title: Village Protected Like Fortress
description: MONTREAL, July 10Change the scenery a bit and Olympic Village could be a concentration camp, a fortress under siege or a Wild West frontier town waiting to face the bad guys.

title: Black TeenAlters'obless Rate Constant Despite U.S. Recovery
Where to Buy The Times
description: Following are major distribution points for The New York Times in Montreal. The Times is also available at major hotels, Metro stations and other newsstands:

title: Stadium Fire in Chicago Forces 5,000 to Evacuate
description: CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)Some 5,000 persons in a crowd of 62,000 attending a rock concert were evacuated today when a fire of undetermined origin broke out on the roof and an upperdeck section of Comiskey Park.

title: Convention reading
description: In the sweepstakes for the next Secretary of Statea widely publicized contest almost unimaginable eight years agoGeorge Ball is still running strong in the stretch. Under Secretary of State for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and considered the foremost opponent of the Vietnam War in the latter Administration, Ball now ranks as one of the most articulate members of the foreign policy establishment. He could easily be labeled an elder statesman, but that would imply a man whose wisdom may be valued solely to ratify a decision, the dispensable Polonius whose ideas are stale. Nothing could be more misleading. Not only does Ball think well, he writes welland I have generally found that this is

title: Foreign Policy Survey Finds 71% Support Policy of Detente
description: Americans participating in a program of the Foreign Policy Association called Great Decisions '76 approve the Ford Administration's policy of dtente with the Soviet Union, favor establishment of full relations with China and recognize the right of Palestinian Arabs to an independent state in the Middle East, the association reported last week.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Two Soviet astronauts are now orbiting the earth aboard the space experiment station Salyut 5 where, according to the Soviet press agency Tass, they will conduct research in weightlessness, medical and biological phenomena, and geological and atmospheric observations.

title: Controversy Is Christianity's Style in Much Of Africa
description: During the recent rioting in the South African black community of Soweto, some of the sharpest criticism of the government's conduct came from dissident church leaders.

title: BRITAIN SUMMONS AIDE OVER UGANDA
description: LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) Britain is recalling its High Commissioner in Kampala, James Hennessy, after having received a totally unacceptable reply to queries about a missing hostage, Dora Bloch, 75, the Foreign Office said.

title: Teterboro Airport: State's Busiest Private Field
description: TETERBORO DURING the course of an ordinary work week, Toshihito Sakow, an industrial architect from Teaneck, may fly to Boston for a 10 A.M. appointment, be back in his office by 2:30 P.M. for consultation with other clients, spend the foltowing morning in Washington and then return in time for a 2 o'clock meeting with his staff.

title: Author's Query
description: For a biography of Richard Halliburton, American authoradventurer, I would be grateful for any letters, photographs, or other personal recollections.

title: Home Style
description: When the time came to build a house on land they owned down the road, they chose this ultracontemporary design. First choice was a onestory atriumlike structure with rooms grouped around an inner court.

title: RubaDubDub, More Fun in the Tub
description: Standing in the shower or sitting in the tub and washing just isn't enough anymore. It has to be more fun. And water pulsating units, or water massages, apparently do the trick.

title: What's Doing Around BAR HARBOR
description: THE OLD DAYSDuring the Depression 30's Bar Harbor, on Maine's Mount Desert Island, was a playground of the rich and prominent. Radio tycoon Arthur Atwater Kent bought the Sonogee mansion from Frederick Vanderbilt, a grandson of the Commodore, added a wing, an Italian garden with 700 rose bushes and a 10car garage complete with carwash and turntable. Kent's Philadelphia chum, E. T. Stotesbury, built Wingwood House nearby at a cost of more than $1 million. Today Bar Harbor's palatial mansions and manicured gardens are reminders of this opulent era whose demise was hastened by a disastrous fire in 1947 that destroyed 40 estates, 280 homes and cottages and three summer hotels. Nowadays the town's economy largely depends on the annual summer influx of tourists. The former Stotesbury estate is now the Bar Harbor terminus of the ferry to Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, and last year work was begun to convert Sonogee into a nursing home.

title: CARTER ARRIVES AND ESTABLISHES CONVENTION BASE
description: Jimmy Carter, who burst from the obscurity of south Georgia into national political prominence only six months ago, arrived in New York City yesterday to claim the Demo cratic Presidential nomination.

title: Criminals At Large
description: On one level, MADONNA RED by James Carroll (Little, Brown, $7.95) is a suspense story about an Irish activist loose in Washington, out to get the British ambassador. Carroll, however, has much more than that in mind. Madonna Red is a very uptodate book about the problems of Catholicism in the modern world; about the role of women in the church; about the obligations of priesthood and the doctrine of unfaltering obedience to the bishop.

title: Engagements
description: KayeCrystal

title: Lister Is Ahead By Shot in Golf
description: MOLINE, Ill., July 10 (AP) John Lister of New Zealand shot a sixunderpar 65 to take the lead after three rounds today in the $100,000 Quad Cities open.

title: Tis Your Thoughts That Now Must Deck Our Kings
description: He marches onto the stage of the Delacorte Theater to the regal beat of four drummers, and he is wearing a long scarlet cloak, a gray ermine collar and a golden crown. Almost from the very beginning, he passionately exhorts his ragtag English army to victory over France ('A just cause, he firmly believes), always with his blue eyes skyward toward a God that he very much believes in, the veins bulging excitedly, nervously, on his cheeks and neck. He very much wants to win, and win he does. He not only conquers France, he gets the girl as welland she happens to be a French princess.

title: Woodall to Go; 2 Jets Traded
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 10 Another era began symbolically today for the New York Jets with the departure of Steve Tannen, Al Woodall and Carl Garrett. Meanwhile, David Knight and Phil Wise agreed to break with the team's tradition of undisciplined individualism by cutting their hair.

title: Joan Tobias Bride Of Philip Hollis 3d
description: Joan Elizabeth Tobias, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Tobias of Pound Ridge, N.Y. was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Daniel Hollis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Jr. of Bedford, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford Village by the Rev. Sennen San Fratello.

title: Marilyn Miller of Ad Agency Engaged to John Growold Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Miller of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Miller, to John Sloane Griswold Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Griswold of Greenwich and Old Lyme, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Soviet Astronauts Prefer Work to Taking Day Off
description: MOSCOW, July 10 (UPI)Ground control gave the hardworking Salyut space station crew a day off today, but the two Soviet astronauts said they preferred to work.

title: From an embattled land
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. The place arouses passions and inflames prejudices, but most of all it confounds notions of time and logic. Tom Mix is on the telly. The band at the Meikles Hotel plays ersatz Cole Porter, and men in dinner clothes and women in long dresses dance nightly as cruising on the Titanic. Black militants, urging allout war, say they cannot go on strike because they will lose their jobs. Jews are not admitted to the Salisbury Club. Polo is played every Sunday. And every day, people are killed. Tortured and maimed, too. The cycle of black rebellion and white repression mounts in cruel intensity. Black families turn away from their children for fear that they might be informers. White families are split over the everpresent question: how much power to share with the blacks, and how soon. Under the pressure, too many people drink too much.

title: 12 REPORTED DEAD IN DJIBOUTI CLASH
description: PARIS, July 10 (Reuters)At least 12 people were killed and 50 injured in tribal clashes early today in Djibouti. capital of the French Red Sea territory of the Mars and Issas, French sources there reported.

title: GARDENING
description: BY July our enthusiasm for garden work has waned, and most of us prefer to sit back and harvest the rewards from our earlier efforts. Nevertheless, weeds continue to grow along with garden plants, and there are tasks to be done if we are to continue that harvest into the fall.

title: Passman Is Said to Face Inquiry On Coercion of Aid Recipients
description: WASHINGTON. July 10Representative Otto E. Passman is under investigation by Agriculture Department agents for allegedly using his Congressional powers to coerce foreign aid recipients to hire a favored shipping agency, according to Government sources.

title: Two Hurt on Tramway As Electricity Fails
description: Two persons were injured yesterday when the aerial tramway between Manhattan and Roosevelt Island stopped, stranding about 170 passengers in the two gondolas for more than half an hour.

title: Jane Piritchard To Wed Aug. 7
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward M. Pritchard of Rumson, N.J., and Pocasset, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Allen Pritchard, to Roger Jackling, son of Sir Roger and Lady Jackling of London.

title: Miss Reilly Fiancee Of Richard Hefferin
description: Chief Judge Gerard D. Reilly of the United States Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia and Mrs. Reilly of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Anne Reilly, to Richard Thomas Hefferin of Washington, who is with the State Department's Office of International Trade Policy.

title: Senator Young May Quit
description: FARGO, N. D., July 10 (UPI) Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, told North Dakota Republican convention delegates yesterday that there was better than 5050 chance that he would resign before the end of his term in 1980. The 78yearold Republican said he was ready to retire two years ago but the challenge issued by those who said he could not win kept him in the race.

title: The Question of Death
description: The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment but it does not say what is cruel and what is unusual. Honorable men may well differ, as the Justices of the Supreme Court recently did, on the subjective question of whether the legal execution of murder ers is either cruel or unusual or both.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Hens Are Willing But People Aren't
description: The revolution in egg farming is just about over. The application of modern technology has dramatically reduced the number of egg farmers while raising the laying capacity of America's hearty hens.

title: POLITICS
description: DESPITE the fact that Governor Byrne helped to organize Jimmy Carter's campaign in New Jersey and that he was the first Governor of a major state to endorse his candidacy, Mr. Carter does not want Mr. Byrne to lead his Presidential campaign in the state. It is a snub that Mr. Byrne's political enemies are seizing upon in opposing his renomination for Governor next year.

title: Nepal Landslides Kill 90
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, July 10 (Reuters)Ninety people were killed in landslides caused by heavy rains in Nepal last week, according to delayed reports reaching the capital today.

title: The Israeli Raid Embarrassed Him
description: Idi Amin, the President of Uganda, is an anachronism armed with the power of life and death, and he uses it to satisfy personal whim and what he understands to be the demands of statecraft.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: VEENDAM (Holl. Amer.) Left Bermuda July 10; cue 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: How Best to Help Animals No One Wants?
A DiningOut Guide: Win, Place and Show
description: The Olympics may be the prime drawing card, but there is little doubt that the hundreds of thousands of Olympic visitors to Montreal this month have a secondary motive in mindthe sampling of the muchtouted cuisine of Canada's gastronomic capital.

title: Rebels in Chad Surrender, Hand Over Their Weapons
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, July 10 (Agence FrancePresse)Some 78 members of the rebel Chad Liberation Front have surrendered to the Government, it was announced here.

title: AllStar Controversy and Conversation
description: The argument for the AllStar Game is argument itself. Nothing else in baseball guarantees such controversy and conversation. No matter which starting players the fans elect, debate develops over some. No matter which pitchers and other players the rival managers select; debate develops over some. That's healthy. At the Olympics, for example. there is more talk of politicians than athletes. But the most unusual AllStar argument this year involves Mark Fidrych, the Detroit Tigers rookie, who may be the American League's starting pitcher, and Thurman Munson, the New York Yankees catcher, who was knighted by the fans for the opening lineup. Nearly two weeks ago Thurman Munson grumbled at Mark Fidrych's antics after The Bird had stopped the Yankees, 71, while talking to the baseball and smoothing the mound as if he were a gardener.

title: Atlanta Rabbi Chosen
description: ATLANTA, July 10 (AP)Rabbi Emanuel Feldman of Atlanta will deliver the benedic tion Monday at the close of the first session of the Democratic National Convention, a spokesman said today. Rabbi Feldman who has led Atama's Congregation Beth Jacob for 22 years, has made a number of speeches in behalf of Jimmy Carter.

title: Bonuses Instead of Strikes
description: AN unusual 10year labor agreement between two New Jersey unions and a Garfield paper mill guarantees the workers annual bonuses based on productivity and protects the employer from slowdowns or a strike.

title: New Antivice Law Takes Effect Today
description: A new law designed to facilitate arrests of pimps, prosti?? and their patrons takes effect today, and civil liberties, ?? and women's groups are planning a series of measures aimed at blunting its effectivepess.

title: VOTERS TO FACE NUCLEAR ISSUES
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 Proposals to restrict the development of atomic power, the hotly controversial question recently rejected by voters in California, may be on the ballot in as many as six other states in the November election.

title: Miss Marlette, Accountant, Fiancee
description: Catherine Bowler Marlette of New York and Frederick Heinz Waddell of Chicago, who graduated with the class of 75 from Dartmouth College, plan to be married Sept. 4.

title: Viking Scientists Studying Photos of a Mars Plateau
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 10 (UPI)Viking scientists torlay were studying radar readings and photographs of a high plateau on Mars, which they said was partly blanketed with haze and had very dynamic weather patterns.

title: The Very Rich Hours Of Adrienne Monnier
description: OdoniaAdrienne Monnier's fanciful name for the street in Paris where her famous bookshop was located  is a vanished world, surviving only in memoirs. And yet that world Was, for over 30 years, the center of intellectual and literary Paris. More than Henry Miller's Montparnasse or the fabled cafes of Hemingway's fiction, it was the rue de l'Odeon that sheltered the French and American writers starting out in the twenties. In Adrienne Monnier's

title: Property Tax Reform Spreading in State
description: An increasing number of towns and cities in New York State are moving to reform the administration of their property tax. In most communities, it is still so unfairly levied as to be almost impossible to conceive, says Michael O'Shea, deputy director of the State Board of Equalization.

title: SHOP TALK
description: CENTRAL Avenue is the Main Street of the Five Towns. Every kind of shop can be found here. And there are more shoe shops per square foot than in any other area.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and Signaled for a Landing at Third Base
description: On a bright, sunny, spring day, the doctor and I went to the baseball game. We fancied ourselves as complete spectators, and once we had taken our seats we fulfilled the roles admirably.

title: Sudan Withdraws Request For Arab Talks on Libya
description: CAIRO, July 10 (AP)Sudan withdrew a request today for an emergency meeting of Arab foreign ministers to consider its allegation that Libya had organized a unsuccessful coup attempt in Sudan on July 2, the Middle East News Agency said.

title: STAMPS
description: The United States, just one day ahead of the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal on July 17, is saluting the event with a block of four 13cent stamps for the XXI Olympiad.

title: CHANA COMBATING PRICES, HOARDING
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 9Confronted with a dire shortage of goods and soaring food prices, the military Government has been taking on a formidable opponentthe Ghanaian market woman.

title: Firemen Holding the Line Against California Blaze
description: BIG BEAR CITY, Calif., July 10 (UPI)Firemen were closing the line around a 4,500acre brush and timber fire today in the San Bernardino National Forest that had destroyed nine structures and caused four injuries. A United States Forest Service spokesman said the blaze, which started Thursday, was whipped up during the night by crratic winds of 30 to 35 miles an hour.

title: Candelaria Stops Reds, 71
description: CINCINNATI, July 10 (AP) John Candelaria fired a sixhitter as the Pirates halted Cincinnati's winning streak at seven games with a 71 victory today.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Today business and government are more vulnerable to intentionally caused losses through use of computerscomputer abuse than they ever were before or ever will be in the future. Computer programmers with little or no tradition of professional trust acceptance can perform a wide range of unauthorized acts resulting in personal gain with little chance of detection. Programmers and others in sensitive electronic data processing (E.D.P.) jobs are potentially the most dangerous people in the world.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: LONG ISLAND Democrats were largely unimpressed with the package of procedural reforms put together hastily by House Democratic leaders recently to try to remove the stain of the HaysRay payroll sex scandal before Election Day.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE 0.4 percent in June and the wholesale price index hit 183.1 percent of the 1967 base period, the Labor Department reported. Higher prices for industrial goods led the advance. April's climb was 0.8 percent The Federal budget deficit estimate was lowered to about $68 billion by the Office of Management and Budget, down from $76.9 billion estimated in March The nation's broadly based money supply (currency in circulation plus savings and checking account deposits) increased by $1.4 billion in the latest week. The narrower money supply (currency plus checking accounts) dropped by $300 million.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  A House committee urged Federal agencies today to tighten safety controls over lowlevel radioactive waste disposal sites.

title: FISHING
description: FISHERMEN are waiting for he next shot of warm ocean water to draw the bluefish into range, and that should be soon after tonight's full moon or we'll be in trou ble, said one partyboat captain.

title: TV VIEW
description: The flag goes up and down, with a rattle and snap, like a window shade on the TV screen. Behind the eyes, between the ears, is a highway. No grass grows. No grass grows because it has been trampled out by 10,000 drum majorettes: amber waves of thighs. No bird sings. No bird would dare to compete with the gurgling of Mike Douglas and Lorne Green, Ed McMahon and Paul Anka, Kate Smith and Anita Bryant. Inside Kate Smith, an Anita Bryant is trying to get out. Why is Anita Bryant singing

title: For young readers
description: Good man, this Gumpy! He proved it in Mr. Gumpy's Outing in which he went punting on the river (and earned his creator, John Burningham, a second prestigious Kate Greenaway Medal in England for the illustrations). Here now Gumpy takes the same children and farm animals for a ride in his righthand drive touring car. For a while they drove along happily. The sun shone, the engine chugged, and everyone was enjoying the ride. But then comes the rainand the mud.

title: Like the Weather: Continual Talk, but What to Do?
description: WASHINGTONPerhaps no social problem has generated more talk and less action in recent years than welfare reform.

title: Mayor in Canada Jailed
description: OTTAWA. July 10 (AP)The Mayor of Hull has been sentenced to three days in jail for refusing to pay a speeding fine because the summons was issued in English. Gilles Rocheleau was sentenced Thursday. He had been clocked at 20 miles above the speed limit on the Ontario side of a bridge) linking Ottawa and Hull. The Mayor speaks French and English but says he objects to (being served a unilingual sumImons only in English in CanIada's national capital.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: COLORADO GIVES REAGAN26,FORD4
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., July 10  President Ford won four convention votes in Colorado this weekend, one more than he had been counting on in his neckandneck race with Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Yoko Morishita Japan's Pioneer Prima Ballerina
description: When I'm on stage, I'm thinking all the time. This is my strength, says Yoko Morishita, the 27yearold Japanese ballerina who received enthusiastic reviews for her New York debut last month as Princess Aurora in American Ballet Theater's new production of The Sleeping Beauty.

title: EDWARD A. KRACKE JR.
description: Edward A. Kracke Jr., a former professor emeritus of Chinese literature and institutions at the University of Chicago, died Thursday in Boston, He was 68 years old. He wrote a major work, Civil Service in the Early Sung Dynasty, and monographs for the Encyclopedia Britannica. He is survived by his wife, the former Joan Hocking, and a daughter, Barbara.

title: Battles Not Limited to Field For AllStar Game Tuesday
description: Baseball's 47th AllStar Game will be staged Tuesday right in Philadelphia but, behind the pomp and ceremony, the final battle linesand pogsibly a peace fprmulawill be drawn in the historymaking warfare between the 600 players and 24 club owners.

title: BOGUS BILLS SUSPECT IS HELD IN MURDER
description: A 29yearold Bronx man awaiting trial on counterfeiting charges was arrested yesterday on charges of murdering an alleged associate in a counterfeiting ring that had floded Westchester County towns with nearly $1 million in bogus money last Christmastime, the police reported.

title: Alice La Sala Wed To Roger S. Elliott
description: Alice Rowena La Sala, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Francis La Sala of Larchmont, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to Roger Stuart Elliott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Elliott, also of Larchmont.

title: The World
description: A new Government has assumed power in Spain, at a time of growing dissatisfaction among organized labor and liberal political reformers with the slowness of change from dictatorship to democracy. The new Government is led by Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez, a conservative with strong ties to the Franco period. Whether his Government can reform the system in time to prevent serious eruptions will probably depend on how it handles several labor disputes in the coming months.

title: Joan Barron Married
description: Joan Sylvester Barron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Barron Jr. of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday at her parents' home to James Robert Danson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Danson of Truro, Nova Scotia. The Rev. Edmund J. Hussey, pastor of Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, performed the ceremony. Mr. Barron is director of investor relations with the Olin Corporation.

title: The Flag Follows the Dollar, Even in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTONNine years ago, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, then the minority leader, rose on the floor of the House of Representatives to defend a new concept of Federal aid called block grants that he and a group of Republican colleagues had devised.

title: It's Not Over Yet
description: THE Declaration of Independence having been commemorated, some of the Island's historians, historical societies and Bicentennial Commissions are going to try to keep the momentum going. The Revolution, after all, took seven years to fight and some will not rest contented until the 200th anniversary of Evacuation Day, Nov. 25, 1983.

title: Drama in Hijacking of Jet to Uganda: A Long Week of Terror and Tensions
description: The seatbelt sign was still lighted eight minutes later when a woman's scream pierced the air. In the firstclass section, a man and a woman sprang to their feet, each brandishing a pistol in one hand, a grenade in the other. While the woman trained her gun on the startled cabin attendants, the man stepped toward the pilot's cabin. Behind the insulated door, Capt. Michel Bacos heard the scream and the commotion in first class.

title: Israeli Is Miss Universe
description: HONG KONG, Sunday July 11 (Reuters)Miss Israel, 20yearold Rina Messinger, was named Miss Universe 1976 here today.

title: Black reunion thirty years after
description: John A. Williams is a black writer, the way the crocus is a spring flower. The Junior Bachelor Society, his latest novel, is the story of nine middleaged black men and what their lives have become in the more than three decades gone by since they played ball together, and grew up together, in Central City, in upstate New York. Some of them, except for absences occasioned by the army or college, never left the town: Richard (Bubbles) Wiggins and Cudjo Evers wind up sweating their lives away in the Obanoga foundry, Shurley Walker manages (and secretly owns) a restaurantbar. Kenneth (Snake) Dumpson escaped the foundry long ago and has risen to be the housing commissioner for the city.

title: Pro Transactions
description: ATLANTA (NFC)  Released Ken Burrow, wide receiver, and Tony Greene, defensive back, for falling physlcals.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE 400 EELS OF SIGMUND FREUD, by A. G. Mojtabai. (Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Precocious teenagers work on esoteric scientific projects under frustrated adults tutelage; intelligent, moving.

title: O Kaplan! My Kaplan!
description: Beck in 1937 people was leffing and scrimming and falling off chers ridding a book. The book was called The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N. The writer was called Leonard Q. Ross, which was cinnamon for Leo Rosten.

title: White Sox Win First From Yanks, 4 to 1
description: After losing their first eight games with the Yankees this season, the Chicago White Sox got a tiny measure of revenge at Yankee Stadium last night with a 41 victory.

title: Saving a Part of the Jersey Midlands
description: FOR too long, the Delaware and Raritan Canal has been relegated to a back seat while historians, buffs and preservationists focused on its northern sister, the Morris Canal. This other New Jersey canal deserves better.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Basll Asclutto

title: Democrats Convene at MacLaine Show
description: Some of Shirley MacLaine's friends went to see her show at the Palace Theater last night and they could have nominated Jimmy Carter right there.

title: Industrial Valves in Infinite Variety
description: We really don't care what route the United States takes to energy independence; we'll be part of it, says Gary E. MacDougal, chairman of the Mark Controls Corporation, ?? major valve producer. Valves will be as essential to nuclear and solar power in the future as they are to petroleum in the present.

title: Novels and stories, kitsch and quality
description: Though Jacqueline Susann died of cancer in September, 1974, there, nonetheless, will be publicity after death. Could one expect less with the publication of her posthumous novel, Dolores?

title: News of the Realty Trade.
description: Felix Lilienthal & Company and Associated Dry Goods Corporation have signed new leases at 417 Fifth Avenue which is now fully rented.

title: Mrs. Nixon's Condition Is Stable
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 10 (Reuters) Doctors treating Pat Nixon said today that she remained in serious condition but was stable and doing as well as can be expected after her stroke last Wednesday.

title: All They Want Is Music, Music
description: NEW MILFORD MERYL TORIN does the ironing to the sound of a nickelodeon and sweeps floors in time with the ragtime rhythms of a pianolin. And once or twice a week, Mrs. Torin and her husband, Paul, don white slacks, dark shirts, redandwhitestriped vests and jaunty straw skimmers and take their giant Wurlitzer band organ to street festivals and fairs.

title: U.S. Strong In Track, Swimming
description: It's that time again, and almost everyone is asking how we will do in the Olympics.

title: U.S. Women's Hopes Are Cast in Bronze
description: Competing in 11 Olympic sportsin two of them alongside their male teammatesAmerican women will seek gold medals in Montreal next week. But, at best, most will find only bronze.

title: Nastase Defeats Connors
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., July 10 (AP)Ilie Nastase dropped the first set at love, but battled back for an 06, 69, 75 victory over Jimmy Connors in the $150,000, fourman Pepsi Grand Slam of Tennis today. He plays Manuel Orantes of Spain in the final tomorrow for $75,000.

title: 2Party Totes for Convention Time
description: If you want to carry your belongings in a smartly conventional manner, the thing to have these days is a donkeyshaped tote bag. Or an elephantshaped one. It all depends on the party of your choice.

title: Albany to Request U.S. Funds for Review of M.T.A.
description: The State Transportation Commissioner, Raymond T. Schuler, has announced, that the state will apply for a $1.2 million Federal grant to continue a management study of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: LETTER
description: Villella Demurs

title: Book Ends
description: Wyeth book. On Sept. 27 Houghton Mifflin will publish Wyeth at Kuerners, a collection of sketches and paintings by Andrew Wyeth, assembled by his wife, Betsy. Mr. Wyeth is probably the most popular American fine artist, so the new book is arousing considerable sales expectations in the tradeas well as some controversy over the publisher's policy of revoking the customary return privilege of booksellers who order the book.

title: Eager Host Poised for A Festival
Taxes The Long Agony
description: TRENTON MANY members of the New Jersey Legislature are in a nowin position after the dreary sixmonth fight over new taxes. Many of the Assemblymen and Senators who voted for a tax bill that would impose a 2 percent tax on personal income up to $20,000 and a 2.5 percent levy on income above that figure will face great difficulty in being reelected. Most of them voted yes so that the state's public schools could he reopened. But for those who de. fled the will of their constituents, there can be no victory of conscience, only the agony of political defeat.

title: Let the Best Machine Win? Precisely, No
description: In this age of computer technology, the average person takes much for granted. Computers control everything from rockets in orbit to phone bills. The sports enthusiast should be made aware of the computer invasion of sports and its effect on the snirit of comnetition.

title: A Rose Is a Rose is a Cabbage
description: PARISFor the world at large July 1976 is more important as signalizing a quadrennial event than a Bicentennial birthday. The United States is diving into its political pool and will come up in less than four months with a new Administration, most likely (according to present odds) Democratic and headed by a man named Jimmy Carter.

title: Rivals in Congress
description: WASHINGTON THE two most powerful members of New Jersey's 15member Congressional delegation have had a longstanding personal rift that has dismayed some of their colleagues and possibly cost the delegation some of its clout.

title: The thought of an Italian heretic
description: Nicola Chiarocnante was an Italian antiFascist from a devoutly Catholic family who fought in Malraux's air squadron against Franco, was an exile in France and the United States, wrote for Partisan Review and other American magazines, and died in Rome in 1972 after taping a radio discussion of J.F. Revel's proAmerican tract, Without Marx or Jesus.

title: Sunday Observer
description: If Lyndon Johnson had said, To hell with it, when his advisers urged him to make war in Vietnam in 1965, he would not have had to resign in 1968 and, with a united party behind him, he would have been reelected through 1972.

title: Don't call me an informant'
description: When you're drinking with black drug dealers, you order something sweet, like a Black Russian or a Harvey Wallbanger, says Irwin Nadborn, gesturing for the waitress. When you're drinking with wise guys [Mafiosi] you order Cutty on the rocks. Irwin pays for the drinks with the $50 bill he peels from a roll that clearly holds upwards of $800. He lights one more Tareyton and leans back in his chair, sipping his Black Russian and looking very much like a young Zero

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: France didn't do it. The United States didn't do it. The United Nations didn't do it. Microscopic Israel did it.

title: Dance: Butler's Medea
description: A year ago, the American choreographer John Butler crated a pas deux called Medea for Mikhail Baryshnikov and Carla Fracci. When the duet received its American premiere with the same dancers as part of American Ballet Theater's season here last January, it was obvious that this slight Ballet was essentially a vehicle for Miss Fracci and Mr. Baryshnikov.

title: INVESTING
description: WASHINGTON its effort to block the invasion by banks into its traditional territory, the securities business can count on support from some quarters seldom considered friendly.

title: It's Time to Sow Biennials
description: NOT even the most ardent of New Jersey gardeners was likely to sow seeds of biennial flowers over the Bicentennial Fourth of July weekend, but how about now? It's time.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Any Fourth of July weekend leads to an increase in snapshots by camera owners, the film and camera manufacturers say. But what of the Fourth marked by Operation Sail in New York, an historic event?

title: Ann Taliaferro to Marry Aug. 28
description: Ann Hollis Taliaferro, who teaches art history at the Lenox School, and Charles W. Bailey Jr., an owner and vicepresident of A.A.A. Couriers International Inc., an express package service, plan to be married on Aug. 28.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: SinatraMarx Wedding Reportedly Set Today
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 10 (AP)Frank Sinatra plans to marry Barbara Marx tomorrow afternoon at the estate of the former United States Ambassador to Britain, Walter H. Annenberg, sources said today.

title: Olympic Village Food: Good, Plenty and Free
description: The food in Montreal restaurants ranks with the best in the world. The food in Olympic Village won't be bad, either.

title: Cosmos Win by 21; Pele, Garbett Score
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP)Pele scored one goal and set up the winning goal as the New York Cosmos defeated the Philadelphia Atoms, 21, tonight in a North American Soccer League match.

title: Hinshaw Expulsion From House Urged; Conviction Is Cited
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Declaring that Representative Andrew J. Hinshaw's bribery conviction reveals a cynical bargain by a public official, a fellow California Republican Representative Charles E. Wiggins, is seeking Mr. Hinshaw's expulsion from the House.

title: Political conventions retain their hoopla, but have lost their function.
description: We can testify, hospitably, from New York this weekend that there really is a Democratic Party. It is a quadrennial party, celebrated every leap year by 30,000 tourists, some 3,000 of whom are delegated to act as unpaid extras in a fourday television spectacle, called Convention, at the climax of which the celebrants choose a previously selected politician as the candidate for President, thus conferring upon him the family name of Democrat and one of the two meaningful places on the November ballot.

title: Why Victories Afield Receive High Priority
description: MOSCOW, July 10  In the Soviet Union, international sports cannot be untangled from international politics, for athletics here are important threads in the tightly woven fabric of power and patriotism that clothes the Soviet drive for preeminence.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Rep. Aspin Questions Toll In Marine Corps Training
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)Thirteen Marine recruits have died in the last five years from injdries, heart attacks and other accidents as result of training, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin says.

title: Samuel Adams, 96, Dies; A Partner in Pressprich
description: Samuel G. Adams, a partner in the investment banking firm of R. W. Pressprich & Company until his retirement three years ago, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 96 years old and lived at 14 East 90th Street.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayHunting Hollow, D.E. McIntyre Farm, Half Hollow Road, Dix Hills, L.I. Regular, Green, AmateurOwner, Junior, Maiden and Children's Working Hunters; special jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Summer Adventure: Books
description: No More pencils, no more books/No more teachers dirty looks is a familiar refrain in June, when kids dash from schools like bats out of a cave. They, of course, look to the summer vacation as freedom from the tyranny of learning, but I, a teacher, like to think of it as renewalrenewal of the spirit as well as renewal of the mind. This is what I try to foster.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Collecting with a camera, or photo collecting, is a hobby that consists of using one's camera and photographic skills to do exactly what the term impliesthat is, take pictures of items, subjects, places, or things that fall into one particular category of interest.

title: ART VIEW
description: Gustave Courbet, the first painter to make of Realism an ideology as well as a style, called his great painting of a gathering in his own studio, executed in 1855, a true allegory. Its full title was: The Painter's Atelier, a True Allegory Summarizing a Period of Seven Years in My Life as an Artist. The painting now hangs in the Louvre.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE only problem with the Fromagerie is that it can't possibly be as good as its adherents claim. And it isn't. It is very good, but not that good. For what ?? worth, though, it is probably the best restaurant in this ?? of the state.

title: Number of Deaths Increases Sharply in Lebanon as the Christians Press Their Offensives
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 (AP)  Rightwing Christians carrying new United States arms and riding in Soviet ve hicles, made assaults today on leftist positions from Beirut to Tripoli. Hospital officials said more than 200 people had been killed.

title: Out of Olympics, Into the Profit Motive
description: A gold medal performance at the Olympics can mean a giltedged business career.

title: When 43 Opera Companies Get Together
description: The nation's opera companies are doing something these days which they haves never done before, and the consequences are being felt by many of the 4.8million people who attend professional productions around the country every year. The opera companies are talking to one another, and they have established an organization called Opera America in order to do so.

title: TAIWAN IS UNEASY OVER TIE WITH U.S.
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanNestled in an inconspicuous compound on the northern edge of Taipei sits the Taiwan Defense Command, the skeletal organization of 80 American military men that embodies the continued United States mutual security treaty with the Chinese Nationalists.

title: Smaller Drop Is Reported In Catholic Pupil Number
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Although Roman Catholic elementary and secondary school enrollment has dropped by 2.1 million pupils in the last 10 years, the decrease is declining each year, the United States Catholic Conference says.

title: Letters
description: Having a feminist consciousness does not mean we must like all women; some women are distinctly not likable. Having a feminist consciousness does not mean we must admire all work done by women; some work done by women is not admirable. Having a feminist consciousness means that we can admire a beautiful painting, whether done by a woman or a man; that we recognize that it is indeed a victory for every woman when one of us coins the Nobel Prize.

title: Hunter Title Is Captured By Dillon
State Report Hits Racing Unit Again
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board came under renewed fire yesterday for allegedly failing to supervise New York's multimilliondollar racing industry properly.

title: Paul Neuberger, a Lawyer, Dies During European Trip
description: Paul Neuberger, a New York lawyer who specialized in handling claims by United States citizens against foreign governments, died Wednesday in Badgastein, Austria. He was 81 years old and lived at 24 West 55th Street.

title: Tibetan Schools Stressing Politics and Manual Labor
description: LHASA, TibetOn a shaded balcony in a village outside Lhasa rows of children, 5 or 6 in age but many looking younger, sit crosslegged on the floor, writing on wooden slates. They copy repeatedly the words their teacher has written on the blackboard in the Tibetan script, some commonplace, others reflecting the new social institutions in which these children live commune, work point, surplus grain, (that is, tax), cattle manure.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Sharks Command Attention
description: MONTAUK, L.I.For years a small group of men, including Montauk's Frank Mundus, went sport fishing for sharks, but until recently the average angler paid no attention to the snecies.

title: Ten Golden Oldies For Entertainment 3
description: As any observant moviegoer knows, nothing succeeds in Hollywood like boxoffice success. So naturally we can look forward to a sequel to That's Entertainment, Part 2, Metro  Goldwyn  Mayer's popular compilation of scenes from some of its choice golden oldies; primarily its musicals. So, before everybody jumps on the bandwagon, let me be the first to nominate my own favorite gems for That's Entertainment, Part 3.

title: Scientist Says C B Radios Face Sunspot Interference in 1978
description: BOULDER, Colo., July 10 (UPI)A Government scientist says that citizens band radios will be nearly useless for several years beginning about 1978 because of increasing sunspot activity.

title: A Pragmatist
description: PLAINS, Ga.When a huge majority of the 3,016 Democratic convention delegates vote Wednesday night to nominate Jimmy Carter for President, some will do so with reservations. Liberals, especially, may still be troubled by the man they must now rally around.

title: To America With Love
description: I don't mean to make light of Anita and Abbie Hoffman's situation, Whether Abbie's cocaine bust was politicallyinspired entrapment or merely a normal exercise of our idiotic drug laws, surviving as a fugitive is no lark; neither is Anita's impecunious single motherhood (whatever the excuse war, art or state persecutionit's always the man who splits and the woman who gets left with the kid). But my chief reaction to the Hoffmans' underground correspondence is that however interesting they may be as individuals, they make an awfully boring pair.

title: Eggs and Cholesterol: The Debate Continues
description: Cholesterol was first linked to heart problems in 1913 when a Russian scientist, Nikolai Anitschkov, fed synthetic cholesterol to laboratory rabbits and they developed arterial lesions. But it wasn't until 1961, when the American Heart Association, supported by what then was considered the best scientific evidence, first advised Americans to limit cholesterol intake.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayEastern Metropolitan Racing Association and American Formula Ford Association races at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit, 1 P.M.; open for spectators.

title: As Their Plants Grow, So Does Their World
description: Gertrude Aarons was repotting a begonia; Sherman Woodward was supervising the planting of a cactus dish garden; and Ann Hastings was proudly showing off her collection of African violets.

title: Delegate for Brown Is Eager but Nervous
description: MARIN CITY, Calif., July 10 (UPI)  Betty Times doesn't know anything about bigtime politics but that has not dampened her enthusiasm about attending the Democratic National Convention as one of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s 204 delegates.

title: Two Musicals That Celebrate New York
When Westbury Was Young
description: AN evocation of times remembered in Westbury  before the railroad, the automobile and the Expressway is now on display in a photographic exhibition at Old Westbury Gardens.

title: JACKSON'S KILLING DEBATED AT TRIAL
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 10 Two defense attorneys in the San Quentin Six murder trial asserted in Marin County Superior Court here this week that the state of California had perpetrated a successful conspiracy to murder George Jackson, the black revolutionary author and prison leader, on Aug. 21, 1971, at San Quentin prison.

title: NATHANIEL BURNELL, RETIRED GENERAL, 78
description: Maj. Gen. Nathaniel A. Burnell 2d, who was responsible for the air defense of New England, New Jersey, New York and Thule Air Base, in Greenland, and who commanded Fort Totten, in Queens at the same time, from 1954 to 1957, died on June 27 in Annapolis, Md., of apparent cardiac arrest. He was 78 years old and lived in Edgewater, Md.

title: Victoria Tilney, Bank Trainee, Is Betrothed to Chips C. Page
description: The engagement of Victoria Merritt Tilney to Chips Chapman Page has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Norcross Sheldon Tilney of Lawrence, LI., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie M. Page of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Denominations Balk at Reappointment of Church Council's Head
description: The reappointment of the Rev. Dan M. Potter as executive director of the New York City Council of Churches last May has refueled a controversy that may lead at least one major denomination to leave the ecumenical agency.

title: SOVIET SEAMAN ASKS FOR ASYLUM IN U.S.
description: A 37yearold seaman off a (Soviet cruise ship berthed at a midtown Hudson River pier asked for asylum in the United States yesterday afternoon and was turned over to the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, the police reported.

title: The Region
description: An income tax, sought by New Jersey governors for a decade, has finally been approved by the State Legislature after months of resistance and only under judicial pressure. The measure offers some reform of the state's generally regressive and chaotic tax structure, now based primarily on sales and property taxes, but not much.

title: Teamster Fund Kept No Files on Pensioners
description: CHICAGO, July. 9Until earlier this year, the Teamsters' Union's biggest pensfon fund kept no file on the names and addresses of its 385,000 members, even though the fund was collecting nearly $1 million a day from employers on their behalf.

title: Dr. King's Niece Dies While Jogging at School
description: ATLANTA, July 10 (AP)Esther Darlene King, 20yearold niece of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., collapsed and died yesterday while jogging at a high school track.

title: Issues in Hospital Strike
description: PARTIESDistrict 1199, National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees representing 30,000 workers, most of whom are nonprofessionals. Thirtythree hospitals, 27 belonging to the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York.

title: Jail for Sue Lyon's Husband
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 10 (UPI)Gary Adamson, the convict husband of Sue Lyon, actress, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison for a March 9 bank robbery committed after his escape from a Colorado State Hospital. He fled the hospital while under treatment for narcotics addiction he alleged he acquired at Colorado ?? Prison.

title: Major League Averages
description: Major League Averages

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9 No Title

title: A Way Is Found to Protect an Odd Little Fish
description: All creatures great and small can be endowed with certain unalienable rights. By a unanimous ruling of the Supreme Court, the 200odd Devil's Hole Pupfish, inchlong creatures that live only in one cavern in Nevada, have the right to a water level high enough to maintain their habitat.

title: Women Stress Feminist Issues In Rally Opposite the Garden
description: About 400 women affiliated with the National Organization for Women held yesterday the first of a series of demonstrations that will be aimed by various groups at the Democratic National Convention. The rally turned out to be peaceful and orderly.

title: Norton, in Tuneup, 10thRound Victor
description: SAN DIEGO, July 10Ken Norton stopped Larry Middleton with less than a minute to go in the 10round fight today as his tuneup for a Sept. 28 date with Muhammad All in Yankee Stadium turned out to be tougher than anticipated.

title: A Book Show to Relish
description: OVER 1,000 cookbooks fill the shelves of a room in Lucille and Walter Fillin's Rockville Centre home. About 150 of themrarities, oddities, standard reference works and lavish tomesare being displayed this summer in CookbooksA Special Collection at the Hofstra University Library. The books on view span more than two centuries, dating from 1774 (a receipt book by Hannah Glasse of Edinburgh) to 1976. The receipts in them cover a considerably larger segment of history, beginning with Apicius ancient Roman delicacies and including most of the world's cuisines.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE ICEBERG HERMIT, by Arthur Roth. (Scholastic/StarLine, 95 cents.) Seventeenyearold Allan Gordon is marooned in the Arctic for seven years, and survives; the ultimate Robinson Crusoe yarn, a historical episode of 1757 skillfully embroidered for readers aged 12 to 15.

title: No Amer Soccer League
description: No Amer Soccer League

title: Senecas and State of New York Strike Historic Pact as Equals
description: ALBANY, July 10The Seneca Nation of Indians has concluded a historic agreement with the State of New York that permits the construction of a new road through its reservation at Salamanca in the western part of the state.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results

title: Champion Bulldog Loved by Fanciers
description: Ch. Hetherbull Arrogant Lazarus probably never will qualify to compete in the United States Obedience Classic, but that makes little difference to devotees of the educated set. For the doughty bulldog owned by Robert A. HetherIngton Jr., president of the First Jersey Savings in Wyckoff, has engendered more cheers than far more polished performers of obedience exercises.

title: Navy Checks Bomb Deaths
description: MANILA, July 10 (AP)The United States Navy today named a panel to investigate the alleged bombing of four Philippine fishermen who were killed last month near the Subic Bay naval base. Philippines authorities said the four fishermen died June 18 of multiple shrapnel wounds. The United States said its planes made a practice bombing run in the area the same day.

title: Watching work, revising Kaplan, publishing in Paris, writing letters
description: In the summer of 1973, Richard Balzer, a suburbiaraised Yale Law School graduate, got permission from Western Electric to work as a bench hand at its Merrimack Valley factory in North Andover, Mass. Balzer, who had a grant, worked in the plant as a participantobserver for five monthsthe average length of service is 12 years. His long hair and semihippie style of dress, and the fact that he was allowed to take photographs. which is normally against company policy, made him stand out like a sore thumb. That he manages to say some useful things in his book is a tribute to Balzer's honesty and openness. And that his testimony lacks a certain bite is mainly due to a selfimposed neutrality, an unwillingness to confront the more uncomfortable implications of the muffled antagonism between worker and boss at Western Electric. Most shop floor problems, Balzer implies, could be solved by better human communications.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The vasty fields of France have had a thorough compressing in New York these past three months. First at the Brooklyn Academy Music, where the Royal Shakespeare Company put on their magnificent version of Henry V. Now in Central Park, where the New York Shakespeare Festival is doing the same play.

title: Bound Holdup Victim Is Raped By Man Who Found Her in Park
description: An 18yearold woman was raped in Central Park early yesterday morning a short while after she and a male companion, who had been strolling in the park after spending an evening with friends, were held up by four youths, robbed, stripped and tied up, the police said.

title: Mosca's marinated crab
description: 1 package crab boil, or one 1ounce box shrimp spice plus 5 or 6 dried hot red peppers

title: SelfHelp Housing: Within Limits, It Works
description: Amateurs cannot build housing, the experts insisted; the beams would collapse, the boilers would explode.

title: Equileo Captures International Trot
description: WESTBURY, L.I. July 10  It was show time for three Frenchmen early today, several hours before the $200,000 Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Opening Night on Broadway
description: Governor Carter is now in the process of changing roles and theatres. He has been touring the states as the triumphant David of his party, but now he's opening on Broadway in the role of Goliath, with a worldwide television audience looking on.

title: A Hot Line on Jersey Tax
description: TRENTON, July 10 (AP)New Jersey will start a hotline service on Monday for residents seeking information on the new income tax, starting at 2 P.M. the first day. From then on, the line will be open from 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M., Monday through Friday. The number is 6093941900.

title: State Is Investigating Putnam Project
description: CARMEL, N.Y., July 9The remains of Putnam County's illfated recycling project were laid out before the State Commission of Investigation this week, revealing a pattern of appartment bribery, political contributions and kickbacks.

title: The 103rd Ballot
description: It's no wonder the Democrats waited 52 years between national conventions in New York. The last time they came to Madison Square Garden it took seven tons of chemicals to get the smell of circus animals out of the place and 103 bitter ballots to choose their nominee for President

title: The Democrats Convene
description: As thousands of Democrats from across the country gather for the opening of their convention tomorrow, the quadrennial process of choosing the nation's future political leadership reaches its culmination.

title: Anniversaries
description: Matrgoles

title: FILM VIEW
description: It was midmorning the day after the Fourth of July and I was walking down Broadway when I stopped to admire one of those genuine oil paintings that often decorate the entrance the former Astor Theater. This particular painting was a sunsetvirtually lifesizedof unusual splendor, not something that one would want to live with, perhaps, but the sort of sunset that people might have seen for months after Krakatowa blew up, it Krakatowa had been full of Orange Julius. My musings were interrupted by a gentle tap on the arm and I turned to greet Stanley Jr., the disreputhble, occasionally disowned, longhaired filmbuff son of my friend Stanley, the successful movie producer. He was with a companion.

title: Newest Hawkers on Midtown Streets Push Carter Invitations and Buttons
description: Sherell Koseluk came to Manhattan yesterday from Whippany, N. J., for the matinee of a musical, then found herself the recipient of an invitation to meet Jimmy Carter.

title: The Games the Networks Play At Convention Time
description: Tomorrow night, before less than half a nation of viewers, politics and television news will again begin their quadrennial intertwining when the Democrats take over Madison Square Garden and virtually all of prime time. Out of the events of this week and the next four months will come a Democratic ticket, a Republican ticket, ultimately a President and Vice President and. simultaneously, new journalistic heroes for the television multitudes, a network able to pall itself most trusted on the strength of the ratings for its political telecasts and possibly a future network anchorperson or pundit.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: The Bonus Babies of Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIROAt a recent dinner party, two businessmen, one from a chemical company and the other from an engineering consulting company, swapped stories about the high salaries that young executives command in Brazil nowadays.

title: Rizzo Ouster Study Results
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (UPI)A lawyer for a group seeking to oust Mayor Frank L. Rizzo said today that a statistical study showed that ouster petitions contained enough valid signatures to force a recall referendum. Under the City Charter, 145,448 signatures are needed.

title: Lovejoy Reeves to Be Bride Aug.
description: Elizabeth Lovejoy Reeves, manager of the recruiting department of Avon Products Inc., and William Mairs Duryea Jr. of Upper Brookville, L. I., plan to be married Aug. 7.

title: A New Mayor Beame Has Risen From the Ashes of the New York City Fiscal Crisis
description: Nibbling on kosher pound cake as the honored guest in the captain's cabin of an Israeli gunboat docked at Manhattan's West Side is a priceless bit of ethnic politicking by New York City standards.

title: Deena B. Rosen To Wed Aug. 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Rosen of Forest Hills, Queens, and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deena Beth Rosen, to Peter Millard Hoagland, son of Mrs. Joseph C. Hoagland Jr. of Washington and the late Mr. Hoagland.

title: Ford Campaign Organization Hit By Factional Strife
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Just as political events have begun to favor President Ford's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, his campaign organization has succumbed to factional strife.

title: An Athens Magistrate Is Told Rightist Unit Killed Panagoulis
description: ATHENS, July 10 (Reuters)A court witness has told an Athens magistrate that Alexandros Panagoulis was killed by a right wing organization called Spider and not in a car accident, judicial sources said today.

title: Black victory in Rhodesia: How bloody will it be?
description: I remember Joshua Nkomo in the early 60'sa burly figure, full of vitality. Laughing and joking, he used to come into the offices of the newspaper I edited in Lusaka, in the heart of the central African plateau, to look up what the British Government was saying about Rhodesia. He had been in the forefront of the independence struggle for a decade, and we all assumed he would become President of Rhodesiaor rather, Zimbabwe, as the blacks had resolved to rename it within three or four years. The tide of nationalism was advancing down the con tinent at breakneck speed in those days.

title: Miss Drucklieb Is Wed to Jeffery Harris
description: The marriage of Catherine Ann Drucklieb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Drucklieb of Rumson, N.J., to Jeffery King Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Wesley Harris, also of Rumson, took place there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Foster C. Wilson performed the ceremony.

title: Bye bye sliderule, hello chip
description: That longtime friend of engineers and science students, with its sliding centerpiece and logarithmic scales has been consigned to the dustbin of history. The silicon chip and the electronic calculator have replaced it. Keuffel & Esser Company, the best known maker of sliderules, now sells calculators made by Texas Instruments Inc. and estimates that less than half of 1 percent of its sales are in sliderules. The microchip is the thing. It's much more versatile than the sliderule, says Richard Wayne, advertising manager of Keuffel & Esser.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The dance reviewer's lot has certainly become a busy one, and one or two events of the last few weeks have been inadvertently ignored. So here are a few footnotes on the Paul Taylor season, the Australian Ballet in The Merry Widow, George Balanchine's new revival Square Dance for the New York City Ballet and the Russian Festival of Music and Dance, which the Hurok Organization is presenting at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: There are certain assumptions in the arguments of the four books on Allende's Chileand to some degree in Peter Winn's review of them (May 9) that I would Like to question from the vantage point of one who travelled extensively in Chile during the five years preceding the military takeover of Sept. 11, 1973. Having spent a large part of my three visits as guest of the poet Pablo Neruda, an avowed Communist and later Allende's Ambassador to France, I was certainly not observing the unfolding Chilean tragedy from the positions of Allende's enemies. Nor did I have any inside knowledge (then or now) of the extent to which our Government may have been giving support to those enemies.

title: ART
description: TRENTON WITHIN the last century, Americans have become a nation of mbitious art collectors. They have formed some of the nost extraordinary, compre?? and beautiful collecions in the world, they have ?? their museums with reasure troves that attract visitors from near and far find their private holdings are he envy of many and the models of accomplishment in collecting.

title: Garen
description: Prune maple, birch, yellowwood and dogwood now; they will not bleed as they would have in the spring months.  Shrubs that bloom in July and August are pruned in early spring of 77; those that bloomed in May and June are pruned now While spraying roses with benomyi to control black spot, squirt some on lilacs to prevent mildew in August. Keep after red spider mites in hot weather on azaleas, annuals, juniper, and roses; use Kelthane.

title: PEOPLE
description: Somehow, his first two careers just didn't appeal to Anthony Whitehouse, who lives in Westfield, but now he finds himself doing what he always really wanted to: starring in a Broadway show.

title: TV VIEW
description: After years of confident announcements and conflicting behindthescenes rumors, New York's Lincoln Center became a television production in 1976. Live from Lincoln Center is being carried on the Public Broadcasting Service as an acquisition of WNET/13. Three productions have been presented: Van Cliburn, the pianist, with the New York Philharmonic conducted by Andre Previn; The New York City Opera's The Ballad of Baby Doe, and, most recently and the most successful by far, American Ballet Theater's Swan Lake, starring Natalia Makarova and Ivan Nagy. Three more productions are planned for the second half of this year as part of the Great Performances series.

title: L.I.R.R. HEAD AIMS FOR ONJOB VIEW
description: Priority No 1 for Robert K. Pattison, the Long Island Rail Road's new president and general manager, is to get out on the trains and be with itto get to know the nation's busiest rail commuter system first hand.

title: A New Pet Travel Season Is Unleashed
description: It's the time of year again when the barking of dogs is heard in increasing volume at international airport boarding ramps and at ship gangplanks. With the foreign tourist season in full swing now, an increasing number of American travellers are taking their dogs along. Exact figures on the movement of pets by air and sea are hard to get, but both international air carriers and the Cunard Line report a substantial number of pet bookings.

title: New Quartet Led By Dewey Redman Is His Best So Far
description: Dewey Redman spent much of the last decade playing the tenor saxophone for two deYnanding group leaders. Ornette Coleman and Keith Jarrett. He was a warm, fluent, adaptable contributor to both groups, but now that Mr. Coleman is relatively inactive and Mr. Jarrett has disbanded his quartet, Mr. Redman's own musical personqiity is coming through more clearly.

title: Billions for Billiards and Whatnot
description: First comes work, then comes play, then comes the sporting goods industry.

title: The Nation
description: President Ford has made important gains in his contest with Ronald Reagan, acquiring a number of additional Republican National Convention delegates and increasing the likelihood that he will arrive at the convention with only a few votes less than needed for the nomination. One way to win those votes, apparently, might be to offer the Vice Presidential nomination to Mr. Reagan; perhaps significantly, Mr. Ford softened his public attitude toward Mr. Reagan last week.

title: Mr. Carter Comes to a Party
description: The Democratic National Convention opens tomorrow with little to decide or debate, unlike the party's conventions of the recent past, and with its certain choice, Jimmy Carter, acting as though he were already nominated and, in some ways, already elected.

title: Taking the Bite Out of Summer
description: THE mosquitoes are coming, and the National Weather Service in Newark says that heavy rains are expected this month. That means the Garden State may become a Garden of Eden for millions of mosquitoes, whose eggs dry in warm weather and hatch in wetness.

title: Juliet Taylor Bride Of James E. Walsh
description: Juliet Sewell Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Harold Taylor of Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday at noon to James Edward Walsh of New York. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Metters at the Taylor home.

title: Miss Armstrong Bride of David Furney
description: Christine F. Armstrong and David J. Furney were married yesterday afternoon in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Thomas Stieres.

title: Unity Is Urged In Curing Mental Ills
description: TRENTON AN 18member task force, which recently completed a twoyear study on the care of the mentally ill in New Jersey, has recommended integration of the state's psychiatric hospitals and communitybased programs and the ultimate creation of a new Department of Mental Health.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: I said. No. I don't owe you money. you owe me! BOOMthe two of them start punching me.

title: Canadians Talk Back to Kramer
description: To the Editor: In reply to Hilton Kramer's article In Canadian Art, It's Yankee Go Home (June 6), it should be made clear at the outset that no serious Canadian artist has ever suggested that our museums should stop buying art from other countries. In fact, Canada is becoming much more international in outlook these days and increased antiAmericanism is the result.

title: In All Cases, Money Was the Essential Ingredient
description: ALBANYThe mood in Albany when legislators trudged back to the capital in January was one of weariness tinged with panic. With only a break for Christmas and New Year's, the lawmakers had spent the last six weeks of 1975 in an emergency session called to deal with the New York City fiscal crisis. The 1976 session did not have a real beginning. Rather, it evolved from that emergency session, and the agenda in January was the same grim imperative that had faced the legislators in December: insure that the state could complete its crucial $4 billion spring borrowing, and keep the giant Housing Finance Agency from going into default and dragging down with it what was left of the state's battered credit.

title: Carolyn Wilson Plans Nuptials
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert N. Wilson Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have made known the engagement of Dr. Wilson's daughter, Carolyn Campbell Wilson, to Dr. Michael E. Newmark son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Newmark of San Antonio.

title: Revolution in the delivery room
description: When a woman I'll call Ellen Phillips, a 26yearold about to give birth to her first child, was recently brought into a labor room in a large teaching hospital in New York City, she was helped into bed by a nurse, her husband was given a chair beside her bed and Mrs. Phillips was hooked up to a machine. A pair of belts was placed around her abdomen, each with a small electronic sensor. Within seconds, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips were intently watching two moving lines on a televisionlike box beside the bed.

title: Kenya Reports Killings
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 10A Kenyan newspaper reported today that about 245 Kenyan citizens had been killed in Uganda since the raid at Entebbe Airport by Israeli commandoes.

title: McTear Is Out of Olympics
description: PLATTSBURGH. N. Y., July 10Houston McTear, the 19yearold schoolboy sprinter from Milligan, Fla., was scratched from the Olympics because of an injury, a victim of his own folly.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Geoffrey Moss

title: West Paterson Is Host to 61 Britons Celebrating the Bicentennial
description: WEST PATERSON, July 10 I adore your English muffinswe don't have them in England, you know, 12yearold Simon Sears was telling Americans before the Bicentennial parade here today.

title: Changing U.S. Mood Worries Democrats
description: The Democrats have come to New York in a jovial mood, but they're a little worried about the changing mood of the country and not quite as confident or cheerful, as they sound. All the trends and computers are goingwith them. The popularity polls favor the Demo eratic frontrunner, former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia, by a substantial margin over either President Ford or former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California. They are offering the nation new leadership, not only in the White House, but in the House and Senate. In short, what promised a few months ago to be one of the great prize fights in the history of Madison Square Garden is turning into a revival meeting. But even so they are vaguely anxious.

title: How Carter Ran in the Primaries
description: Jimmy Carter ran in all but one of the 27 Presidentialpreference primaries this yea and won 39 percent of the votefar more than any other Democratic candidate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater: World of Sholom Aleichem
description: The stories in Arnold Perl's The World of Sholom Aleichem (the title is misleading since the pieces are not all by Sholom Aleichem) are gentle and wistful folk tales about the enduranceoften against heavy oddsof ordinary people. They may be foolslike the citizens of Chelmbut their failings are decidedly human. These are innocents subjugated not only by their society but by the rigidity of their own way of life.

title: Harriet Kass Wed To Alan Y. Medvin
description: Harriet A. Kass, an assistant professor of economics at Temple University, was married yesterday afternoon to Alan Y. Medvin, a partner in the Newark law firm of Horowitz, Bross & Sinins. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Kass of Trenton, parents of the bride.

title: Patients' Relatives Join Volunteers In Providing Care at Struck Hospitals
description: Four relatives of Eugenia Alcazar, who is in the intensivecare unit of Roosevelt Hospital sat in the hospital lobby yesterday afternoon taking turns looking in on her.

title: Suzanne H. Rappaport Is Married
description: Suzanne Helen Rappaport and Robert Loren Boydstun were married yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Vice Presidents: Lintheads, Knaves, and Some Great Men
description: As the investiture of Jimmy Carter as the Democratic Presidential nominee approaches, the only suspense is over whom Mr. Carter will choose as his VicePresidential candidate.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: (For week ended July 9, 1976)

title: Sometimes Old Shares Still Have Some Value
description: Suppose you inherit a batch of musty old shares in some corporation that you can't find any record of. Or maybe, in an attic, you find some yellowed stock certificates of a company that was established in the 1920's but has since gone out of business. Such securities may not necessarily be worthless. During the years since the shares were filed away, many situations could have arisen to convert them into valuable asset.

title: Carey and Beame to Greet Garden Delegates Tonight
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame, who played important roles in bringing the Democratic National Convention here, will speak from one of the most prestigious political platforms tonight when they welcome the 5,800 delegates and alternates and 10,000 newsmen and guests in Madison Square Garden as well as millions more on nationwide radio and television.

title: Miss Dancik Bride Of Richard Bahman
description: Susan Wilma Dancik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Dancik of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday in Easton, Conn., to Richard Lee Bahman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Bahman of Rochester, Minn.

title: Suspected Prostitute Held Under New Law
description: New York State's new law making it a crime to loiter for the purpose of engaging in prostitution was enforced for the first time yesterday in midtown Manhattan when a 22yearold woman was arrested for allegedly offering a potential customer a good time for $20, according to the police.

title: Venezuelans Flee Floods
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 11 Reuters)More than 25,000 people have been forced to abandon their homes in southwestern Venezuela after a week of torrential rain that caused flood damage totaling about $35 million, official sources said.

title: Figueroa Takes 10th
description: The Yankees ended the first half of their season yesterday with the same note of success that has punctuated it so fara 50 victory over the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: Maureen B. Liekens Bride of Richard Pelc
description: Maureen Bernadette Liekens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Liekens, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Eugene Pelc, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Pelc. Both families live in Brooklyn, where the ceremony was performed in Mary Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Richard Ferris, chaplain of St. Joseph's College and a professor of religious studies there.

title: UNION TALKS GO ON AT WESTINGHOUSE
description: PITTSBURGH, July 11 (UPI) A Westinghouse Electric Corporation spokesman said tonight that the four national unions bargaining with the company had agreed to a daytoday extension of the contract through this week.

title: Siderowf and Kaskel 9and8 Golf Victors
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 11  It was not unexpected, but the margin of victory was overwhelming as Dick Siderowf and Howard Kaskel of Doral won the 40th Anderson Memorial fourball golf tournament today.

title: CARTER PROMISES NO. 2 SPOT WILL GO TO 1 OF 7 QUERIED
description: On the eve of a Democratic National Convention that he has shaped in his own image, Jimmy Carter said yesterday that he planned no surprises and would choose his running mate from a group of seven nationally prominent prospects.

title: A Correction
description: Closing quotations for Pfizer Inc. shares in both the Saturday and Sunday editions of The Times were erroneously reported in computerized recordings of consolidated trading for New York Sto ??? Exchange issues furnished by The Associated Press.

title: Setback for Taiwan
description: Taiwan lost its fight to be represented at the Olympics in Montreal as the Republic of China. As a result, indications were that the Taiwanese would not participate in the games, which begin Saturday. Details on Page D9.

title: Directory
description: A complete guide to entertainment, dining, cultural events and other activities during the Democratic National Convention appeared in the Weekend section of The Times last Friday. Copies are available at no charge at the citizens committee's hospitality booths at 19 delegate hotels, at press headquarters at the Statler Hilton Hotel and the Felt Forum and at the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau, 90 West 42d Street. Here is a digest of information for convention visitors:

title: Four Earthquakes Strike PanamaColombia Border
description: PANAMA, July 11 (AP)Four earthquakes struck the sparsely populated jungles of the PanamaColombia border region today. Authorities said that the tremors had destroyed some buildings, but there were no reports of injuries.

title: Sutton Acts Like a Candidate for Mayor at a Party
description: It appeared to be more like a campaign kickoff affair than merely another champagneandsoul food party, and Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, for whom the event was being held, seemed to act more like a candidate for Mayor of New York City than just another Borough President.

title: Miss Di Paola Wed to Richard Natelson
description: JeriAnn Di Paola, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Di Paola of Rockville Centre, L. 1., was married yesterday afternoon in Tuxedo, N. Y., to Richard M. Natelson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Natelson of Stony Point, N. Y., and Mount Laurel, N. J.

title: Washington and Business The Problem of Accounting Standards
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Not many people whose business is subject to close scrutiny by Government regulators have been bold enough to directly challenge their overseers.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: New York Receives $15,000 in U.S. Aid To Assist Runaways
description: The New York City Youth Board has received a $15,000 grant from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to develop a summer program to provide temporary shelter, food and counseling for runaways up to 18 years of age.
