title: Lebanese Leftists Appeal To Arab Lands for Help
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11As rightwing Lebanese forces advanced toward Tripoli in the north today and pressed their offensive in Beirut, the leaders of the beleaguered Palestinian and leftist troops sent urgent appeals for help to Arab countries.

title: Rabbi Isaac Siegal, Leader Of Jersey City Congregation
description: Rabbi Isaac Siegal, spiritual leader of Congregation Ohab Sholom in Jersey City and an honorary president of the Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada, died yesterday at the age of 100 in the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in Jersey City. He lived at 1855 Kennedy Boulevard in Jersey City.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Eastern Europe, Despite Parley, Remains Wary of the Red Army
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 11Despite signs that Moscow has momentarily become more tolerant of divergent views in the European Communist community, Eastern Europeans harbor no doubts that for them the ultimate political arbitor remains the Soviet Army.

title: Ban the Balm!
description: Around the beginning of this century, the Democratic Party in convention assembled followed its heart and chose William Jennings Bryan with his philosophy of populism. Three times, Bryan and his populist dream of the redistribution of wealth went down to defeat.

title: 2 LITHUANIANS QUIT TURKEY FOR ROME
description: ISTANBUL Turkey, July 11 (Reuters)A Lithuanian father and son, freed this weekend by Turkey after spending six, years in custody for hijacking a Soviet airliner, left today for Rome, the staterun radio reported.

title: Leonia Artist, 62, Found Dead; Body Nude, Bound and Gagged
description: LEONIA, N. J., July 11An artist and antique dealer who had lived in this community for more than 50 years was found apparently murdered in his residence here at 141 Prospect Street.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6 No Title

title: A Rare Debate, on Rules
description: About the only controversy likely to roil the placid surface of the Democratic National Convention this week will come when the delegates debate a series of proposed rule changes affecting conventions, elections and party affairs.

title: Music
description: Ending a three  week American tour, the Sandejord Girls Choir stopped off at Carnegie Hall Saturday night before returning home to Norway. The chorus. 80voices strong, hails from the small town of Sandefjord, 75 miles south of Oslo, and is regarded as something of a national treasure, having won a number of local and international prizes for choral excellence.

title: Nearby Yachting Results
description: Nearby Yachting Results

title: Supplementary OverCounter
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: New York City Welfare Office Gets New Head
description: Bernard C. Fisher, a career socialwork leader and consultant, has been named to head the State Board of Social Welfare office for the New York City area.

title: Commodities
description: It would be difficult for the average investor to follow the stock market without the popular Dow Jones or Standard & Poor's averages or the New York Stock Exchange index to serve as a guide to general price movements.

title: Dynamic of Despair
description: The Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat may have made a fateful miscalculation within the past month or so, for which his Palestine Liberation Organization and the people of Lebanon are paying a terrible price. By encouraging allout resistance to Syrian advances into Lebanon, the P.L.O. leader has prolonged and intensified a futile civil warand pitted his political movement against strong and previously sympathetic forces in the Arab Middle East.

title: Opera: Ring Cycle Starts in Munich
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 11Bayreuth is not the only festival staging a Ring cycle this summer. Two weeks before Bayfeuth celebrates its centenary with the Ring, the National Theater in Munich is also putting on the Wagner tetralogy. Officials of the Munich Opera hasten to assure one and all that the duplication is pure coincidence. It is after all, the 100th anniversary of the first performance of the Ring cycle, and Munich, which was so important in Wagner's career, wanted to do something about it. Plans were laid several years back.

title: Jets Open Drills and Holtz Opens Up
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 11  That downhome Tom Sawyer image Lou Holtz projected during the offseason vanished today as he took the practice field for the first time as coach of the New York Jets.

title: Some Unemployed Young Blacks Find Jobs, but Many Are Returning to Street
description: When Johnnie Allen was not in the employment office looking for a job this time last year, he was hanging out in the streets of Harlem, and some of what he learned then, at 19 years of age, helped him cope with the frustration and the anger he felt over not findinz a job.

title: Calendar of Events
description: During the Democratic National Convention, New York will be alive with events, some of them special, inspired by the visiting delegates, and others that carry on the city's reputation as a place to see things, do things and experience things. Here is a selection of some of the activities on a daybyday basis.

title: Bulldog Takes 37th Top Prize
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 11The topwinning bulldog bitch in America, Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone, whn last year captured 78 blue rosettes, more than any other dog in the nation, was named best in a field of 1.187 today at the 29th Twin Brooks Kennel Club Show.

title: Rights Group Says Sakharov Will Join Board of Directors
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, has been elected to the position of honorary vice president and member of the board of directors of the International League for Human Rights, it was announced here yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Arizona Reporter's Death Has Big Impact,
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 9The renewed investigation into the killing of Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, is sending repercussions through the political and economic life of Arizona well beyond the issue of the slaying itself.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Colwell, Johnson Take Bowling Title
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 11 (AP)Paul Colwell and Don Johnson won the Professional Bowlers Association's first doubles championship today, defeating Steve Neff and Eddie Ressler, 447 pins to 414, in the title match.

title: Norell Shows That Culottes Are Graceful if Done Well
description: When Norman Norell last showed culottes, it created quite a furor. There were discussions about their decency; celebrities, were photographed wearing them and quoted extolling their comfort, and the designer offered to make his patterns available to copycats on Seventh Avenue to be sure they were made properly.

title: Boy Catches Big Shark
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., July 11Kenneth Sellin, 16 years old, of New York caught a 507pound tiger shark yesterday off Shinnecock. Sellin, who used 50poundtest line, fought the fish for an hour from a 22foot boat after the shark had taken a frozen mackerel bait.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 75yearold Bronx man was mugged and robbed of $3 by two men yesterday morning at Fifth Avenue and 40th Street. One assailant tied a rope around the neck'of the victim, Morris Siegal, while his partner robbed him. A passerby notified two police officers in a radio car, and after a brief chase, the officers arrested Ronald Glover, 27, at 43d Street and Vanderbilt Avenue. The suspect was charged with robbery, assault and the possession of the rope as a dangerous weapon. The second assailant escaped.

title: Setback for Taiwan
description: Taiwan lost its fight to be represented at the Olympics in Montreal as the Republic of China. As a result, indications were that the Taiwanese would not participate in the games, which begin Saturday. Details on Page D9.

title: Businessmen Wary About the Long Run, Though
description: Oil embargo was slow in reaching South Africa, but it hit hard when it arrived. Analysts expect it to linger until at least mid1977.

title: Coach Stop Takes Honors in Jumpoff
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 11Coach Stop, one of the United States Equestrian Team's leading Olympic mounts, won the Adirondack Grand Prix today, the closing event of the nineday Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: U.S. Warns Europe On a Soybean Curb
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)  Frederick B. Dent, President Ford's special trade representative, said today the United States will move immediately and firmly to defend its trade interests if the European Economic Community imposes a tax on vegetable oil imports.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON July 11Many state legislators believe, or so they have said in recent speeches, that much of the tax money appropriated to run the New Jersey government is being wasted.

title: RadioTV Schedule
description: Only one television network, NBC, has announced full gaveltogavel coverage of the Democratic National Convention. The tentative schedule is for the broadcasts to begin at 7 P.M. Monday, 3 P.M. Tuesday, 7 P.M. Wednesday and 12:30 P.M. Thursday.

title: Rumanians, While Not Jubilant, Count Gains From Berlin Talks
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 7  Rumania is not crowing over the results of the East, Berlin conference of 29 European Communist parties, mainly because crowing does not fit in with its deadpan style of diplomacy.

title: GLADYS HOUSE WILLIAMS
description: Gladys House Williams, widow of Edward H. Williams 3d, a civil engineer and banker in Woodstck, Vt., died yesterday while visiting a son in Portsmouth, N.H. She, was 85 years old and a resident of Woodstock.

title: Lebanese Leftists Appeal To Arab Lands for Help
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, July 11As rightwing Lebanese forces advanced toward Tripoli in the north today and pressed their offensive in Beirut, the leaders of the beleaguered Palestinian and leftist troops sent urgent appeals for help to Arab countries.

title: Miss Brown Wed To David Colman
description: Katheryne Elizabeth Brown, a registered nurse at Roosevelt Hospital, was married yesterday afternoon to David Colman, an assistant district attorney for New York County. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony in Stamford, Conn., at the home of Mark H. Brown, the bride's father.

title: Clergy Rallying to Social Causes
description: Episcopal Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of New York has placed his personal and ecclesiastical prestige behind a drive to stress the moral aspects of the problems brought about by the city's fiscal difficulties. And in the process, he has aroused the religious community to its highest level of concern for social and economic issues in many years.

title: Ebullient Democratic Chairman
description: In his four years as chairMan of the Democratic National Committee, Robert Schwarz Strauss has seldom lacked for critics. He was chosen as his party's leader in 1972 by a very narrow majority and attacked by liberals and reNews formers as a creature of the old guardbig city bosses, reactionary labor and Texas oil.

title: Convention Is Prelude To Others on the Way
description: The Democratic National Convention has brought 20,000 visitors into the citybut it is not unusual for New York to accommodate a convention of that size.

title: Djibouti Alert for Violence As 13 Riot Dead Are Buried
description: PARIS, July 11 (Reuters)Police reinforcements today patrolled Djibouti, capital of Afars and Issas, France's last African territory, to quell any possible violence at the funerals of 13 people killed in tribal clashes yesterday, officials said here.

title: How to Watch The Convention
description: FOLLOWING is a brief guide to help increase the observer's understanding of the proceedings at the Democratic National Convention this week: The keynote speech is tonight. The speakers are Senator John H. Glenn Jr. of Ohio and Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas. Miss. Jordan will be more fun to listen to  she is one of the party's truly accomplished orators  but Mr. Glenn is the one to watch carefully. He wants to be the VicePresidential candidate, and a rousing reception could help.

title: About New York
description: His role in the Democratic National Convention has been overlooked, even by the most astute analysts, and Jimmy McManus prefers it that way.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Some Key Faces On the Podium
description: Representative from Louisiana  first woman to preside over a national convention as the permanent chairman  active for 30 years with her husband, the late Representative Hale Boggs, campaigning in New Orleans and living in Washington  won a special election in 1973 with 81 percent of the vote after the death of her husband in a plane crash in Alaska  has attended nearly every Democratic convention since 1948  votes a solid liberal line  her chief interests are family and child services  she says of her convention chairmanship, I assume I'll command with a strict gavel  member of the national convention's site committee  considered for years one of the most knowledgeable Congressional wives  serves on the Banking, Currency and Housing Committee and the House Administration Committee and is chairman of the Joint Bicentennial Arrangements  was cochairman of the inaugural balls of President Kennedy and President Johnson  born and raised on a Southern sugar plantation  was graduated from the Sophie Newcomb College of Tulane University in 1935  taught history and English in St. James Parish, La.  has two daughters and a son.

title: Democrats Flout History in Returning to City
description: There must be some reasons that this is only the third time in 144 years that the Democrats are holding their national convention in New York, and that the Republicans have never held a national convention here. Perhaps some clues can be found in a dispatch sent to The Cincinnati Enquirer just after the first New York convention opened on a sweltering July 4. 1868:

title: Economic Impact of Rioting Is Less Than in 1960
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 11Demand for guns and guard dogs is up, but just about every other indicator is pointing sharply down these days as South Africa assesses the impact that the recent black rioting is likely to have on an economy that was already mired deep in recession before the violence broke out.

title: New Briefs
description: A 17yearold youth is scheduled to be arraigned today on charges of stabbing to death a North Bergen High School junior last week. The youth, who was not identified because of his age, has been held in the Hudson County Youth House in Secaucus since his arrest Saturday. The body the victim, Corinne Weckwert, 16, was found by a man walking his dog in North Hudson Park, about five blocks from her home, last Thursday.

title: AMIN IS FINISHED WITH TERRORISTS
description: TEL AVIV, July 11President Idi Amin of Uganda telephoned an Israeli friend this weekend and said that he was finished with the terrorists because they caused me a lot of trouble, the Israeli said.

title: Clark Center for the Performing Arts Opens Dance Festival on 42d Street
description: Dance works that bore a strong personal imprint turned out to be the most impressive among the nine pieces by as many young choreographers Saturday night in the first event of the new dance festival of the Clark Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Coast Forest Fire Quelled; 4 Hurt, 10 Buildings Ruined
description: BIG BEAR CITY, Calif., July 11 (UPI)Firefighters today contained a 5,000acre brush and timber fire in the San Bernardino National Forest that injured four firemen and destroved 10 buildings.

title: A Time For Change
description: In a country with serious unemployment the Government tends to spend its money in ways that create relatively few jobs. A grossly disproportionate share of the money goes to regions that need it least. States with the worst economic troubles subsidize the prosperous.

title: Nastase Defeats Orantes
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., July 11 (UPI)Ilie Nastase of Rumania defeated Manuel Orantes, 64, 63, today to win the $75,000 first prize in the Pepsi Grand Slam of Tennis.

title: A Platform Built Of Flexible Planks
description: In years past, the Democratic National Convention's platform debates have involved the great, divisive issues of the nation's history slavery and Reconstruction, free silver and monopolies, Prohibition and women's suffrage, civil rights and the Vietnam war.

title: A Contributor to Beame Is Reported Under Inquiry in Possible Tax Fraud
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has subpoenaed the records of two foreign corporations in an effort to learn whether Arnold E. Kagan, the financier and builder, may have committed tax fraud, sources close to the principals in the case said yesterday.

title: Citizenship Controversy May Delay Independence for South African Area
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 11Police gunfire that stemmed rioting in black townships of the Pretoria and Johannesburg areas last month has reverberated sharply hundreds of miles away in the Transkei, the first of South Africa's black homelands to accept statehood.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A recipe for a provencale beef dish that appeared in this column called for marinating the various ingredients for a period of several hours, overnight or longer.

title: Clergy Rallying to Social Causes
description: Episcopal Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of New York has placed his personal and ecclesiastical prestige behind a drive to stress the moral aspects of the problems brought about by the city's fiscal difficulties. And in the process, he has aroused the religious community to its highest level of concern for social and economic issues in many years.

title: Teamster Fund's Image
description: The teamsters union principal pension fund has started to mount a public relations defense of its activities in preparation for a legal fight that the fund's leaders expect to be forced to make. With Government investigations closing in on the embattled Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund, the top staff members,; led by the executive director, Daniel J. Shannon are concert ing some wrongdoing in the past, denying that there is any and attempting to put some distance between themselves and the 16 trustees, including the union president, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, who are ultimately accountable.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: The Touch of Royalty
description: BOSTON, July 11Of the mass of unresolved trivial questions raised during The visit, the most controversial was whether or not Queen Elizabeth II, on viewing the Liberty Bell, had succumbed to the impulse that seizes most ordinary tourists and reached out a (whitegloved) finger to touch it.

title: 10,000 Antiabortionists Attend a Protest Rally
description: Ten thousand persons rallied yesterdayfirst under a blazing sun in Central Park's Sheep Meadow and then in a twomile march to the Madison Square Garden areain an effort to persuade the Democratic National Convention to come out against abortion.

title: New York Joins a Party for the Party
description: Jimmy Carter knows who Mary Lasker is and he has met Andy Warhol, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Halston, the W. Averell Harrimans, the Robert Wagners and the Edgar Bronfmans, and they're all going to be around for the Democratic National Convention. So is Shirley MacLaine.

title: A Leader of Arab Baathists Reported Slain in Damascus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 11 (AP)  A leader of the Arab Baath Socialist Party was killed by a bomb in Damascus yesterday, the Syrian radio reported today.

title: New York Plays the Upbeat Host to Delegates
description: Relentlessly, John Mastrion swept up and down, up and down West 34th Street on his Sanitation Department scooter. Happily, Abraham D. Beame said, We're on our way up. Breathlessly, Ruth Ann Pastrick told of losing her Cartier cigarette case and lighter on the airplane from Chicago and having them returned within an hour.

title: W.T.T. Puts On a Good Show
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 11 World Team Tennis officials, club owners, players and rooters were ecstatic today at the way their second annual nationallytelevised AllStar extravaganza turned out last night here.

title: REBELS IN ANGOLA REPORT ADVANCES
description: LISBON, July 11  Guerrilla forces opposed to the Luanda Government have spread from southeastern Angola to a broad belt across the central part of the country, aocording to a military report from the proWestern rebel movement known as the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

title: The Medium's the Thing At a National Convention
description: On television's summer schedules, the Democratic National Convention is wedged into a narrow trough between two events of sufficiently high viewer interest and network enterprise to qualify as spectaculars, the Bicentennial and the summer Olympics.

title: G.M.'s FuelSaving Chevette: Right Car at the Wrong Time
description: DETROIT, July 11General Motors Chevette is the smallest, lightest and most economical automobile that is massproduced in this country. Last fall it was introduced with all the fanfare befitting America's first minicar. Some called it the wave of the future.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings
description: Monday, July 12. 1975

title: Dividend Meetings
description: ??? list of scheduled ??? for Week followss

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Three Medicaid Facilities Charged With Drug Abuse
description: New York City's Health Department has cracked down on three Medicaid centers that it said had one purposeto provide pills for a drug population.

title: COLORADO GIVES REAGAN 26 VOTES
description: DENVER, July 11 Colorado's Republican state convention ended finally in a tennis score: 15Lovethat is, 15 out of 16 atlarge national convention delegates for Ronald Reagan, and former Gov. John A. Love, a supporter of President Ford's, squeaking onto the delegation by dint of longago service to all party factions here.

title: Women's Olympic Crew Pulling Toward Medal
description: HANOVER, N.H., July 11 The eight oars, their blades painted red, white and blue, swing back in unison parallel to the water, turn, dip and dig hard, making the graceful shell seem to hop a little as it glides ahead faster. The muscles on the thighs, shoulders and arms of the rowers tighten and bulge and their faces contort with the effort.

title: Mr. Carter's Economics
description: In his wellplanned and shrewdly executed campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Governor Jimmy Carter has sought to avoid making the two fundamental mistakes on economic issues that hurt Senator George McGovern so badly, in his contest with Richard Nixon in 1972.

title: Fewer Minority Delegates
description: The representation of women, minorities and young people among the delegates who will cast 3,008 votes at the Democratic National Convention in Madison Square Garden will be slightly smaller than at the party's convention four years ago in Miami Beach.

title: Climatologists Forecast Stormy Economic Future
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.It was supposed to have been just a brief chat. Nelson Bunker Hunt is a busy man. But the Dallas man, who is a millionaire many times over, became so intrigued with what Then Browning had to say about climate shifts that he spent the whole day listening.

title: Met Opera Ballet Ensemble Bows at Dance Festival
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 11Like choristers seizing solo opportunities, the Metropolitan Opera Ballet Ensemble has thrust itself forward from the mass of thelarger opera ballet as an independent, concert group. It will continue to work in opera productions during the regular season but has substantially increased its choreographic and performing opportunities.

title: Poverty Found to Persist in Older Inner Cities Despite Aid Plans
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The older neighborhoods in the center of large industrial cities, despite the infusion of Federal and private antipoverty money in the 1960's, emerged from the decade in some respects worse off than they began it, according to a study by the National Center for Urban Affairs.

title: CORRECTION
description: In Saturday's New York Times, an article on the Concorde supersonic airliner stated incorrectly that the one sonic boom created by the plane in the first month of flights to the United States had stirred up public complaints. It stirred no public complaints. In the same article, several words were dropped from a sentence that should have read, in part that in June operations, the noise was essentially equal to that of the oldest, loudest fourengine subsonic jets on Asydings but twice as loud as the subsonics on takeoffs.

title: Label Licensing Bolsters Seventh Ave.
description: Seventh Avenue has extended its influence on life styles far beyond fashion apparel, with top designers licensing their names for hundreds of other products. The resultant retail sales have run into hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Arkansas Family, Here for Convention, Delights in Swarm of People and Cars
description: The Eugene T. Kelleys, who live on an Ozark Mountains farm a little smaller than Roosevelt Island, arrived at La Guardia airport during the rush hour yesterday afternoon.

title: Lavallette Fights County Plan to Erect Sewerage Pumping Station on Beach
description: LAVALLETTE, July 11Officials and residents of this coastal resort are furious over a stateapproved plan to put a sewerage pumping station on one of its beaches.

title: Teacher Weds Jennifer Stern
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue yesterday, Jennifer Anne Stern, daughter of Leonard Stern of London and the late Mrs. Stern, was married to Marshall Jordan Breger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miles Breger of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Model of Garden Used to Plan Convention
description: The bustle, the constant swirl of people conferring, carrying papers or whatever, that cluttered the televised images of previous political conventions will be curbed, if Raymond Hertler's cardboard cutouts are accurate, at the Democratic show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Barbara Katz Bride of Stephen Brown
description: Barbara Diane Katz and Stephen Brown, both of Ithaca, N. Y., were married yesterday at the Forsgate Country Club in Jamesburg, N. Y. Mayor Harold Berman of Highland Park, N. J., performed the ceremony.

title: Two Killed in Batavia By Lightning in Storm
description: BATAVIA, N.Y., July 11 (AP)  Two persons were struck and killed by lightning during a thunderstorm here this afternoon, the police said.

title: Jankunis Thinks Highly Of His Jumping Future
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., July 11The members of the United States Olympic men's track team were assembled in a dining room at their training base, the State University of New York campus. One by one, they stood and introduced themselves.

title: New Law Will Divide Cuba Into 14 Provinces by Fall
description: HAVANA, July 11 (Reuters) Cuba is to be divided into 14 provinces under a new law eliminating the six provinces that were formed in 1878 when the island was a Spanish colony.

title: 5,000 Picnic on a Pier With Carter Family
description: Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter welcomed 5,000 delegates to the Democratic National Convention last night at a huge, oldfashioned country picnic in a freshly forested Hudson River pier.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALEXANDERRussell C. Forever in my, heart. Mina.

title: CORRECTION
description: In Saturday's New York Times, an article on the Concorde supersonic airliner stated incorrectly that the one sonic boom created by the plane in the first month of flights to the United States had stirred up public complaints it stirred no public complaints. In the same article, several words were dropped from a sentence that should have read, in part, that in June operations, the noise was essentially equal to that of the oldest, loudest fourengine subsonic jets on landings but twice as loud as the subsonics takeoffs.

title: City U. Tuition: Obstacle in Leap From Kitchen to Campus
description: The day they voted to end free tuition at the City University of New York was the day the dinner table debates began in modest middleclass homes, debates that threaten to heat up as the summer wears on.

title: Women Fail to Agree With Carter on Their 80 Role
description: Jimmy Carter and a group of leading women Democrats were unable to reach agreement yesterday on a specific proposal for expanding the participation of women in the party's 1980 convention.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The New York Times/George Times

title: Star Filly Is Injured At Aqueduct
description: Richard E. Bailey's Dearly Precious, the 2yearold filly champion last year, may never race again.

title: Ellen Tannenbaum Bride
description: The marriage of Ellen Ivy Tannenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Tannenbaum of Brooklyn, to Elliott Michael Lavietes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Lavietes of Bayside, Queens, took place yesterday afternoon in the Seaview Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Herman Strizower performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Harpur College, is studying for a master's degree in social work at New York University. Her husband, an accountant, received an M.B.A. degree from St. John's University.

title: Carter Hears Sermon by Black Pastor, Then Hears Dixie, Played at 21 Club
description: Manny Carter, whose speeches sometimes resemble sermons, heard a sermon here yesterday that resembled a speech.

description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Television
description: Morning

title: PERCIVAL C. KEITH, SCIENTIST, 75, DIES
description: Percival Cleveland Keith, construction chief of the atomic bomb plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn., an expert in the chemistry of coal and petroleum and an advocate of the conversion of natural gas to gasoline, died Friday at his home in Peapack, N. J. He was 75 years old.

title: Nannine Joseph, Headed Literary Agency Since 30
description: Nannine Joseph, who had headed her own literary agency since 1930, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived at 200 West 54th Street.

title: Matthew J. Connelly Dies; Served as Aide to Truman
description: Matthew J. Connelly, President Truman's appointments secretary who was later imprisoned in a tax bribery case, died Saturday of cancer at the Rust Suburban Hospital in Oak Park III. He was 68 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: Tom Yawkey was vice president emeritus of the American League but in his late years he hardly ever attended either the business meetings or the boozy revels of the baseball hierarchy at AllStar Games, the World Series or the winter convention. He had little in common with other club owners and they were mystified by him, if not downright suspicious, because he was a strange fish who was in baseball not to make a buck or feed his ego but because he happened to love the game. Not many of the others could understand this, and it embarrassed them. When they were counting their money or posing for television cameras, Yawkey would be off somewhere fishing or hunting with a couple of his players, or in the summer when the game was over and the crowds had left Fenway Park he would put on spikes and baseball pants and a sweat shirt and get Johnny Orlando, the maitre de clubhouse, to pitch to him he could bit line drives off that leftfield wall. His feeling for the game was rooted in his boyhood. When he was 3 years old his father died and he was adopted by an uncle, William Hoover Yawkey, who owned the Detroit Tigers from 1904 through 1907. Bill Yawkey, who was to die in Ty Cobb's arms at the age of 43, entertained some of the most famous players of his time on his estate near Detroit, and young Tom grew up in these surroundings.

title: The Convention Program
description: Following is the tentative program for the fourday Democratic National Convention:

title: Talks Stepped Up to End Hospital Workers Strike
description: Federal mediators intensified the pace of talks in the hospital workers strike yesterday, but made no apparent progress toward ending the fiveday walkout of 35,000 nonmedical employees at 57 hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area.

title: Prosecutors Say West Point Limited Code Cases
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., July 11  Prosecutors in the West Point cheating scandal have told United States Military Academy officials that if there were a proper Investigation they could refer 300 to 400 cars to trialInstead of the 173 now officially admitted to be involved.

title: Montanez Paces Braves
description: ATLANTA, July 11 Nine couples were married at Atlanta Stadium today before the New York Mets played nine innings with the Atlanta Braves and lost, 98.

description: Hispanic Arts Festival Staged at Lincoln Center to Be an Annual Affair

title: New York Polishes Its Image
description: The image we project will be very important, because for the few days of the convention, not only the country but the world will focus on New York City.

Article 7  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Demonstrators Asking Amnesty Clash With the Police in Spain
description: MADRID, July 11Street clashes today in Madrid, Barcelona and Pamplona, where thousands of tourists are gathered for the annual festival of the bulls, marked a continuing opposition campaign for political amnesty.

title: CARTER PROMISES NO. 2 SPOT WILL GO TO 1 OF 7 QUERIED
description: On the eve of a Democratic National Convention that he has shaped in his own image, Jimmy Carter said yesterday that he planned no surprises and would choose his running mate from a group of seven nationally prominent prospects.

title: ANGELA VARONA KING
description: Angela Varona King who founded Angela Varona Inc., a cosmetics manufacturing concern, in 1923 and headed it until 1968, when the business was sold, died Saturday in Washington, where she had been living. She was 82 years old.

title: Beirut's People Succumb at Last to City's Daily Agony
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11 More than ever before, Beirut has the look of a dying city.

title: Olympic Preview
description: Vladimir Tkachenko, the center of the Soviet Union's basketball team is 7 feet 2 inches tall.

title: JAMES C. FORBES
description: James C. Forbes, general manager in the United States for the Bermuda Department of Tourism, died Saturday at New Rochelle, N.Y., Hospital following a stroke. He was 55 years old and lived at 106 Beach Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Have the Democrats Found Peace or Only Exhaustion?
description: There is an eerie tranquillity in the Democratic party this week. It means not so much that old antagonisms have died in the choice of Jimmy Carter, but that the old antagonists of 1968 and 1972 were all about evenly out of the running in presidential politics last spring.

title: A TEXAS DELEGATE SAYS HE WAS HELD UP
description: The Texas Democratic chairman, Calvin Guest, reported yesterday that one of his convention delegates informed him he had been held up just before midnight Saturday near the Essex House, the delegation's Quarters on Central Park South.

title: A Futures Index
description: Traders in commodity futures are paying increasing attention to a price index provided by the Commodity Research Bureau of New York. Page D4.

title: Older Art Invades the Modern Museum
description: Invading halls long sacred to Picasso and Pollock, works by such 19thcentury American realists as Asher B. Durand, Thomas Cole, George Caleb Bingham and Albert Bierstadt will appear at the Museum of Modern Art this fall.

title: Advertising
description: When account executives (or any other kinds of executives) at N. W. Ayer ABH International or Young & Rubicam want to dictate a letter or memo, they don't call in their secretaries. They reach for their phones.

title: Byrne Throws a Party, But Some Can't Make It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, July 11Governor Byrne and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority gave a sumptuous party this afternoon to celebrate the opening of the Democratic National Convention tomorrow and to publicize the new sport complex rising from the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Fidrych and Jones To Start on Mound In All Star Game
description: Mark Fidrych, the rookie pitching sensation of the Detroit Tigers, Will be the American League's starting pitcher in tomorrow night's AllStar Game in Philadelphia.

title: Egyptian Wins Swim
description: NAPLES, July 11 (AP)Marawam Ghazawi of Egypt won the 18mile CapritoNaples swimming marathon today in 9 hours 5 minutes 34 seconds. He beat 15 swimmers from nine nations.

title: Jimmy Carter's Roots: Rural, Middle Class And Old White South
description: PLAINS, Ga.About a mile west of this tiny village, a narrow macadam road trails off the main highway and leads in a long, gentle curve through a tunnel of trees to yesterday.

title: Altman Agency Picked By M.&J.'s Love Line
description: Altman, Stoller, Weiss, which last Tuesday announced it had resigned the Yardley of London account, picked up the Love division of Menley & James on Friday. The billings could be between $1.5 million and $2 million a year.

title: 2 Women In Golf Playoff
description: SPRINGFIELD, Pa., July 11 Little Sandra Palmer, the defending United States Women's Open golf champion, sank a crucial putt on each of the last two holes today and tied JoAnne Carver for first place after 72 holes of the 31st Open. The two will play off for the title tomorrow.

title: No Accord Is Evident on Young Blacks Job Problems
description: Despite chronic unemployment among young blacks that now officially exceeds 40 percentsome estimates range upward of 70 percentthere has been no agreement among experts about how to avert what could become a human disaster in which millions of blacks become adults with no hope of ever finding jobs with a future.

title: Sports Today
description: GOLF

title: Soviet Astronauts Are Busy On a Tay for Active Rest
description: MOSCOW, July 11, (UPI)The two astronauts orbiting earth aboard the Salyut 5 space laboratory took a delayed day off today, but kept busy anyway. The Soviet press agency Tass said their duties during the day for active rest were exercises, medical checks and renorts to Soviet television.

title: Vietnam
description: Vietnam is united after 22 years; the old Vietminh movement rules an undivided country from its capital of Hanoi. The flag and anthem of North Vietnam are now seen and heard offidally, from Cao Lang in the north to Cau Mau in the south.

title: Mrs. Nixon Moved to Room With View of Pacific Ocean
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 11 (UPI)Pat Nixon, listed in stable but serious condition, has been moved to a room with a view of the Pacific Ocean to further help improve her spirits, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: BEAME AND BUCKLEY CRITICIZE DETENTE
description: Mayor Beame and Senator James L. Buckley assailed the Ford Administration's policy of detente with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe yesterday at a Bicentennial Salute to the Captive Nations held on Lib. erty Island.

title: U.S. Frigate, Patrol Plane Make Stopovers in Kenya
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) A United States Navy patrol plane and a frigate have arrived in Kenya in what the Defense Department said last night were routine stopovers not connected with tensions between that African country and neighboring Uganda.

title: Krakora Captures Penn Tennis Final
description: Joe Krakora, a Princeton player from Westfield, N.J., defeated Sachio Kato of Japan, 36, 76, 64, in the final of the Penn Summer men's tennis tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday. Krakora fought back from 14 in the second set. Kato is playing in Eastern tournaments this summer.

title: Third Grande Parade du Jazz Is Under Way in Nice
description: NICE, France, July 11Jazz passengers on this side! shout ed a guide, separating a stream of people surging through the Charles de Gaulle Airport north of Paris. Normal passengers over there.

title: No Amer Soccer League
description: No Amer Soccer League

title: MIN IS FINISHED WITH TERRORISTS
description: TEL AVIV, July 11President Idi Amin of Uganda telephoned an Israeli friend this weekend and said that he was finished with the terrorists because they caused me a lot of trouble, the Israeli said.

title: Sinatra Wed in Palm Springs; Reagan, Agnew Among Guests
description: RANCHO MIRAGE. Calif., July 11Frank Sinatra, the singer, was married today to a former model and showgirl, Barbara Marx, in a desert wedding surrounded by security befitting an international summit conference.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY JULY 12, 1976

title: Ford's Television Aide Resigns  Following Criticism by Nessen
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)  President Fords television adviser, Robert Mead, resigned today after criticism of his performance by Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary.

title: Egypt's Help Asked
description: CAIRO. July 11Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today appealed to Cairo to supply gasoline and diesel fuel to the beleaguered Palestinians in Lebanon, the Egyptian Government news agency reported.

title: Say, What's in the Duffel Bag? It's an Upholstered Chair
description: Upholstered furniture may look the same on the surface but underneath there are big changes. The trend is toward portability, knockdown design and allaround cornercutting to keep production costs down. The result is a breakthrough in both the design and the price of soft seating for the home.

title: Alan Jones Wins 500 Race at Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 11 (AP)Alan Jones of England, in a new March he really didn't want to drive, edged past Al Unser with two laps to go for a disputed victory today in a rainplagued 100mile event for Formula 5000 roadracing machines.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: LEFT:

title: New York Plays the Upbeat Host to Delegates
description: Relentlessly, John Mastrion swept up and down, up and down West 34th Street on his Sanitation Department scooter. Happily, Abraham D. Beame said, We're on our way up. Breathlessly, Ruth Ann Pastrick told of losing her Cartier cigarette case and lighter on the airplane from Chicago and having them returned within an hour.

title: TV: Alternatives to That Convention
description: For those determined to igrnore the bulk of television convention coverage, this evening's alternatives include a dramatized portrait of other political powers and intrigues. At 9, Public Television's Piccadilly Circus series, a collection of programs imported from Britain, is offering The Man on the Rock. The man is Napoleon Bonaparte. The rock is St. Helena, an island of volcanic ash in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. The single actor who narrates and plays all the roles in contemporary dress is Kenneth Griffith.

title: Boondocks Convention
description: The natural habitat of the Democrat is Washington, D.C.

title: Jabouille Wins in Renault
description: SCARPERIA, Italy, July 11 (AP)Jean Pierre Jabouille of France guided his Renault to victory today in the eighth race of the European drivers championship for Formula two cars. His average speed was 170.257 miles an hour.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Phils Sweep Padres, 30; Kaat's First N.L. Shutout
description: After 17 seasons of pitching in the major leagues, Jim Kaat has learned to do his work quickly. The 37yearold lefthander who is spending his first season in the National League, needed just Sq pitches yesterday as his Phillies topped the San Diego Padres. 30. at Philadelphia.

title: Women Fail to Agree With Carter on Their 80 Role
description: Jimmy Carter and a group of leading women Democrats were unable to reach agreement yesterday on a specific proposal for expanding the participation of women in the party's 1980 convention.

title: Commerce in Ireland Limping Along on a Cash Basis While Nation's Banks Are Idle Because of a Strike
description: DUBLINIreland already anxious over its impoverished economy and signs of a new spillover of terrorism from the North, has become a country without banks.

title: Boston, Where It Began, Salutes the English Queen
description: BOSTON, July 11  Queen Elizabeth II spent her last day in the United States in this city with its Revolutionary past and heavily Irish present. She was received with applause by large, friendly crowds and restrained protest by a relatively small number of demonstrators.

title: Bridge:
description: When major matches are shown to an audience on a Vugraph screen, four of the players are bathed in limelight. Every move they make is scrutinized by a large audience and by expert commentators, who are in a position to provide doubledummy analysis.

title: Don Bolles Legacy
description: The news from Arizona during the past month has made it clear that the Southwestern sun has drawn more than Northern busifiess and the retired elderly to the nation's frontier country. In the wake of the murder of Don Bolles, a 47earold reporter for The Arizona Republic, investigations have indicated that the migrants money not only has pulled organized crime to the sunbelt, but has nourished a good deal of indigenous greed as well.

title: HARRISES TO TELL ABOUT MISS HEARST
description: LOS ANGELES, July 11A state jury may soon learn William and Emily Harris's versior of the Patricia Hearst story.

title: Peking Hero Buried in Quiet Ceremony
description: HONG KONG, July 11  The ashes of Chu Teh, modern China's greatest military leader and head of the country's Parliament, were buried in Peking today in a restrained ceremony that contrasted sharply with the far more emotional services for Prime Minister Chou Enlai last winter.

title: Medford Girl Is Miss New Jersey
description: RUNNEMEDIE, N.J., July 11 (AP)Lori Johnson, a 19yearold communications major in college, has been crowned Miss New Jersey and will represent the state in the Miss Amrica Pageant this September.

title: White Quits CBS Role To Work on New Book
description: Theodore H. White, the author, has bowed out as a consultant and guest commentator for CBSTV at the nominating conventions, to devote his time to a book on the making of yet another President.

title: Climatologists Forecast Stormy Economic Future
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.It was supposed to have been just a brief chat. Nelson Bunker Hunt is a busy man. But the Dallas man, who is a millionaire many times over, became so intrigued with what Iben Browning had to say about climate shifts that he spent the whole day listening.

title: Taiwan Loses Fight, Likely to Quit Games
description: MONTREAL, July 11Idealism gave way to political reality tonight when Lord Killanin of Ireland conceded he had lost the battle over Taiwanese participation in the Olympic Games.

title: Execution in Angola Viewed As Hurdle to Ties With U.S.
description: LISBON, July 11Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, declared here today that the execution by Angola of an American mercenary, Daniel F. Gearhart, would likely retard the development of normal relations between Washineton and Luanda.

title: Talks Stepped Up to End Hospital Workers Strike
description: Federal mediators intensified the pace of talks in the hospital workers strike yesterday, but made no apparent progress toward ending the fiveday walkout of 35,000 nonmedical employees at 57 hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area.

title: Carter's Coup Nears Its Climax
description: Jimmy Carter was the right general for this war at this time in this place.

title: Festival in Lhasa: Gaiety in the Garden of a God King
description: LHASA, TibetOn a festival day in Lhasa's short high summer all roads lead to the Norbulingka, the pleasure garden of the ugod longs who used to rule Tibet. It stands two miles from the Potala, the huge and forbidding palacefortress that dominates Lhasa, and one of old Tibet's greatest pageants was the annual progress of the Dalai Lama from his winter quarters to his summer palace.

title: Hostage's Death Feared
description: LONDON, July 11British officials, angered at Uganda's statement that it knows nothing about the fate of Mrs. Dora Bloch, expressed fears today that she has been killed.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECT BONDPRICE RALLY TO CONTINUE A BIT
description: The credit markets rallied briskly of Friday, propelled, toward higher bond prices and lower interest rates by the conviction that the Federal Reserve, had eased its credit stance and also by the news that the Wholesale Price Index rose less than expected in June. While the rally was pleasant enough for Wall Street, the real question in the minds of most many managers was whether it would continue.

title: Transition
description: At first, it will seem like quite change, to be at the Democratc National Convention as an alternate in the California delegation, only eight years after having been gassed and indicted in Chicago. But times have changed. Those who wanted to jail the likes of me have gone to jail themselves, or are purged from office.

title: Books of The Times
description: You expect extremes of violence and grotesqueness in the fiction of Harry Crews, and in his latest novel, A Feast of Snakes, you surely get them. Just to sample some of what happens during the Annual Rattlesnake Roundup in the rural redneck town of Mystic, Ga.: rats get fed to rattlesnakes; wives get beaten by husbands; a bulldog is nearly worn to death on a treadmill training device and then is killed by its opponent in a grisly pit fight; the local sheriff, who has already lost a leg from stepping on a pungee stake in Vietnam, gets his sexual organ severed by a demented black woman he has forced to sleep with him; a woman commits suicide by putting her head in plastic bag and knotting her husband's only tie around her neck; her daughter spends her days and nights lying in bed watching television, even when only the test pattern is showing, stopping only long enough to occasionally rub feces in her hair. All in 177 mean, angry pages, and I'm leaving out a lot.

title: A Dull Convention Brightened
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 12The convention heaved itself into being and sentience this afternoon at 12:05. 35 minutes late.

title: India's Ban on Violence Inhibits Film Production and Investment
Budget Cut Forces Hunter To Cancel All Arts Events
COURT GIVES RAISE TO NASSAU POLICE
description: MINEOLA, July 12  An award of a 9.5percent wage increase for 3,300 members of the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association was upheld unanimously today by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Vietnam Retains Scars And Reminders of U.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 12 (AP)A CanadianAmerican couple just back from a motor trip in Vietnam say vast destruction and poverty are still evident in northern Vietnam while people in the southern cities of Danang and Hue cling to a life style learned from Americans.

title: A Taxi Driver Returns Cameras Left in Cab
description: A 23yearold reporter for The Anderson (S.C.) Independent and Daily Mail, on her first visit here, had only praise yesterday for the taxi driver who returned the camera equipment she left in his cab in the confusion of her arrival.

title: Carter's June Donations Are Listed at $2 Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Jimmy Carter was showered with $2 million in ?? last month as Democrats rushed to support a runaway winner.

title: Freedom as a ForeignPolicy Base
description: WASHINGTON  There are two kinds of political harmony.

title: Conventioneers Find New York Both a Fun and a Friendly City
description: Arm in arm, Lynette Gittens and Bill Mc Ewen and Teresa Lunsford and Ray Stevens did a wiggly sort of dance to When the Democrats  Come Marchin In, on the stage of the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday. Miss Gittens, Miss Lunsford and other members of the AllCity Chorus danced down off the stage to where guests at the Democratic National Convention were picnicking, some of them seated on the flowered carpet of the ballroom. And they danced back up, with Mr. McEwen, an alternate from Maryland and Mr. Stevens, a delegate from Ohio, and other Democrats.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Monday. London: Morning fixing $122.20, down $0.30; afternoon fixing $121.85, down $0.30. Paris: Afternoon market quotation $123.51. down $0.53.

description: Law enforcement officials reported that fewer prostitutes were walking along midtown strees yesterdaythe day after a strict antiloitering law went into effect.

title: Steel Output Down By 2.7% in Week; Use of Capacity Off
description: Steel production In the week ended July 10 declined 2.7 percent to 2.59 million net tons from 2.66 million tons the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended July 12, 1975 total steel production Was 1.91 million tons.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: ES. SENDS FRIGATE TO KENYA IN SHOW
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The United States has sent a frigate and a Navy patrol plane to Kenya in a symbolic show of support for the East African nation in its dispute with neighboring Uganda.

title: ISRAEL IS DETAINING 50 WEST BANK ARABS
description: TEL AVIV, July 12Israel announced today that its security forces in the occupied West Bank of Jordan had smashed eight terrorist cells belonging to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

title: U.S. SENDS FRIGATE TO KENYA IN SHOW
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The United States has sent a frigate and a Navy patrol plane to Kenya in a symbolic show of support for the East African nation in its dispute with neighboring Uganda.

title: 4 Days in a Sea of Good Will, Mostly
description: Outside Madison Square Garden, a sidewalk vendor delighted in the attention paid to her stock of lapel buttons bearing nothing but a strikingly familiar set of grinning teeth. They were, said the vendor, really unique.

title: PERU'S GOVERNMENT EXPELS TOP LEFTIST
description: STOCKHOLM, July 12 (Reuters)Hugo Blanco, the Peruvian leftist leader, said today that he had been arrested by Peru's military Government and expelled from his home country with no explanation.

title: Largest Harvest of Corn Is Forecast in U.S. Report
description: CHICAGO, July 12Farmers will harvest the nation's largest corn crop this year, as well as a bumper wheat crop, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

title: Olympic Preview
description: The Soviet Union does not make concessions easily. So when its gymnastics coaches say that nothing but a fall will prevent Nadia Comeneci of Rumania from capturing allaround honors at Montreal. take note.

title: Incendiary Cigarette Packs Are Set Off At Midtown Stores, I gniting Tiny Fires
description: A series of incendiary devices in cigarette packs set off tiny fires in midtown department stores here yesterday, and a Puerto Rican nationalist group later said it had placed the devices to protest the presence of the Puerto Rican delegation at the Democratic National Convention.

title: New Baseball Contract Limits Reserve System
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 12Baseball's owners and players reached agreement today on a fouryear pact that for the first time gives the players freedom of movement.

title: Two Air Race Entrants Are Injured in Crash
description: PARKERSBURG, W. Va., July 12 (UPI)Two California women were injured seriously today when their plane crashed on the final leg of the coasttocoast Powder Puff Derby.

title: Shirley MacLaine Returning to Films
description: Shirley MacLaine, who has been touring in her onewoman revue here and abroad, will return to the screen after an absence of four years as costar of the Herbert Ross film, The Turning Point, it was announced yesterday by Alan Ladd Jr., senior vicepresident of 20thCenturyFox.

title: Making the Scene at Those Hors d'Oeuvres Acts
description: The Democrats are an energetic lot. They spent the first day of their national convention going to two or three luncheons topped by three to five cocktail receptions. By the time the gavel slammed the opening session to attention, they were stuffed.

title: Cucacao Getting Water Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Navy tankers have began carrying water to the Dutch island of Curacao, which has been short of drinking water since midJune, the Navy said today.

title: Arabs Seek New Truce
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, July 13The 20nation Arab League began a new attempt here yesterday to find a way of ending the Lebanese civil war, and Egypt offered to send tanks but not troops to strengthen the league's peacekeeping force in the Beirut area.

title: 6 Hosts to Delegates Delight in Their Role
description: Fiftysix New Yorkers are having a wonderful time showing convention delegates wonderful time.

description: Prices extended last week's late upturn in the credit markets in quiet trading yesterday.) This week's new offerings start today, which gave market particioants on Monday an onnor

title: India Lifts Passport Of Emigre Critical Of Gandhi Policies
description: The Indian Government has lifted the passport of Srikumar Poddar, a wealthy Michigan businessman and publisher of Indian birth, who has been critical of recent policies of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: PROSTITUTES HEED LAW ON LOITERING
description: Law enforcement officials reported that fewer prostitutes were walking along midtown streets yesterdaythe day after a strict antiloitering law went into effect.

title: Pact Curbs Hertz, Avis and National
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Federal Trade Commission announced today an agreement with the nation's three biggest automobile rental companies prohibiting them from conspiring to monopolize the business or to fix prices anywhere in the United States.

title: I.M.F. Loans in 6 Months Top Any Previous Year's
description: WASHINGTON. July 12The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that it had lent more money to its member countries in the first six months of this year than in any previous full year of the fund's history.

title: Players, N.B.A. in Court Again
description: The National Basketball Players Association went hack into court yesterday, contending that the spirit of the Oscar Robertson antitrust suit settlement was being violated.

title: Mrs. Carter Seeks Help Of Professional Women
description: Rosalynn Carter spent the opening day of the Democratic National Convention yesterday in much the same way as she has spent most of the last 14 months; campaigning for her husband and best friend, Jimmy Carter.

title: Commuter Taxpayers Lose
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (UPI)  Nonresident taxpayers were rebuffed by the courts today for the second time in their effort to get an increasefrom 3.3 percent to 4.3 percent ?? the city wage tax voided.

title: Beatrice Mathieu Is Dead at 71; Fashion Writer on New Yorker
description: Beatrice Mathieu, the first and only Paris fashion correspondent for The New Yorker magazine, died early yesterday in her sleep at her home, 870 United Nations Plaza. She was 71 years old.

title: Carter Ends Interviews on Running Mate
description: Jimmy Carter completed his interviews with possible running mates yesterday and said he might reach a decision tonight.

title: Mrs. Carney Takes Open Golf Title
description: SPRINGFIELD, Pa., July 12 JoAnne Carner won the United States Golf Association Open championship today by beating Sandra Palmer, last year's champion, in an 18hole playoff that included a swing of eight strokes over the last five holes. It was Mrs. Carner's second victory in the Open. She had triumphed in 1971.

title: Dr. Joseph Horan, Expert In Medical Insurance, 85
description: Dr. Joseph C. Horan, who retired 15 years ago as medical director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital after an illness of several months. He lived at 565 Park Avenue and was 85 years old.

title: Compromise Reached on Women's Role
description: A negotiating team of leading Democratic feminists won from Jimmy Carter yesterday what they termed acceptable commitments concerning the future role of women in the Democratic Party and in a ?? adminstration.

title: NEW MARS PHOTOS SHOW SMOGGY DAY
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 12 (UPI)Viking scientists, still planning a July 20 landing on Mars, looked at highaltitude pictures today that showed that the martian atmosphere was not as clear as had been indicated by some photos.

title: Largest Harvest of Corn Is Forecast in U.S. Report
description: CHICAGO, July 12Farmers will harvest the nation's largest corn crop this year, as well as a bumper wheat crop, the Agriculture Department predictled today.

description: At Dangerfield's, 1118 First Avenue, between 61st and 62d Streets, DAVID FRYE is the headliner of a full evening's show. There is $5 cover charge ($6 on weekends) and a $7 minimum that includes food as well as drink. 5931650.

title: Pact Reached on European Parliament
description: BRUSSELS, July 12  Common Market government heads reached tentative agreement tonight on how to distribute seats in a new, directly elected European Parliament.

description: The stock market closed yesterday at its highest level in 41 months as the Dow Jones industrial average reached 1,011.21, up 8.10. Analysts attributed the increase to the continuing economic recovery. Page 47.

title: A Heavy Fine Is Paid, $360 (All in Pennies)

title: VicePresidential Candidate
description: The most important decision Governor Carter is likely to make for a very long time to come is the decision he has to arrive at within the next two days  if he has not reached it already. It is a decision of vital significance, not only for the prospective Presidential nominee and for the Democratic Party but, more to the point, for the American people. It is the selection of the Democrat best qualified for the Vice Presidency of the United States.

title: Among the AlsoRans, Brown Spurns Loser Role
description: There is going to be only one big winner at the Democratic National Convention here this weekand his name will not be Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: HOSPITALS UNION WOOS DELEGATES
description: Thousands of striking hospial workers sought to attract help for their cause from Democratic National Convention delegates last night with a rally on 33d Street across from Madison Square Garden.

title: Olympics Betrayal
description: The cynical calculation of Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau that the International Olympic Committee was a paper tiger has proved correct. On the ground it had no other alternative, the executive board of the committee has bowed to Canada's decision to bar the Republic of China team that comes from Taiwan.

title: Delegates Outnumbered by the Press at Convention
description: The Democratic National Convention is the secondlargest convention in town.

title: CONNECTICUT BLOC IS FACING DISCORD
description: The Connecticut delegation was sitting up front at the opening last night of the Democratic National Convention, but it was obviously preoccupied. For the first time in nearly 30 years, Connecticut Democrats have been caught up in an internal fight that will probably determine which factions and personalities will control the party for years to come.

title: SPAIN CAUTIONED ON PRESS CONTROL
description: MADRID, July 12Spanish officials are on notice that they can no longer manage the news with discreet telephone calls to the press.

title: Janet Laib Married To James Byrnes Jr.
description: Janet Laib Amgott, daughter of Mrs. Isadore Levin of Palm Beach Fla., and Fast Hampton, L.I., and the late Walter Laib, was married yesterday afternoon, to James W. Byrnes Jr., son of Mrs. Martin Kinsella of Newport, R.I., and the late Mr. Byrnes.

title: WHEAT AND CORN SHOW PRICE DROP

description: Jimmy Carter has so far shown few signs of being able to win the landslide margin ?? Roman Catholic voters that has helped to elect every winning Democrat in this coun try, according to an analysis of surveys conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Operating Earnings At J. P. Morgan Up By 3.4% in Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan and Company Inc., the holding company for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, reported yesterday 3.4 percent higher operating earnings in the second quarter of $45.1 million, against $43.6 million reported in the like 1975 period.

description: CORONA DEL MAR, Calif., July 12A quarteracre test module is ready for launching at sea here to determine the feasibility of a chain of huge offshore kelp plantations that would produce abundant quantities of methane gas for fuel and nutrients for food crons and livestock.

description: SPOLETO, Italy, July 12The 19th Festival of Two Worlds ended yesterday with an openair performance of the Verdi Requiem, and a number of spectators remarked that a requiem seemed appropriate.

Troy, a selfconfessed tax cheat.

description: The 37th Democratic National Convention opened last night in Madison Square Garden in a blare of upbeat music accompanied by thunderous attacks on the Republicans.
