description: Bank Earnings

title: Union Denies Backing Bavh on Oil Breakup
description: WASHINGTON, July 13Disputing Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union said it has not endorsed Mr. Bayh's bill to break up 18 big oil companies.

title: Rocket Concern Indicted On Technology Exports
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13A Southern California aerospace company and its president were indicted by a Federal grand jury last night on seven counts of illegally exporting technology to France related to the fabrication of missiles and rockets.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State and Federal biologists have concluded that the ocean dumping of raw sewage and sewage sludge caused the immense fish kill covering 2,000 square miles of ocean bottom from Barnegat to Ambrose Light. The State Environmental Protection Department and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Laboratory issued statements saying the kill was an end result of a chain of events that began with ocean dumping. The scientists said nutrients from the dumping combined with natural nutrients in the water to provide food for a huge bloom of tiny ocean plants known as phytoplankton. The plants were trapped against the ocean floor by an upper layer of warm water that prevented normal water circulation, they said.

title: 2 JAPANESE GROUPS ON TRADE ACCUSED
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)  The Justice Department today charged the United StatesJapan Trade Council Inc. and the Japan Trade Promotion Office with filing misleading statements about their activities on behalf of Japan.

title: Carter's Economics
description: What are the economics of Jimmy Carter? The question has become a hot one, with critics of the virtually certain Democratic Presidential nominee charging that he is vague or contradictory on the major economic issues. Mr. Carter's advisersled by Prof. Lawrence R. Klein of the University of Pennsylvaniaconcede that he has not been particularly concrete about his economic plans or programs. Even Wlieri his advisers have Economic suggested specific numbersas Dr. Klein and Charles L. Schultze of the Brookings Analysis Institution have done on changed priorities for the Federal budgetMr. Carter has deleted the numbers from his ontherecord responses to questions.

title: U.S. Is Ready to Pay Teton Dam Victims
description: WASHINGTON, July. 13The Federal Government prepared today to reimburse flood victims for losses caused when the Teton Dam collapsed in Idaho last month.

title: Merrill Lynch's Earnings Off Sharply, Reflecting a Drop in Market Volume
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage organization, announced yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter declined 65.7 percent to $19.5 million, or 55 cents a common share, from the yearearlier $29.7 million, or 83 cents a share.

title: Major Policy Positions Taken in Democratic Platform
description: Following are the chapterbychapter highlights of the platform adopted last night by the Democratic National Convention. Extensive excerpts from the platform were published by The New York Times on June 18.

title: Mobutu Sees U.S. Official
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 13 (Agence FrancePresse)President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire met today for two hours in Lumumbashi with William E. Schaufele Jr., the United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, who briefed him on the meeting last month between Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Energy & Conflict: The Life and Times of Edward Teller, by Stanley A. Blumberg and Gwinn Owens (Putnam, $9.95).

title: Princess Anne Arrives
description: MONTREAL, July 13 (AP) Princess Anne, a member of Britain's equestrian team, arrived without fanfare at Montreal's Mirabel Airport tonight to compete in the Olympic Games. She went to Bromont, site of the equestrian competition. 40 miles southeast of Montreal.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: Jackhammer Concerto in Fisher Hall
description: Irwin Miller pushed back his helmet and looked over the battleground like a general whose troops are in control of the situation. I can visualize the whole thing now. he said with a sweeping look around an apparently bombedout interior of Avery Fisher Hall. It looks like we're going well. Right on schedule.

title: Israeli Charges Uganda Tries to Blackmail U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 13Israel charged in the Security Council today that Uganda was threatening foreign residents in an attempt to influence the Council's consideration of the recent Israel commando raid on Uganda's Entebbe airport.

title: Red Smith
description: It was generally agreed around Athens 23 centuries ago that Aristotle was about as sharp as a Greek can get, yet the old crock might learn a thing or two if he could visit Monticello Raceway this weekend. On Sunday he would see pacers competing in trials for the richest event in harness racing, the $300,000 Gold Rush that comes off a week later at the Catskills gambling hell. Horseplayers around Grossinger's, Kutsher's and the Concord see nothing remarkable about a horse employing the pacing gait but the sight would curl old Ari's whiskers because he proved by unassailable Aristotelian logic that if a horse tried to move both legs on the same side at the same time, he would inevitably fall. As almost everybody since Aristotle has known, a harness horse is either a pacer who strides forward with his left forefoot and left hindfoot simultaneously or a trotter whose diagonal gait moves the left forefoot and right hindfoot together. Up at Monticello, though, there is a schizophrenic steed who is both.

title: City Hall, Where the Action Is
description: City Hall in New York is not only the place you go tell it to. It's also the place where medals are awarded, dignitaries, foreign and domestic, received, heros feted, and in the adjacent park, lunches eaten. Yesterday, housing policemen who had been laid off held a rally for reinstatement, and a group of Austrians from the Tyrol danced In dirndls and lederhosen, performed on wheels, played Tyrolean music, complete with yodels, and left the impression, by no means unintentional, that Tyrol might be a nice place to visit.

title: SUIT BY U.S. CHARGES BIAS OVER RELIGION
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) The Department of Justice filed today its first religiousdiscrimination suit against a school district that had dismissed a teacher who took several days off to observe religious holidays.

title: Children's Psychiatric Center Gets Grant
description: EATONTOWN. July 13The Children's Psychiatric Center here has become the first such facility in the state to receive a Federal grant from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, for $1.4 million.

title: WIDE SPECULATION
description: Jimmy Carter said last night he was obviously in the process of boiling down in my mind his final selection of a running mate, but stressed that he had not told even his closest advisers who is preeminent in my mind.

title: Social Security of 133,000 In Nonprofit Units in Peril
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 13An administrative oversight by most of the nation's 133,000 nonprofit organizations has jeopardized the Social Security coverage of many of their employees.

title: Delegates Beginning, To Savor City Life
description: Patricia Lee came to New York City from Augusta, Ga., eager for political combat and instead, in an effusive state matching that of the host city, she gave away her two tickets to A Chorus Line and went to the convention that would nominate her husband's old boss for President of the United States.

title: Charles Ritz Dead at 84; Ran Famed Paris Hotel
description: PARIS, July 13 Charles Ritz, director of the Ritz Hotel on the Place Venome here, died on Sunday, according to staff members at the elegant hotel that his father founded 78 years ago. The cause of death has not been disclosed.

title: Two Botanical Remedies For New York's Tumult
description: Even the most ardent convention follower needs to take a break from the tumultuous predictable now and then. What better way to escape the mobdelegate syndrome than to visit one of New York City's splendid botanical gardens?

title: Schools of South Africa Are Separate and Unequal
description: JOHANNESBURG. July 14Moses Pere always wanted to be one of the small band of South African blacks who grad. uate from high school. But when his father died last year, his mother, a kitchen hand, could no longer afford the $50 a year it cost to keep him in primary school.

title: The Death Penalty
description: In the death penalty cases decided a few days ago, the Supreme Court was asked whether, at the levels of civilization America had achieved by 1976, the taking of a human life was not so harsh and cruel as to be an impermissible punishment for the state to inflict. After reflecting on the judgments of a number of state legislatures, the Court decided that under the right circumstances, the death penalty does not violate the Constitution.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1915, with little experience and only a love of literature to commend her, a young Frenchwoman named Adrienne Monnier opened a bookshop on Paris's Rue de I'Odon. The shop, which subsequently acquired the happy name of Maison des Amis des Livreshouse of the friends of bookswas, along with Sylvia Beach's Shakespeare and Company, a center of Paris's literary and artistic life between the wars.

title: U.S. Army Blocks German Tank Project
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Army and its contractors succeeded earlier this month in blocking a plan, worked out between the Defense Department and the West German Defense Ministry, for the two nations to build common components for their new main battle tank, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Alcoa Asserts a U.S. Envoy Solicited Payment Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, July 14An unidentified United States ambassador solicited at least $25,000 from the Aluminum rnmnanv of America that apparently was paid to officials and political parties of a foreign country, according to papers filed by the company recently with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: TV: The Convention Covers Itself
description: Television coverage or the Democratic convention reached its peak of effectiveness last night as politicians and delegates pushed television newsmen out of the picture. For a good part of the evening, the camera simply turned to the podium or the state delegations while commentary and wandering interviews were kept to a minimum. A national ritual. with all of its dignity and silliness intact, was allowed to come through remarkably undiluted.

title: RECEPTION MIXED IN NEW OFFERINGS
description: A variety of new offerings were well received yesterday in the corporate, or taxable. sector of the credit markets on a day marked by some modest price declines in taxexempt issues. The day's new municipal offerings thus got off to a slower start. Government market participants. in turn, were not sur prised to learn yesterday afternoon that the Treasury Department is planning to sell $2.75 billion of twoyear notes next Tuesday.

title: Money
description: Money

title: Figures on Unemployment Are Up in New York State
description: ALBANY, July 14 (AP)The number of persons claiming unemployment benefits in the state rose substantially in the first week in July, apparently because of schools and factories closing for vacations.

title: Bonds Faces Surgery
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 14 (AP)Bobby Bonds, California Angels outfielder, may have to undergo offseason surgery for a chip fracture of the middle finger of his right hand, an Angel spokesman said today. Bonds should not miss any further games this season because of the injury, the spokesman said.

title: Phipps Replaces Dreyfus at N.Y.R.A.
description: Jack Dreyfus turned over the chairmanship of the New York Racing Association to Ogden Mills (Dinny) Phipps yesterday. Dreyfus resigned the post to devote more time to his Dreyfus Medical Foundation, a worldwide operation that is involved with the drug Dilaniin. The 35yearold Phipps apparently will continue under the course set by Dreyfus, who took over the post in early 1975 as a temporary measure. At the time, the position of vice chairman of the N.Y.R.A. was created for Phipps.

title: Rizzo Check at Midpoint
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP)The checking of signatures in the recall drive against Mayor Frank Rizzo has reached the halfway point. About 105,000 of the 211,000 signatures have been considered by workers of the City Commission.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 14Efforts to put New Jersey's new state income tax into effect ran into more difficulty in the Legislature today. But the new tax, approved last week by the Legislature, does not appear to be in serious trouble.

title: Catherine Plagemann, Led Children's Science Fair
description: Catherine Plagemann, an author and director of the First Children's Science Fair from 1931 to 1938, died yesterday at her home, Field House, Palisades, N.Y. She was 70 years old.

title: Reagan Begins 2Day Bid to Raid Ford's jersey and Pennsylvania Delegates
description: NEWARK, July 14Ronald Reagan swung east today on a twoday raiding expedition among New Jersey and Pennsylvania convention delegations leaning heavily to President Ford in the Republican Presidential nominating contest.

title: Price Spiral Persisting in Spain Amid Change in the Government
description: MADRID, July 14There have been no riots, as in Poland, but Spain's shock, embarrasment and anxiety over the cost of living intensified just as the Government was being replaced.

title: Busby of Royals To Have Surgery
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 14Steve Busby, the Kansas City Royals most successful pitcher the last three seasons, will undergo surgery on his injured right arm and likely will miss the rest of the season, the Royals announced today.

title: A QUICK VICTORY
description: Jimmy Carter of Georgia won the Democratic Presidential nomination last night.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 5.3311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.3900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Shaw, Hurok Competitor, to Work With Its Artists
description: Hurok Concerts Inc., which has lost most of its top artist management executives, announced yesterday that Harold Shaw, one of its competitors, would devote a substantial portion of his time to Hurok artist management affairs.

title: Ronald Tree Is Dead in London; Friend of U.S., British Leaders
description: Ronald Tree, a grandson of Marshall Field, a former member of the British Parliament and for almost half a century an intimate of the men and women who shaped American and British history, died in London yesterday after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Vintage Autos Stop in Town En Route to San Francisco
description: Ed Schuler, a little whitehaired man, played Yankee Doodle Dandy yesterday on the horn of his 1914 Dodge.

title: Witness Whose Car Was Seized by the Harrises Says He Never Feared They'd Kill Him
description: LOS ANGELES, July 14A prosecution witness, testifying in the first crossexamination conducted by William Harris, said today that while Mr. Harris and his wife, Emily, took his car at gunpoint in the name of Symbionese Liberation Army, he never thought the revolutionaries would kill him.

title: Carter Thanks Georgians
description: Jimmy Carter thanked Georgia convention delegates yesterday for their support back when not many people thought I had a chance to be Democratic Presidential nominee, United Press International reported. Hours before his assured nomination, Mr. Carter told his home state's delegates that he did not intend to lose the general election in November.

title: If
description: As the secretary called the roll of the states last evening for the one and only ballot that made Jimmy Carter the nominee of the Democratic Party, more than one person in Madison Square Garden may have been thinking how events might have produced a different winner if

title: Rain Mars Bastille Day Parade but Delights Farmers
description: PARIS, July 14 (AP)A steady downpour marred the Bastille Day parade down the ChampsElysees today but brought joy to farmers in the drought stricken French countryside.

title: City Baffles and Amuses Arkansas Family
description: The cab driver, a friendly, earnest man of advancing years, learned that the Eugene T. Kelleys were from a small town in the Ozark Mountains. seen among other marvels a stuffed calf priced at $700. That is $200 more than they paid for a registered Hereford bull last month.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 29yearold man has been convicted in Mineola, L.I., in the fatal shooting last fall of a Nassau County police officer who was investigating a burglary at a restaurant in West Hempstead. The jury of 11 men and one woman deliberated for two days before convicting John Mackenzie, formerly of Whitestone, Queens, of firstdegree manslaughter, felony murder and burglary. The police officer, Matthew Giglio, 35, was shot once in the abdomen last Oct. 7, and died 10 weeks later. He was an 11year veteran of the police force.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Jimmy Carter of Georgia won the Democratic Presidential nomination on the first ballot, By an overwhelming margin, the convention ratified Mr. Carter's startling electoral ascendancy of the last six months, making him the first majorparty nominee from the Deep South since Zachary Taylor in 1848 and installing him as the early favorite to capture the White House in November. [Page 1, Columns 18.]

title: Much Gibberish By Irwin Corey At Playboy Club
description: When in the course of humanly stultifying agendas it superfluously behooves us to root out the unadorned ornately plainspeaking respite well, anyway, who is to compare with Irwin Corey? Not even convention orators.

title: Delegates Sample City's Wares, Limited Only by Their Budgets
description: It's been a mixed bag of an offduty week for the delegates, alternates and honored guests of this Democratic National Convention: a week of sightseeing, eating and shopping; of riding subways and ferries, tour buses and tramways; of elevating to the tops of the Empire State Building and World Trade Center and escalating to department store shopping bazaarsa completely eclectic week limited only by the tight budgets of many of the delegates.

title: Stolen Pants Found
description: Down on the convention two politicians were huddling. one thanking other for finding out about lost trousers.

title: S.E.C. Offers Changes in Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON. July 14The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today proposed amendments designed to simplify its requirements for periodic corporate disclosure and to require disclosure of the size. and source of financial backing in corporate takeover offers.

title: New Taiwan Plan For Olympic Role Gets U.S. Support
description: MONTREAL, July 14Taiwan will try to take part in the Olympic Games, at least on a token basis, under a plan drawn up today with strong support from both the United States and the International Olympic Committee. Unless the new proposal is accepted by the Canadian Government, the United States is prepared to pull its 425member team out of the Games.

title: New Tremor in North Italy
description: TRIESTE, Italy, July 14 (UPI)A mild tremor rattled window panes in the Friuli region of northeastern Italy today. No injuries or damage was reported.

title: MAY INVENTORIES. CLIMBED SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Total business inventories rose in May by the largest amount since the economic recovery began more than a year ago the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio WNEW, 7 P.M.

title: Spanish Parliament Liberalizes Penal Code, Making Political Activity Legal
description: MADRID, July 14Parliament agreed today after a month's delay to liberalize the penal code. The revised code establishes the principle that political parties, propaganda and meetings are now legal with specific exceptions. Until now, they have been banned.

title: REILLY TO BE TRIED ON LOWERED CHARGE
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 14 (AP)A state prosecutor has agreed to charge Peter A. Reilly, who faces a new trial in his mother's slaying, with manslaughter instead of murder, Mr. Reilly's lawyer said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Through an editing error, an article in The Times yesterday reported the average salary of welfare mothers who work as $149.12 a week. The average earning was $149.12 a month during March for the 16,074 welfare families with jobs.

title: GOLD PRICE SUPS AT I.M.F. AUCTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The International Monetary Fund sold 780,000 ounces of its gold at auction today at a price of $122.05 an ounce.

title: U.S. JUDGE LIMITS CLEAN AIR PLAN
description: The Federal cleanair plan for New York City has been substantially curtailed by a Federal judge.

title: Carter Gives a Preview Of Unity Drive in Party
description: In a significant preview of the way he hopes to pull together the disparate ideological wings of the Democratic Party, Jimmy Carter said yesterday that he hoped to reconcile conservatives and liberals behind a program of national common needs.

title: JERSEY, IN SHIFT, GOES FOR CARTER
description: Responding to an appeal for unity behind Jimmy Carter and after holding out some of their votes for coveted guest tickets to the Democratic National Convention, New Jersey's delegation voted unanimously last night in support of the former Georgia Governor's Presidential nomination.

title: Jimmy Carter's Three Sons They're Smiling in Amy's Shadow
description: Amy. Amy. Amy. So much has been written and said about Jimmy Carter's 8yearold blond, frecklefaced daughter with the gaptoothed grin that many people are unaware that the Democratic Presidential nominee also has three sons.

title: Funds for Needy Delegates Being Raised by Strauss
description: Although unable to use some $2 million of Democratic National Committee funds to help cover expenses of needy delegates to the National Convention, the party chairman, Robert S. Strauss, has raised some money privately to help hardship oases, United Press Interlational reports.

title: HERBERT R. HASTINGS OF GENERAL FOODS
description: Herbert R. Hastings, former treasurer of the General Foods Corporation, died Monday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Sarasota.

title: CLARK AND MOYNIHAN GET THE SIGNATURES
description: Ramsey Clark and Daniel P. Moynihan have both collected the 20,000 petition signatures needed to give them extra insurance for their places on the Democratic Senate primary batlot, spokesmen for the two said yesterday.

title: 6YearOld Boy Foils Kidnap Attempt
description: MINEOLA, L.L. July 14A wily 6yearold boy, kidnapped and held in a Westbury motel room for $100,000 ransom, turned the tables on his abductor this afternoon.

title: Television
description: Live telecasts on Channel 4 at 12:30 P.M. and Channel 2 at 1:30 P.M. Edited coverage on Chan. nel 7 at S P.M. The latenight schedules for these stations are indefinite and depend upon the time of adjournment of the convention.

title: Ford Suspect Committed
description: OMAHA, Neb., July 14 (UPI)  United States District Court Judge Robert Denney has dismissed a charge of threatening the life of President Ford filed against Raymbnd Farnham, 23 years old, of Fredonia, N. Y. The Douglas County Men tal Health Board had ordered that Mr. Farnham be committed for psychiatric treatment and Judge Denney ruled the man was incompetent to stood trial.

title: Market Place
description: A broker who looks for hidden values recently examined the Morse Electro Products Corporation and concluded that the company's stock was undervalued.

title: Bridge:
description: Beginners soon learn that they can bid a threecard minor suit when circumstances so dictate, but threecard majors are quite another matter.

title: ALLSTARS OUTDRAW CONVENTION ON TV
description: The stars of the Democratic Party were no match for the stars of baseball Tuesday. night. The overnight Nielsen ratings for New York found that 48 percent of the audience watched the AllStar game on IABC, while only 15 percent were tuned to the coverage on ICBS and NBC during the hours of the ball game.

title: President, 63 and Healthy, Treated to Lunch by Wife
description: WASHINGTON, July 14President Ford celebrated his 63d birthday today with his doctor proclaiming him in excellent health.

title: 3,095 Heart Devices May Be Defective, U.S. Agency Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that 500 implanted heart pacemakers and 2,595 heart defibrillators may be defective.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Symbol and Victim of U.S., Bald Eagle Found in Peril
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) After 200 years of nationhood. the United States now may be forced to list its national symbol, the bald eagle, as an endangered speciesa victim of shooting, pesticides and human intrusion.

title: Chess:
description: BIEL, Switzerland, July 13 In the first round of the Interzonal Tournament being played here to select candidates for a world championship challenge, only two games finished decisively. A former world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, picked up a point when Raul Sanguinetti of Argentina went astray in a queenandpawn ending and lost two pawns, and Oscar Castro of Colombia defeated an exchange sacrifice by Andre Lombard of Switzerland to win on the black side of a Gruenfeld Defense.

title: Carter Gives Insight On DecisionMaking
description: It was the most important day in Jimmy Carter's life. As he sat and talked in his suite on the 21st floor of the Americana Hotel, the prize for which he had toiled 19 long monthsthe Democratic nomination for President of the United States  lay only 12 hours ahead.He seemed as calm as if he were spending the day inspecting peanuts back in Plains, Ga., instead of discussing in his orderly and almost detached manner, his choice for Vice President, his acceptance speech and his plans for the campaign.

title: Plains Moves Up From Almanac to History Books
description: PLAINS, Ga. July 14The tiny town of Plains, in jubilant celebration of a local hoy's dream, faded from the ranks of absctite American villages tonightfor better for worse.

title: AUTO SALES RISE IN 10DAY PERIOD
description: DETROIT, July 14 The American auto industry reported today shortages in some lines were holding down new car sales, but deliveries for the July 110 period were still 14.3 percent ahead of last year.

title: The Program For Today
description: Following are highlights from the tentative program for the Democratic National Convention today:

title: A Petition for Seat Belts On School Buses Denied
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)The National Highway Transportation Safety Board has denied a petition by the New Jerseybased Physicians for Automobile Safety to require seat belts in school buses.

title: Football Regular Dies
description: ATLANTA, July 14 (AP)Hugh Hendrix, a starting offensive guard on the University of Georgia football team. died today of a cardiac arrest brought on by an acute blood infection. The 21yearold senior had been attending summer school before going home to nearby Decatur over the weekend, where he developed flulike symptoms of chills and fever, according to a school spokesman.

title: Eights Favored
description: Rowing is one of the best run of all the United States' Olympic sports, having contented coaches and competitors. Contentment, however, gives no assurance of success because the fabulous East German program dominates the sport on the international level (10 firsts in 14 events at the 1975 world championships).

title: Convention Applauds Antiterrorist Stand
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI)  The Democratic National Convention applauded loudly Tuesday in endorsing coordinated action by nations against international terrorism.

title: SAVINGS INFLOW SLOWED IN JUNE
description: The inflow of money into savings institutions across the country slowed sharply in June, reflecting the general increase in moneymarket interest rates that had made savings deposit rates less attractive.

title: Artifacts From Tut's Tomb Coming to U.S
description: CAIRO. July 13Christel Faltermeier was worried about the ancient blue paint. Thomas Logan studied a crack in a 3.000yearold statuette. Thomas P. F. Hoving discussed museum finances.

title: These Reds Appeal to the President
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14In his miniature Cincinnati Reds uniform with 14 and Rose on the back, 6yearold Pete Rose Jr. was twirling a bat near his father's locker in the National League clubhouse after the AllStar Game when somebody asked him what he thought of the American League team.

title: No. Arner. Soccer League
description: No. Arner. Soccer League

title: Palestinians Say Syrians Quit Lebanon Port Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. July 14Syrian artillery and armored forces today withdrew from strategic hills dominating the vital port city of Saida in southern Lebanon, Palestinian officials said.

title: Democrats Turn to Nixon And Watergate as Issues
description: Jimmy Carter pledged that he never would tuttut aloud about Watergate as a way to supplant President Ford in the IWhite House. But his fellow Democrats still choose to kick Richard Nixon around to get at his successor.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4

title: Opera: A Dark Siegfried in Munich
description: MUNICH, Germany, July 14As in so many contemporary productions of Wagner's Ring cycle, the current staging by Gnther Rennert for the Munich Festival is predominantly dark. One leaves the theater with eyestrain after three and a half or more hours of trying to puncture the prevailing gloom.

title: Electronics Sector Back in the Black
description: Net income of the RCA Corporation doubled in the second quarter to the highest level for the period in the 57year history of the company, Anthony L. Conrad, chairman and president anounced yesterday.

title: New York City Making Point as Host to Parley
description: What is the motive behind the relentless hopitality that New York City has been pressing upon the guests to the Democratic National Convention?

title: Nonprofit Theaters to Get Ford Aid for New Plays
description: The Ford Foundation will underwrite a threeyear program beginning Oct. 1 for the presentation of new American plays by nonprofit theaters. In the first year, the foundation will allocate $600,000 to provide theater companies with up to $7,500 or 5 percent of total operating expenses, whichever is less, to cover a portion of expenses for works that have received not more than one previous professional production.

title: CHANGE OF GUARD AT CONVENTION
description: The Democrats have broken at least one recent convention tradition by replacing the grim private security guards who sternly policed the aisles in 1968 and 1972 with a group of young volunteers who try to clear the aisles with kindness.

title: DANIEL U. HANRAHAN
description: Msgr. Daniel U. Hanrahan, pastor emeritus of Sacred Heart Church in Cambria (Heights, Queens, died Tuesday at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: CANDIDATE SILENT
description: Jimmy Caror indicated yesterday that he had chosen a running mate, but he took elaborate precautions to shield the name from disclosure before he formally announces his choice today.

title: Sets Easily Triumph Over Friars
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 14  Tile New York Sets beat the San Diego Friars, 3026, in a World Team Tennis match beore 3,569 in the Nassau Coliseum tonight by winning four of the five events.

title: Film to Trace Carter Candidacy From Its Start to Its Triumph
description: Before Jimmy Carter strides to the podium tonight at the Democratic National Convention to accept the Presidential nomination, Madison Square Garden will be darkened and a 15minute film will be shown, tracing his candidacy from its unlikely beginnings last year to its triumph here.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service said today oil companies would have to pay royalties to foreign governments before taking a credit for foreign taxes against United States income taxes.

title: DAVID BURTON LEVIN
description: David Burton Levin, a certified public accountant with an office at 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, died Tuesday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L. I., after having been taken ill while riding a bicycle. Mr. Levin, who lived at 793 Cornell Road, Franklin Square, L. I., was 45 years old.

title: The Mailpox
description: Through the Camellia vines at my study window I watch my wife go down the drive for the mail. She carries a broom. In recent years we have had problems with dogs. Recent years have been very good for problems I see that my neighbor has left her kitchen light burning. That is a signal for me to keep an eye on her house. Her dog barks at my wife but is overjoyed at the sight of thieves.

title: Quake on Bali. Levels Town, Kills at Least 50
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, July 15 (AP)  An earthquake leveled a town on the island of Bali yesterday, killing more than 50 people and injuring hundreds, Indonesian authorities and newspapers reported today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Through an editing error, an article in The Times yesterday reported the average salary of welfare mothers who work as $149.12 a week. The average earning was $149.12 a month during March for the 16,074 welfare families with jobs.

title: Union Rooted in Social Struggle
description: If there is no struggle, there can be no progress, reads an inscription on the facade of District 1199's building at 310 West 43d Street.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results; (OTB payoffs subject to 5% Srate tax)

title: Music: Cologne Visitors
description: Sometimes it is difficult to gauge the worth of a touring orchestra and its conductor at first hearing. simply because the pieces they bring on tour have been rehearsed and polished for many hours to make the best possible impression. If. for instance, one had come in near the end of Tuesday night's Mostly Mozart concert at Alice Tully Hall. when Helmut MilllerBriihl was leading his youthful Cologne Chamber Orchestra in Haydn's Symphony No. 44 in E minor. the impression gained would have been almost entirely positive.

title: ENNIS OLGIATI, 46, LED PAROLE UNIT
description: Ennis J. Olgiati, chairman of the New York State Board of Parole, died of cancer yesterday at his home at 135 West 10th Street. He was 46 years old.

title: Service Groups in Dispute On World Food Problems
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) Two of the nation's most respected service organizations are publicly quarreling over how the United States should respond to the world hunger crisis. Involved are the Environmental Fund, one of the nation's leading ecology and population  control organizations, and Bread for the World, a Christian citizens organization aimed at mobilizing public opinion toward ending hunger.

title: Excerpts From Rodino Talk for Carter
description: It is with a deeply felt sense of humility and pride that I stand before you tonight to place in nomination the name of the next President of the United States, Gov. Jimmy Carter.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany July 14. (Reuters)The State of Pennsylvania and Volkswagen have signed a provisional agreement for Volkswagen to establish an assembly plant in New Stanton, the company announced tod ay.

title: The Vote by Delegations
description: Following is a tabulation of how delegates voted on the first Presidential nominating ballot last night at the Democratic National Convenion. These were figures at the end of the rollcall, before the traditional switches.

title: Two of Four Flu Vaccines Held Unacceptable for Military Use
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Advisers to the Army. Navy and Air Force have concluded the swine influenza vaccine made by two of the four manufacturers is unacceptable for the 2.1 million active duty military employees.

title: Judge Troubled by Special Prosecutor's Actions in Justice Brust Perjury Case
description: Justice Leonard H. Sandler of New York State Supreme Court said yesterday that he had difficulties with the evidence that led to the indictment of Justice Joseph A. Brust of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, who was charged last February with lying to a grand jury.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEMPHIS, July 14 (AP)4 dispute over a $3,000 payment on a bank note threatened to put Denny McLain, former major league pitching star, out of his job as general manager of the Memphis Blues today. But after a discussion by lawyers, McLain wrote out a check, and control of the Blues was retained by a group headed by a Kansas City businessman, Jerry Bilton.

title: American Moderns Fail to Stir Tokyo
description: TOKYO, July 13  New York City's Whitney Museum of American Art is staging its first overseas exhibition here with indications that the Japanese are perhaps not quite ready to apreciate fully modern American art.

title: St. Bernards Suit ExMaior's Fancy
description: Don Coss is a retired major in the Air Force. For the last eight years of the 22 he spent in the service, Coss was engaged in earthsatellite tracking. But he now is very much down to earth in Colorado dog show circles, where he is engagd in all phases of the sport  breeding, exhibiting, iudging and club work.

title: Schools of South Africa Are Separate and Unequal
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 14Moses Pere always wanted to be one of the small hand of South African blacks who graduate from high school. But when his father died last year, his mother, a kitchen hand, could no longer afford the $50 a year it cost to keep him in primary school.

title: For Mark Cross, Old World Charm In a New Setting
description: Some years ago, a prominent Washingtonian ordered a $14,000 matched set of crocodile luggage from Mark Cross. Before the commission was completed, he asked that plastic covers be made for the cases. His request was unequivocally refused. I couldn't do it, said Edward Wasserberger. the president of Mark Cross. and stanlard bearer of taste and design. The customer settled for fabric covers, although Mr. Wasserberger still doesn't approve of any cover on beautiful luggage.

title: AFRICANS ABANDON ANTIISRAEL MOVE IN U.N.'S COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14The Security Council tonight ended four days of inconclusive debate on Israel's rescue of hijacked hostages in Uganda without condemning the Israeli raid or approving a rival resolution against hijacking and terrorism.

title: Minors Release Bryant
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 13 (AP)The Pacific Coast League Albuquerque Dukes gave Ron Bryant, a former major league pitcher, an unconditional release today. The former San Francisco Giants lefthander played in 13 games for the Dukes. a farm club for the Los Angeles Dodgers, and had a 6.89 earned run average in 492/3 innings.

title: Elaborate Hotel Setup for Carter and His Staff Is Fit for a President
description: The elevators, rewired by the hotel to ignore anyone who pushes button 21, sail past his floor. The stairwells leading there are blocked by armed guards and no one gets by them who does not have special laminated credentials around his neck. The chambermaids had to get security clearances. Every guest, big or small, must sign in and out at a table near the stairs and he escorted even to staff rooms by an accredited official.

title: City University Dropping Tenured Staff Members
description: After a frenzied year of attempting to retrench without affecting longstanding traditions of job security for senior professors, the nine senior colleges of the City University system have begun to send dismissal notices to tenured faculty members.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURESRISE DAILY LIMIT
description: A rumor and strong soybean oil prices sent soybean futures up yesterday the daily limit of 20 cents a bushel. August delivery beans on the Chicago Board of Trade closed at $7.34 a bushel. up 20 cents.

title: Amex Market Index Rises by 0.11 Point; OT C Climbs 0.44
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange continued to move upward yesterday, with the market value index closing at 107.05, up 0.11.

title: Notes on People
description: Peter F. Kaye, press secretary for President Ford's campaign committee, confirmed yesterday that he planned to leave the job after next month's Republican National Convention in Kansas City. Mr. Kaye, in New York to observe the Democratic convention, would only describe his reasons for quitting as personal. But his departure from the staff of Rogers C. B. Morton, the Ford campaign chairman, follows a shakeup in the communications staff at the White House, where Mr. Kaye's candor with the press has not always been applauded.

title: The Man Who Refused to Lose
description: I don't intend to lose, he said. He said it again and again, in Honolulu and Hastings and Des Moines and Detroit and Fairbanks and Philadelphia, in bowling allies and allnight cafes and supermarkets and motel lobbies and middleclass living rooms and Park Avenue apartments.

description: NEW BRUNSWICKWhat should you do if your car breaks down on the New Jersey Turnpike?

title: KenyaUganda Border City Found Calm
description: BUSIA, Kenya, July 14This city on the Uganda border is calm but vigilant. There are no Kenyan troops in sight and market women cross the border checkpoints unchallenged by the three policemen on the Kenyan side.

title: Irish Village Troubled by Lack of Jobs, But Enjoys Rain and Tries to Stay Tidy
description: MOUNT BELLEW, Ireland, July 9Now that the carnival is over and most of the hay has been harvested, what seems to matter most here is the Tidy Town Competition.

title: The Only Way?
description: Rising tempers on the picket lines and growing tensions within affected hospitals point to serious trouble ahead unless something is done promptly to break an intolerable impasse in negotiations between District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees and the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes.

title: Law Sought for LowCost Power Needed for Life
description: NEWARK, July 14The failure yesterday of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to adopt a system of electricity rates that benefits lowincome consumers has inspired a new drive to establish the system through legislation.

title: STATE AIDES HELP AT NURSING HOMES
description: More than half of the 50 State Health Department staff members sent from Albany to monifor the care of patients in struck nursing homes in New York City wound up caring for patients and doing orderlies jobs on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Japan Bank Buys $100 Million Or More to Stem Rise of the Yen
description: TOKYO, July 14 (Reuters)The dollar fell to a 13month low against the yen today as the Bank of Japan bought between $100 million and $140 million in active trading to stem the yen's advance, dealers said today. Other sources reported central bank intervention as high as $200 million.

title: Lockhart Retires; Giant for 11 Years
description: Spider Lockhart completed his version of Only in America yesterday by retiring from the New York Giants after 11 seasons and driving off in his white Jaguar to Bache & Company, stockbrokers.

title: Dean Witter Jr., 54, Investment Banker, Is Dead in Florida
description: Dean Witter Jr., a retired investment banker, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 54 years old.

title: AFRICANS ABANDON ANTIISRAEL MOVE IN U.N.'S COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14The Security Council tonight ended four days of inconclusive debate on Israel's rescue of hijacked hostages in, Uganda without condemning the Israeli raid or approving a rival resolution against hijacking and terrorism.

title: June Trade Deficit For Britain Grew To $648 Million
description: LONDON, July 14 (UPI)Britain's trade deficit widened in June by $34.8 million to $648 the Department of Trade announced today.

title: Hanratty Injures Finger
description: LATROBE, Pa., July 14 (AP) Terry Hanratty dislocated the middle finger of his throwing hand today during the first scrimmage at the Pittsburgh Steelers preseasoze camp. Hanratty's finger was hit on a delayed snap from center. Xrays were scheduled for tomorrow to determine if the finger is broken.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Jimmy Carter of Georgia won the Democratic Presidential nomination on the first ballot. By an overwhelming margin, the convention ratified Mr. Carter's startling electoral ascendancy of the last six months, making him the first majorparty nominee from the Deep South since Zachary Taylor in 1848 and installing him as the early favorite to capture the White House in November. [Page 1, Columns 18,]

title: Strong as Ever

description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 14 (UPI)The Inter American Press Association warned today that any new communications policies drafted at the conference of the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization could undermine freedom of expression in Latin America and the Caribbean.

title: Something Happened
description: The press thrives on dispute and disorder, so the 1976 Democratic convention is not going to go down as the journalists favorite. But there is news of a kind deeper than passing headlines. Anyone who thinks nothing has happened here has forgotten what Sherlock Holmes said about the significance of the dog that did not bark in the night.

title: Common Market Unity
description: BRUSSELS, July 13It became increasingly clear at this week's meeting of the Common Market summit here that the member nations could neither solve their most urgent problems alone nor leave their weakest partners to sink or swim without unacceptable damage to themselves. Thus, West German of ficials point out that, however much Chancellor Helmut Schmidt may disdain Italy's economic mismanagement, Italy is the fourth biggest market for West Germany's exportoriented economy. A big drop in that trade would mean a loss of jobs in Germany.

description: It was the most important day in Jimmy Carter's life. As he sat and talked in his suite on the 21st floor of the Americana Hotel, the prize for which he had toiled 19 long monthsthe Democratic nomination for President of the United States  lay only 12 hours ahead.

description: Jimmy Carter indicated yesterday that he had chosen a running mate, but he took elaborate precautions to shield the name from disclosure before he formally announces his choice today.

description: Rohr Industries, San Diego. Calif.. said yesterday it had obtained an agreement with its lending institutions under which the creditors received virtually all of the company's assets as collateral for outstanding loans. The assets assigned amount to $140 million in loans and exeluded inventories.

description: MOSCOW, July 14The Soviet press has reported with approval Canada's refusal to allow athletes from Taiwan to compete in the Olympics as representatives of the Republic of China.

title: Strike at Private Hospitals in 2d Week
description: The strike against 33 private nonprofit hospitals entered its second week yesterday with no progress reported in settling the dispute, and District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees began stepping up pressure against the struck hospitals.

title: Pate in Field for $300,000 Westchester Classic Today
description: HARRISON, N.Y., July 14 Jerry Pate's first Professional Golfers Association tournament as a pro was the 1975 Westchester Classic. Although he was the 1974 United States amateur champion, fans were asking. Who's he?

description: Following are excerpts from some of the major addresses delivered at the Democratic National Convention this week:

title: Unseeded Pohmann Topples Ashe in Austria, 64, 63
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, July 14 (UPI) Unseeded Hans Jurgen Pohmann of West Germany defeated topseeded Arthur Ashe of the United States, 64, 63, today in the biggest upset so far of the Kitzbuehel tennis tournament.

title: Democrats Meet Designers and Get High Marks for Style
description: It's been a week of surprises all around. Democratic conventioneers are pleasantly impressed with the city (one delegate even said that the city was clean), while fashion watchers call this the bestdressed convention in years.

title: Westinghouse Net Gains 31% for Second Quarter
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second largest manufacturer of electrical eauipment (after General Electric) reported profit increases of 31 percent for the second quarter and 36.3 percent for the first half. The earnings and sales in both periods were records.

title: Ballet: Potential of Yoko Morishita
description: The Japanese dancer Yoko Morishita might be regarded as something of a problem ballerina. She is awfully good, but, at the same time, awfully ordinary. Her talents are unquestionable. Her physique is not perfecta slightly short torsobut, in fact, most of the world's greatest dancers have started with physical deficiencies. Her style is virtually impeccable, allowing for a certain discrepancy in her line. She has all the makings of a major ballerina.

title: Uruguay Appoints A New President For 5Year Term
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 14 (AP)Uruguay's conservative Council of the Nation today named Aparicio Mendez, a 72yearold lawyer, to be the country's new President.

title: 27,892 See Cosmos Top Rowdies, 54
description: The New York Cosmos defeated the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 54, at Yankee Stadium last night before 27,892 fans who created an atmosphere of bigtime soccer.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FAST DRAW When the exhibition called A Cartoon History of United States Foreign Policy: 17761976 first opened here briefly last December, The New York Times noted that once upon a time, a firstrate political cartoonist could be one of the most powerful men in the country.

title: Unsightly 'Tunnelvision'
description: "Your mother has passed away, but that's no reason to lose touch," says the television announcer in a commercial for the telephone company. At which point, we see a young man pick up a telephone, dial a number and say, "Hello, mother? What's it like up there?"If this sketch strikes you as being even dimly amusing, then you might want to see "Tunnelvision," which opened yesterday at theaters around the city. If it doesn't, stay away. The sketch is an accurate indicator of the level of humor of this very wan revue that pretends to give us a sampling of TV programming in 1985. The prediction: it will be just like today's though not as piously, innocently funny.It's junk like "Tunnelvision" that make one appreciate the mad inspirations of Alan Abel ("Is There Sex After Death?"), the master of a kind of humor often labeled "undergraduate," though its irreverence and fondness for terrible gags can be as liberating as any other kind of humor. There is one catch, however. When undergraduate humor fails, as it does in "Tunnelvision," it doesn't die alone, it threatens to take you with it.

title: ISRAELIS DOUBLING LONGRANGE FLEET
description: Israel is to add six missile boats to its navy, doubling the size of its longdistance combat fleet, according to authoritative sources.

description: Herbert Cohen has been named president of Arno Press, it was announced yesterday by Sydney Gruson. executive vice president of The New York Times Cornpany.

description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14Loud but only minimal opposition emerged today as baseball's club owners were briefed on the new fouryear agreement with their players. The owners, however, postponed a vote to approve the pact so they could have more time to study its complex terms.

title: Executives Swarm to Convention City
description: There seems to be no reason for businessmen to come to New York for the convention. Almost none are delegates, the modest fundraising permitted under the new campaign laws is largely over, and Jimmy Carter has never been particularly attractive to them anyway.

description: Even before Jimmy Carter's nomination last night, supporters of the Georgia Democrat began organizing his Presidenvial campaign in New York, a state where he ran poorly in the Presidential primary and which is usually a must state for a Democratic Presidential eandidate.

Unless the new proposal is accepted by the Canadian Government, the United States is prepared to pull its 425member team out of the Games.

description: WASHINGTQN. July 14An outside group of experts consuited by the National Cancer Institute has recommended that the agency discontinue the routine use of Xray screening for breast cancer in symptomfree women under the age of 50, according to informed sources.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A recount produced the required number of signatures to place a proposal on the November ballot to change Essex County's form of government, according to the group that proposed the change. The group, the Citizens for Charter Change in Essex County, has validated 4.617 signatures, said Jeanne Graves, Its chairman. Election officials said last year that the group had fallen 4,181 signatures short of the 56,721 (15 percent of the county's registered voters) required to put their question on the ballot last November. The group then called for a recheck of the signatures, saying officials had erred in validating them.

description: Wednesday, July 14, 1976

title: Seven ExPressmen Are Indicted Over Washington Post Damage
description: WASHINGTON, July 14A Federal grand jury indicted seven former pressmen at the Washington Post today on charges of rioting, inciting a riot, malicious destruction, theft and assault.

title: Dow Off 0.90 to 1,005.16 As Volume Shows Decline
description: The stock market churned indecisively yesterday in the area just above the 1,000 mark in the Dow Jones industrial average and closed virtually unchaneed in declining volume.

title: Details of the Private Life of Howard Hughes Will Be Disclosed in a New Book
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 14The shield that Howard R. Hughes carefully built to protect the secrecy of his private life is about to be pierced by a book based on the stories of two men who were with him for a decade before his death.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Partita No. 6 in B flat, Pachelbel; Piano Trio in G minor, Haydn; Courtly Dances from Gloriana, Britten; Flute Quartet in A, Mozart; Giselle Suite, Adam.

title: Steps Taken to Halt Taino Tower Vandals
description: The Federal hnusing agency says it is taking steps to prevent further vandalism at a $45 million East Harlem building project where the nearly completed construction has been halted because of financial problems.

title: ExG.I, a Defector to China, Will Visit U.S.
description: PEKING, July 14In the late 1940's a young man from Pennsylvania named James G. Veneris drifted from job to job and city to city. It wasn't much of a life.

title: New York Depicted by Media as Prodigal Back in Fold
description: The touch of boosterism that has infected this city since the onset of its fiscal crisis is being reported across the country this week as evidence of overdue contrition.

title: Advertising
description: One of the distinctive characteristics of Wells, Rich, Greene has been that it hired only top professionals and trained no one. It made for a lean operation.

title: SUFFOLK'S POLICE DRAFT JOB ACTION
description: Suffolk County police officers, who are the highest paid in the country have asked for a 40 percent wage increase and are now threatening job action within the next few days even though the wage issue is currently before a state arbitrator.

title: Inquiry Team Starts Breaking Into Mine Where 26 Died in Blasts
description: WHTTESBURG, Ky., July 14A mine rescue team accompanied by Federal and state mine safety officials today began breaking down the seals at the Scotia Coal Company mine where 11 men were killed in the second of two fatal methane gas explosions four months ago.

title: EARNINGS SLUMP Al 2 LARGE BANKS; Bankers Trust and Chemical Report Sharp DeclinesWells Fargo Has Rise; EARNINGS SLUMP AT 2 LARGE BANKS
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the Chemical New York Corporation reported sharp declines yesterday in secondquarter operating earnings. Other major bank holding companies around the country, including the First National Boston Corporation, the Girard Company of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia National Corporation also reported lower earnings.

title: A List of Events For Delegates
description: The following is a tentative schedule of some of today's events of interest to convention delegates.

title: Philadelphia to Press A Drive for Tourists
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP)This city, where predictions of 20 to 40 million Bicentennial tourists were made last winter, has decided to begin a crash campaign costing $100,000 to $200,000 to encourage visitors during the rest of the summer.

title: Georgian's Surprising Triumph.
description: The history of American politics since the beginning of the last World War has been a tale of astonishing surprises. but few of them have been more startling than last night's nomination of Jimmy Carter of Georgia for the PresiWendell Willkie in 1940. Harry Truman in 1948, John Kennedy in 1960, and George McGovern in 1972 all came from behind to win their Presidential nominations, and Richard Nixon in 1968 made the greatest comeback since Lazarus, but they all had more visibility or outside support than Mr. Carter.

title: XEROX EARNINGS AND REVENUES UP
description: The Xerox Corporation, the leader in the copier industry, reported yesterday a 4 percent rise in secondquarter earnings from the yearearlier level on a 6 2 percent increase revenues.

title: David Graham Shares Lead With White at 63
description: HARRISON, N.Y., July 15  Following a script that is 10 years old now, a field of 167 golf professionals shot the lights out today in the opening round of the Westchester Classic. As so often happens on the first day of golf tournaments, the firstday leaders included a rookie little known beyond his family and neighbors, who is tied with an established player.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts; 1976, by Trtangle Publication. Inc. (The Daily Racine Form) Thursday, July 15. 14th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Kawaida Towers Given a Quiet Burial
description: NEWARK, July 15Kawaida Towers, the housing project once visualized by its black sponsors as the centerpiece for lowand middleincome people in the predominantly white North Ward here, and which became instead an object of sevete racial antagonism, was buried quietly today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Jimmy Carter picked Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota as his running mate yesterday and delegates to the Democratic National Convention jubilantly endorsed the VicePresidential nominee at the closing session last night. Then the Presidential nominee, in his acceptance speech, promised that 1976 would not be a year of politics as usual, but a year of quiet and sober reassessment of out nation's character and purpose of inspiration and hope. Mr. Mondale brought the delegates to their feet when he denounced President Ford as a President who pardoned the person responsible for the worst political scandal in American history.

title: Excerpts From Carter's News Conference Presenting Mondale as Choice for Vice President
description: I haveI have two announcements to make. One is that I've decided to accept the nomination of President. And the other one is that I've asked to serve as my running mateif the delegates will approveSenator Walter Mondale from Minnesota.

description: Incoming

description: (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Liberals in Connecticut Are Seeking New Role
description: Even before the last of the speeches had trailed away at the Democratic National Convention last night, the activist liberals in the Connecticut delegation were pondering an apparent new role for themselves on the fringes of the Democratic establishment in the state.

title: Libyans Arm and Train World Terrorists
description: LONDON, July 15A broad terrorist network, stretching from the Middle East to Africa and Europe, is being trained, armed and financed by Libya's leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, according to diplomats in Europe, the Middle East and the United States. This zealous adventure, starting early in the 1970's, is said to be designed to unite Arab countries into a radical Islamic union.

title: Pennsylvania Visit Fails To Add Votes for Reagan
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 15Ronald Reagan had five sure Pennsylvania delegates when he arrived here this morning. Eight hours later, after meeting most of Pennsylvania's 103 delegates to the Republican National Convention, in small groups and en masse, Mr. Reagan still had five sure votes here.

title: FOUNDATION AWARDS JOURNALISM GRANTS
description: The ScrippsHoward Foundation will provide scholarships and cash grants valued at more than $180,000 to undergraduates and graduates in the field of journalism as well as to universities and colleges.

title: NatureWalking on Fire Island
description: Last Friday, Anthony, who is seven years old, had his usual breakfast of orange juice, Front Loops and milk. Last Saturday, Anthony had sheep's sorrel, glasswart, cattail pollen and four blueberriescourtesy of the nature walk at the Fire Island National Seashore.

title: Mondale Controlling High Blood Pressure
description: Senator Walter F. Mondale Is among an estimated 25 million Americans who have high blood pressure, or hypertension, a disorder that until recently was widely neglected as a public health problem despite the fact that its consequences are among the leading causes of death in the United States.

title: Amalrik Departs From Soviet for West, Ending More Than a Decade as Dissident
description: MOSCOW, July 15Andrei Amalrik, the dissident writer, left the Soviet Union today for exile in the West after struggling for more than a decade against Government attempts to silence him.

title: EastWest Talks to Recess
description: VIENNA, July 15 (Reuters)EastWest negotiations on force reductions in Central Europe will adjourn next week until September. it was announced today.

title: Many Used the Convention To Push for Local Goals
description: Large numbers of delegates to the Democratic National Convention paid almost no attention to Jimmy Carter this week: they were devoting themselves to the kind of polltics that interests them the mosthome style.

title: YEN UP SHARPLY 3D STRAIGHT DAY IN HECTIC TRADING
description: TOKYO, July 15For the third straight day the yen rose sharply in hectic foreignexchange trading here today despite central bank intervention to dampen it. The intervention apparently came as a result of subtle pressure put on the Japanese by President Ford at the economic summit conference in Puerto Rico.

title: HAROLD C. LUMB, 66, EXSTEEL EXECUTIVE
description: CLEVELAND, July 15Harold C. Lumb, retired vice president for corporate relations and public affairs of Republic Steel Corporation, died last night in University Hospital here after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Art People
description: ANEW GIG for Larry Rivers, painter, sculptor, film maker, video artist, stage designer, panelist, lecturer, showman and saxophonist, has been provided by a very official body, the Soviet Artists Union. At its request, he will visit the Soviet Union for 10 days in September to meet with Soviet artists, give lectures and slide demonstrations, and take a whirlwind tour of the Soviet cultural front.

title: At the Movies
description: STRANGE, NOT ALTOGETHER WONDROUS, things are happening on the silver screen. Banking on the public's unslakable thirst for jolts and shivers, film makers are flooding theaters with juicily detailed supernatural shockers, with weird and bloody tales of the occult, ambitious ventures and trashy potboilers that toy with possession, reincarnation, inexplicable mayhem and otherworldly menace.

title: A Former Bank Officer Is Guilty of Embezzling
description: A 35yearold former bank officer pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of a fourcount Federal charge accusing him of embezziing almost $600,000 in Manhattan.

title: For Humphrey, Politics Of No Regret, if Not Joy
description: Continued from Page B1 that the time for his generation and style of leadership might be passing.

title: A Taste of Brine on a Sailing Ship
description: The days of the sailing ships are gone now, leaving only the yearning for a glimpse of towering masts standing tall on the horizon and the feel of a solid deck underfoot. But down at the tip of Manhattan, where Fulton Street meets the water, Pioneer stilt sails five days a week.

title: Alcoa Net Is Up From '75, But Below Quarter of 74
description: PITTSBURGH, July 15The Aluminum Company of America reported today that net income in the second quarter was $42.4 million, nearly double the yearearlier $22.1 million.

title: A.B.A. Clubs Make Merger Payments
description: Four teams from the American Basketball Association paid $1 million each yesterday, meeting their first obligation for entrance into the National Basketball Association. The next payment, of $2 million each by the New York Nets, the San Antonio Spurs, the Denver Nuggets and the Indiana Pacers, is due Sept. 15. The third and final payment of $200.000 each, is due next summer.

title: Amex Declines, Index Off 0.45; OTC Climbs
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but showed a modicum of strength in the overthecounter market, ending several days of rising prices.

title: Anon Cautions Syrians On Lebanon Takeover
description: JERUSALEM, luly 15 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Yigal AIIon said today that Israel could not ignore a Syrian takeover of Lebanon.

title: Motel Man Felt Abducted Boy Had a Tall Tale of Kidnapping
description: MINEOLA, Li., July 15When a 6yearold boy who was kidnapped near his Jericho, Li., home Tuesday night and held captive for 20 hours in a Westbury motel room told the motel manager about how he had been abducted, the manager was incredulous.

description: When Walt Disney Productions reported record earnings for its third fiscal quarter yesterday, Wail Street was clearly disappointed.

title: Fluke Fishing Good in Nearby Waters
description: AREA AFluke in abundance seem to be filling the waters off the New Jersey coast. They have been averaging 3 to 4 pounds, with an occasional 7pounder, in Barnegat Inlet, south of Manasquan Inlet and off the beach at Surf City. Squid, smelt spearing and sand eels have all produced good catches.

title: Gov. Carter's Strategy
description: The Carter strategy begins to unfold. It is based on the quiet and effective moral eloquence of his acceptance speech; it is not, and never has been, primarily a religious or ideological crusade, but rather an oldfashioned struggle for powera marshaling of the Democratic conservatives of the South and the liberals of the North to restore the old Roosevelt Coalition to the White House.

title: Corporation Affairs

title: How to Get There
description: By car from New York, take the New Jersey Turnpike to New Brunswick, Exit 9. Drive west to Route 1 and then south toward Trenton. At the Princeton traffic circle on Route 1, turn right. This is the shortest route, but you can also take the turnpike to Hightstown. Exit 8 and head west.

title: Business in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGEThis is the third and final summer construction season on the $7.7 billion transAlaska pipeline, and as thousands of highpaying jobs disappear, government and business leaders have been asking themselves what lies ahead.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: On the heels of the Democratic National Convention, marathon coverage of the summer Olympics begins this weekend. Before it ends on Aug. 1, two weeks before the Republican National Convention, ABCTV will have devoted, according to current plans, 79 hours to the sports event. The overall schedule thereby begins to look like a programming monster surrounded by businessasusual fillers.

title: New York City Hospitals Move Toward Arbitration
description: The League of Voluntary Hospitals agreed in principle last night to submit the 10dayold hospital strike to binding arbitration, clearing the way for en end to the walkout today.

title: MEXICO DENIES ROLE IN EDITOR'S OUSTER
description: MEXICO CITY, July 15 President Luis Echeverria varez stated yesterday that the ouster of the editor of Excelsior last week was decided without Government intervention by a majority vote of the cooperative that owns the newspaper.

title: Management
description: The choice of Jimmy Carter the outsider bearing the message of conciliationas the Democratic Party's standard bearer parallels a trend developing in corporate management. Or so it seems to Harry Levinson, one of the country's best known corporate psychologists.

title: Poll Shows Carter Leads; Best Margin in 40 Years
description: Jimmy Carter's strong prospects of election this fall were underlined with the release of a new Gallup Poll Wednesday that showed the Georgian with the widest lead a challenger has ever held over an incumbent since the advent of scientific polling more than 40 years ago.

title: Pornography Store In Times Sq. Opens After Court Order
description: The Crossroads Bookstore, the large hardcore pornography operatiqn in Times Square, whose closing by city officials last week received wide publicity, was ordered reopened yesterday by Justice Oliver C. Sutton in State Supreme Court.

title: Restaurants
description: DIVAN, A NEW TURKISH restaurant at 338 East 49th Street, is still getting under way but already has a fan club. Regarding fan clubs, let me suggest that when the membership decides to write letters to a restaurant reviewer urging him to try a place, it is a good idea to use different papers and different typewriters and different phraseology to give the impression that each letter is individually inspired. Formulas to avoid are: I just happened to be passing by the other night and dropped into  and I hate to let the secret out, but

title: James Shocknessy Dies at 69
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15James W. Shocknessy, who was chairman of the Ohio Turnpike Commission since it was formed in 1950, died today in University Hospital here afteri minor surgery Monday. He was 69 years old.

title: Builder in Las Vegas Is Indicted For Perjury in Teamster Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15William In Daley, a Las Vegas building contractor, has been indicted for allegedly lying twice to a Federal grand jury investigating possible kickbacks and bribes in connection with a $50 million hotel project financed by the principal pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Abbey Glen Is Acquired By Genstar
description: Genstar Ltd. announced in Montreal yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Capital and Counties Property Company of London to purchase Capital and Counties 62.4 percent interest in the Abbey Glen Property Corporation of Toronto for about $49.3 million. The purchase involves 7.3 million common shares of Abbey Glen at a cash price of $6.75 a share. Following completion of the purchase, Genstar said, it will make a tender offer of $6.75 a share to minority shareholders, or in lieu of cash will exchange securities to be created. These steps are expected to take a number of months.

title: City's Churches Sing a Hymn to Architectural Variety
description: In a guidebook to New York issued in 1866, the subject of hotels was exhausted in five pages, public buildings in four. But churches filled nine pages. If some of that attention was due to a greater religious interest on the part of the average 19th. century tourist, at least as much derived from the fact that in the preskyscraper era, churches were the city's monumentsthey dominated the skyline and were the structures visitors went home talking about.

title: U ganda Reports Ouster of 2 Britons for Spying and C.I.A. Ties
description: NAIROBI, Kenya July 15 (Reuters)  Uganda announced today that it had deported two Britons, a man and a woman. who were accused of spying and were involved in activities the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

Riddick, who was made a member of Fordham University's Athletic Hall of Fame after becoming a star football player there in 1937, and later a player for the Green, Bay Packers, died Wednesday while vacationing in Hampton, N.H. Mr. Riddick, who had been ill with cancer, lived in Lowell, Mass., and was 58 years old.

description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 15 (Reuters)The Trans Mountain Pipe Line Company said it would proceed with plans to build a 750mile oil pipeline from Kitimat, British Columbia, to Edmonton, Alberta, to carry oil from Prudhoe Bay, Alaska to Midwest United States oil refineries. title: And the Cloisters Offers Echoes of the Medieval Past
description: The great churches of Europe gently remind tourists that they are, after all, houses of worship. The Cloisters must, on occasion, gently remind tourists that it is not a house of worship, but a museum. The reliquaries no longer contain saintly relics, the tombs are empty, the altan no longer sanctified. But sometimes, a visitor prays.

description: MONTREAL, July 15  Uncertainty over the staging of the Olympic Games ended tonight when both the International Olympic Committee and the United States approved a compromise final offer by Canada that would allow Taiwan to take part with its own flag and anthem.
