title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: In the early 1700's, John Peter Zenger, a printer, published a newspaper that frequently got under the skin of the Colonial authorities, and he was haled into court for telling the truth. The case established new concepts of freedom of the press and has been hallowed incident ever since. Now a short play, The Case and Tryall of John Peter Zenger, is being enacted to standup audiences in the Rotunda of Federal Hall, at the corner of Wall and Nassau Streets, the spot where George Washington was sworn in as our first President. It's in costume, with a cast of about half a dozen, and a minimum of props. The work involves the spectators as members of the jury. Private funds and a contribution from Germany (whence Zenger came to America) make it possible. Admission is free. Showtlmes today, 11:45 A.M., 12:45, 1:45. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1, 2 and 3 P.M. Information: 2648711.

title: Old Chiefs Fade Away
description: Though deprived of suspense and drama, the Democratic National Convention managed this week to stage a rare political pageant, somberly enacting the passage of power to a new and hybrid breed. With palpable emotion, from sentimental tribute to respectful pity, the Democrats retired from Presidential politics a whole generation of their most sprited warriors. With no apparent fear of the memories of conflict and defeat thus evoked, they let these warriors parade across the television screens to speak their lines in The Taming of the Clan and to give testimony that Jimmy Carter had inherited some genetic strain from each of them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Jimmy Carter picked Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota as his running mate yesterday and delegates to the Democratic National Convention jubilantly endorsed the VicePresidential nominee at the closing session last night. Then the Presidential nominee, in his acceptance speech, promised that 1976 would not be a year of politics as usual, but a year of quiet and sober reassessment of our nation's character and purpose of inspiration and hope. Mr. Mondale brought the delegates to their feet when he denounced President Ford as a President who pardoned the person responsible for the worst political scandal in American history. [Page A1, Column 8.]

title: Italians Say Kidnapping Was Fraud
description: ROME, July 15When a 35yearold builder was kidnapped two months ago, his friends and relatives expressed some surprise. We never thought he was very rich, said a neighbor.

title: Pop Life
description: JEFF BECK'S new record, Wired, is good in itself so good, that its excellence alone might be worthy of comment. This is, at its best, as convincing a jazzrock record as has come along in quite some time. Especially since the jazzrock wave had seemed to be ebbing of late, with much of the vitality in long, extended instrumentals taken over by rock bands (the Allman Brothers, the Grateful Dead) and even, in a far more formalized way, by disco ensembles.

title: New Figures Show Climb in Welfare Costs Is Slowing
description: The long and steep rise in welfare cases in New Jersey over the last decade has been checked, according to state figures just released that cover recent months.

title: Democrats Add to Rise in Visitors to Exchange
description: The ripples from the thousands of convention delegates and assorted hangerson swirling around Madison Square Garden have reached even to Wall Street where the New York Stock Exchange reports that attendance at its visitors center has jumped.

title: BIG BANKS REPORT DECLINING PROFITS IN SECOND PERIOD
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Corporation, Marine Midland Banks Inc, and the Charter New York Corporation, which rank among the nation's largest bank holding companies, reported yesterday that their earnings had declined in the second quarter.

title: The Presidency
description: In the wake of the Nixon Presidency, the American people have taken a renewed and serious interest in the personal makeup of Presidential candidates. A healthy President must he capable of earning the trust of the American people. He can do so only if he tells the truth, obeys the law, and respects the American public and their right to an accounting of his leadershin. Such a President will reject what some have called the paranoid school of American politics, and under such leadership the chances of another Watergate should diminish.

title: Schmidt OpensVisit To U.S. by Warning Against Troop Cut
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that any reduction by the United States of troop strength in West Germany without consultations would have a catastrophic impact on world equilibrium.

title: Man Kills Himself in Bar
description: ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP)A gunman held several persons hostage in a tiny bar near downtown St. Louis before shooting himself to death last night, according to the police. They said the man was Gregory Moore, 24 years old, of north St. Louis. For three hours the police and two clergymen had tried to persuade him to surrender.

title: Don't Wait Till 2028
description: Any comparison between the Democratic conventions of 1924 and 1976 must prove upsetting to professional pessimists specializing in the Decline of the West in general and New York in particular. On that last occasion when a Presidential nominee was chosen in this city, it took 103 ballots to produce the man whohowever distinguished he wascouldn't beat Calvin Coolidge. This time it took one ballot to name a candidate with an excellent chance to beat Mr. Coolidge's political descendant.

title: Change of Tishman From a Corporation To Partnership Set
description: The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, one of the nation's major real estate concerns, is planning to liquidate its corporation and convert it to a partnership.

title: Early Americana in Hamptons
description: The artistic policy at the John Drew Theater is as changeable as the weather in East Hampton. This weekend, theatrically speaking, the sun is shining.

title: City U.'s Plan to Discharge the Tenured Is Assessed
description: Colleges and universities across the country will feel the tremors if the City University follows through with its contemplated dismissal of dozens of tenured faculty members. Until now, with rare exceptions, the nation's tenured professors, whose jobs are virtually guaranteed for life, has escaped wholesale dismissals as institutions I of higher education adjusted to the economic realities of standstill budgets and dwindling enrollments.

title: Earthquake on Bali Kills At Least 233, Hurts 2,300
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 15 (AP)An earthquake on the island of Bali has killed at least 223 people and injured 2,300, officials said today.

title: Bridge:
description: The Fun City championships, the second of New York's three annual regional tournaments, begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

description: Article 1  No Title

description: Following is a tabulation of how delegates voted on the first VicePresidential nominating ballot last night at the Democratic National Convention. These were figures at the end of the rollcall, before switches.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Nineyearold Eddy likes to talk about last summer's vacation in Franconia Notch. N.H., when he climbed to the top of a mountain with his parents, Carl and Rachel Rossow, and several of his brothers and sisters. The climb end the recounting of the adventure are both major feats for the gutsy young boy who was born with a condition known as aglossia adactylia, which translates loosely as an absence of tongue and extremities.

title: A HardNosed Dreamer
description: He is an unusual politician: a liberal dreamer who is always in search of compromise; a hardnosed investigator who shuns publicity; an open, friendly man who finds it impossible to hold a plastic smile and difficult to slap a back; an effective Senator with a broad range of legislative achievements who detests buttonholing and cajoling colleagues.

title: World Team Tennis
description: New York 30, San Diego 26.

title: The Labor Scene COLAA Vital Ingredient in 76 Contracts
description: At the collective bargaining table COLA is not a soft drink that union and industry negotiators turn to when they tire of black coffee. It is the most arguedover element in 1976's heavy round of contract talks, and nowhere more so than in the deadlock that has stretched the strike in the Big Four rubber companies into a threemonth siege.

title: A JUBILANT PARTY
description: Jimmy Carter picked Senator Walter F. Mondale as his running mate yesterday, and delegates to the Democratic National Convention jubilantly endorsed the Minnesotan last night.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Statdium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: Uganda Rescue Gives Big Boost to Rabin
description: JERUSALEM, July 15When Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin walked into an Israeli Philharmonic concert in Tel Aviv the day after the Uganda rescue, the entire audience of nearly 3,000 people rose to give him the most spontaneous, exuberant ovation he has heard in many months.

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, July 15The United States took its quarrel with the European Economic Community's measures that damage American exports of soybean products a step further today by calling for a formal examination of its complaint by independent experts.

title: Business Trends
description: The metals industry. one of the hardest hit in the recent recession, is now one of the leaders in the comeback.

title: Dr. Joseph Kott Is Dead, 78; Led the Israeli Red Cross
description: Dr. Joseph Kott, president of Israei's Red Cross, died, in Tel Aviv on Wednesday, He was 78 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: To have a reason to get up in the morning, it is necessary to possess a guiding principle. A belief of some kind. A bumper sticker, if you will. So read the opening three sentences of Judith Guest's quiet but intensely felt first novel, Ordinary Peopleabout a young man recovering from a nervous breakdown. They are typical of the way Mrs. Guest scales down the experience of madness and makes it seem of a piece with the familiar strains of quotidian living. To be crazy is not necessarily to writhe in snake pits or converse with imaginary gods. It can sometimes be not knowing what to do in the morning. Too many details crowd [his] mind. Brush his teeth first? Wash his face? What pants should he wear? What shirt? The small seed of despair cracks open and sends experimental tendrils upward to the fragile skin of calm holding him together. To be crazy is something that happens to the order of things. And to ordinary people. It is something that has happened to Conrad Jarrett, the 17yearold son of an affluent Midwestern tax attorney and his efficient BetterHomesandGardens wife. True, Conrad has had his share of pits and savage gods. Eight months before the opening of Ordinary People, he has attempted suicide by literally attacking himself with a razor blade, and he has spent the interim confined in a mental institution. But all that is past, the stuff of nightmares. What Mrs. Guest's novel focuses on is Conrad's attempts to knit himself back into the fabric of suburban middleAmerican life. And to judge from what Conrad goes through in the process, we might as well all of us have been mad at once time or another.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: Nearby Golf Results

title: Broadway
description: ARTHUR KOPIT has written a new play, Secrets of the Rich, which will have its premiere not in one of the usual tryout cities, or in a summer theater or even in what is ordinarily considered Ofi or Off Off Broadway. Instead, Secrets of the Rich will be done in workshop form at the O'Neill Theater Center in Wallingford, Conn., as part of what the center calls its National Playwrights Conference. The conference begins Sunday and runs through Aug. 14.

title: US., Canada: Diplomatic Rift
description: MONTREAL, July 15Differences between Canada and the United States over the disputed position of Taiwan in the Olympic Games have added a corrosive element to the relations between Ottawa and Washington, relations that are normally polite even in disagreement.

title: Sayers Takes Post At Southern Illinois
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., July 15 (UPI)  Gale Sayers, a 33yearold former running back with the Chicago Bears, was named athletic director at Southern Illinois University today.

title: ExPost Pressmen Decry Indictment
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Spokesmen for the newspaper pressmen's union in Washington today accused the United States Attorney's office here of joining with the management of The Washington Post in a union busting attack by bringing a felony indictment against seven former Post pressmen for damage to the paper printing equipment.

title: For Children
description: A PARK LOVER'S GUIDE, to the 842 acre playground and nature preserve, Identifies 150 major features in the Park, Including where to find ponr cart rides, the carousel ride and the children's zoo, and also lists 21 named gates. It is free. The tors color. 8 by 24 rich mar, mar be obtained from Central Park Commentry Fund, 1775 Broadway, N.V. 10019. Or call 2471631.

title: Jamaica's Emergency Rule Reduces Political Violence
description: KINGSTON, JamaicaStringent emergency rule by the leftist Government here has kept the peace between violent political factions for a month now, but disorders still threaten this Caribbean island 90 miles south of Cuba.

title: Smith, Stockton Win
description: CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) Stan Smith and Dick Stockton advanced to the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Western tennis championships today.

title: Amy, a Glenn Supporter, Cheers Up in Zoo Visit
description: Amy Carter, who cried when she learned that her father had not chosen Senator John Glenn of Ohio as his running mate, quickly recovered her good spirits yesterday on a tour of the Central Park Zoo.

title: Yonkers Education Board Chief Retreats on School Reopenings
description: YONKERS, July 15  The president of the Board of Education retreated today from an earlier unofficial decision to use extra funds to reopen three Yonkers elementary schools.

title: Commodity Price Index Up From WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 219.3 from 215.6 last week.

title: Brownstone Renewal Creates Dispute
description: A longsimmering dispute over the housing opportunities to be given poor and middleincome people in the West Side Urban Renewal Area flared, again yesterday during a drawing held by New York City in connection with the sale of 13 brownstones.

title: About Real Estate
description: Across the street in one direction stands the dignified quarters of Lehman Brothers, the investment banking house. At a diagonal the elegant brownstone housing India House, once the Hanover Bank, gracefully presides over Hanover Square.

title: Democratic Unity Reflects Changes in South
description: As joyful Carter Geiegates swirled about the convention floor, Aaron Henry, the aging black. veteran of the worst of Mississippi's civil rights battles, threw an arm around the neck of the smiling white man at his side and hugged him.

title: The Vote for Carter
description: Following is a tabulation of how delegates voted on the first Presidential nominating ballot Wednesday night at the Democratic National Convention. These were figures at the end of the rollcall, before the traditional switchies.

title: Roland H. Coleman Dead at 67; Retired. Head of Remington Arms
description: Roland H. Coleman, retired president and general manager of the Remington Arms Company of Bridgeport. Conn., died yesterday at Bridgeport Hospital. He was 67 years old and a resident of Fairfield.

title: Notes on People
description: Pat Nixon walked on her own yesterday, for the first time since her stroke on July 7, and her physical therapist said the steps were a most significant sign of improvement for the wife of the former President. A spokesman for Long Beach Memorial Hospital said Mrs. Nixon could be released from the hospital as early as Monday but more likely would stay longer, depending on her response to her two 20minute therapy periods each day.

description: NEW YORK (AP)Morey rates for Thurs. day.

title: Youth Seized by Harrises Denies He Felt Kidnapped
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15An affable college student, held captive by William and Emily Harris and Patricia Hearst in their flight from the police more than two years ago, described his captors today as awfully nice and said he never felt he had been kidnapped by them.

title: CARTER STAFF TOLD OF CITY U. PROBLEMS
description: Two of Jimmy Carter's campaign aides met yesterday at the Americana Hotel with student and faculty representatives from the City University to discuss the university's problems and those of higher education in general.

title: How to Get There
description: Windows on the World is situated on the top floor of the north tower of the World Trade Center, which is No. 1 World Trade Center. It is accessible by taxi to the West Street entrance, and by subway  the IRT West Side local to Cortlandt Street, the IND AA or E train to Chambers Street. Once there, follow signs to No. 1 World Trade Center and specially marked express elevators. The ride up is almost worth the trip.

description: Jimmy Carter picked Senafor Walter F, Mondale as running mate yesterday, and delegates to the Democratic National Convention jubilantly endorsed the Minnesotan last night. Then the Presidential normnee, in his acceptance speech, promised that 1976 would not be a year of politics as usual but a year of quiet and sober reassessment of our nation's character and purpose, of inspiration and hope.

description: Contract No. 2

title: Connecticut G.O.P. Selects Candidates In Congress Races
description: Connecticut Republicans selected nominees for the November Congressional elections in district conventions last night, United Press International reported.

title: RUNG BY COURT BACKS SPORTSMEN
description: TRENTON, July 15The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that conservationists and environmentalists did not have an inherent right to membership on the New Jersey Fish and Game Council, which regulates aspects of hunting and fishing and which is, by statute made up entirely of sportsmen, farmers and commercial fishermen.

title: Gov. Thomson Enters Race
description: CONCORD, N.H., July (AP)Gov. Meldrim Thomson, heating the filing deadline by only seven hours, made official today his bid for a third term, promising to campaign on his record and on his strong opposiition to state sales and income taxes.

title: White Quits CBS Role To Work on New Book
description: Theodore H. White, the author, has bowed out as a consultant and guest commentator for CBSTV at the nominating conventions, to devote his time to a hook on the making of yet another President.

title: Australia Said to Bar 2 Russians as Spies
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, July 16 (UPI)A Melbourne newspaper reported today that Australia had barred entry to two Soviet diplomats who were said to work for the secret police.

title: After Op Sail and the Convention: New York Is an Encore
description: THE tall ships have cleared port, the Democrats are scattering to spread the words proclaimed in Madison Square Garden and New Yorkers have rediscovered their city and the treasures it holds for them. The big acts of summer have closed, but New York is back again, as it is every week, for encores.

title: Chess Lions and Lambs Clash
description: In a narrow woodpaneled room on the third floor of 155 East 55th Street, 16 crack chess players, including three grandmasters and three international masters, have squared off this week for what is billed as the first internationally rated chess tournament to be held in New York City in 25 years.

title: Carter Names Mondale as Running Mate
description: Jimmy Carter's acceptance speech was like Jimmy Carter's campaign: a plural effort with a singular impact.

title: How to Get There
description: Except for the bridges at the state and county parks, Fire Island is inaccessible by car, and there are no roads on the island, for driving. Nearly everyone takes the Long Island Rail Road and then a ferry across the bay. Sailor's Haven is served by the ferry terminal in Sayville, L.I.; Watch Hill by the terminal at Patchogue, L.I.

title: Saratoga Mixes Nostalgia and Arts
description: There are those who think that the principal glory of Saratoga, N.Y., is its houses, and unquestionably most visitors at least notice the houses, perhaps because they cannot help it. Saratoga has a past, and it marches up and down Broadway, turns off onto Union Avenue, goes by way of Caroline Street and ends up near the lake. Saratoga's past is Italian villa, French mansard, Victorian gothic, Romanesque revival, Queen Anne and Adirondacks kitsch.

title: PPG Joins Antiknock Price Rise
description: PPG Industries announced in Pittsburgh yesterday that, following other producers, it would raise prices of lead antiknock compounds about 2.4 percent, effective Aug. 13. PPG said also that its industrial chemical department would raise prices of certain chromic and sulfur chemicals Aug. 1.

title: Yugoslav Five Wins
description: PROVIDENCE, R. J., July 15 (AP)  Drazen Dalipagic scored 21 points in leading Yugoslavia's Olympic basketball team to a 1069S victory over the Providence College AllStars last night in a tuneup for the Montreal Games.

title: A U.S. Team Links Teton Dam Collapse To Internal Erosion
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) An Interior Department investigating team said today that the Teton Dam, which collapsed June 5 in Idaho, was eaten away from within and was not destroyed by any outside cause.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is a bizarre Newspeak quality to the denunciations, in terms of asserted international law, of the Israeli rescue of hijacked passengers from the Entebbe airport in Uganda on July 4.

title: New York City Hospitals Move T oward Arbitration
description: The League of Voluntary Hospitals agreed in principle last night to submit the 10dayold hospital strike to binding arbitration, clearing the way for an end to the walkout today.

title: Rhetoric of Democrats in 1976 Leans Heavily on Unity and God
description: Thanks to the Democratic National Convention, there is now material for a new edition of the political manual of cant.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Hudson Shad Fishing To Continue in Spring
description: New York State's Conservation Commissioner, Peter A.A. Berle, said yesterday that in all likelihood commercial shad fishing would continue to be permitted in the Hudson River next spring. mayed by the lack of definitive data on sturgeon.

title: Odometer Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) A Bill strengthening the laws against tampering with motor vehicle odometers, which register mileage, was signed today by President Ford. It sets a maximum civil penalty for tampering with an odometer of $1,000 a violation.

title: Drifting Arctic Station Planned To Study Ice Ages and Climate
description: Plans are in preparation to allow an aging Coast Guard icebreaker to become frozen into the Arctic ice pack north of Siberia and be carried by drift past the North Pole toward the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Merck Posts a 14.5% Rise For Profit in 2d Quarter
description: Merck & Company, one of the world's largest ethical drug houses, reported yesterday a 14.5 percent increase in second quarter net income to a record $72 million, or 95 cents a share, on a sales gain of 8 percent to $409.6 million.

title: Red Smith
description: MONTREAL, July 15Gutless is the word for the International Olympic Committeeor was, until today. Then, to the surprise of scholars who have made a study of the breed, the worms showed signs of turning. Although their leader, Lord Killanin of Ireland, had not dared to call the bluff of the Canadian Government, the playground directors assembled here from other lands proved less willing than he to run out on their friends from Taiwan. The 67 members of the I.O.C. were in a daylong meeting, still insisting that the Taiwanese be given at least token recognition as participants in the XXI Olympics under the banner of the Republic of China, the name by which they are accredited. Their tardy display of firmness has begun to show results, for late this afternoon Canada's Prime Minister, Pierre Elliot Trudeau, backed away from his earlier position. Although he was still refusing to let Taiwan into the Games as the Republic of China, he did agree that all her representatives could compete under the flag of their choice and, if they should win anything, have their national anthem played at the victory ceremony.

title: FOUR ARE INDICTED IN BOSTON BLASTS
description: BOSTON, July 15  Grand juries here and in Portland, Me., have indicted four men said to be linked to a radical prison reform terrorists group in connection with the bombing of an Eastern Airlines jet, two National Guard trucks and a suburban courthouse here on the beginning of the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Joan Mondale: Advocate of DayCare and the Arts
description: On Wednesday, Joan Adams Mondale had some time to do what she likes best, and went to the Whitney Museum. Yesterday, no longer just the wife of one of Minnesota's two Senators, she made her first appearance at a new level of celebrity, a tandem press conference with Rosalynn Carter.

title: Democratic WinnerTakeAll Primaries Abolished Despite Opposition by Carter
description: Delegates at the Democratic National Convention voted yesterday to abolish winnertakerall primaries in which a Presidential Candidate who carries a Congressional district receives all its delegates instead of a share proportional to his vote.

title: Libya Presses P.L.O. to Talk With Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon July 15Libya is putting heavy pressure on. the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization to enter into negotiations with Syria in an effort to stop the war in Lebanon.

title: Delays Delayed Session
description: Democrats usually offer all kinds of excuses for why the opening of the day's convention of the day's convention session is delayed. Yesterday, according to United Press International, there was one simply answer. there are no people here, a convention official said whenasked about the delay.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Justice Sidney H. Asch in State Supreme Court ordered that bank records of the Arol Development Corporation be turned over to the city's Department of Investigation. The department had sought the records from the Chase Manhattan Bank as part of its yearold inquiry into allegations of bribery in the leasing of the Bronx Terminal Market to Arol. Justice Asch denied the contention of Arol that the bank records were protected by the right of privacy.

title: G. O. P. TO PORTRAY CARTER AS LIBERAL
description: Jimmy Carter's Republican opposition seized yesterday on his addition of Senator Walter F. Mondale to the Democratic, ticket as the basis for a clash over ideology in the election campaign.

title: Where to See Early America Alive Again
description: AT ALLAIRE, a restored village near Lakewood, NJ., that was once a thriving ironproducing town, a woman in Colonial dress appears to be bearing urgent news as she hurries across the broad lawn, away from the massive smelting furnace and toward the old carpenter shop.

title: Mrs. Young, Bower Reach 36Hole Final
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 15Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham Country Club and Mrs. Robert Young of Aspetuck Valley in Weston, Conn., advanced today to the final of the 32d Women's TriCounty golf championship at Hampshire Country Club.

title: Mexican Leader Criticized For Views on Uganda Raid
description: UNITED NATIONS N.Y., July 15The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations in a statement today criticized President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico for his country's position on Israel's rescue of hijacked hostages in Uganda.

title: Convention Challenge: Getting In
description: Ben Wattenherg, the social scientist. became a Senator for a day. John Trezevant, executive vice president of Field News Syndicate, was a podium guest. A newspaper reporter's badge read, Lieutenant Governor. as he roamed the convention floor nervously avoidint! California delegates.

title: Japan's Industrial Output Is Revised Down for May
description: TOKYO, July 15 (Reuters)The Japanese Ministry of Trade and Industry revised downward today the nation's May industrial production index to 123.9, seasonally adjusted, from the preliminary 124.0 figure. The 100 base is 1970.

description: Business Records

title: Ohl Subway Trains To Roll Once Again On Weekend Tours
description: Subway trains of yesteryear, the Transit Authority calls them, and they will roll again as Nostalgia Specials every Saturday and Sunday beginning tomorrow at 1 P.M.

title: Kawaida Towers Given a Quiet Burial
description: NEWARK, July 15Kawaida Towers, the housing, project once visualized by its black sponsors as the centerpiece for low and middleincome people in the predominantly white North Ward here, and which became instead an object of severe racial antagonism, was buried quietly today.

title: Choice Seating Arrangement
description: It is just a coincidence, decided by the luck of the draw when location assignments were made, but seated fronttoback at the Democratic National Convention the Associated Press reported, were the Georgia and Minnesota delegations, who ended up with the nominees for President and Vice President.

title: Antigua Op Sail Ship in Distress Again
description: An Antiguan schooner that came here to join Operation Sail has ended up impounded at the South Street Seaport, along with its slightly bewildered crew.

title: Palmer of Orioles Downs Angels, 4O
description: Jim Palmer, who was passed over as a member of the American League AllStar squad and made no bones about his displeasure, pitched the Baltimore Orioles to a 40 victory over the California Angels in Memorial Stadium last night.

title: SCHOOLS ARE SHUT BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 15 The South African Government, alleging attempts by agitators to provoke new violence among the 18 million blacks, announced tonight that black schools that were to reopen Tuesday would remain closed until the threat of trouble had uassed.

title: Canada Softens on Taiwan; Start of Olympics Assured
description: MONTREAL, July 15  Uncertainty over the staging of the Olympic Games ended tonight when both the International Olympic Committee and the United States approved a compromise final offer by Canada that would allow Taiwan to take part with its own flag and anthem.

title: Rohatyn to Serve on Control Board, Too
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and a key fiscal adviser to New York City, was given another powerful position yesterday as Governor Carey appointed him to serve on the state's Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Weekend Gardening
description: The lushest corner in almost any garden is that little patch of green beneath the faucet where the garden hose hangs. Try all the washers you will, water will eventually start dripping from the faucet hose connection. Looking at the dense growth of ferns, blackeyed Susans and weeds beneath my own faucet, as I was about to water the garden for the umpteenth time after six weeks of strong winds and no rain, it suddenly struck me that what my garden really needed was a whole series of leaking faucets.

title: In memoriam
description: LEVINENona, July 16th, darling Nona, rest in peace, 1 miss you so. MURRAY. WOLLANGail Stephanie. A sweet precious dauahter, Happy Birthday, lovingly remembored for the gift of the beautiful years I was fortunate in sharing with you.

title: Watching the Ponies Play Polo
description: Not many people play polo but anybody can be a polo groundskeeper.

title: HomeCare Plan for Oldsters Scored
description: The city's home attendant program providing care for homebound disabled older people was criticized yesterday as having at least in some instances made possible the ripping off of the people it was set up to help.

title: Money Supply Surges in Week; Sag in Stocks Laid to Mondale
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange melted slowly all day yesterday in moderately active dealings. A number of brokers said the market was reacting to Jimmy Carter's selection of Walter F. Mondale of Minnegota as his Democratic running mate in the Presidential election.

title: Art: Victorian India's Lure
description: THE ROMANCE of Victorian India, so familiar to us from dozens of novels and short stories, from histories and biographies and even some trashy old movies that somehow stick in the mind, is now for the first timethe subject of an absorbing photography exhibition. Called The Last Empire: Victorian Photographs of India, the show is currently on view (through Aug. 29) at the Asia House Gallery, 112 East 64th Street.

title: Garden Variety
description: Not long before Ohio clinched the Democratic Presidential nomination for Jimmy Carter, a large black man stood up in the North Carolina delegation and held up a hand painted sign that read: Robeson County for Carter.

title: U.N. Draws a Blank
description: Summoned into session on the wrong issue for the wrong purpose, the United Nations Security Council at least managed to preserve a minimum of integrity and freedom from pro forma bloc voting. After four days of swirling debate, the Council majority decided it could not stomach the fatuous palliative which Uganda's mountebank President Idi Amin demanded after Israel's success in dealing with the airline terrorists who were holed up in his main international airport.

title: G.O.P. TO PORTRAY CARTER AS LIBERAL

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: said. But let them not call themselves the Republic of China.

title: Officials Hailing Mondale as a Friend of City Aid
description: Senator Walter F. Mondale who supported all the crucial Federal legislation affecting New York City and the metropolitan area, was hailed by the region's officials yesterday as a Vice  Presidential nominee who would prove sympathetic to their problems.

title: Issues in Hospital Strike
description: PARTIESDistrict 1199, National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees representing 35,000 workers, most of whom are nonprofessionals. Thirtythree hospitals, 27 belonging to the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York. Fourteen nursing homes, including nine belonging to the league. Ten municipal hospitals that have affiliations with voluntary hospitals.

Just as quite a lot of BalletTheater energy used to be put into finding a suitable partner for Cynthia Gregory, the latest company game seems to be finding a match for Miss van Hamel.

title: Trenton Topics

And it is not fair, he told a tax symposium in Washington last night, to expect the gray belt to continue to finance the emergence of the Sunbelt by paying more than its fair share of Federal taxes.

They seem very much like a young woman who has just become engaged to the son of the richest man in town; they're sure they have a winner, but they're not vet sure they're in love.

title: Mr. Carter's Choice
description: The thought and care that went into Governor Carter's decision about a VicePresidential running mate have been justified by his final choice of Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota. Regarded by many Democrats as a shade to the right of center, Mr. Carter would have confirmed that impression had he picked a relatively conservative running mate. By choosing so devoted and unquestionable a liberal as Senator Mondale, the Democratic nominee has strongly suggested that the kind of Presidency he has in mind is in the more progressive tradition of his party.

The Coait Guard said that commercial cleanup crews were standing by in case it hits shore. A spokesman said the oil spilled from a Gulf Oil Company well yester day.

Iowa, said that he and his brother drove to New York City from Wilton, Conn., Wednesday after they they escaped unscathed from a commuter train wreck Tuesday night, according to United Press International. Mr. Myers is a delegate to the Democratic National Convention and was aboard the connecticut commuter train that smashed into the rear of another train, killing two persons and injuring 24.

title: Prices Close Lower In Credit Markets
description: Prices dosed lower in the credit markets yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported a $2.6 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended July 7. A fairly broad upturn in the Government market, for example, was blunted and prices backed down about  to  of a point. Government market participants noted that an increase in the money supply had been expected but the magnitude of the latest increase was somewhat above expectations.

title: Dance: Eleo Pomare at the Bijou
description: Eleo Pomare's most effective works all have a stormy emotional pressure arising from inner personal conflicts or dramatic confrontations. His range is narrow, but within it he has a sure hand. Of the three new dances he presented Wednesday evening at the Bijou Theater, only The Queen's Chamber drew effectively on his particular strengths. The others. Sex tet and Tetramain, moved along with an unflurried surface smoothness, more memorable for their style than their theatrical energy.

title: Spanish King Is Looming Larger
description: MADRID, July 15  The fate of the Spanish crown may be determined in the next few months, in the view of a large body of political experts who have watched King Juan Carlos suddenly begin to rule as well as reign. The King was at the center of a weeklong crisis that began when he dismissed Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro and ended lase week when he swore in a new Government under Adolfo Suarez Gonzlez.

title: SPAIN PROMISES PARTIAL AMNESTY
description: MADRID, Saturday, July 17The 10dayold Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Surdrez Gonzales promised today to amnesty political prisoners except for those convicted of violence against persons. It also promised to hold general elections by June 1977.

title: Mayor Beanie Goes to Bat For Young Brooklyn Team
description: Go get em champs, Mayor Abraham D. Beame of New York City told members of a Brooklyn teenage basebail team yesterday as he donated $10 to a fund to send them to the national championshp games.

title: British Inflation Rate Fell in June
description: LONDON, July 16 (Reuters)Britain's rate of inflation fell in June for the 10th month in succession, the Government announced today.

description: The Democratic Lett, a prominent and contentious feature of every party convention since 1964, was strangely and uncharacteristically silent at the Madison Square Garden gathering that joyfully nominated Jimmy Carter this week.

title: City to Fight Reopening of Smut Shop
description: City officials said yesterday that they would try, once again, to close the Crossroads Bookstore in Times Square by appealing to the judge who ordered it reopened Thursday after it was shut by the city as part of a crackdown on hardcore pornography.

title: Film on Black Baseball Is a 'Bingo'
description: The time is 1939. Hitler is moving into Czechoslovakia and making plans to invade Poland. A man in a contemporary newsreel amuses us by eating razor blades. The same newsreel takes us to Yankee Stadium to watch an all-star Negro baseball game.This is the preface to the genial, slapdash, high-spirited and occasionally moving comedy called "The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars and Motor Kings," about a barnstorming black baseball team in those long-ago, pre-Jackie Robinson days before the major-league ball clubs admitted black players.The film, which opened yesterday at five theaters in New York, stars Billy Dee Williams as Bingo Long, the flashiest pitcher in the entire Negro National League, and James Earl Jones as Leon Carter, the catcher with whom Bingo forms his own ball club when it becomes apparent that the owners (black) of the Negro teams are the new slave masters.For a comedy whose principal mission is to entertain, "The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars" also manages to provoke a lot of more sober, subsidiary responses that, happily, never get in the way of the show. The film was written by Hal Barwood and Matthew Robbins (who wrote "Sugarland Express"), based on a novel by William Brashler and directed by John Badham, whose earlier credits are in television. It moves in fits and starts of exposition and action, dipping into melodrama from time to time as well as into farce, as it traces the rise and fall and rise of the Bingo Long All-Stars on their travels through the Middle West and South.The team is a smashing success until the owners of the Negro National League teams put pressure on the owners of the local stadiums not to book the Bingo Long group. This forces the All-Stars to seek games with white teams, which, in turn, makes it necessary for the black barnstormers to adapt themselves to the fantasies of the predominantly white audiences.The All-Stars are required to "shine," to become clowns, in order to reassure the white audiences that they know their places. Bingo at one point pitches a game wearing a gorilla suit. At the same time, though, the black players are dazzling their audiences with extraordinary skills that laughter cannot obscure.Shining, Bingo says in effect, is simply performance, or theater, or show business. It's a mask. Where Robert Altman's "Buffalo Bill and The Indians" uses show business as a metaphor for American life, "The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars" acknowledges show business to have been one of the practical means of black survival.The large, virtually all-black cast is fine, particularly Mr. Williams, Mr. Jones and Richard Pryor, who plays a ballplayer who schemes to get into the major leagues, first as a Cuban, then as an American Indian. Ted Ross, who won a "Tony" for his performance in "The Wiz" on Broadway, is very funny as the most villainous of the ball-club owners, and Stan Shaw is winning, literally, as the Bingo Long rookie, who, at long last, breaks the color barrier in the white leagues."The Bingo Long All-Stars" has been rated PG. The film includes one razor-cutting scene, which is not funny at all, and a riotous sequence in a whorehouse, which is.

title: Rangers Halted by Holtzman
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 16  The New York Yankees and the Texas Rangers matched their June pitching acquisitions tonight at Arlington Stadium: Ken Holtzman against Bert Blyleven, respectively.

title: Mrs. Rankin Gains Shot Lead
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 16 (AP)Judy Rankin, the alltime singleseason money winner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, carded a 68 today in the raindelayed opening round of the Columbus Classic.

description: As measured by a crosssection of special interest groups, Senator Walter F. Mondale's voting record has been at times more liberal than some of his better  known liberal Senate colleagues, such as Hubert H. Humphrey and Edward M. Kenmedy.

description: Dr. Stephen A. Leslie, an obstetrician and gynecologist, died yesterday at Kennebunkport, Me., while on vacation. He was 69 years old and lived at 1150 Park Avenue.

title: General Foods Hit By F.T.C. Charge On Coffee Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today issued a complaint against the General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest seller of regular ground coffee, charging that it had attempted to monopolize the coffee market in the Eastern United States through its Maxwell House brand.

title: Jill Isles Aguilera Is Remarried
description: Jill Isles Aguilera and Keith Torrey Middleton Jr. were married yesterday afternoon at the bride's home in Southamplon, L.I., by the Rev. Ivan F. Gossoo of the United Methodist Church in Southampton.

title: You Want to Go? Go!
description: Who needs New York? Obviously a lot of businesses don't. They have been leaving the city in a way that a prominent clergyman condemned as immoral in an Easter Sunday sermon.

title: Singapore Airlines Denies Flying Hijackers to Athens
description: SINGAPORE, July 16 (Reuters)Singapore Airlines today denied that it transported proPalestinian guerrillas to Athens before they hijacked an Air France airbus to Uganda.

title: Safeway Profits Dip 2d Quarter in Row; Decline Attributed to Price Competition
description: Safeway Stores, the nation's largest supermarket chain after having nudged the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company out of first place two years ago, reported yesterday profit decreases of 26.3 percent for its second quarter and 27.1 percent for the halfyear.

title: Business Records

title: Many Angry Outbursts Threatened Negotiations
description: The two chief negotiators involved in the hospital strike put on their coats last night to announce, in backtoback news conferences that the dispute had ended.

title: SCHOOL UNITS BALK AT U.S. DATA PLEA
description: LOS ANGELES, July 16 (UPI) Five suburban school districts that were asked to turn over detailed data on personnel practices to the United States Justice Department have decided to decline the invitation.

title: Gold Down $5 in Day to $117 an Ounce; Nearly All of Big 1974 Gains Are Lost
description: LONDON, July 16Gold, in the view of a banker here, is becoming just another commodity. In only 24 hours, its price in London has dropped $5, ending the day at $117 an ounce.

title: Queen Elizabeth Will Open Olympics Amid Security and Pageantry Today
description: MONTREAL, July 16 Queen Elizabeth arrived here today to open the 21st and most expensive Olympic Games in modern history, a twoweek pageant that will begin tomorrow with lavish pomp, maximum security, international disputes and staggering cost.

title: Careless Driving Trips Up Hijackers
description: An attempt by three men to hijack a truck delivering clothes in Howard Beach, Queens, was thwarted when the men drove through a traffic stop sign. The police said that the driver and the truck, owned by Rand Cleaning Inc., had been seized by the suspects at North Conduit Avenue and 130th Street. One of the men boarded the truck and ordered the driver, John McMillan, to follow a car carrying two other men. When the car and the truck failed to stop at the stop sign at Albert Road and 95th Street, a police radio car flagged them. Two of the suspects escaped. The third man, Joseph Cusumano, 33 years old, of 1006 Autumn Avenue, was arrested.

title: 3 Sentenced in Hijacking
description: HOUSTON, July 16 (AP)A Federal judge sentenced three convicted airplane hijackers today to 100 years each in prison, and ruled that the sentences were not to run concurrently. Charles A. Tuller, 52 years old, and his sons, Bryce, 22, and Jonathan, 21, were convicted, on June 21 on air piracy and kidnapping charges. They were indicted after an Eastern Airlines ticket agent was shot to death on Oct. 29, 1972, when. a jetliner was hijacked from Houston Intercontinental Air. port and flown to Havana.

title: Laos and Burma Seen Curbing Drugs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 16 Officitals from 14 Asian and European countries who have been trying to establish new cooperative arrangements to reduce narcotics traffic were told at discussions this week that the two principal sources of Asian opium, Burma and Laos, have agreed to curb the traffic and cut back on supplies.

title: Parents of Student Slain on Subway WinLeniency for Man Who Took Part
description: A 19yearold man who took part in killing a graduate student on a crowded IRT subway train last year was placed on probation yesterday after the victim's parents asked the presiding judge not to be harsh in sentencing, him.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 16Sidney Glaser, director of the Division of Taxation, said today that more than than 6,000 people had called this week to find out about the state's new tax package, including the asyet inoperative state income tax.

title: Reagan Supporters In Connecticut Lose Ruling on Delegates
description: HARTFORDRonald Reagan supporters in Connecticut failed at the Republican State Convention here tonight to force a change in the rules for the state's delegation at the Presidential convention in Kansas City, Mo., next month, thus assuring the state's 35 votes for President Ford.

title: Fat Cat Political Aid Becomes Leaner
description: While the day of the fat cat contributor has ended, many welltodo businessmen still help bankroll political campaigns, though in a more modest fashion. Howard Stein, chairman of the Dreyfus Corporation, the big mutual fund concern.

title: MARTINE VAN HAMEL FINE IN THE RIVER
description: The River is more a collection of discrete incidents than a unified ballet, This independence of causeandeffect structuring allowed Martine van Hamel to dance both Lake and Two Cities, sections that are ordinarily quite distinct. It made no real difference to the logic of the ballet, but it did provide an additional opportunity to appreciate her smooth, voluptuous style. The work was presented by American Ballet Theater Thursday evening at the State Theater.

title: Police Precinct 110's Noted Resident: the Commissioner
description: A couple of months ago, when Capt. Donald P. Brosen was told he was to be transferred to the 110th Precinct in Elmhurst, Queens he was flattered, but worried.

title: Soothsayer Captures Dexter Cup
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 16 In a contest in which the crowd of 19,243 was kept in the dark during most of the mile trot because of a dense fog, Michael Crocco Jr.'s Soothsayer captured the $166,290 Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The son of Lindy's Pride, who scored his first 1976 victory last week at Goshn, beat Nevele Thunder, last season's top 2yearold trotter, by 5 lengths. Spedy Colonel, an Ohio campaigner, was third, a neck in Thunder's wake.

title: Town Hoped and Prayed For the Missing Children
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 16 About 50 persons of various religious beliefs gathered at the First Baptist Church early this afternoon to hear the pastor talk about Christians putting their trust in God to reach down and perform a miracle in our midst.

title: Brown Vows to Stump Widely for Carter
description: His first venture in national politics behind him, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. planned to fly back to California yesterday, promising to campaign hard for the Democratic ticket in California and elsewhere in the nation.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Treasury disclosed today the completion of an unusual deal with Saudi Arabia under which the United States Government was designated as the procurement agent for almost $50 million worth of electrical generating equipment. facturers but also was in line with the basic strategy of Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon to promote economic cooperation with the oilrich countries as an alternative to confrontation.

title: The Gray Suitcase on the Bunk
description: MONTREAL, July 16He arrived a week ago but he never completely unpacked. Some of his clothes remain in the gray suitcase that was spread open across one of the five whiteblanketed bunks in the Olympic Village room where C. K. Yang was supposed to live with four Taiwan athletes. I am here, he had said, all by myself. But today the Republic of China delegation, too proud to call itself anything but that, withdrew from the XXI Olympics that open tomorrow. Soon the athletes will upstage the politicians and that's the way the Olympics should be. But the historical and dangerous precedent of these Olympics is that the politicians of Canada, not the International Olympic Committee, established the guest list. And so tonight, or perhaps tomorrow, C. K. Yang, the winner of the Olympic silver medal in a memorable decathlon duel with Rafer Johnson at Rome in 1960 and now the Olympic coach for the Republic of China, will be closing that gray suitcase that he never completely unpacked. The room will be empty. So will the five other rooms that had been reserved for the Republic of China's athletes.

title: Theater
description: Don Appell's Lullaby had a brief run on Broadway in 1954, was revived some years later as a Play of the Week on television, and should have been laid to rest. Instead for some unfathomable reason, this hapless comedy reappeared Thursday at the Provincetown Playhouse.

title: FRANC PLUNGES 2% IN BIG 1DAY DROP
description: PARIS, July 16The French franc today gave up 2 percent of its international value in the Paris foreignexchange market, the biggest oneday drop since it was pulled out of the joint European currency float in midMarch. the selling nao necn building up all week, following assessments by experts, both inside and outside the Government, of the effects on foreign trade and inflation of the drought now plaguing French farmers. Agricultural products last year accounled for 15 percent of France's exports. Not only will farm sales be held back, but Also food prices will be higher for French housewives.

title: Use of Capital Punishment is Curtailed in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Canada, July 16 (AP)The Canadian Government today formally abolished capital punishment for all crimes except traitorous military offenses. As expected, the Senate approved the law and Governor General Jules Leger signed it immediately.

title: Fisher Named Publisher Of Wilmington. Del., Papers

title: Carter Warns Democrats To Avoid Overconfidence
description: Jimmy Carter cautioned his fellow Democrats yesterday on the perils of overconfidence, then told them he would not concede a single state to the Republicansnot even California to Ronald Reagan or Michigan to Gerald R. Ford. such an outsider that he conceded in his speech on Thursday night that he had never met a Democratic President. But he made no effort to install his own leadership team at the committee, preferring instead to reassure the party hierarchy by stressing continuity.

title: Court Upholds Dismissal Of Homosexual Airman
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell upheld today the right of the Air Force to discharge Tech. Sgt. Leonard P. NIatlovich, an acknowledged homosexual.

title: Beirut Factions Foresee More Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16The major factions in the Lebanese war say they are convinced that their basic objectives can be fulfilled only by further military battles and that political negotiations if they come, will be ineffective.

description: A 21yearold woman was found shot to death in the fifthfloor hallway of an apartment building at 2101 Creston Avenue, in the Tremont section of the Bronx. A police spokesman identified her as Anna Rivera of 2240 Grand Avenue and said she had been shot in the face. A motive for the shooting was not known. An unidentified man was shot at 103 West 127th Street shortly after 3:30 P.M. by an unknown gunman who escaped. The victim was reported in serious condition at Harlem Hospital A woman was found dead in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, and while the police were investigating the cause of her death a man walked into a station house six hours later and reportedly told them that he had strangled her during an argument. The victim. Maria Santiago, 35, lived at 2294 West Eighth Street in the Bensonhurst section, with Jose Ortiz, 30, who was arrested for homicide.

description: LONDON, July 16, (UPI)  A consortium of banks led by Bankers Trust International has arranged a $250 million Eurocurrency loan for the Bank for Foreign Trade of the Soviet Union, it was reported today.

title: Screen:Huge Creatures Roam in 'Food of the Gods'
description: On a remote island in Puget Sound, a substance that looks like pancake batter begins to ooze from the earth and not long afterward local animals and insects are growing as big as all outdoors. Chickens stand six-feet tall in their bare claws. Bees grow to the size of turkey buzzards, while rats as large as lions roam the woods, eating everything in sight, including farmers and Volkswagens.What all this has to do with ecology is never made clear, but the ads for "The Food of the Gods," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama 1 and other theaters, ask ominously, "Has nature finally rebelled?" The answer, I think, is no, but it may be putting us on. Certainly the movie is."The Food of the Gods" is a stunningly ridiculous mixture of science-fiction and horror-film clichs, and it's said to be "based on a portion of the H. G. Wells novel" which I've never read. It prattles pieties about clean environment (which would seem to be no big problem in the film's island setting), but it's devoted mostly to showing us Man in the siege of Hollywood Special Effects, though not very good ones.When the giant rats attack a farmhouse, it's a teeny-tiny miniature farmhouse, and when Marjoe Gortner, the hero of the film, meets them face to face, it's via a split screen, or dummy-rats. There's very little excitement, but quite a few laughs, all provided by the dialogue contributed by Bert I. Gordon, who wrote the screenplay and then produced and directed it. Ida Lupino and Ralph Meeker are among those he conned into appearing in it.The film has been rated PG, which may be just as well, though it gives the film credit for being scarier than it ever succeeds in being.

title: Minority Students Take A Course on Convention
description: I Elizabeth Smith had never known what politicians go through to get elected; Linda Robinson learned that delegates are more than people running about not knowing what theyare doing, and Beulah Bel intends to take the knowledge she has gathered right back to the ghetto.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 16 (Reuters)  Defense Minister James Gichuru said the Kenyan Army would crush forthwith Uganda soldiers if they moved even one inch into Kenyan territory, the official Kenya News Agency said today.

title: Offshore Atlantic Drilling Leases Set
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)The Interior Department is preparing to begin leasing offshore drilling sites off tha Atlantic coast. It will open the Eastern United States coast for oil and gas drilling for the first time.

title: Screen: Newest Disney:'Ride a Wild Pony' at the Neighborhoods
description: It isn't the message that's the trouble with "Ride a Wild Pony," the new film from the Walt Disney organization that opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters on a double bill with a revival of "101 Dalmatians." It's the medium.The messageor messages, reallyare suitable for the young audiences that can be expected to turn out for "Ride a Wild Pony": respect for the law; facing up, rather than running off.But the medium turns out to be a fundamentally uneventful and somewhat padded story, set in a small Australian community in the days between world wars, that leads up to a legal contest between a poor boy and a rich but handicapped girl over ownership of a pony.It may be to the credit of the film makers that neither of the children is sugarcoated. In fact, neither is especially likable. Some children are like that.But, as a result, it is difficult to care which of the two winds up with the pony and even more difficult to find much suspense in the film's climax. In fact, toward the end some adults might find themseves hoping the horse will declare a pox on both youngsters.Determined editing might reduce this film to a length appropriate to television, where its essential dullness might be less noticeable. Otherwise, only those youngsters afflicted with rapture at the merest glimpse of horseflesh are likely to mistake "Ride a Wild Pony" for an absorbing movie.

description: New Jersey officials are considering legal action block the Aug. 17 sale of offshore leases by the United States. The move comes after a decision by Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe to press forward with the sale of the leases for oil and naturalgas drilling on almost a million acres of underwater land off the coast of New Jersey and Delaware. A spokesman for Governor Byrne said that while no decision had been made, New Jersey could join in a lawsuit initiated by New York State that seeks to restrain the sale of leases for areas off Long Island.

description: New Jersey Briefs

title: FIRE MEDICAL AIDE RESIGNS IN PROTEST
description: Dr. Aaron M. Schwartz, who has been a medical officer for the Fire Department for 13 years, said yesterday that he had resigned because department officials had pressured physicians to send unfit firefighters back to duty rather than on sick leave.

title: Town's Residents Pray; Some Patrol With Guns,
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 16 About 50 persons of various religious beliefs gathered at the First Baptist Church early this afternoon to hear the pastor talk about Christians putting their trust in God to reach down and perform a miracle in our midst.

title: Philadelphia Mint Aide Is Under Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)The Treasury Department said today that the second highest official at the world's largest mint was under investigation for alleged conflicts of interest in dealings with private cornpanics.

title: Reds Keeping Order in a Thai Border Town
description: BETONG, ThailandThis is a town run by an arrangement.

title: Cancer Search
description: An ultrasonic system, which can perform as a television camera is expected to speed use of sound waves in the detection of human malignancies, Page 33.

title: Carter Warns Democrats To Avoid Overconfidence
description: Jimmy Carter cautioned his fellow Democrats yesterday on the perils of overconifidence, then told them he would not concede a single state to the Republicansnot even California to Ronald Reagan or Michigan to Gerald R. Ford.

title: Ford Is Pressing Drive for Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, July 16President Ford, going allout to win delegate support in his nipandtuck battle with Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination, has invited the entire New York State Republican delegation to the White House next Thursday.

title: Ireland's Catholic Church Losing Influence on How People Live
description: Catholicism is stronger here than anywhere outside the Vatican itself. Ninetyfive per cent of the Irish are baptized nembers of the Catholic Church, and 90 percent of ??? ??? Catholics go to mass at least once a week. Each town with barely more than 1.000 Inhabitants has its priest, its church, and its churchconroiled school.

title: Taiwan, Nigeria Quit Olympics; More Withdrawals Threatened
description: MONTREAL, July 16Polit icat controversy continued to surround the Olympic Games today as Taiwwan withdrew because of termlnology for the name of its team and Nigeria pulled out in a growing dispute over the participation of New Zealand.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: A statesponsored survey showed recently that the cost of eyeglasse varies by up to 300 percent without any significant difference in quality, yet retailers have not been allowed to publish or broadcast prices.

title: Lower the Bunting And Pay the Bills Convention's Over
description: The set of the Democratic National Convention  from Walter Cronkite's anchor booth to the breezy, sunny mood of Manhattan  was struck yesterday with the ambivalence of a circus not quite ready to move on.
