title: Labor and Uranium, Among Other Things, Now Cost More
description: WASHINGTONBertram Schwartz, a senior vice president of Consolidated Edison, was asked the other day if utilities could still order nuclear power plants for a fixed price. Mr. Schwartz chuckled at the naivet of the question. No, he said, those days are gone.

title: Wood, Field &Stream: Patience Pays
description: MENEMSHA, Mass.For a long time it seemed as if we were not going to find any fish for our visiting, angler, Bing McClellan of Traverse City, Mich.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your recent editorial Wrong Way on Oil, you correctly summed up the problems confronting the nation in terms of energy. We need to reduce our excessive demand for oil, increase our domestic production and accelerate the development of new energy sources. Your conclusion, however, that divestiture of the oil industry is an irrelevant or counterproductive solution is mistaken.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Continental is easily one of the best restaurants at the New uersey Shore, if not the best. It is also one of the least wellknown outside of a knowledgeable crowd of wellheeled track fans who are principal customers. In fact, the Continental gears its season precisely to that of Monmouth Park which is only a few miles away.

title: Carter Aides Doubt Changes in Campaign Strategy
description: Jimmy Carter, back home in Plains, Ga., after a successful week in New York, is determined to wage a general election campaign no different from the one that earned him. the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Detractors and Supporters Agree His Positions Are Genuine
description: Soon after Jimmy Carter picked Walter F. Mondale to be his running mate, a spokesman for President Ford remarked, Mondale is a 100 percent, bona fide liberal. To Republicans like Mr. Ford, that description is pejorative.

title: Army Buying Its New Tank: A $4.5 Billion Decision
description: WASHINGTONWith a speed that even an armadillo might find a little lumbering, the United States Army, after 13 years of lookingand spending hundreds of millions of dollarsis about to settle on a new main battle tank for the next quarter century.

title: Prison Terms of Three to Six Years Sought for Poles Accused of Riot Damage
description: WARSAW, July 17 (Reuters) The Polish state prosecutor today demanded prison terms of three to six years for workers charged with damaging state property in last month's foodprice riots, according to unofficial reports from the courtroom.

title: R & D Can Help With the ABC's
description: Basic research in education receives, proportionately, much less financial support than is given other major sectors of social concern. Only about 5 percent of all spending on education, both public and private, is devoted to research and development, compared with more than 3 percent for health and agriculture, which benefit from large Federal subsidies.

title: Enticed by Call of the Mountains, Suburban Family Goes West
description: GREAT NECK, L.I.About a year ago Brooklynborn Walter Davis began to be haunted by mountains and by the thought that, although he'd lived in a good many places, not one of them had been completely by choice. And certain. ly none of them had had mountains.

title: Sweet basil
description: It is indisputably true that a single dish can cause an upsurge of interest in one herb or spice. That is certainly the case with oregano, which was little known in this country until the pizza craze arrived after World War II. It is also true of basil, which has gained a vast following in America during the last decade, largely, in our books at least, because of the popularity of pesto genovese, that seductive sauce made with fresh basil, garlic, grated Parmesan or Pecorino cheese and nuts, generally pine nuts. Basil is, of course, one of the most delectable of all sweet herbs. We offer several recipes here for the basil that now flourishing in abundance in thousands of gardens in this country. We also offer a new version of pesto genovesethis one made with pistachio rather than pine nuts. Pine nuts or walnuts may be substituted, however.

title: Ordinary People
description: The Hollywood legend of discovering a starlet at the soda fountain is hard to match in the world of publishing. But each industry creates its own Cinderella stories. Touted as a real publishing fable, Judith Guest's first novel, Ordinary People, was an unsolicited manuscript by an unknown writer delivered, in the parlance of the trade, over the transom. The pulishers are gleeful with selfcongratulation: the first unsolicited novel to be accepted by Viking in more than ten years. Ordinary People is now a BookoftheMonth Club selection, a big money paperback, a genuine property. It all seems like publicity fluff, and slight encouragement to those thousands of aspiring novelists out there in America, except Ordinary People is a fine and sensitive novel, if small and not completely successful.

title: Maureen Trotter, Stewardess, Is Bride
description: Maureen Patricia Trotter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edward Trotter of Garden City, L. I., was married there yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to Thomas Giordano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Alfred Giordano, also of Garden City.

title: Poland vs. Cuba In Soccer Today
description: MONTREAL, July 17 (AP) Powerful Poland opens the Olympic soccer tournament tomorrow against an illprepared Cuban team, drafted into the finals to fill a lastminute gap.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Tomorrow  East Coast Corvette Owners meeting in Bensonhurst area of Brooklyn. Information: Richard Moss, phone (212) 6333205 or Joseph Di Terlizzi, phone (201)9476222.

title: ACCORD RELIEVES BONN OF PAYMENT FOR U.S. SOLDIERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The United States and West Germany announced today that they had agreed that the socalled offset arrangement by which Bonn had helped defray the costs of stationing American troops in West Germany since the late 1950's had lost its relevance and would not be continued.

title: Solved: the Mystery of the Rock Drinking Fountain
description: AS the Island has become crammed with the trappings of civilization, very little natural wonder remains unexplored. Now one of the last tiny mysteries of the East End has been totally demolished  the Legend of Jason's Rock.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Violet Weingarten, 61, Novelist And an ExNewspaper Reporter
description: Violet Weingarten, novelist, and former newspaper reporter, died yesterday of cancer at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center. She was 61 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South and in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: TV VIEW
description: Conventional television wisdom insists that live coverage is automatically good and infinitely more exciting than filmed or taped presentations. It would thus follow that marathon live coverage gaveltogavel, sunrise to midnight, openingshottoclosingbellmust be great. In the cur rent period of marathon bloat, conventional wisdom is being confronted with some refreshing skepticism. The emerging conclusion seems to be that there is no single infallible formula for covering events as disparate as July Fourth Bicentennial celebrations, political conventions or a White House dinner in honor of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Old Subway Cars Start Nostalgia Runs
description: Such is the capriciousness of New Yorkers that many of them paid $3 for a subway ride that some people complain about paying 50 cents for.

title: DJIBOUTI LEADER SAYS HE RESIGNS
description: PARIS, July 17  Ali Arif Bourhan said today that he was resigning as President of France's last African possession, the territory of Afars and Issas, strategically situated to the south of the Red Sea.

title: Chinatown Breaking Out of the Shell
description: Beyond the provincial aromas and tourist tinsel of Mott Street, Manhattan's Chinese community is looking for room to grow, occupying every piece of available property in an effort to accommodate an increasing number of businesses and a population that has more than doubled in the last decade.

title: Hospital Workers Accept Agreement on Arbitration
description: Hundreds of nonmedical workers began returning to work in New York City late yesterday afternoon as they ended their 11day strike at 57 hospitals and nursing homes by voting overwhelmingly to accept an agreement to submit their contract dispute to binding arbitration.

title: Arthur Hornblow Jr., Producer On Broadway and MovieMaker
description: Arthur Hornblow Jr., who gave up a legal career to become a Broadway producer and then one of Hollywood's preeminent movie makers for almost 40 years, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: DEMOCRATIC SLATE ASSAILED BY FORD; G.O.P UNITY URGED
description: HARTFORD, July 17President Ford made his first attack on the Democratic Presidential and VicePresidential candidates today, saying that the CarterMondale combination was a ticket which tries to be all things to all people.

title: The Train as Time Machine, Encompassing a Nation
description: Two weeks of unlimited train travel for $150. The prospect of such a bargain warmed the cockles of my heart. Plus which, I owed my collegegraduate son a longpromised crosscountry expedition. Plus which, as a onetime rail huff forced to take to jets for his business travel, I was curious to see how the realities of Amtrak, the fiveyearold National Railroad Passenger Corporation, compared with my golden memories of days gone by.

title: Businessmen Can Look Better If They Try
description: Businessmen these days still complain about the mediaespecially television. They say that we don't'pay enough attention to business, and that when we occasionally do a story about business we don't know what we're talking about They also say we have an antibusiness bias and don't give spokesmen for business a fair chance to speak their niece.

title: Selected Poems
description: For three decades, says his publisher justly, Robert Lowell has been regarded as the premier American poet, perhaps the greatest in the English language. This being so, and human nature being what it is, it is difficult at this stage not to be mutinous and carpingnot to ask, for instance, why it is unthinkable that her Australian publisher should make any such claim for Judith Wright, though she is surely in the competition for the laurels. Isn't it the fact of the American imperium, which Lowell's poems have sometimes castigated so harshly, that makes such a claim plausible, where in the case of the Australian it wouldn't be? Art may or may not be independent of power politics; the making of artists reputations certainly isn't.

title: Marvie McGregor Wed To Roland L. Redmond
description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dayton, Ohio, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Marjory Lindsay McGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McGregor of Dayton, to Roland Livingston Redmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Woodward Redmond of Washington.

title: Noel Mulcahy Engaged
description: Noel Anne Mulcahy, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Mulcahy of Bronxville, N.Y., plans to be married Sept. 25 to R. Dennis Dubak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Dubak, also of Bronxville.

title: FISHING
description: BLUEFISH are here  in force. Large schools of hefty blues moved solidly into the fishing grounds off the South Shore and Montauk last week, while schools of small bluefish were reported racing through the Sound, chasing the moss bunkers into bays and inlets.

title: Miss Wayland Bride Of Dennis Peter Woos
description: Joanna Wayland and Dennis Peter Woos were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Sloan R. Wayland of Central Nyack, N.Y.

title: Carey Opts for No Involvement in the FiveWay Race for the Democratic U.S. Senatorial Nomination
description: Most of New York's Democratic Party leaders and many public officials are taking sides in the fiveway race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by Senator James L. Buckley, but the state's top Democrat. Governor Carey, will remain neutral.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: A New Type of Arthritis Found in Lyme
description: LYME, Conn.  A teenage boy suddenly developed severe pains in his leg and could not walk. His attacks, lasting a week or more, have come and gone several times.

title: Water Tank Held Key To Cutting Utility Bill
description: A utility company thinks a tank full of water might be the key to savings on electricity bills.

title: Jane Meredith Shanholt Bride Of Orlando Sacasa, Bank Aide
description: The marriage of Jane Meredith Shanholt, daughter of Mrs. Sayre McFarlane of Washington and East Hampton, L. I., and the late Berne Harcourt Shanholt of Dallas, to Orlando Antnio Sacasa took place yesterday in East Hampton, L. I. Mr. Sacasa is the son of Noel Sacasa Sevilla, Nicaraguan Ambassador to Argentina, and Mrs. Sacasa of Managua, Nicaragua, aud Buenos Aires.

title: MARINES CONTINUE ABUSE OF RECRUITS
description: SAN DIEGO, July 17The maltreatment of boot camp recruits by drill sergeants at the Marine Corps's training depot. here has continued in the wake of the scandal arising from the fatal beating of a mentally retarded youth seven months ago, official sources have acknowledged.

title: Music Notes: Thomson's Opera, Indiana's Painting At Santa Fe
description: I've known The Mother of Us All forlet's see30 years, and I think it is infallible. It works, no matter what you do. The source of this observation is the opera's composer, Virgil Thomson, who may be considered an authority on the subject, and he made it while musing, in a decidedly oldpro mood, on the new production of his opera to be presented in Santa Fe this August. Sets and costumes are by Pop artist Robert Indiana, and the connection between composer and painter dates from 1964, when the latter had a oneman show at The Stable Gallery in New York.

title: Carter Relaxes at Home And Maps Election Plan
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 17Jimmy Carter stayed home today, spending most of his hours out of the sultry Georgia heat that clung to this farming community. He caught up on the week's newspapers, made and received few phone calls, and tried to finish two books his wife gavc him on their recent 30th wed ding anniversary.

title: Editors Choice
description: General

title: Joe Greene Plays
description: PITTSBURGH,July 17 (AP)Joe Greene, defensive tackle, who has been nursing an injured shoulder since last season, took part in 11 plays today as the Pittsburgh Steelers held a 32play scrimmage.

title: POLITICS
description: DESPITE its image as one of the more powerful and monolithic Republican units in the state, the Suffolk G.O.P. organization has serious problems. Perhaps the most serious is that it is not as unified as it may appear. A basic division, which had been papered over in recent years, emerged over the recent selection of a candidate for sheriff.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AROUND 11 o'clock one Saturday night, my son, Joe, was attacked. Six teenage boys jumped him, pushed him to the ground and used his head as a football. When two girls started screaming, the attackers fled into the night. Actually, Joe was lucky, his only injuries were a chipped tooth and a sore jaw. This attack did not happen downtown in Elizabeth or Newark, it happened on a manicured lawn in Edison at a party.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide;Theater Opening This Week
description: GUYS AND DOLLSAn attbiack edition of the musical based on the story and characters by Damon Runyon. Book by Jo Swerling and Abs Burrows, music and lyrics by Frank Loesser. Directed and choreographed by Billy Wilson. Broadway, 1681 away, at 53d St. (CI 77992) Opens Wed.

title: Soviet Mathematician Dies
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (Reuters) Nikolai I. Muskhelishvilli, one of the Soviet Union's leading mathematicians, died Thursday at the age of 85, the newspaper Pravda reported today. He was a Georgian whose main research was on the theory of elasticity, integral equation and the theory of functions.

title: A New Theory: Inflation Triggers Recession
description: WASHINGTON  A remarkable development has taken place in economic thought in the industrial world and particularly in the United States. It may even be termed a new theory. Its adherent though with some nuances of differences, range from William Simon to Otto Eckstein, from the conservative President of France to the socialist prime minister of Britain.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  York K.C. allbreed and obedience, Fair Grounds, Route 74, York, Pa.; 1,719 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: A Sluggish Bureaucracy Endangers Children
description: In August 1972 Consumer Reports magazine launched an assault on children's car seats with a scathing report on the nonprotective design of most seats. Only two seatsboth made by auto companies, General Motors and Fordpassed simulated crash tests.

title: Officer of Bank Becomes Fianc Of Mary C. Miles
description: Mary Capell Miles and Leonard Hearne Armistead 3d, members of Tennessee newspaper publishing families, plan to be married Aug. 21 at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Memphis.

title: Canada, Taiwan, China and Other Fun and Games
description: Hurrah for Canada! The farce of pretending that the Chiang regime on Taiwan represents China has gone on long enough. A regime which needs a defense treaty with a foreign nation to protect itself from the Chinese people, a regime which has for 26 years not set foot on more than 99 percent of the Chinese territory and has not known or heeded the voice of more than 98 percent of Chinese people can in no way represent China. Thus, the song and the flag which such a regime chooses to sing and fly at international gatherings are not the national anthem and the national flag of China.

title: City of The Dead
description: Here are 10 rough days in the life of Dr. Paul Konig, Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, worldfamed in his profession, up to his dour, grizzled armpits in corpses, crises and the historical present. Uppermost on his mind is his vanished daugnter, Lolly, a girl in her early twenties, who is in the habit of making punishing phone calls from somewhere  in  the  city during which she does not speak, sending Konig into paroxysms of guilt, worry and grief over the way he has treated her and her dead mother, Ida. (The job always came first.) But these calls come to seem as bliss once Lolly is kidnapped by a psychopath masquerading as a hippie radical, who rings up Konig at odd hours so that he may listen to the screams of Lolly being tortured. The psychopath masquerading as a hippie radical wants a hefty ransom.

title: Events Today
description: Rathayatra Parade: Floats, music, art, dance by Hare Krishna Society; 2 to 4 P.M.; parade starts at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South and concludes with festival In Washington Square Park.

title: Spain's New Cabinet
description: Spain today is a young and renewed nation, King Juan Carlos told a joint session of Congress in Washington last month. Twothirds of us are under 40 years of age. We are an old race, but at the same time a new people.

title: Catherine Seckel Plans Fall Bridal
description: Catherine Schmid Seckel and William Glasgow Thompson plan to be married in Bridgehampton, LI., on September 25.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Helen C. Evarts, Burt L. Kozloff To Wed Aug. 28
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Maxwell Everts Jr. of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helen Coleman Everts, to Burt Louis Kozloff, son of Mrs. Jacob Kozloff of Reading, Pa., and the late Mr. Kozloff.

title: Cragun Joins Makarova In Magical Swan Lake
description: An enchanted lake overflown by swans at dusk draws a confident young prince to his destruction. The crucial element is the enchanted maiden who must make him renounce all that he is familiar with to release her from a spell. Natalia Makarova brings the improbable story of Swan Lake songfully alive and was partnered for the first time Friday evening by Richard Cragun as the bedazzled young noble. The production is one of the jewels of American Ballet Theater's repertory and confidently filled the stage of the New York State Theater with a panoply of ensemble and solo dances.

title: It Passively Controls Schedules but Not Basic Choices
description: Although television plays a major part in the primaries, helping to advance photogenic candidates, when the election moves into the nominating convention, as it did here last week, the role of television seems much more passive. The small screen apparently has a controlling effect on the procedures that are followed but a minimal influence on the political decisionmaking itself.

title: And If It's Busy?
description: Easterners, having enough trouble coping with the present, aren't universally eager to move into Washington Mutual's future.

title: BRIDGE
description: In the World Team Olympiad in Monte Carlo recently the Americans discovered, to their cost, that several small European countries have excellent teams fully capable of beating the world's best, in a short match. Among these are Denmark and Turkey, and when these countries met there was a most interesting defensive deal. The Danish stars, Stig Werdelin and Steen Moeller, sitting East and West, made every right move in defense to defeat Mehmet Kortay of Turkey in a game that was invariably made at other tables. Their effort was noted by Henry Francis, Editor of the American Contract Bridge League's World Championship book, and he entered it for the Bols Brilliancy prize.

title: At Grey Gardens, Some Subtle Changes
description: THINGS have not hanged much at Grey Gardens in the two years since the documentary filmmakers, Albert and David Maysles, recorded with frequently agonizing fidelity the unusual lifestyle of Jacqueline Onassis's East Hampton relatives, Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Edie. Or have they?

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: What's up in the traditional summer snacks?

title: In Memoriam
description: KOPPDr. Mortimer M. Cherished and loving memory. July 20, 1973.

title: Discovery of Oilfield in Arabian Sea Raises India's Hopes of Becoming SelfSufficient in Fuel
description: BOMBAY, IndiaFor more than a month, an oil tanker has been shuttling daily between a drilling ship stationed 100 miles out in the Arabian Sea and a refinery near here.

title: Room intheNorth
description: In the suburban sprawl of four major North Jersey counties there is still plenty of room for residential and commercial developmentas well as for farming according to a new survey of tax records.

title: Miss Bauer Bride Of Gary Myers Jr.
description: In the Presbyterian Church in Westfield, N. J., yesterday, Victoria Margaret Bauer and Gary Catterton Myers Jr. were married by the Rev. Theodore Sperduto.

title: Sets Beat Gaters, 2826, in Overtime
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 17 The New York Sets turned back the Golden Gaters, 2826, in an overtime World Team Tennis match tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Although today's cameras with their builtin electronic exposure meters, computer designed optics, and precision shutters are supposed to take practically all the guesswork out of taking good color pictures, all too ofter slides and color prints come back from the processing lab with some pictures underexposed and some overexposed; some with green foliage that has turned blue, blue skies that have turned magenta, and skin tones that range from red and orange to a macabre bluegreen.

title: What's Doing in ATHENS
description: THE GREEKS  Many visitors think of Athens as a very old city but most of it is quite modern. When Greece gained its independence from the Ottoman Empire in 1830, this was a provincial backwater with fewer than 10,000 people. Today, with a population of 3 million, Athens has all the noise and traffic of Paris or Rome, with little of the charm. But Athens has one thing you cannot find in those capitalsGreeks. Although they can be maddening at times, they have retained one quality that many Americans seem to have lost. They enjoy things as they come. Perhaps because this country has had such a troubled history, its people have learned to live in the present tense, not the future. So forget the clock. Wander into a shop, have a chat, sit in a cafe, sip a coffee, sniff a flower, take a siesta, admire a figureeither in stone or in jeans. The real Athenian is not Pericles or even Zorba. It is the taverna owner who brings you another carafe of his own wine and says in halting English, Where are you from? I have a cousin in Tzicago

title: U.S. Checking Soviet Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) A threeman team of American wheat experts left yesterday for an onthespot inspection of spring wheat production prospects in the Soviet Union.

title: 28 HURT IN CHICAGO IN A RACIAL MELEE
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (AP)An estimated 150 black civil rights marchers clashed with a crowd of whites at the edge of a city park today. At least 62 persons were arrested and 28 others treated for cuts and bruises, the police said.

title: Bonjour Olympique
description: MONTREAL, July 17  In its mod architecture, the Olympic Village resembles four stairways to the stars. Its pretty hostesses in candystriped blouses try to project that image with their cheery Bonjour to everyone. But here in V. O., short for Village Olympique, reality is only a glance away. On the lawn inside the 10foot wire fence that surrounds its 45 acres, Canadian soldiers in green uniforms patrol in pairs with carbines slung over their shoulders. At the entrances, residents and visitors with dogtag identification check in through airporttype security. The memory of the massacre of the Israelis at Munich has created the largest military operation in Canada since the Korean conflict. On a map in the Village's police headquarters, the positions of various policemen and soldiers are marked by yellow, blue, red and green pins.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Obituary 3  No Title

title: 2 Groups Investigating Advertising Agencies in New York City Over Charges of Racial Discrimination
description: There were seven fullservice blackowned advertising agencies in New York City in 1973. There is one today.

title: Collecting Political Memorabilia Is Reaching a Crest
description: There's no question, said Ed Veleber. It only happens once every four years. The bunting. The police. Limousines. The guys with their credentials. When that wave starts, it just pulls at your heart. You're so happy to be part of the crowd. It hasn't lost the torchlight flavor. It just makes the blood boil.

title: Cornelia Green Bride in Boston Of Rolf S. Stutz
description: Cornella Porter Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin T. Green of Cambridge and Marblehead, Mass., was married yesterday to Rolf Sturman Stutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Stutz of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy performed the Ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION ROSE 0.3 PERCENT in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported, with index at 129.9 (1967100)The Government said gross national product in 1976 is now expected to reach $1.687 billion, up 12.5 percent over the 1975 level. Real G.N.P. growth, after adjustment for inflation, is expected to be up 6.8 percentInventories in May rose by $1.93 billion, the largest increase in more than a year, after a rise of $960 million in April.

title: Sidewalks Are For Playing
description: As a purebred city kid, I spent almost all the summers of my youth in the hot, steamy streets of Brooklyn, but I never felt deprived in any way. Because there was always so much to do in the city, my two brothers and I were able to convince our parents that it was not necessary to ship us off to summer camp each year.

title: Bankrupt by Computer, Frenchman Wins $300,000
description: GRENOBLE, France, July 17 (Reuters)A fruit and vegetable wholesaler has been awarded $300,000 in damages after being driven to bankruptcy by a bank's computer error.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Jazz Quartet Led By Harold Ousley At Club in Village
description: Harold Ousley is a tenor saxophonist in a great mainstream jazz tradition that has its roots in such giants as Coleman Hawkins and Ben Webster, colored by the lighter, pliant sounds of King Curtis or Sonny Stitt. Leading a quartet this weekend at Willy's, 7 West Eighth Street, Mr. Ousley gives performances carefullyand successfully  calculated to be easily accessible to his listeners.

title: Memorial Seruirrs
description: GLEESONAlice Pearson. 17 July 1964. A low Mass of Requiem was offered In Latin by a Father of the Society of Jesus.

title: OSLO AND MOSCOW IN DELICATE TALKS
description: OSLO, Norway  A few weeks ago the Norwegian border commissioner in the north noticed on glancing toward the Soviet frontier that the flagpole bearing the hammer and sickle had become taller than the adjacent one on which Norway's colors were flying.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Obituary 2  No Title

title: They've been writing Coney off for 50 years, but here we are, says an oldtimer: You just wait till the place hits its real potential.
description: The thing that is so wonderful about Coney Island is that for so many, many years, including the 200th anniversary of the Republic, it has sturdily refused to pander to good taste. It simply will not talk up to any of the millions of people who have spent so much time and money and sweat pursuing the simpleminded pleasures lining its dingy shores or baptizing themselves fervently in the dubious waters of New York Harbor. It has one of the most spectacular beaches in the world, a good part of it pumped out of the sea in the 20's. There are times in the summer when that beach is so crowded that it is impossible to see the sand, but I find something even more intriguing about the beach than that.

title: Frank W. Abrams Dies
description: Frank Whittemore Abrams, former chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) now Exxondied yesterday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: CHESS
description: The modus operandi of such an Inveterate tactician as Larry Gilden of the Washington Plumbers team in the National Chess League is to sling an array of pins, forks and xrays that frays an opponent's nerves and sets him up for the kill.

title: They're Off to Italy For That Elusive M.D.
description: WHEN Thomas Apuzzo was in his final year at Boston College, his premedical advisers suggested he not bother applying to medical schools. He graduated with a 2.4 average out of 4 in biology, a 3.4 in philosophy and an overall average of 2.8.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Agnes de Mille is commonly regarded as the most American of ballet choreographers, This point was highlighted in a message from President Ford that was read recently to Miss de Mille at the State Theater, where American Ballet Theater staged an allde Mille program in her honor and where four of her ballets will be on view throughout the company's current season.

title: Chowchilla Families Cite Faith in God And Call Children's Return a Miracle
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 17What happened was written by God to happenHe was watching over the children, said Bertie Hargis, expressing a widespread feeling here about the safe return of 26 schoolchildren abducted Thursday along with their bus driver.

title: Miss Murphy, B. I. MacKinnon Plan Marriage
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Lee Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Murphy of Bronxville, N. Y., to Bruce Ian MacKinnon, son of Dr. Ian MacKinnon of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Mrs. MacKinnon, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: ART
description: THE inherent significance of the Bicentennial has been painfully diminished by the grossest forms of exploitation. Although the widespread observance of it has brought much good, the crass commercialization of Amen can history has in many intances put a quick buck in the hands of hucksters and tainted the dignity of our past.

title: ExMets, Dodgers and Giants Flood Shea With Memories
description: Monte Irvin stood easily in the batting cage, smoking the inside pitch to center field the way he did 20 years ago at the Polo Grounds. Billy Loes, who once complained of losing a ground ball in the Ebbets Field sun, smiled and waved to the shirtsleeved crowd. Jack Fisher, representing the Mets losing ways, had a fan club from Easton, Pa., complete with banners celebrating his girth and his disastrous wonlost record.

title: Nancy Wilson Wed To William Drake
description: Nancy Duke Hance Wilson and William Lloyd Drake, graduates of Bucknell University, were married yesterday afternoon in the Truro Episcopal Church in Fairfax, Va., by the Rev. Stephen Noll.

title: Arms Agency Weighs New Approach to Recycle Spent Uranium
description: WASHINGTON, July 17In hopes of lessening the risk that nuclear electricpower reactors might help other countries make atomic weapons, the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency is examining a new approach to the recycling of spent uranium fuel rods.

title: The Democratic Ticket
description: With the nomination of Governor Jimmy Carter Georgia and Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota, the Democratic Party is now entering the 1976 election campaign full of hope, overflowing with unity and confident in its appeal to the widest possible segment of the American public.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The paint on my kitchen walls has a lot of spidery cracks which I felt was due to there being too much paint on the walls. I started to use a paint and varnish remover to take the paint off, but when I scraped with the scraper I dug into the plaster. Can you tell me what I can do get rid of the cracks in the paint?Mrs. A. K., Baltimore, ???

title: Instruction Outpulls Entertainment on TV in India
description: JAIPUR, India Instructional television programming  traditionally considered by American producers as the pariah of commercial broadcasting has been winning popularity contests over entertainment shows in an unexpected quarter: among uneducated farmers and their families in isolated villages here in this vast nation of 610 million people. Top hits include programs on pest control and others on how to increase crop yields, and the audiences are clamoring for reruns. Furthermore, special instructional programs have stemmed a 60 percent school dropout rate in these test villages.

title: FluShot Controversy
description: LAST Feb. 4, David Lewis, a 19yearold Army recruit from Ashley Falls, Mass., collapsed during a forced training march at Fort Dix. He died later, and an autopsy showed that he had had influenza.

description: Birth Notice 1  No Title

title: The Fire Came By
description: This book is for U.F.O. scoffers and von Daniken skeptics. In a commendably straightforward prose, the authors lay out the verified facts concerning one of the greatest unexplained mysteries known to science: the awesome explosion that took place over the basin of the Stony Tunguska River in the desolate wastes of Central Siberia at approximately 7:17 A.M. local time on June 30, 1903. Although the site of the explosion was (fortunately) sparsely inhabited, there were numerous witnesses to its impact. A gigantic pillar of fire was visible to startled Siberians in towns several hundred miles away; the heat was so intense that people shielded their faces from the blast 40 miles away; seismographs around the world trembled; and a few hours later weather stations in England registered unusual fluctuations in barometric pressure. At the site itself, enormous trees were either uprooted or stripped bare of branches and left standing like so many forlorn telegraph poles. Almost as remarkable as the blast itself is the fact that Russian scientists did not visit the remote site until 1927. For many years thereafter, it was assumed that the destruction was caused by a giant meteorite; but no fragments were ever found and there is not the slightest sign of an impact crater. (The famous Meteor Crater in the Arizona desert, known to have been formed 10,000 years ago, is threequarters of a mile wide and 570 feet deep.)

title: One Novice Admits That He Learned the Hardy Way
description: As a novice gardener who a year ago didn't know an aphid from a nematode, I have blundered onto valuable information for the newcomer. Here are some things I've learned.

title: Kinnon Jones To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Kinnon Jones to Louis Vollers Farrar Jr. has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James E. Jones of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mr. Farrar is the son of Emily Farrar of Weston, Vt., and Louis V. Farrar of Katonah, N.Y. The wedding will take place on Aug. 14.

title: Ishaq Jud Weds Marianne Baker
description: Marianne Elizabeth Baker, daughter of Mrs. Daniel C. Baker of Demarest, N. J., and the late Dr. Baker, was married yesterday afternoon to Ishaq Daniel Arnold Jud. The Rev. Cherag Shahabuddin Less of the Church of All performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: AT orre time, the only outdoor appliance that people used on their terraces or patios was a charcoal grill. Nowadays, however, many homeowners also are using an increasing number of electrical appliances  lamps, radios, electric broilers, frypans and coffee pots, record players and power tools of various kinds.

title: Families Form Commune for Vacations in Mansion
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y.Where Janet Livingston Montgomery planted white lucusts in memory of a husband killed In the Revolutionary War, where the late Louise Clews Timpson, once the Duchess of Argyll, kept her Louis XVI mirrors, Flemish tapestries, Georgian chests, Battersea enamel, and Sheraton, Hepplewhite and Chippendale furniture, there, on holidays and vacations, live the Cantors, the Spectors, the Bells and the Scheins.

title: Endpaper
description: The advent of the Olympic Games in Montreal compels me to speak out publicly for the first time on a matter of grave importance for all true sportsmen, those who stand ready to fight for freedom and decency in the sport they love.

title: LETTERS
description: Mrs. Huxtable's article raises a very serious question regarding the future of architecture. It suggests that a group of architectural young Turks represented by Robert Venturi and Denise Scott grown have mounted a challenge to the fundamental concepts of the Modernism generated in Europe in the 1920's. In fact, this new movement neither challenges nor comes to grips With the basic concerns raised at that time. Modern architecture is indeed at a turning point but the alternatives are not represented by Venturi on one hand and Van der Rohe on the other, but rather by a fundamental choice between ??? of style and ??? of reason.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. asked the Supreme Court yesterday to take another searching look at the Florida, Georgia and Texas capital punishment laws before consigning 166, persons in those states to death.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The current show in a fourth floor hallway Seagram House, 375 Park Avenue, is the tiny tipoftheiceberg of an immense photographic project, the documentation of the county courthouse in the United States. Nothing quite like this has been undertaken since the government sponsored Farm Security Administration program or the 1930's. More than 6,000 photographs have already been taken by twentythree photographersmost of whom are young Americans  covering nearly a third of the 3,101 county courthouses in the 48 contiguous states. The program, which is the Seagram company's Bicentennial project, is direted by. Phyllis Lambert, with Richard Pare as general editor. Together, they selected the photographers.

title: They're mad about Alicia
description: Success is the most potent of wonder drugs and the most unpredictable in its side effects. Consider the case of the Spanish pianist, Alicia de Larrocha, who in the last 10 years has found herself propelled by her own talent and by fate's whimsy into a success bracket so lofty that she now is judged by standards applied only to a handful of artists in her field. But, far from getting high on success, the 53yearold Catalonian musician finds it all puzzling, even a little frightening. A small, neat person, outwardly prim and serene, she reveals herself on longer acquaintance to be a turbulent woman given to wide swings in mood, going from girlish gaiety at one meeting to brooding introspection at the next. And, in the latter mood. Miss de Larrocha can turn almost melancholy in contemplating the music world's current Alicia craze. The more critics and concertgoers exhaust themselves in praise of her, the more she worries and questions their sanity.

title: Countries Absent At Games Opening
description: Friday: Gambia, Nigeria, Taiwan, Tanzania.

title: Independence
description: Most Americans in 1776 were countrymen, and therein may lie one compelling reason why July was the month in which they proclaimed independence two hundred years ago. This is the time of the year when anything less than freedom seems intolerable to anyone living and thinking close to the land.

title: Laos Says Refugees Return
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 17 (Agence FrancePresse)Nearly 1,000 former refugees have returned from Thailand to southern Laos during the last six months, the Laotian radio said today. The radio report said that the refugees, all originally from Champassak Province, had been returned to active life after being reeducated by provincial authorities.

title: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES
description: ELEMENTARY PARTICLES

title: The Genesis Strategy
description: Science is little except observation of past events interpreted sd as to predict future ones. We depend on science and scientists to cast a beam of light into the dark tunnel of civilization's future. The relationship of global dimate to food supplies is a case in point: climatic researchers are becoming alarmed that in the next 10 to 100 years humanity will be unable to feed itselfnot through technolbgical insufficiency or political mischiefbut because of climatic changes that it can barely understand or control.

title: The Days of Coups and Anarchy Are Behind
description: LISBONWith political calm apparently restored for the time being, Portugal's new President, Antnio Ramalho Eanes, and a new Government must now turn to the country's remaining major difficulty, reviving the troubled economy.

title: Janet C. Dockendorff Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Janet Cornell Dockendorff to Frederick D. Ballou 2d, a trust officer at the State Street Bank and Trust Company in Boston, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Noyes C. Dockendorff of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Catholic Bishops Urge the Church To Fight Injustice
description: MARYKNOLL, N.Y., July 16 A cardinal, two archbishops, half a dozen bishops and 75 priests, nuns and lay people have challenged the Roman Catholic Church to make social justice and human rights integral parts of the Christian gospel.

title: A Budget Bus Trip Across Europe
description: At noon the bus swings out of Victoria Station, down Chelsea Bridge Road and across the Thames. The passengers seem agreeable but not gregarious, perhaps influenced by the taciturnity of the English countryside at winter's end. Then, too, there is something mednative, conducive to reverie, about longdistance bus travel. Most of these people, for a fare of $62, are en route to Athens. My friend Steve and I are going them one better: We are busing to Byzantium.

title: Mr. Schmidt Has Come With a Message
description: PARISIn the third decade after Hitler, West Germany is the strongest economic power in Western Europe, producing more goods and services than any other nation in the world except the United States and the Soviet Union. And it is this economic clout that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt carries with him as he visits the United States for discussions with President Ford and other officials on economic, defense and political matters.

title: Jimmy Carter's Economic Team
description: When Jimmy Carter's forces began looking around last winter for a prominent economist or two to advise the Presidential hopeful, they got one: Lawrence R. Klein, a professor of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: It looked like a terrific week last Monday, when, propelled by the lingering effects of positive economic news. the stock market eclipsed the year's high and went on to notch a 41month record.

title: The Old Front Porch
description: DUNMORE, Pa.  Airconditioning, electric fans, refrigerators and even home insulation all have changed the nature of hot summer nights in Small Town, America.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSFrank W., on July 17, 1976, of Southold, N.Y., husband of the late Ruth F. (nee Corrigan), father of Frank W. Jr., also survived by 2 granddaughters, Susan B. Abrams and Mrs. Nancy A. Mullen, and I greatgranddaughter, Karen Anno Mullen. Retired In 1953 as Chairman of the Board of Exxon Corporation. Reposing at (DoFrlost Funeral Home, Inc., Main Rd., Southold, N.Y. Sunday evening 7.9 & Monday 25 & 79 P.M. Funeral services Tuesday, July 20, 1976, 2 P.M. at the Southold Presbyterian Church. Interment Cutchogue Cemetery, Cutchogue, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Southold Presbyterian Church Memorial Fund.

title: Diana Guiragossian Bride of R. A. Carr
description: Diana Guiragossian and Richard A. Carr, professors of French literature at Indiana University in Bloomington, were married in New York yesterday afternoon in the St. Vartan Armenian Orthodox Cathedral. The Rev. Mampre Kouzouian performed the ceremony.

title: Deaths
description: WACHTERRichard P., of New York City, formerly of Floral Park, L.I., on July 16, 1976. Beloved son of Carl O. and Helen M., fond brother of Carl E., devoted uncle of Robert Christopher. Friends may visit 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 P.M. Monday at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave. (at R.R. Plaza), Floral Park, N.Y. Religious service Monday, 8 P.M. to lieu of flowers, contributions to American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Miss Stacy, Mrs. Rankin Tie for Lead
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, July 17 (UPI)Hollis Stacy, a thirdyear pro, shot a fiveunderpar 67 today to tie Judy Rankin for the lead after the second round of the $70,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Borden Classic.

title: Massachusetts Gun Curb Is Assayed
description: BOSTON, July 17Massachusetts tough new mandatorysentence gun control law had a mixed impact in its first year, according to a Harvard University study.

title: Royal Touch Personal
description: MONTREAL, July 17 (AP)Do you see Anne? Prince Philip called excitedly to his wife, Queen Elizabeth II, who was reviewing the march of Olympic athletes today. Waving from the thirdtolast row ofthe British women's team about 30 yards away, her largerimmed white sun hat bobbing, her white chiffon wraparound scarf flying as she walked, was Princess Anne, the Queen's 26yearold daughter She is with the British Equestrian Team and is the first member of a ruling British royal family to participate in an Olympic Games.

title: Watchdog Turns Into Show Victor
description: It was either a shotgun or a dog, said Dr. Roscoe B. Guy, director of health services at Metropolitan Hospital and a professor at New York Medical College. We live in West Nyack [N.Y.] and Jacqueline [Mrs. Guy] and our children are alone a great deal. he said. She wasn't enthusiastic about a shotgun, so we decided on a dog and a big one.

title: All Connecticut Delegates Are Pledged to President
description: HARTFORD, July 17Despite raucous attempts by supporters of Ronald Reagan to win places on Connecticut's 35member delegation to the Republican National Convention, party leaders at the state convention here today obtained approval of a delegation committed to a man to President Ford.

title: Deaths
description: MAYERMarlon S. Beloved wife of peter, devoted mother of Judith, passed in Harrison, Maine, Friday, July Services Tuesday, July 20, 10:15 A.M., The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may sent to Jewish Family Service, Tucson, Arizona. Arizona papers please copy.

title: Crossing The Border
description: In Joyce Carol Oates's collection of short stories, a strange, erratic man named Blaine writes prose poems that draw unusual conclusions from trivial events. Housewives pushing carts around the local Kroger's supermarket were participating in evil, bloody, capitalistic acts of violence  people who broiled or roasted or otherwise prepared meat were disguising blood as gravy  old men playing checkers in the airpolluted park near a nursing home were wrestling to see who would outlive the other.

title: Bridget Whelan Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Whelan of Whitestone, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bridget Pauline Whelan, to John Robert Daly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Daly of Bayside, Queens.

title: POLICE REHIRINGS DELAYED BY SUIT
description: A Federal judge ruled this weekend that the city must include 38 former women police officers in a group of 60 officers, dismissed during last year's budget crisis, whose reinstatement had been scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I put on my old sneakers and went to play tennis. I hated the idea, but there was no escape. All my friends played tennis. When they weren't playing tennis themselves, they watched other people playing tennis on television. In their leisure, they read books about tennis, and at night they went to each other's houses and talked about their backhands. Young couples in our circle were refusing to have babies and starting to have tennis racquets.

title: Federal Aid and the Cities
description: IT is time the Federal Government, states and counties stopped shirking their responsibilities to the cities and, in particular, stopped freeloading on the cities for services the cities can no longer afford to furnish free.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M.

title: Each Is Active, but Through Surrogates
description: WASHINGTONThe Soviet Union and the United States now face each other through surrogates in a checkered belt that runs down across Central Africa, from Somalia to Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya, Zaire and Angola. It is the position of the Ford Administration that it neither intended nor willed this situation, but officials talk as if the United States now has no choice but to maintain it.

title: The Mondale Gamble
description: No sooner had Jimmy Carter chosen Walter Mondale as his running mate than the Republicans moved to make bigspending liberalism the issue of the fall campaign. The Carter and Mondale acceptance speeches, ringing with promises of social justice and economic reform, can only have confirmed the Republican intention.

title: Patricia Croke Wed To John G. Gaine
description: Patricia Ann Croke and John Gerald Gaine were married yesterday afternoon in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., by the ev. John Budwick.

title: POLITICS
description: SONIE of New Jersey's most influential political leaders are determined to insulate the Presidential campaign this fall from the jockeying now going on each party for the gubernatorial nomination next year.

title: Clarke, 17, to Face Updegraff in Final
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., July 17 (AP)Doug Clarke of LaJolla, Calif., defeated Randy Simmons of Shreveport, La., 4 and 3, today and reached the final of the 73d TransMississippi amateur golf tournament.

title: Sewers Aren't Always the Answer
description: SEWERS with marine outfalls are expensive and disruptive to construct, difficult to maintain (they often leak) and pollute the environment. They are also extremely wasteful of drinking water (a commodity in periodic short supply), which foms 99 percent of sewered material as a carrier for the 1 percent waste. Sewers are, however, essential in urban and in low coastal areas where oesspools cannot operate.

title: Lewis Carroll
description: The Rev. C. L. Dodgson (18321898) had in many ways a most enviable life. Gifted with a brilliant and versatile intelligence, he made full use of it. He had very good health. (Almost to the day of his death he could walk 18 miles at a stretch and think nothing of it.) He was never poor, never hungry, and rarely had to eat with dull people. When his books made money, he gave a lot of it away. He lived for 47 of his 66 years in one of the grandest and most beautiful of Oxford colleges. As a professional logician and mathematician, he was good enough to earn praise from Bertrand Russell. He had firm friends among the best English painters and writers of his day, and he adored acting, actors and actresses: few men can have seen so many bad plays for pleasure. He was a pioneer photographer in the days when it seems to have been almost impossible to take a bad photograph, so rich was the potential of the medium. With almost no apparent effort he wrote, under the name of Lewis Carroll, two booksAlice's Adventures in Wonderland and Alice Through the LookingGlasswhich have given innocent and lifelong pleasure to millions of people in a total of 48 languages. A clergyman's son, he was born into a faith which he never doubted. He does not seem ever to have behaved badly to anyone, or to have done anything of which he could reasonably be ashamed.

title: Minorities vs. the Police
description: IT is my opinion that Nassau County is headed toward unnecessary racial confrontation between the police and the minority community. It is the opinion of the black and minority community that the police force in Nassau County is dedicated to saw enforcement against them as opposed to police protection for them. The distinction is not a small one. It is also the kind of distinction that tends to distort and amplify, at times unreasonably, the motivation and intent of police action against minority citizens. In my opinion, it is also the kind of distinction that must inevitably result in a massive response on the part of the minority community toward the police of Nassau County.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Regarding Robert Hanley's article, July 4How to Spend the Long Holiday (June 27):

title: PEOPLE
description: AGREAT many politicians around the State House in Trenton laughed last April when Orin Kramer quit his job as counsel for the State Treasurer, Richard C. Leone, to become a speechwriter for Jimmy Carter. It now appears that if Mr. Carter becomes President, Mr. Kramer will be the New Jerseyan closest to him. Although not now a member of the inner circle around Mr. Carter, which is composed mainly of Georgians, Mr. Kramer at least has the ear of some members of this inner circle and known by them to be a corner. The 31yearold Mr. Kramer, a native of Newark, is helping coordinate research on the issues for the upcoming Presidential campaign.

title: SLAYINGS ANGER ARGENTINE CHURCH
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 17The highest Roman Catholic authorities in Argentina have expressed deep concern to the military authorities over the lack of an investigation of the killing of three priests and two seminarians in a parish residence.

title: C. J. HARTENSTINE, A U.S. MAGISTRATE
description: Charles J. Hartenstino Jr., a United States magistrate for the Southern District of New York, died Friday of a heart attack while vacationing at Ocean City, N.J. He was 54 years old and lived in Millburn, N.J.

title: Picking Your Own
description: Torn ACO THE morning sun shone benignly on the hacks of the four women and a young boy as they worked their way diligently down the strawberry field. It was a peaceful and quiet moment.

title: Ghanaians Weathering Lag Between Harvests
description: ACCRA, Ghana  How is life? is the greeting heard all over Accra. It is used when friends meet unexpectedly in the street and thwack their palms together, when a waiter takes an oraer for beer in the drowsy afternoon and when a young man with razoredge creases in his trousers saunters up to a woman under the fluorescent canopy of the Ambassador Hotel.

title: From Drugstores to Doctrine
description: Lewis Lehrman might he called the envy of every businessman. At the age of 37, he had built a family business into a 467store public company that is the Northeast's largest and the nation's fourthlargest drug chain. He has made a multimutton dollar personal fortune in the process, and he has founded policy institute that serves him as rostrum from which to preach the gospel as he sees it.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Some Interesting and unique types have come out of North Babylon High School. Surely the Limengellos are at the head of the list. Both make a strong case of coining a new phraseFate is blind. Fourteen years ago neither struck me as having the potential for achievement.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: College. Morris Avenue, tinionDay of Absence. by New York's Alonzo Players. Monday, 8 P.M. 201) 5272046.

title: Mail Box: Doctor J
description: To the Sports Editor: With baseball season in full swing and the summer Olympic Games just about to begin, as is football training camp, It is a wonder that all I feel is a growing anticipation of the upcoming basketball season. With Dr. J playing the National Basketball Association, the thoughts that cross my mind.

title: In Memorium
description: BECKEREtta. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Becker. Darling Mama, never forgotten, forever beloved.

title: Television This Week
description: 11:00 A.M. (2) CAMERA THREE. Richer By Russia. Filmmaking in the Soviet Union is discussed by three artists of the Russian cinema who now live In the United States  director Mikhail Bogin, actress Victoria Fyodorova, and cinematographer Mikhail Suslov. Art critic Faubion Bowers is host.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The largest gathering of coin, medal and paper money collectors in the world is the annual convention of the 33,000member American Numismatic Association, and one of its stellar attractions Is the auction. The A.N.A.'s giant 85th anniversary convention will be held in New York's Americana Hotel from Aug. 24 through 29, and the auction will be conducted by a numismatic giant in its own right  Stack's. Five separate sessions will be required to handle the more than 4,000 lots of U.S. and world coins, medals, paper money, tokens and related material dating from ancient times to the present. Consignments from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and the Massachusetts Historical Society are featured. There will be, of course, mail bidding as well as floor bidding.

title: Chrysler Pact Ratified
description: DETROIT, July 17 (UPI) Members of United Autoniobile Workers Local 212 ratified. today a new contract that ended a 10day strike by 800 workers at a Chrysler Corporation tol and die plant. The yobs was reported to be 293 to 55. The walkout involved health and safety issues, working conditions and the contractingout of work. Details of the pact were not made public.

title: JAPAN'S TOP COURT SENDING 2 TO U.S.
description: TOKYO, July 17Japan's Supreme Court dispatched two officials to Los Angeles tonight as part of the unusual transPacific judicial negotiations over Japan's continuing Lockheed Aircraft bribery investigation.

title: Foyt Wins Pole Spot in Michigan
description: BROOKLYN, Mich., July 17 (AP)A. J. Foyt won the pole position for the Indianapoliscar division in the seventh annual Twin 200 auto race today at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Jobs for Canada's Indians
description: AMHERST, N. S., July 17 (AP)Canadian officials say $150,000 has been allocated for 240 jobs for Indian students in the maritime provinces this summer. To be eligible, students must intend to return to high school or university in the fall.

title: When Pele Awakes, Cosmos Have No Cause for Alarm
description: When I walked into the dressing room and I saw him asleep with all the players around him half an hour before the game, I knew it would be his night, that he would have a great game, Prof. Julio Mazzei said about Pel's performance last Wednesday night, When the New York cosmos defeated the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 54, here.

title: Derrel Thomas Disabled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (AP)The San Francisco Giants placed Derrel Thomas, second baseman, on the 15day disabled list last night and recalled Bruce Miller, infielder, from Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Joiners, Not Fighters, Make Decorative Use of Rocks
description: When it comes to dealing with stones, gardeners can be separated into two schoolsFight em or Join dem.

title: Man Ray
description: If the very fractious Surrealist artists lacked esprit de corps inihe usual sense, they had it in another way: in the spirited wit with which they assaulted the human bodyor parts thereof, usually feminine in gender. Man Ray has produced some of the more famous Surrealist icons in this vein: the photograph of the shapely nude back of the Parisian model, Kiki, transformed into a violin; the painting of a pair of woman's lips hovering in a blue sky; a disembodied eye affixed to a real metronome.

title: Susan Bacon Is Wed To Calvin J. Turley
description: Susan Truss Bacon and Calvin Jones Turley were married yesterday in the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Bacon Jr., in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Marvin H. Hummell performed the Episcopal ceremony, The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry McCorry Turley of Memphis.

title: Asbury Park and the New Rock Music
description: THE Jersey Shore is not my home, but it might as well be. For the last seven years I have spent more time in Asbury Park and the assorted townships that run north and south along Ocean Avenue and Route 35 than in what my driver's license claims to be my native state. Pennsylvania.

title: 9 New Commanders Named by Ethiopia In Army ShakeUp
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia July 17 (Reuters)Nine new commanders in the Ethiopian Army have been sworn in, including a man to replace Brig. Gen. Getachew Nadau, the martiallaw administrator of Eri trea who was shot to death a week ago reportedly while resisting arrest.

title: Democrats Big Worry Is Not Enough Worrying
description: An incumbent President, facing dissension in his own party and unpopular with the voters, is grudgingly renominated, though the polls show him far behind a confident challenger chosen by acclamation at a harmonious convention. The challenger campaigns cautiously around the issues, fearful of risking his lead; the unspectacular President never abandons the attack and, to everyone's astonishment but his own, wins.

title: Betty Sandford Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abner Gold of Springfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gold's daughter, Betty Ann Sandford, to Steven Randell Lytle. Miss Sandford is a daughter also of the late Lloyd Sandford of Fair Lawn. N. J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Lytle of Columbus, Ohio.

description: Adrienne Chute, a reference librarian at the National Criminal Justice Reference Service in Washington, and John Robert Shortall, a trustee of St. David's School in New York, were married yesterday afternoon in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. James English, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Nation
description: Still Counting

title: Alison Kaplan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Kaplan of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Kaplan, to Norman Axelrod, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Axelrod, also of White Plains.

title: de Meyer
description: Even the remote possibility that Darwin's principle of natural selection may be at work in photography today is very cheering. One could take comfort in the thought that of the billions of chemical images produced annually for public and private use, almost all within a few hundred years may fade and vanish from the face of the earth. Photography itself and the excessive claims for it as an art form are in danger of becoming a plague, or at least a kind of pollution.

description: Geraldine Ann Schilling, head of the art department at Agawam (Mass.) High School, was married yesterday morning to Reidar Johannes Nordal, a technician for the Westinghouse Company in its Springfield, Mass., plant. The Rev. Walter J. Joyce performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Agawam.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE weather has been fine and the treeshaded patio between the house is as seductive as ever. We sit there and doze off there and put our company there. But we have not eaten out there yet this summer and it worries me.

title: Giants Play And Offense Is the Loser
description: BRIARCLIFF, N. Y., July 17 The Giants offense bought the beer for the defense today after losing a 306 decision in an annual intrasquad game that attracted 2,000 fans.

description: Marriage Announcement 9  No Title

Schirripa of Yonkers and Mr. and Mrs. Francis John Castanaro of Moscow, Pa.

title: Convention Is Described as Bringing A Legacy of Good Will to New York
description: The Democratic National Convention brought fewer dollars to the New York City economy than its boosters had predicted, but just about everyone in a position to profit from convention business believes there will be longterm benefits from the event for years to come.

title: Bicentennial Art: Beating Bogus
description: AS expected, much patriotic hoopla has surrounded the 200th anniversary of our country inch of it has been praise heaped on our Founding Fathers for their cour

description: TOKYO  Davis Kotey, 126 pounds, Ghana, knocked out Shige Fukuyama. 125, Japan, rounds; Kotey retained his World Boxing Council featherweight title.

title: Majestic Light Wins
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 18 (AP)Majestic Light, the favorite from the East won the $112,200 Cinema Handicap at Hollywood Park today.

title: Israel Broadens Its Pound's Exchange
description: TEL AVIV, July 18Israel tonight removed its pound from an exclusive tie with the American dollar. Effective at midnight, Israeli exchange rates will be reckoned against a basket of currencies consisting of the dollar and four major European currencies.

title: TRAINING IS PLANNED FOR LOW  PAY JOBS
description: The country's public vocational school system in the next decade will train the bulk of its graduates for relatively lowpaying jobs, according to a study issued this weekend by the Conference Board.

title: INVESTORS REACT ON MONEY SUPPLY
description: It did not take the credit markets long to react to the $2.6 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply reported by the Federal Reserve last Thursday afternoon. Prices turned lower later that day in the Government  securities market and took a further drubbing last Friday, with declines ranging from a quarter to a full point.

title: Cosmos Victors In Rout
description: Despite playing half the game without Pele, the New York Cosmos exploded for five goals yesterday, defeating the Washington Diplomats, 50, at Yankee Stadium.

title: Bomb Scare Is Only Beans
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (AP)The Postal Service airmail facility at O'Hare International Airport was evacuated last night when a package began making strange ticking sounds. The police bomb and arson squad very carefully opened the package. Inside were three cans of Mexican jumping beans.

title: On Working Closely With Jimmy Carter
description: William Safire began a recent attack on Jimmy Carter by conceding the obviousthat Safire's own motives are rightly suspect. Indeed they are. As best I can make out, Safire is trying, in some convoluted way, to purge himself of the taint of Nixonism by the repeated assertion that politicians in general, and Carter in particular, are all just as bad as Nixon was.

title: Bangladesh Court Dooms Man for AntiRegime Plot
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, July 18 (Reuters)A special military tribunal has sentenced to death the leader of a plot to overthrow the Government of Bangladesh, the official press agency reported today.

title: Visitors Give Bergen's 4H Club Fair an A1 Rating
description: LEONIA, July 18Texans who were among the 20,000 visitors to the Bergen County 4H Club Fair felt at home during much of the fourday program in Overpeck Park.

title: Ethiopian Massacre
description: Ethiopia has undergone another political massacre. Eighteen military leaders and merchants have been killed, charged with crimes ranging from plotting a revolution to hoarding food. The news brings back memories of November 1974, when 60 leading military and civilian figures were executed on similar and related charges. But the situation in Ethiopia has deteriorated sharply between these two political bloodbaths, and the basic situation in that unfortunate country is much worse than was in late 1974 even though the number of those executed now is considerably smaller.

title: Studies Assail Management Of U.S. Arms Sales in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters)  United States military advisers are giving Iran's armed forces conflicting advice and in some cases providing inadequate supervision of American military sales to the country, according to two State Department studies made public today.

title: Israelis Report Seizing Ship With Munitions for Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, July 18 (UPI)The Israeli Navy has seized Greek freighter carrying ??? tions from Egypt to Palestinian forces in Lebanon, military sources said today.

title: BERGDORF'S SUMMER SWIMSUIT SALE
description: 1/3 off original prices Don't miss itl Swimsuits from some of the world's most famous names ready to hit the beach right now  Gottex, Cole of California, Elisabeth Stewart, Anne Klein for Penfold, Giorgio Sant Angelo  and oodles and oodles of coverups, as well.

title: USERY JOINS TALKS AT WESTINGHOUSE
description: PITTSBURGH, July 18 (UPI) Labor Scretary William J. Usery intervened today in the dispute between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and three unions whose strike has closed company plants and repair shops across the country.

title: Use of British Six In Games Vetoed
description: MONTREAL, July 18 (Reuters)The International Hockey Federation decided today not to bring the British field hockey team to Montreal to compete as a substitute in the Olympic Games.

title: 5 L.I. Residents Killed In Jersey Plane Crash
description: Five Long Island residents were killed yesterday when their singleengined plane crashed as they were attempting an emergency landing at Nairobi Airport near the Jungle Habitat amusement park in northern New Jersey.

title: A's Slug and Get. That Feeling Again
description: Even though they trail firstplace Kansas City by 10 games in the American League West race, the Oakland A's feel they have a good chance to win the division title for the sixth time in a row.

title: M.A.C. TO REQUEST LONGER BOND TERM
description: Trustees of the five city pen sion funds will be asked today to consider extending the term of their $660 million in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds from the current 10 years to 15 years.

title: Bergen Museum Seeks To Fix the Unbearable
description: PARAMUS, July 18Beset by a lack of funds, the Bergen Community Museum here is seeking public and private assistance either to move or to have its deteriorating building renovated.

title: Trenton Salutes Bicentennial With 2Day Program of Music
description: TRENTON, July 18 The Mercer County Cultural and Heritage Commission put forth its best Bicentennial foot this weekend with a show that featured 50 displays of handcraft and a full program of music that ranged from classical to jazz.

title: ForemostMcKesson Strikes Back As Posner Presses Takeover Drive
description: When it became known last May that Victor Posner, the controversial conglomerater, would attempt to take over ForemostMcKesson Inc., the giant wholesale drug and liquor distributor, the reaction in Foremost's headquarters was fear bordering on panic.

title: Scientists Await Outcome of Mars Gamble That Could Bring the First OnSite Pictures or Silence
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 18 Shortly before 8 A.M., Eastern daylight time, Tuesday a multimillion dollar gamble will pay off, delivering pictures and scientific observation for the first time from the surface of Mars. or end in silence.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (RadioWNEW, 8 P.M.)

title: Carter Speaks to Sunday School Class On Need for Love, justice and Humility
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 18Jimmy Carter returned to the simple white First Baptist Church here today and taught a Sunday school lesson on the need for love justice and humility.

title: Policeman Kills Himself
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI)A Chicago patrolman, James R. Podgorny, 28 years old, a sixyear police veteran, accidentally shot himself to death today while he was examining a revolver in the front yard of his home.

title: Ford Traffic Security Dents Some Sensibilities
description: HARTFORD, July 18 (AP)  Security measures designed to prevent President Ford from having another fenderbender Saturday left at least 17 unhappy persons.

title: Summertime Is Cram Time for Students
description: For weeks now they have not been to a movie or seen their friends, and they are only dimly aware that the Bicentennial celebrations and the Democratic National Convention ever happened.

title: Songs of Robison By Barbara Lea At Michael's Pub
description: It was just a year ago that Barbara Lea, a singer who had disappeared 20 years earlier after what had seemed to be the start of a promising career, suddenly reappeared, singing one night a week in an Italian restaurant on Third Avenue.

title: Floods in Venezuela's South Leave 50,000 Homeless
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 18 (Reuters)  At least 50,000 people have been left homeless by Venezuela's worst floods in 30 years, relief officials said here today.

title: Events Today
description: MOVIES IN THE PARKS, a series of shod films at Junlner Valley Park, Juniper Boulevard North and 80th Street, Queens, 9 P.M.

title: S. African Golf Winner
description: STOCKHOLM, July 18 (UPI)  Hugh Baiocchi of South Africa won the $70,000 Scandinavian Enterprise open golf tournament by two shots today with a closing 68 for 271.

title: Agricultural Abundance
description: The largest corn crop and the second largest wheat crop in history are the 1976 harvest prospects seen by the Department of Agriculture as of July 1. A statistical projection is hardly the same as the crop safe in the bin, and bad weather this summer could well make the final 1976 reckoning far less cheerful. Nevertheless, for the moment there is certainly reason for optimism since the forecast implies that the United States this year will gather huge crops sufficient not only to meet all domestic needs, but also to contribute substantially to foreign requirements.

title: Namath Displays Old Form Quickly
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.L., July 18  The resurrection of the New York Jets began today, and the team was led by the man who once promisedand delivered  the Super Bowl: Joe Namath.

title: Devereux Duer Robinson, ExMathematics Professor
description: Devereux Duer Robinson, for more than 15 years chairman of the mathematics department at Townsend Harris High School, and later professor of mathematics at City College, died Friday in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Hudson View Gardens, 150 Pinehurst Avenue.

title: Now the Republicans
description: Now that Jimmy Carter of Georgia has actually achieved the impossible by walking away with the Democratic nomination for the Presidency, and brilliantly capped his triumph by selecting Senator Mondale Minnesota as his running mate, the Republicans are left in more of a quandary than ever.

title: 5 Killed in Plane Near Jungle Habitat
description: Five Long Island residents were killed yesterday when their singleengined plane crashed as they were attempting an emergency landing at Nairobi Airport near the Jungle Habitat amusement park in northern New Jersey.

title: Fort Lee Remembers Its Revolutionary Heritage
description: Fort Lee Remembers Its Revolutionary Heritage

title: In Memoriam
description: DRUCKHarry. July 19, 1972. Forever In loving and cherished memory. Ann.

title: Park Party In a Salute To Yiddish
description: Thousands of people gathered in Central Park yesterday to celebrate the 100th birthday of Yiddish theater and the 200th birthday of the country and spent much of the time discussing the seemingly ageless question of whether Yiddish can survive.

title: Johncock, Foyt Win
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 18 (UPI)Gordon Johncock captured the championship car part of the Michigan Twin 200 today, at Michigan International Speedway.

title: HARRIET H. DAVIS
description: Harriet H. Davis, for 13 years a kindergarten and firstgrade teacher at Public School 1 in the Bronx, died of cancer Saturday at the North Shore Hospital, Great Neck, L. I. She was 48 years old and lived at 8518 Wareham Place, Jamaica Estates, Queens. Mrs. Davis graduated from City College in 1948 and later earned a masters degree at New York University. She leaves her husband, Alfred; two daughters, Ellen and Mona, and her father, Harry Rubin.

title: G.O.P. Parley Drawing Extra Press Members
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 18 (UPI)  Republican National Convention officials say the close race between President Ford and Ronald Reagan has swelled the number of journalists expected to attend the convention, which begins Aug. 16.

title: Olympic Games Summaries
description: Olympic Games Summaries

title: Why Some Designers Like to Lower a High Ceiling
description: High ceilings have always been considered desirable, except by those who dream of thatched cottages, saltbox houses or log cabins. Since they are so desirable, why would anyone want to lower them?

title: Gymnastic Scoring Draws U.S. Protest
description: MONTREAL, July 19 (UPI) The first official protest of the Olympic Games was filed tonight by the coach of the United States men's gymnastics team.

title: Montreal Greets Queen, But Reservations Remain
description: MONTREAL, July 18Queen Elizabeth, who opened the Olympic Games here yesterday in her role as Canada's head of state, was received cordially but not without reservations by her Canadian subjects.

title: Mets Win as Kingman Hits 32d
description: The Mats and Mickey Lolich reached an accommodation at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon as the lefthander shut out the Atlanta Braves. 20.
