description: Today's Schedule

title: Hallman Will Head Gimbels New York
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc. announced yesterday the appointment of Matt Kaltman as chairman and chief executive officer of the 10store Gimbel New York division.

title: BEIRUT RIGHTISTS ATTEMPT TO TAKE PALESTINIAN CAMP
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18Christian rightists launched a new attack on the isolated Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar today as military activities were stepped up on several fronts

title: Goldin Charges DayCare Giveaway
description: The possible political influence of a small group of developers who are responsible for a large part of the city's daycare centers is under investigation, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: CATS MUTILATION LAID TO MUSEUM
description: The American Museum of Natural History has spent almost $500,000 over the last 15 years in a study of the sex lives of cats involving experiments that animal rights groups have deplored as cruel and inhumane.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: New Corporate Bonds

title: 40 Relive Restaurant Holdup at a Dinner
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 18 A year ago, 20 couples from Stamford, Conn., rented a bus and traveled to a restaurant in Harlem in New York City for a Chinese dinner. Last night, they drove their own automobiles to a restaurant in Scarsdale to reminisce and complete an evening that had been interrupted.

title: Olympic Games Started; Guyana Joins in Boycott
description: MONTREAL, July 18The African boycott of the Olympic Games picked up Caribbean support today when Guyana officially withdrew during the first day of competition. Indications were that the total withdrawal would level off at about two dozen teams involving perhaps 600 athletes.

title: 3 ARAB LEADERS CONTINUE PARLEY
description: CAIRO, July 18The leaders of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and the Sudan discussed interArab problems and other matters today in their second day of talks in Saudi Arabia, Egyptian sources reported tonight.

title: Crepe Pans: Easy Method Can Be More Trouble Than It's Worth
description: If you don't know that crepes are the latest fond fad, it's only because you haven't been looking. Restaurants with menus based entirely on these thin French pancakes are proliferating and being franchised around the country. Cookware departments are adrift with crepe pans ranging in price from $5 to $595, many of them merely ordinary skillets renamed to cash in on the new wave of popularity.

title: Tax Breaks for the Few Hinge on Access to Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 18This year, four welltodo California business executives wanted a special provision in the tax law, one that would apparently benefit no one but them.

title: 18 Injured in New Orleans As Rock Fans Fight Police
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 18 (UPI)Rcck music fans with beer cans and bottles battled policemen, who used clubs, in scattered skirmishes at a concert last night attended by 50,000 Persons in Tulane Stadium.

title: Sherrner L. Sibley, 62, Drowns; Pacific Gas and Electric Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18Shermer L. Sibley, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the West's largest utility concern, drowned Friday afternoon in the Dean River, 300 miles north of Vancouver, British Columbia, the company has announced.

title: Books of The Times
description: Who could have foreseen, before getting really into the war, what was inside the foul and idle, heroic soul of man? It was a thing that had come up from the depths and here it was on top of us.

title: SOVIET SAYS CARTER VIOLATES 75 ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters) A Soviet comrne.ntator today accused Jimmy Carter of violating the spirit of the European Security Conference held last year in Helsinki.

title: Lisbon's New Premier
description: LISBON, July 18Mario Soares, the 51yearold Socialist who has been named Prime Minister of Portugal, is a compulsive politician.

title: The Rising Yen
description: In recent months, the United States and other Western industrial countries have been critical of Japan for allegedly preventing a rise in the value of the yen, in order to help Japanese export sales.

title: Deborah Mayer Is Bride
description: Deborah Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Mayer of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Edward J. Kosinski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kosinski of Wilbraham, Mass. The interfaith ceremony was performed in the Chapel of the Peace of the Community Church of New York by the Rev. Bruce Alan Southworth. The bride is a fourthyear student at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Dr. Kosinski recently began a twoyear fellowship in cardiology at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston.

title: Soviet Union Romps
description: The Soviet Union, which took the gold medal from the United States at Munich in 1972, had an easy time in its first game tonight, defeating Mexico, 12077.

title: Summer time Is Cram Time for Students
description: For weeks now they have not been to a movie or seen their friends, and they are only dimly aware that the Bicentennial celebrations and the Democratic National Convention ever happened.

title: RAIN HELPS CREWS CURB FIRE IN WEST
description: GRAND VALLEY, Colo., July 18 (UPI)Scattered afternoon showers today helped firefighters contain a blaze that has consumed more than 880 acres of timber and caused the death of four men, a Bureau of Land Management spokesman said.

title: Concert: Stranje Sirius
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Albert Einstein Spacearium in the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum provided the perfect setting this weekend for four performances of the world premiere of Sirius, Karlheinz Stockhausen's latest and in some ways strangest comnocitinn. Perhaps acoustical environment would be a better description of the piece, for Mr. Stockhausen, who has been a leader in musical avantgarde circles since the early 1950's, has always sought to write music that frees itself from a conventional concert ambience.

description: Aaueduct Race Charts

title: MARY T. 0. WALSH, 59, PUBLISHING OFFICIAL
description: Mary Tsuta Ohata Walsh, former vice president of the John Day Company, book publishers, and wife of Richard J. Walsh Jr., former president of the company, died yesterday at FlowerFifth Avenue Hospital following several years of treatment for cancer. She was 59 years old and had been living in retirement with her husband at Sun City, Ariz., for more than a year.

title: 10 Qualify for Classic
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y, July 18  Del Miller, whip in hand, sat in the Monticello Raceway paddock today keenly watching the horses score for the third race. It was minutes before the start of the race, the first of three today that would qualify 10 horses for next Sunday's $300,000 MonticelloNew York City OTB Classic, for 3yearold pacers bred in New York State.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: To U.S. 330Pounder, It's Case of Eat to Lift
description: MONTREAL, July 18 When you weigh 330 pounds and want to become the world's strongest man, you need plenty of food to sustain your energy and strength.

title: Paine Tombstone Uncovered Upstate Revives Mystery About Pamphleteer
description: TIVOLI, N. Y., July 18A tombstone in memory of Thomas Paine was found here yesterday, buried a few feet under the roots of a hemlock tree, creating a new mystery about the whereabouts of the remains of the Revolutionary War pamphleteer and author of Common Sense. place remains a mystery. Mr. McNeil was unable to shed any new light, saying he knew nothing that could link Paine to this once prosperous Hudson River village, near Rhinebeck.

title: Dole for Connally
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention, who has campaigned actively for President Ford, said today that he favored John B. Connally, former Governor of Texas, as a running mate for the President.

title: Janet Tatu Wed to Dr. Richard Holzman
description: Janet Tatu, an elementary school teacher in Willingboro, N. J., and Dr. Richard B. Holzman, superintendent of schools in Cinnaminson, N. J., were married yesterday afternoon at the Princeton University ??? Rabbi Louis Bornstein of Temple Sinai in Cinnaminson performed the ceremony.

title: Economic Meeting in Paris Deadlocked on Procedure
description: PARIS, July 18Developed and developing countries have reached a deadlock in their negotiations here over new international economic structures.

title: POOR NATIONS FEAR U.S., NYERERE SAYS
description: President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania is quoted in the latest issue of Time magazine as saying that the poor nations of the world fear America and we struggle against America, even while we admire the great principles of America and her people's achievements.

title: Belgian First in Tour de France
description: PARIS, July 18 (AP)Lucien Van Impe of Belgium won the 63d Tour de France cycling race today, streaking to a finish down the Champs Elysees before thousands of cheering fans. His overall time in the race that began June 25 and covered about 2,500 miles around France and part of Belgium was 116 hours 22 minutes 23 seconds. Second was Joop Zoetemelk of the Netherlands, trailing by 4 minutes 14 seconds.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: As of this date, we have pie all over the face and the filling tastes more than a little like curried crow. It results from a column we wrote some time ago in which we quoted Lauretta Thistle of Ottawa, who informed us that there was mischief in the curry world. to wit, she had stumbled on a series of recipes calling for leaves and, what's more, there was a local merchant who was selling said leaves labeled curry leaves in a dried form. She was indignant. So were we and, a bit petulantly, stated, perhaps, that anyone worth his weight in turmeric knew that curry powder is a blend of numerous spices. Furthermore, we added, there is no such thing as a curry plant, shrub or tree.

title: French Band Tours the City Streets
description: They sailed into New York on July 2 and marched on Hanover Square two days later. The city hasn't been the same since.

title: A Soviet Carrier Enters Mediterranean First Time
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 18 (ReutersThe 40,000 ton Kiev, regarded in the West as the Soviet Union's first aircraft carrier, sailed through the Bosphorus today for its first appearance in the Mediterranean.

title: Mexico Puts Troops On Patrol to Insure Safety of Tourists
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, July 18Mexican officials, concerned for the lucrative American tourist business, sent armed troops on border patrol this weekend to prevent terrorist attacks and robberies.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTONNearly every business, large or small, at some time or another has to borrow money. And, even though interest on borrowed money is a taxdeductible expense, the interest rate still matters as a cost of doing businessmore so than ever in recent years as interest rates have moved higher.

title: Graham Golf Victor
description: David Graham of Australia won the $60,000 first prize in the Westchester Golf Classic in Harrison yesterday. He shot a final round of 71 and finished with 272, 12 under par, for a threestroke victory. Page 15.

title: Major Break Expected in Mass Abduction
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 18  Law enforcement officials here and in neighboring counties said today that they believed they would soon have a major break in the kidnapping of 26 local schoolchildren and their bus driver last Thursday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State officials are preparing to cope with a flood of income tax returns next spring by using computers and and hiring up to 500 additional people to check taxpayers mathematics. The State Taxation Director, Sidney Glaser, said that computers would go over every figure on returns and that if there are any errors the return will be kicked out. In addition to the computers, he said, some 400 to 500 people would be hired, including auditors, lawyers and clerks, to process returns.

title: Dalai Lama's Brother, NowaJerseyan, Eniovs His fob as a School Janitor
description: In Peking, he dined with Mao Tsetung and Chou Enlai and other Chinese leaders. In his native Tibet, he dealt familiarly with Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norkay, the Sherpa guide, conquerors of Mount Everest. In Lhasa, the capital, he was keeper of the goods of his younger brother, the 14th Dalai Lama, now exiled and living in India.

title: GLORIA SCHAFFER SENATE NOMINEE
description: HARTFORD, July 18Secretary of the State Gloria Schaffer, the leading votegetter in the Connecticut elections two years ago, was chosen today to be the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: Major League Box Scores and Standings

title: SURVEY FINDS OIL NOT COMPETITIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 18A survey of the oil industry shows that it is not competitive, according to Senator Floyd K. Haskell, chairman of the special subcommittee that commissioned the study.

title: Action on Coast Initiative Charged to Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Nine public interest groups charged today that the Energy Research and Development Administration put up an official front of neutrality on a California nuclear safety initiative this spring but actually worked hard to defeat the measure.

title: BOMBINGS STRIKE 8 SPANISH CITIES
description: MADRID, July 18  A series of bombs were exploded in eight Spanish cities yesterday and early today, damaging public buildings and monuments and injuring seven persons.

title: Russians Seeking to Counter Disunity of Talks in East Berlin
description: MOSCOW, July 18As a counterpoint to the conflicts in European Communism, the Soviet Union has been attempting to strengthen its ties with the foreign parties that it already dominates. especially those in Eastern Europe. The effort, which has a long history, has grown more pronounced as nationalist trends and electoral politics have driven some of the West European Communists, among them the Italians and the French, to the periphery of Moscow's ideological orbit.

title: Columbus Golf To Judy Rankin
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 18 (AP)Judy Rankin, who last week became the first Ladies Professional Golf Association player to win $100,000 in a single season, added $10,000 to her winnings today with a fivestroke victory in the $70.000 Columbus Classic. Mrs. Rankin, from Midland, Tex., matched the tournament's low round with a 67 for a 54hole total of 205, 11 strokes under par for the 6,200yard Riviera Country Club course.

title: Scholarship Fund Opens Locked Academic Doors
description: With $300 and a lot of confidence in his students, John Simon got six New York City youths accepted at colleges and private high schools with scholarships totaling $76,000.

title: Olympic Going Is Rough For American Oarsmen
description: MONTREAL, July 18 (AP) American hopes for gold medals in men's rowing faded quickly today after a disappointing day of preliminary Olympic trials.

title: Four Win 2d Races at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18Orison MacPherson, with Jackrabbit in the International Class, and Joachim SchulzHeik and his Soling Class sloop, Lady Katharine, won their second races today on Long Island Sound as a fleet of 255 continued the 78th Larchmont Race Week. MacPherson and SchulzHeik represent the Larchmont Yacht Club.

title: Reductio ad Absurdum
description: President Ford moved quickly the other day to curb one of the silliest interpretations of legislation to come out of Washington in many a year. The Scottsdale, Ariz., school system had asked the Office of Civil Rights in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare if the traditional motherdaughter and fatherson events would violate statutes barring sex discrimination in schools which receive Federal aid. Incredibly, H.E.W. ruled that sponsorship of the events would violate the law.

title: Waldheim Urges Africans to Return
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 (AP)  SecretaryGeneral Kurt Waldheim today urged the African nations boycotting the Montreal Olympics to return to the Games in a spirit of brotherhood and understanding.

title: About New York
description: Many residents of that modest apartment building in Yorkville that figures in this column from time to time find an excuse to be out of work during the summer. The young women, in particular, are apt to spend their weekends and their weeks in the Hamptons, exhausting their savings but renewing minds and hearts, and returning to the city only to report to the unemployment lines.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at at which securities could have been sold (hid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: BEIRUT RIGHTISTS ATTEMPT TO TAKE PALESTINIAN CAMP
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18Christian rightists launched a new attack on the isolated Palestinian camp of Tell Zaatar today as military activities were stepped up on several fronts.

title: 49er Ouits Camp
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 18 (UPI)The San Francisco 49er wide receiver, Terry Beasley, left camp yesterday, saying he wanted to be traded to a team near his home in Alabama. He recently signed a threeyear contract with the National Football League team.

title: WILLIAM ALLEBAUGH
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 18 (AP)William Allebaugh, who supervised the bronze casting of Rhode Island's Independent Man statue, which symbolizes freedom of expression, died Friday at a home for the elderly here. He was 101 years old.

title: Mondale's Staff Preparing for Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, July 18As the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, Senator Walter F. Mondale, was enjoying a last few days of relaxation fishing for walleyed pike in northern Minnesota, his staff was back in Washington getting ready for a week of planning for the campaign.

title: Rubber Strike Nears Record
description: CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP)The rubber workers strike against the industry's four major manufacturers, the first in which all were struck at the same time, will set a record Wednesday if it is still unresolved. The longest previous major strike in the industry came in 1967, when the union, and Uniroyal Inc. held out 97 days. Wednesday will be this strike's 98th cipy and will start its 14th week.

title: As in the Past, Politics and Athletics Mingle at Olympics
description: The withdrawal of more than 20 nations from the Olympic Games that opened in Montreal over the weekend illustrates again that national pride and the glamour of championship sports sometimes force the mingling of international politics and athletics.

title: Sheriff's Descriptions Of Abduction Suspects
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 18Following are descriptions provided by the Madera County Sheriff's office of three suspects wanted in connection with the kidnapping of the 26 school children and their bus driver:

title: News Summary and Index
description: The African boycott of the Olympic Games in Montreal got support from the Caribbean yesterday when Guyana withdrew, bringing the total withdrawal to about two dozen teams involving 600 athletes, as the first day of competition began. The International Olympic Committee will not invoke sanctions against the protesters. Officials of the I.O.C. say that disciplinary measures would only aggravate a very emotional situation. The I.O.C. is not expected to try to arrange a reconciliation either, since it regards the dispute as being beyond its jurisdiction. [Page 1, Columns 56.]

title: Angolan Leader Reported Worried About Dissidents
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 18 (AP)President Agostinho Neto of Angola acknowledged today that his Government was troubled both by continuing guerrilla attacks and dissidents within, the Yugoslav press agency. Tanyug. reported.

title: Viking 1 Prepares for Landing on Mars Tomorrow
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 18After a journey from earth of almost a year and nearly half a billion miles, the first of two Viking landing craft is set to descend to the surface of Mars for what could be the most remarkable landfall thus far in the history of human exploration.

title: Fans Erupt At Big A
description: A disturbance by scores of fans during which five of them climbed over the railing and onto the track and others jostled some of Aqueduct's private police, disrupted yesterday's program at the Big A.

title: McCarthy Isn't Thrilled By Choice of Mondale
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 Former Senator and former Democrat Eugene J. McCarthy, and Independent candidate for the Presidency this year, didn't sound either con vinced or threatened by his old party's show of unity in Madison Square Garden last week. He wasn't much impressed, either, by Jimmy Carter's choice of his old seatmate from Minnesota, Senator Walter F. Mondale. for second spot on the ticket.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Economic Meeting in Paris Deadlocked on Procedure
description: PARIS, July 18Developed and developing countries have reached a deadlock in their negotiations here over new international economic structures.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The voluntary hospital employees strike points up a dilemma which, unlike many of our problems, could be remedied; the poor working conditions, low morale and danger to patients could be avoided. The American ideal is represented by those businesses in which a boyor girlenters at the bottom and rises to the top in terms of merit, application and further education. The good business is one which affords its lesseducated employees a chance at such advancement from stock clerk to programmer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four women overpowered a guard and escaped from the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Bedford. N.Y., but all were recaptured within 12 hours, authorities reported.

title: SCRUGGS AND WHEEL CONTRAST 2 STYLES
description: Country music, a catchall term for folk and popular musical styles from the rural South and Southwest, is patently inadequate when used to categorize groups as different as the Earl Scruggs Review and Asleep at the Wheel. Both groups played to a lively capacity crowd at the Schaefer Festival on Saturday, and both inspired much jubilation, but with radically divergent musical anoroaches.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The African boycott of the Olympic Games in Montreal got support from the Caribbean yesterday when Guyana withdrew, bringing the total withdrawal to about two dozen teams involving 600 athletes, as the first day of competition began. The International Olympic Committee will not invoke sanctions against the protesters. Officials of the I.O.C. say that disciplinary measures would only aggravate a very emotional situation. The 1.0.C. is not expected to try to arrange a reconciliation either, since it regards the dispute as being beyond its jurisdiction. [Page 1. Columns 56.]

title: MORE FLEE HOMES IN MEXICO'S FLOODS
description: MEXICO CITY, July 18 (AP)  Flooding continued today in coastal regions of Mexico and by this evening more than 75,000 persons had fled 13 communities in Tamaulipas and Veracruz states. The crest of the Panuco River surged toward Mexico's Gulf coast.

title: Commodities
description: After the close of trading last Monday, the Government issued its version of grain harvest prospects as of July 1 in which it forecast a record corn crop and the secondbest wheat crop for this year.

title: Viking 1 Prepares for Landing on Mars Tomorrow
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 18After a journey from earth of almost a year and nearly half a billion miles, the first of two Viking landing craft is set to descend to the surface of Mars for what could be the most remarkable landfall thus far in the history of human exploration.

title: Yanks Bow To Rangers In 12th, 32
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 18 Losers of 10 games in a row, the Texas Rangers saw their luck begin to change in the fourth inning against the New York Yankees. Trailing by 20 (both runs unearned), they hit consecutive doubles that landed just inside the foul line for a run, They tied the score, 22, with two out in the ninth and won in the 12th, 32, after surviving their fourth error tonight.

title: Marylander Wins Road Runners Race
description: Bruce Robinson of Bethesda, Md., representing the Washington, D.C., Road Runners Club, won the New York section of the national club's 10mile championships yesterday. The 25yearold Robinson turned in a time of 51 minutes 53.2 seconds. This was the thirdfastest time in the history of New York City postal competition, behind Tom Fleming's 50:09.4 in 1973 and Pete MeArdle's 51:14.1 in 1962.

title: Schmidt Says Israeli Raid. Aided Drive on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (Reuters)  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said in a television interview broadcast today that the Israeli raid Into Uganda to rescue hostages of a hijacking had aided efforts to halt international terrorism.

title: Press Worried by Third World's Move to Restrict Flow of News
description: A major movement appears to be under way by thirdworld and Latin American countries that would restrict the free flow of news reporting in and out of these areas and eventually replace it exclusively with governmentcontrolled information.

title: A Boy, 8, Is Killed Here While Playing With Elevator
description: An 8yearold boy was killed last night while playing with an elevator in his apartment, building at 92 St. Nicholas. Avenue, the police said.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: BOMBINGS STRIKE 8 SPANISH CITIES
description: MADRID, July 18  A series of bombs were exploded in eight Spanish cities yesterday and early today, damaging public buildings and monuments and injuring seven persons.

title: Ford Traffic Security Dents Some Sensibilities
description: HARTFORD, July 18 (AP)  Security measures designed to prevent President Ford from having another fenderbender Saturday left at least 17 unhappy persons.

title: Sweden Pentathlon Leader
description: MONTREAL, July 18 (AP)Hans Lager and Gunnar Jacobson produced perfect scores of 1,100 points in jumping events and helped Sweden gain the lead in the fiveday Olympic modern pentathlon. The United States was in seventh place.

title: Suffolk Still Awash in Controversy Over Detergent Ban
description: SYOSSET, L.I.The rush begins at 5 P.M., when the industrial plants disgorge their workers. The cars stream down Jericho Turnpike, not to a bar for a quick beer, not to a diner for some supper, but to the supermarket for a 20pound box of laundry detergent.

title: Anne Thomas Bride on Coast
description: Anne Cameron Read Thomas and Melburn Coe Knox Jr., both of San Francisco, were married there yesterday morning at the home of the bride. The Rev. Michael McKinley, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: 10 Injured by Bomb Blast In Bus in Tel Aviv Suburb
description: TEL AVIV, July 18 (Reuters) Ten persons were injured when a bomb exploded in a bus in a northern suburb of Tel Aviv today. the police said.

title: Aged Return Home as the Strike Ends
description: Esther Israel sat on a ledge outside the Sephardic Home for the Aged in Brooklyn's Bath Beach section yesterday, resting as her soninlaw went to fetch a wheel chair.

title: Fire Believed to Be Arson Kills 6 in Family in Detroit
description: DETROIT, July 18 (UPI)A flash fire believed to have been arson killed six members of a family today in a crowded twostory home on the city's Southwest Side. Five of the dead were children.

title: Anita Frank Married To Hugh P. Schieren
description: Anita B. Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Frank of the Bronx, was married yesterday evening to Hugh P. Schieren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruben Schieren of Long Beach, L.I.

title: Dalai Lama's Brother, Now aferseyan, Enjoys His Job as a School Janitor
description: In Peking, he dined with Mao Tsetung and Chou Enlai and other Chinese leaders. In his native Tibet, he dealt familiarly with Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norkay, the Sherpa guide, conquerors of Mount Everest. In Lhasa, the capital, he was keeper of the goods of his younger brother, the 14th Dalai Lama, now exiled and living in India.

title: Top Artists Quit Hurok Agency for ICM
description: A number of the world's leading concert artists have dropped Hurok Concerts Inc. as their representative and switched to ICM Artists Ltd., a new management concern headed by Sheldon Gold, who was dismissed as president of Hurok last May.

title: And Now the Election
description: When people have come to think that politics will do nothing for them, they don't careand they don't vote. How does a challenger convince them that the system can be made to work for them?

title: OLAV OLMHOLP
description: Olav Olmhop, president of the GrenzRay Corporation, maker of Xray equipment, died Friday at West Hudson Hospital in Kearny, N. J. He was 75 years old and lived at 6 Woodland Avenue, Kearny. Surviving is a sister, Gunvor.

title: Guyana Pullout Turns Boxer's Golden Dreams to Nightmare
description: MONTREAL, July 18To Kenneth Bristol, the chance to win an Olympic gold medal in boxing was more important than being tied down to a permanent iob.

title: East Meets West in Hare Krishna Fete
description: In size, it was dwarfed by Operation Sail. In popular concern, it was outweighed by the Democratic National Convention.

title: EXSULTAN OF MOROCCO
description: NICE, France, July 18 (AP) Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafat former Sultan of Morocco, died at his villa near Nice today. He was 87 years old.

title: ADM. JOSEPH STIKA OF THE COAST GUARD
description: A retired Coast Guard vice admiral, Joseph E. Stika, a veteran of two world wars, died Wednesday at Marine Hospital in Norfolk, Va. He was 87 years old.

title: Thirty Questions
description: WASHINGTONEight years ago, in an acceptance speech, a nominee used a device that speechwriters call the train whistle, as he spoke of his childhood: I see another child  he hears the train go by at night and he dreams of faraway places.

title: FORD AND REAGAN FAIL TO LOCK UP G.O.P. NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The long, long process of choosing the 2,259 delegates to the Republican National Convention has ended with neither President Ford nor his challenger, Ronald Reagan, able to muster a clear majority.

title: Edward N. Horn, Poet And Novelist, Dies at 73
description: Edward Newman Horn, poet and novelist, died of cancer yesterday at Trafalgar Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 336 Central Park West.

title: Nations Tackle NuclearWaste Disposal
description: DENVER The problems or processing and disposing of radioactive wastes will be resolved within 10 years, according to representatives of nuclear development programs from nonCommunist countries.

title: Some Postal Rates Rise; Fee for Junk Mail Drops
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Postal Service charges for special delivery, insurance, money orders and certified or registered mail went up today. but the cost of sending socalled junk mail came down.

title: Tax Breaks for the Few Hinge on Access to Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 18This year, four welltodo California business executives wanted a special provision in the tax law, one that would apparently benefit no one but them.

title: Jewish Museum Opening Has a Colonial Theme
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15 The Museum of American Jewish History opened here this week, with thanks to the A1mighty for his favor and to the banks for their mortgage.

title: Bridge:
description: The Fun City regional knockout championship at the New York Hilton Hotel during the weekend proved to be a triumph for the seeding committee. All four topseeded teams survived to the semifinal stage, although one of them had a narrow escape in the quarterfinal round: Alan Greenberg of New York and his team won by 3 international match points over Ira Ewen of New York and his side.

title: Advertising
description: The advertising agency growth formula is to make each client a success and grow with it. That's certainly the case with Gerald Rafshoon Advertising of Atlanta. It got a client in 1966 with insignificant billings, but during the rest of this year it will probably bill between $8 million and $10 million.

description: TRENTON, July 18The state will make a big pitch in Washington on Thursday for Federal money to start an energy research center.

description: MONTREAL, July 18The African boycott of the Olympic Games picked up Caribbean support today when Guyana officially withdrew during the first day of competition. Indications were that the total withdrawal would level off at about two dozen teams involving perhaps 600 athletes.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: New York 5, Washington 0. Chicago 7, Hartford 1. Los Angeles 8, Boston 0. Rochester 2, Dallas 0 (n). Portland 2, Vancouver I.

description: DENVER, July 18 (AP) Sheik Jassem alThani, whose brother is the ruler of the Arab state of Qatar, died yesterday at Colorado General Hospital, three days after undergoing exploratory surgery, a hospital snokesman said.

title: Lightning Kills 9 in Italy At AntiFascist Celebration
description: AREZZO, Italy, July 18 (AP) Lightning killed nine persons today when a thunderstorm struck during a celebration here in central Italy.

description: MERIDIAN, Miss., July 18 (UPI) Al Key, who once set an aviation record, died yesterday at a local hospital. He had been injured in an automobile accident two weeks ago. He was 71 years old.

description: Television

title: Graham Golf Victor
description: David Graham of Australia won the $60,000 first prize in the Westchester Golf Classic in Harrison yesterday. He shot a final round of 71 and finished with 272, 12 under par, for a threestroke victory;Page 15.

description: BRANDS HATCH, England, July 18 (AP)James Hunt survived a multicar crash at the start of the race today and became the first English driver in 18 years to win the British Grand Prix, defeating the world champion, Niki Lauda of Austria.

description: TIJUANA, Mexico, July 18Mexican officials, concerned over the possibility of losses in the lucrative American tourist business, sent armed troops on border patrol this weekend to prevent attacks and robberies by armed gangs.

description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 18  Law enforcement officials here and in neighboring counties said today that they believed they would soon have a major break in the kidnapping of 26 local schoolchildren and their bus driver last Thursday.

title: Drug Center Stirs Controversy on Patients Records
description: A small, statefinancial drug rehabilitation and mental health center in Geneseo, N.Y., has become embroiled in a dispute over the confidentiality of patient records, with broad implications.

title: Cyclists Fight Helmet Law
description: HARRISBURG, July 18 (AP)  Hundreds of helmetless motorcyclists assembled today at the tsate Capitol to protest the Pennsylvaia law requiring them to wear helmets. They said that helmets should be worn as a matter of choice for anyone over 18 years old and that helmets were in some ways unsafe because they could cause head injuries.

title: Bruner's World Mark Leads U.S. To Sweep in 200Meter Butterfly
description: MONTREAL, July 18Competition began today in the Games of the XXI Olympiad and with it the start of what may be the fastest swimming meet in history. World records were broken in three of the four opening events, including the men's 200meter butterfly in which the Americans finished one, two, three.

title: Police Buff Is Held In Killing of Woman Who Refused Help
description: A 15year old boy who responded to a call he had heard over his police radio dispatching a patrol car to a Queens street to aid a women was charged with her murder yesterday.

title: Black Students Riot in South Africa; Third University Is Ordered Closed
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 18Demonstrating students at one of South Africa's three black universities today threw a gasoline bomb into one of the main campus buildings and damaged others before being subdued by policemen using tear gas.

title: Westchester Golf To David Graham
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 18 There were no heroics, no late charges, and indeed, it was nearly soporific: David Graham simply cruised the course at even par, challenging the field to catch him. No one was able to put any heat on him, and so, Graham won the 10th Westchester Classic today by three strokes and took the $60,000 first prize.

title: Latin Refugees End Protest, Citing Resettlement Promise
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 18 (Reuters)  About 600 Latin American political refugees ended a hunger strike here today after receiving assurances that they would be resettled in other countries as soon as possible, a refugee spokesman said.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The heaviest artillery in the campaign against the existing international economic order is aimed at the world's commodity markets. The havenot nations are shooting for a greater share of control over commodity pricing, more price stability and higher prices for a number of raw materials.

description: Radio

title: Close Ties to Its Former Colonial Ruler Are Aiding a Prosperous Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory CoastThis is the Switzerland of Africa, said the American banker, swiveling around in his chair to catch a confirming viewwhite skyscrapers, broad parks and busy bridges.

title: Limit Order to Broker Can Save a Trader Money
description: It is an understatement to say that in recent years the average investor has had trouble making money in the stock market. But rubbing salt into this wound is the fact that commission rates, at the same time, have been going up. Thus, in a sense, the investor is paying more to make less. Since May 1, 1975, with the advent of fully negotiated rates, the commission situation for the average investor has become even more painful.

title: PASSPORTS REVOKED BY INDIA FOR 3 IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Indian Government has impounded the passports of three more citizens of India who live in the United States and are leaders of Indians for Democracy, an migr organization that opposes the policies of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHORESIDE Starting tonight, square dancing and ethnic folk dancing will be featured on six consecutive Mondays, beginning at 7:30 o'clock, at the South Street Seaport, Fulton Street and the East River, with audiences encouraged to join either group.

description: Dividend Meetings

title: ARCHITECTS SCORED ON HOUSING PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)A Governmentfinanced report released today gives architects part of the blame for the increasing vandalism, burglaries and muggings in huge apartment projects.

title: Seewagen Beats Guerry in Final
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., July 18 (AP)  In a match interrupted by rain, Butch Seewagen of New York beat Zan Guerry of Houston, 64, 64, today and won the $10,000 Waterville Valley open tennis tournament. It was the opener of the sixtournament American Express Challengers circuit. Seewagen and Guerry were teammates at rice University.

title: Screen: 'My Friends,' Italian Comedy:4 Middle-Aged Men in the Provinces Outrageous Practical Jokes in a Parable
description: Their lives are going nowhere except into loveless middle age. Mascetti (Ugo Tognazzi) has gone through two fortunes (his wife's and his own) and makes a living of sorts in the door-to-door selling of encyclopedias. Melandri (Gastone Moshin) is an architect of no great promise. Perozzi (Philippe Noiret), separated from his wife and father of a maddeningly fastidious son (the sort of fellow who puts a tarpaulin over his car at night), is a crime reporter, a job he's had too long, and Necchi (Duilio Del Prete) runs the local bar where the friends hang out.Their lives are going nowhere but does it really matter? That's the question that is answered in sometimes uproariously funny terms in "My Friends," a new Italian comedy that was directed by Mario Monicelli ("Big Deal on Madonna Street") after the death of Pietro Germi ("DivorceItalian Style." "Seduced and Abandoned"), who had collaborated on the screenplay and prepared the production for filming."My Friends," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is a cross between Claude Sautet's "Vincent, Franois, Paul and the Others" and Federico Fellini's "I Vitelloni." It's a film about supportive male friendship, set in the Italian provinces, and though the milieu is bleak, the comedy is blithe.Singly, each of the men is a failure, with the possible exception of the bar owner, whose life is simply boring. Together, on their occasional "gypsy" outings, they discover a sense of camaraderie that becomes purpose. The friends, who've grown up together and know each other so well they can communicate virtually without talking, devote themselves to the outrageous practical joke.Sometimes the joke is not elaborate, only a trip to the station where they have a high old time with the passengers on a train just as it's pulling out. The passengers can't respondthe train is carrying them off at mounting speedand though it's never stated, it may be that in this particular joke, the four friends are doing to strangers what life has done to them. It's as if each man were trying to deal with a mysterious, totally inexplicable slap in the face.Sometimes the jokes are terribly elaborate, as when they execute a series of complex charades for the benefit of a stingy old pensioner (Bernard Blier), who believes that the four friends are members of a Mafia drug-selling ring. At least once the joke backfires with curious results.When Melandri, the architect, thinks he has fallen madly in love with the wife of a local doctor, the friends court her for him with obscene telephone calls that are enormously successful. Melandri wins the wife, as well as her two children, the governess and a giant dog, while the doctor (Adolfo Celi) does not lose a wife, he gains four lunatic friends. It turns out that he is their soul brother.Before someone writes in to note that "My Friends" appears to take a pretty dim view of women, I should say that may be true, except that isn't the point of the film, which, if I understand it correctly, uses provincial Italian manners to illustrate a parable about self-realization.The four friends of "My Friends" achieve this only in the company of one another, and always in the performance of the practical joke that is the metaphor of the movie. Having said this, I'm afraid that I've made "My Friends" sound lugubrious. It isn't. Its method is marvelously comic and the mood gallant.In addition to the actors, who are superb, the film features several performances of equal exuberance by actresses, especially by Angela Goodwin, who plays Mascetti's pretty young mistress, who uses him as he uses her, and Olga Karlatos, as the beauty who is so successfully wooed by telephone."My Friends," which carries a PG rating, contains one quick scene of female nudity and a scatological joke that is among the funniest things in the film.

title: Dibbs Bows To Tanner In Net Final
description: CINCINNATI, July 18 (UPI)  Roscoe Tanner recovered in both sets to defeat topseeded Eddie Dibbs, 76, 63, in the final of the $100,000 Western tennis championship today.

title: FORD AND REAGAN FAIL TO LOCK UP G.O.P. NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The long, long process of choosing the 2,259 delegates to the Republican National Convention has ended with neither President Ford nor his challenger, Ronald Reagan, able to muster a clear majority.

title: The Dance
description: Lynn Seymour, who is appearing with the American Ballet Theater this season as a guest artist, is one of the Royal Ballet's most gifted ballerinas. Audiences who have seen her here with the British company know her as a magnificent danceractress. She has been unmatched in many roles in contemporary ballets. In romantic roles such as Giselle, she has brought an emotional depth that has made such 19thcentury ballets speak persuasively to a modern public.

title: Legal Conflicts Subdued in Harris Trial as State's Witnesses Testify, but a Battle Looms Over a Tape
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 For four days, the state's 11 major witnesses in the trial of William and Emily Harris have told the jury about their experiences with the revolutionary couple and Patricia Hearst some two years ago, experienees some described as friendly, zany or frightening.

title: Mongoose, Oui
description: MONTREAL. July 18Far from the clash of ideologies and politics, Archie Moore relaxed today in his home beside the Wabash Freeway in San Diego, the splendid house with the swimming pool shaped like a boxing glove. title: DeBrito Is Victor
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 18 Carlos DeBrito, a Hampton Institute freshman from Brazil, upset topseeded John Hayes of Cos Cob, Conn., 46, 62, 6.4, to win the Eastern claycourt men's championship today at the Valley Tennis Court.

title: Homer Wood, 96, Lawyer, Owned California Papers
description: Homer Wood, a lawyer and West Coast newspaper publisher, died Sunday in Porterville, Calif. He was 96 years old.

title: Yonkers Raceway Open for Summer
description: YONKERS, July 19 With some of America's top trotting and pacing events on its agenda, Yonkers Raceway tonight opened a 78program meeting with speculation among tans about the track's future as a major harness racing establishment. The big question was how much the popular haltmile track, which provided $40 million in revenue last year to the state, Westchester County and the city of Yonkers, would suffer from competition once the Meadowlands track in New Jersey opens for the first time Sept. 1.

title: Volume Advances
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday an increase in secondquarter net Income from the depressed yearearlier level. Sales rose 20 percent to $2.16 billion.

title: HOSING STARTS ROSE 4% IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Housing starts rose moderately in June as the longsluggish sector of apartment house building continued its slow rebound, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Market Place
description: Two of Wall Street's bestknown theories on forecasting stock prices appear to be on a collision course. One has just flashed a signal that higher prices are ahead. The other soon may flash a warning signal that the market is headed downward.

title: Future Kind Sampled U.S. Life in 1797
description: PARIS, July 19The future King of France, Louis Philippe, Duke of Orlans, was 24 years old when he and his two younger brothers, the Duke of Montpensier and the Count of Beaujolais, with their manservant Beaudoin, visited the United States in 1797.

title: Albany Reports a Decline In Claims of Unemployment
description: ALBANY, July 19 (UPI) The State Labor Department said today that 48,346 persons filed new claims for unemployment compensation during the week ended July 9, down 206 from the previous week.

title: Fire Damages a Press At The New York Times
description: A printing press caught fire at The New York Times last night about two hours before the scheduled run of today's first edition.

title: SAMUEL HARBISON DIES IN PITTSBURGH
description: PITTSBURGH, July 19 Dr. Samuel P. Harbison, admissions director of the University of Pittsburgh medical school. where he was a professor of surgery and former associate dean, died today in his home He was 67 years old.

description: The Mets lost Dave Kingman, the major leagues leading slugger, for at least six weeks when the outfielder tore a ligament in his left thumb trying for a diving catch last night at Shea Stadium.

title: New North River Plant May Be Downgraded
description: The North River sewagetreatment plant probably will not provide the kind of treatment that was intended  if it is ever built at all.

title: New York Opens a Study Of Hospital Strike Deaths
description: A study was begun yesterday by the New York City Health Department to find out how many deaths, if any, might have been caused by the 11day hospital strike that ended last Saturday.

title: Prospective Jurors Being Questioned In Howe Sex Case
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 19 (UPI)  Representative Allan Howe went on trial today on charges of soliciting as a result of allegedly offering $20 to two policewomen posing as prostitutes.

title: Kresge Fund Gives PBS $1.55 Million for Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Public Broadcasting Service announced today it had received a grant of $1.55 million to help public television stations put into use their planned satellite interconnection system.

title: CORRECTION

Copies of the report can he obtained from the center at 1521 16th Street, N.W., Washington, D. C. 20036.

title: Pentagon Official Attacks Bill for Aiding Shippers
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  A Pentagon expert said today the Household Goods Forwarders Association of America was trying to push through Congress a special interest bill to keep the Government from saving millions each year on overseas shipment of servicemen's belongings.

title: U.S. Delays Evacuation of 400 in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 (UPI) Citing security reasons, the United States Embassy today postponed the departure of an evacuation convoy of more than 400 Americans and foreigners from embattled Beirut.

title: Gold Stocks Are Weak; Dow Average Dips 2.38
description: Gold issues and a number of prominent technology stocks were weak yesterday as the market turned downward in relatively slow trading.

title: House Aide Reports Progress in Inquiry Into Disclosure of Report on Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  A fourmonth, $150,000 investigation has narrowed the search but has not yet found the person who made an unauthorized disclosure of the report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, a House investigator testified today.

description: BETHESDA, Md., July 19 Directors of breast cancer detection projects around the country defended today the continued use of an Xray examination called mammography to screen ostensibly healthy women below the age of 50 years for hidden breast cancer.

description: DENPASAR, Indonesia, July 19 (AP) The toll in the earthquake in Bali five days ago has risen to more than 500 people killed and 3,400 injured, the Governor's office reported today.

title: CARTER TO PLAN STRATEGY TODAY
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 19 Jimmy Carter, who has been relatively at rest here since he returned from New York City Friday night, will hold his first campaign strategy meeting tomorrow since he became the Democratic Presidential nominee. He is scheduled to meet with several of his principal advisers and a representative of Senator Walter F. Mondale, his running mate.

description: Dividends

title: INQUIRY FOCUSES ON HOOVER'S LINK TO AN F.B.I. FUND
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 The Justice Department is investigating the possibility that funds belonging to the Federal Bureau of Investigatibn's Recreational Association were converted to the use of J. Edgar Hoover, the late F.B.I. director, and other senior bureau officials.

title: Security After Entebbe
description: The hijacking of an Air France plane that culminated in the brilliant rescue operation at Entebbe airport in Uganda is an incident that now belongs to history. But what is still very much alive is the problem of enforcing and improving airline and airport security in order to prevent such hijackings in the future. One would have thought by this time that enough had already been said and donein the wake of many such hijackings in the pastto have resulted in procedures that would have thwarted this latest murderous attempt on the lives of civilian airline passengers.

title: Helpin New York
description: It was Jerry Barnwell's birthday, and since he had not spoken except for an occasional monosyllable since he entered the Broadjump summer program nine days ago, the director thought a surprise party might help.

title: Reagan Camp Denials
description: LOS ANGELES. July 19 Everyone in the Reagan campaign but Ronald Reagan, himself stepped forward today to deny reports that they are losing hope in the cliffhanging struggle with. President Ford.

title: Concert: Couple at Piano
description: This year's Mostly Mozart Festival is taking advantage of its more intimate surroundings in Tully Hall in a number of ways. Chamber music, of course, is getting extra attention, and a special series of six weekly piano recitals got under way on Sunday night with the joint appearance of Claude Frank and his wife, Lilian Kallir.

title: Player Agreement Ratified by Owners
description: Major league baseball's owners have voted to ratify the fouryear agreement with the Players Association that was reached during last week's AllStar break, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced vesterday.

title: A Guarantee Policy In Rhodesia Shaped By U.S. and Britain
description: LONDON, July 19The United States and Britain seeking to persuade the Rhodesian Government to negotiate a transfer to black majority ride, are quietly shaping a joint policy that assures financial aid and property guarantees to the white minority, according to diplomatic sources in London.

description: The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had levied a $10,000 fine against one of its specialist firms for permitting the price of a listed stock to plunge nearly 50 percent in two hours without moving to halt trading because the market had become disorderly.

title: AMEX INDEX DROPS IN HEAVY SELLING
description: A spate of selling on inflation fears brought prices lower on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter markets yesterday.

title: Federal Law Proposed To Bar Bus Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Legislation to make the hijacking of a bus a Federal offense with penalties comparable with those for airplane hijacking was introduced today by Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of Westchester.

description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rales for Monday.

description: After achieving what even an I.B.M. computer had con

title: Sheriffs Believe They Know Identities of Abductors of 26 Children
description: MADERA, Calif., July 19 Law enforcement officials investigating the kidnapping last Thursday from nearby Chowchilla of 26 summer school students and their bus driver said today they believed they knew the identities of the abductors. They said they expected to make at least one arrest very soon.

title: Two New Television Aides Added to the Ford Staff
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) White House officials said today that President Ford had installed two former New York television experts, Don Penny and Daniel Fitzgerald, as his new television advisers.

title: A Guarantee Policy In Rhodesia Shaped By U.S. and Britain
description: LONDON, July 19 The United States and Britain, seeking to persuade the Rhodesian Government to negotiate a transfer to black majority rule, are quietly shaping a joint policy that assures financial aid and property guarantees to the white minority, according to diplomatic sources in London.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Pledges Support to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Pledging allout support, the A.F.L.C.I.O. abandoned its neutral political posture today and endorsed the Democratic ticket of Jimmy Carter for President and Walter F. Mondale for Vice President.

title: Grant Aims to Amplify Canadian Ballet
description: The National Ballet of Canada returns tonight to the Metropolitan Opera House for the fifth time since 1973 and for the first time since Alexander Grant became its artistic director.

title: Hearst Bullet Said to Have Hit a House 6 Blocks Away
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19 Patricia Hearst fired so erratically at a sporting goods store to help William and Emily Harris escape arrest on May 16, 1974, that a bullet struck a house six blocks away and bounced into a driveway where children were playing, according to a Prosecutor witness.

title: Blast and Fire Injure 8
description: Blast and Fire Injure 8

title: The People Beeper: It's Peace of Mind To Some, Electronic Leash to Others
description: What is to be made of the people beeperthe electronic paging device housed in a little black box hat hangs on a person's belt or nestles in a purse?

title: News Summary and Index
description: The International Olympic Committee said yesterday that 17 nations and 465 delegates had officially left Olympic Village in Montreal or made final plans to do so. The withdrawal, led by predominantly black African countries, resulted from New Zealand's approval of a rugby team's tour of South Africa despite that country's apartheid policy. Among the departing countries were Kenya, Nigeria and Ethiopia. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Understanding Italy
description: At this critical time when Giulio Andreotti is striving to construct a Government capable of halting Italy's slide toward economic collapse, one major service that country's partners can perform is to refrain from public admonition and threats. It is even more important for allied governments to eschew such hectoring now than it was during the election campaign that brought further gains for the Italian Communist Party in the June balloting.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: New Rule By I.O.C. Has Teeth
description: MONTREAL, July 19 (UPI) The International Olympic Committee, in a move to stop future governmental influence in its affairs, passed a rule today giving the committee onthespot power to expel nations that break I.O.C. rules. The rule, headed supreme authority. would apply to countries withdrawng from competition on political grounds.

title: Thomas Paine Mystery At Tivoli, N.Y., Solved
description: WHITE PLAINS. July 19 The mystery of a Thomas Paine tombstone discovered nearly 100 miles north of the Revolutionary author's original burial place in New Rochelle was apparently resolved today. The tombstone was a token of admiration ordered by a local resident one century ago.

title: AMY CARTER MAY GO TO A PUBLIC SCHOOL
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) If the Jimmy Carter family moves to Washington after the November elections, 8yearold Amy Carter may be sent to the oldest public school in the District of Columbia.

title: ROBERT MORSE, 54, FORMERLY ON LIFE
description: Robert Morse, former news bureau chief for Life magazine, was drowned Friday near his home in Poros, Greece, according to word reaching his brother in Oregon. He was 54 years old.

title: Carpenters Strike Talks Are Bogged Down Upstate
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., July, 19 (AP) A strike of several hundred carpenters continuel into its sixth day in four upstate cities today with negotiations stalled.

title: Pirates Slay Two On Crippled Sloop, Coast Guard Says
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 19 (UPI) Two Americans were slain yesterday by four Spanishspeaking pirates who hoarded their crippled sailing sloop off the coast of Colombia, according to the Coast Guard. Two other Americans survived the early morning attack.

title: Hog Cholera Case Reported
description: BOSTON, July 19 (UPI) The Department of Agriculture said today that it had uncovered another outbreak of hog cholera in Massachusetts. The new case was discovered last Saturday in a herd of 400 hogs in Holden, the agency said. The disease affects only hogs and is not a danger to humans or other animals.

title: Astronomers Form System to Chart Sources of Radio Emissions in Space
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 19 Radio astronomers in Maryland, California, Australia and the Soviet Union have banded together to form an observing system as wide as the earth. It is capable of determining the angular width of objects as narrow as a human hair 100 miles away.

title: Ford Names Woman To Key Air Force Post
description: Ford Names Woman To Key Air Force Post

title: FUTURES PRICES OF GOLD IN SLIDE
description: Gold futures prices have dropped sharply in the aftermath of last week's auction by the International Monetary Fund and yesterday the decline continued, taking prices to the lowest levels in 18 months. The I.M.F. plans another sale on Sept 15.

title: U.S. Women's Five Falls to Japan, 8471
description: MONTREAL, July 19 (AP) Women's basketball made its debut as an Olympic Games event today, with the United States losing the first game to Japan, 8471, and with the Soviet Union unleashing a 7foot2inch, 281pound center.

title: Savings May Revive Convention Center
description: The chairman of the Munici pal Assistance Corporation proposed yesterday that savings realized from the latest plan to stretch out city debt obligations he used to help finance New York City's proposed new convention center.

title: Custom Shoemakers Cling to a Vanishing Art
description: The room Is small and crowded. Shoes are piled everywhere, and models of feet of every imagiriable shape and size are strewn around the floor. The air is pleasantly redolent of glue and tanned skins. There is the sound of a hammer tapping a soft surface, and nearby, the bent figure of the shoemaker, stitching the sole on a shoe.

title: Light on Swine Flu
description: Six months have passed since the localized swine flu epidemic occurred at Fort Dix. With the passage of time, there has been an increasing incongruity between the panic measures advocated by President Fordand reaffirmed by him yesterdayand the reality that not a single natural case of this supposedly deadly disease has been observed in this period. Meanwhile, the national swine flu immunization program is bogged down in disputes over insurance for suits that might arise from the vaccination effort.

title: Leftists in Spain Say They Set Off Bombs in 8 Cities
description: MADRID, July 19 An extreme left Marxist organization has claimed responsibility for a wave of bombings in eight Spanish cities over the weekend.

title: Exiles in Argentina Reported Seized
description: BUENOS AIRES. July 19 A new largescale kidnapping of Uruguayan political refugees was reported here today by the United Nations High Commission for refugees.

title: U.S., Soviet in Pact On Shipping Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The United States announced today the signing of an agreement in principle with the Soviet Union designed to curtail Russian undercutting of United States shipping charges.

title: Britain to Leave Last Mideast Bases
description: MUSCAT, Oman, July 19 (Reuters) The Omani Government announced today that Britain would withdraw next March from air bases has used on Masira Island and at the southern town of SalaIa. The installations are Britain's last in the Middle East.

title: CHICAGO JAZZMEN A HIT IN NEW YORK
description: Muhal Richard Abrams is a pianist and composer from Chicago whose presence was felt in the New York jazz world long before he began playing locally. As the founder of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a Chicago musicians cooperative, he has been regarded as an inspiration by a number of Midwest musicians who preceded him to Manhattan.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings
description: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings

title: Results of Olympic Games at Montreal
description: Results of Olympic Games at Montreal

title: Advertising
description: Now that fortune has begun at long last to smile on the Russell, Harris, Levenson advertising agency, its three partners can also smile. And Edward T. Russell, the president, can look back to May and June without cringing and say, We really had some sweatingbullets days.

title: Lebanese Shoppers Visit an Israeli Town
description: QIRYAT SHEMONA, Israel, July 19 Israel allowed shoppers from wartorn Lebanon through its formidable security fence today to shop in this border town, which has been intermittently shelled by guerrillas from Lebanese territory.

title: Tuna Concern Pays Costs In Check on Short Weight
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 19 (UPI) The Nassau County Consumer Affairs Commissioner, James E. Picken, said today that inspectors from his office, in response to complaints, had found 65 cans of StarKist tuna that were shortweighted by up to of an ounce.

title: Woman Killed by Arrow Identified in Connecticut
description: The Stamford, Conn., police said yesterday that the woman apparently killed by an arrow has been identified through dental charts as Marge Olson. a 24yearold waitress, who had moved from Stamford to Norwalk, Conn., within the last month.

title: Ballet: Yoko Morishita
description: The partnership of Fernando Bujones and the Japanese ballerina, Yoko Moroshita, is one of considerable interest. Not merely because Mr. BuJones is one Of America's leading dancers, but even more because in Miss Mornchits we are really seeing our first extended glimpse of a Japanese ballerina developed in Japan. This, frankly, is somethine exotic.

title: Europe's TV News Stars Begin to Shine
description: PARIS, July 19 European television, after decades staid if not stodgy presentation of the news, is rapidly developingwith a smile here and a smirk there and a nuance of inflectionits own newscasting personalities.

title: Violence in the Amazon: Brazil Echoes U.S. West
description: PARAGOMINAS, Brazil, July 14In scenes vividly reminiscent of the taming of the American West, large landowner, squatters and Indians are pitted against each other in violent clashes as Brazil burns, hacks and plows its way through the Amazon jungles, an area twothirds the size of the continental United States.

title: MELVIN M. ABOFF, 53, PAINT STORE OWNER
description: Melvin M. Aboff of Huntington Bay, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., philanthropist and owner of Aboffs chain of paint stores, drowned Sunday afternoon in Fairchild's Cove off Lloyd Neck, L.I., while swimming.

title: Violence in the Amazon: Brazil Echoes U.S. West
description: PARAGOMINAS, Brazil, July 14 In scenes vividly reminiscent of the taming of the American West, large landowner, squatters and Indians are pitted against each other in violent clashes as Brazil burns, hacks and plows its way through the Amazon jungles, an area twothirds the size of the continental United States.

title: U.S. Men Smash 3 World Swim Marks And Capture 2 Gold Medals in Olympics
description: MONTREAL, July 19 John Naber won an Olympic gold medal in swimming tonight and broke a world record. Fiftyfive minutes later, he almost won another gold medal (Bruce Furniss did) and almost broke another world record (Furniss did that, too).

title: BENEFITS STUDIED FOR CANCER TESTS
description: The Blue Cross Association said yesterday that the recent sharply rising cancer death rate in this country and rising costs of health care had spurred it to take a first step toward providing coverage for screening tests to diagnose malignant tumors at an earlier stage among its nearly 90 million subscribers.

title: State Gets Nine Calls About Lottery Tickets
description: At least nine persons have called in about winning tickets in the belated drawing Friday that completed last October's lottery, John. Quinn, director of the New York State Lottery, announced Yesterday.

title: House Votes to Give Five More Years To the Delta Queen
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The riverboat Delta Queen moved closer to five more years of life today with a House vote to extend her exemption from Federal laws that bar most wooden passenger vessels.

title: Law Officer Killings Down
description: WASHINGTON. July 19 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that 58 state and local law enforcement officers were killed by criminal action in the first six months of this year, compared with 64 slain during the same period of 1975.

title: Wietecha's Hopes Are High Walking the Line for Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 19 The Giants, admitted Ray Wietecha today, were in limbo the last few years.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN NOW HAS MAJORITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Ronald Reagan has the support of 1,140 delegates to the Republican National Convention, or 10 more than a majority, the executive vice chairman of his campaign, John P. Sears, said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that municipalities must still call for competitive bids on garbage contracts even though the business is now regulated as a public utility. The court rejected, 70, an appeal by the Borough of Saddle River, which had difficulty finding a garbage collector for the town. Saddle River officials contended that garbage collection contracts should be subject only to negotiations and approval by the Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

title: STATE WILL STUDY L.I.R.R. DISMISSAL
description: Governor Carey's legal staff said yesterday it planned to review the case of Roy W. Tate, a Long Island Rail Road engineer who was dismissed in 1973 after the passenger train he was operating hit a standing freight train at the Ronkonkoma station.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WNCNFM. Eclogue, Liszt; Alcina Overture, Handel; FourNote Pavan, Farrant; Concerto Grosso No. 11, Corelli; Morning, Noon and Night in Vienna, Suppe; Fugue in D, Bach; Rondo (K. 386), Mozart; Spanish Dance No. 6. Granados; Etude in Csharp minor. Scriabin; Two Sonatas for Violin and Guitar. Paganini, Micaela's Air from Carmen, Bizet; Overture to Russian and Ludmila, Glinka; Pastorale and Toccata, Scarlatti. 7:308:55, WNYCFM. Overture 1812, Tchaikovsky; Variations on La Follia for Recorder, Corelli; Chaconne pour Orchestre, Berton; Quintet for Horn, Violin, Two Violas and Cello. Mozart; ThreeCornered Hat Suite No. 1, Falla.

title: ABUSES CHARGED IN EYEGLASS SALES
description: A fivemonth study by the Department of Consumer Affairs in New York City has found that one in five eye examinations given by the optometric establishments that were surveyed resulted in unnecessary prescriptions for eyeglasses, according to Elinor, Guggenheimer, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner.

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691803; CONNECTICUT (203) 3467767.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: LEAD

title: Blacks College Gains
description: One of the most important findings of educational research is that educational attainment and income are closely related to each other. In other words, the more years of schooling a person has, the higher his income is likely to be.

title: Aide Says New Limits on Contributions Helped Carter Campaign
description: WASHINGTON. July 19 Jimmy Carter might not have won the Democratic Presidential nomination if the new campaign law had not imposed the first limits in American political history on the size of campaign contributions.

title: CORRECTION
description: The National Center for Urban Ethnic Affairs, which recently issued a report on troubled older neighborhoods in large cities, is an independent agency affiliated with the United States Catholic Conference, not Catholic University, as stated in an article in The Times on July 12. Copies of the report can be obtained from the center at 1521 16th Street, N.W., Washington, D. C. 20036.

title: Hawks Coach Hires Old Friend
description: A pair of former Niagara University roommates and basketball teammates were reunited yesterday when Frank Layden joined Hubie Brown as the assistant coach of the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR A PROSECUTOR OF U.S. OFFICIALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 19President Ford called today for the creation of a permanent special prosecutor's office to investigate wrongdoing by Government officials. He also said that it would be up to the American people to decide whether his pardon of President Nixon would be a campaign issue.

title: MRS. GRASSO'S FOE WINS REELECTION
description: HARTFORD, July 19 The Democratic state chairman in Connecticut, William A. O'Neill, won reelection by a wide margin tonight despite the determination of Gov. Ella T. Grasso to remove him.

title: Former New Yorker Donates $5,000 to City
description: An expatriate New Yorker has sent the city $5,000 of her own retirement money in gratitude for some oldage welfare and as a boost to the city in coming out of the red.

title: Disclosure of Informant's Name Is Ordered in a Suit Over Arrest
description: MORRISTOWN, July 19 In a highly unusual move, a Superior Court judge ordered today the release of the name of a confidential police informant whose tip was used by three detectives to arrest falselv a Wharton man on bookmaking charges in 1970.

title: Other Highlights
description: BASKETBALLThe Soviet Union beat Australia, 9377. The United States women were defeated by Japan, 8471, in the first Olympic women's basketball game.

title: Yankees Win, 32, On Save by Lyle
description: CHICAGO, July 19  The Yankees, who had exercised such mastery over the White Sox this season that they couldn't wait to get to Chicago, had to wait an extra hour and 25 minutes before playing the Sox tonight.

title: Zambia Asks U.N. Council To Meet on Border Incident
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 Zambia has requested a meeting of the Security Council to take up charges that South Africa attacked a border town last week, killing 22.

title: Sanitation Protestin Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, July 19 (UPI) Several hundred sanitation workers marched on city hall on a oneday holiday today while garbage began to pile up on the city's streets. The holiday was called by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees union to dramatize a demand for a $500 annual pay increase it said had been promised but rescinded by Mayor Maynard Jackson.

title: Murphy, Solarz and Stratton Top List Of MostTraveled Congressmen in 75
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 Three New York State Congressmen were among the most traveled of the 535 members of the House and Senate in 1975, encircling the globe, usually at taxpayer's expense, according to a report published today.

title: British Leyland Unveils a New Rover Sedan in Revival Push
description: LONDON, July 19  This month, Britons have been assaulted by a cacaphony of publicity celebrating the debut of a new automobile. It's an annual event as much a part of summer as Henley and strawberries.

title: OLYMPIC GAMES LOSE 17 NATIONS
description: MONTREAL. July 19 The five interlocking Olympic rings symbolizing world brotherhood suffered another major blow today when 17 nations vith 465 athletes officially left the Olympic Village or made final plans to do so.

title: Sales Climb 52%
description: The United Technologies Corporation, the nation's largest producer of aircraft engines and elevators, reported yesterday profit increases of 29.2 percent for this year's second quarter and 26.9 percent for the first six months, reflecting a rise in sales of 52 percent for the quarter and 47 percent for the half.

title: The Story of a Facelift: A Painful Search for Self
description: Joyce, it would seem, has everything.

title: Movies in Park, Part II, To Begin Tonight in S.I.
description: The second program of this summer's Movies in the Park, the series of free films soonsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center Inc., in cooperation with the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, will be presented at Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island tonight at 9 o'clock. It can be seen in Brooklyn's Prospect Park tomorrow and at Cunningham Park, Queens, Thursday.

title: Viking Poised for Landing And Mars Pictures Today
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 19The exploration of Mars by camera, soil scoop and lifedetection instruments is scheduled to begin early tomorrow when the Viking I landing craft should be settling gently on a broad arid plain of the planet.

title: Gottfried and Fillol Upset in Openers
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Two upsets marked the opening round of the $125,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament today.

title: Msgr. H. J. Watterson. 101, Pastor Emeritus in Jersey
description: Msgr. Henry J. Watterson, pastor emeritus of Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, Westfield, N.J., died Friday at the age of 101 in a nursing home in Scotch Plains, N.J. He had retired in 1968 after serving as pastor for 55 years.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  President Ford announced today that he was nominating Juanita Ashcraft, a former assisant appointments secretary to former Gov. Ronald Reagan, of California, as Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for manpower and reserve affairs.

title: Mondale Goes Water Skiing
description: HIBBING. Minn., July 19 (AP) Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, went skiing today as he continued a brief vacation before returning to Washington tomorrow. He is expected to spend next weekend with the Presidential nominee, Jimmy Carter, in Plains, Ga.

title: The Danger of Ideology
description: With so many genuine and difficult problems confronting the nation, it would be most unfortunate if the 1976 Presidential campaign should degenerate into an ideological slugfest.

title: State Says Farms Housed Workers in Chicken Coops
description: TRENTON, July 19  The State Department of Labor and Industry sued two South Jersey poultry farmers today, charging them with exploitation of nine workers by housing them in converted chicken coops and illegally deducting excessive rent from their pay.

title: Notes on People
description: In Moscow yesterday, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Thomas P. Hoving, director of the Metropolitun Museum of Art, met with Ministry of Culture officials and lunched with United States Ambassador Walter Stoessel Jr. They planned to view a Kremlin exhibit of Russian costumes before traveling to Leningrad today with their party. It is Mrs. Onassis's first trip to the Soviet Union.

title: The Charlotte Ford Look
description: If there's a Ford in your future this fall, it may well be on your back.

title: Viking Poised for Landing And Mars Pictures Today
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 19 The exploration of Mars by camera, soil scoop and lifedetection instruments is scheduled to begin early tomorrow when the Viking 1 landing craft should be settling gently on a broad arid plain of the planet.

title: INQUIRY FOCUSES ON HOOVER'S LINK TO AN F.B.I. FUND
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 The Justice Department is investigating the possibility that funds belonging to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Recreational Association were converted to the use of J. Edgar Hoover, the late F.B.I. director, and other senior bureau officials.
