description: NEWARK, July 20 (AP)New Jersey had 7 percent more crime in 1975 than in 1974, with the greatest increase occurring in rural areas, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said in a report released today.

title: M.A.C. Throws a Party To Mark Its 1st Birthday
description: Except for the police helicopter circling overhead and the fivespray salute from a fireboat, it might have been almost any group of revelers, who jammed the decks of a Circle Line party boat for last night's threehour cruise.

title: Mets Sink Reds, 21 For Koosman's 11th
description: CINCINNATI, July 20Will the injury to Dave Kingman stymie the weak attack of the New York Mets? Will the Mets pitching staff start to press to make up for fewer runs? Will the loss of Kingman for the next six weeks put a crimp in the Mets will to win?

title: Three Striking Electrical Unions Agree on a Westinghouse Pact
description: PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP)  Three electrical workers unions staging a nationwide strike against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed today to new threeyear contracts.

title: Fireworks Aug. 3 to Open Philharmonic Park Series
description: A fireworks display over Central Park's Sheep Meadow will highlight the New York Philharmonic's concert on Tuesday night, Aug. 3, when the orchestra's 12th season of f rce programs in the city's parks opens. Andre Kostelanetz will conduct the first week of the threeweek series, followed by Thomas Schippers and Erich: Leinsdorf.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Levitt Criticizes Goldin On PettyCash Analysis
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt released another of his critiques of government agencies yesterday, using his impersonal, numbersstudded style to deliver what some politicians took as a significant message: Don't mess with the master.

title: Spain Forty Years After
description: PARISKing Juan Carlos's choice as his first personally selected Prime Minister, Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez, might conceivably be likened to General de Gaulle's selection of his first Prime Minister, Michel Debra. Mr. Debre, known for advocacy of French rule in Algeria, was brutally forced by de Gaulle to lead a governmental policy designed to shed such rule.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Monday reported incorrectly that Costa Rica and Honduras had been involved in the 1969 conflict known as the soccer war. The two nations in that conflict were Honduras and El Salvador.

title: G.I.'s Guarding Korean DMZ, Last Outpost on Asian Mainland
description: GUARDPOST OUELLETTE, Demilitarized Zone, South Korea, July 20Pfc. Thomas Tucker and the other men of this isolated lookout donned their flak jackets, grabbed their M16's and put on their steel helmets as usual.

title: Fire Loss Put at $25 Million
description: BIG SPRING, Tex., July 20 (UPI)Company officials estimate damage in an explosion and fire at West Texas's largest oil and chemical refinery, at $25 million. At least 10 persons were treated and released with minor injuries after the fire Sunday at the Cosden Oil and Chemical Company.

title: ronx Woman Held In Alleged Swindle Of Hopeful Tenants
description: Posing as a city employee, an unemployed Bronx woman was said by the police last night to have bilked 500 people out of more than $100,000 by collecting rents in advance For apartments that were never provided.

title: Mars Photos and Olympics Technology Dazzle
description: The technology seems to he taken for granted by everybody except some of the artists who experiment with the medium and define its ingredients in various video environments. But occasionally broadcasting explodes with the extraordinary event, and the phenomenon of pure technology is given a fresh impact. This week is providing two outstanding examples: the Viking I pictures being sent from Mars and the pictorial coverage of the Summer Olympics in Montreal.

title: CONTEST WEAKENS GRASSO POSITION
description: HARTFORD, July 20Gov. Elia T. Grasso of Connecticut, who tried and failed last night to remove William A. O'Neill as Democratic state chairman, now finds herself isolated from both the legislature and the party. And, political leaders say, her failure has opened the way for extensive changes in personnel at the highest levels of the party organization.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: Jennings Prefers Basketball, But Gets Kicks From Football
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 20The veterans have been in camp a week now and Dave Jennings's right leg is tired.

title: News Summary and Index
description: At least one black man was reported killed in the South. African coalmining center of Witbank, 75 miles east of Johannesburg, when police reinforcements were rushed to the scene of serious rioting. Reports said about 3,000 black youths had poured out of black townships and attacked people and buildings in areas occupied by Indians and people of mixed descent. [Page 1, Col. 3.]

title: N.B.A., Players at Impasse, Imperiling Plan for Merger
description: The Federal judge in charge of overseeing professional basketball's antitrust lawsuit said yesterday that negotiations between the National Basketball Association and its players had reached an impasse, endangering the Merger between the N.B.A. and the American Basketball Association.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Burma Reports an Officer Plot To Kill Ne Win and Seize Rule
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 20 (AP)A group of young Burmese military officers tried to kill President Ne Win and two senior officials in an attempted coup earlier this month, the Rangoon radio said today.

title: KINGS POINT SENIOR LOSES COURT APPEAL
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday denied a motion by a senior at the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point to enjoin the Academy from dismissing or suspending him.

title: Vatican Displays American Graphics
description: VATICAN CITY, July 20 (AP)  The Vatican, which has said that modern art is one of Pope Paul VI's favorites, Is showing a special exhibition of American spiritual works.

title: About New York
description: Now that Willard R. Espy, the dapper, waxed mustached squire of Beekman Place, father  in  law of George Plimpton and author of An Almanac of Words at Play, is known as a. collector of palindromes, conundrums and other linguistic oddities, his mail is full of contributions for possible inclusion in a companion volume he is working on.

title: Food Prices: Fairly Stable
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City has remained fairly stable for the last month even though last week it increased 2 percent above the previous week's level, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: 1974 Newspaper Found in Jury Room Interrupts Harris Trial
description: LOS ANGELES. July 20A 1974 newspaper aescribing the ordeal of the Hearst family two days after their daughter, Patricia, was kidnapped, was smuggled into a jury room in a maximum security courtroom where William and Emily Harris, members of the revolutionary group that abducted the publishing heiress, are now on trial.

title: Ford Gains 10 Delegates And Needs Only 18 More
description: WASHINGTON, July 20President Ford gained substantial delegate strength today to pull within 18 votes of the total needed to gain a firstballot nomination at the Repub lican National Convention.

title: Strings Sign Pasarell
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP)Charles Pasarell, a fourtime member of the United States Davis Cup team, signed a contract with the Los Angeles Strings of World Team Tennis today.

title: 3 U.S. Dancers Gain Ballet Finals
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, July 20 (Reuters)  Three American dancers and one Canadian have reached the final round of a 27country international ballet competition in this Black Sea resort.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: The News From Mars
description: American space scientists and engineers yesterday registered another superb and historic achievement.

title: MSOR. J. GERALD KEALY
description: Msgr. J. Gerald Kealy, former rector of the North American College, the Roman Catholic institution in Rome, died Monday in St. Francis Hospital in Chicago. He was 83 years old and a resident of Chicago.

title: MacRae of Royals Leads dh'son 352
description: Hal MacRae of Kansas City's Royals leads all designated hitters in batting by 45 points, according to figures issued yesterday by the American League. MacRae, with a 352 batting average in 210 times at bat, leads Craig Kusick of Minnesota, batting 307 through Monday's games. Rico Carty of Cleveland is the only other hitting over 300 with a 301 average.

title: Film Figures Endorse Revival Effort
description: HACKENSACK, July 20Representatives of the motion picture industry rallied today behind New Jersey's effort to reestablish itself as a filmmaking center.

title: Soviet Lets Foreigners Deal With Official Agencies
description: MOSCOW, July 20 (AP)The Soviet Union published a decree today that permits Government officials to deal direct ly with foreign journalists.

title: Provident Mutual Life to Give More Jews Role in Management
description: In what it termed a landmark agreement, the American Jewish Committee announced yesterday that the Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission and the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company, in Philadelphia, had agreed that the insurance company would broaden the involvement of Jews in the management of the concern.

title: Yonkers ReSults
description: Yonkers ReSults

title: Music: Violinist Leads
description: For a violinist, the lure of a conducting career must be especially powerful. Conductors, after all, seem to go on forever, and are considered merely in the ripening stage at an age when most violinists have had to retire. That, of course, says something about the relative difficulty of conducting and playing the violin.

title: Ivan Morris of Columbia Is Dead; A Specialist in Oriental Cultures
description: Ivan Morris, a linguist, writer, translator, critic and former chairman of the department of East Asian languages and cultures at Columbia University, died of a heart attack on Monday night in Bologna, Italy. He was 50 years old and lived at 173 Riverside Drive.

title: IMPORTS TERMED KEY IN AUTO TALKS
description: DEARBORN, Mich. July 20Ken Bannon, the head of the United Automobile Workers Ford Department, said today that a key issue in the bargaining with the Ford Motor Company was that of finding a way to protect workers from the loss of jobs through imports and outside contractors.

title: POOR LANDS WARY OF U.S. TRADE PLAN
description: GENEVA, July 21 Developing countries are wary of a United States plan for an international trade code that would permit restrictions on imports causing injury to domestic industries without provoking retaliatory measures.

title: COSTS UP SHARPLY IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Up sharply by sixtenths of 1 percent last month, the Consumer Price Index in the New YorkNorthern New Jersey area reflected primarily the higher costs of food and utilities, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Carey Signs a Bill Mandating Open Meetings by Public Bodies
description: ALBANY, July 21 (AP)Governor Carey has signed into law legislation designed to let the public and press observe almost all governmental bodies at work.

title: New York State Issue Sold
description: New York State's $45 million issue of general obligation bonds came to market yesterday, received a single bid that won the deal and then met a favorable reception from buyers. The Chase

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Blue Cross Rate Increase
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 21 (UPI)The Pennsylvania Insurance Department approved yesterday a $16.2 million rate increase for subscribers of Blue Cross of Greater Philadelphia. The increase, which takes effect Aug. 1, affects the plan's 480,000 smallgroup and nongroup subsribers. The smallgroup subscribers face an 18 percent increase and nongroup subscribers a 27.5 percent increase.

title: Pentagon Aide Is Chosen For Ford Campaign Job
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 William I. Greener Jr., the Pentagon spokesman, has reportedly agreed to become the director of communications for President Ford's campaign committee.

title: South Africa Yields to Black Pressure, Will Reopen Schools Shut After Riots
description: JOHANNESBURG. July 21 The Government acceded to pressure from the black community today and agreed to the immediate reopening of schools in the black townships near Johannesburg and Pretoria. They have been closed since the outbreak of antiGovernment rioting last month.

title: Prison Still Most Pervasive Force in Town of Attica
description: ATTICA, N.Y., July 20 Chiseled into the gray marble headstone standing in a flower bed in front of the walls of the Attica Correctional Facility are these words:

title: Article 3  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Consumer Board, Set Back in Albany, Alters Goals
description: Rosemary Pooler, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, assessed her agency's success with the New York State Legislature during its recent session in a comment that was quick and biting.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT BACKS AFUEL SALE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The State Department said today that the United States must be allowed to sell more atomic fuel to India in order to maintain restraining influence over nations capable of building nuclear bombs.

title: Nets Victims,.4 to 0, Of Norman Conquest
description: CINCINNATI, July 21 TPie Big Red Machine was pl'Ogrammed for mostly singles and stolen bases tonight, but it didn't need more as Fred Norman's fourhit pitching stopped the Mess, 40.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International A bomb under his car on a road outside Dublin killed the British Ambassador to Ireland, Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs. A secretary also was killed and Frank Cubbon, Permanent Under Secretary of State to the Northern Ireland Office in Belfast, and the chauffeur were seriously injured. The Irish Government offered a 20,000 reward for information leading to arrest of the killers. Police assumed they were either linked to the Irish Republican Army or part of a breakaway group. [Page 1, Columns 13.]

title: EDUCATION BOARD DROPS RAISE PLAN
description: Responding to pressure from Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, the New York City Board of Education voted last night to withdraw without perjudice a resolution that would have authorized pay increases totaling $445,000 for 252 board employees.

title: Herbert G. A. Woolley, 80, Dies; Organized Training of Frogmen
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Herbert G. A. Woolley, who organized the training of frogmen in World War II, died Monday in Honolulu after a brief illness. Mr. Woolley, who was 80 years old, lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: LUCIEN SCHMIT DIES; CELLIST ON RADIO, 78
description: Lucien S. Schmit, a cellist who first performed publicly at the age of 7 in Paris and who became a member of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra at 13, died in Manhasset (LI.) Hospital on Tuesday after a stroke. Mr. Schmit was 78 years old and lived at 78 Bourndale Road South, Manhasset.

title: Callaghan Voices Sorrow
description: LONDON, July 21  Prime Minister James Callaghan told a hushed House of Commons today that the killing of Ambassador EwartBiggs was illustrative of the fact that hundreds of innocent men and women have been slaughtered on the altar of Ireland.

title: Mars? New Realities for SciFi
description: Viking 1 is down on the Chryse Planitia, the Golden Plain. Alas for Shakespeare, that plain does not much resemble An eye like Mars, to threaten and command. From the photographs, it looks more like Arizona with a hangover. Are we perhaps jaded?

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold Prices Wednesday. London: Morning fixing $110.00, up $2.25; afternoon fixing $113.00, up $5.15. Paris: Afternoon market quotation $119.43, up $6.61.

title: TRAVEL LIMIT PUT ON RUBIN CARTER
description: A Passaic County judge yesterday ordered Rubin (Hurricane) Carter to remain in New Jersey while awaiting his new trial on triplemurder charges.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Robert Walker

title: Index Shows Advance In Buyer Confidence
description: The Conference Board said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence which fell sharply in March and April, recovered moderately in May and June. In the latest period the index rose to 86.7 (19691970 equals 100), up 4.5 points from the March  April reading but down 6.6 points from January and February.

title: Advocates of Tax Reform Win Victories in House Committee and in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Advocates of taxing the wealthy more heavily and the middleand lowerincome groups less heavily won victories on both sides of the Capitol today.

title: 4 Admit Helping Troopers Get Cash With Gas Cards
description: TRENTON. July 21 (UPI)Four attendants at a New Jerscy Turnpike service station have pleaded guilty to charges of heaping state troopers use their gasoline credit cards to get cash.

title: DR. L. F. SHAFFER, PSYCHOLOGIST, 72
description: Dr. Laurance Frederic Shaffer, professor emeritus of psychology and education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and former associate dean there, died on Tuesday in his home, 495 Birch tree Road, Oradell, N.J. He was 72 years old

title: Federal Safe Rifled
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) A small freestanding safe in the fiscal management office of the Comptroller of the Currency was pried open last night. Missing is $856.90 in petty cash funds, a spokesman said. The office is in a privately owned building in L'Enfant Plaza.

title: New Guys and Dolls Comes Seven Again
description: Yes, it still works. Guys and Dolls, which in a new production opened at the Broadway Theater last night, remains as wry and as funny, as enchanting and as entrancing as ever. This musical based on Damon Runyon's nevernever land of a mythic Broadway that never was still seems magical. That floating crap game just keeps on floating.

title: Nadia Comaneci Takes Gymnast Title on 4th, 5th Perfect Scores
description: MONTREAL, July 21 On the uneven bars, she whirls as easily as a sparrow fluttering from limb to limb on a tree. On the balance beam, she clings to it as surely as a squirrel would. On the vault, she lands as softly as a sea gull on a beach. In her floor exercises, she is part gogo dancer, part ballerina, part cheerleader. And today Nadia Comaneci, her dark pigtails tied with red and white yarn, won her first Olympic gold medal as the allround champion in women's gymnastics. But at 14 years old, she is not a woman. An athlete, yes; an artist, yes. But with her 80pound rubber body, she's hardly much more than a child. That, of course, the essence of her charm. And she was carefully choreographed to project that child image in these Olympics by her Rumanian coaches. When she toured the United States a few months ago, she didn't smile. I never smile, she often said then.

title: Albert Appoints 15 For Reform Panel On House Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Juiy 21 (UPI) Speaker Carl Albert today named 15 members of a commission on administrative review that grew out of reforms that Demorats initiated to blunt the effects of sexscandal allegations involving some members of the House of Representatives.

title: Tioga Tax Approved
description: ALBANY, July 21 (UPI) Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a bill that will allow Tioga County to impose a 3 percent tax on admissions to quarterhorse races.

title: Viking Photo Shows Mars Has Red Soil With Varied Rocks and a Light Blue Sky
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 21 Viking 1 transmitted today its first color photograph of Mars, revealing light blue skies above reddish soil and rocks of apparently varied chemistry, and also gave scientists further reason to suspect that life might exist on the distant planet.

title: Higuera Tied at 68 With Silvestrone
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 21 Roger Stone, the Essex County Country Club golf professional, describes the difficult front nine and extremely difficult back nine of his 6,800yard course by saying, You have to get the birdies on the front nine and protect them on the back.

title: Roger E. Spear Sr., Investment Writer, Advised in Column
description: Roger E. Spear Sr., who for 50 years was identified, with investment advisory operations centered in Babson Park, Mass., and who was the author of a widely syndicated newspaper column dealing with investment problems, died last Friday at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 77 years old.

title: Butz to Vote for Reagan
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Earl Butz, President Ford's Secretary of Agriculture, will vote for Ronald Reagan on the first ballot at the Republican National Convention. Dr. Butz, a strong backer of Mr. Ford, is bound by Indiana's primary election results, which gave 45 delegates to Mr. Reagan and nine to Mr. Ford. He is bound to Mr. Reagan far the first ballot only.

title: MIRABAI INTRODUCES SONGS AT SWEENEY'S
description: Mirabai, who is performing in Reno Sweeney this week, has changed her image and improved as a singer and songwriter without really altering her style. When she began performing around town several years ago she was a willowy, longhaired folk singer with a strident, somewhat uncertain voice and a repertory of starryeyed songs. Now her hair is shorter and she dresses in a more stylish manner. Her voice is under control, and her songs, though they still have their starryeyed moments, are a bit more believable.

title: Carter Blanche
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 In our last installment on the moral leadership of Jimmy Carter, it was revealed here that one of the members of his inner circle, Patrick CaddellCarter pollster, strategist and apologistwas not only on the payroll of the Saudi Arabian royal embassy for $80,000 per year but provides poll answers to questions submitted by them and personal consultations to help them employ the information he gathers in their behalf.

title: MORE AIR ROUTES TO EUROPE URGED
description: In what officials called potentially the most important airroute decision in years, the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended yesterday that 11 additional metropolitan areas in the United States be permitted direct airline service to Europe.

title: Latin News Panel Backs SatelliteRelay Controls
description: SAN. JOSE. Costa Rica, July 21 (A P) A proposal that Latin American and Caribbean governments determine what information should be distributed by satellite in their regions was approved here today at a United Nationssponsored conference.

title: Denver Lease Spurs Scouts Move
description: DENVER, July 21 (UPI) A Colorado group headed by Bud Palmer, the broadcaster, said today a lease agreement had been worked out with the city of Denver for use of McNichols Sports Arena, thus meeting orre requirement set out in a letter of intent with the National Hockey League permitting the transfer of the Kansas City Scouts to Denver.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: FORTALEZA (PRMMI). Left Jan Juan Jun 19; due 9:30 A.M. at Eltzbein, N.J.

title: Andrianov Wins Gold
description: MONTREAL, July 21 (AP) Nikolai Andrianov of the Soviet Union won the men's individual allround Olympic gymnastics gold medal tonight.

title: Mets Box Score
description: METS(N.) CINCINNATI (N.)

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The former comptroller of the Federal antipoverty program in Paterson was indicted on charges that he stole $204,000 in agency funds. The former official, Odis Walker, 54 years old, of Passaic, was accused of taking the money over a fouryear period from the Paterson Task Force for Community Action Inc., which receives $4 million a year in Federal funds.

title: U.S. Gives 7 Cities Record Transit Aid; New York Included
description: In the largest single block of Federal mass transit grants ever awarded, Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr., announced yesterday the approval of $340 million in aid to seven cities, including $66.2 million for New York City.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Campaign Notes column in The Times last Monday, it was implied that Dr. Peter Bourne was incorrectly referring to himself as deputy director of the Jimmy Carter campaign. That is his designation, he is one of four deputy campaign directors.

title: Earle Combs Dies
description: Earle Combs, center fielder of the celebrated Yankee teams of the 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday at the age of 77. Details on Page 34.

title: The Watergate Reform
description: Capitol Hill was alive yesterday with the memory of watergate as the Senate put its final touches on a package of reforms developed in response to the scandal. The most striking feature of the Senate hill is the creation within the executive branch of a new and permanent special prosecutor and the most interesting aspect of its history is the Administration's sharp lastminute reversal of its strenuous opposition to that feature.

title: Murder in Dublin
description: The murder by terrorist bombing of Britain's ambassador to the Irish Republic and a secretary is another horrible reminderthough one is hardly neededthat the senseless campaign of killing, maiming and desstruction over the issue of Northern Ireland's political future rages unabated. Ireland's Justice Minister hints that the Dublin slaying was the work of an Irish Republican Army faction. It could well have been just that; but it also could have been carried out by an equally extremist Protestant group from Ulster.

title: State Authority Says It Could Not Supply Westchester Power
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 21 The Power Authority of the State of New York does not have enough available electric energy to supply Westchester County, a spokesman said today.

title: Connally Favored
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) John B. Connally is the top choice for Vice President of Republican delegates who named a candidate for the second spot, mainly because of strong support from those who favor Ronald Reagan for President.

title: Bank Sues Former Aide For Losses in Department
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 21 (AP)The Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark has filed suit against a former employee and a New York insurance company, hoping to recover up to $3.3 million in losses the bank's municipal bond department incurred in 1974.

title: In Memariam
description: HESSWalter J. July 20 3rd Anniversary In Heaven. Masses offered. More words cannot express my love or the great loss I ??? I miss you so. Eternal rest my dearest Walt. Your loving wife.

title: Boys Club to Abandon Catskill W
description: The Boys Club of New York has put its 4,300 acres of Catskills wilderness up for sale. The land is the site of Camp Harriman, and the problem is that fewer and fewer boys go camping there every year.

title: Chess
description: BIEL, Switzerland, July 20 Robert Huebner of West Germany, Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union and I shared the lead with 4 points after six rounds of the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspirants here in the Kongresshaus.

title: Godsil Is Rarely Seen In Role as Dog Handler
description: Professional handlers play important roles in the breed ring and in the field but in obedience they rarely are seen. As far as I know, I'm the only pro in the Midwest,

title: 25th Beached Dolphin Dies
description: ORLANDO, Fla., July 21 (AP) The last surviving dolphin of 25 that beached themselves on the rocky shores of Casey Key is dead. The young male spinner died yesterday at the Sea World marine park, where he was under constant care for a week. Scientists ordered an autopsy.

Beckerle, president Liabilities $e22,291: assets $461,870. Sale, lease and repair of construction eoulpment.JACK A. description: Yonkers Entries

title: Transit Authority Is Awarded $60.6 Million in Federal Funds
description: Federal masstransit grants announced in Washington yesterday include S60.5 million to the New York Transit Authority for 124 new buses, additional subway construction and sub

title: Uganda Reports Bid by Amin To Release Hijacked Airliner
description: NAIROBI, Kenya. July 21 (AP) President Idi Amin of Uganda informed France today he would release the Air France jetliner hijacked to his country last month. He also sent a telegram to President Jomo Kenyatta of Kenya asking him to forget our differences, the Uganda radio reported.

title: Bridge
description: The British invaded Philadelphia Tuesday night, but when the battle was broken off, neither side was able to claim a decisive victory.

title: PAKISTAN AND INDIA RENEW NORMAL TIES
description: NEW DELHI, July 21 With the exchange of Ambassadors and the resumption of passenger flights, India and Pakistan formally reestablished normal relations today.

title: Europe's Labor Scene
description: The outlines of a new industrial society have begun to emerge in Western Europe. Confrontations between unions and employers are slowly giving way to accommodations aimed at peaceful social change. The dimensions of the change are obscured by upheavals in currency systems, the lack of governmental stability in Italy and the shockwaves generated by British unemployment.

title: Saudis Occupy Strategic Beirut Crossing
description: BEIRUT Lebanon, July 21Saudi Arabian soldiers of the Arab League's peacekeeping force, despite almost constant sniper fire from the Christian side, took up positions today at the Museum, the only crossing point between Moslemcontrolled west Beirut and the Christianheld eastern part of the city. They were deployed on the Moslem side of the line.

title: Riviera Bank Gang Made Its Getaway By Land and Sea
description: NICE, France, July 21 (AP) Amazement over the $12 million bank robbery here increased today as investigators disclosed that the thieves who had burrowed in from a sewer made an underground getaway by van and inflatable rafts.

title: Other Highlights
description: SHOOTINGLenny Bassham of Bedford, Tex., an Army captain, and Margaret Murdock of Topeka, Kan., placed 1,2 in the smallbore rifle, threeposition event.

title: Strings Are Victors Over Sets, 2726
description: UNIONDALE, LI., July 21 The Los Angeles Strings won the final event, mixed doubles, to top the New York Sets, 2726. in a World Team Tennis match tonight before 2.583 people at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Alleged 1970 Hijacker Held After Arriving at Kennedy
description: Ira David Meeks, who allegedly hijacked a Cessna Skyhawk airplane from Gastonia. N.C., to Cub in 1970, was arrested last night by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation at John F. Kennedy Internatinnal Airport.

title: Flat Grant Welfare Rule Is Challenged in Jersey
description: BRIDGETON, NJ., July 21 (AP)The. Appellate Division of Superior Court has been asked to overturn the flat grant welfare regulation of the City of Bridgeton.

title: Ford and Congress Clash Over Military Funds and B1 Bomber
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Ford Administration and the Democraticcontrolled Con. gress collided on defense policy today as the White House moved to increase the military budget by about $1 billion while the Senate Appropriations Committee voted to defer production of the B1 bomber.

title: SIRICA GIVES H.E.Y. ORDER ON SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) A Federal judge has ordered the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to begin enforcement proceedings against certain Northern and Western School districts for violations of school desegregation requirements.

title: SENATE OVERRIDES VETO OF JOB BILL WITH HELP OF G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Senate, which sustained President Ford's veto of a public works jobs bill last February, today overrode his veto of a scaleddown measure aimed at stimulating employment in the construction industry.

title: Many FreeFood Sites Are Facing Closining Because of Abuses
description: Incidents of waste, theft and mismanagement are commonplace at up to twothirds of the sites distributing free food to needy New York City children, and many of these sites may have to close, state and Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Davis Named Coach
description: BALTIMORE, July 21 (UPI) Tommy Davis, a former Baltimore Colt, will join Morgan State University's football staff in September as defensiveline coach, it was announced today.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, JULY 22, 1976
description: A bomb under his car on a road outside Dublin killed the British Ambassador to Ireland, Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs. A secretary also was killed and Brian Cubbon, Permanent Under Secretary of State to the Northern Ireland Office in Belfast, and the chauffeur were seriously injured. The Irish Government offered a 20,000 reward for information leading to arrest of the killers. Police assumed they were either linked to the Irish Republican Army or part of a breakaway group. [Page 1, Columns 13]

title: JOSEPH H. ADLEMAN
description: EASTON, Pa., July 21 (AP) Joseph H. Adleman, retired executive editor of The Easton Express, died today in Easton Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: OFFICIALS OPPOSE CON ED RATE RISE
description: The latest request by Consolidated Edison for an increase in electric rates was vehemently opposed yesterday at a hearing by six public officials who described the bid variously as unnecessary, arrogant. unjustified and intolerable.

title: WARRANTS ISSUED FOR 3 IN ABDUCTION OF COAST STUDENTS
description: MADERA, Calif., July 21Warrants were issued today for the arrest of at least three San Mateo County residents in connection with the kidnapping last Thursday of 26 young summer school students and their bus driver from nearby Chowchilla.

title: Africa Sportsmen Seeking A Compromise on Boycott
description: MONTREAL, July 21Concerned African sportsmen were endeavoring behind the scenes today to find a formula that would halt the spreading boycott of the Olympic Games by African, Asian and Caribbean nations in a protest against South African racial policies.

title: Chinese Let Reporter Join in the Harvest
description: PEKINGThe smiles of the women at Hwangtukang Commune were friendly but betrayed some puzzlement about what foreigners were doing there.

title: Court Strikes Down Need of Citizenship For Alien Teachers
description: A New York State law that bars aliens from teaching in the public schools unless they have applied for United States citizenship wes declared unconstitutional yesterday by a panel of three Fedcral judges in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Gives 7 Cities Record Transit Aid; New York Included
description: In the largest single block of Federal mass transit grants ever awarded, Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr.. announced yesterday the approval of $340 million in aid to seven cities, including $66.2 million for New York City.

title: U.S. Men Win Two Olympic Swim Finals
description: MONTREAL, July 21 The American men continued to race away from the rest of the world in Olympic swimming today. They swept the medals in the 100meter butterfly with Matt Vogel, Joe Bottom and Gary Hall. Then they won the 800meter freestyle relay for the seventh straight United States gold medal in four days in the Olympic pool.

title: It Helps a Lot If You Like Blueberries
description: It Helps a Lot If You Like Blueberries

title: Mikhail Menshikov Dies; Was Soviet Envoy to U.S.
description: Mikhail A. Menshikov, the Soviet Ambassador in Washington during the Eisenhower and Kennedy administrations, has died in .Moscow, the Soviet press reported yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Women Grumble, Too
description: If the shoe fits, wear it. Well, doesn't, wails a woman with a very narrow foot: she can no longer buy summer sandals in quadruple A.

title: SENATE OVERRIDES VETO OF JOB BILL WITH HELP OF G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Senate, which sustained President Ford's veto of a public (works jobs bill last February, today overrode his veto of a scaleddown measure aimed at stimulating employment in the construction industry.

title: SHORT INTEREST UP AT BIG BOARD
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the short interest position in its listed shares had increased 697.770 shares to total 24.225,588 shares in the month ended July 15.

title: Magoon Captures Ocean Powerboat Race in Fog
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 21 You are going 70 miles an hour in the ocean off the New Jersey shore; you cannot see much because of fog and haze and you are racing a speedboat full of engines and gasoline. What do you do? You keep going, hoping for the best, relying on bouncing compasses and intuition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of July 2 is a welcome voice of support for our efforts to bring governmental electronic surveillance under effective control. However, in addition to the arguments you advance for the strongest possible control, we believe there are several additional points to he made.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES REVERSE DECLINE
description: After losing about 75 cents a bushel in the last four trading sessions, soybeans reversed their downtrend and moved up in price yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders called it a technical rally after the sharp decline.

title: Hughes Pledges Backing For Alcoholisrn Program
description: VERONA, July 21 Chief justice Richard Hughes, of the New Jersey Supreme Court pledged his support today to an effort to make the state the first and the best in the treatment and rehabilitation of alcoholics.

title: Higuera Tied at 68 With Silvestrone
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 21 Roger Stone, the Essex County Country Club golf professional, describes the difficult front nine and extremely difficult back nine of his 6,800yard course by saying, You have to get the birdies on the front nine and protect them on the back.

title: Shadow Of the Gunmen
description: LONDON, July 21 Last March in New York, Mayor Beame attended a memorial mass for a Provisional Irish Republican Army leader, Frank Stagg, who had starved himself to death in a British prison. Afterwards an honor guard wearing black berets, the I.R.A. symbol, marched to a rally where a large crowd was addressed by other New York politicians: Paul O'Dwyer, Mario Biaggi, Robert Abrams.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make a list available yesterday.

title: U.S. Five Subdues Yugoslavia, 11293
description: MONTREAL, July 21 I kept thinking, it's just like the Big Ten, said Phil Hubbard of the University of Michigan after the grappling had ended. I'm always in foul trouble there, too.

title: New York Prisons Chief Says Overcrowding Is Affecting AL
description: ALBANY, July 21  Overcrowding is the primary reason why the state prison system is in a period of crisis, Benjamin C. Ward, the State Correctional Services Commissioner, said today.

title: Mets Records
description: Mets Records

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: New York Area Showing Signs of Economic Health
description: Signs of modest improvement in the economies of New York City, the metropolitan region and the state are being discerned by economists and public officials who for several years have been unrelentingly gloomy about New York's prospects.

title: Dancer, Producer and Star: 3 Roles for Nonstop Nureyev
description: How are things? Rudolf Nureyev is asked at the opening of the National Ballet of Canada's season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Not that bad, he replies. It is only his 14th week of nonstop dancing with five companies on two continents, and only one foot is injured and bandaged. By the time the evening's performance is ended, ballet's most famous superstar will have audiences out front and fellow dancers backstage cheering his solos.

title: PRICES FOR JUNE ROSE MODERATELY
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Consumer prices continued to rise moderately in June and energy took over from food as the main factor in pushing up the price level, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.N. Says World Water Supply Is Not as Reliable as It Appears
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 The United Nations reported today that at least onefifth of the world's city dwellers and threequarters of its rural people lacked reasonably reliable supplies of drinking Water.

title: All Round Gold to Rumanian Star, 14
description: MONTREAL, July 21 Nadia Comaneci won the Olympic gold medal as the world's most versatile women's gymnast today, and she did it with style and the precision of two more perfect scores.

title: Wilson, as a Delegate, Will Vote for Ford
description: Former Gov. Malcolm Wilson, a New York delegateatlarge, announced yesterday that he would vote for President Ford at the Republican National Convention next month. Mr. Wilson, a Westchester resident, had been one of nine uncommitted New York delegates.

title: Vietnam Agrees to Let Americans Leave
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Vietnam has agreed to allow all Americans stranded in that country since the end of the war to leave, beginning Aug. 1, and to take Vietnamese members of their families with them, it was disclosed today.

title: Robert Kenny, Attorney, Dead; Led National Lawyers Guild
description: Robert W. Kenny, who became Attorney General of California and also served as a judge even though he never finished law, school, died Tuesday at Sdripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Advertising
description: The microwave oven market is really heating up and those already in it wouldn't be surprised to see 35 different brand names available in the fall.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Oakland A's at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 1:55 P.M.)

title: Dancer, Producer and Star: 3 Roles for Nonstop Nureyev
description: How are things? Rudolf Nureyev is asked at the opening of the National Ballet of Canada's season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Not that bad, he replies. It is only his 14th week of nonstop dancing with five companies on two continents, and only one foot is injured and bandaged. By the time the evening's performance is ended, ballet's most famous superstar will have audiences out front and fellow dancers backstage cheering his solos.

title: Spikes Drives In 3 Runs as Indians Win
description: Rick Waits, a lefthander, held the California Angels to seven hits and Charlie Spikes drove in three runs as the Cleveland Indians beat Nolan Ryan, 62. last night in Municipal Stadium.

title: E.P.A. Tests Show IllSet Carburetors Are Polluting Air
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Thousands of 1975 Ford, Chrysler and General Motors automobiles are polluting the air because dealers and drivers have misadjusted their carburetors, some apparently deliberately, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Sets Rise in Bank Rate and Deposit on All Imports
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 21 (UPI) Reflecting the Government's concern over the falling price of gold, the South African reserve bank announced today it would raise the bank rate from 8.5 percent to 9 percent effective tornorrow.

title: Box Scores and Standings
description: Thursday, July 22, 1475

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: Children's Center Still Awful Place But Needed for Now, New York Says
description: The Children's Center, at 104th Street and Fifth Avenue, described by investigators as a house of terror two years ago, is still a place where children harm each other, themselves and staff members, Carol Parry, assistant city commissioner of special services for children, acknowledged yesterday.

title: Homosexual Is Candidate
description: SYRACUSE, July 21 (UPI) The Onondaga County Liberal Party has endorsed a homosexual activist to oppose Representative James Hanley for the 32d New York Congressional Dist He seat. Mr. Hanley is a Democrat. The Liberal Party gave its endorsement to Earl Colvin, 43 years old, a political newcomer, who said the National Gay Task Force had told him he was the first avowed homosexual to seek a seat in Congress.

title: Contact With Viking Lander Is on a Tight Schedule
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 21 The Viking I Lander planted on the rocky, reddish surface of planet Mars is exchanging messages with Earth on a tightly circumscribed schedule.

title: New Breed of Explorers Maps Amazon Treasures
description: BELEM, Brazil, July 15  In the last five years, a group of 150 Brazilian geologists, botanists, agronomists and technicians has discovered more about the vast Amazon jungles than in four centuries of earlier exploration.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted) Open

title: Occidental Mixed
description: The first of the secondquarters earning reports of the large oil companies were released yesterday, with the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announcing an increase for both the quarter and the first six months of 1976 and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation reporting a gain for the quarter but a decline for the half.

title: Britain's Envoy in Dublin Killed by Mine
description: DUBLIN, July 21 The British Ambassador to Ireland, Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs, was killed today when a land mine was detonated beneath his moving car, about 150 yards from his official residence on the southern outskirts of Dublin.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A special time capsule prepared in 1975 to commemorate the yearlong celebration of 200 years of continuing operations by Bowne & Companywas buried in the floor of a steel safe of the concern's print shop restorakon at 211 Water Street. Founded in 1775, the company describes itself as the largest financial printing concern in the country and the city's oldest business operating continuously under the same name since its founding. The safe, it was said, is not to he opened until the year 2075 when Bowne &. Company commemorates its Tricentennial. The print shop restoration was described as part of the South Street Seaport Museum project in Lower Manhattan.

title: Screen: Goose Chase
description: THE WILD GOOSE CHASE, directed by Claude Zidi; executive producer, Pierre Grunstein; distributed by EDP Films Inc. At the Cinema II theater. This flim has not been rated.

title: BONDS EXCHANGE DISAPPOINTS M.A.C.
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation closed its latest debtexchange offer yesterday with the most meager response yet and a warning from its chairman that holders of New York City notes who rejected the offer would find no alternative but continued nonpayment of the principal.

title: Jobs at Decent Wages
description: ATLANTAThe most notable feature of Congressional debate over the HumphreyHawkins Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act has been the lukewarm response of liberal economists. Although the bill's goalreducing adult unemployment to 3 per cent by 1980makes it the first major employment legislation since the mid1960's, it has not gained the political or intellectual support that the goal of overcoming poverty and achieving social justice did ten years ago.

title: Project Manajer for Viking
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 21 Someone asked James S. Martin Jr., the Viking project manager, about the role of luck in the successful landing on Mars, and his re ply was in char Man acter for the tough, driving and in the thorough leader News of the $1 billion space program. I don't plan on luck, Mr. Martin said, his jaw set, his gray crew cut bristling and his large shoulders thrust forward. I believe that most of what you call luck you make yourself. It's people doing that extra job.

title: 36 Policemen Suspended
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 21 (UPI) Thirtysix Louisville police officers have been found guilty of disciplinary violations and ordered suspended without pay for 5 to 10 days for participation in a work slowdown The slowdown started minutes after the police contract expired at midnight July 1. Officers reported that 32 police cars were disabled by flat tires, and police supervisors charged that the police radio system had been deliberately jammed.

title: U.S. SUES TO BLOCK LITTON SHIP THREAT
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Government went to court today to block a threat by Litton Industries to halt work on helicopteramphibious assault ships the company is building under a $795 million Navy contract.

title: Unraveling the Martian Mystery
description: The Viking 1 lander has been on the surface of Mars only two days, but its findings have already given scientists a striking new conception of conditions on that Planet.

title: 4 Peregrine Falcons Released in Brigantine
description: BRIGANTINE, N.J., July 21 (UPI) Four young peregrine falcons, which ornithologists hope will help save the species from extinction, in the eastern United States, were released today in the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Stocks Rise Slightly in Sluggish Trading
description: The stock market plodded sluggishly along yesterday to post its first general advance in the last seven sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 1.15 at 989.44 after running ahead as much as 5.49 points earlier in the afternoon.

title: Oil Companies Are Preparing. Bids for Offshore Leases
description: TRENTON, July 21  A spokesman for major oil companies said today that the corn panies were preparing to bid on leases for oil and natural gas off New Jersey and Delaware shores despite pending legal action aimed at stopping the lease sale scheduled for Aug. 17.

title: Hay Brings Record Auction Prices as Popularity of Horses Grows
description: NEW HOLLAND, Pa.At $96 a ton, that ain't hay, said a bearded bidder of the highest auction price for forage this summer paid here recently.

title: Sweeney Wins Yachting Prize
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21  The threepart Junior regatta, which was a special series within the 78th Annual Larchmont Race Week, ended without enough wind for sailing on Long Island Sound today and prize winners were decided on the basis of Monday's and yesterday's races.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Management Realigned At Marine Midland Bank
description: The Marine Midland Bank announced a toplevel management reorganization yesterday, apparently in preparation for naming a new president.

title: 14 FOOD CONCERNS CITED ON VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Health Department has cited 14 more food businesses for failing a healthcode Inspection and warned that closing orders would result if violations persisted upon a final visit by its inspectors. The names of the establishments and the actions taken follow:

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 21 In an effort to rescue his sagging legislative program, Governor Byrne met today with Democratic leaders in his office.

title: Gold Slide Halted Price, Up by $3, Ends at $110
description: LONDON, July 21 (UPI) A small but steady demand on London's bullion market today stopped a fourday slide in gold prices. The market closed at $110 an ounce, up $3 from yesterday, when the price was at its lowest in two and a half years.

title: COALITION PUSHES FOR COURT CHANGE
description: An unlikely coalition of bankers, feminists, bar association leaders, labor officials, law school deans, publishers, former convicts and people in the arts yesterday called the New York State Legislature irresponsible and insensitive for not enacting a package of court  reorganization amendments this year.

title: STRIKERS RETURN TO WESTINGHOUSE
description: PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP) Westinghouse plants struck by bluecollar workers began to reopen today as a new three year pact brought some employees back for the overnight shift.

title: MORE DEAD FISH FOUND OFF SHORE
description: More dead fish were reported yesterday in the New Jersey surf from Long Branch to Barnegat, and marine scientists expressed concern that the offshore fish kill, first noticed two weeks ago, had spread from Sandy Hook to Atlantic City.

title: Women's AllRound Gymnastics Final
description: Women's AllRound Gymnastics Final

title: Summaries of Montreal Olympic Games
description: Summaries of Montreal Olympic Games

title: PRICES FOR JUNE ROSE MODERATELY
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Consumer prices continued to rise moderately in June and energy took over from food as the main factor in pushing up the price level, the Labor Department ??? ??? today.

title: The Gold Slump
description: Gold has long been promoted as the most secure of investments and the one true form of money. But this week the price of gold, which almost touched $200 an ounce eighteen months ago, fell as low as $105.50, before rallying yesterday to $110. However, the slump in gold is likely to continue, for the bullion auctions of the International Monetary Fund that have been knocking down its price will continue for the next four years.

title: Events Today
description: MOVIES IN THE PARK, a series of short films, at ??? Park, Queens, Union Turnpike and 196th Street, 9 P.M.

title: Sealing of Mandel Papers Is Overturned on Appeal
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, ruled yesterday that the sealing of all court papers in connection with the corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland was an unnecessary prior restraint on freedom of the press and that it violated the First Amendment.

title: Equipment Put on Sale At the Manhattan Hotel
description: Thousands of items, ranging from toilet paper (10 rolls for $1) to a large bar with rail ($350), went on sale yesterday as is at the 1,300room Royal Manhattan Hotel.

title: Bella Abzug Right at Home In Social Whirl
description: She might have been happier discussing the arms race, the fiscal crisis or anything but her wardrobe and her diet. Nevertheless, Bella Ahzug, the candidate of an increasing number of people who support causes at cocktail parties, discussed with characteristic gusto her weight and clothes Tuesday night at an East Side gathering to raise funds for her Senate campaign.

title: Henry Gross Sings His Sunny Melodies At the Bottom Line
description: Henry Gross writes some of the sunniest rock songs around, abut his one top 10 hit so far, Shannon, was a ballad. He was born in Brooklyn, but he first attracted notice as a solo performer in the South.

title: Labor Leaders Form a Group to Elect Moynihan
description: Raymond R. Corbett, president of the New York State A.F.L.  C.I.O., yesterday announced the formation of a committee of labor leaders from New York City, the suburbs and upstate to support Daniel P. Moynihan for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

title: Modern U.S. Art Is Shown in Geneva
description: GENEVAThis city's Museum of Art and History is staging an exhibition titled American Painting 19501965 that Charles Goerg, a museum curator, hopes will help to arouse public interest in modern art.

title: N.B.A. and Players Clear Way for Pact
description: The National Basketball Association and its players reached a tentative agreement yesterday on the clanfication of the Oscar Robertson antitrust lawsuit as it affects the future signing of rookies. The pact cleared the major stumbling block to the N.B.A. merger with the American Basketball Association.

title: Wrestling Defender Out
description: MONTREAL, July 21 (UPI) Peter Kirov of Bulgaria, the defending flyweight GrecoRoman Olympic wrestling champion, withdrew today with a shoulder Injury he suffered late in the second period yesterday in his openinground match with Nicu Ginga of Rumania.

title: Appeal in Busing Case
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 20 (AP) Indiana will appeal a Federal court decision that would require the busing of black children from Indianapolis to suburban schools to achieve a racial quota, State Attorney General Theodore L. Sendak announced today. The decision, handed down Friday by the United States Court of. Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago, would require busing to achieve a 15 percent black enrollment in suburban Marion County schools.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: the blackandwhite photographs produced by the radar equipment indicate different levels of terrain, possible mineral deposits, varying density of vegetation, and hidden streams and rivers.

title: SENATE APPROVES PROSECUTOR POST
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Three years after its highly publicized Watergate hearings, the Senate approved today legislation creating a permanent independent special prose cutor to investigate wrondgoing by government officials at the highest level.

title: Truth Tests to Be Used at Harris Trial to Find Source of Newspaper
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 Sheriff's investigators will begin administering polygraph tests tomorrow in an effort to discover who smuggled a 1974 newspaper, containing an artick with a banner headline one the Patricia Hearst kidnapping, into a heavily guarded courtroom where Miss Hearst's former companions, Emily and William Harris, are on trial.

title: Environmental Lobby Campaifins to Oust 12 in House
description: PHOENIX, Ariz.Good afternoon. I'm Martha Foley, field organizer of the Dirty Dozen campaign

title: Business Briefs
description: ROME, July 21 (Reuters) The Italian Treasury said today it would extend by three months the 50 percent noninterest bearing deposit plan applied on imports arid other exchange transactions due to expire in the first week of August.

title: U.S. Man, Woman Take Top 2 Spots in Shooting
description: MONTREAL, July 21 (AP) Lanny Bassham, a United States Army captain from Bedford, Tex., won the Olympic gold medal in the smallbore rifle, threeposition competition today. His score was 1,162 of a possible 1,200 points.

title: Europe's Labor Scene
description: The outlines of a new industrial society have begun to emerge in Western Europe. Confrontations between unions and employers are slowly giving way to accommodations aimed at peaceful social change. The dimensions of the change are obscured by upheavals in currency systems, the lack of governmental stability in Italy and the shockwaves generated by British unemployment.

title: One of 2 Tried in Slaying Enters Plea of No Contest
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., July 21 (UPI)One of two Monmouth County brothers has pleaded no contest in Superior Court to charges he killed a Bradley Beach, N.J.. policeman over the Memorial Day weekend.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Campaign Notes column in The Times last Monday, it was implied that Dr. Peter Bourne was incorrectly referring to himself as deputy director of the Jimmy Carter campaign. That is his designation, he is one of four deputy campaign directors.

title: COURT WON'T SEAL W. R. HEARST WILL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 A Superior Court judge refused yesterday to seal permanently the will of William Randolph Hearst because he said that would be tantamount to denying the public the right to know what was done in probate court.

title: Mozart Bill Offers Bach, Hummel, Kuhlau, Doppler
description: They rummaged around in the spare room of musical history at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Tuesday night, and for a couple of hours the dust and cobwebs flew at Alice Tully Hall.

title: AIRCRAFT CARRIER ASSET FOR SOVIET
description: The addition of the Soviet Union's first aircraft carrier, the 40,000ton Kiev, to the naval squadron in the Mediterranean Sea will mean a significant strengthening of that Squadron's capabilities, according to United States Navy sources.

title: ExCounsel Asserts Security Was Lax In Intelligence Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 [UPI] Security in the House intelligence committee was so lax that staff members kept top secret papers on their desks and copied material for their own files, a former committee counsel testified today.

title: MORE AIR ROUTES TO EUROPE URGED
description: In what officials called potentially the most important airroute decision in years, the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended yesterday that 11 additional metropolitan areas in the United States be permitted direct airline service to Europe.

title: Britain's Envoy in Dublin Killed by Mine
description: DUBLIN, July 21 The British Ambassador to Ireland, Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs, was killed today when a land mine was detonated beneath his moving car, about 150 yards from his official residence on the southern outskirts of Dublin.

title: In Men's Shoes, Squeeze Is On, As Choice of Widths Narrows
description: Thanks to the pressures of economic competition and the lure of fashion, equality between the sexes is likely to become a reality in yet one more realm: sore feet.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of the Hesston Corporation, a producer of specialty hayhandling equipment, slumped in heavy trading on Tuesday after the company's board of directors suspended the quarterly dividend and forecast losses for the third and fourth quarters of the fiscal year ending in September.

title: U.S. Indicts 3 in Manhattan As Cocaine Conspirators
description: An artist, a lawyer and a stockbroker were accused yesterday in Manhattan of conspiring to deal in cocaine.

title: Television
description: Television

title: A Battle Begins for Control of New York Legislature
description: With scarcely anyone but the candidates and their political leaders paying attention, the battle for control of the New York State Legislature has quietly begun.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR ART'S SAKE What makes a pile of bricks, or a painting of a can of soup or a plain whitepainted canvas art? Some men and women, who, to a large extent, determine what art in America is may answer this and more significant questions in a series of lectures entitled: Art Critics View Contemporary Art.

title: Catholic Official Urges U.N. To Aid Indochina Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The general secretary of the Catholic Conference in the United States appealed today to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to aid in providing temporary asylum for scores of Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees.

title: Bush to Brief Carter
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  President Ford instructed today the Director of Central Intelligence, George Bush, to give Mr. Carter an intelligence briefing next week.

title: Carter Due in New York For Several Talks Today
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 21 Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, will interrupt his working vacation at his home here tomorrow to fly to New York for the day.

title: Combs of Yanks Dies at 77; Led Off Murderers Row
description: Earle Combs, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame who was the leadoff man in the New York Yankee Murderers Row batting, order that featured Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, died yesterday in Richmond, Ky., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto Grosso No. I, Handel; Sonatas, Scahlatti; Violin .Sonatina No. 3. Schubert; Flute Concerto in B minor, De Croes.

title: City U. Giving More Funds to Colleges
description: The chancellor of the City University of New York, following weeks of protests from Brooklyn and Queens Colleges, that they were being cheated in budget allocations for this year, has decided to give more money to most of the senior collegesand the greater part of that to the two borough colleges.

title: Olympic Sidelights
description: MONTREAL, July 21 The passenger in the back of the cab thought that the driver was listening to the GrecoRoman wrestling matches on the radio.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Soldier Killed by Bomb
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, July 21 (AP) A bomb smuggled into a heavily guarded British Army barracks exploded tonight, killing a soldier and demolishing part of the building, an army spokesman said. He said the fivepound bomb blasted the second floor of a sleeping area of the Egrington Barracks in the center of Londonderry.

title: Marine Academy Reinstates Woman Caught With Man
description: A woman who resigned from the United States Merchant Marine Academy under pressure because she was found in bed with a man has been reinstated provided that she face the academy's interrupted disciplinary procedures.

title: Idea of Life on Mars Is Renewed by Viking
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 21 Yesterday's discovery in the Mars atmosphere of the one previously missing ingredient considered necessary for the evolution of lifenitrogenhas rekindled the idea that the planet may at least once have harbored life.

title: S.E.C. PLANS MOVE ON WESTINGHOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is under investigation for the second time in a year by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a suspected failure to make proper disclosures of its operations to stockholders.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford's nominee to head the White House Office of Science and Technology, which was recently established after three years of oblivion, will be H. Guyford Stever, director of the National Science Foundation for the last four years.

title: Shift of Mississippi G.O.P. To Ford Termed Imminent
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, long regarded as a bulwark of Ronald Reagan's candidacy was reported today to be on the verge of a decisive shift to President Ford.

title: Another Godzilla Movie
description: Godzilla vs. Megaton completes the canonization of Godzilla, the creature who came from beneath the sea in 1955 (in Godzilla, King of the Monsters) to destroy Tokyo and has returned in sequels again and again to protect the land he once loathed. It's been a remarkable transformation of characterthe dragon has become St. George.

title: 8 MORE INDICTED IN PAPER STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Eight more former Washington Post pressmen were indicted today by the Federal grand jury investigating the pressroom sabotage that interrupted publication of the newspaper last October at the outset of a long, bitter strike.

title: Northrop Earnings Rise 78.2% In 2d Quarter From Year Ago
description: THE Northrop Corporation, the diversified aerospace manufacturer that has been involved in payments scandals, reported yesterday a 78.2 percent increase in secondquarter earnings from the yearearlier level. Its backlog on June 30 of $2.47 billion was up 145 percent from a year ago.

title: SLAIN ENVOY HELD POST JUST 2 WEEKS
description: LONDON, July 21 Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs, the British Ambassador to Dublin, who was killed there today just two weeks after taking up the post, had lived in fear of violence before.

title: Shift of Mississippi G.O.P. To Ford Termed Imminent
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, long regarded as a bulwark of Ronald Reagan's candidacy, was reported today to be on the verge of a decisive shift to President Ford.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Instant Millionaire an Instant Hit at Track
description: OCEANPORT, July 21 The veteran horseplayers at Monmouth Race Track responded today to Wanda Oughton as they probably would not have to a movie goddess.

title: JOSEPH K. LOWENSTEIN
description: Joseph K. Lowenstein, a realestate man, of 385 Ocean Boulevard, Long Brabch, N.J., died yesterday at the Westwood Hall Nursing Home in Long Branch. He was 83 years old. Mr. Lowenstein retired in 1972 as a vice president of Feist & Feist, with which he had been associated for 50 years.

title: 110 Illegal Aliens Seized
description: AVALON, Calif., July 21 (UPI) A Coast Guard cutter yesterday landed 16 Federal Immigration officers and sheriff's deputies on Santa Catalina Island, where they arrested 110 illegal aliens. The operation followed complaints by island residents that they could not find work because so many illegal aliens from Mexico were working as gardeners, domesties and in restaurants.

title: Books of The Times
description: Along with everything else that is disintegrating in the London of Paul Theroux's seventh and most interesting novel to date (he is also the author of last year's successful travel book, The Great Railway Bazaar), the telephones are no longer working properly. So it's not entirely outlandish that in one of the book's early scenes, Ralph Gawber, a respectable but timid accountant, picks up his phone, finds himself eavesdropping on an argument over an unsolved clue in that morning's Times crossword puzzle, supplies the answer and quickly hangs up. Yet the incident is sufficiently odd to make us wonder what purpose it is supposed to serve, especially in a story that so far has concerned some political terrorists holed up in a building in the center of London, awaiting instructions from the Provisional Irish Republican Army. And the more we wonder about the telephone incident the more we realize it reflects in miniature Ralph Gawber's larger role in The Family Arsenal (so named for the weapons the terrorists later cache in their building).

title: TEXACO LIFTS GAS BY CENT A GALLON
description: Texaco, the country's second largest oil company, announced yesterday that it had raised the price of gasoline by 1 cent a gallon, effective immediately.

title: TV: Real World, Various Looks at Anthropology
description: In another of those proggramming efforts to bring a touch of new life to rerun schedules, Channel 13 is offering, on Thursdays at 9, a 12part weekly series called The Real World. The collection purports to take a variety of looks at anthropology, the study of ourselves but, in several instances, this justification gets extremely fuzzy.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Kraftco Corporation of Glenview, Ill., the large food and dairy products processor that sells under the Kraft and Sealtest labels, announced yesterday that it had sold its Metro Containers division to the Midland Glass Company for $45 million.

title: Personal Finance
description: Life insurance is an aspect of an individual's financial planning that should be periodically reviewed particularly when important family events occur. But the one time in life when policies should certainly be examined to determine whether changes are required is at, or lust before, retirement.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Lawrence, MassTony Lopes, Brockton, Mass., 146 pounds, knocked out Jaun Colon, Lowell, Mass., 147. 8 rounds; Jimmy Lopez. Lawrence, Mass., knocked out Frank Maldonado, Lowell, Mass., 2.

description: Yankee Box Score

title: ITT Baking Introduces Fiber Loaf
description: You say you want a little more fiber in your diet to help your digestive tract? Well, then step this way, the ITT Continental Baking Company has a loaf for you.

title: CANADA WILL BUY LOCKHEED PLANES
description: A Canadian purchase of 18 Lockheed antisubmarine planes was finally consummated yesterday after months of talks tht were repeatedly jeopardized by financing snags and the company's involvement in the overseas bribes scandal.

title: From 6 Geometrics, Myriad Designs
description: When Verner Panton designs a group of fabrics, he doesn't fool around. The eminent Danish architect and designer, who now lives in Switzerland, had already touched practically every base when it came to design, from buildings to furniture to decorative accessories and consumer products.

title: 2,000 Feared Lost in Quake In Indonesia Turn Up Safe
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 21 (Reuters)  Nearly half the 5,000 people who had been missing and feared killed in last month's earthquake and landslides in the remote Indonesian province of Irian Jaya have returned to their villages after fleeing into the jungles for safety, Antara news agency said today.

title: New Breed of Explorers Maps Amazon Treasures
description: BELEM, Brazil, July 15  In the last five years, a group of 150 Brazilian geologists, botanists, agronomists and technicians have discovered more about the vast Amazon Jungles than in four centuries of earlier exploration.

title: Negotiation Halted For S. Klein Store
description: Julio Tanjeloff, owner of the Astro Minerals and Georg Jensen retail businesses, said yesterday that negotiations under which he would reopen the closed S. Klein department store on Union Square had been suspended.

title: Wisconsin Inmates Free 14 Hostages Held for 12 Hours
description: MADISON, Wisconsin, July 21 (Reuters) Rebellious inmates at the Wisconsin State Prison released 14 hostages late tonight in exchange for a promise of amnesty from state officials; authorities said.

title: WARRANTS ISSUED FOR 3 IN ABDUCTION OF COAST STUDENTS
description: MADERA, Calif., July 21 Warrants were issued here today for the arrest of at least three San Mateo County residents in connection with the kidnapping last Thursday of 26 young summer school students and their bus driver from nearby Chowchilla.

title: Many DayCare Facilities Open Despite Aid Cutoff
description: You just don't break up a home for no reason, said Mabel Dean. T am always optimistic. I know we are going to go on no matter what.

title: Kuhn Defends His Blocking of A's Deals
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn defended before Congress today his tion of the sale of three Oakland A's players as in the best interests of the sport. As expected, Charles O. ??? owner of the A's disagreed.

description: Today's Schedule

title: Mars? New Realities for SciFi
description: Viking 1 is down on the Chryse Planitia, the Golden Plain. Alas for Shakespeare, that plain does not much resemble An eye like Mars, to threaten and command. From the photographs, it looks more like Arizona with a hangover. Are we perhaps iaded?

description: Daths

title: Richardson Urges a Moderate Course
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Elliot L. Richardson, a leading Republican moderate, asserted today that if conservatives dominate the party's convention, ticket and campaign, the inevitable result will be to blow the election.

title: 7 Judges Appointed by Beame, Including the Brother of Leone
description: Mayor Beame appointed seven new judges yesterday, including John Leone, the brother of Borough President Sebastian Leone of Brooklyn.

title: Lisbon Office Bombed
description: LISBON, Thursday, July 22 (Reuters)  A powerful bomb exploded outside the Lisbon offices of the Mozambique national airline early today causing severe damage but no casualties. The blast shattered windows in the Ritz. Hotel in front of the airline offices.

title: 1Year Bills Auctioned By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 5.887 percent.

title: Burns Calls Drop in Gold Good; Sees No Need for Policy Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Ar thur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he thought that the recent decline in the price of gold was on balance a good thing.

title: Restaurateur Held In Scheme Involving 14 Japanese Aliens
description: A Japanese restaurateur was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of bringing illegal Japanese aliens into this country and harboring them at his five suburban Japanese steakhouses.

title: Duty, Honor, Country
description: Following is a condensation of a June letter sent by Lieut. Gen. Sidney B. Berry, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy at. West Point, to graduates and parents of cadets.
