title: LUTHERANS BACK VIETNAM AMNESTY
description: BOSTON, July 22 (AP)The eighth biennial convention of the Lutheran Church in America, today adopted a resolution calling for unconditional amnesty for Vietnam War resisters and pardon for those convicted of related offenses.

title: Miss Velez Brassy In Reggae
description: Martha Velez, who used to belt out bluesrock in a neoJoplin style, is now singing reggae. Her latest album, Escape From Babylon, was produced by Bob Marley and features his hand, the Wailers. Her traveling band is no match for Jamaica's finest reggae ensemble,but it is a lean, energetic, wellbalanced group, with an especially tasteful guitarist and a crisp rhythm section.

title: On the Sidewalks of New York, a New Silhouette for Pants
description: All you need to keep in step with fashion these days is a bit of string. A pair of shoelaces will do. Or a length of wool yarn, the kind used to tie packages or Ponytails.

title: Rahsaan Kirk Comes Back Strong
description: Late last November, Rahsaan Roland Kirk, the blind and amazingly versatile jazz musician who often plays two or three saxophones simultaneously, felt dizzy after supper in his home in East Orange, N. J. He went upstairs to lie down.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES 1914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. 1516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: City Tree Planting Fails to Take Root
description: New York City's wellpublicized neighborhood treeplanting program is suffering from a virulent city diseasefiscal blight.

title: Broadway
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS will be back on Broadway again sometime next season with, of all things, musical. It is as yet untitled, but it will be based on Mr. Williams's Camino Real, and it will start its travels at Buffalo's Studio Arena Stage Oct. 1. Mr. Williams and Larry Arrick, who will direct the production, wrote the book, and Mr. Williams and Barbara Damashek, who also did the music, wrote the lyrics. When Camino Real opened here in 1953, Brooks Atkinson called it strange and disturbing drama and a kind of cosmic fantasy and he said .that Mr. Williams's pessimism frightening. This new production will not be Little Mary Sunshine.

title: RADIO
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Oboe Concerto No. 11. Albinoni; Dances, Gervaise; Theme and Variations in E flat, Beethoven; Concerto for Four Claviers in A minor, Bach; Emperor Waltz, Strauss.

title: Whitehurst Brothers Gain in Yachting
description: KINGSTON, Ontario, July 22Warned by both his Canadian girlfriend and his team doctor to win or else, Bob Whitehurst gave the United States a firstplace finish today in the 470 Class of the Olympic yachting competition.

title: St. Tropez Also Likes It
description: ST. TROPEZ, FranceBrigitte Bardot was paid a million francs (almost $200,000) for wearing tight pants this summer in a television commercial, but most St. Tropez regulars don't look for such a monetary incentive. They are pouring themselves into skinny pants because it's fashionable.

title: Trenton Panel Rules Judge Is Unfit to Remain on Bench
description: TRENTON, July 22, (AP)A Special threejudge panel stated today that a Jersey City municipal judge, John W. Yengo, had demonstrated he was unfit to remain on the bench.

title: Yaun Leads by 3 In N.Y. State Golf
description: LIBERTY, N.Y., July 22 (AP)Radford Yaun of Liberty took a threestroke lead today after the third round of the New York State men's amateur golf tournament at Grossingers. With one round remaining tomorrow, Yaun had rounds of 74, 75 and 74 for a 223 total. Steve Cruse of Fairport was second with a 226 after a sixoverpar 77 today.

title: Stuck Scoop May Stall Hunt for Martian Life
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 22An apparent malfunction in the Viking 1 landing craft's soilcollection scoop was reported tonight by James S. Martin Jr., the project manager. If it is not understood and solved in short order, he said, the problem could delay plans to begin gathering soil on Mars for initial examinations for living organisms set for next Wednesday.

title: Business in Europe
description: PARIS, July 22The output graphs in Economics Ministries across Western Europe are all showing a comforting upward curve. Bankers and businessmen are talking a little more optimistically about future profits. Slowly, the high jobless rates have been coming down.

title: Advertising
description: Just about a year ago Don Durgin, once president of the NBCTV Network, was named president of McCaffrey & McCall, the advertising agency. Now, after a visit to his office adorned with memorabilia of his broadcast days, it can be reported that he is happy in his work.

title: A Bad Attitude in Vietnam
description: NO BUGLES, NO DRUMS. By Charles Darden. 287 pages. Viking. $8.95.

title: About Real Estate
description: WASHINGTON  Within the Department of Housing and Urban Development a detailed reevaluation of the new towns program is in progress. This is the program under which the Government has guaranteed $280 million in loans since 1970 to help build large new residential and commercial clusters throughout the nation.

title: Surgery Error Is Blamed In Music Executive's Death
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 (UPI) Taft B. Schreiber, an executive of MCA Inc., died because he had been given a transfusion of incompatible blood in surgery, the County Coroner's office reported today.

title: Nomination Of Shirk Held Questionable
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Queens Democrat, raised conflictofinterest goestions today about the nomination of Stanley E. Shirk. a retired accountant, as Comptroller of the Currency.

title: Antiques
description: FLEA markets represent booming business to hundreds of thousands of parttime entrepreneurs these days. They are also the bazaars many eagleeyed collectors comb for what only they may recognize as true rarities.

title: The Labor Scene
description: The storms that were expected to make a shambles of labor management relations in the first half of 1976 never materialized, but the second half is off to a turbulent start. Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr., the Federal Government's most expert industrial troubleshooter, has had to put on repeatedly the mediator's hat he thought he was hanging up for good when he entered the Cabinet early this year.

title: BRITISH ANNOUNCE PLANS TO REDUCE SPENDING IN 1977
description: LONDON, July 22  Britain announced today that it was going to cut Government spending next year by 1 billion in an effort to protect the pound, reduce the nation's budget deficit and sustain its fragile economic recovery.

title: Fifth of City's Medicaid Mills Called Responsible for Abuses
description: The executive medical director of the New York City, idealth Department's medical program said yesterday that a fifth of the city's Medicaid mills either were involved in Medicaid fraud or provided substandard medical care.

title: Utility to Try Out a Lower, Night Rate
description: NEWARK, July 22 The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today announced an experiment to determine the value, in terms of energy conservation and utility costs, of reducing electricity rates at night to encourage the use of power consumption over a 24hour period and lower the costly peaktime demand during daylight hours.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Notes on People
description: Pat Nixon is scheduled to be discharged from the hospital in Long Beach, Calif., today. She suffered a stroke 15 days ago that left part of her left side paralyzed and affected her speech. She has responded well to therapy at the hospital, according to doctors, and will continue the therapy at her San Clemente home. A hospital aide said doctors had predicted full or neartotal recovery from the stroke in three or four months.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRACKETTS. Cora. July 23, 1967. Absence can be measured in time, but fortunately Fond Memories are not limited to any dimension. REG.

title: TWO SITES STUDIED FOR A POWER PLANT
description: STUYVESANT, N.Y., July 22 (AP)A $3.2 billion, 2,400. megawatt power plant may be built on a site in this Columbia County town, about a halfmile from the Hudson River, Newl York State Electric and Gas Company officials announced yesterday.

title: Motorcycling Cult: From Wild Ones To Mild Ones
description: Some time ago, Malcolm Forbes; decided he was spending much of his time enveloped in a compartment of steel, so he bought a motorcycle. It was an event that changed his life.

title: Inner City Mother Goose Ban Asked
description: WEST ORANGE, July 22The Policemen's Benevolent Association in this Essex County suburb is seeking a court order that would force the library to remove what it describes as a book that is not only antiblack, antipolice, and antiJPuerto Rican,, but which also glorifies crime and drug use.

title: White House Denies Reagan Accusation On Bid to Delegates
description: WASHINGTON. July 22 The White House rejected. today Ronald Reagan's cornplaint of heavyhanded campaign tactics by asserting that President Ford had ordered Cabinet officers to spurn any attempts by delegates to the Republican National Convention to trade their votes for Government jobs or favors.

title: CARTER PROMISES CAUTION ON TAXES
description: Jimmy Carter told a group of leading corporate executives yesterday that, if he was elected President, he would move cautiously on tax reform and would retain the credit on foreign taxes paid by American companies.

title: Business Trends
description: When Conrail, the federally financed Northeast railroad, recently unveiled its new corporate symbola stylized C on a double tracksome railroad men quipped that it looked like the C had hit an obstacle and was toppling over.

title: Aid Sought By Parent Of Pennsy
description: The Penn Central Company, holder of all the stock of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, joined its subsidiary yesterday in filing for court protection from creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Harvard to Return jade To Mexican Government
description: A unique and priceless collection of 240 Mayan jade artificats, excavated from sacrificial well in Yucatan between 1904 and 1909, will be returned to the Mexican Government in Mexico City tomorrow by the Peabody Museum of Harvard University.

title: People and Business
description: Thomas G. Labrecque a banker who was deeply involved in the New York City debt restructuring last year, has been named to the management committee of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: How to Get There
description: Head for the intersection of Interstate Route 684 and Route 35 in northern Westchester. This can be done several ways: from the New England Thruway or the Tappan Zee Bridge by taking the Cross Westchester Expressway (287) to its interchange with 684. From the West Side Highway by following its extensions, the Henry Hudson and Saw Mill River Parkways, to their convenient terminus at the 68435 intersection. From there, take Route 35 east to Route 121, a fiveminute drive, and turn right. The entrance to the reservation is on the left, a few hundred yards from that intersection.

title: Uganda's President Allows Release of French Airlner
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 22An Air France airliner that had remained at Entebbe airport. Uganda, since it was hijacked late last month, was flown to Paris today after President Idi Amin gave his permission.

title: Week's Auto Output Off
description: DETROIT, July 22American auto production is scheduled to total 102,933 cars this week off 27.6 percent from last week's 142,124 units because of; model changeover operations at more plants, according to the trade paper Automotive News. However, this week's output is still 31.7 percent ahead of the, 78,128 cars built in the same week last year.

title: ARMY POSTPONES TANK ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Army, in what could develop into a major step toward standardization of weapons among the Atlantic allies, reluctantly and unexpectedly delayed today its selection of a new main battle tank.

title: South Africa, in Economic Crisis, Pins Hopes on Gold
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 22South Africa, a country built on gold, is facing one of its most serious economic crises since World War II as a result of the fall in the metal's price.

title: Offshore Oil Bill Takes Environment Info Consideration
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The House has approved an offshore oil and gas bill designed to balance environmental needs with those for energy and give small companies a better chance of having bids accepted for Federal leases.

title: Health Services Emergency
description: The agreement last week to settle the strike against voluntary hospitals through arbitration in no way eases the growing health services emergency in New York.

title: TAPE IN DISPUTE AT HARRIS TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 22Legal battles erupted today at the trial of William and Emily Harris over an inquiry into possible jury tampering and the admissibility into evidence of a crucial tape the prosecution wants the jury to hear as its case closes.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: H.E.W. Threatens to End Aid In 10 Northern School Districts
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it was preparing to take formal civil rights enforcement action against 10 school districts in the North that could lead to a cutoff of Federal funds.

title: Quarry Owner's Son Called a Loner Fond of Old Cars
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22Fred Newhall Woods, who is being sought for questioning in the investigation of the kidnapping of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver in Chowchilla, is the scion of a prominent California family and has been described by acquaintances as a loner with a fascination for old cars, which he collected on a vast estate his family has owned for generations.

title: Deaths
description: ARNOLDSamuel, In his 93rd year. Belove?? father of Dr. Lean, cherished fatherinraw of Bernice and Iris, adored grandfather of Robyn, Richard, Robert, Rosemarie, Elizabeth Susan, Joan and Nancy. Services today 2 P.M. at Park West Chapers, 115 West 79 St.

title: Director Says House Unit Staff Did Not Give Report to Schorr
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)  The staff director of the House intelligence committee said oday he was confident that none of his employes had given a secret report to Daniel Schorr, a televisin reporter.

title: A's Defeat Yanks On Run in 9th, 65
description: The ingredients for a party were all there, Thirty champagne glasses, plates, forks and a chocolate cake saying Happy Birthday Sparky in green adorned a table in the Yankee clubhouse. Two bottles of Taylor New York State champagne waited in the cooler in the players' lounge.

title: B. F. Goodrich Net Off 74% in Period; Sales Up 10.2%; Others Report
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company. one of the four major rubber companies on strike since April 21 reported yesterday a 74 percent decline in secondquarter profits to $3.4 million, or 20 cents a share from a restated $13.1 million, or 88 cents a share, a year earler.

title: Untangling Tanglewood
description: DESCRIBING Tanglewood is simple. It's place where a quartre of a million people go each summer to hear the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Yes, and Don Giovanni is simply an opera about a rake, and the Mona Lisa is a picture of a girl with a crooked smile. The barebones facts, though unassailable, always leave out the flesh and blood of truth.

title: Good Plan for Rhodesia
description: An allout war between blacks and whites in southern Africa would be a horror in itself, would poison race relations in many parts of the world and virulently exacerbate international tensions in Africa and beyond.

title: Rwanda Suffering Gasoline Shortage Over Uganda Snag
description: KIGALI. Rwanda, July 22 (UPI)  This landlocked East African country appears on the brink of economic collapse. It has only enough gasoline for five days because its supplies, which normally conic from Kenya through Rwanda's northern neighbor, Uganda, are not getting through.

title: EDUCATION BOARD DROPS RAISE PLAN
description: Responding to pressure from Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, the New York City Board of Education voted on Wednesday night to withdraw without prejudice a resolution that would have authorized pay increases totaling $445,000 for 252 board employees.

title: Kidnapping Inquiry Seeks Son of Owner of Quarry
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., July 22Law enforcement officials said today that they were seeking Fred Newhall Woods of Portola Valley and two of his friends for questioning in the kidnapping last Thursday of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver near Chowchilla, 100 miles east of here.

title: Executions Stayed By Justice Powell As Petition Is Filed
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Justice Lewis F. Powell today stayed the imposition of death sentences in three states until the Supreme Court could hear a request that it reconsider its decision upholding capital punshment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gateway to the Outdoors
description: It is very early in the morning. The sky is making the transition from predawn black to the soft glow of sunrise. Two young lovers are walking along a pebbly beach, stooping every now and then to pick up clam shells that were washed ashore. Near the beach is a marshy area that is beginning to come alive with the sounds of nature waking up.

title: Override on Jobs
description: Both Senate and House have now overridden President Ford's veto of the $3.95 billion public works employment bill, with plenty of room to spare beyond the required twothirds majority.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: EG.Maddox, DPPhiladelphia 3. LOBPittsburgh 6, Philadelphia 3. 2BJohnstone. SBBowa.

title: Some Find Children's Center Better Than Expected
description: Nydia Stewart and Sal Gala tioto were surprised by what they found when they went to work at the Children's Center on 104th Street and Fifth Avenue  which they had heard was an unruly place where violent children assault each other and staff members.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two masked gunmen invaded a garden apartment Lawrence, L.I., Wednesday night and, after handcuffing Seymour Torem, 52 years old; his wife, Renee, and 17yearold daughter, Jill, escaped with $150,000 in jewelry and $1,000 in cash, the Nassau County Police reported. During the robbery, Mrs. Torem's brother, Emanuel Wennick, 47, saw one of the masked men through a window. He summoned the police from a nearby store, but the gunmen were gone by the time they arrived. No one was injured.

title: Ford Host to New Yorkers In Bid for Delegate Votes
description: Dramatizing his intense pursuit of Republican National Convention delegates, President Ford was host to more than 100 New York delegates at the White House last evening.

title: For the Leopard's Lovers, Good News. For the Cheetah's, Bad.
description: OXFORD, EnglandThe leopard in Africa is alive and moderately well, but the cheetah is in poor shape.

title: Loews Paradise (and Others) Regained
description: Through the late 1920's, the depressed 30's and the warstricken 40's, movie palaces loomed over the New York landscape like transplanted Taj Mahels or Versailles. They were built to entertain the masses, and they didincomparably. To their ornate interiorsmarble columns, pseudoGreek and Roman and Egyptian sculpture, cupids frolicking in murals on the ceilingscame millions of moviegoers, eager to snare the romantic frustrations and fulfillments of such legendary names as Garbo and Gable and Dietrich and Boyer and Harlow. At Loews Paradise in the Bronx, and some others, the mood was enhanced by stars and clouds that drifted ceaselessly across the ceiling.

title: Getting There Is Half the Battle
description: On Friday nights if the traffic is jammed on the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive, John Howard will steer his Peugeot from his residence on East 69th Street up Third Avenue to 124th Street across the Triborough Bridge and the Major Deegan Expressway. This route, you would think, should he used by motorists connecting north to Albany, but at a crucial moment, Mr. Howard turns onto the Cross Bronx Expressway and then onto the Throgs Neck Bridge and toward his destination, Long Island, and his weekend home in Amagansett.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: In the heat of a July afternoon, the events of last winter's snowfall remain vivid. School had been canceled. Eric and his friend Greg, bath 12, were sledding in Riverside Park.

title: SOWETO'S SCHOOLS REOPEN AMID CALM
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 22Calm prevailed today in Soweto and other black townships around Johannesburg and Pretoria as black students returned to classes for the first time since schools were closed during last month's rioting, in which 176 people died.

title: Taylor Trounced By Connors, 61, 61
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)SecondSeeded Jimmy Connors trounced Roger Taylor of Britain, 61, 61, today in the third round of the $125,000 Washington Star tennis tournament.

title: COUNTIES TO FIGHT OILLEASE PLANS
description: While the State of New Jersey hopes for Congressional action to protect its shores from the impact of offshore oil drilling, resort areas of the state are planning legal action without waiting for Congress.

title: Itek, Now Diversified, Is Product of Space Age
description: The amazing clarity of the pictures of the surface of Mars brought back to Earth this week by the electrooptical camera system of the Itek Corporation seems to have rekindled somewhat the apparent waning interest of the American public in space.

title: U.S. Men Continue Dominance in Olympic Swimming
description: The United States men continued their dominance in swimming at the Olympic Games in Montreal yesterday with two more goldmedal victories, both in worldrecord time. They have won all of the nine events thus far.

title: 6 State Troopers Are Indicted For Misuse of Turnpike Credit
description: TRENTON, July 22A grand jury indicted today six state troopers and an employee of the Exxon Company on charges of misusing gasoline credit cards of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: Gaps Loom In Opening Of Track
description: MONTREAL, July 22  Finals in the women's long jump and the men's 20kilometer walk will highlight the start of track and field competition tomorrow at the Olympic Games.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Favorite Ousted In Junior Tennis
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22 (AP)  Topseeded Larry Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla was upset by John McEnroe of Douglas Manor, Queens, 67, 62, 75, today in the quarterfinals of the National Junior claycourt tennis championships. McEnron was seeded eighth.

title: Burns, With 65, Leading By 1 in Canadian Open
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, July 22 (AP)George Burns didn't seem to believe his fiveunderpar 65 would hold up. It nearly didn't.

title: United Methodists Get a New Bishop
description: PRINCETON, July 22The reins of spiritual and administrative authority in the New Jersey Area of the United Methodist Church were informally transferred here today in an aura of good fellowship and warmth.

title: Voight Is a HamletinProgress
description: Hamlet was a work in progress at Rutgers University this week.

title: Bridge:
description: Four American sharpshooters, Robert Jordan, Arthur Robinson and Norman Kay of Philadelphia, and Edgar Kaplan of New York, took leisurely aim yesterday in Philadelphia and made every shot tell.

title: Stuck Scoop May Stall Hunt for Martian Life
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 22An apparent malfunction in the Viking I landing craft's soilcollection scoop was reported tonight by James S. Martin Jr., the project manager. If it is not understood and solved in short order, he said, the problem could delay plans to begin gathering soil on Mars fo?? biological examination next Wednesday.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars) Dally Averages for the weeks puded:

title: NEW WEEKLY HIGH IN ELECTRIC OUTPUT
description: The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that total output of electricity in the 48 contiguous states for the week ended July 17 had hit a new weekly high of 42.46 billion kilowatt hours. The previous high was the 41.79 billion k.w.h. set in the week ended Sept. 1. 1973.

title: Records: Secular Josquin
description: If you tend to think of preBaroque music as primarily a religious phenomenon, this record will set you straight. Josquin, like other great Renaissance composers, wrote many masses, some of which are available on records. But he also turned his attention to worldly matters, as liefitted the age in which he lived

title: Princess Astride
description: BROMONT, Quebec, July 22The program is entitled Jeux de la XXIie Olympiade, Sports equestres, and on Page 15 the reader is advised that as its name implies, the ThreeDay Event . . . takes four days to complete. It goes on to say that the first two days of the competition are devoted to dressage, a demonstration of the horse's obedience, suppleness and impulsion as well the rider's accuracy, balance and rhythm in cooperation with the horse. The words look good on the page. They look so good they really ought to mean something, but a man frowning over them in the press box must have betrayed his unfamiliarity with the sport by his expression, for the lady at his left spoke reassuring. The judges know very little about it, she said. She was a charming lady from Copenhagen with a name like a University of Minnesota football star, Dinny Lund. It turned out that she was also knowledgeable. Like that countryman of hers who could tell a hawk from a handsaw, she knew a canter from a trot.

title: TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: FRIDAY

title: U.S. Judge Says H. E .W . Erred In Denying 13 States $1 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) A Federal district judge has ruled that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare wrongfully withheld at least $1.3 billion in payments sought by 13 states for social services programs.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: PRIME RATE CUT IS EXPECTED SOON
description: A reduction in the prime lending rate of commercial banks may be in store as a result of the recent downward trend in shortterm money market rates confirmed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Two Banks Termed Enforcers Of Arabs' AntiIsrael Boycott
description: The American Jewish Congress said yesterday that it had filed a complaint with the State Division of Human Rights against Citibank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company charging them with serving as enforcers of the Arab boycott against Israel, in violation of a recently enacted state law.

title: News Guild Beats Independents In Election at Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Members of the Newspaper Guild at The Washington Post have voted, 445 to 315, to retain the Guild as their bargaining agent, the National Labor Relations Board said today.

title: Amex Stock Prices Drop, OTC Gains in Slow Day
description: Stock prices moved down a little on the American Stock Exchange in slow trading yesterday. The Amex market value index closed at 104.57, down 0.23.

title: 3 Big Stores in New York Plan to Open on Sundays
description: Three of New York City's largest retailersMacy's, Korvette and Alexander's  which collectively transact a billion dollars in annual sales in the area  are mapping plans for the first largescale Sunday openings of department stores in the city and in the metropolitan area, starting possibly as early as Aug. 29.

title: Renoir Stolen in '74 Returned to Museum In Brooklyn by Mail
description: A small Renoir painting that was stolen from the Brooklyn Museum 19 months ago was returned undamaged to the museum in the afternoon mail on Wednesday.

title: CARTER PROMISES CAUTION ON TAXES
description: Jimmy Carter told a group of leading corporate executives yesterday that, if he was elected President, he would move cautiously on tax reform and would retain the credit on foreign taxes paid by American companies.

title: Rosengarden Above It All
description: Bobby Rosengarden, the drummer, has been a ubiquitous figure for the last three weeks. During the Newport Jazz Festival, he drummed in Pee Wee Erwin's band at the Jersey Jazz picnic at Waterloo Village, with the World's Greatest Jazz Band on the festival's Hudson River boat ride and with the New York Jazz Repertory Company in its survey of the music of Duke Ellington.

title: JUNE ORDERS UP IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, July 22New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods rose substantially again in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 3 Skippers Keep Marks Unbeaten
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22  The 78th Larchmont Race Week reverted to its normal course today as a small fleet of 144 raced over 11.4, 10.2 and 9.2 mile courses.

title: The Liberry
description: A small boy in one of William Saroyan's stories finds himself in the public library for the first time. He looks around in awe: All them books, he says, and something written in each one!

title: EDWARD J. MULLER
description: Edward J. Muller, secretarytreasurer of the J. C. Bossong Company, a hosiery manufacturer, died yesterday after he was hit by a truck near his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: News Summary and Index
description: Britain announced yesterday that it was going to cut Government spending next year by billion, about $1.78 billion, by today's exchange rate, to protect the pound, rescue its budget deficit and sustain its fragile economic recovery. [Page AI, Col. 3.]

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.14 billion, up 9 percent from the yearearlier $1.05 billion. Total retail store sales were about $12.37 billion, up 8 percent from last year's $11.42 billion.

title: Prices Fall In Soybeans And Grains
description: Rains came for the third day to the Midwest growing areas, and the longstraders who owned contracts  abandoned their positions as fast as they could.

title: Ballet Theater Has U.S. Stars, Too
description: Can a young dancer from Kensington, Md., Parsons, Kan., or Los Angeles find success in a ballet company famous for its roster of international imports? The answer is an emphatic yes, if you ask Marianna Tcherkassky, Clark Tippet and Charles Ward, three rising young stars at American Ballet Theater, which is performing this weekend at the New York State Theater.

title: And Steelers Vie Tonight
description: CHICAGO, July 22The football season opens here tomorrow night, ready or not. Ara Parseghian, the retired Notre Dame coach, has in 16 days put together the annual edition of the College AllStars, and they will take on the National Football League champions, the Pittsburgh Steelers, at Soldier Field before a crowd of about 45,000  10,000 fewer than capacity.

title: Sir Mortimer Wheeler Is Dead; British Archeologist Was 85
description: LONDON, July 22 (UPI)Sir Mortimer Wheeler, a pioneer of modern scientific archeology, (died today at a friend's home at Leatherhead, 18 miles southwest of London. He was 85 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Federal Power Commission decided today on a price increase on natural gas from new fields and on about 20 percent of present interstate gas supplies. However, the agency sa:d it would keep secret until Tuesday the size of the increase so that the threemember majority and the one dissenter, Don S. Smth, could wirte their respective opinions.

title: Kissinger Suggests A 4CountryParley On Korea's Future
description: SEATTLE, July 22 (UPI)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger proposed today that the United States, China, North Korea and South Korea hold a conference on Korea's future.

title: Legislatures in South Resisting Prison Officials on Reforms to Reduce Crowding
description: ATLANTA, July 22Southern prison officials have run into stiff resistance from their state legislatures in attempts to implement prison reforms that would relieve severe overcrowding.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Art People
description: FEDERAL judges, who know what they don't like in the way of art, are raising an offbench flap in Baltimore over a sculpture commissioned for their courthouse by the Federal Government. Concerned that the largescale environmental work, by the New York artist George Sugarman, might serve dissidents as a platform for speaking or hurling objects, or a place to secrete bombs or other explosive objects, the judges want the project scrapped.

title: Large Irish Force Hunts Killers of Britain's Envoy
description: DUBLIN, July 22Four thousand policemen and hundreds of soldiers were involved today in one of the biggest manhunts in Ireland's history for the killers of the British Ambassador, Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs, and Judith Cooke, a 26yearold civil servant.

title: Riding Tall in the Saddle in New York
description: When I was six years old, I won a horse in a raffle at the Winnebago County Fair in the great state of Iowa. I named him Topper, after Hopalong Cassidy's faithful silver steed. Since that day, I have been nuts about horses, and that is why my favorite thing to do on a New York weekend is to glide through the bridle paths of Central Park on the back of Gay Emily.

title: LABOR SUPPORTERS LISTED BY O'DWYER
description: Paul O'Dwyer, President of the New York City Council, made public yesterday a list of 54 trade union leaders and members supporting him for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator and said many more were prepared to endorse him.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.7 billion tonmiles, 7.1 percent above the corresponding week year ago.

title: Prison Search Finds Guns
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 22 (AP)Three pistols were discovered at the New Hampshire Prison on Tuesday night after the officials were informed of plans for an armed escape by some inmates, Attorney General David H. Souter said today, Mr. Souter said the three weapons were discovered on prison property about 11:30 P.M., just 10 minutes after the police began searching for them.

title: White House Denies Reagan Accusation On Bid to Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The White House rejected today Ronald Reagan's complaint of heavyhanded campaign tactics by asserting that President Ford had ordered Cabinet officers to spurn any attempts by delegates to the Republican National Convention to trade their votes for Government fobs or favors.

title: Argentine Chief Meets Bishops On Political Slaying of Priests
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 22President Jorge Rafael Videla, head of Argentina's military junta, met today with bishops of the Roman Catholic Church here to discuss political violence in which five priests have been killed in a little more than two weeks.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: AT HEMPSTEAD G.C. L.I.G.A. JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Americans on Watch in Sinai Passes Find Life Boring
Influenza Virus Continues to Keep Scientists Guessing
description: In creating the influenza virus, nature unleashed one of the most tickle, enigmatic and persistent microbes known to attack man or beast.

title: A National Bulletin Issued For 3 in Coast Kidnapping
description: REDWOOD CITY. Calif., July 22Alameda County officials issued a national allpoints bulletin late today for the arrest of three young men for questioning in the kidnapping last Thursday of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver near Chowchilla, 100 miles east of here.

title: The Night Was Made for Music
description: THE OUTDOOR CONCERT season is at its peak this weekend with performances in skating rinks, hail parks, sculpture gardens and parkseven in a hand shell.

title: Mondale Seeing Carter About Campaign
description: WASHINGTON. July 22Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Vice  Presidential nominee, leaves early tomorrow for what amounts to his first real campaigning and several days of meetings with Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Market Profile
description: Thursday. July 22 1976

title: WILLIAN SCATCHARD
description: Willian Beaumont Scatchard, a retired Smith College music professor, died Saturday at Lexington, Mass., nursing home. She was 84 years old.

title: Olympic Sidelights
description: MONTREAL, July 22A pair of American shooters gave sexual equality a shot in the arm today as a man and woman shared the victory stand to protest the method used to break ties in the threeposition, smallbore rifle event.

title: The Senate Leadership
description: Although the Senate majority leadership is not to be decided for another five months, the rival candidates are already energetically at work trying to line up committed votes. The issue is to be decided by a secret ballot by members of the Senate Democratic caucus, and a considerable number of Senators are keeping their intentions very much to themselves.

title: Lebanon Moslems Form Own Civil Rule
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 (AP)  A leftist leader announced today the creation of a civil administration for Moslemcontrolled territory of Lebanon.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: One of the best ways to learn how to have a beautiful vegetable garden is to read the backs of seed packets. These will tell you when and how deep to plant the seeds, how much to thin out the young plants, and inform you about water needs and potential pestsin fact, just about everything except when to harvest your crops.

title: Bond Traders Hail MoneySupply Data
description: Trading was quiet and price changes were small yesterday in the credit markets as dealers exhibited their typical Thursday caution while awaiting the release of weekly moneysupply figures. The Federal Reserve's announcement that the basic money supply fell by $200 million for the week ended July 14 had the effect of cheering the credit markets late in the afternoon.

title: EDWARD W. DURNER
description: Edward W. Durner, who retired in 1968 as an assistant jvice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, New York, died Wednesday in Bayshore Community Hospital, Holmdel, N. J., after a lingering illness. His age was 73.

title: Pop Life
description: TWO hundred musicians and their equipment and instruments left John F. Kennedy International Airport yesterday for Le Cartellet, France, where between 200,000 and 300,000 people are expected to attend Riviera '76, a threeday festival that begins this evening. The producer of the event, Mike Lang, was coproducer of the Woodstock festival of 1967. He was caught by surprise by the crowds that came to Woodstock, but this time he is prepared. The festival site is the Circuit Paul Ricard, a 1,500acre race track surrounded by a concrete wall eight feet high. Ample medical, culinary, and sanitary facilities are promised, along with a threedimensional laser light show. A nearby island has been rented for the musicians, who will be ferried to the festival by helicopter and speedboat.

title: Dance: Nadia Potts as Aurora
description: From its first visit here three years ago, the National Ballet of Canada has always presented four different dancers in the role of Princess Aurora in Rudolf Nureyev's production of The Sleeping Beauty.

title: HOUSE POST URGED FOR MRS. CHISHOLM
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The New York State Democratic Congressional delegation which, with one fleeting exception, has not been represented in a top leadership position in the House of Representatives since the Civil War, today nominated Representative Shirley A. Chisholm of Brooklyn to be chairman of the House Democratic Caucus.

title: Marcia Haydee Brings Fall River to Life
description: Agnes de Mille is a special American sensibility. She evokes America, in a way some other choreographers only suggest. I happen not to admire too much Fall River Legend, her dramatization of what might have happened to Lizzie Borden, and yet, as time goes on, I can recognize its strength. Nothing that audiences like so much can be bad. What can a critic say?

title: Shift in Winds Could Aid Fishermen in Local Area
description: The recent shift in coastal winds from the traditional southwest to northeast may bring improved marine angling from New Jersey to Cape Cod this weekend.

title: Court Rejects Brutality Suit Against Suffolk Police
description: A Federal judge has dismissed 11 suit filed by a coalition of civil rights organizations that had charged the Suffolk County Police Department with using excessive physical force and racial insults against members of minority groups.

title: World Team Tennis
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Lisbon Bombings Imperil Ties With 2 ExColonies
description: LISBON. July 22Bomb at tacks against the offices of the Mozambique airline and an unofficial consulate of Angola within 24 hours of each other have jeopardized Portugal's already tenuous relations with its two former colonies.

title: 3 HELD IN SLAYING OF GUARD IN QUEENS
description: Three men were charged yesterday with the murder of a Transit Authority detective during a $34,000 holdup of a Long Island City, Queens, checkcashing company last month.

title: Terrorists' Techniques Improve, and So Do Efforts to Block Them
description: PARIS July 22Radical groups from several countries and of various persuasions are increasingly able to coordinate their acts of terrorism and threaten the lives of hundreds of people in a single operation. At the sanie time the identities of individual terrorists and their organizations, training areas, patterns of activity and support are becoming increasingly known to intelligence specialists around the world.

title: No.Amer.Soccer League
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: PUBLIC JOBS BILL ENACTED AS HOUSE ALSO UPSETS VETO
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The House of Representatives overrode President Ford's veto and enacted into law today a $4 billion public works bill that has the primary aim of creating jobs. The Senate overrode the veto yesterday.

title: Flu Vaccine Drive Meets Snags That Could Limit It
description: The program of mass immunization against swine flu an nounced by President Ford nearly four months ago has been meeting an increasing barrage of scientific and medical criticism and technical obstacles.

title: L.I. Panel Is Divided on Banned Books
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 22A special committee appointed to review 11 books that had been removed from the junior and senior high school libraries in the Island Trees school district appears to be divided on whether the books should be returned to the shelves, a school source said today.

title: Publishing: What Jimmy Carter Reads
description: QUOTES from a newly nominated candidate for President: On books: I think my favorite book of all time, strangely enough, is Let Us Now Praise Famous Men, by James Agee, because of the analysis of the way I lived. That was the way I grew up. As far as an analysis of the Presidents are concerned, Presidential Character [by James David Barber] is the best book I've ever read.

title: NEW ABUSES CITED ON FOOD FOR NEEDY
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, charged yesterday that Istate inspectors had made apparently false declarations that hid abuses in the Summer Food Service Program for needy New York City children.

title: Beame Is Given a Major Role In Carter's Campaign in State
description: Mayor Beame will play a major role, Governor Carey a lesser role and Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, not much of a role at all in the CarterforPresident campaign in New York State, according to those involved in shaping the plans.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITIES

title: Assembly Votes Package Of 3 Bond Referendums
description: TRENTON, July 22  The State Assembly passed a threebill package this evening that would place $225 million in bond referendums for water, housing and institutional needs before the voters for approval in November.

title: MARIE BALDRIDGE
description: Marie Baldridge, a teacher of English and psychologist, died Tuesday at Sloan  Kettering Memorial Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 41 Fifth Avenue.

title: Silvestrone Leads by a Stroke
description: WEST ORANGE. N. J., July 22Jack Kiefer, the defender, made a rush at the lead in the second round of the 56th New Jersey State Golf Association open championship today but could not. quite overtake Art Silvestrone Sr., who hung on by a stroke at the halfway point of this 72hole tournament.

title: How to Get There
description: By car from New York, take the Garden State Parkway for the entire 160mile trip, or take the New Jersey Turnpike and connect with the parkway at Woodbridge. The Parkway endsor beginsin Cape May.

title: Better Training Is Key to Swim Records
description: MONTREAL, July 23 There were no world records in Olympic swimming today, only because there was no Olympic swimming. Five days of competition are over. and the last events will be held tomorrow and Sunday. Then, of course, more world records will be broken.

title: About New York
description: I remember Johnny telling me that one of the first shows he saw after he came to New York from Savannah in 1928 was the Music Box Review right in this theater. said Stanley Adams.

title: CHARGES RULED OUT IN FATAL BUS CRASH
description: MARTINEZ, Calif., July 23 (UPI)There is insufficient evidence to warrant criminal prosecution in the May 21 bus crash that killed 26 Yuba City youngsters and a chaperone, the Contra Costa County district attorney said yesterday.

title: Canada Issues Rules Limiting Use of French in Air Control
description: OTTAWA, July 23 (AP)The Government issued regulations today forbidding the use of the French language in Canadian airtraffic control except at certain Quebec airports.

title: The Cast
description: FOUR SCHUMANN PIECES (American premiere). Choreography, Hans van Manen; music, Robert Schumann; costume and set design, Jean Paul Vroom. Presented by the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Carter's Aides Meet With Catholic Bishops' Staff
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI)There have been some intermediate level contacts between Jimmy Carter's campaign staff and the staff of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops to outline certain issues the church is interested sources at the bishops' conference said today.

title: Brazil Nears Mining Boom With Bonanza of Iron Ore
description: SERRA DOS CARAJAS, BrazilThe old DC3 glided past the Amazon rain forests and touched down on a gravel airstrip that felt as smooth as a metal runway.

title: Red Cross Officials Enter Beirut Camp
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23Red Cross representatives managed to enter a besieged Palestinian camp here today for the first time to try to arrange the evacuation of more than 1,000 wounded. They said the next move was up to the combatants.

title: The Flu Problems
description: The Federal Government's plan to immunize every American against swine influenza illustrates the dilemma officials face in making riskbenefit decisions about public health matters at a time when the state of the economy stresses costeffective analyses and when preventive medicine is emphasized.

title: Texaco Net Rises; Hess Shows a Drop
description: Texaco Inc. announced higher earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1976, while the Amerada Hess Corporation reported a drop in profits for both periods.

title: F.B.I. Is Told to Report On Its Rosenberg Files
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)Federal District Judge June L. Green today ordered the Federal Bureal of Investigation to search the files of its 59 field offices for any information on Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and report back to her within 21 days.

title: Tally Indicates That Ford Is Close to Delegate Goal
description: WASHINGTON, July 23President Ford moved today within close range of the 1,130 delegates needed to secure the Republican Presidential nomination, a tally by The New York Times showed, while his campaign leaders asserted that he already had more than enough.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITIES

title: 14 Disputed TaxBill Provisions Deleted
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Senate Finance Committee decided today to remove from the pending tax bill 14 provisions that affect only one or two companies each and to modify five other provisions.

title: CORRECTION
description: The sales and earnings of Solitron Devices Inc. were incorrectly listed in the corporate earnings table in The Times yesterday. The correct figures appear in today's table on Page 34.

title: Howe Found Guilty in Sex Case; He Will Continue in House Race
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 23Representative Allan T. Howe was found guilty today of offering money to two police women decoys for the performance of sex acts for hire.

title: MINERS BROADEN WILDCAT STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A wildcat strike by coal miners that began last week in West Virginia spread across the Appalachian coal fields today, bringing the number of strikers to 25.000.

title: Security Tightened
description: MONTREAL, July 23The already tight security at the Olympic Village was reinforced today after two incidents that ruffled the Canadian police, who have been going to extreme measures to prevent the kind of terrorism that cost the lives of 11 Israeli athletes in Munich in 1972.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 24, 1976

title: Forego and Foolish Pleasure To Match Strides at Aqueduct
description: A pair of millionairesLazy F Ranch's Forego and John Greer's Foolish Pleasureare slated to hook up again at Aqueduct this afternoon. The two stars are to head a field of 11 in the $100,000 added Brooklyn Handicap. Although beaten by Foolish Pleasure by a nose on their previous outingin the 1 3/16mile Suburban on July 5  Forego, who will have an entrymate in Arabian Law, is the 7to5 overnight favorite. Foolish Pleasure is second choice at 3 to 1.

title: Soviet Five Routs American Women
description: MONTREAL, July 23How often does a 7foot Soviet woman score in a basketball game?

title: Nathaniel Goldfinger, 59, Dies; A.F.L.C.I.O. Research Head
description: WASHINGTON, July 23Nathaniel Goldfinger, an economist who was research director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for 13 years, died last night at his home in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A $165 million pulp and newsprint manufacturing complex jointly owned by American and Japanese interests will be built at Longview, Wash., the North Pacific Paper Company said yesterday.

title: Jersey Open Title Retained by Kiefer
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 23Jack Kiefer intends to go out on the Professional Golfers' Association tour sometimes this fall. At age 36, he might he one of the oldest tour rookies in P.G.A. history.

title: Toth Plans Statement
description: DENVER, July 23Laszo Toth arrived in Denver tonight aboard a United Air Lines flight from New York. He was met by officials of the Great Western Sugar Company and members of his family.

title: How They Stand Today
description: Saturday, July 24, 1976

title: YUGOSLAVIA FREES AMERICAN CITIZEN
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23A Yugoslavborn American accused of economic espionage was freed today after nearly a year in prison and flown to the United States.

title: SCIENTISTS FEEL THEY CAN FIX ARM ON VIKING LANDER
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 23Viking 1 project officials expressed growing confidence today that they understood the problem with the spacecraft's balky soilsampling arm and should be able to correct it in time to scoop up Martian soil for scientific analysis next Wednesday.

title: Rhodesian Law Would Conscript Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 23 (AP)  Rhodesian blacks would be drafted into the armed services for the first time under legislation introduced today. Prime Minister Ian D. Smith also said that his white minority Government would ease some public restrictions on blacks, but he has rejected three major racial reforms.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: Payment Cutoff Ordered In Food Center Abuses
description: Federal officials yesterday directed the State Department of Education to withhold, starting in August, all advance payments to sponsors of the Summer Food Service Program for needy children in New York City unless the state can certify that the sponsors are in full compliance with regulations.

title: Yanks' NoHit Bid Fails in 91 Romp
description: Doyle Alexander, who four weeks ago pitched seven perfect innings before allowing a hit, allowed no hits for eight innings last night but had to settle for a threehitter as the Yankees bombed the beleaguered Boston Red Sox, 91.

title: BANKS TO MONITOR NEW LOAN TO PERU
description: A group of American commercial banks is on the verge of approving a new loan of $150 to $200 million to the hardpressed Government of Peru.

title: Westchester Sniper Is Using a Dartgun To Attack Women
description: YONKERS, July 23Several Westchester County women have been struck in the neck, chest and shoulders by sharp steel darts shot through their lighted windows late at night by a sniper lurking outside gardenapartment buildings.

title: A Former Male Tennis Player Seeks to Join Women's Tour
description: A 41yearold tennis player who was ranked nationally two years ago in the men's 35andover division won a women's tennis tournament in La Jolla, Calif., last week.

title: The Ballet
description: The Dutch choreographer Hans van Manen is most curiously musical. He has an instinct for music, a feel, a sense, a sensibility for it. Which is probably why he is one of the most interesting choreographers around.

title: PAUL MORAND, 88, NOVELIST, IS DEAD
description: PARIS, July 23 (Reuters)Paul Morand, novelist, diplomat and member of the Academie Frangaise, died here today. He was 88 years old.

title: Nicklaus, on 67134, Gains 2Shot Edge
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, July 23 (IP)Jack Nicklaus shot his second consecutive 67 today and took the lead after 36 holes of the 67th Canadian open golf championship with a sixunderpar 134.

title: CAREY BACKS ROLE OF SCHOOL BOARD
description: ALBANY, July 23Governor Carey today vetoed a bill passed by the Legislature that would have limited the authority of the New York City Board of Education to dose school buildings.

title: The Japanese Devise a Handy and colorful Way to Carry a Load
description: TOKYOWomen and men alike carry them along this city's winding back lanes. Children swing them off to school.

title: MINERS BROADEN WILDCAT STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  A wildcat strike by coal miners that began last week in West Virginia spread across the Appalachian coal fields today, bringing the number of strikers to 25,000.

title: Turkey Sends Oil Survey Ship Into GreekContested Aegean
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 23 (Reuters)Turkey sent an oil exploration vessel to the Ae gean Sea today, risking a naval confrontation with Greece which has conflicting claims to the mineral riches of the sea bed.

title: New York's Volatile Prisons
description: Familiar and threatening shock waves are pulsing through the 25 prisons of the New York State correctional system. Benjamin C. Ward, State Correctional Services Commissioner, says that the system is in a period of crisis? Attica, the ultimate symbol of prison violence, now seems perpetually on the verge of a new conflagration.

title: Sunglasses for Children: More Than Just a Fashion
description: Mother wears them, father wears them, teenage brothers and sisters probably wear them, so do movie stars, athletes and legions of ordinary folk. The sunglass may just be the uniform of the American eye.

title: Bridge:
description: Britain's Bicentennial effort in the last four days to recapture Philadelphia for the Crown was decisively defeated by a powerful sextet of patriot bridge players.

title: Citibank Prime Rate Stays Unchanged at 7% Level
description: Citibank said yesterday that it would keep its prime interest rate unchanged at 7 percent. Under Citibank's formula, the rate fell between 7 and 7 percent, leading a number of market analysts to think it might lower it to 7 percent, possibly by yesterday.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: Librarians Hear Boorstin Warning On Cuts in Service
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (UPI)Nearly 13,000 librarians ended their centennial conference today after hearing a warning from Daniel Boorstin, Librarian of Congress, that the nation was on the brink of turning out the lights on its libraries.

title: Maude Busch Byrnes, 93, Widow of Roosevelt Aide
description: COLUMBIA, C., July 23 (UPI) Maude Busch Byrnes, widow of James F. Byrnes, former Supreme Court Justice and Secretary of State, died today in a local hospital after a long illness. She was 93 years old.

title: Court Revokes Rubin Carter Gag Order
description: A New Jersey appeals court yesterday revoked a judicial gag order that prevented public discussion of the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter triplernurder case by the defendants, their lawyers and the prosecution.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Friday, July 23, 1976

title: GUARD IS WOUNDED IN HOLDUP ATTEMPT
description: A security guard was shot in the neck last evening in the Times Square area as he and another guard became the targets of an attempted holdup while collecting receipts from Broadway theaters, the police reported.

title: 6 Killed as Riviera Express Derails at Simplon Tunnel
description: BRIG, Switzerland, July 23 (AP)The Riviera Express jumped the tracks and overturned as it came out of the Simplon Tunnel at high speed early today, killing six persons and injuring 34.

title: Papers Filed by Subpoenaed Financier Sealed to Protect Grand Jury's Inquiry
description: At the request of defense counsel and with the consent of the prosecution, a Criminal Court judge yesterday sealed papers filed on behalf of Arnold E. Kagan, a financier and builder who has been subpoenaed to produce corporate records.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran said the Hartford Insurance Company had agreed to postpone a requirement that policyholders keep their cars in garages to get collision and comprehensive insurance. Mr. Sheeran said he would meet Aug. 4 with company officials to discuss the proposed policy. He said that the proposal, if adopted by the entire insurance industry, effectively would limit auto insurance and possibly new car ownership to the suburbs and rural areas.

title: Sunrise in Portugal
description: Anyone launching Portugal's first democratic government in half a century could count on good will from democratic countries, especially those of Western Europe and North America. But there is unusual respect for Mario Soares for his long, courageous fight against the repressive regimes of Antonio de Oliveira Salazar and Marcello Caetano, and thus a special eagerness to help him establish Portugal firmly on the democratic path.

title: District Attorney Denies Charge of Sexual Assault
description: SYRACUSE, July 23Jon K. Holcombe, the Onondaga County District Attorney, has been charged with a felony count of firstdegree attempted sexual abuse involving a woman who until recently was a secretary inthe trial unit of his office.

title: Foster's Hit Gives Reds a 31 Victory
description: George Foster, another one of those buttons that Manager Sparky Anderson of the Cincinnati Reds pushes to put the Big Red Machine in high gear, broke a 11 tie with a tworun single in the eighth inning last night in Atlanta to give the Reds a 31 victory over the Braves.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: WIRETAP INCREASE BY U.S. IS DISPUTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) A House subcommittee chairman said today that the Ford Administration wiretapped more than the Nixon Administration did. But the Justice Department replied that he had misinterpreted its records and that the number of taps had actually declined.

title: GROUP OF CADETS ACCUSES ACADEMY
description: WEST POINT, July 23  A group of cadets at the United States Military Academy, standing in the shadow of the Academy, held a news conference today and told of being forced to testify against themselves and of being retried in cases where they had already been acquitted.

title: Scene From Meistersinger Opens Bayreuth Festival
description: BAYREUTH, West Germany, July 23The 100th anniversary of the Bayreuth Festival started tonight, and the program consisted mostly of speeches. After Karl Bhm conducted the orchestra in Wagner's Meistersinger prelude, the curtain rose to reveal the set for the last scene of the same opera. The entire chorus was on stage, in costume and ready to go, for it was this scene that was scheduled to end the evening. But first there was some 60 minutes of talking.

title: Teamster Pension Fund Files Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 The largest pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, beset by a ruling by the Internal Revenue Service, appealed today to the Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt it from having to register as an investment company.

title: How The World Looks At Carter
description: PARISThere is particular interest in Jimmy Carter abroad because he has indicated that if elected President he hopes to be more or less his own Secretary of State, in terms of initiating and supervising United States foreign policy. Yet, at the same time, very little is known overseas about what kind of man he really is and what sort of innovations he plans for America's world role.

title: Woman Committing Suicide Kills Neighbors Accidentally
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., July 23 (UPI)  A woman committing suicide by running her car in a closed garage inadvertently killed an elderly couple living next door.

title: 1 Dies, 23 Are Hurt As Bus Hits a Rail On Dewey Thruway
description: One woman was killed and 23 other passengers suffered, injuries and shock when a Greyhound bus overturned on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway yesterday afternoon near Herkimer, N.Y., in the Mohawk Valley area.

title: Tally Indicates That Ford Is Close to Delegate Goal
description: WASHINGTON, July 23President Ford moved today within close range of the 1,130 delegates needed to secure the Republican Presidential nomination, a tally by The New York Times showed, while his campaign leaders asserted that he already had more than enough.

title: Tempest in Italy Over Allied Threat to Bar Aid if Reds Share Rule
description: ROME, July 23A Rome weekly suggested today that while the next prime minister here undoubtedly would be an Italian, the treasury minister could well turn out to be Helmut Schmidt, the West German Chancellor. The sarcasm reflected the anger and sadness with which Italians of all political parties reacted to Mr. Schmidt's statement last week that Bonn, Washington, Paris and London had agreed not to aid Italy should Communists enter its government. Mr. Schmidt, who is not the most popular foreign leader in Italian eyes anyway, clearly generated a tempest.

title: If You're Brown or Maybe PurpleYou're White
description: When are Chinese Japanese? When is chocolate black? And, when can you be brown, white, purple, pink and polkadot at the same time?

title: Abigail Booth Becomes Bride
description: Abigail Booth, coordinator of the Bicentennial Inventory of American Paintings at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to William H. Gerdts of New York, professor of art history at Brooklyn College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.

title: Controlling Water
description: New York City officials are bitterly contesting a bill, now awaiting Governor Carey's signature or veto, that would give the State Department of Environmental Conservation control over water releases from upstate reservoirs owned by the city.

title: Geico Cites an Improving Loss Trend; Shareholders Back Capitalization Shift
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The financially troubled Government Employees Insurance Company reported new figures at a special stockholders' meeting here today that supported hopes that an 18month period of large underwriting losses that has threatened its solvency might end by fall.

title: It's Drought or Plenty At Park Tennis Courts
description: Double faults of flood and drought had tennis players raising a racket recently at the Central Park courts.

title: BAR TO G.E. MERGER WITH UTAH HINTED
description: The Justice Department yesterday refused to give assurances that it would not challenge the acquisition of Utah International by the General Electric Company. The department said in Washington that it was unable to indicate an intention not to sue. The agency's stand on the merger, the largest in history leaves considerable doubt that it will be consummated.

title: A Successor to Waldheim To Be Topic for Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23The United Nations issued a provisional agenda today for the 31st regular session of its General Assembly, due to open here on Sept. 21.

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STONED The Ryoanji Temple Stone Garden, a copy of the 500yearold original Zen temple in Kyoto, Japan, and the Roji Garden and the Tallman Memorial Dwarf Plant Garden will all be reopened to the public at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden today.

title: GOODRICH REPORTS ILLEGAL PAYMENTS
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday its four top executives, including its chairman, president, and two executive vice presidents, had been illegally reimbursed for a total of $12,500 in domestic political contributions between 1969 and 1973.

title: How La Traviata Gets to Civics Class
description: The talk won't all be of climates and capitals in Ken Morris's eighthgrade social studies class next fall. His students at Junior High School 127 in the Bronx may find themselves discussing the way composers compose or how a play is produced.

title: Goodyears Net Down 40.5%; Other Concerns Report
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the industry leader, reported yesterday a 40.5 percent drop in secondquarter earnings despite a 5.6 percent sales rise.

title: DR. WAYNE DENNIS, 70, A PSYCHOLOGIST
description: Dr. Wayne Dennis, a wellknown child psychologist, anthropologist, author and professor emeritus of Brooklyn College, died Wednesday in McGuire's Veterans Hospital, Richmond, of injuries received in an auto collision last May 25. Dr. Dennis, who lived at Doswell, Va., was 70 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: The sales and earnings of Solitron Devices Inc. were incorrectly listed in the corporate earnings table in The Times yesterday. The correct figures appear in today's table on Page 34.

title: Market Place
description: The Getty Oil Company, which has announced discussions that could lead to a merger with the Skelly Oil Company, has purchased relatively few shares of Skelly this year.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Yesterday's Olympic Games Results in Montreal
description: Medal Standing

title: Consumer Notes
description: The ParsippanyTroy Hills Office on Aging sponsors an Aging Talent Bank designed to make use of the skills of older people.

title: Lisbon Erasing Scars of Political War of Words
description: LISBON, July 23  They are painting Lisbon's central Black Horse Square a new democratic pink despite ideological and artistic protests.

title: DOLLAR CLIMBS; GOLD DOWN A BIT
description: BRUSSELS, July 23 (UPI)The dollar made firm gains on all major European money markets today, forcing the Belgian central bank and the Bank of France to intervene in efforts to buoy their currencies.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 24, 1976

title: Hospital Strike Authorized
description: More than 300 members ?? Service Employees Loc?? voted unanimously last night to authorize a strike against 18 proprietary hospitals in the city. Peter Ottley. president of the local, said the strike would begin at 6 A. M. on Aug. 2 against members of the Association of Private Hospitals and one independent hospital. The ??te s taken at a meeting ?? the Diplomat Hotel.

title: Business Briefs

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, July 23, 1976

title: Lifeguard,' About Freedom and Vanity
description: "Lifeguard" is the quintessential California "problem" picture. What, it asks, would you do if you were a fine, strong, healthy, handsome Santa Monica lifeguard who finds himself over the hill at the age of 32? Take a job selling Porsches? Stay on with the Parks Department? Shoot yourself?Only people bred in California could examine this problem in such solemn detail without cracking up, which may be one of the reasons why California fascinates us, and why we sit through a movie as witless as "Lifeguard" experiencing both helpless laughter and undisguised envy. California weather really is great. The beaches are spectacular, the people apparently all beautiful, and sex is everywhere.The only problem is age, an issue that "Lifeguard" faces unflinchingly. Aging lifeguards are suspectto themselves as well as to other peoplein the California youth culture. Should they be put to sleep? Should they be sent to rehabilitation camps in Nebraska to learn a new trade? Should they be allowed to stay on the job as long as they can perform their duties? Should they be treated with the same respect given 22-year-olds?The movie that opened yesterday at Loews State I and other theaters doesn't mince words. It is the most prolifeguard film ever made."Lifeguard" looks to be two different movies at the same time. The one directed by Daniel Petrie means to be about freedom and self-realization, while the one written by Ron Koslow and acted by Sam Elliott is about vanity, narcissism.Quite early in the film, which spends one summer on the Santa Monica sands, Rick Carlson (Mr. Elliott), the lifeguard of the title, is told by one of the young women in his life that though he is great in bed "technically," he doesn't feel anything. This bit of analysis is confirmed by the lifeguard's mannerisms and decisions during the rest of the movie, and explains the unintentional laugh that greets his statement that he likes winter duty at the beach best because it gives him time to think.Thinking would be a totally alien activity to the character written by Mr. Koslow and acted by Mr. Elliott who, consciously or not, moves through the moviethrough affairs with a sweet beach-groupie (Kathleen Quinlan) and with a former highschool sweetheart (Anne Archer)with all of the intellectual and emotional sensitivity of a man holding up a pack of cigarettes in a Marlboro ad.That Mr. Elliott looks like a successful male model also has the effect of undermining any urgency we may be expected to feel on behalf of the character. After all, if he can't cut it on the beach any longer, he can always go out and make television commercials.As a film, "Lifeguard" is romantic twaddle, but as sociology it's a spontaneous assault on a very American way of life. People smile a lot, even when they have nothing to smile about. Characters drive to places to commit suicide in expensive sports cars. The interior decoration is the sort that makes every house and apartment look like a motel room. If people read, you know it's TV Guide.Since I doubt that "Lifeguard" was intended as sociology, one must consider it as entertainment, and as entertainment it ranks somewhat above "Bikini Beach" but below "Godzilla Versus Megalon."The film has been rated PG. It hasn't a thought in its head, but there are some nudity and rough language, as well as one very ornate love scene photographed in such close-ups that the audience must guess whether a mound of flesh is an elbow, a hip, a nose or a breast. I still don't know.

title: Clifford Crain Weds Miss Frothingham

title: Pope at Seminar on American Art
description: ROME, July 23It is three years since Pope Paul VI opened the gallery of modern art in the Vatican Museum, where more than 600 worksmainly on religious or philosophical themesare shown in a wing of their own not far from the rooms that house works by Raphael and Michelangelo.

title: Out of the Pool Every Four Years
description: MONTREAL, July 23In the four years before the Olympics, they swim virtually every day, sometimes for miles, sometimes for hours. But hardly anybody watches. And hardly anybody cares. Then suddenly they are competing in the Olympics and the world is watching and the world cares. In the splash of the Olympic Pool itself, one race resembles another. Only the times on the electronic tote board change. On the medal platforms, one ceremony resembles another. Not even the music changes The StarSpangled Banner for the men, the East German anthem for the women. But then the gold medalists comb their hair and towel their faces and put on their sweatsuits and come upstairs into the interview area where they sit behind a small table with microphones. Perhaps 200 newsmen surround them. Interpreters translate their words that are scribbled in notebooks and spun into tape recorders. And for many of the swimmers, this attention is what makes the Olympics special.

title: MONDALE BEGINS CAMPAIGN TALKS

title: Books of The Times
description: The significance of Byron Farwell's mostly laudable book is its subject's intimate hearing on the current racial problems of South Africa. To read it is to understand the stiffnecked attitudes of the white minority in that beautiful but unhappy land, to see how principles of freedom, selfgovernment and justice have been contorted to serve xenophobia and apartheid, how piety has been transmuted into satanism, how ideology has warped and narrowed philosophy and, finally, how it is possible to win a war on the battlefield only to lose it through loss of nerve in peace.

title: The Search for A Musical Utopia At Marlboro
description: MARLBORO, VT. It is a rainy night and 75 professional musicians, their husbands, wives and children are gathered in the rustic hall that serves as a communal dining room here. At one table, the octogenarian Micezyslaw Forszowski, 24yearold Cynthia Raim and 73yearold Rudolf Serkin are discussing rehearsal plans for the Bach Triple Piano Concerto which they will play with Alexander Schneider and the Marlboro Chamber Orchestra. Luis Baffle, director of the Kolischer Conservatoire in Montevideo, and YoungUck Kim, the Korean violinist, are waiting on tables. A din composed of French, Japanese, Italian, Hungarian, Spanish, German, Hebrew, Russian and English soon reaches a forte.
