Her first job at the age of 15 in a dress shop, her campaigning for women's suffrage, her years as a New York City high school teacher are recalled in vivid detail, complete with dates, places and the names of people long dead.

title: Mary O'Connor Bride of John Quinn 3d
description: Mary Agnes O'Connor, daughter of Mrs. Thomas W. O'Connor of Crestwood, N. Y., and the late Mr. O'Connor, was married there yesterday to John Joseph Quinn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Quinn Jr. of Maplewood. N. J.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Eager Dolphin Save Day
description: NAGS HEAD, N. C.Beneath a long, trailing raft of eel grass that had been borne by the wind and tide from the vast, shallow reaches of Pamlico, Albemarle, Currituck or Croatan Sounds some 35 miles offshore to the edge of the Gulf Stream, we found a school of dolphin eager to take whatever we offered them.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: Criminals At Large
description: Stories about amnesiacs are ever with us. As one picks up IF I DON'T TELL by Donald Olson (Putnam's, $6.95) and starts reading, the worst is expected, all the more in that this is a first novel. But Olson foils us. He does indeed start with the survivor of a plane crash. This man wears the wrist bracelet of a longdead man, says that he remembers nothing and manages to disappear from the hospital, presumably in a state of deep amnesia.

title: Ballet: Lynn Seymour in Pillar of Fire
description: For years Antony Tudor was the absent force from British ballet. To someone such as the Canadianborn ballerina Lynn Seymour, growing up in Britain and dancing as a star with Britain's Royal Ballet, this must have been singularly frustrating. For a dramatic ballerina the Tudor repertory was among the most tantalizing, and for a British dramatic ballerina it must have seemed peculiarly unattainable.

title: An Acropolis Building To Be Moved Indoors
description: ATHENS, July 24 (AP)The 2,500yearold Erectheum, the little temple whose roof is supported by six caryatids, will be moved from the Acropolis to a museum next year to protect it from further ravages of pollution, the Government has announced.

title: TRADE GROUP BACKS EXPORTS OF AFUEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The best way to discourage the spread of nuclear weapons to developing nations is for the United States to be a reliable exporter of atomic fuel for power reactors, a nuclear industry trade association said in a report today.

title: The Viking Miracle
description: Walter Cronkite wasn't in Pasadena last Tuesday morning and neither was Barbara Walters. Jimmy Carter was nowhere in evidence there nor was Vice President Rockefeller nor even California's present Governor Brown or exGovernor Reagan. There were so few beautiful people around that the television reporters present were reduced to interviewing science fiction writers.

title: 2d Trial in Kidnapping
description: ATLANTA, July 24 (AP)The second extortion trial of William A. H. Williams, charged in the abduction of Reg Murphy, former editor of The Atlanta Constitution, will he held Aug. 16 in Key West, Fla., a Federal judge has ruled. Mr, Williams, who testified at the first trial in Atlanta that he had abducted Mr. Murphy from the editor's home in 1974, had pleaded insanity.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Ring cycle that is the big feature of the ninth Munich Festival has just concluded. It contained some interesting ideas and also the major trappings of what has come to be known as the neoBayreuth style. Has there been a Ring cycle anywhere since 1951 that is not strippeddown and symbolic? When Wieland Wagner sprang his Ring cycle on an unprepared world that year, every opera house immediately got the message. The old order was out. On with the new. Besides, it was less expensive to stage the Ring cycle in the neoBayreuth manner.

title: Sue Flatow Bride Of Stuart Savage
description: Sue Flatow and Stuart Savage were married yesterday afternoon in an outdoor ceremony on South Hill in Ludlow, Vt, The Rev, Sidney Lambert of the First Congregational Church in Bennington, Vt., officiated.

title: Terms of Baseball's New FourYear Accord Explained
description: Sometime in the first half of next November, a player draft that could be the most intriguing in sports history will be held to determine which clubs will compete for which freeagent baseball players.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BURLINGTON COUNTY COLLEGE, PembertonBrowns Mills Rd., PembertonThe Matchmaker, in Foundation Theater production. Opens Wednesday (through Aug. 14,. (609) 8949311. Ext. 460.

title: Real Losses, Imaginary Gains
description: WE BUY JUNK AND SELL ANTIQUES

title: HURRICANE UNIT FEARS LATE STORMS
description: MIAMI, July 24 (AP)Although there has not been a hint of tropical storm activity since the hurricane season began June 1, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center have warned that some of the worst hurricane years have turned out to be late starters.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Come and visit us again and again, but for heaven's sake, don't come here to live, Gov. Tom McCall of Oregon warned outsiders in March 1971. By 1973, he was not sure he even wanted many visitors.

title: Five Killed in Illinois Crash
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (UPI)A tow truck driving in the rain struck the driver's side of a car in Wheeling Township, 30 miles northwest of Chicago, early today, killing five persons in the car. They were identified as Richard Widing, 26 years old, of Wheeling; his wife, Patti, 19; John Hupt, 29, of Grayslake; his wife Karen, 17; and Ronald Martin, 21, of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILLS ON JUVENILE EQUITY
description: ALBANY, July 24 (UPI)A package of bills to revamp the state's juvenile justice system has been signed by Governor Carey, it was announced today.

title: ART VIEW
description: How odd it is that so little is written about art museumsso little, I mean, about the actual experience one acquires in them, about the values they embrace, about the way they function in our culture and the way they have come to shape our thinking about art and the place it occupies, or fails to occupy, in our lives. There is probably no other institution of comparable importance in our society that has inspired so little serious thought, so little in the way of philosophical reflection, sociological analysis or critical study. The literature on the subject is so meager that it can scarcely be said to exist. More money and more people are drawn to museums than ever before in our historyand there are more museums, drawing themyet the ideas governing these remarkable institutions are seldom examined outside the board rooms or curatorial offices where decisions are made that affect our entire culture.

title: Hoo's Who: The Radio Night Owls
description: AROUND 11 o'clock at night, when most people are tuning in the news on television before going to bed, Phil Wurtz is beginning his day, driving to a radio station in South Vineland in Cumberland County. A disk jockey for WMVBFM (97.3), Mr. Wurtz mans one of the New Jersey radio stations that broadcast during the wee hours of the morning for an audience of working people, night owls and insomniacs.

title: U.S. Suffers Defeat In 2 Track Events At Olympic Games
description: United States track and field athletes suffered disappointments at the Olympic Games in Montreal yesterday as they failed to win medals in either the 100meter dash or shotput events.

title: PepsiCola Comes Out of the Kitchen
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.For decades, Pepsi has played second fiddle to its archrival Coke in the fiercely competitive world of the colas.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Elm City Ii.C. allbreed and obedience, Airport, Route 63, Bethany, Conn.; 1,123 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: It's a Women's Olympics, Despite the Politics and U.S. Men Swimmers
description: MONTREAL, July 24From Queen Elizabeth to little Nadia Comaneci, the dramatic development of the XXI Olympiad so far has been that it's a women's Olympics, despite the politics, protests, security and American men's swimming team. They turned into the second week of performances today, and the stage was being cleared for the big boys in basketball, boxing and track. But in the streets of Montreal and the corridors of the $685 million Olympic Stadium, most of the talk and emotional response were lavished on the women Kornelia Ender's winning, Shirley Babashoff's losing, Princess Anne's falling front her horse, Nadia in triumph and Olga Korbut in tragedy. and the 7foot Iuliyaka Semenova, the gentle Amazon of the basketball court.

title: Gray Gordon, 72, Directed Dance Band in the 1930's
description: Gray Gordon, a dance band leader in the 1930's and 1940's, died of cancer Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in New York City.

title: U. S. Five Nearing Soviet Showdown
description: MONTREAL, July 24 (AP)The preliminary round of the men's Olympic basketball tournament ended today with Canada joining the Soviet Union, the United States and Yugoslavia in the medal round of semifinals.

title: Students Feeling Cuts at City U.
description: Michael Yonchenko, a 24yearold veteran studying at Brooklyn College, needs the use of a videotape recorder to complete a project for his degree. The television department of the college fighting like every other one to survive the newest budget cuts, is seeking to dramatize its case, he says, by keeping the equipment idle for lack of maintenance money even though he offered to furnish the money himself.

title: Sets Defeat Nets; Mrs. King Stars
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) Billie Jean King defeated Martina Navratilova, 63, and teamed with Virginia Wade for a doubles victory as the New York Sets downed the Cleveland Nets, 2618, in World Team Tennis at the Coliseum tonight.

title: Who Would Finance a Xerox Today?
description: The history of American business is studded with tales, of small companies that have grown into large and highly successful onesin earlier eras, the giants of the aircraft and automobile industries, and more recently, International Business Machines, Eastman Kodak and Xerox, to name a few.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times July 11 on a Foreign Policy Association survey of Americans said 58 percent of those responding opposed a formal United States alliance with Israel in return for Israel's giving up occupied Arab territories and accepting an independent Palestinian state. However, the article failed to report that those polled favored45 to 36 percentguarantees, other than an alliance, from the United States and its NATO allies to Israel for relinquishing the territories and accepting a Palestinian state. The same article gave incorrect figures on those favoring diplomatic relations with Peking. The correct figures are 63 percent for and 18 percent against.

title: 3 CUBANS SEIZED WITH A PIPE BOMB
description: Police officers on a stakeout seized three Cuban men early yesterday as they allegedly attempted to ignite a powerful pipe bomb outside a Union Square theater where a concert sponsored by a proCastro organization was scheduled for later in the day.

title: ART
description: TWO leading New Jersey art museums have recently received a major art gift from Lorillard Companytwo sets of prints by 12 celebrated contemporary American artists.

title: Klynt's Law
description: Klynt's Law and Hoyt's Child are modular books, bolted into being from interchangeable parts: big money, exotic setting and newsmagazine ideas, sensationalism and suspense.

title: FILM VIEW
description: He's the biggest thing at the boxoffice this summer no matter what you call him: Satan, Devil, Abaddon, Apollyon, Lucifer, Beelzebub, Ehlis, Tempter, Asmodeus, Belial, Dragon, Serpent, Evil One, God of This World. Prince of Darkness, Prince of The Devils, Prince of The Power of The Air, Prince of This World, Wicked One, Hornie, Nick, Author of Evil, Clootie, Old Harry, Old Ned, Scratch, Azazel, Father of Lies, Foul Fiend, Mephisto, or, my particular favorite, Old Gooseberry.

title: Auto Premiums Up 100% For Many New Yorkers
description: The cost of auto insurance coverage has more than doubled during the last year for many New York State residents, according to the New York State Insurance Department, and the premiums now being demanded may put coverage out of the reach of some low and moderateincome drivers.

title: Rhodesians Are Using Foreign Soldiers
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 24 (AP)The Rhodesian Govern ment has reportedly begun an international recruiting drive for foreigners to join the Rhodesian Army to fight black nationalist guerrillas. The white minority Government says that the recruits are not mercenaries but immigrants who get the same pay as Rhodesians.

title: Most Passengers on QE2 Arranging to Fly to the U.S.
description: LONDON, Juy 24 (AP)Her engine room a shambles and her funnel blistered by fire, the British ocean liner Queen Elizabeth 2 slowly sailed up the English Channel today after a fire halted a voyage to New York.

title: Nancy Noel Bride of Lincoln A. Werden
description: Nancy Louise Noel, a doctoral candidate at Teachers College of Columbia University, was married yesterday afternoon to Lincoln Anthony Werden, a chartered a nalyist with Thomson,

title: Shelby's Days of Glory Are Recalled
description: Carroll Shelby gave the motor sports world much more than a good recipe for chili. Through the garages of Shelby American, Incorporated, he produced some of the finest highperformance cars that this country has seen. Today, because of the dwindling fuel supply, the 55milesanhour speed limit and the high cost of owning and operating a performance car on the street, you don't hear as much about men like Shelby as you did in the 1960's.

title: Caro Says County Can't Afford Raises
description: IT would be nice if these were fat times and the county's taxpayers could afford to give their Civil Service Employees Association members a pay raise this year. But the times are leanleaner than they have ever been, as public employees across the nation are discoveringand the county's taxpayers cannot afford it.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater 3, 6, 8

title: SYDNEY CLAMAN
description: Sydney Claman, former owner and operator of the Times Square Hotel, on West 43d Street, and the Breslin Hotel, at Broadway and 29th Street, died Thursday at the Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N. J., after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived at 28 Wigwam Road, Locust, N. J.

title: MOSCOW STEPS UP RUSSIAN TEACHING
description: MOSCOW, July 24 (AP)The Soviet Union is stepping up efforts to spread the use and knowledge of Russian around the world.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: The late Chris Dunphy, the benevolent diFtators who ran the Seminole Golf Club in Florida, had a favorite cluba 6wood. He knew exactly how far he could hit it, and he used it shrewdly to win many a money game.

title: The Economic Impact of the Ford Years
description: In the early days of spring, when the numbers on the American economy's superlative performance during the first quarter were becoming apparent, supporters of the Administration's policies were bemoaning the fact that the Presidential election was not scheduled for that time.

title: Packing Houses Lose Plea To Curb BeefGrading Rule
description: DALLAS, July 24 (UPI)A Federal judge says that although the Department of Agriculture apparently did not consider the impact of new beef grading standards on the cattle industry, it acted within its jurisdiction in issuing the guidelines.

title: Sportswoman Appointed
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 24 (AP)Dr. Irene Shea has been named women's sports director at Sacramento State University. She leaves a post as assistant director of intercollegiate athletics for womon at the State University of New York at Brockport, where women's softball teams she coached won two state titles in five years.

title: The New York Times Book Review
Headliners
description: An American engineer, Laszio Toth, has been freed from a Yugoslav prison after serving more than a year there on charges of spying. Mr. Toth, a naturalized American citizen born in Yugoslavia, had returned there on business and was arrested while visiting an oil refinery. Laurence H. Silberman, the United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, worked persistently for Mr. Toth's release, despite being denied ordinary diplomatic access to him. It was Mr. Silberman's efforts, sometimes conducted, he said, over State Department protests, that ultimately resulted in Mr. Toth's release. When. we get to the point where we don't care about an American citizen innocently imprisoned, said Mr. Silberman, then we're not much of a country any more.

title: Rocking All the Way to the Bank
description: What's loud, hard on the grass and grooving all the way to the bank?

title: Environmental Aide Resigns
description: ANCHORAGE, July 24 (AP) Alaska's only representative on a nationwide environmental panel overseeing the transAlaska pipeline has resigned. Dr. David Klein of the University of Alaska's Alaska Cooperative Research Unit in airbanks said that the Arctic Environmental Council had lost its effectiveness and was too closely associated with Alaska Pipeline Service Company, the concern building the pipeline.

title: U.S. AGENCY URGES ALLIGATOR CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 24They stroll the fairways of golf courses in Florida, sun and swim in the backyards of the new housing developments there and on occasion are seen crossing busy intersections in the hearts of cities.

title: Opera: New Rheingold
description: BAYREUTH, Germany, Jul 24  Bayreuth tonight lived up to its reputation as a center of avantgarde operatic staging. The 30yearold French director Patrice Chereau presented a Rheingold as the beginning of his Ring cycle that caused a massive reaction from the audieince. At the end, there were screams of rage and screams of applause. If traditionalists in previous years had been disturbed by the psychological, strippeddown staging of Wieland and Wolfgang Wagner, tonight they were outraged.

title: Income Fifth in U. S.
description: FOR $795 you can flyto Europe and back And if you are the average New Jerseyan, $795 represents the amount. of annual income that you have in excess of the per capita figure for the nation as a whole.

title: Hanoi Says Rain Shortage Is Threat to Rice Harvest
description: HANOI, Vietnam, July 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  Vietnamese authorities are worried about this year's rice harvest, which is threatened by a sixweekold rain shortage, the newspaper Nhan Dan reports.

title: DR. LEONARD HERRICK
description: Dr. Leonard Herrick, a dentist wo treated many prominent patients in his offices at Rockefeller Center, died yesterday of bone cancer at the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. He was 61 years old and lived at 25 Whisler Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Nuptials Aug. 14 Set By Marie deVenoge
description: Marie Dorina deVenoge and Edwin M. Ceccarelli plan to be married on Aug. 14. Mr. and Mrs. Vincent P. deVenoge of Manhasset, L. I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ceccarelli of Orchard Park, N. Y.

title: On Trial: The Courthouse
description: Some of the hottest courthouse arguments these days are about courthouses.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: LEBANESE INFLUX ANNOYS LIBERIANS
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 24 (Reuters)A civil war thousands of miles away in Lebanon has brought growing numbers of refugees to Liberia, prompting complaints from unemployed Liberians and action by the Government to limit the influx.

title: ARMS SALES ABROAD BY U.S. DECLINE 2%
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI))  The value of United States arms sales to foreign nations dropped nearly 12 percent in the last fiscal year to $8.3 billion, according to preliminary Pentagon figures obtained today.

title: Elizabeth Tufts Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Vickery Tufts and David Warren Swanson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Swanson of Brooklyn Heights and Williamstown, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany by the rector, the Rev. Ernest Hunt.

title: Africa: Cheaper By the Herd
description: Four old friends, work obsessed and actionoriented, got together one cold evening last December and shared a fantasy: Wouldn't it be terrific to sign up for an African safari? It seemed larky to make some exploratory phone calls. When we came up with an allinclusive, 17day package tour that miraculously fit our available time slotits price tag of $1,195 a person, only a shade more than the flat price of a roundtrip plane ticket to Nairobi, and $400 cheaper than the group package rate offered by the ranking safari agencywe were faced with an offer we couldn't refuse.

title: Site for Big Power Plant Sets Off a Debate Upstate
description: STUYVESANT, N.Y., July 23 The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation has selected two potential sites for a gigantic new 2.4 million kilowatt electric power stationone here in the northwestern tip of Columbia County near the Hudson River and the other in New Haven, a few miles east of Oswego near Lake Ontario.

title: Mets, With 14 Walks, Rout Expos, 104
description: MONTREAL, July 24The New York Mets received 14 walks from a succession of Montreal pitchers tonight and turned eight of them into runs that resulted in a 104 victory for Mickey Lolich.

title: DINING OUT
description: DESPITE a spectacular location and fresh seafood brought in daily (also sold wholesale and retail at their store up the street), Brawn's is not a firstrate seafood restaurant. Too bad. If the kitchen cared enough it might be; at one time perhaps, it was.

title: Soviet Names 3 Americans Held in Heroin Trafficking
description: MOSCOW, July 24 (UPI)A Soviet publication has identified three young Americans arrested here last month with 71 pounds of heroin in falsebottom suitcases. It also accused China of being the world's major narcotics supplier.

title: U.S. Election: The Views Abroad
description: PARIS, July 24The feeling has spread abroad that an American election is really a world election, because of the power of the U. S., as one commentator put it, and so officials around the world are struggling to find out what they can about the Democratic Party's candidate, Jimmy Carter.

title: PEOPLE
description: MOTHER NATURE did her part a couple of hundred years ago: The rest of the effort took the better part of human nature and has resulted in a new exhibit at the Town Marine Museum in Amagansett. It is the Culloden cannon, mounted on an authentic carriage in a section of gun deck typical of an 18thcentury British warship. H.M.S. Culloden was grounded at Will's Point, Montauk, in a gale on Jan. 25, 1771. A couple of centuries later, the twoandahalfton cannon that was part, of her armament was raised by Carlton Davidson, a Navytrained amateur diver from Moriches. A communitywide East Hampton effort resulted in a display design by Ralph E. Carpentier, the museum director; construction of the wooden gun carriage by George A. Schulte; creation of the gundeck platform by young carpentry students, and fundraising efforts undertaken by the Baymens Association and by Councilwoman Mary Fallon. Benevolent critics may want to call the cannon display a bangup job.

title: Julius Cardinal Dopfner Dies; German Liberal Cleric Was 62
description: Julius Cardinal Dopfner, who campaigned for religious freedom in East Germany when he was Archbishop of Berlin, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Munich, West Germany. He was 62 years old.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Translated From the Greek by N. C. Germanacos. 115 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $6.95.

title: New to group travel, the author was wary; then 14 elephants stopped by for a drink.
description: Tshirt had already caused some comments.

title: Land Rich
description: The song might be How you goin' to keep them down on the farm after they see the prices.

title: In Jersey, TV Still Sputters
description: FOR the last few years, Governors and other public officials concerned with New Jersey's future have portrayed the state as a television wasteland lost between the two major markets of New York and Philadelphia. The depravation, they contend, has cost the state the opportunity to communicate with itself.

title: Expos Sign No. 1 Pick
description: MONTREAL, July 24 (AP) Robert James, the Montreal Expos' No. 1 choice in last month's freeagent draft, signed a contract last night and will report to their Lethbridge farm team in the Pioneer League.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MONTREAL, July 24In the hours before Hasely Crawford of Trinidad won the 100meter final today, James Gilkes was wondering what might have been. James Gilkes (pronounced JILkes) is from Guyana in South America and attends the University of Southern California, but when Guyana joined the African boycott, he requested to compete under the Olympic flag. No, intoned the International Olympic Committee from on high. Typical of its bureaucratic philosophy, the I.O.C. recognizes national Olympic committees, not athletes. And so, James Gilkes emerged as the sprinter without a country.

title: Todd, Top Jets' Pick, Signs; Turk, Mulligan Injure Knees
description: The New York Jets won a couple and lost a couple yesterday. First they won over and signed their last holdout, Richard Todd, the quarterback and No. 1 selection. Then they won their controlled scrimmage against the Philadelphia Eagles. However, the Jets also lost their best linebacker and their starting center with injuries.

title: American Natural's Future Look
description: DETROIT  Two months ago the American Natural Gas Company became the American Natural Resources Company. It's not that the Detroitbased company is up to its pipeline in natural resources; it's just that executives know they'd better start looking for additional business because there isn't that much gas.

title: Design
description: By many accounts, the first potter was the Lord and the first pot was Adam. Certainly, shaping things out of clay is a very ancient human activity, one that was already highly developed in China and the Sumer 7,000 years ago.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, July 24 (Reuters)Mayor Wu Teh of Peking has taken over the duties of chairman of the National People's Congress, China's nearest equivalent to a head of state, it was disclosed today.

title: Cooperation to Halt Spread Of Atomic Weapons Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) A nuclear industry group recommended today that the United States develop cooperative measures with other nuclear technology nations to control the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

title: The Californian Is Also Helped by the Rising Sunbelt
description: WASHINGTONIt was hard for many of the delegates to the Democratic National Convention to understand how they came to be nominating someone from the Deep South for the first time since 1848, and a oneterm governor of Georgia at that. It is even harder for many of the delegates to the Republican National Convention to understand how they can even be contemplating the possibility of denying renomination to an incumbent President for the first time since 1884.

title: Mailbox: The American Way Receives an OlympicSize Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas &Trends
description: For the second time, the Blue Cross Association has begun a feasibility study to determine whether it can extend coverage to treatment of public health problems before hospitalization is required.

title: Mohawk Games Olympic Sideshow
description: CAUGHNAWAGA INDIAN RESERVE, Quebec, July 24 Rejecting the white man's presentation of native culture as depicted in the official cultural program for the Olympic Games, the energetic Mohawks of this prosperous reserve just outside Montreal are staging their own daily portrayal of Indian life, present and past, for Olympic visitors.

title: Mae West to Star Opposite Six Leading Men
description: Los ANGELES It was pathetic, Hollywood observers scoffed, that a woman over 80 should star in a movie opposite six young and handsome leading men. That was last spring when Mae West declared that she would return to the screen in an updated version of her play Sextette.

title: Kendall: Blunt and Politically Minded
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.  Donald M. Kendall, 35 years old, who earns $440,000 a year as chief executive of Pepsico inc., was standing on a dais at Western Kentucky University, his alma mater, in May, 1972, delivering the commencement address.

title: Midwest Farmers Apprehensive on Ford Grain Policy
description: SYLVIA, Kans., July 24One of the largest winter wheat crops ever grown in the leading wheat state was safely in the elevators today and Kansas farmers were plowing under dark gold stubble, preparing to plant another huge crop this autumn.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: Idiscovered a little while ago that those Newark City Council persons who refused a court order to vote for reassessments of 49,000 pieces of Newark real estate were not going to jail after all.

title: GAMING CONTROL BY STATES URGED
description: WASHINGTON, July 24A Government commission has recommended that the states be given the power to determine what forms of gambling may take place within their borders.

title: Thailand Town Faces a Sterner Life Without G.I.'s
description: UDON, Thailand, July 22At the little noodle stand where she works near here, Amnuay Nuongparcot ponders a grim future.

title: Jewish Congress Organizes a Drive Against Air Piracy
description: The American Jewish Congress has started a campaign to mobilize broad public support for immediate antihijacking legislation action by the Federal Government to try to bring an end to air piracy.

title: First to Shatter 2 Minutes in Backstroke
description: MONTREAL, July 24 With his 6foot6inch frame as that giant extra, Long John Naber shattered the twominute barrier in the 200meter backstroke tonight en route to a world record and his fourth gold medal of the Olympics.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I note that in the July 4 Long Island Weekly section of The Times. Phyllis Shaw comments that house guests on the Island arrive like lemmings. I assume she means that her visitors have a suicidal impulse to reach the seashore, though her article indicates that most of her guests are truly murderous, at the least.

title: Notes: For Flying Golfers
description: The exasperation of vacationing golfers who stagger around the country saddled with 40pound bags of clubs may be par for the course, hut a new organization called Golf Rental Inc. wants to get them out of the trap. The Los Angelesbased company is opening a chain of equipmentrental shops close to airports in golf country. Its first outlet, four minutes from the Log Angeles International Airport, opens next Sunday; others are scheduled to start between now and Nov. I in San Diego, Las Vegas, Miami, Honolulu, Palm Springs, Houston, Orlando, San Francisco, Atlanta and Phoenix.

title: The West Without Crowds
description: I have a confession to make: I've never really liked the Grand Canyon. The first time I saw it was in July, years ego, from South Rim, and it was jammed with people and cars. The second time was in May, in a light plane, hovering over the South Rim: Same cars, same people, only smaller. The third time was at a cruising altitude of 30,000 feet from a jet en route to Los Angeles. Couldn't see the cars or the people, but this time the canyon didn't look like much.

title: Book Ends
description: Local Option. Best sellers pretty well blanket the country, so that you have people reading The Final Days, or whatever in Dallas, Minneapolis, San Diego, Hartford, points east, west, north, south. Still, a measure of local pride remains, and there are books that do well in specific geographical areas. New York publishers sometimes refer to such books on their list as regional publishing, and, although their traditional orientation is to books of national appeal, the nonfiction book focusing on a particular area  or even the novel set in an area or by a local boy or girl  offers the advantage of an assured, if smaller market, assuming it has appeal and the local stores get behind it.

title: Shafer Victor in TransAm
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 24 (AP)Carl Shafer was a runaway victor today in the 100mile TransAmerican championship race around Road America's fourmile course.

title: The BiennaleA Show of Compromises
description: VENICE Postponed for a month due to the Italian elections, the Venice Biennale opened last Sundaythe first Biennale since political demonstrations in St. Marks Square against the Biennale of the bosses closed the show in 1972.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I am about to paint the front doors and garage door of my house, but notice that the doors have very fine, hairline vertical cracks in the paint. The garage door also has spiderlike fine crackssomething like an eggshell. Can you suggest the simplest method for preparing these surfaces for painting?W.P., Montreal, Que.

title: NEW YORK AWAITS GRANTS FROM U.S.
description: Cashstarved New York City is due for a tidy windfall from the Federal Public Works Act, enacted Thursday over President's Ford's veto, but has yet to decide exactly how to use the money.

title: Pincay's 5 Firsts Give Him the Lead
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP)Laffit Pincay Jr. rode five winners at Hollywood Park today, including Bastonera II in the $60,000 featured Beverly Hills Handicap, and overtook Sandy Hawley as the leading rider at the meet.

title: Mrs. Sulzberger's Funeral
description: PARIS, July 24Funeral services for Marina Tatiana Sulzberger will be held on Wednesday, at 10:30 A.M. in the Greek Orthodox Church here at 7 Rue Georges Bizet. She was the wife of C. L. Sulzberger, the foreign affairs columnist of The New York Times. The services will be conducted by Archbishop Meletios.

title: Outdoor Cafes Go Indoors
description: To a host of New Yorkers and visitors, one of the city's more salubrious treats is a drink, a snack or a full repast at one of the more than 100 sidewalk cafes that have made their appearance here over the last few years.

title: India Greets Pakistani
description: NEW DELHI, July 24 (Reuters)  Syed Fida Hassan, Pakistan's first Ambassador to India since 1971, presented his credentials to President Fakruddin All Ahmed here today. Under an agreement two months ago to resume diplomatic relations, the two nations have also restored civilian airline flights and railroad links.

title: ARCHITECTURAL VIEW
description: Alot has happened in the ten years since Battery Park City was conceived as a new mixeduse community and kicked off into the Hudson River. Most notably, the sky fell in on New York, and Battery Park City didn't get built. But if that sounds like the end of the story, it's not. As things go in this city, it may only be the beginning.

title: Life Under The Sign Of the Deer
description: BUTLER, Mo.Every year the newspapers, television and radio stations around here are filled with stories about the wheat crop.

title: Efforts to Clean Up Great Lakes Gain, but New Problems Emerge
description: CHICAGO, July 24  The nation's ecological problem children, the Great Lakes, are benefiting from an international cleanup campaign. But they are manifesting new and perplexing pollution troubles as fast as old ones can be resolved.

title: WEST POINT FACES NEW DIFFICULTIES
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., July 24With the number of West Point cadets officially accused of cheating approaching 200 and likely to go higher, the United States Military Academy is facing some unexpected morale and administrative problems.

title: Miss Ferguson Is Bride of Pediatrician
description: Deborah Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Ferguson of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon in Holliswood, Queens, to Dr. David George Bekker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Bekker of Everett, Wash.

title: ENCOUNTER:
description: I've come to Vienna for the first time with childlike expectations of gemtlichkeit  what Webster calls friendliness. I grew up believing it was an inherited antibody in my system.

title: Miss Soviero Wed To Brian J. Calvey
description: Grace Marie Soviero, daughter of Cordelia R. Soviero of Fort Salonga, L. I., and the late State Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Soviero, was married yesterday morning to Brian J. Calvey, a lawyer with the New York firm of Rogers, Hoge & Hill. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Calvey of Wilton, Conn.

title: Postal Rate Rise Forecast Unless Subsidy Is Enacted
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar said today that a new mail rate increase would be needed in 11 months unless Congress passes a $1 billion subsidy the Senate will debate next week.

title: What's Doing in the HAMPTONS
description: DASICSThe Hamptons are a summer state of mind, weighted with emotional laissezfaire  a playground for the wealthy in their pillared villas and for singles of more limited income who go shares in communal rented houses. When people speak of the Hamptons, they are referring mainly to communities in two townships in Suffolk County, Southampton and East Hampton, both on Long Island's bucolic South Fork. Their yearround population is about 54,000; during the summer, vacationers lift it to more than 200,000.

title: Down with everything
description: Skyscrapers are not economically sound or efficientin fact they are ridiculously unprofitableand the Trade Center's fate is to be ripped down as nonsensical.

title: Results of Olympic Games at Montreal
description: Basketball, Men GROUP B

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Wilbur

title: Putting on the Dog
description: HUNTINGTON

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S about that time of year again: Everyone is locking up the house, and driving away on vacation. As the car pulls away, it's a touching moment and the family is simultaneously eager and tremulous.

title: Tax Money And Education: A Quandary
description: DESPITE the political machinations and suburban frontlash, the citizens of New Jersey will be paying an income tax to support the schools of the state.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE walls of the spacious entrance foyer to this Sussex County landmark restaurant are covered with accolades from guests, awards from magazines and testimonials from eating clubs with formidable names. The menu, along with the bill of fare, offers a family tree to help diners identify the owners.

title: Ballet: Fracci Dances With Nureyev
description: Carla Fracci was scheduled to appear as guest artist with Rudolf Nureyev and the National Ballet of Canada Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House  and she did. But not exactly as planned and the program was the worse for it. Still, it was the first time Mr. Nureyev and Italy's prima ballerina had danced together in New York and the combination of two such ballet personalities was newsworthy.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Milkweed
description: Botanically it is Asclepias, in honor of Aesculapius, the Greek god of healing. The everyday name is milkweed, and the two best known members of the family, butterfly weed and common milkweed, are now in bloom. The bright orange flower of butterfly weed is found only in favored places, but common milkweed grows almost everywhere, with its fragrant tufts of lavender and white florets.

title: Libretto for a Fine Feast
description: LEONIA OVER the last four years, two professional singers have been refining a recipu that calls for a generous helping of culture, a goodly portion of gourmet curiosity and a liberal lacing of nostalgia. The tastefuland tasty result is a petite musicale, a novel way to spend an evening modeled after a turnofthecentury musical soire.

title: LEBANON RIGHTISTS AND PALESTINIANS DRAFT CEASEFIRE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24A new ceasefire agreement was reported today to have been reached between the Palestinian guerrilla organization and the rightwing Christian Phalangist Party.

title: SLUDGE BAN BY '81 STIRS SKEPTICISM
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., JULY 24Two members of a House of Representatives subcommittee expressed skepticism today over a Federal environmental official's statement that all municipalities in the New York metropolitan area would be required to end the ocean dumping of sewage sludge by 1981.

title: 5 Youths Are Appointed To Traffic Safety Council
description: ALBANY, July 24, (UPI)Five youths have been appointed to the State Youth Advisory Council on Traffic Safety, the Motor Vehicle Commissioner, James P. Melton, announced yesterday.

title: Nina Tishman to Be the Bride Of Richard Alexander Sept. 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan V. Tishman of Stamford, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia B. Tishman, to Richard H. Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Alexander of New York.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIn May of this year Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon went to Brazil, following a trip by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. The aim was to establish a kind of special relationship with that leading and economically advanced member of the group of less developed countries.

title: ART
description: EAST HAMPTON FEW small museums are as energetic, enterprising and succossful as Guild Hall. Once a rural showcase with a crackerbarrel timetable, over the last decade it has become a bustling arena of dynamic activity.

title: 3d World Students Learn Ills Derived From Technology
description: ST. LOUIS, July 24Every year hundreds of students from the developing nations come to, the United States to absorb the lessons of American technology. Yesterday, 50 such students finished six weeks of intensive work here, but they had been learning a contrary lesson, a sort of deprogramming at the hands of Dr. Barry Commoner.

title: Margo J. Peter, a Bank Analyst, Married to Thomas Paull Randt
description: Margo Joan Peter, a senior analyst at the Bank of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Paull Randt, a student at the Southern Methodist University Law School.

title: F.B.I. REJOINS HUNT FOR 2 IN ABDUCTION
description: MADERA, Calif., July 24The Federal Bureau of Investigation today joined the California authorities in a nationwide hunt for two young San Mateo County residents suspected as participants in the July 35 kidnapping of 26 schoolchildren and their bus driver outside Chowchilla, 17 miles north of here.

title: EGYPT SPURRING EGG PRODUCTION
description: CAIRO, July 20The Egyptian Government is pushing plans to enlarge the poultry industry, spruce up the Suez Canal and carry out other development projects despite the country's burden of debts, now unofficially estimated at $10 billion or more.

title: Mrs. Lissitzyn Wed to J. Michael Parish
description: Susan Sgarlat Lissitzyn and J. Michael Parish were married here yesterday at noon at the bride's apartment by Robert Berson, a leader in the Ethical Culture Society.

title: Miss Carroll Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Carroll of Massapequa L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne Carroll, to Stephen J. Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Rogers of Woodcliff Lakes, N. J.

title: Williams's Career Takes New Detour
description: The dismissal of Dick Williams as manager of the California Angels Friday completes one of the more ironic sequences in baseball's long history of managerial shifts

title: Randall White And Ceci Werbe To Wed Aug. 21
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Werbe of Lausanne, Switzerland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Chandler Werbe, to Randall B. White of London, where he is with Jones. Lang & Wooten, an international real estate company.

title: The Poet As Journalist
description: For a hundred years certain avantgarde writers urged a separation between art and life. The modernists, whose gods were Flaubert and Baudelaire, decreed that the work of art was answerable only to itself, its own internal laws of style and structure. The poet does not serve the world.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: When I read that thousands of people watched Operation Sail from Kingswood Bluff in Weehawken, it brought back many memories  memories of a boyhood during the early 1920's when Kings Woods was a favorite spot to go to, especially during the summer months. The boys in our neighborhood of walkup flats didn't usually get to go to the shore or the country during school vacation.

title: The case against regular physicals
description: Health maintenance has become our national obsession. Logic suggests that in order to maintain health, we must prevent disease, and that this is best accomplished by eating balanced meals, exercising regularlyand seeing the doctor once a year for a checkup. This latter ritual, the annual physical, has been extensively promoted by physicians and enthusiastically accepted by patients as an effective means of maintaining health. But is it?

title: Helping Couples With Money Troubles
description: SMITHTOWN WHEN poverty comes in the door, love flies out the window is an old saying that is being repeated anew in these times of high unemployment and inflation. The money crunch is not only stifling the life style of scores of couples, it's also rupturing their marriages.

title: FRANK A. SHERER
description: Frank A. Sherer, a former senior vice president of the Chemical Bank and president of the Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York, died Friday of cancer at the Sloan Kettering Memorial Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 49 East 92d Street.

title: Crawford Looks to Football
description: MONTREAL, July 24As the Olympic 100meter champion, Hasely Crawford of Trinidad acknowledged today that, If I get a chance, I'll play football. The world's fastest human is a muscular 6 feet 2 inches and 195 pounds. He is understood to be on the negotiation list of the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League.

title: The Revolutionary Age of Andrew Jackson
description: No figure in American history has more excited the imagination of historians than Andrew Jackson. From James Parton, writing his mammoth three volumes in the 1850's to Marquis James's and Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s Pulitzerwinning works, Jackson has inspired historians, who, like Robert Remini, see the outlines of modern America in the transitional age of Jackson; the Civil War was merely the legitimization of the birth.

title: Andrea Doria Speculation And Legends Will Not Die
description: Twenty years ago today, the 29,500grosston Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria and the Swedish passenger ship Stockholm collided in the Atlantic. The Andrea Doria sank the following morning, and 52 lives were lost in the accident. In the intervening two decades, speculation has continued on the cause of the accident. And there still are legends of a treasure trove aboard the Doria and recurring talk of trying to raise the vessel.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market wound up the week with little change, in lackluster trading that included the lowestvolume day in more than six weeks.

title: Union's Head Calls Workers Underpaid
description: Two out of three mediators agreed recently that Nassau County's C.S.E.A. workers were underpaid and deserved at least a 6.6 percent salary increase this year to keep pace with the cost of living.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment to keep antirecession tax cuts in effect through calendar year 1977, which passed, 66 to 28, July 20.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, July 24  A record fleet of 240 yachts started the 69th annual ChicagotoMackinac Island race today, a 333mile passage north to the island in the straits between Lakes Michigan and Huron. This drinkingwater event, usually a midsummer search for wind all over Lake Michigan, began with a fair breeze of 8 to 10 knots from the north as the fleet was started in eight different sections. The smallest were 27foot sloops with crews four.

title: Red Smith
description: MONTREAL, July 24A guy from Germany said he was taking a poll and needed an American opinion: would the Olympic Games survive or collapse? Would there be another carnival four years hence in Moscow and if so, what about 1984? If the American had to bet, would he bet that Olympics would take place in 1984? The American said he sometimes bet on horses and even guessed right on rare occasions, but that was the limit of his imbecility. To bet on people would be stupid; trying to predict how politicians and playground directors would behave four or eight years hence would be sheer madness.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JULY 25, 1976

title: Holly Pyne Is Married To Geoffrey M. Connor
description: Maud Howland Pyne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wright Pyne of Far Hills. N.J., was married there yesterday evening to Geoffrey M. Connor, a lawyer in the London office of the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton.

title: Other Highlights
description: BASKETBALLCanada joined the Soviet Union, the United States, and Yugoslavia in the medal semifinal round when the U.S.S.R. eliminated Cuba.

title: A New Hand at Hofstra's Helm
description: HEMPSTEAD HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY, like many of the country's independent colleges and universities, is in a precarious financial position, but it is looking forward to the future with confidence.

title: Tigers Win
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) Ben Oglivie's leadoff homerun in the top of the eighth inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 54 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: They Stand Behind Smith, and They Remember England
description: JOHANNESBURGDespite its public bravado, the isolated community of 270,000 whites whose Government rules Rhodesia has surprised itself as much as the rest of the world with its successful defiance of international trade embargoes, global opprobrium and boycotts and rising black militancy that turned guerrilla warfare.

title: FISHING
description: THE recurring pattern of red tides and fish kills has put a damper si what had been, at least until last week, a fine fishing season. However, bluefish seem unaffected and should continue to provide good action from the Samegat Ridge north to the Shrewsbury Rocks.

title: Independence Is Launched, Faces Ocean Tests
description: The first new United States 12Meter yacht for the next America's Cup challenge splashed down the marine railway after launching ceremonies yesterday at Minneford's yard on City Island. The elegant, whitehulled Twelve with a red trim line and flush light blue decks, was designed by Ted Hood, the defending Cup helmsman.

title: Cyclist Injured in Grand Prix Trial
description: ANDERSTORP, Sweden, July 24 (AP)  Barry Sheene, the hottest performer in international motorcycling, took a bad spill in today's final trial session and was a doubtful starter for tomorrow's Swedish Grand Prix. The British rider, 25 years old, was unconscious when he was taken to a nearby hospital, where doctors said he had suffered a brain concussion.

title: Battle of Long Island Is Fought at New Site
description: WEST NEWBURY, Mass., July 24 (UPI)The battle was a reenactment of another that had taken place two centuries ago, in another state and involving much larger forces.

title: Anne DuBosque Is Bride in Capital
description: Anne Matheson DuBosque, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hutchinson DuBosque of Laurel Hollow, Syosset, L.I., and Peter Deme, son of Dr. Alexander Deme and Mrs. Vladimir Sykora of Nove Zamky, Czechoslovakia, were married yesterday afternoon in an outdoor ceremony in Montrose Park in Georgetown, Washington.

title: Marilyn Fee Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Fee Jr. of Rockville Centre, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter. Marilyn Patricia Fee, to Paul J. White 3d, son of Mrs. White Jr. of Rye, N. Y., and the late Mr. White. A wedding in October is planned.

title: Where to go, what to take
description: The signs of the backpacking boom are everywhere: in specialized stores, in the variety of packs manufactured most are acceptable as long as they have a light frame and a good beltand in the avalanche of backpacking hooks and magazines now on the market. Although the hooks and stores are the best sources for backpacking details such as equipment lists, here are a few extra tips, gleaned from my own trial and error.

title: The World Grows Larger
description: Exactly seven years after man first walked on the moon, he has now placed a surrogate, the Viking 1 lander on the surface of Mars, the third heavenly body that humans have visited either in person or by robot machine for direct scientific observation.

title: TV VIEW
description: If nothing else, television coverage of the Democratic National Convention was not skimpy. In Manhattan, at least, insatiable convention buffs had between 10 and 14 hours a day available for gluttonous consumption. Also in Manhattan, some viewers had access to two forms of coverage representing ultimate extremes. Network coverage, available to anyone with a TV set, offered a tightly structured package of live events, special features, commentaries and commercials, all brought to the nation at a cost of millions of dollars. Alternate video coverage by a group called Image Union, available only to subscribers of Manhattan Cable, was completely unstructured, sometimes meandering into pointless and irritating corners, but often tripping into moments of brilliance. Its budget was obviously in the shoestring category.

title: DOROTHY BURGESS
description: Dorothy Cross Burgess, wife of the late Robert W. Burgess, who was director of the Bureau of the Census from 1953 to 1961 and chief executive of the Western Electric Company, died Friday at the New Rochelle Medical Center after a short illness. She was 82 years old and lived at 440 Pelham Manor Road, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: To Study Dying is to Fear It Less
description: The pretty, solemn face has been staring out from magazine covers, newspapers and television sets for the better part of a year now, forcing each American, as no public event ever has before, to see not just the consequences of today's technology, but his own inevitable end.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: A Cry For Help
description: ISPENT over three years in a psychiatric hospital. I have seen the horrors you've read about; I have experienced institutionalization  which simply means being in an institution long enough to lose the desire to leave it; I have, upon finally leaving, felt the effects of discrimination and have been rejected at jobs and schools because I was naive enough to think that I would be able to avoid the stigma of mental illness; therefore, I foolishly and honestly revealed my hospitalization; I have seen friends crumble beneath the burden of loneliness and rejection and return to the hospital. . . . I propose that we focus on the possibilities of community centers where a better informed public could deal with emotional problems in their earliest stages and in the community and to help those leaving the hospital in their struggle to readjust to the responsibilities and requirements of the outside.

title: Nepal Creates Parks
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, July 24 (UPI)Nepal has declared three areas, including 480 square miles around Mount Everest, as wildlife reserves and national parks. Wildlife in the Everest National Park includes the Himalayan Panda, which is in danger of extinction.

title: Interest in Energy Conservation
description: In Seattle, if you are buying a new car, home or boat and it's labeled energy effident, you'll get onehalf to threequarters of a point break on interest charges from the Seattle Trust and Savings Bank. That can be $5,000 saving in 30 years on a $40.000 home.

title: Mutinies in Democratic Ranks
description: A Governor is usually the leader of his state's political party as well as the chief executive of the state government. But that tradition has been badly battered in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where firstterm Democratic Governors have been embarrassed by rebellions within their party ranks that could threaten their legislative programs and political fortunes.

title: U.S. Citizen Freed by Belgrade Again Denies Charge of Spying
description: THORNTON, Colo., July 24 (UPI)Laszlo Toth, flanked by the wife and daughter he had not seen in nearly a year, today denied the industrial spying charges that had led to his imprisonment in Yugoslavia.

title: GARDENING
description: EVEN the most enthusiastic gardener is receptive to suggestions that will take the work out of gardening. Time saved in carrying out garden tasks is time available for other pursuits or just to sit back and enjoy one's accomplishments.

title: Higher Taxes in Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana, July 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Higher taxes on gasoline, beer and cigarettes were announced here in the Government's 197677 budget.

title: LETTERS
description: Gristly Problem

title: 9 South African Animals Are Considered Endangered
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 24 (AP)The leopard, the Cheetah and at least seven other South African animals are considered endangered species, conservation officials say.

title: Robin Knox Bride of A. D. Magee
description: Robin Hunt Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gaillard Knox of Allentown, Pa., was married yesterday noon to Andrew Davies Magee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Weston Magee of Newport, R. I.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Fast book. Traditionally book publishing is a gentleman's business, with long summer weekends and six to ninemonth intervals between the time a manuscript is received and the finished book is in the stores. But ever since 1964, when they rushed the Warren Commission Report through the presses and into dealers' hands within six days, the folks at Bantam Books have been playing a game they call instant publishing whenever there's an appropriate occasion.

title: Mondale's Assets Relatively Modest
description: MINNEAPOLISIn national politics, where the accumulation of wealth appears to be easy, Walter Frederick Mondale has not accumulated very much.

title: ARREST IMMUNITY IN CAPITAL TO END
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The District of Columbia police will end next week a policy, more than 100 years old, of avoiding arrests of members of Con. cress, which Chief Maurice J. Cullinane says was based on a misinterpretation of the meaning of the founding fathers in the Constitution.

title: CEMETERIES
description: ONE. Cemetery Plot, 6 graves, Intersectarian. Mt Hope. NY. Value $1800. Will seli $1000,. 5163241461

title: Group to Buy Area in West For Use as Wildlife Refuge
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) A private conservation group says that it will purchase 119 square miles of land, much of it wilderness, about halfway between Yellowstone National Park and Glacier National Park to protect its status as a wildlife refuge.

title: Communist Elected in Sicily
description: PALERMO, Siciliy, July 24 (UPI)Sicily's regional Assembly has elected its first Communist President, choosing Pancrazio de Pasquale by a vote of 70 to 88. The onesided vote resulted from a political deal.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: SWIMMING POOL WATER (July 4) P.G.H., Greenwich, Conn. asked if swimming pool water could be used for the vegetable/flower E garden since they have to drain the pool for a crack repair. We checked with manufacturers of swimming pool chemicals and the general opinion is no, do not use pool water/treated with chlorine on garden plants. The chlorine concentration plus the effect of sun on the plants would probably cause severe damage. Ed.

title: Bulgarians Unearth A Thracian Chariot
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 24 (UPI)  Bulgarian archeologists have unearthed a fourwheeled chariot that belonged to a nobleman of ancient Thrace and the skeletons of four horses nearby, according to the official press agency.

title: Mets' Box Score
description: EFoll 3, Hodges 2. Thornton. DPNew York 3, Montreal 3. LOBNew York 13, Montreal 4, 2BRivera 2, Milner, J.White, J.Mangual, SFPhillips, Thorn. ton, Valentine.

title: Clark Asks U.S. to Aid Transit; Senate Hopefuls Have Busy Day
description: Ramsey Clark yesterday called for a national transportalion policy fulfilling the basic human need for fast, safe, efficient, comfortable and inexpensive travel.

title: More Than 1,500 Killed in the Last Seven Years
description: DUBLINOn the same day that a land mine killed the British Ambassador to Dublin and a secretary, the Irish Republican Army smuggled a fivepound bomb into the heavily guarded Ebrington Barracks in Londonderry and killed a young British soldier.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Leonard A. Gordon, author of Bengal: The Nationalist Movement, teaches at Brooklyn College.

title: Letters: Is Tipping Getting Out of Hand?
description: We are thinking of going to Europe or South America and are reading travel books on various countries. Why do travel writers suggest that Americans tip an additional 5 to 15 percent for service on top of the already steep 15 to 20 percent added to the hotel and restaurant bills?

title: Lamps to Help Trees Grow
description: Trees can be grown indoors even though they require high light intensities. What makes it all possible are the RID or high intensity discharge lamps.

title: Christine Semenenko Is Bride
description: The marriage of Christine Semenenko, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Semenenko of Boston and Wianno, Mass., to Anthony M. Warrender, son of Lord and Lady Bruntisfield of Gstaad, Switzerland, took place yesterday evening.

title: Tests to Seek Life on Mars Begin
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 24After thousands of years of speculation on whether or not life has originated elsewhere in the universe, observations began today on Mars to learn whether this has occurred at least on one place beyond earth.

title: Industry Urged to Offer Exercise Plan to Employees
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (UPI)An official of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports says that two of the most serious occupational health hazards are the desk and swivel chair.

title: Bills Sign Top Pick
description: BUFFALO, July 24 (AP)Mario Clark, the club's No. 1 choice in the National Football League draft, was signed to a series of oneyear contracts by the Buffalo Bills

title: Why the Gas Lights Must Go
description: A Cape May resident, Mark Forrest, chided the Publie Utility Commission (July 4) for ordering the conversion of gas street lights to electricity and ridiculed the commission as a fumbling, bumbling bureaucracy whose officials are motivated more by a desire to exercise their egos than to serve the needs of our state's citizens.

title: Keeping a Low Profile
description: Even though American Natural Is the most successful major utility in Michigan, its profile in its home state is so low as to be almost invisible.

title: Oil Burner Highly Regarded In $300,000 Harness Race
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 24Randy Perry looked like a boy among men last night in the raindrenched Monticello Raceway paddock as Billy Naughton, Bill Popfinger and Norman Dauplaise towered over him.

title: Who needs the B1?
description: WASHINGTON. Like a jet transport accelerating down the runway, a new strategic bomber is about to take off on potentially the most expensive weapons program ever undertaken by the Defense Department. The bomber is the B1, the Air Force's supersonic successor to the Bfit, which for 20 years has been the airborne symbol of America's nuclear might. With a needlelike nose and bulbously streamlined body that give it the look of wasp coming in for the attack, the B1 is a remarkable airplane, a tribute to the technological prowess of the United States. The only thing is, the executive branch and Congress are backing the multibilliondollar investment without a clear. logical examination of whether a sophisticated new strategic bomber is neededwhether the plane is off on a Strangelovian flight of Air Force pride and fancy or on a mission essential to the nation's security.

title: A Teacher Talks Back
description: AS a teacher in a high school in Senator Alene S. Ammond's Cherry Hill district, I must dispute some of the conclusions reached in her commentary of July 4.

title: Tioga Park Cancels Portion of Schedule
description: NICHOLS, N. Y., July 24 (AP)Tioga Park has canceled its Tuesdaynight racing schedules for this season because there arc not enough quarter horses at the track to hold races six days a week, according to Jacob Iberger, president and general manager.

title: Builder Ruffles a Village
description: ASHAROKEN, L.I.  It is difficult to believe that any controversy at all could occur in this genteel village of 613 residents. Asharoken nestles atop a rise overlooking Long Island Sound, and its remoteness has provided its residents not just bucolic calm but also a sense of security from the sort of development that has transformed western Suffolk County into a collection of suburban communities.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Next Saturday, July 31, is the deadline for ordering the official National Bicentennial Medal.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Saturday, July 24, 22d day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Robert C. Guile to Wed Charlotte Parker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy B. Parker of Flatts, Bermuda, and Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte Huger Parker, to Robert Cass Gillie of Greenwich, Conn. He is the son of Mildred Cass Gillie of Rye, N. Y., and Dr.

title: POLITICS
description: ALTHOUGH the Republican Presidential nomination is still to be decided next month in Kansas City, both major political parties are thinking ahead beyond the Labor Day weekend to the hard campaign for the White House and the Congressional elections throughout New Jersey.

title: GRACE ORLAND BARNETT
description: Grace Orland Barnett, who designed jewelry, died Friday at her home at 785 Fifth Avenue. She was 70 years old. Mrs. Barnett, who was born in Lodz, Poland, came to the United States as a young child and attended schools in New York.

title: Michael Krasnoff Fiance of Donna Field
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl M. Field of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Nancy Field, to Michael Barg Krasnoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Krasnoff, also of Brooklyn.

title: Three Killed Before Suicide
description: DONORA, Pa., July 24 (UPI) The police said today that a 39yearold mother, apparently distraught with personal problems, shot and killed her three young children while they slept and then killed herself with the gun. The victims were Geraldine Hansen, and Christopher, 10, Perry, 5, and Victoria, 2.

title: Only Money, Safety Limit Scientific Imagination
description: PASADENA, Calif.Not long after Viking l's successful landing on Mars last Tuesday morning, Dr. Thomas A. Mutch, a project scientist, was gazing in wonder, and some wistfulness, at photographs of the planet's rocky desert landscape. You just wish you could be standing there, Dr. Mutch remarked absently, as if his wish had already taken him far away from the Viking control center. You wish you were walking across that terrain.

title: Olympic Sidelights
description: MONTREAL, July 24  Peter Kormann, the winner the first United States medal in men's gymnastics since 1932, realized he had to do something spectacular to get the attention of the judges, even if he came up with egg on his face.

title: The World
description: The murderous religious war in Northern Ireland, which occasionally spills its blood onto Ireland to the south, did so again last week. Christopher T. E. EwartBiggs, a distinguished diplomat who had just become Britain's Ambassador to Ireland, was killed by a bomb exploded in the roadway just outside his home near Dublin.

title: NEW YORK STATE TRIES TO IMPROVE BUSINESS CLIMATE
description: Since the beginning of the year, New York State has begun to close the gap between itself and other states in the aid, tax relief and incentives that it offers to new or expanding businesses.

title: TV VIEW
description: There must have been some nervousness during the Democratic Convention in the command modules of the networks, those glowing bubbles in the sky. The conspiracy against television had taken on a new form. This form was the short movie. Both keynote speakers, Senator John Glean and Representative Barbara Jordan, were introduced by brief films. So, of course, was the designated President, Jimthy Carter. And there was a silly 16 minutes of Edward Asher impersonating Finley Peter Dunne's Mr. Dooley. That the quality of the movies left almost everything to be deairedthey were really commercials for the self, and not very, adroit onesis beside the point. The point is that when they came on the lights in Madison Square Garden were turned off, and the networks were helpless. All those electronic floor reporters; those space cadets with their Captain Video headsets, trying to storm the Winter Palace of Amy Carter's ennui, were blotted out, disenfranchised, unplugged and debugged. They needed light in order to interrupt the business of the convention, and for as long as the movies chose to run, there would he no light. Imagine the frustration, the panic, in Kansas City if the Republicans learn this lesson and act accordingly: w,hy not film the nominating and seconding speeches in advance, and the platform debate? Why not a visual essay on Ronald Reagan's pomade; clips of an unflinching President Ford, the height of the Mayaguez crisis, facing down the armed might of Cambodia; home movies of Julie Eisenhower tapdancing and John Connally being acquitted and Nelson RoCkefeller higuying ten thousands of his most faithful retainers, his Fido Ronans, in a bomb shelter underneath the Albany Mall? They could hold their entire convention in the dark, thereby rendering the hated networks speechless.

title: KOREAN'S U.S. WIFE IN APPEAL FOR HIM
description: What is it like to be the American wife of a South Korean clergyman on trial because he has outspokenly opposed the regime?

title: Controlling a Seasonal Pest: Groupers
description: FIVE years ago the East Hampton area was plagued by gypsy moths. Their larvae ate the trees bare, messed up our cars and our houses, and generally made us miserable. Aerial spraying killed off some of themplus a lot of birds and beesbut didn't stop the gypsy moths from coming back. What did help was letting Nature take charge: predators, and overbreeding by the gypsy moths, eventually, restored the natural balance.

title: The Scene
description: Given that it is only incidentally about art, postmodern (whatever that is) or otherwise, and that its title harbors at least three unsupported assumptionsthat there is (or has been) a Scene integral enough to rate the definite article, that Calvin Tomkins knows what it is and that his book is a comprehensive view of itgranted all these fairly significant irritations, The Scene is still as good a piece of generalinterest writing about the New York art world in recent times as anyone has a right to expect. It is eight pieces of writing, actually, all but one of which originally appeared in The New Yorker; their subjects are certain persons and phenomena in or about the arts during the late 1960's and early 1970's: powerful curator Henry Geldzahler, Andy Warhol, print impresario Tatyana Grosman, the artandtechnology movement, underground cineast Jonas Mekas, earthworks, video artist Nam June Paik and the spectacular slowmotion theater of Robert Wilson.

title: Bankers Blow Up at the Accountants
description: A change in accounting methods Yawn.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: The Region
description: Connecticut's Governor, Ella T. Grasso, a Democrat, last week tried to remove William A. O'Neill, the state party chairman, and failed. The result was to splinter the Democrats and to isolate herself from both party and legislature, which is heavily Democratic.

title: Inquiry Pressed in Slaying Of Inmate at U.S. Facility
description: Federal authorities began an investigation yesterday into the fatal stabbing of an inmate in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan. The incident occurred about 8 P.M. Friday.

title: MAGNET SCHOOLS SHORT OF GOALS
description: HOUSTON, July 24Reports filed with the Federal District Court here show that Houston's magnet school program, one of the largest such experiments in the country, failed to achieve as much integration in its first year of operation as school officials had predicted.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Adult Bookstore
description: Karl Shapiro's slim new volume (32 poems) is best described as a graceful, playful stepchild of its mighty predecessor, The Poetry Wreck: Selected Essays 19501970. Normally in short reviews one likes to keep to the book in hand. But Shapiro is not your ordinary essaywriting poet. I admit to liking his verse a good deal more than his prose, and the new book does nothing to change my opinion. I agree with Randall Jarrell about the notable visual and satiric force, the real precision, a memorable exactness of realization in the poetry. But the question at issue is not entirely what a reviewer may like but what the phenomenon Karl Shapiro has at 63 become in the poet's own eyes.

title: Lynn Named Outstanding As Race Week Skipper
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 24William H. Lynn Jr. of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y. was named the outstanding skipper of Larchmont Race Week for the second time in eight years today at the end of the midsummer sailing jamboree on Long Island Sound.

title: The Measure of Greatness
description: MONTREAL, July 24It is a padded piece of wood, only four inches wide and 16 feet long, and it is hardly the object for a 14yearold girl to be using to fool around with acrobatic moves such as aerial front somersaults, double full twists and consecutive handsprings.

title: Outrageously rich
description: One of the most unusual and tempting desserts we have sampled in many an age we discovered on our last trip to London. It was in a busting and generally excellent restaurant (the noise level is a bit high) named Lacy's, 26 Whitfield Street. Lacy's is owned by the patronchef, William Lacy, and wife, Margaret Costa, who also happens to be a cookbook author and is food editor of The Times of London. The dessert in question was a marvelous jumble of fresh fruits, baked, we divine, with that outrageously rich clotted cream of England. That cream we cannot duplicate, so we have devised an approximate dish made with pastry cream, one of the basic and finer things in the repertoire of the French pastry chef. We offer our version of Mr. Lacy's dessert, plus an apple and pastrycream tart in the style of Normandy.

title: Defoliating the L.I.R.R.'s Trackside Jungle
description: THE Long Island Rail Road's war against weeds, using a new chemical spray along its right of way in the name of passenger safety, has evoked expressions of concern despite the railroad's efforts to allay fears.

title: Figueroa Takes 13th, Beating Red Sox
description: The Yankees put away the dispirited Boston Red Sox at the Stadium again yesterday, 41, to reduce the suspense in the American League East.

title: 1978 Asian Games Bar Israelis Over Security
description: MONTREAL, July 24 (Rcuters)Israel was barred today from the 1978 Asian Games, a move that an Israeli official said felt like a thunderbolt.

title: A Matter Of Life Or Death
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S electric chair is 69 years old and needs dusting. It has been unused since Jan. 22. 1963, and it sits in an execution chamber that is being used as a storage closet for mattresses in the State Prison on the south side of town.

title: Police Charge 4 Killed Detective During Queens Robbery in June
description: Four men who the police believe worked together on a number of robberies in New York and Chicago have been charged with the murder of an offduty transit police detective in a $34,000 robbery in Long Island City, Queens, in June.

title: M. W. Sands Fiance of Miss Dietel
description: William M. Dietel, president of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, and Mrs. Dietel of Ridgefield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lynn Dietel, to Michael Winthrop Sands, son of Dr. and Mrs. G. Winthrop Sands of Wilmot, N. H., and Edgartown, Mass.

title: British Budget Cuts
description: In the face of bitter opposition from its left wing and the trade unions, Britain's Labor Government has taken a daring step to achieve economic recovery. Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey has announced cuts in public spending for next year of $1.78 billionmany in areas such as housing, health, education and unemployment benefits that have long been at the heart of the Labor Party program.

title: Suspect's ExWife Says He Shot at Teenagers
description: ATLANTA, July 24The former wife of a suspect in the kidnapping of 26 California school children said today that he had refused to have children and had become so angry with trespassing teenagers that he had shot at them.

title: Edith A. Phyfe, Lowell Johnson To Wed Aug. 21
description: Edith Anne Phyfe, a greatgreatgrandaughter of Duncan Phyfe, the cabinetmaker, and Dr. Lowell Erwin Johnson, professor of economics at Wells College and Cornell University, plan to be married Aug. 21.

title: Fox Hound Best In Rhode Island
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., July 24Ch. Brown's Fire Fighter, a 4yearold American fox hound owned by Gilbert and Wilma Beck of Weston, Conn., and handled by Ted Young of Wilton. Conn., was the best of the 1,055 dogs in today's 71st annual allbreed dog show and obedience trials of the Providence County Kennel Club at Victory Field. The winner has been shown 88 times, and has won the breed 85 times, including at Westminster. He has 15 group placements, but this was the first hound group and best in show for him

title: POLITICS
description: THE 60's were a golden era for Nassau Democrats. Their county chairman, John F. English, was one of the state's top Democratic Party leaders. He was even moving onto the national scene as a leader of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, which soared for a time only to plummet to earth and failure.

title: BRITISH REPORTER MISSING IN AFRICA
description: LONDON, July 24 (Reuters) Jon Swain, foreign correspondent of The Sunday Times of London and Britain's Journalist of the Year in 1975, has been missing in Ethiopia for more than a month, his newspaper announced in its issue tonight.
