title: Fan Hurls Bottle, Pirates Walk Off
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP)  Pittsburgh's center fielder, Al Oliver, was almost hit by a bottle thrown by a fan during the second game of the PhilliesPirates doubleheader at Veterans Stadium tonight.

title: W. H. Watson 3d Weds Judy Frey
description: Judith Anne Frey and Winsor Hays Watson 3d were married yesterday afternoon in an outdoor ceremony at the Pelham (Mass.) Country Club. The Rev. Arnold Westwood of the Unitarian Church in Amherst, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: He Might Have Been Another Lindbergh
description: CHARLES FITY was flying airplanes before Charles Lindbergh knew east from west. With better luck he might have been a hero, a legend for the ages. Now, clearheaded and 87 years of age, Mr. Fity has outlived the more famous pioneers of aviation, quietly surviving in West Hempstead with his memories of flying only a few years after the Wright Brothers.

description: LOUISVILLE, July 24 (AP) John McEnroe of DouglasIon, Queens, defeated Van Winitsky of North Miami Beach, 76, 63, and won the national junior claycourt tennis championshin today.

title: Milton Brown, Aide at NBC For News Information, at 61
description: Milton Brown, coordinator of news information services for the National Broadcasting Company since 1962, died Friday of a heart attack following surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was 61 years old.

title: Fear in paradise
description: Every year half a million tourists fly into Jamaica, the lush 144milelong island just to the south of Cuba. After going through customs and past the very stoned calypso quartet that welcomes every plane, the vacationers fan out among the North Coast resorts to revel in what is still an archetypal paradise spangled with crystal beaches, flowered with bougainvillea and oleander, and washed by a tropic sea so aquamarine that on a bright day the eye is blinded by the diamonds of sunshine glistening on the water.

title: Henze's First Opera in a Decade Seen in London
description: LONDON Hans Werner Henze is one of the most highly regarded opera composers of the age, yet his We Come to the River, first performed by the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, earlier this month, is his first opera in 10 years.

title: A Concrete Terrace That Can Be Built in Squares
description: One of the fastest ways to build a permanent terrace or patio is to make it of concrete by pouring the entire slab in one operation. However, many feel that a concrete slab is rather drab and sterile looking, and has a commercial look that they find objectionable.

title: Sets Beat Nets, 3019, in W.T.T.
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 24 Billie Jean King defeated Martina Navatrilova, 64, in the feature women's singles match as the New York Sets beat the Cleveland Nets, 3019, in a World Team Tennis contest before 2,219 in the Nassau Coliseum last night.

title: Bob Wynn, Seeking First Major Victory, Posts 66202 to Lead Pate by 2 Strokes
description: WINDSOR. Ontario, July 24 (AP)Bob Wynn, bidding for his first Professional Golfers' Association maintour victory, carded a fourunderpar 66 today to take the lead after three rounds of the 67th Canadian open golf championship.

title: Misuse of Funds Charged
description: TRENTON, July 23 (AP)An audit of a Trenton education program shows the city used $471,560 in Federal funds from 1971 to 1973, according to the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The 49page report said the program, Project Build, had been designed to develop exemplary programs which showed the promise of reducing the number of children who do not complete their education in elementary and secondan schools.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Amateur photographers who want to increase their batting averages by taking a higher percentage of pictures that are good enough to exhibit or sell can do so most easily by giving themselves photo assignments on a regular basis. The process of selection and assignment involved will improve anyone's ability to increase the number of good pictures that will result. Since this is basically editorial work, the photographer becomes in essence his own editor.

title: Power Plant Curb Sought
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) The National Resources Defense Council said yesterday that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission should cancel the license of the Vermont yankee atomic power plant in the wake of a Federal court ruling that the agency paid too little attention to the threat of radioactive waste from the plant.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: As a further austerity measure in New York City's budget crisis, all municipal agencies have been ordered to reduce their cost of leasing space in privately owned buildings by 10 percent. To monitor the effectiveness of the effort, the agencies have been directed by First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti to report monthly on their progress.

title: CORRECTION
description: Last week's Washington Report incorrectly attributed to Otto Eckstein a statement that had been made by Jimmy Carter: I think just common sense shows that one of the major inflationary pressures has been brought about by very high unemployment rates.

title: Rx for Getting an M.D.
description: WHEN Thomas Apuzzo was in his final year at Boston College it was suggested that he not bother applying to medical schools. He graduated with a 2.4 average in biology, 3.4 in philosophy, and an overall average of 2.8.

title: Sunday Observer
description: You meet more and more people who are worried that they will never become grandparents. It's a side effect of the falling birthrate, and in the next few years, I suppose, if unbirth continues to increase, it will escalate into one of those national problems  the grandparent shortage, grandchild frustration anxietyso dear to special Presidential commissions, sociologists and magazine editors.

title: Hospital Pact Ratified
description: CINCINNATI, July 24 (UPI) Members of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal employees yesterday ratified by an overwhelming margin an agreement to end a 10day strike by 1,800 persons at General and Holmes Hospitals and at the University of Cincinnati.

description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI)Most Americans think the rose should be the national flower, according to poll results from across the country.

title: Experts Fear Court Refusal to Hear Two Cases Will Erode Newsmen's Privilege of Confidentiality
description: Two recent decisions by the United States Supreme Court not to review cases in which newsmen were held in contempt for not disclosing their sources are viewed with alarm by some First Amendment experts. They feel that a dangerous precedent may have been set toward eroding the traditional privilege of reporters and editors to protect the people who give them information.

title: Economy Is Better, Political Mayhem Worse
description: BUENOS AIRESFour months ago, the generals who deposed President Isbel Martinez de Pern said Argentina was entering a new era. But they also warned that the country was undergoing a most difficult period.

title: Klein Wins a Key Vote
description: THE speech lasted barely 10 minutes but, as he would himself acknowledge later, it was probably one of the most important in John V. N. Klein's political life.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City's Human Resources Administrator, J. Henry Smith, announced what was described as the successful completion of the first of seven programs aimed at reducing city welfare expendtures by $20 million in the current fiscal year. This initial program, the announcement said, has resulted in the reclassification of 2,552 cases from the home relief category (which is financed entirely by state and city money) to the aidtodepenoentchildren category (in which the Federal Government provides 50 percent of the financing). As a result, Mr. Smith said, city tax levy expenditures will be reduced by $3,725,000 in the 197677 fiscal year.

title: National Affairs
description: MILWAUKEE, July 24 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit has upheld a lower court decision that declared the Milwaukee school system unconstitutionally segregated.

description: Geoffrey Wolff is a novelist and critic. Black Sun, his biography of Harry Crosby, will be published in August.

title: URUGUAYAN EXILE FACES INDICTMENT
description: An exiled Uruguayan who told a House subcommittee last month that United States policies helped maintain dictatorships in Uruguay and other Latin American countries says that as a result an indictment has been issued by a military court and his holdings have been confiscated.

title: South Africans Hail Start Of New Zealand Matches
description: JOHANNESBURG. July 24The rugby series between South Africa and New Zealand that set off the African boycott of the Olympic Games in Montreal began today in a frenzy of enthusiasm.

title: Mondale Cites Assurances by Carter That Stage Is Large Enough for Both
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., July 24Senator Walter F. Mondale, who is taking his first steps along the campaign trail this weekend, says that he has not talked to Jimmy Carter about specific VicePresidential duties but that Mr. Carter had assured him he did not mind sharing the stage.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: July 28Taconic Auto Sports Club 25mile night rally preceding general meeting; start and finish at Nino's Restaurant, Old Route 6, Jefferson Valley, N.Y. Registration: 7 P.M.. first car off 7:30. Information: Walt Eisenstark, phone (914)5924214 days.

title: C.I.A. Sued on Mail Opening
description: HARTFORD, July 24 (UPI) A Yale Law School graduate is suing the Central Intelligence Agency for $120,000, charging that the agency opened and copied six of his personal letters while he was a Federal exchange student in Russia. Michael Avery, 31 years old, who now practices law in New Haven, said yesterday that the suit sought $20,000 for each of six letters the agency concedes it opened while he studied at the University of Moscow in 196869.

title: The Region
description: The budget of the City University of New York has been cut from last year's $539 million to $470 million for the coming academic year, a reduction that will mean a smaller student body, fewer faculty members and, many people fear, a decline in academic quality.

title: Mexican Wins Marathon
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 (UPI)  Demitrio Cabanillas, a Mexican national steeplechase champion running his first marathon, sprinted to an early lead and coasted home today to win the seventh annual Deseret News Marathon by more than six minutes. Cabanillas, 21 years old, of Tamasula, Mexico, was timed in 2 hours 25 minutes 15 seconds for the 26mile385yard race.

title: An Invitation to The Butterfly Ball
description: A Counting Rhyme. By Jane Yolen. Illustrated by Jane Breskin Zalben. Unpaged. New York: Parents' Magazine Press. $5.50. (Ages 4 to 7)

title: College Farm Setup Termed Not Fruitful
description: While professional basketball and football rely on the colleges as a farm system, the same is not true for soccer, which starves for native talent in the United States. One general manager in the North American Soccer League feels the league should drop the college draft and search for another way to develop American soccer players.

title: Miss Zwick Bride Of John Keydel Jr.
description: Margaret Jean Zwick, daughter of Fred Daniel Zwick, supervisor of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Mrs. Zwick, was married yesterday to John Flint Keydel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Keydel cf Riverside, Conn.

title: Meredith Luce, James Hoblock Plan Marriage
description: Meredith Hamilton Luce, granddaughter of the late Henry R. Luce, founder of the TimeLife magazine empire, and James Courtney Hoblock will be married Aug. 14 in Huntington, L.I.

title: FOOD
description: STRAWBERRIES were only the beginning. Once the last of them have been plucked from their stems and the fields are turned over to the daisies, it's time for other berriesraspberries, blueberries and later, blackberries. Raspberries and blueberries can be picked wild or purchased cultivated. Occasionally, they may be picked cultivated.

title: The White Pumpkin
description: By Denis Hills. Illustrated. 344 pp. New York: Grove Press. $10.

title: Karen Anne Hutchinson Is Bride
description: Karen Anne Hutchinson and Robert Paul Williams were married yesterday afternoon in St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury, Conn. The Rev. William Charbonneau, who concelebrated the nuptial mass with the bride's cousin, the Rev. Gerald Hutchinson.

title: HEIMAN LOOMER
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 24 (UPI) Heiman Loomer, a member of the United States Communist Party's Central Committee, died Thursday of a heart attack while vacationing on the Black Sea coast in Varna, the Bulgarian Communist Party said today.

title: The road less traveled
description: Discovering backpacking is a bit like leaving home for the first time. There's a mixture of pain and new freedom, and your family is not sure it approves. The comparison is imperfect, of course; the pain of the hike is only physical, and from backpacking you always return. But there's a root similarity. In wilderness, as in that first apartment, you find independence that you didn't know was there.

title: Capturing Florence In a Single Piazza
description: After a fitful sleeptoo much good Chianti wineI woke up in a stuffy Florence hotel one morning and dressed quickly to walk around the town. When I finally looked at my watch. I found it was only 7 A.M.

title: Deborah Dodd Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William D. Dodd of Napa, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Dodd, to Henry Raymond Lambert, a profitability analyst with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. The wedding is planned for Sept. 11 in Napa.

title: French Bank Offers Reward
description: NICE, France, July 23 (Reuters)  The Socit Gnrale Bank today offered a $210,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the thieves who looted a branch office here of an estimated $10 million.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Filly Is Winner At Ascot
description: ASCOT, England, July 24 (AP)  Frenchtrained Pawneese captured the $180,000 King George VI and Queen Elizabth Diamond Stakes by a length today.

title: BRIDGE
description: Almost all the Bicentennial celebrations this month have represented a conscious effort to recreate the historical circumstances of 1776. But it is unlikely that any of the planners have had as much assistance from a genie as did some players of a Bicentennial bridge match in Springfield, Mass., during the holiday weekend earlier this month: The fortunes of bridge war in 1976 paralleled in microcosm the fortunes of revolutionary war 200 years earlier.

title: Summer in Saratoga With the City Ballet
description: SARATOGA, N. Y. In the beginning which was only 11 years ago, the theater would have many empty seats, and you could hardly give the tickets away. Saratoga was famous for Dutch elms, mineral springs and old memories, and Arabesque was probably the name of some horse. Now Saratoga has not exactly surrendered to ballet, but the seduction is advanced, and local people who might otherwise drive over to Albany to ponder the Mall frequently go to the Performing Arts Center instead. The other day, a matinee for The Nutcracker was sold out long before the performance, and this was striking because Nutcracker is supposed to be for Christmas, and where do you find enough people here to go to a matinee, anyway? Dance and Saratoga are now entwined.

title: The time of the hateful bugle
description: Deep in the woods and along the shore, the sounds of summer are rising: the persistent hum, slap!, and the muttered curse. Though we swap mosquito hearsay as we scratch (I hear that if you make a cross with your fingernail, the bite doesn't itch so much), there's no reason why facts shouldn't be as distracting as rumors. Here, then, are a few things to occupy your mind as you're eaten alive:

title: GARDENING
description: YUCCAS are not hardy in New Jersey, my dentist said. I nodded my head and waved one finger wildly in the air. I don't think he believed me (he is familiar with the yuccas of the Southwest), but one yucca not only thrives in gardens throughout the state but is native to New Jersey. It grows wild in the southern coastal areas of the state.

title: Management Audit Of City Purchasing Ordered by Beame
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered a management audit and general review of the Department of Purchase as part of what was described as the city's continuing study of agency management and procedures.

title: Phillips's Oiler Camp Is the Envy of N.F.L.
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., July 21 (UPI)  Sometimes, at the Houston Oilers' training camp in this quiet rural college towns a player gets off to holding five doubles in a game of FortyTwo,

title: Culinary Union Is Facing U.S. Inquiry on Finances
description: The Labor Department and the Department of Justice have agreed to begin a major investigation into the internal management and financial affairs of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees' and Bartenders' International Union, the nation's 14th largest, which has close ties to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Correction
description: The following credit was inadvertently omitted from the drawing of a Stegosaurus published in The Review of June 27, 1976: Copyright 1976 by Prof. Daniel E. Rosner.

title: Games For an Urbanite
description: Watching the skills, strengths, and endurance of the participants at the Olympic Games, it seems these men and women are from a world other than the one to which I am accustomed. I was born, raised and have always lived in New York City. Even the American athletes in these competitions seem foreign to an apartment dweller.

title: LEONARD MALLET, PLANE EXECUTIVE
description: Leonard C. Mallet, of Farmington, Conn., who headed the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group of the United Technologies Corporation from 1958 to 1967, died Friday at his home. His age was 71.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ROSE 0.5 percent in June, to 170.1 [1967=100], as transportation costs surged 0.9 percent, but food prices rose by only 0.2 percent. . . Gross national product in the second quarter grew at a rate of 4.4 percent in real terms as against a rise of 9.1 percent in the first quarter. . . The Conference Board reported that its index of consumer buying plans jumped to 105.9 [19691970=100] in May and June, from 96.7 in MarchApril, with improved prospects for homes and major appliances.

title: Being the Greatest Is Not a Handicap to Nicklaus
description: There can be little doubt that Jack Nicklaus is the greatest golfer there has ever been. I don't think I could say that about any other athlete in any other sport. You could never, for example, convince me that Joe Namath was a better quarterback than Dutch Clark, or that Johnny. Bench was a better catcher than Mickey Cochrane. But I really believe that Jack Nichlaus could have consistently defeated any golfer in the history of the sport.

title: Yemen Gives Envoy Asylum
description: SANAA, Yemen, July 24 (Reuters)The Ethiopian Ambassador to Yemen, Tasew Desta, has been granted political asylum here, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: Ring Hater Becomes Judge
description: Frank Shain was an avid boxing fan. He would rather go to a boxing match than to a movie or a baseball doubleheader or out to dinner. Eva Shain, his wife, couldn't stand boxing. She refused to go to the fights with her husband, even after he had become a boxing judge. I didn't want to watch two men beating each, other up in the ring, said Mrs. ShaM. Besides, there were never any women at the fights, only a bunch of men.

title: The Prisoners Of Ancora
description: A FEW weeks ago, a bus carrying members of a softball team of prison inmates housed at Ancora Psychiatric Hospital rolled off the hospital grounds on its way to a scheduled league game in Winslow Township.

title: French Bishop Suspended By Pope Over Ordinations
description: ROME, July 24 (Reuters) Pope Pau! has suspended a controversial French bishop from all priestly activities, the Vatican announced today.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Last weekend In Ottawa I took part in a conference regarding the relation of the critic to society, and also the responsibility, if any, of the critic toward the artist. I only caught the final session, but it did seem that one of the concerns of the conference was the relationship between the critic and what might be termed generally the cultural institution. How much should a critic view an institution simply as an event? Should he consider its aspirations and the pattern of its existence? Should he take into account its past and possible future as well as its present? Indeed, in general and simple terms, should he behave any differently toward the cultural institution than toward the isolated artistic event sponsored, hopefully for profit, by an entrepreneur? To me it is a fascinating subject, about which I have fairly strong views.

title: Success Is So Lovely The Second Time Around
description: STOCKBRIDGE, MASS. The natives are pleased, but perplexed. One does not expect to see Mary Hartman's mother walking down the main street of Stockbridge, Mass. What is Dody Goodman doing in the Berkshires?

title: TENANTS LOBBYING ON RENT CONTROL
description: Leaders of tenant groups started an action campaign yesterday to safeguard rent control, rent stabilization and tenant protection in conversion of rental buildings to cooperatives.

title: CHESS
description: When you have blown the game and your opponent is making hash out of you, drop a bomb, any bomb you can get your hands on, for a startled opponent is a vulnerable one. There is nothing like an audacious, unexpected sacrifice to rattle your opponent, causing l??m to lose concentration.

title: STAMPS
description: The culture and causes of an earlier time have inspired new issues of unusual interest from Great Britain, Canada and Nationalist China along with other stamps that attest to individuals of note and national attainments.

title: Carey Is Lukewarm to Discussions About a Beanie Reelection Campaign
description: Although it is clear that Mayor Beanie's top aidesif not the Maybr himselfare preparing for a Beame reelection campaign next year, Governor Carey hardly sounded like a New York Bea me cheerPoliticalleader when he was asked in a Notes recent interview whether the Mayor should seek reelection.

title: Amy E. Porterfield Is Bride of Furrier
description: Amy Evans Porterfield and Robert Lee Pearlstein were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Robert Tabscott in the Des Pres Presbyterian Church in Frontenac, Mo.

description: Firearson and accidentmay be booming but the fire truck manufacturers complain that they are getting burned.

title: Winnett Is Seeking Medal in Dressage
description: Both Bert de Nemethy and John Winnett were in Europe a quarter of a century ago, but they were not acquainted. De Nemethy was a Hungarian who had made his country's 1940 Olympic team, only to see the Games wiped out because of World War II. The war ended and he spent some time coaching European teams.

title: Arthur Andersen: Combat Among the Footnotes
description: CHICAGO  Spend a few hours with Harvey Kapnick and you can go away with the feeling that he may be the Lone Ranger in disguise. Or, as some of his colleagues might see it, Captain Kidd.

title: 179 Italians to Be Moved From Poison Gas Area
description: MILAN, Italy, July 24 (Reuters)Local officials decided tonight to evacuate 179 persons from an area north of Milan contaminated by a cloud of poison gas.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Indira Gandhi
description: My family, Mrs. Gandhi said in a 1967 campaign speech, is not confined to a few individuals. It consists of crores (tens of millions) of people . . . my burden is manifold because crores of my family members are povertystricken and I have to look after them. Since they belong to different castes and creeds, they sometimes fight among themselves, and I have to intervene, especially to look after the weaker members of my family, so that the stronger ones do not take advantage of them.

title: Bergen Spurs Arts Effort
description: BERGEN COUNTY has taken a step toward the expansion of its cultural facilities with the naming of the first three members of a study commission charged with drafting recommendations for a new cultural and arts center.

title: Today's Olympic Schedule
description: All teams Eestern Daylight

title: Martha Stoddard Ferguson Bride.
description: Martha Stoddard Ferguson, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. T. Lee Ferguson Jr. of Fishers Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Ritchie Elliot Buller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Buller of Mount Carmel, Conn.

title: Eastern Airlines Acts To Tie Pay to Profits
description: MIAMI, July 24 (AP) Eastern Airlines has promised its employees a wage increase of at least 8 percent next year, but the company wants its workers to tie their future paychecks to the airline's profits.

title: Miss Ender Facing Dramatic Reunion
description: MONTREAL, July 24Mrs. Rosalie Lehmann of Salina, Kan., has two tickets for the final night of the Olympic swimming competition tomorrow. She will be watching Kornelia Ender, the East German champion, with more than routine interest.

title: They Agonize, They Consult, They Enjoy the Attention
description: WASHINGTONJohn Sellie conducted a poll in a booth at the North Dakota State Fair. Sherry Martschink asked her South Carolina dentist, who happens to be the Governor, Thomas Bruinooge consulted luncheonette waitresses, bank tellers and clients of his New Jersey law firm. All to no avail.

title: MAYOR FOR COUNTY IS URGED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24Los Angeles County may get its own mayor to help unify it.

title: U.S. Airlifting Mexican Aliens Home
description: SAN DIEGO, July 24With $1.20 in pesos in his pocket, Miguel Guiterrez boarded Western Airlines champagne fiesta flight to Mexico City yesterday on the way home at the American Government's expense after a disappointingly brief 36hour visit to the United States.

title: Do Not Steal the Patents
description: WASHINGTON  Visitors have always walked pretty freely among the files of the United States Patent Office. No more.

title: The Question Of Death
description: The nation has been spared, for at least a little longer, its first legal executions since 1967. Georgia, Florida and Texas, whose death penalty statutes were declared constitutional by the Supreme Court on July 2, were each about to put a man to death, but Mr. Justice Powell stayed the executions.

title: Donald Angliss Weds Cynthia Ann Sinnott
description: Cynthia Ann Sinnott and Donald Angliss, both of Atlanta, were married yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Donan Jude, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Summer is Shakespeare season in England, not only at StratforduponAvon, but also at Chichester, at the National Theater, in Regents Park, in the West End, and at the new St. George's Theater in north London. This month one could see Robert Stephens's Othello, Alan Badel's Richard III. Albert Finney's Hamlet and Donald Sinden's Benedick in Much Ado about Nothing. In common, these actors are all too old for their roles, but age never seems to deter British actors from challenging themselves or Shakespeare and often the result is profitable.

title: PULLMAN PORTERS AWARDED BACK PAY
description: DENVER, July 24 (AP) United States District Court Judge Alfred A. Arraj awarded back pay that in some individual cases amounted to almost $2,900 to an estimated 1,500 former Pullman porters denied promotion because of their race.

title: H.E.W. Is Openng Its RuleMaking Procedure to Public From Start
description: WASHINGTON, July 24In a move to quell a growing public controversy over Federal regulations, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare is changing its procedures for writing those rules, Secretary F. David Mathews announced today.

title: Research Planned in Cave That Yielded Rare Fossils
description: CARLSBAD, N.M., July 24 (UPI)Officials at Carlsbad Caverns National Park say there are plans for research in an undeveloped cave where fossil remains of extinct animals were discovered earlier this year.

title: FIG TREE IS ISSUE IN FLORIDA FIGHT
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., July 24A gigantic fig tree here has become the center of an ecological and legal controversy that could have constitutional implications.

title: Dance: Bella Lewitzky
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 24The note first performance in the East, meaning on this side of the Mississippi, occurs frequently in connection with the work of Bella Lewitzky, a choreographer resident in Los Angeles. She is one of the talented ones who tours extensively, but the designation sets off chains of speculation about others who have neither the inclination nor the opportunity to tour.

title: A Retired Brittany Is Dual Titleholder
description: When Ch. Sequani's Dana Macduff was retired from the ring on June 10, 1973 at the LongshoreSouthport show, he went out on a high note. For the Brittany spaniel, three days short of his seventh birthday, won his 14th group, with a record of having defeated more than 6,000 dogs in the sporting breeds during the six years he was campaigned.

title: Miss Griffith Wed to W. T. Simonds
description: Pamela Evans Griffith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Evans Griffith of Bedford Hills, N. Y., was married there yesterday morning to William Trafton Simonds, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Langdon Simonds of Cambridge, Mass.

title: Tour Earnings
description: U.S.T.A. HARNESS DRIVERS (Money won by horses)

title: A Good Neighbor Policy at Home
description: RESTON, Va.Iris Lloyd, a woman who can perform wonders with a sewing machine, is a management analyst in a Government agency who lives by herself in this planned community of cluster housing 20 miles from Washington.

title: Game Halted by a Rainstorm Is the First. in N.F.L. History
description: CHICAGO, July 24For the first time in the history of the National Football League, and perhaps for the first time in the 107yearold history of the sport, a game last night was halted in progress on account of adverse weather conditionsa heavy rain squall. And then it was terminated by decree 12 minutes later because an uncontrollable crowd was cavorting on every foot of the slippery playing field and both goalposts had been torn down.

title: End of a Tradition
description: PARISThanks to the imaginative efforts of a French educator, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, the ancient competition known as the Olympic Games was revived in 1896. Coubertin reasoned that ancient Greek emphasis on physical culture helped produce the vigor of the Hellenic Golden Age.

title: Chart of Brooklyn Handicap
description: EIGHTHThe Brooklyn Handicap, $100,000 added, 3YO and up, 1m. Start scod, won ridden out. Off, 5:27. Winner, b.g., 6, by Forli Lady Golconda, by Hasty Road. Trainer, F. Y. Whiteley Jr. Value to winner, $67,860; second, $24,882; third, $13,372; fourth, $6,786, Times22 4/5; 46 4/5; 1:11 1/5; 1:36 2/5; 2:01 1/5.

title: Kassandra and The Wolf
description: One day, my Mother... brought me a lovely doll as a present. She was big, and she had yellow strings instead of hair.

title: Everybody Is Climbing Their Family Tree
description: Genealogythe study of one's ancestral family treehas become an increasingly popular leisure time activity in recent years. Some people have speculated that the celebration of the Bicentennial has prompted more Americans to wonder about their pasts, and about who their great, great grandparents were, or what their ancestors were doing 200 years ago.

title: Marijuana Seizures Rise
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI)Marijuana seizures in Los Angeles County increased 768 per cent during the first six months of California's marijuana decriminalization law, according to the authorities. Sheriff Peter Pitchess, a major opponent of the ew law, said the midyear report showed that he was right when he warned that the measure would creat a climate for illicit drug dealers.

title: Scientists to Aid Grizzlies
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Government scientists are preparing to designate parts of Idaho, Montana, Washington and Wyoming as essential to the survival of grizzly bears in the lower 48 states. Grizzlies are officially listed as a threatened species.

title: Ford Drives for FirstBallot Victory
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) President Ford feels the delegate count is moving exactly as he expected it to toward a firstballot victory at the Republican National Convention next month, his spokesman said today.

title: Miss Prudden, Henry Clark 3d, Bank Aide, Wed
description: Pamela Prudden, daughter of Dr. John F. Prudden of Upper Nyack, N. Y., and Mrs. Louis R. Seybold of Omaha, was married yesterday afternoon to Henry Austin Clark 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Jr. of Glen Cove and Southampton, L. I.

title: Nina Rothschild Married On L.I. to John D. Larkin
description: Nina Elisabeth Rothschild, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Rothschild Jr. of Laurel Hollow, LI., was married there last evening to John David Larkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Larkin of Quincy, Mass. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple EmanuEl in New York performed the ceremony at the Rothschild home.

title: PEOPLE
description: JUDITH M. OWENS of Ocean Township, the president of the New Jersey Education Association, was presented the 1976 achievement award of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Womens Clubs in Atlanta yesterday. The award was made Mrs. Owens for her activity in education and for her role in promoting the rights of minority groups. Mrs. Owens, a fourthgrade teacher in Asbury Park, comes from a family of teachers. Both of her parents taught in Maryland.

title: TollFree Access to Sports Complex
description: PART of the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike will be rollfree for fans who drive from the George Washington Bridge to see football games at the new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands when it opens in a few weeks.

title: How Jack Weston Makes Human A Tragicomic Schlemiel
description: The scene is a luxury suite in the Beverly Hills Motel. The suite's occupant, a Philadelphia businessman who is in California to attend a nephew's bar mitzvah, awakens after a night on the town to find a girl in his beda stuporously drunken prostitute presented to him as a surprise gift by his brother. Horrified, the hungover, overweight philanderer realizes he must dispose of his unconscious bedmate before his wife's imminent arrival. Looking like a baby hippo suffering a slowmotion coronary, he stumbles around the room in his underwear, jowls quivering and wispy gray hair flying as he tries to jam the girl under the covers, lips pursing and eyes popping as he considers dragging her into a closet or depositing her in the hallway. It is his first indiscretion in 15 years of marriage  a marriage which may be ended at any moment. Oh God!, he bleats, pudgy hands kneading his belly, beady eyes rolling beneath a sweat  beaded Oh God!

title: JETHRO TULL BAND AT SHEA STADIUM
description: Shea Stadium reverberated) to the sound of rock music again Friday evening, but it reverberated soggily. While three groups from England performed under a gigantic umbrella held aloft by two cranes. 40,000 to 50,000 fans sat in the bleachers under ponchos and regularsize umbrellas. There were dry periods, but rain fell again, and again throughout the 4hour show.

title: A British Woman Married 50 Times To Illegal Aliens
description: LONDON, July 24 (AP)Scotland Yard is looking for a slim blond woman who married for money, not loveat least 50 times. All of her bridegrooms were illegal immigrants who thought that marriage would enable them to stay in Britain.

title: Forego Repeats in Stakes; Foolish Pleasure Is Third
description: Martha F. Gerry's Forego captured the 88th Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday to round out a string of three victories in the stakes that was achieved only once beforeby Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Discovery four decades ago.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Leroy Walker, United States Olympic track team coach, on the African athletes who had to withdraw: My heart bleeds for them . . . they had worked so hard and had such great expectations for these games.

title: Amin Halts Supply Of Power to Kenya, Threatens Attack
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 24 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda today cut electricity supplies to Kenya and threatened to attack it unless the Kenyans lifted their economic blockade and allowed petroleum supplies through.

title: 5 Seized on Ferryboat For Robbing S.I. Man
description: Five men suspected of holding up a Staten Island grocer then fleeing aboard a ferry boat were seized by the police Friday night when the craft arrived at its Manhattan terminal.

title: The Arabs In Israel
description: On March 30 of this year, savage rioting erupted in several Arab towns in the Galilee region of Israel. Thousands of Arab teenagers blockaded roads and stoned military vehicles. Israeli soldiers responded with firearms. When it was all over seven Israeli Arabs were dead, with scores on both sides injured. It was the worst outbreak of communal violence in Israel's history. Coming on the heels of similar demonstrations by Palestinian Arabs on the occupied West Bank it created shock waves throughout an already beleaguered country. Having previously convinced themselves that their Arabs had been reconciled to the Jewish state, many Israelis were now wondering whether there was a new Palestinian nationalist time bomb within their own borders.

title: Teachers And Bias
description: THE EDUCATIONAL problems in a segregated school system are not solved automatically when students are bused to achieve desired racial or ethnic balances. Teaching techniques, curiculums and textbooks that did the job in a homogeneous settingwhere all the students have the same basic backgroundoften fail to meet the needs of the new mixed student populations.

title: The Nation
description: The candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination, Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan, have together produced a mathematical impossibility: both contenders now claim more than a majority of the delegates to the nominating convention. By the unofficial estimate of The New York Times, neither man has a majority, although President Ford is close to one.

title: Naber Collects 4th Swim Gold Medal: U.S. Shut Out in 100 Dash, ShotPut
description: MONTREAL, July 24 The world's fastest human is not Valery Borzov of the Soviet Union. Nor Don Quarrie of Jamaica. Nor Harvey Glance of Phenix City, Ala.

title: Costly Rulings for Nassau
description: AN $80,000 home in Great Neck and a $40,000 home in Long Beach are both assessed at $12,000. The owner of a $50,000 business in Mineola pays taxes on the basis of a $14,000 assessment, while the owner of a $50,000 home in the same village is assessed at $8.500.

title: Elizabeth Hall To Wed Aug. 14
description: Elizabeth Poindexter Hall, who received a master's degree in May from the University of Virginia, and Dr. William Hugh Baugher of Charlottesville, Va., an orthopedic resident at the University of Virginia Hospital, will be married Aug. 14 in the Virginia Theological Seminary Chapel at Alexandria.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Gas Lights Called Indefensible Waste

title: Road Steps Up Life in a Berlin Suburb
description: WEST BERLIN, July 24For Editha Fischer and her neighbors, life has changed drastically in the four years since the tiny community of Steinstcken was put on the map as an integral part of West Berlin.

title: Brendan Behan: A Remembrance
description: Brendan Behan's diabetes became evident during a lunch at the Dublin pub Mooney's in 1956. His nocturnal thirst had become so severe that he had started to seek relief by drinking watera solution he regarded as entirely unnatural and therefore, pathologic. Even as he spoke, his breath was loaded with acetone.

title: Nancy Hogan Wed in Suburb
description: Nancy Hogan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Hogan of Riverside, Conn., and Alfred R. Perna Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Perna, also of Riverside, were married there yesterday in St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church. Bishop Andrew J. McDonald of Little Rock, Ark., officiated, and the Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor, pastor of St. Catherine's, was concelebrant.

title: Taiwan Wins in Baseball
description: AGANA, Guam, July 24 (AP)Taiwan, the fourtime world champion, won the opener of the Far East Senior Little League baseball tournament today, defeating Guam, 53. The winner of the threegame series advances to the Senior World Series in Gary, Ind.

title: Plots and Counterplots
description: Most American women grow up with one of two attitudes about Louisa May Alcott. Those who remain loyal to their childhood affection for her novels may already have become acquainted with her adult Gothic potboilers, writter by A.M. Barnard or Anon or ?? ?? income for the Alcotts just as Jt.) March in Little Women rashly took a plunge in the frothy sea of sensational literature to feed the Marches. The first volume of these stories appeared last year as Behind a Mask. The present volume, Plots and Counterplots, reprints two more novellas and three stories. Each of the two collections has an introduction by Madeleine Stern, who first dug them out of popular 19thcentury periodicals.

title: Pro Transactions BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL)  Traded Earl Williams, catcher, to Montreal for future considerations.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: In a Life of Firsts, She Has Few Regrets
description: She was painted six times by Rouault and three times by Dufy; she photographed Monet, Maillol, Pirandello, Prokofiev, SaintExupry; a bust of her wearing an Agns hat is in the Prado in Madrid; she founded the first American illustrated press service in Europe; she was the first foreign correspondent to capture the coming of the RussoFinnish War; her pictures of children uprooted by the Nazi invasions of Europe broke Franklin Roosevelt's heart and made Winston Churchill lift the Atlantic Blockade so that Red Cross ships with $4,000,000 worth of help could reach them.

title: PARAPLEGIC FREED IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: A 30yearold paraplegic who pleaded guilty to a substantial narcotics charge has received a suspended sentence from a Fedral judge who said that the law should not be remorseless, implacable and without mercy.

title: The Kill Price
description: As a symbol for Hell, you could do worse than imagine a hot summer night in New York with your best friend dying of lung cancer in his West Side apartment, his young wife trying to brave it all but going to pieces, his allegedly bisexual brotherinlaw from a past marriage showing up after many years to try to buy a movie option on one of the dying man's novels, and a middleaged actress on TV commercials who is an old lover of the dying man and has just spent the night with the brotherinlaw. Add to this, talk of the Watergate hearings and literary chitchat ranging from references to Julian Sorel, don't care at all: they have that huge garden to play in.

title: Issues, Not Laws
description: With the next election barely three months away, Congress returned to work last week for what is likely to be little more than a moppingup session.

title: The World/Continued
description: JOHANNESBURGA group of 40 South African businessmen recently flew from Johannesburg to Maputo, capital of Mozambique, to discuss ways of improving the efficiency of freight handling in the port of Maputo. The businessmen, as quoted in a Johannesburg newspaper, returned full of praise for the cooperative approach of the Mozambican authorities, who were reported to have agreed to steps that will ease the port and rail congestion that has been bottling up nearly a quarter of South Africa's exports.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: Ecumenical Rite Held For 11 Slain Israelis
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, July 25While world attention was focused on the Olympic Games in Montreal, community residents and religious leaders gathered today to memorialize the 11 Israeli athletes who died as a result of a terrorist attack on the Olympic compound in Munich. West Germany, Sept. 5, 1972.

title: A NEW CEASEFIRE IN LEBANON FAILS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25A new ceasefire agreement failed to take effect today when an Arab peacekeeping force came under heavy attack as it tried to expand a neutral zone between rightwing Christian and leftist Moslem forces.

title: Books of The Times
description: Given Walden, Jack London, and Joseph Wood Krutch, is there anything left to say about man's relationship to the other animals? Bear, the latest work of fiction by the talented Canadian writer Marian Engel, begins as a brisk adventure in selfexploitation. Lou, a molelike young woman who works as an archivist for a Toronto historical institute, is assigned to research a valuable island estate that has just been willed to the institute. As she drives north toward the island, she begins to feel liberated, to have an odd sense of being reborn. (For some time things had been going badly for her . . . as if life in general had a grudge against her. Things persisted in turning gray. Although at first she had revelled in the erudite seclusion of her job, in the protection against the vulgarities of the world it offered, after five years she now felt that in some way it had aged her disproportionately, that she was as old as the yellowed papers she spent her days unfolding.) She finds on the island estate the promise of relaxation, good reading,, a healthy outofdoors life and a chance to unwind. The only possible drawback to the setup is that with the estate comes a bear, who is chained to a shed out back of the kitchen. (Lou is not especially fond of animals.

title: Today's Olympic Schedule
description: TRACK AND FIELD10 A.M., men's 110meter hurdles; men's hammer throw qualifying; women's high jump qualifying; 10:30 A.M., women's long jump, pentathlon; 11 A.M., men's 400meter heats; 11:45 A.M., men's 110meter hurdles, second round; 2:30 P.M., men's javelin throw final; 2:45 P.M., men's 200meter semifinals; 3:15 P.M., men's 400 meters, second round; 3:45 P.M., women's 200 meters, second round; 4:20 P.M., women's 400 meters, second round; 4:50 P.M., men's 200 meters, pentathlon; 6:20 P.M., women's 800meter final.

title: Sue Berning Victor, Ends Her Drought
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 25 (AP)Susie Kerning, wearing new contact lenses, birdied the final hole for the third straight day, closed with a par 72 and won the $50,000 Lady Keystone open golf tournament today by three strokes.

title: Social Changes Wrought by the Dutch Are Sweeping, if Not Revolutionary
description: THE HAGUE, July 19 There are no poor people in the country any more, and really no very rich, a radical young editor said recently. The intellectuals are looking for the last taboo. It's all too dull. Here, the new left is in the Government and nothing has changed.

title: A Turkish Chief Visits U.S.
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 25 (AP)  Bulent Ecevit, Turkey's opposition leader and a former prime minister, flew to the United States today for an eightday visit.

title: Booting Silky Home
description: WASHINGTONSilky Sullivan was my favorite horse. He never won the Derby, or took home the kind of money Secretariat did, but he is remembered by racing fans for a certain exciting quality.

title: Hints of Unease And Indiscipline Appear in China
description: PEKING, July 25A decline in public discipline. Growing tension. A sense of unease.

title: Local Talent Enlivens Old Newark
description: NEWARK, July 25  The people attending a free cultural festival in Barringer High School here today not only supported a worthy cause, but also, clapping their hands to the jazz music and swaying along with the Africanstyle dancers, had a good time.

title: Advertising
description: Anyone who has had dealing with Robert L. EdgeII knows he is a publisher who does things with flair. So it is to be expected that, as president of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications, he will not overlook his organization's becoming a major force in the healthcare publishing field.

title: Shelby V. Timberlake, Dies; National Biscuit Official, 80
description: Shelby V. Timberlake, retired general sales manager of the National Biscuit Company, died Saturday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 1 Wilton Road, Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Title for Taiwan Nine
description: AGANA, Guam, July 25 (UPI)  Taiwan rallied for seven runs in the sixth inning today and beat Guam, 125, for the Senior Little League Far East championship.

title: Three Escape From Center For Addicts in Brooklyn
description: Three addicts escaped from a state rehabilitation center in the Fort Green section of Brooklyn last night by lowering themselves down the building's facade on a makeshift rope of bedsheets, the police reported.

title: White House Shooting
description: A man who scaled the White House fence was wounded by a guard last night when he failed to heed an order to halt. Page 14.

title: Hints of Unease And Indiscipline Appear in China
description: PEKING, July 25  A decline in public discipline. Growing tension. A sense of unease.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: R.O.T.C. Student Killed
description: FORT LEWIS, Wash., July 25 (AP)A 21yearold student who was in the Reserve Officer Training Corps died after he struck his head during war games here, a military spokesman said. Steven K. Merritt, of Marengo, Iowa, died Saturday night during escape and invasion maneuvers, according to Rill Wood, the Fort Lewis publicinformation officer. Mr. Merritt was a student at Iowa State University.

title: Some Passengers Aboard QE2. Complain of Confusion in Fire
description: LONDON, July 25 (AP)Passengers disembarked today from the firedamaged ocean liner Queen Elizabeth 2, some of them complaining angrily about confusion on board and an offer of compensation by Cunard Lines for the aborted cruise from England to New York.

title: Hyman Lumer, 67; Edited U.S. Communist Periodical
description: Hyman Lumer, editor of Political Affairs, the theoretical organ of the Communist Party in the United States, died of a heart attack Wednesday while vacationing in Bulgaria, according to the party's headquarters in New York City. He was 67 years old and livad at 125 Ashland Place in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn.

title: Billie Asch, 65, an Olympian And Beauty Winner in 1932
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 25 (UPI)Billie Asch, who won an Olympic gold medal in 1932 and later that year was named Miss California, died last Friday. She was 65 years old.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We are in receipt of a highly amusing criticism of our use of the English language.

title: Israeli Is Killed in Explosion In West Bank Refugee Camp
description: TEL AVIV, July 25 (AP)An explosion believed set by Arab guerrillas killed an Israeli soldier today in a Palestinian retugee camp in the occupied West Bank, a military spokesman said.

title: Boy, 17, Wins Pentathlon
description: Odis Sanders, a 17yearold from the Freeport (L.I.) Track Club, scored 356 points and won the fifth New York Road Runners Club track pentathlon at St. John's University yesterday. The runnerup was 31yearold Frank Handleman of the Central Park Track Club.

title: 8 Honored for Aviation
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 25 (UPI)  Gen. Nathan F. Twining, U.S.A.F., retired, and Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut, were among eight persons, seven living, who were enshrined into the Aviation Hall of Fame last night, increasing the membership to 69. General Twining was the first Air Force member to he the nation's Joint Chief of Staff. Mr. Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, was the first American to orbit the earth. Honored posthumously was Sanford Alexander Moss (18711946), a scientist and engineer.

title: Opera: Die Walkure
description: BAYREUTH, West Germany, July 25The Patrice Chereau Ring cycleone hesitates to say the Wagner Ring cyclecontinued tonight with Die Walkilre,  the second of the four operas. One is beginning to get an idea of what Mr. Chereau is driving at. Perhaps he has been looking into George  Bernard Shaw's Perfect Wagnerite.

title: Night Journey
description: LONDON, July 25The audience in the Royal Opera House stood to watch and applaud as Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, glitteringly regal in coronet and diamonds, took her seat in the center box. Then a slim angular woman in a tubular green dress slipped onto the stage, and there was a roar of welcome for the longreigning symbol of American modern dance.

title: Educational Reforms Under Fire
description: AMHERST, Mass.Liberal educators are in retreat. The reform movement that gathered force in the 1960's excited the public imagination and captured the heights of the policymaking system. It is now in shambles. Like unfit mutations in a period of famine, the liberal innovations are falling prey to the Darwinian test of economic survival. Public support of education is on the wane: Schoolbond issues are rejected by the voters about twice as frequently nowadays as during the late 1960's.

title: A Chorus Line Is Smashing in London
description: LONDON, July 25First they said it's just a New York show and it would never make it in California, said the creator of A Chorus Line, Michael Bennett. Audiences loved it in California, and then people said it's too American, it'll never make it in London.

title: Walter Hedden, 78, ExOfficial Of Port of New York Authority
description: Walter P. Hedden, director of port development for the Port of New York Authority from 1942 to 1953 and an internationally known consultant in transportation circles, died Saturday at Hartford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Westport Conn.

title: 15 of 21 TV Repairmen in Study Distorted Prices for Services
description: A high proportion of television repairmen across New York City are either highly dishonest or extraordinarily incompetent, Consumer Affairs; Commissioner Elinor Guggenheimer said yesterday.

title: SPANISH PRELATE IN AMNESTY PLEA
description: MADRID, July 25 (UPI)A Roman Catholic archbishop formally asked King Juan Carlos today to make a promised political amnesty generous enough tO serve as a starting point for reconciliation in postFranco Spain.

title: WILLIAM PALITZ
description: William Palitz, a lawyer with the firm of Abraham, Koenig & Silver, died of cancer Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 2 Horatio Street in Greenwich Village.
