description: (For week ended July 23, 1976)

title: 6 Film Studio's Vie Over Entebbe Raid
description: At least six American film makers are planning movies on the spectacular Israeli commando rescue of hostages at Entebbe Airport near Kampala, Uganda, on July 3, and a fierce competition has developed among the producers for Israeli Government cooperation and endorsement.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 25According to state tax estimates and to calculations made by the State Chamber of Commerce the 7.5 million residents of New Jersey will be paying $23.435 billion in taxes this fiscal year.

title: Carterites Introduce the NonFundRaising Social
description: WAINSCOTT, L.I., July 25 This is the kind of group where you would have loved to have fundraising.

title: Parents Day: Joy and Tears Mark Reunion at a Summer Camp
description: JAVA CENTER, N.Y., July 25Octavia Black runs her summer camp here with oldfashioned ways and a sense that things are not as they were. She is 73 years old. I'm getting old, she says. I am old.

title: About New York
description: At the Benson Plaza, which is described as Brooklyn's largest and most elegant ballroom, some 400 men and women gathered on Saturday night.

title: Yanks Win on Homer in 9th
description: The Yankees' lateinning lightning struck out of a flawless blue sky yesterday at Yankee Stadium as Chris Chambliss hit a threerun homer with two out in the ninth to give New York a 65 victory over the helpless Boston Red Sox.

title: Brazilians Assail Auto Industry
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  With oil imports soaring and traffic congestion growing, Brazilians are turning a critical eye on the automobile industryonce the most glamorous part of their country's economic miracle.

title: The Dance
description: The Rudolf Nureyev marethon continues. Not only has be danced every night with the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House this week, but on Saturday he also tossed off two performances of The Sleeping Beauty in one day. At the matinee, Vanessa Harwood made her first appearance of the season as his Princess Aurora while Veronica Tennant did the same Lin the evening.

title: Olympic Sidelights
description: MONTREAL, July 25Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, and his brother, Prince Edward, joined Queen Elizabeth, Prince Philip, Princess Anne and Prince Andrew at the Olympic Games this weekend, setting a mark of a sort. This is believed to be the first time the United Kingdom has been without the Queen and all her immediate family at once.

title: Guided Tours on a Sunny Day Attract Thousands
description: They saw the East Side mansions and the West Side's leafy parks, they went uptown into Harlem, they went downtown past the Metropolitan Museum.

title: Oil Tanker in Collision
description: SINGAPORE, July 25 (AP)A Soviet freighter collided with a Philippine oil tanker today in the Strait of Malacca about 14 miles from Singapore, a salvage company source said. No one was hurt, but two tanks of the 100,748ton Diego Silang were leaking, the source said.

title: Winifred White, 24, Dies; Design Student at Harvard
description: Winifred George White, a student of landscape architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, died of leukemia yesterday in Boston. She was 24 years old.

title: No. Am. Soccer League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Other Highlights
description: BOXINGSugar Ray Leonard of Palmer Park, Md., and Clint Jackson of Nashville, advanced to the quarterfinals and Chuck Walker of Mesa, Ariz., was eliminated on a split decision.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Hoboken man was stabbed to death and a woman was slashed in a dispute with another man, who shared their apartment, the police reported. The police said Fleming Weller Jr., 50 years old, was pronounced dead of a stab wound near the heart shortly after arrival at St. Mary's Hospital at about 4 A.M. He and Eunice Clester Moore had been attacked with an 11inch kitchen knife in a dispute with James E. Tillman, 55, about 3:30 A.M. in the topfloor apartment the three shared at 107 Jackson Street, the police said.

title: A Travesty of Tax Reform
description: In an effort to widen his business support and to still worriesinspired partly by some populist rhetoric in his speech accepting the Democratic nominationthat he might be antibusiness, Jimmy Carter returned to New York last week to break bread with a group of industrial and financial leaders. He told them that his goal had never been for Government to dominate business and that he would propose no substantative changes in the tax laws until at least a full year of very careful analysis.

title: Horowitz to Teach
description: Vladimir Horowitz will join the faculty of the Mannes College of Music this fall, and without fee, he will teach specially chosen students. It is the pianist's first formal association with a music conservatory. Page 30.

title: Rheingold Begins Using Telephone as a Medium
description: Part of Rheingold's $3 million advertising program is going into telephones.

title: ARAB PACT TO OUST QADDAFI REPORTED
description: Egypt and the Sudan, with financial backing from Saudi Arabia, have agreed to try to oust Libya's bead of state, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, Newsweek reports in its current issue.

title: Screen: A Winning 'Cousin, Cousine':New French Comedy Is Tenant at Paris Tale of Two Families Possesses a Heart
description: Ludovic (Victor Lanoux), a dance instructor who has also been a mushroom specialist and a horn player in a jazz band, has been married for eight years to Karine (Marie-France Pisier), a pretty, perpetually morose young woman who finds solace in sleep cures and hypnotherapy.Marthe (Marie-Christine Barrault), a radiant blonde in her early 30's has been married for 11 years to Pascal (Guy Marchand), a classic French bourgeois Casanova. He conquers women (bus drivers, receptionists, sales clerks, family guidance counselors) not because he's especially drawn to them, but because something will have been left unproven if he doesn't.Jean-Charles Tacchella's completely approving new French comedy, "Cousin, Cousine," which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, is the story of the growth of the love between Ludovic and Marthe, who are first thrown together at a wedding when Pascal, who can't stop himself, and Karine, who is bored, go off for a quick assignation in the bushes. Ludovic accepts his wife's behavior without panic. Marthe locks up her feeling.Some weeks later, long after Pascal and Karine have forgotten their brief affair, Ludovic and Marthe meet again at a family funeral. On the way to the cemetery, Ludovic and Marthe establish their first intimacy. While the new widow sits in the front of the bus weeping and the other members of the funeral party stifle yawns, Ludovic and Marthe sit together in the rear, humming cheerfully and making tentative gestures toward an understanding that will eventually split their two marriages."Cousin, Cousine," which I believe is the first film by Mr. Tacchella to be released in this country, and which was awarded the Prix Delluc in France, is an exceptionally winning, wittily detailed comedy that is as much about family relationships as it is about love.Both Marthe and Ludovic belong to large, affectionate families that are infinitely patient and flexible in coping with temporary lapses in behavior, be it a loss of temper, a fit of falling-down drunkenness or blatant adultery.At first Ludovic and Marthe meet in secret, being amused by the thought that although their relationship is platonic, no one would believe it. Their mates become worried. Pascal, for whom infidelity is serious self-expression, makes a big point in renouncing all his mistresses. When he breaks with the bus driver, she insults him in the worst way she knowsshe makes him get off the bus between designated stops. Karine firmly decides that she will again be amusing.But it's too late, and since everyone believes them to be lovers already, Ludovic and Marthe oblige.In a rather startling way, no one seems to get seriously hurt in this film, even though there are deaths and profound disappointments, not because Mr. Tacchella takes a superficially rosy view of things, but because, with the help of his actors, he creates a group of characters who appear either to have inner resources or, like Karine, to be too self-absorbed to feel anything too deeply.Miss Barrault, who is the niece of Jean-Louis; Miss Pisier, Mr. Lanoux and Mr. Marchand are very good company, especially when they are misbehaving. "Cousin, Cousine" possesses a heart that is both light and generous.

title: Some New York Delegates Making Demands on Ford
description: The demand for special considerations from the Ford Administration by New York delegates to the Republican National Convention appears to be increasing despite a Presidential ban last week on such potential votetrading.

title: Ford Plays a Round of Golf At Congressional Club
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) President Ford joined the golfer Lee Elder today to try out the Congressional Country Club course in nearby Bethesda, Md., which will be the site of the 58th Professional Golfers Association championship tournament Aug. 915.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDY PSYCHIC EVIDENCE
description: MIAMI, July 25Physicists, engineers and an anthropologist joined parapsychologists here this weekend in proclaiming psychics and psychic phenomena valid and promising subjects for serious scientific inquiry that would possibly result in major scientific breakthroughs in medicine and space travel.

title: Forced Merger of Schools in Morris Is Working Well
description: MORRISTOWN, July 25A forced merger of two school systems that turned out to be a productive union will marks its sixth anniversary with an even brighter outlook in September.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: IRWIN A. ROCKMAN
description: Irwin A. Rockman, a partner in the Rockland County Law firm of Zoldan, Rogers, Ferraro, Cody & Rockman, died Saturday of a pulmonary ailment at the National Heart and Lung Institute in Bethesda. Md. He was 31 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.

title: Amin Says Gasoline Is Nearly Depleted And Hints Action
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 25 CAP)  President Idi Amin of Uganda said today that his country had only enough gasoline to operate emergency vehicles for five more days. He spoke of a fight for survival against what he said was an economic blockade by neighborine Kenya.

title: AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JULY 26, 1976

title: V.D. FOUND RISING IN: HOMOSEXUALS
description: disease has rissen dramatically

title: Nuns' Group Seeks to Make Religious More Concerned About Social Justice
description: Awaiting the start of a reflective session with five other nuns seated on chairs in a circle, Sister Maureen Roach shrugged, reached into her bag and began handing out leaflets opposing the B1 bomber.

title: Book About Raid Says 50 Israeli Agents Paved Way in Kenya
description: Three days before Israeli commandos raided the Entebbe airport in Uganda to rescue 103 hostages, 50 Israeli agents flew to neighboring Kenya to assure that the Nairobi airport could be used by the raiders to refuel their planes on the way home, according to a book published today.

title: Derailed Tanker Leaks Gas
description: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., July 25 (AP)A skinirritating gas escaped from an overturned railway tanker sometime last night and spread through parts of this town before firefighters stopped the leak. Fire Chief Bob Gavagnie said that sufficient direct exposure to the gas could cause skin burns, but he said there were no reported injuries. The tanker was part of a 17car train that derailed yesterday.

title: All Members but One Quit Howe's Paid Campaign Staff
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 25 (AP)All but one of Representative Allan T. Howe's paid campaign staff members resigned during the weekend following Mr. Howe's misdemeanor conviction for soliciting sex for money.

title: Phillies Beat Pirates, 137; schmidt Hits 26th Homer
description: Mike Schmidt's 26th home run of the season and his four runs batted in helped the Philadelphia Phillies outslug the Pittsburgh Pirates, 137, yesterday and increase their lead to 13 games over the secondplace Pirates in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: New York City Cuts Back Police RadioCar Patrols
description: Radio car patrols, which the Police Department calls its No. 1 crimefighting priority, have been quietly reduced throughout the city during the last year in the wake of budget and personnel cuts.

title: MilkPrice Order Making Some Farmers AntiFord
description: Charles N. Dodd is a milk jugger in Corry, Pa., and was long counted a Ford delegate to the Republican National Convention. But when he visits the White House next week, with the rest of the Pennsylvania delegation, Mr. Dodd will bring petitions with 100.000 signatures on them to explain why under no conditions would I vote for President Ford. I am definitely going to be for Reagan even though I don't agree with all his positions.

title: INVESTORS AWAIT REFUNDING MOVE
description: The main event in the credit markets this week will be the Treasury's announcementdue late Wednesdayof plans for its August refunding operation. A total of $4.5 billion of Gov emment obligations in public hands will mature next month and the big question is this: How much new money will the Treasury raise?

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed In order of cost positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Foreign Industries Expanding In U.S.
description: GREENVILLE. S. C., July 23  The Michelin Tire Corporation, a French company famous for its radial tires, has just begun production at a new plant here. Another Michelin factory, only slightly older, is down the road in Anderson, ground is about to be broken for a third in nearby Spartanburg, and the company plans to build still a fourth somewhere in the area.

title: Oil Burner Takes Pace and $118,125
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 25Stanley Dancer's selling mistake proved a windfall today for Bill Brooks, who nervously watched the feature pace from the rail at Monticello Raceway, chewing on a bigblackcigar.

title: U.S. Women Swimmers Win First Gold in Relay, Last Event; Moses Sets World Record in Hurdles; Wilkins Takes Discus
description: MONTREAL, July 25The United States struck gold today in Olympic track. Silver and bronze too. The total was two gold medals, one silver and two bronze.

title: Mets Lose on a Misplay by Kranepool
description: MONTREAL, July 25  A line drive that was misjudged by Ed Kranepool in right field in the ninth inning today proved costly to the Mets. The Montreal Expos converted it into the run that gave them a 21 victory.

title: Rich Coast Race To Fleet Dragoon
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 25 (AP)Fleet Dragoon won the $160,750 Hollywood juvenile championship today, leaving the favored Super Joy to finish out of the money in the sixfurlong battle among 2yearold colts and geldings.

title: HENRY K. BEECHER, DOCTOR IN BOSTON
description: Dr. Henry K. Beecher, a physician who attained world eminence in making anesthesia more scientific, and who won further distinction in advocating ethical limits on medical research, died yesterday at his home in Boston. He was 72 years old.

title: VIKING SOIL SCOOP BACK IN CONDITION TO TAKE SAMPLES
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 25Viking 1's robot arm, which had balked in an earlier test, was flexed today and found to be ready and able to begin picking up Martian soil samples Wednesday.

title: GENEVIEVE MOLLESON
description: Genevieve Istel Molleson, the wife of John D. Molleson, a former reporter on The New York HeraldTribune, died yesterday at her summer home. Shinnecock Hills in Southamp ton, L.I., after a long illness. She was 53 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State's Welfare Inspector General called for the prosecution of a Bronx woman who had allegedly collected nearly $10,000 in fraudulent welfare payments for being unemployed, while she was actually working for the City Welfare Department. The inspector, Rican V. Horan, without disclosing the name of the 35yearold woman, said he had turned the matter over to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx for criminal prosecution.

title: Woods, Wealthy Kidnap Suspect, Described as a Loner and a Loser
description: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., July 25  Frederick Newhall Woods 4th, subject of a nationwide hunt as the key suspect in the bizarre kidnapping of 26 school children near Chowchilla, Calif., was the child of wealth and privilege, but one who was beset by selfimposed loneliness, by the fear that he did not measure up to his father's expectations and by flashes of anger that caused him more than once to threaten with a shotgun those he felt sought to trespass on what was his.

title: Blunt, Evenly Matched Adversaries Lead Prosecution and Defense in Harris Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25Inside the courtroom where Emily and William Harris are facing charges that could send them to prison for life, Leonard I. Weinglass, the chief defense attorney, is scowling and shouting over the prosecutor's response to charges of possible jury tampering.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON, July 25In January 1975 the Council on Wage and Price Stability began a study of the aluminum industry as part of a wider examination of what the agency's former director, Albert Rees, called pricing in concentrated industries.

title: School Acts to Name Dean
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 25 (AP)University of Massachusets officials said they would recommend tomorrow the appointment of Mario D. Fantini, dean of the State University of New York's School of Education at New Paltz, to head the University of Massachusetts School of Education. The school has been without a permanent head since former Dean Dwight W. Allen resigned last year after criticism that Federal funds had been misused at the school.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Siete Canciones Populares Espanolas, Falla; Violin Sonata No. 2, Handel; Cello Concerto in A, Tartini; Fantasia in F minor. Chopin; Divertimento in B. Mozart.

title: Australian Leader in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)  Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia arrived here today for a fourday visit that includes talks with President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger on security issues.

title: Man Killed at White House; Scaled Fence and Went On
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A man carrying a threefoot metal pipe was fatally shot tonight by a White House security guard, the Secret Service said, after he had clambered over the black iron fence surrounding the Executive Mansion and moved across the lawn despite warnings from guards to halt.

title: Oliver Triumphs In Formula 5000
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 25 (AP)Jackie Oliver started from 14th place, but ended in the winner's circle, driving his ShadowDodge at an average speed of 109.65 miles per hour to win the 100mile, Formula 5000 Road America race today.

title: Blunt U.S. Envoy Nettles Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 25 The case of a United States citizen who was jailed by Yugoslavia for nearly a year has drawn attention to divisions among American policymakers and especially to Ambassador Laurence H. Silberman. By enunciating a viewpoint that has been growing among Americans as Yugoslav policies have turned increasingly against the United States, the Ambassador has angered both the authorities here and the Eastern European section of the State Department.

title: Leonard, Jackson Advance in Boxing
description: MONTREAL, July 25 (AP) Sugar Ray Leonard danced his way into the quarterfinals tonight after his American teammate, Clint Jackson, took a much shorter routea onepunch, firstround knockout in Olympic boxing.

title: Mammography Puzzle: Benefits Versus Risks
description: After Betty Ford and Happy Rockefeller were treated for breast cancer in 1974, thousands of women throughout the country flocked to, screening centers and radiologists' offices to have their breasts examined by an Xray technique called mammography, which, they were told, could find breast cancers as small as an o on this page. They were also told the cancers were curable in 85 to 95 percent of case.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: JAMES COTTON BAND IN ELECTRIC BLUES
description: Electric blues, a supercharged music that first came out of the deep South and Chicago during the 1940's, has not been very viable commercially since gospelderived soul music developed during thel succeeding decade. Few bluesmen have been able to adapt to newer styles without sacrificing the essence of their music, but James Cotton, whose band appeared at the Bottom1 Line this weekend, is an exception.

title: Pate Golf Victor
description: Jerry Pate, the golf, rookie who won the United States Open, triumphed in the Canadian open yesterday in Windsor, Ontario. He finished with a final round of 63, a course record, and beat Jack Nicklaus by four strokes. Details on Page 18.

title: Personal Finance: Bank Box Safer With Check List
description: At a burglary last week of a large bank's safe deposit boxes in France, more than $10 million worth of valuables was stolen. What would happen to a, customer of an American bank if his locked box in a bank vault was broken into and its contents stolen?

title: Pate Cards 63 to Win By 4 Shots
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, July 25 (UPI)  Jerry Pate, the winner of the United States Open golf tournament, added the Canadian open to his victory list today. He came from two strokes behind after three rounds to win with a courserecord 63 today and a 72hole total of 267.

title: 1977 Mayoral Issues
description: There are issues to be faced in New York City's 1977 mayoral election. It is not too early to spell out some of them.

title: MISSISSIPPI SLATE DRAYS ENDORSING UNTIL G.O.P. MEETS
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 25The Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, torn between President Ford and Ronald Reagan, decided tonight to refrain from endorsing either candidate until the convention opens next month in Kansas City, Mo.

title: H.E.W. Scored on Loans
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois criticized today the Health, Education and Welfare department for allegedly failing to correct abuses in the $3.8billion student loan program. In a letter to F. David Mathews, Secretary of H.E.W., Mr. Percy said that Congressional hearings on profitmaking schools in the program showed that H.E.W.s Office of Education lost records, tolerated an excessive default rate of 47.6 percent among the proprietary schools and allowed unscrupulous hucksters to bilk the program of millions of dollars.

title: Mechanism Found In a Bomb Threat At Games Stadium
description: SHERBROOKE, Canada, July 25 (UPI)A bomb disposal unit removed a shoebox containing an alarm clock and some wires from a public washroom beneath the Olympic sports stadium late last night shortly after a caller told the police a bomb had been planted.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: It S. SUIT FACED BY STEINBRENNER
description: The Department of Justice is expected to file a suit, possibly today or tmorrow, challenging a claim against the Government for $5.4 million in cost overruns on vessels built by the American Ship Building Company.

title: Fern Colton Is Bride
description: Fern Jill Colton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Colton of Manhattan, was married at noon yesterday to Daniel Lampert, son of Mrs. Jules Roistacher of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Edward Lampert of Boston. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Regency. The bride is a magna cum laude graduate of Ithaca College. Her husband graduated from Cornell and plans to attend the New York University School of Law this fall.

title: Remarks by McCarthy Anger Carter's Mother
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 25 (UPI) Lillian Carter, Jimmy Carter's 77yearold mother, was angry today when Eugene J. McCarthy, an independent Presidential candidate, compared Mr. Carter to former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: CASTRO SHOWS NETO WHERE HE WAS JAILED
description: ISLE OF PINES, Cuba, June 25 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Fidel Castro today showed the visiting Angolan President, Agostino Neto, the penitentiary where he was jailed 23 year, ago after his first guerrilla action.

title: Bridge:
description: Declarers with an eightcard trump fit do not usually pause to consider the need to guard against a 50 trump split. But as a celebrated Wodehouse character, Psmith, used to remark, one should not confuse the improbable with the impossible.

title: KIRK, SANTAMARIA PLAY AT THE BEACON
description: Rahsaan Roland Kirk, the blind multiinstrumentalist who, suffered a stroke last November, appeared at the Beacon Theater Saturday evening, playing his tenor saxophone with one handsomething he has done before since he often used to play two or three saxophones simultaneously  and directing his band through a lone set.

title: MISSISSIPPI SLATE DELAYS ENDORSING UNTIL G.O.P. METS
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 25The Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, torn between President Ford and Ronald Reagan, decided tonight to refrain from endorsing either candidate until the convention opens next month in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Carter and Mondale Approach Issues Differently but Arrive at Similar Conclusions
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Jimmy Carter and Walter F. Mondale seem to approach national issues from a different perspective.

title: New York City Cuts Back Police RadioCar Patrols
description: Radio car patrols, which the Police Department calls its No. 1 crimefighting priority, have been quietly reduced throughout the city during the last year in the wake of budget and personnel cuts.

title: Deaths
description: BALLANTINEJohn Holme, of Delray Beach, Fla., on July 25, 1976. In his 84th year, after a long Illness, Survived by his wife, the former Dorothy Bortz, his brother Herbert W. Ballantine of Sarasota, Fla., and his daughter, Helen Ridgely Smith, 4 grandchildren and 5 greatgrandchildren. Memorial services at 11 A.M., Tuesday, July 27, St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Delray Beach, Fla. No flowers, by request of family. Donations may be made to Friends of the Bullet Hill School Inc., Southbury, Conn.

title: Goldin Finds City Losing Park Concession Revenue
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin called yesterday for competitive bidding and administrative reforms to increase New York City's revenue from park concessions by $3,224,000 a year. The current return is only $1,754,666 from 201 concessionaires and vendors, he said.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: FIRST GAME

title: Tennis Results
description: 21ANDUNDER CIRCUIT

title: Princess Anne Says She Rode in a Blur After Fall in Games
description: BROMONT, Quebec, July 25 (AP)Princess Anne of Britain said today that she felt fine but was still a bit stiff from the tumble she and her horse, Goodwill, took yesterday in the crosscountry race of the Olympic equestrian event.

title: G.O.P. Rolls Up Big Guns To Press 7th District Bid
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, July 25 The Republicans lost the Seventh Congressional District for the first time two years ago, and today they got off to an early start in their effort to win it back.

title: Air Crash Kills Fish Spotter
description: BOSTON, July 25 (AP)A Narragansett, R.I., man, Norman Pariseau was killed Friday when his singleengine plane crashed into the sea about 165 miles east of Boston, the Coast Guard said. The authorities said Mr. Pariseau was apparently working as a fish spotter when his plane crashed.

title: GLENN HEFNER
description: CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI)Glenn Hefner, father of Hugh Hefner, the Playboy Enterprises magnate, died of a stroke yesterday in a resort area of Door County, in Wisconsin, a spokesman for Playboy said today. He was 80 years old.

title: The Gap, a Retail Chain Success, May Face Problems
description: The Gap is neither a new geological find nor a new roadside tavern with booming band and nude waitresses. A chain of 167 jeans shops in some 20 states, the Gap is one of the most successful new retail enterprises of the 1970's.

title: Mondale's Career Notable for Luck
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 25One of the most popular topics of conversation in the political meeting places of Minnesota is the amazing luck of Walter Frederick Mondale.

title: $31 Million Loan to Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 25 (AP)  The United States has made a loan of $31 million to Egypt to improve and modernize the port of Alexandria, an official statement said today. The loan is to be repaid over 40 years with an interest rate of 2 percent during a 10year grace period and 3 percent thereafter.

title: A NEW CEASEFIRE IN LEBANON FAILS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25A new ceasefire agreement failed to take effect today when an Arab peacekeeping force came under heavy attack as itii tried to expand a neutral zone between rightwing Christian and leftist Moslem forces.

title: Spanish Golfer Wins
description: CRANS  SUR  SIZRRE, Switzerland, July 25 (Reuters)  A fourunderpar final round of 68 gave Manuel Pinero his first victory outside his native Spain today in the $57,600 Swiss open golf tournament. Dave Hill finished three strokes behind at 277.

title: Olympic Village Gives Athletes a Slice of Life and Security
description: MONTREAL, July 25  They rise like giant sawedoff pyramids opposite the Olympic Stadium, and they might be just four ultramodern apartment buildings except for two things: They house 7,000 of the world's best athletes and they are guarded by patrols of armed Canadian soldiers.

title: Going Out Guide
description: BIG IMPRESSIONS All the art displayed in this city is not confined to galleries and museums and homes of the rich. This city abounds with art that is an intrinsic part of such functional objects as cathedral doors, hotelelevator doors, museum facades, tombstones and even sewer and manhole covers.

title: Two Ethiopian Officers Are Executed as Rebels
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 25 (Agence FrancePresse) Two Ethiopian Army officers, one a colonel, were shot by a firing squad today for inciting soldiers to rebel, the Ethiopian press agency reported.

title: Horowitz Joining the Faculty at Marines
description: Vladimir Horowitz, a virtuoso who has heretofore avoided teaching commitments to conservatories, will join the faculty of the Mannes College of Music here this fall. The 71yearold pianist has agreed to teach one or two pupils of outstanding talent as a contribution to the school.

title: KISSINGER ASSAILED IN VERMONT PROTEST
description: NEWFANE, Vt., July 25 (AP) Carrying signs denouncing Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of Imperialism, about 40 demonstrators gathered at the village common today to protest his visit here.

title: John Holme Ballantine, 83, ExCompany Chairman
description: John Holme Ballantine, retired chairman of the Neptune Meter Company, now Neptune International Corporation, maker of meters and control devices for liquids, died yesterday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: Shore Town Has a Party To Mark Its Centennial
description: MONMOUTH BEACH, July 25This Monmouth County community allowed New York and Operation Sail to hold the spotlight on July 4, but the 2,000 people got together yesterday for a joint celebration of the nation's Bicentennial and the town's centennial.

title: The Cast
description: COUSIN, COUSINE, directed by JeanCharies Tacchelia; screenplay (French with English subtitles) by Mr. Tacchella; produced by Bertrand Javal; director of photography. Georges Lendi; editor, Agnes Guilemot; music. Gerard Anfosso; distributed by Libra Films. Running time: 95 minutes. At the Paris Theater, 58th Street west of Fifth Avenue. This film has not been rated.

title: Outside the Village, Celebrities Glitter
description: MONTREAL, July 25Sirens add to the din of traffic in this city's congested streets as squads of motorcycle police escort a royal limousine through downtown Montrea 1 to some function that tile public will read about in the morning.

title: HSU CHINCHIANG, 61; COAL AIDE IN PEKING
description: HONG KONG, July 25 (UPI) Hsu Chinchiang, a leader of China's petroleum, chemical and coal industries, has died in Peking, the press agency Hsinhua reported today. He was 61.

title: Taxicab Minifleets Stir Heated Debate
description: It works like this: a couple of hack driverslet's call them Harry Langsam and Cary Pigroneget together and buy two cabs from one of the big but ailing taxi fleet operators. The next thing you know, the HarryCary Taxicab Corporation is in business, a twoman, twocab minifleet.

title: Two Journals of Opinion Stop Publishing in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 25I am afraid it is not going to be possible to print any more issues of Seminar.

title: She Teaches a Modern Form of an Ancient Art
description: When Cecily Barth Firestein does a rubbing of a New York manhole cover, people gather round, wondering what that nut is up to. And when you do it in the middle of the street with traffic dodging you, she said, they know you've got to be crazy. Once a policeman stopped by to see if she was doing anything illegal. Mrs. Firestein charmed him by doing a rubbing of his badge.

title: VIKING SOIL SCOOP BACK IN CONDITION TO TAKE SAMPLES
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 25Viking 1's robot arm, which had balked in an earlier test, was flexed today and found to be ready and able to begin picking up Martian soil samples Wednesday.

title: Top Feats by Montgomery, Strachan
description: MONTREAL, July 25United States swimmers went out in a blaze of goldmedal glory tonight, and even the American women had something to cheer about.

title: BODY OF MERCENARY IS RETURNED TO U.S.
description: The body of Daniel Gearhart, who was executed in Angola as a mercenary, was returned to the United States yesterday and unloaded from a Portuguese airliner onto a conveyor belt with luggage.

title: Relieves Tormenting Rectal Pain & Itch Of Hemorrhoidal Tissues
description: In many cases Preparation H gives prompt, temporary relief for hours from such burning pain and itching and actually helps shrink swelling of hemorrhoidal tissues due to inflammation and infection.

title: Blacks See Detroit as Their Own, and Hope to Rebuild
description: DETROIT, July 25Back beyond the gloompast the elegant bar where black auto workers and politicians and athletes come to sit and listen to jazz and to drink the wines that have eclipsed cognac as the favorite at Watts's Club of MozambiqueCornelius Watts sat in his office and expressed what he and many other black Detroiters think today of this often troubled old industrial city.

title: New Frontiers
description: With all the sophisticated techniques of modern technology, today's explorers have found hills and mountain ranges on terrain that formerly seemed flat; there is a 400milelong river shrouded by continuous cloud cover; geological formations suggesting mineral deposits; soil conditions different from anything that had been previously surmised.

title: New York Court Politics
description: The evasive minuet now being carried out by members of the State Senate and the Assembly around the issue of court reform fools nobody. There is no question that reform is badly needed, but there is a large question that a majority in either party really wants it.

title: Olympic Village Gives Athletes a Slice of Life and Security
description: MONTREAL, July 25  They rise like giant sawedoff pyramids opposite the Olympic Stadium, and they might be just four ultramodern apartment buildings except for two things: They house 7,000 of the world's best athletes and they are guarded by patrols of armed Canadian soldiers.

title: FORD VOWS TO AID SEARCH FOR G.I.'S
description: WASHINGTON. July 25President Ford has promised 500 relatives and friends of American servicemen Still missing in Indochina that I will not rest until a fullest possible accounting of your loved ones has been made.

title: Ballet: La Sylphide
description: Bournonville's La Sylphide had two very different interpretations at the New York State Theater on Saturday. In the afternoon, American Ballet Theater presented Martine van Hamel and Ted Kivitt, while in the evening the leading roles were taken by Gelsey Kirkland and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: Wilkins Says U.S. Officials Threatened to Expel Him
description: MONTREAL, July 25Mac Wilkins, the goldmedal discus thrower from San Jose, Calif., charged today that United States Olympic officials had threatened to expel him from the team for training in nearby Three Rivers, Quebec, until last Wednesday.

title: Steel Mills Are Looking For Outside Financing
description: The steel industry for years has been playing a conservative financial hand. It has added little new capacity, has concentrated mainly on modernizing existing plant, has shied away from taking on much debt and has relied mostly on such internal sources as retained earnings and depreciation for its capital needs.

title: Red Smith
description: MONTREAL, July 25The eight best halfmilers in the worldif you don't count Mike Boit of Kenya, who wasn't hereambled into their assigned lanes on the brickred track and studiously ignored one another. Each had his little territory, identified by a big black number on a yellow block two feet high, where he shuffled about, hitching his pants, doing kneebends, kicking heels high, shrugging, loosening up in his own way. No Vandamme of Belgium had Lane 3. He is a tall character with tufted blond ?? whiskers. Rick Wohlhuter, a Notre Dame graduate, was on his right and a little ahead of him in the staggered start, a skinny insurance man from Chicago with a tidy mustache. In Lane 5 was the tallest of all, 6feet2inch Alberto Juantorena, a bushyhaired Cuban with sideburns down to the jowls.

title: Commodities
description: The boom in commodity futures prices that began last April petered out just after the Fourth of July, to judge by the market's behavior since then.

title: G.M. Adds to Capital Spending Figure
description: DETROIT, July 25Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said the giant auto maker would increase its capital spending by at least another $200 million over the next few years, and the figure could top $300 million if demand for new cars and trucks continues to improve.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: All indications are that everything is fine.James S. Martin Jr., Viking project manager, announcing that the Viking 1's robot arm is now able to pick up Martian soil samples. [1:4.]

title: Some New York Delegates Making Demands on Ford
description: The demand for special considerations from the Ford Administration by New York delegates to the Republican National Convention appears to be increasing despite a Presidential ban last week on such potential votetrading.

title: STATE'S DRUG CARE IS FOUND SHOCKING
description: Closing the books on its inquiry into the New York State Office of Drug Abuse Services, the State Commission of Investigation issued a report yesterday accusing the agency of shocking fiscal and treatment abuses.

title: MORE FACTS ASKED IN HORSES' DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Humane Society of Utah. questioning a Government explanation for the deaths of 50 wild horses on the Army's Dugway Proving Ground in Utah, has begun its own investigation into the incident.

title: Mammography Puzzle: Benefits Versus Risks
description: After Betty Ford and Happy Rockefeller were treated for breast cancer in 1974, thousands of women throughout the country flocked to screening centers and radiologists' offices to have their breasts examined by an Xray technique called mammography, which, they were told, could find breast cancers as small as an o on this page. They were also told the cancers were curable in 85 to 95 percent of

title: Cannery Talks Resumed
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Talks resumed today between the teamsters union and management in efforts to end the fiveday strike of 30,000 California cannery workers before the nearing fruit harvest. The Federal Mediation and Counciliation Service is participating in the negotiations. The walkout has closed 70 California canneries that process peaches, apricots, pears, tomatoes, grapes and other fruit.

title: PraiseandProtest Rally Held in a West Side Lot
description: Some came to protest and to remember; others were there for the sun, the food and the music.

title: Two Men Charged In Phils' Incidents
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 25Two men were being held today in $25,000 bail on charges stemming from two separate incidents at Veterans' Stadium last night, one of which prompted the Pittsburgh Pirates to leave the field during their game with the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Coal Miners to Spread Walkout To Protest U.S. Judges' Curbs
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 25 (AP)More than 500 striking West Virginia coal miners vowed today to spread their weekold walkout into other areas to protest being kicked around by Federal judges.

title: El Pitirre, at $7.20, Victor in Tom Fool
description: Laz Barrera, one of America's premier trainers, demonstrated yesterday he had made a shrewd decision in scratching El Pitirre from Saturday's $113,100 Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct, which was won by the favored Forego.

title: Time of Joy, Tears: Miss Ender Reunited With Grandmother
description: MONTREAL, July 25Mrs. Rosalie Lehmann opened the door somewhat nervously, then she saw her granddaughter. She looks as pretty in person as she doesin the photographs, Mrs. Lehmann thought, although the blond hair was dry and combed out this time instead of wet and stringy after a race.

title: Drug Test Positive, Rumanian Ousted
description: MONTREAL, July 25 (Reuters)Rumania's only weight lifter in the Olympics was disqualified today after a drug test on him proved positive, officials said.

title: Let My People Postponed
description: Phil Oesterman has postponed the Broadway opening of Let My People Come at the Morosco Theater from tomorrow night to Aug. 11. Previews will continue till openling night.

title: Small New Countries in the Caribbean Are Starting to Follow Cuba's Example
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad (AP)  The small emerging nations of the Caribbean are moving to the left, and the pace is accelerating.

title: Results of Olympic Games at Montreal
description: Basket ball, Men

title: Blacks See Detroit as Their Own, and Hope to Rebuild
description: DETROIT, July 25Back beyond the gloompast the elegant bar where black auto workers and politicians and athletes come to sit and listen to jazz and to drink the wines that have eclipsed cognac as the favorite at Watts's Club of MozambiqueCornelius Watts sat in his office and expressed what he and many other black Detroiters think today of this often troubled old industrial city.

title: Horowitz to Teach
description: Vladimir Horowitz will join the faculty of the Mannes College of Music this fall and without fee he will teach specially chosen students. It is the pianist's first formal association with a music conservatory. Page 30.

title: Connors, Ramirez Reach Washington Final Easily
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)Jimmy Connors and Raul Ramirez of Mexico swept aside unseeded opponents today to reach the final of the $125,000 Washington Star tennis tournament and set up another replay of their Davis Cup duel last September.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: New York Catastrophe Is Reported by Tass
description: New York's beaches were closed to the public for several weeks because of the ecological catastrophe in the New York Bay. the Englishlanguage service of the Soviet press agency Tass informed the world yesterday.

title: Navy Missile Project Illustrates Interaction Of Contractors, Consultants and the Military
description: WASHINGTON, July 25When its Condor missile was being criticized earlier this year, the Navy turned for supporting advice to a consulting company cofounded by an engineer who also works for Rockwell International, the defense contractor developing the missile.

title: Bombs Explode in Bogota
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 25 (Reuters)A bomb exploded at the Chilean pavilion of an international trade fair here, slightly injuring six people and causing about $15,000 in damages, the Colombian police said today. Another bomb exploded in front of the West German pavilion but cause, no injuries or damages.

title: Exit the FatCat
description: With the primary stage of the 1976 Presidential elections now over, it is apparent that the reform law for financing campaigns has creditably met its first test. It is also apparent that it has loopholes that will have to closed and modifications that must be made if new electoral weaknesses are not to replace the old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: All indications are that everything is fine.James S. Martin Jr., Viking project manager, announcing that the Viking 1's robot arm is now able to pick up Martian soil samples. [1:4.]

description: To the Editor:

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following Is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: New Paddlewheel Steamer Commissioned in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, July 25 (UPI)Longer than a football field and swankier than a grand hotel, the new 500passenger sevendeck Mississippi Queen  the first overnight cruise paddlewheel steamboat built in the United States in 50 yearswas commissioned today and pronounced fit to sail.

title: EGYPT IS REPORTED FAIDING BEIRUT ALLIES
description: CAIRO, July 26The Egyptian Government has recently been sending modest, unannounced shipments of military supplies to the PalestinianLebanese leftist side in Lebanon, well  placed informants sympathetic to the Government reported this week.

title: James Crayhon, Press Aide For Exxon Corporation, 74
description: James W. Crayhon, a retired press aide of Exxon Corporation, died Sunday at Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 74 years old and a resident, lof Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: AMEX INDEX DOWN IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange declined slightly yesterday in slow trading of only 1.5 million sharesthe slowest day since Jan. 2 of this year. The Amex market value index closed at 104.57, off 0.08.

title: PILOT KILLED ON LI. IN AIR COLLISION
description: A pilot was killed last night when his small aircraft plunged to the front yard of a Syosset, L.I., home after striking a seaplane carrying five passengers from Fire Island to Manhattan.

title: Communists in Italy Win 4 Chamber Chairmanships
description: ROME, July 26For the first time in the history of the Italian Republic, the Communist Party tonight won chairmanships of committees in Parliament.

title: Talking Cornputer Aids Blind
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP)  A talking computer is being used by the Civil Service here to aid its blind employees. The experimental program enables workers to get information from a Honeywell computer in audible as well as printed form.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SING ALONG WITH RINA Most Italian festivals here emphasize food. Tonight there is one that emphasizes song. The Italian Actors Union is sponsoring Canti d'Italia, a variety show featuring Italian comedy and songs.

title: Notes on People
description: Fritz Efaw was jailed in Oklahoma City yesterday, following his arraignment for draft evasion and ordered to stand trial the week of Aug. 12 on a charge the United States attorney had moved to dismiss. Eleven days earlier, Mr. Efaw, who returned from England voluntarily as an alternate delegate of overseas Democrats, had been placed in nomination for Vice President at the convention here so he could speak in favor of a general

title: Schweiker Says He Can Help on Unity
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Senator Richard S. Schweiker said today that he had accepted Ronald Reagan's invitation to be his running mate if Mr. Reagan won the Republican Presidential nomination because he thought that as a team they could unify the party.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka of Japan was arrested in Japan early today for alleged involvement in the multimillion dollar Lockheed Aircraft Corporation bribery scandal. He was taken to the Tokyo prosecutor's office for questioning and 90 minutes later was charged with having violated Japan's foreignexchange and currency regulations by accepting money illegally brought into Japan. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: POLICY BRIEFINGS BEGUN BY CARTER
description: PLAINS, Ga., July 26Jimmy Carter, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Senate Walter F. Mondale, began a series of national policy briefings today with a session on defense involving eight experts ranging from scholars to former top Pentagon officials.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JULY 26,1976.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Friday incorrectly identified a Brooklyn gypsy cab driver who was shot and killed during an attempted holdup. He was David Wayne Gibson, 21 years old, of 28 St. James Place.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Auto Racing May Revive Idled Newark Stadium
description: NEWARK, July 26  The Ironbound Recreation Center, a monument to $6 million in poor planning and the success ofi vandalism in New Jersey's larg est city, may yet become a source of revenue for the finan cially strapped urban center if a plan to turn it into the site of weekly midget auto races comes to fruition.

title: 3 Development Units Combined By Beame in CostSaving Move
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday ordered the consolidation of three midtown development offices into a single new Midtown Action Office and created a separate umbrella agency to take over the work of the development offices in upper and lower Manhattan, downtown Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens.

title: Olympic Fears Stir Border Patrol Shift
description: FRANKLIN, Vt.A Border Patrol agent, Sterling Smith, his heavy silver and turquoise expansion watchband and cowboy boots marking him as a man of the Southwest, stood by the bright orange metal gate at the Canadian border, scanning the unfamiliar, densely wooded landscape.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, July 26, 1976

title: Helping New York
description: A school for working adults seeking a high school equivalency diploma faces an uncertain future because of the city's financial straits. Ironically, the school doesn't cost the city anything, since the teachers donate their services.

title: DR. JOHN C. SLATER, PIONEER IN RADAR
description: SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla., July 26 (AP)Dr. John C. Slater, whose research led to the development of radar in World War II, died after a heart attack last night at his home Itere. He was 75 years old.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1876. by Triangle Publications. Inc. The Daily Raclng Form)

title: Communists in Italy Win 4 Chamber Chairmanships
description: ROME, July 26For the first time in the history of the Italian Republic, the Communist Party tonight won chairmanships of committees in Parliament.

title: Tension and Despair Prevail at West Side Unemployment Office
description: With one out of every 10 people in the labor force out of a job, the tension is often high and the frustrations deep on both sides of the counter at the unemploymentinsurance claims office on the Upper West Side.

title: Strike by Miners Expands, Closing Some Pits in Ohio
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 26 (AP)Striking coal miners shut down West Virginia's rich coal industry today to protest the use of Federal restraining orders and fines against union members in labor disputes. Meantime. the strike spread into neighboring Ohio.

title: Can Women Compete With the Men?
description: By GORDON S. WHITE Jr. Women are eligible to enter the United States Golf Association's open championship tournament by starting in the qualifying round, the way most men begin.

title: BEAME ACTS TO NAME A MEDICAL EXAMINER
description: Mayor Beame has asked panel of experts, including three forensic pathologists, to evaluate the professional qualifications of Dr. Dominick J. Di Maio for the post of Chief Medical Examiner.

title: Reserve Assets Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (Reuters)The nation's total reserve asset rose to $18.3 billion in June from $17.9 billion in May and compared with $16.2 billion in June, 1975, the Treasury Department reported today. The gold stock was unchanged at $11.55 billion.

title: U. S. Women's Five Wins For a Silver Medal, 8367
description: MONTREAL. July 26 (UPI) Win or lose. the United States women's basketball team was going to have a party this afternoon. The way things worked out it was a big celebration because the Americans defeated Czechoslovakia, 8367 and won a silver medal in the first women's competition held at the Olympic Games.

title: Television
description: 7:30 P.M. XXI Olympic Games (7)

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)The InterAmerican Development Bank reported today the United States and other industrialized nations were in the midst of economic recovery after suffering through the most severe recession since World War II. But Latin America and most of the rest of the developing world, now feeling the full impact of that recession, will have to wait at least until 1977 for a full economic resurgence, the bank said.

title: TIMES CO. SHOWS 35.5% PROFIT RISE
description: The New York Times Co!!. pany yesterday reported secondquarter consolidated net income of 56.2 million, or 54 cents a share, an increase of 35.5 percent over the $4.6 million, or 42 cents a share, reported in the second quarter of 1975.

title: Rash of Fires in Catskills Points Up Growing Decline
description: FLEISCI1MANNS, N.Y.In the last 30 years, more than 100 hotels, motels, boarding houses, camps and private homes in this area have burned to the ground under suspiciouscircumstances. At least 20 of the fires have occurred in the last five years.

title: Earthquake Hits Idaho
description: GOLDEN, Colo., July 26 (AP) mild earthquake rolled over eastern Idaho early today, but there were no reports of damage or injuries, the National Earthquake Information Service reported.

title: French Franc Sinks To 29Month Low; Gold Price Up a Bit
description: PARIS, July 26 (AP)The French franc plunged to a 29month low today, closing at 4.94 to the dollar, down from 4.926 Fridaya slide of 8 percent since the beginning of the year and 4 percent in recent weeks.

title: Byrne's Taking of Rise In Pay Rekindles Protest
description: TRENTON. July 26In the throes of the state's fiscal crisis last year, Governor Byrne decided to forgo a $5,000 raise. It was only a gesture, but it undercut the badgering of political opponents.

title: Rise in Productivity Cuts Cost of Labor
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The labor cost for each unit of output in the manufacturing sector of the economy was lower in the second quarter of this year than a year earlier despite the rise in wages, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Hague and Wife Go Public In Performance at Drake
description: She was smiling athim, and he was looking at the piano, and when he started to speak he sounded like Henry A. Kissinger. Still, with the smile, the big bow tie and the spotlight's reflection off his glasses he was gemiltlich, a middleaged Teutonic cherub. This was Albert Hague performing.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: The Toth Case
description: What can there possibly be of a security or classified nature about sugarbeet refining, wherever it is done? The question arises inevitably in the wake of I'Affaire Toth, the almost yearlong imprisonment in Yugoslavia of a naturalized American citizen, Laszlo Toth, allegedly for having taken pictures of a sugarbeet refinery. Mr. Toth was released the other day and has returned to his Colorado home, but it took a great deal of American pressure  particularly by United States Ambassador Laurence H. Silberman in Belgradebefore the Tito regime terminated this particular bit of nastiness.

title: For Urban Egyptians, Turban Is Out, But Villagers Wear It to Look Good
description: CAIRO, July 26  Gaber Abdelkader, a seller of cloth for turbans, surveyed his plain and fancy bolts of Egyptian cotton with a proud but melancholy eye.

title: Recital: Poised Pianist
description: A piano recital divided between Mozart and Beethoven, as Rudolf Firkusny's was on Sunday night at the Mostly Mozart Festival in Alice Tully Hall, makes great ,demands on the performer's sense of the differences in the two composers styles. Mr. Firkusny, a pianist of impeccable taste and a techn:que that allows him to do just about whatever he wishes at the keyboard, gave poised and restrained performances of Mozart's Fantasy in C minor (K. 396), and the Sonatas Nos. 10 in C (K. 330) and No. 14 in C minor (K. 437).

title: Chrysler Reports Best Quarter Ever
description: DETROIT, July 26  The Chrysler Corporation today reported secondquarter earnings of $155.1 million, its best three months ever and a strong turnaround from a $58.7 million loss in the second quarter last year.

title: ELEANOR M. STRAUSS
description: Eleanor McGregor Strauss, widow of Moses Strauss, who was managing editor of The Cincinnati TimesStar and author of What's The News? and Newspaper Practice in Changing World, died Saturday in Cincinnati. Mrs. Strauss, who lived in Cincinnati, is survived by a son. Dr. Victor Strauss, and a daughter, Mrs. Paul W. Steer, both of Cincinnati, and eight grandchildren.

title: Castro Says Cuban Soldiers Will Continue to Protect Angola
description: MIAMI, July 26 (AP)Prime Minister Fidel Castro said today that Cuban troops and arms would remain in Angola to protect the West African nation from any future invatsion and help its development.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Chess:
description: BIEL, Switzerland, July 24 Bent Larsen of Denmark took over the lead with 61/2 points after nine rounds of the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspirants here in the Kongresshaus.

title: 33 Sublet E. Side Apt., Suspct Seizd w/o Dpsts
description: A 33yearold man who allegedly sublet his Upper East Side studio apartment to 33 people last January and then ran off with their $17,000 in deposits on the day they all arrived to move in has been arrested and charged with grand larceny.

title: Miss Hearst's Trial Put Off 6 Months but Her Lawyer Doubts He'll Find Jury
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26Pa, tricia Hearst, still looking pale, and gaunt, won a six month delay in her state trial today; with her lawyer predicting that! even by the new trial date, Jan.; 10, he would not be able to; find jurors who had never, heard of her bank robbery conviction in San Francisco.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Monday. July 26. 1976

title: Text of Reagan Statement
description: LOS ANGELES. July 26 [UP]Following is the text of Ronald Reagans announcement today that he would select Senator Richard S. Schweitzer, Republican of Pennsylvania, as his running mate if Mr. Reagan wins the Republican Presidential nomination:

title: Reagan's Bold Gamble
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Ronald Reagan's bold runningmate gamble stunned the Republican Party today and seemed bound to alter the pre

title: Soviet Five Loses, Foiling Title Rematch With U.S.
description: In one of the biggest surprises of the Olympic Games at Montreal, the defending champion Soviet Union men's basketball team was beaten, 8984, yesterday by Yugoslavia. The victory put the Yugoslays into tonight's final against the United States and prevented a goldmedal rematch between the United States and Soviet teams. The Americans advanced by beating Canada, 9577.

title: What Strategy for Health?
description: The new conventional wisdom in the field of health policy stresses prevention and the early detection of disease. Two recent developments. however, suggest that the issues involved are more complicated than generally assumed.

title: Richard Clare Partridge Dies; Retired Army General Was 77
description: Richard Clare Partridge, a retired major general, who served as chief of staff of the VII Army Corps in World War II, died of a heart attack Friday near his home in New London, Conn., at the age of 77.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLOCKElizabeth MY dearly beloved, beautiful mother, devoted and true, so very sadly we miss You. Annette, Jack. LIBERMANTonney.The tears haven't Mooned since YOU left us so suddenly a year any.

title: Cleaning Up the Parks
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's detailed findings serious managerial incompetence in the administration of municipal parks concessions are striking, but hardly surprising. In a city that has rarely distinguished itself for managerial excellence, the patronageridden Parks Department has long beenan especially notorious example of gross mismanagement.

title: Lions Kill Park Attendant After He Leaves His Jeep
description: KINGS MILLS. Ohio, July 26 (UPI)An attendant in an animal preserve at an amusement park was mauled to death by lions after leaving his protected jeep, the investigating coroner said today. Dr. Ralph Young, Warren County coroner, also said there was a report that the attendant had been seen opening his jeep door and patting lions on the head.

title: Heavyweight Paces U.S. Ring Advance
description: MONTREAL, July 26Proceeding with what its manager called an esoteric game plan designed for East European opponents America's young Olympic boxing team put three more men into the quarterfinals today.

description: A school for working adults seeking a high school equivalency diploma faces an uncertain future because of the city's financial straits. Ironically, the school doesn't cost the city anything since the teachers donate their services.

description: To the Editor:

title: A DoctorAuthor in Hemingway Country
description: FORT BENTON, Mont.It was close to midnight. Onlythe inebriated antics of a few young farmers down by the levee on the Missouri River disturbed the quiet of the little town.

title: Olympics Outdraw All Other Programs
description: The Montreal Olympic Games on ABC have been eclipsing all other summertime programming in the national ratings, drawing 45 to 50 percent of the viewing audience most evenings.

title: Market Place
description: The recent sparkling performance by the shares of Energy Conversion Devices Inc. suggests that a small contract with a leading corporationin this case, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Companycan do great things for the stock of a promising but deficitridden company.

title: House Panel Asks Reprimands For Sikes in Stock Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The House Ethics Committee formally recommended today that Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, be reprimanded on two of three complaints alleging that he used his office for personal gain.

title: Route 18 Bridge Plan Stirs More Protests
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 26The State Department of Transportation and community environment groups clashed today at a public hearing on the proposed construction of a highway bridge over the Raritan River here as part of a project to develop State Route 18 into a major eastwest freeway.

title: Harvard Returns Jade Taken From Mexico
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 26 (AP)  Harvard University said today that it had returned to the Mexican Government valuable Maya jade artifacts taken from a funeral well at Chichen Itza in Yucatan from 1904 to 1909.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Michel Jobert was Foreign Minister of France from April 1973 to May 1974. This article was translated from the French by Leonard Mayhew.

title: SECURITIES PLAN OPPOSED BY U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Justice Department formally expressed today its opposition to the formation of the National Securities Clearing Corporation, saying the merger of three major clearing agencies into one would violate antitrust laws.

title: Recital: Poised Pianist
description: A piano recital divided between Mozart and Beethoven, as Rudolf Firkusny's was on Sunday night at the Mostly Mozart Festival in Alice Tully Hall, makes great demands on the performer's sense of the differences in the two composers styles. Mr. Firkusny, a pianist of impeccable taste and a technique that allows him to do just about whatever he wishes at the keyboard, gave poised and restrained performances of Mozart's Fantasy in C minor (K. 396), and the Sonatas Nos. 10 in C (K. 330) and No. 14 in C minor (K. 457).

title: Summit Child Center Gets New Home
description: SUMMIT  The Summit ChildCare Center, a second home for 102 children of working families, say its environment is designed to stimulate fun, curiosity and creativity. The center's planners seem to have achieved their goals.

title: Hope Is Fading in Albany For Court Reorganization
description: The chances that constitutional amendments on court reorganization will be passed this year were dimmed yesterday when leaders of the Legislature announced that they would not botherto reconvene the Legislature in Albany this week to act on any of Governor Carey's vetoes.

title: Experts Are Puzzled by a New Beaching of Whales
description: MIAMI, July 26 (AP)  As a lighthouse crew in the Dry Tortugas fought to save some of 30 beached pilot whales today, experts were puzzling over who, after four years without such beachings, three groups of deep water mammal have stranded themselves reshore in two weeks.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: IANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 54311 UNTIL S:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M.
