title: Roberts 3d in Vault After Gamble Fails
description: MONTREAL, July 26 Alone in the rain, with a 16foot fiberglass vaulting pole in his wet hands, Dave Roberts, a 25yearold medical student from Florida, took the biggest gamble of the Olympic Games tonightand lost.

title: PRIME CUT TO 7% BY CHICAGO BANK
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, one of the nation's largest commercial lending in stitutions, announced a quarterpoint reduction in its prime lending rate yesterday, signalling the first general decline in the cost of business credit since January.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 27, 1976 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on small territories11 A.M. SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. on the complaint by Zambia against South Africa.

title: PILOT KILLED ON LI. IN AIR COLLISION
description: A pilot was killed last night when his small aircraft plunged to the front yard of a Syosset, LI., home after striking a seaplane carrying five passengers from Fire Island to Manhattan.

title: Report Finds U.S. Canada Ties Strained and Likely to Stay So,
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Relations between the United States and Canada are becom ing increasingly strained, and there is little hope for improvmerit, a new research study concluded today.

title: MARKET IS MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
description: Dow Up by 0.60 to 991.51, but 746 Stocks Fall as 604 Show Advances

title: U.S. DEFICIT IN 76 WAS $66.6 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Federal Government finished the fiscal year 1976 with a budget deficit of $65.6 billion, which was $10.4 billion below earlier estimates, the Government said today.

title: Nephew of Carter, a Prisoner, Says Family Has Disowned Him
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI)Jimmy Carter's 29yearold nephew, imprisoned for two armed robberies, says that his family disowned him when his uncle began to close in on the Democratic Presidential nomiI nation, The San Francisco Chronicle said in a copyrighted article today.

title: TV: Pat Collins Tackles Homosexuality in Sports
description: The ways of programming manipulation can be wondrous, if not devious. ABC, of course, is quite happy with its Montreal Olympics these days, anxious to perk up the smallest details with unflagging optimism and cheer. Not to be outdone in the popular arena, yesterday morning's The Pat Collins Show, on WCBS at 9:30, also tackled the sports market, but in this case the subject was Homosexuality in Sports, hardly cpie designed to make Jim McKay and ABC Sports more cheerful.

title: Books of The Times
description: As World War II ground to an end, mood of rising expectations swept through a civilian populace weary of homefront shortages and 15 million servicemen and women weary of military rigamarole and fighting and dying on obscure coral atolls in the Pacific. Peace was a word breathed with votive fervor, and the high priests of advertising stocked the postwar paradise with an inventory of shiny new civilian goods, advertised in mouthwatering colors. The war had left many Americans with money in their pockets from high warplant wages, and, after four years of relative selfdenial, they needed new cars, new tires, new clothes, new homes, new appliances. The popular song There's a Great Day Comin Manama promised, There'll be strawberries floating in cream, while a G.I. doggerel had it, The best years approach, for you and I. Yet there were anxieties tooabout wartime infidelity and profiteering, about a possible depression, about the shape of the postwar world.

title: Merchant Academy Declines to Press SexConduct Case
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., July 26 (UPI)The United States Merchant Marine Academy announced today that it would not press sexualmisconduct charges against Cadet Nancy Donnelly, who resigned after being found in bed with her fiance but who was later reinstated after charges of sex discrimination were raised.

title: Soy Numero Uno Finds His Old Zip
description: Soy Numero Uno is healthy horse again. Bill Borders, the assistant trainer, pays so. Patrick Day, who has been riding him says so.  And those in yesterday's

title: A TOTAL SURPRISE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 Ronald Reagan broke with tradition today and named Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the man who will be his running mate if the Californian wins the Republican nomination for President.

title: Getty Gasoline Up a Cent
description: The Getty Oil Company announced yesterday an increase of 1 cent a gallon in the price of gasoline, effective today. The increase follows a similar announcement by Texaco Inc. on July 21.

title: Anna Marie Bartnett. 69. Educator in New Rochelle
description: Anna Marie Bartnett, who taught in the New Rochelle schools for 48 years and became its supervisor of language arts, died Sunday in New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. She was 69 years old and lived at 30 Perth Avenue, New RoI chelle.

title: Lady Banting, 64, Widow Of Discoverer of Insulin
description: TORONTO, July 26 (Reuters) The widow of Sir Frederick Banting, who discovered insulin, died today of a brain tumor. Sh was 64.

title: Enriching Decision
description: More than five Years after the idea first emerged from the Nixon Administration, Congress is scheduled to vote this week on a proposal to let private industry on the 30year Government monopoly on manufacturing fuel for nuclear power plants. Whatever its ideological appeal may be, the idea falls flat in economic terms and the proposal should be defeated.

title: CELEASE OF REPORT TO SCHORR DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Representative Robert N. Siaimo. Democrat of Connecticut, testifying at public hearings today, denied under oath any knowledge about how a secret House Intelligence Committee report was leaked to the press. He did not believe the report was a classified document. he added.

title: Razzle Dazzlinem
description: Richard Schweiker said it well. Ronald Reagan's announcement that if he wins the Republican nomination for President he will choose Senator Schweiker as his running mate was a bold, unprecedented action. It may also prove decisive.

title: JAPANESE ARREST FORMER PREMIER IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 27Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka was arrested this morning for alleged involvement in the multimilliondollar Lockheed Aircraft bribery scandal.

title: Motive of White House Intruder Eludes Police
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Law enforcement officers were unable today to explain what motivated a 30yearold taxi driver who was fatally shot last night after he scaled a White, House fence carrying a threefoot length of pipe.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Community Colleges Cut To the Basics in City U.
description: The community colleges of the City University of New York, which are scheduled to take on added importance by eventually absorbing most of the system's enrollment, are planning cutbacks for the fall that range from the elimination of most elective courses at one college to the loss of half the parttime teachers at another.

title: HEROIN SMUGGLER GETS 15YEAR TERM
description: A 43yearold woman who operates a Chinese restaurant in Asbury Park, N. J., received a 1.5year prison sentence yesterday for conspiring to smuggle SS pounds of heroin into the United States from Hong Kong.

title: Young Summer Class Students Learn Architecture by Building
description: When Michael Altschuler decided to explain what Gothic architecture was, he did not talk about pointed arches and stainedglass windows. Instead, he arranged six students in two rows of three, and asked them to join their hands high in the air across the center.

title: Wild Trial Is Focusing on Contribution to Inouye
description: WASHINGTON. July 26Claude C. Wild Jr. the former Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyist who over a period of 13 years received more than $'l million front the company's overseas affiliates for distribution to political campaigns in this country, went on trial here today for making a $5,000 contribution to Senator Daniel K. Inouye. Demorrat of Hawaii.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Officials, Seeking to Deport Gypsies, Frustrated
description: OGDENSBURG, N.Y., July 26 (UPI)A gypsy caravan has been fleecing its way across the country for two years, frustrating efforts of authorities to deport them because no other country will take them, United States Border Patrol officials said today.

title: 5 Named to Consumer Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)President Ford appointed five persons today to the Consumer Advisory Council for twoyear terms. They are Beatrice K. Chernock, a Philadelphia councilwoman; Edna Johnson. director of consumer services, Baltimore Urban League; RodolIfo B. Sanchez, of Arlington, Va., national director of the Coalition of Spanishspeaking Mental Health Organizations; Currin V. Shields, University of Arizona, Tucson, and Muriel Stevens, hostess of the Muriel Stevens Show, Las Vegas.

title: WILLIAM I. COHEN, 72, SMALL CLAIMS JUDGE
description: William I. Cohen, a lawyer and Small Claims Court judge who had long been active in Manhattan Republican politics, died Sunday at his home, 45 Sutton Place South. He was 72 years old.

title: Inquiry Is Said to Oppose Prosecuting C.I.A. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Justice Department lawyers investigating the Central Intelligence Agency's 20year program of opening mail between the United States and Communist countries have recommended against the criminal prosecution of agency officials involved in the project, a Government official familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Reagan's Coalition
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Americans for Democratic action, that weathervane of liberal voting in Congress, last year found the voting record of Senator Rich and Schultz Schweiker so acceptable it rated him 89. This was only six points be low the score the A.D.A. gave Senator Walter F. Mondale, Jimmy Carter's VicePresidential candidate, and a score that would have done a liberal Democrat proud.

title: West German Business Mergers Trouble Bonn Monopoly Panel
description: BONN, July 26 (AP)A Government commission on monopolies has expressed concern over the growth of economic concentration through business mergers in West Germany, which has the strongest econoI my in Europe.

title: U.N. Official Calls Boycott Noble Act
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. (AP)The head of the United Nations committee against South Africa's policy of apartheid, or racial segregation credited today the countries boycotting the :Olympics with a noble act. . Leslie 0. Harriman of Nigeria, chairman of the committee, said: The sacrifices made by these countries and their sportsmen is a noble nct, which I hope, will help Persuade governments and sports bodies in New Zealand, as well other countries concerned, that verbal condemnation of apartheid is meaningless so long as there is collusion and fraternization with the practitioners of that

title: Bias Toward a Vietnamese Charged in Housing Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Justice Department announced today that it had filed its first housingdiscrimination suit involving a Vietnamese refugee. Attorney General Edward H, Levi said the suit was filed in Federal District Court in Mobile, Ala., charging Daniel F. Mason with having an illegal policy of discriminating in the operation of Mason's Mobile Home Court at Semmes, Ala.

title: Oil Companies Show Rises in Profits
description: The earnings posture of the oil industry in the first half of 1976 was clarified yesterday as a number of the major companies announced higher profits for both the second quarter and the first six months of the year.

title: A TOTAL SURPRISE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 Ronald Reagan broke with tradition today and named Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the man who will be his running mate if the Californian wins the Republican nomination for President.

title: SOYBEANS DOWN IN SHARP TURN
description: Soybeans closed down the permissible 20cent daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, reversing Friday's trend.

title: Raid on the Range
description: In the true tradition of the old Westerns, Ronnie Reaganwith feather in his cap, eyes squinting, guns ablazin'swoops down on the enemy camp on his black stallion, snatches a hostage right out of the hands of his sleeping guardians, and, crossing a neighboring Ford, triumphantly rides off through the yastnesses of Penn's Woods into the western sunset. Fadeout.

title: Spending Cuts Arouse British; Labor Party Facing Defections
description: LONDON, July 26Nearly every segment of British politics and industry has reacted skeptically to the Labor Government's decision last week to cut public spending and raise business taxes despite rising unemployment.

title: Semifinal Loss Eliminates Russians
description: MONTREAL, July 26There will be a grudge game for the Olympic gold medal in basketball tomorrow night, but it will not be a United StatesSoviet Union final.

title: Kidnapping Suspect to Plead Not Guilty, More Are Sought for Questioning
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26Richard A. Schoenfeld's attorney said today that his client would plead not guilty to 43 charges of kidnapping and robbery in connection with the ab1 duction earlier this month of! 26 children and their school bust driver near Chowchilla in San Joaauin Valley.

title: Me is in Rare Form In 41 Loss to Phils
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26The Mets, who just came from Montreal, caught the Olympic spirit. They played like amateurs tonight.

title: Moods, Not Issues, Dominate West German Election
description: BONN, July 26In West Germany, the candidate with the teeth is Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. and though his smile is as broad as Jimmy Carter's, his edge over his conservative opponent looks much narrower now.

title: For Serious Gardeners, a Comic Book
description: Want to learn how to transform the bathroom into a tropical paradise of plants? Or perhaps how to take advantage of such disposable vases as green peppers or hollowedout melons? And to smile while you're learning?

title: FIREFIGHTERS GIVE REPORTING AWARDS!
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association's awards for 1975 to reporters and photographers for coverage of fires and other stories related to New York City's firemen were presented yesterday by its president, Michael J. Mayo, at a luncheon at the Downtown Athletic Club.

title: The Age of Discovery
description: This has been a thrilling and historic month in the saga of man's exploration of space.

title: Other Highlights
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALLThe United States defeated Czechoslovakia, 8367, in its last game and won the silver medal. The Soviet Union took the gold, beating Japan, 9875.

title: Met Plans New Art Publications Center
description: To expand its $8 million business in art reproductions and books, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will construct a fivestory art publications center in space within the museum.

title: Official Italian Payroll Of $550,000 Is Stolen
description: ROME, July 26 (AP)Three gunmen raided the accounting office of the Labor Ministry today and made off with a $550,000 payroll. There was no policeman around to stop them.

title: KallinkTer Report Released
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 26 (UPI)The attorney for Joseph Kallinger won the right today to review a Pennsylvania court psychiatric report, which described the Philadelphia shoemaker and murder suspect as insane. Judge Thomas Dalton in Superior Court ordered Pennsylvania authorities to turn over the psychiatric report on Mr. Kallinger to Paul Giblin. Mr. Kallinger's lawyer. The report, written in 1972, described the 40yearold defendant as schizophrenic and paranoid, according to Mr. Giblin.

title: Tennis Results EASTERN SENIOR CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: AT TENNISPORT

title: Tonight's Entries at Yonkers
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: BOND PRICES EASE. IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices eased slightly in slow trading in the credit markets yesterday as dealers awaited two critical developments set for this week in Washington.

title: In Montreal, Uniforms to Swap
description: MONTREAL, July 25Susan Morgan clomped through the Olympic Village last night in an enormous pair Dutch wooden shoes, bright blue Rumanian sweat socks, a red rowing club shirt from the Soviet Union and pair of Polish rowing trousers that looked like short long johns.

title: MIN HINTS STEP AGAINST KENYANS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 26President Idi Amin of Uganda, acknowledging that his country is suffering a severe shortage of gasoline, .has resumed his war of words against neighboring Kenya.

title: Governor Visits Prison In Elmira Unannounced
description: Governor Carey made an unscheduled visit to the Elmira Correctional Facility here today, his first inspection of a state prison since he took office 19 months ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Friday incorrectly identified a Brooklyn gypsy cab driver who was shot and killed during an attempted holdup. He was David Wayne Gibson, 21 years old, of 28 St. James Place.

title: Today's Schedule
description: Times are Eastern Daylight

title: Results of Olympic Games at Montreal
Soweto Schools Closed Again As Most Students Stay Away
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 26Schools in Soweto closed again today after most of the township's 250,000 students stayed away, as they have onl each of the three days since the schools reopened last week. Most other townships reported normal or nearnormal attendance.

title: Steel Output Up 0.6% in Week; Imports for May at Yearly High
description: Steel production for the week ended July 24 posted a gain of 0.6 percent and thus ended three consecutive weeks of declines, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The nation's steel mills poured 2.6 million tons in the most recent week, which meant that their production capability utilization was 85.6 percent.

title: Polish Vaulter Victor, With Roberts 3d
description: MONTREAL, July 26Don Quarrie, a Jamaican who lives and trains in Los Angeles, won the Olympic 200meter dash gold medal today, a prize that eluded him four years ago. Americans took the two other medals as 20yearold Millard Hampton of San Jose, Calif., finished second and 17yearold Dwayne Evans of Phoenix, Ariz., third.

title: Advertising
description: There might have been a time around the turn of this decade when black agencies got business from national advertisers that was a form of conscience money.

title: Coop City Strikers Give Up $20 Million
description: Leaders of the Coop City strike against increased carrying charges yesterday lugged $20 million in withheld payments to State Supreme Court in the Bronx and handed it over to themselves, since they Row are the bcard of directors for the giant housing project.

title: 7 FOOD BUSINESSES TERMED VIOLATORS
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of seven food establishments it accused of violating the health code. It has warned that closing orders will result if violations persist upon a final visit by its inspectors. The establishments and the findings are:

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings
Wright's 67 Leads Field at Siwanoy
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.. July 26Jimmy Wright of Fenway won medalist honors by two strokes in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship today, carding a 33, 3467 on the 6,403yard Siwanoy Country Club course here, where oar is 36. 3571.

title: Chain Store Sales Rose 9.6% in June
description: Chain stores throughout the country registered a sales gain of 9.6 percent in .Tune over the 1975 month, according to figures compiled by Chain Store Age magazine. The June results showed some improvement over May's volume, which was only 7 percent ahead of the yearearlier month, but were clown considerably from high percentage gains achieved in the first four months of the year.

title: Japan Releases Papers On Postwar Rule by U.S.
description: TOKYO, July 26  Many Japanese are reliving the period of the American occupation of their nation these days with the continuing release of hitherto secret postwar documents that shed some light on the sometimes shaky relationships between conqueror and conquered.

title: State Defends Referendum on Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 26A deputy attorney general joined a battery of Atlantic City lawyert in Superior Court here today to defend the constitutionality of a casino gambling referendum that will appear on the general election ballot in November for the second time in three years.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 26Last February, Governor Byrne said in a statement from his office: There continues to be some confusion over the Governor's salary.

title: Executed Mercenary's Body Is Received Only by Officials
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The body of the executed mercenary Daniel Gearhart ar41ved home today in a plain wooden box bearing his name and shipping instructions to a funeral home in suburban Silver Spring, Md.

title: Soviet Farmers Study Midwest's Methods Firsthand
description: FLANAGAN, Ill., July 19If President Ford is still concerned about using the word dtente in dealing with the Soviet Union, he could draw some comfort today from the fact that Geria Ulianov does not use that term either_ Indeed, Mr. Ulianov does not even recognize it.

title: Scouts Lose Franchise to Denver
description: KANSAS CITY, July 26 (AP) Owners of the defunct Kansas City Scouts voted today to sell their National Hockey League franchise to a group of Denver investors ending speculation where the financially orphaned team would wind up. A lastditch effort to save the twoyear expansion franchise for Kansas City was rejected by the league in favor of the Denver offer, John Ziegler, league lawyer, said. The Scouts finished last both seasons in the Conn Smythe Division and suffered financial setbacks estimated at $5 million. Bud Palmer, former New York Knick Basketball player, heads the Denver group.

title: U.S. ASKS PENALTY ON AMERICAN SHIP
description: WASHINGTON. July 26 (AP) The Justice Department is seeking damages from the American Ship Building Company for alleged inclusion of illegal political contributions in claims for Government pay ments on a shipbuilding contract.

title: George Souders, 75, Dies; Won Indy 500 Race in 27
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 26 (AP)George Souders, a former Indianapolis 500 auto race winner, was found dead in his apartment here today. He was 75 years old. Death was attributed to natural causes.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Camden County woman pleaded guilty to stabbing her husband, who drove himself to a hospital before dying of his wound. The woman, Mildred Bonnie Anderson, 25 years old, of Pennsauken, told Judge Leon Wingate in Superior Court in Camden that she stabbed her husband, William Anderson, 33, m the stomach last August during an argument. Mr. Anderson drove to Cooper Medical Center in Camden, but died several hours later. Mrs. Anderson faces up to 10 years in prison on her guilty plea to the manslaughter charge.

title: Connors Beats Ramirez In Capital Final, 62, 64
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)Jimmy Connors relentlessly ground out a 62, 61 victory over Raul Ramirez of Mexico and captured the $125,000 Washington Star tennis tournament tonight.

title: Todd Impressive In First Jet Drill
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.. July 26 In his outlandish shoulder pads, Richard Todd gave the appearance today of a football player wearing a zoot suit.

title: Rash of Fires in Catskills Points Up Growing Decline
description: FLEISCHMANNS, N.Y.In the last 30 years,more than 100 hotels, motels, boarding houses, camps and private homes in this area have burned to the ground under suspicious circumstances. At least 20 of the fires have occurred in the last five years.

title: Freight Derails in Danbury
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 26 (UPI)Several cars derailed on a Penn Central freight train today, damaging the track and public roads but injuring no one, authorities said. The accident occurred about 5 P.M. and caused a temporary rushhour traffic jam because three railroad crossings were blocked.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the most successful clubs in the New York metropolitan area will move to bigger quarters later this week. The Vanderbilt Club in Great Neck, which has long been a focal point of bridge on Long Island. has been flourishing under the management of Frank Schuld, and will he transferred Friday to a luxurious home, with space for three duplicate sections and several other activities including backgammon, at 1362 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I.

title: SPANISH KING HEARS WORKERS
description: MADRID, July 26 (UPI) Thousands of auto workers crowded around King Juan Carlos I at their plant today, shouting demands for a political amnesty and the rehiring of colleagues dismissed for joining in an illegal strike.

title: Now, if I Were Your Secretary of State...
description: PARISI'd like to be always taken seriously, without, however, having to take myself seriously. Anyhow, that's my attitude as I write this article. Even if the marvelous uncertainties of the upcoming American elections in the fall have sparked the wild hope among the various candidates for Secretary of State that they will be swept into this post in the wake of the victorious Presidential contender, there is one thing everyone agrees is certain: I shall not be the new Secretary of State. The French rarely come to the aid of the Americans  once every two centuries.

title: Carty of the Indians Drives In 4 As Red Sox Lose 6th in Row, 94
description: Rico Carty has become a muchtraveled player since he broke into the major leagues with the Milwaukee Braves in 1963. Since then, he has tested the batting background in such places as Atlanta, Arlington, Texas; Oakland, Calif.; Cordoba, Mexico, and, more recently, Municipal Stadium in Cleveland.

title: High Marks for Dior, as Fall Collections Get Under Way
description: PARIS, July 26  Pierre Cardin showed some dresses with one pants leg, JeanLouis Scherrer presented outdoor gear for the upperclass woodsman, and all the Americans in town turned out for the Christian Dior show after lunching at the Relais Plaza. The weeklong Paris fall couture sweepstakes were off and running and the winner of the first day's race, by many lengths, was Christian Dior.

title: Inquiry Is Said to Oppose Prosecuting C.I.A. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Justice Department lawyers investigating the Central Intelligence Agency's 20year program of opening mail between the United States and Communist countries have recommended against the criminal prosecution of agency officials involved in the project, a Gov ernment official familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Gunman Threatens Turkish Official at Waldorf
description: A man with a gun was overpowered and disarmed last nlght as he began to point loaded automatic handgun at Bulent Ecevit, the former Prime Minister of Turkey, in the lobby of the WaldorfAstoria.

title: CONNECTICUT PLAN SAVES OPEN LAND
description: HARTFORD, July 26 (AP)A 13yearold plan to encourage preservation of open spaces, farmland and forests has worked, but needs help, state report says.

title: Merchant Academy Declines to Press SexConduct Case
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., July 26 (UPI)The United States Merchant Marine Academy, announced today that it would not press sexualmisconduct charges against Cadet Nancy Donnelly, who resigned after being found in bed,with her fiance but who was later rein, stated after charges of sex discrimination were raised.

title: Ford Signs Bill Meant to Help Coast Localities Cope With Offshore Resource Development Problems
description: President Ford signed legislation yesterday that would provide communities in coastal states with $1.6 billion to meet the problems of growth that might accompany the development of offshore oil and gas resources.

title: VIKING SNIFFER FINDING NITROGEN
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 26Viking 1 instruments have reported that Mars has an atmosphere that project scientists believe is encouraging to the search for life but by no means conclusive.

title: Potato Growers Get Futures Assurance
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Mc., July 26 (UPI)The head of the new Commodity Futures Trading Commission assured potato farmers today that people who caused a massive default of May Maine potato futures contracts would receive more than a reprimand.

title: JAPANESE ARREST FORMER PREMIER IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 27Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka was arrested this morning for alleged involvement in the multimilliondollar Lockheed Aircraft bribery scandal.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Trudy L. Mason has been appointed deputy director of the New York City Office of Neighborhood Services charge of special projects and public affairs. Miss Mason, who had been deputy assistant administrator of the Economic Development Administration, replaces Janet Langsam who on July 19 was appointed deputy commissioner cultural affairs. Miss Mason's salary will remain $27,787 a year.

title: Turk Threatened
description: A man with a gun was overpowered as he threatened Bulent Evecit, former Prime Minister of Turkey, in the Waldorf Astoria while Greek sympathizers demonstrated outside. Page 3.

description: Leaders of the Cobp City strike against increased carrying charges yesterday lugged $20 million in withheld puymeats to State Supreme Court in the Bronx and handed it over to themselves, since they now are the board of directors for the giant housing project.

title: Arthur D. Rooney Jr., 74. ExChief Bank Examiner
description: Arthur D. Rooney Jr., who retired in 1970 as a supervising New York State bank examiner, died Saturday in Nassau County Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived at 143 Floral Parkway, Floral Park,

title: Olympic Scene
description: MONTREAL, July 26As the dinner crowds head for the fine French restaurants that line the cobbled streets of Old Montreal, the site of the first fur trading settlement in pioneer days and now this sophisticated city's core, thoroughfares usually clogged with honking automobiles at such an hour have become temporary malls. The city's tolerant police officers don't just look the other way when merrymakers block motor traffic with dancing in the middle of the street. Entering into the lighthearted Olympic spirit, they close the streets so that cars won't hamper the dancers.

title: Tin Pan Alley (Remember?) Is Celebrated
description: The original Tin Pan Alley, famed street of songs where many of America's popular tunes were created, lived again yesterdayif only for a halfhour.

title: TIDAL MARINE FIGURE1 GETS 5 YEARS IN JAIL
description: James D. Hanlon, a lawyer for the Tidal Marine International Corporation, received a fiveyear prison sentence yesterday for his participation in a fraudulent scheme that allegedly obtained bank loans of more than $60 million.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: In Search of the Crabeater
description: HATTERAS, N. C.Blazing down from a cloudless sky, the sun had raised the temperature to over 90 degrees by the time we set forth with Ken Lauer, fishing guide, from Teach's Lair Marina for an afternoon of cobia fishing on Pamlico Sound.

title: Solar Energy Collector
description: HOUSTON (UPI)Two engineers say they have designed a simple solar energy collector using air instead of water for heat transferral that may be the key to a lowcost solar energy system. Earl P. Herndon and Kenneth G. Anthony of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration estimate a solar energy system could save a household 75 percent of its normal heatine exnenses.

title: Wolfman Mac and His
description: MONTREAL, July 26On the victory stand in his red USA sweatsuit, Mac Wilkins stood with his hands clasped in front of his waistline as The StarSpangled Banner was played. His pose resembled a reverse parade rest, respectful enough for a bearded giant who had won the Olympic discus throw. Wolfman Mac also smiled during yesterday's ceremony. When he was asked why later, his earthy explanation prompted laughs from newsmen unable, through propriety, to report it to their readers and listen ers. But then Wolfman Mac began talking about his hassles with United States Olympic officials, about how he had been threatened with expulsion from the United States team for having trained until last Wednesday in nearby Three Rivers, Quebec, and about how the gold medal represented an achievement for myself rather than for his country. What he didn't mention, of course, is that if he were an Olympic athlete from some other countries, he presumably would not have dared to talk like that. And if he had dared talk like that, Wolfman Mac would be an endangered species.

title: Long Fight by Williams To Avoid Jail Is Failure
description: The twoyear fight of Calvin Williams, a former State assemblyman, to stay out of jail ended yesterday when a judge refused to lift his sixmonth sentence on perjury charges.

title: L.I. Aide Linked Raises To Political Contributions
description: The assistant sanitation supervisor for Hempstead, L.I., dmitted yesterday that he had cold sanitation employees that to get raises or promotions they would have to donate 1 percent of their pay to the Nassau County Republican. Party. There was no indication of how many employees may have been involved.

title: 2 NAMED IN THEFT FROM UNION FUND
description: A Miami real estate operatori who has served two jail sen1 tences for fraud and the chief financial officer of a union were indicted by a special. Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of siphoning off more than $1 million from the union's welfare fund.

title: R. C. Cummins Weds Miss Timmons
description: Monica Kathryne Timmons, an analyst with the credit department at C. Tennant Sons & Company of New York, international traders in nonferrous metals, concentrates and ores, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Clyde Cummins, an account representative for the banking division of the United States Trust Company of New York.

title: Theater
description: Kingdom of Earth is at least the fourth title and incarnation of the Tennessee Williams play that began life, briefly, on Broadway in 1968 as The Seven Descents of Myrtle. Last year it appeared, under its present title, at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N. J. Now. in revival Off Off Broadway at the I.R.T. Theater, it turns out to be a fascinating little Gothic tale, a comedy with menace.

title: U.S. Pullout Leaves Thai Economy in a Shaky State
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 26 Along Bangkok's garish Petchaburi and Patpong Roads, huge neonlit gogo bars, nightdubs and massage parlors used to echo to Midwestern trangs, Southern drawls and Bronx nasalizing. Now it is Thai voices that are heard, and the customers, once crowded out by freespending Americans, are enjoying bargain  basement prices in the wake of the United States military withdrawal.

title: Double Play, Sinkerball Beat Yanks
description: BALTIMORE, July 26Now that they are in second place, the Baltimore Orioles are taking the Eastern Division race seriously.

title: Embassy Says Belgrade Jails U.S. Citizen as Spy
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 (UPI)United States Embassy officials said today that Yugoslavia arrested a former American army captain two, years ago and sentenced him to five years in prison for espionage.

title: United Hospital Fund Picks Campaign Chief
description: The United Hospital Fund of New York has named DeWitt Peterkin Jr. as chairman of its 1976 citywide campaign to raise money for its 52 voluntary, nonprofit member hospitals. Mr. Peterkin is vice chairman of the hoard of J. P. Morgan & Company and of its subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Comnanv

title: House Panel Asks Reprimands For Sikes in Stock Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The House Ethics Committee formally recommended today that Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, be reprimanded on two of three complaints alleging that he used his office for personal gain.

title: Lebanese Fighting Goes On in Defiance of New Pact
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon. July 26Heavy fighting continued in various parts of Lebanon today in disregard of the ceasefire agreement the warring factions were reported to have reached Saturday.

title: Nonswimmer Drowns
description: A 60yearold Manhattan man who was unable to swim, drowned yesterday while floating off Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn, The victim, who weighed 300 pounds, was identified as Antonio Stoia of 653 Ninth Avenue. His body was ,recovered by David Suntag, a lifeguard.

title: VIKING SNIFFER FINDING NITROGEN
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 26Viking I instruments have reported that Mars has an atmosphere that project scientists believe is encouraging to the search for life but by no means conclusive.

title: HEAD OF H.E.W. CITES MEDICARE OVERUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Federal public health officials told Congress today that overuse and abuse of the Medicare itnd Medicaid programs were a much greater problem than outright fraud.

title: Reagan's Bold Gamble
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Ronald Reagan's bold runningmate gamble stunned the Republican Party today and seemed bound to alter the pre carious balance of a fiercely competitive contest for the party's Presidential nom ination. But only the events or the next several days will determine if the California's designation of Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania to be his running mate was a stroke of tactical brilliance or a devastatingly bad mistake.

title: Texas Instruments Profit Doubled in 2d Quarter
description: Texas Instruments, the leading producer of semiconductor products, reported yesterday doubling in second  quarter sales and earnings from the depressed yearearlier level.

title: Senate May Delay Oil Bill Vote
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Senator Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, said today that the Senate might not have time to vote this year on a bill to break up 18 large oil companies.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Itel Corporation announced yesterday in San Francisco that it had agreed in principle to acquire AutEx Inc., of Wellesley, Mass. in a stock trade valued at about $13.8 million.

title: Olympic Sidelights
description: MONTREAL. July 27In some circles, it might sound corny: The family that prays together stays together.

title: Gabor Szabo Quartet Appearing At Bottom Line With Davis Trio
description: Gabor Szabo's quartet and the Richard Davis trio comple ment each other so perfectly that one wonders whether their booking at the Bottom Line this week was a matter of chance or of intelligent forethought. In any event, the two groups finish their run tonight, and both are worth hearing.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Bank Robbery Suspect Killed
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (UPI)One suspected hank robber was dead and two others were in custody today following the robbery of upwards of $15,000 from the Thornridge State Bank in suburban South Holland yesterday. A Federal Bureau of Investigation spokesman said that Howard Frank Killeckis, 36 years old, of Calumet City. was shot dead by a South Holland policeman when the police stopped a car with the three suspects in it. Gregory Narug, 28. of Blue Island, surrendered immediately, and his brother, Stanley Narug, 36, of Calumet City, was capItured about 90 minutes later, the police said.

title: John Lennon Wins His Residency in U.S.
description: Yesterday, all of John Lennon's troubles seemed so far away and now it looks as though he's here to stay.

title: Musical Gone With Wind
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 27Six and a half years after it opened in Tokyo and after playing on three continents, the musical Gone With the Wind is still trying to reach Broadway.

title: El Salvador and Honduras To Discuss Border Clashes
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 27 (UPI)The Foreign Ministers of El Salvador and Honduras have agreed to meet in Guatemala on Thursday to discuss how to prevent a renewal of border clashes between the two countries, the. Salvadoran President's office said yesterday.

title: Wright Is Victor In Two Matches
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 27 Jimmy Wright of Fenway won both his matches today in advancing to the quarterfinal round of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship at Siwanoy Country Club.

title: Sales Show Gains
description: PITTSBURGH, July 27The United States Steel Corporation today reported a 7 percent secondquarter earnings decline to $119.6 millin, or $1.47 a share, from $128.6 million, or 51.58 a share, in the 1975 quarter.

title: Giants Find It Tough to Choose Among 14 Defensive Linemen
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 27There are 14 defensive linemen on the New York Giants roster and only six or seven will survive training camp. But sometimes it looks as if Jay Fry is determined that no one will survive his training methods.

title: About Real Estate
description: The hoarded Royal Manhattan Hotel on Eighth Avenue at 44th Street reopened the other day, not for guests but for a liquidation sale. When the furniture, kitchen equipment and other paraphernalia of the hotel's sunnier days as a theater district tourist center are sold, the locks will go on again.

title: U.S. Agency Will Review Tests On Cats at American Museum
description: The National Institutes of Health said yesterday that they would scrutinize the American Museum of Natural History's federally financed study of the sex lives of cats, which animal rights groups in New York City have called cruel and inhu mane.

title: Shockwaves in Japan
description: The arrest of Japan's former Prime Minister, Kakuei Tanaka, is the most dramatic indication yet of the heights to which the rot of corporate bribery may have spread in world trade. No wonder the ruling Liberal Democrats of Japan were so nervous about the unfolding disclosures of Lockheed Aircraft's multimilliondollar payoffs, a nervousness shared by United States Government investigators who presumably were aware of possible Tanaka link to the web of corruption.

title: Ford Sends Congratulations
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) President Ford congratulated the Americans who carried out today's evacuation and also thanked those who had helped make the operation a success, including the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Biting a Hand While Feeding Ends Dog's Little Bit of Luck
description: Some dogs, like some people, have very little luck.

title: Sunday for Macy's
description: Macy's New York has confirmed reports that 15 of its 16 stores including the Herald Square store would begin Sunday operations sometime between Aug. 29 and Sept. 19. Page 47.

title: The People of Chowchilla Relive Scenes of Children's Abduction
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif., July 27The nightmare and miracle of kidnapping and escape were relived with trepidation and curiosity here last night by local residents who flocked to the fairground auditorum to watch a rerun of television coverage of the events of two weeks ago.

title: Open Interest

title: Mackinac Race Won By Dora IV
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 27Dora IV won overall honors in the 333mile Chicago  to  Mackinac race for the third straight yeir this week and her skipper, Lynn Williams, says he's ready to retire.

title: VIKING 2 PREPARES FOR MARS ORBIT
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 271 Another Viking spacecraft, now approaching Mars, fired its rocket tonight to change course slightly in preparation for orbiting the planet Aug. 7 and joining Viking 1 in its historic Martian explorations.

title: Carey Signs Bills Easing Adoption of Abandoned
description: ALBANY, July 27Governor Carey signed into law today package of bills designed to ease the freeing of abandoned children for adoption.

Four U.S. Boxers Advance To Semifinals in Olympics
description: MONTREAL, July 27Leo used an uppercut, Chuck southpaw's jab and Howard a combination of guile and dynamite. Then Sugar Ray finished off the evening with a razzledazzle display that brought shouts of Ali from an Olympic boxing crowd of 6,500.

description: DETROIT. July 47 (AP)Bill Reagan, the commissioner of the International Hockey League, was asked today by the United States douse of Representatives to appear before its select committee on professional sports Thursday in Washington.

title: Sic Transit . . .

An urban joy can be as simple as taking a small boy to Coney Island on the old Sea Beach line and choosing to return to Manhattan on the F train because of its bright, quiet, new cars and the view it affords of the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge before it scuttles into a tunnel for the long serious journey under Brooklyn.

But an international dispute was averted when the United States indefinitely postponed a trip by women gymnasts to South Africa, the nation whose racial policies embroiled the Olympics last week.

description: WASHINGTON, July 27The wide grin is still there but it disappears a bit more quickly these days. The big, square body is still trim and athletic but some of the spring is gone and it occasionally sags a little from fatigue.

However, neither he nor representatives of the Amalgamated Transit Union, the bargaining organization, would disclose details of the tentative pact.

Inouye because the threeiyear statute of limitations ran lout before the Government indicted him.

title: ILLEGAL REBATING LAID TO AEROFLOT
description: The Soviet airline Aeroflot was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday for offering illegal rebates of approximately 50 percent on tickets for transAtlantic flights beitween Paris and Washington.

title: Derringer, Lofgren Introduce Groups With Similar Styles
description: Nils Lofgren and Rick Derringer, two rock guitarists, introduced their new bands to New York at the Schaefer Festival on Monday. Mr. Derringer is the oldtimer of the two in terms of experience. He is only 26 years old, but he was making hit records with the McCoys back in 1965 and later performed with both the Winter Brothers, Edgar and Johnny. He is a steaming, direct guitar player and a convincing, if somewhat ordinary, vocalist.

description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange reported the sale of a seat Monday at $89,000, down $1,000 from the previous sale on Friday, July 23.

description: PEKING, Wednesday, July 28 A powerful earthquake shook Pelting before dawn today, cracking walls, smashing windows and sending thousands of people rushing into the streets.

title: ExPeruvian Chief Stricken
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters)  Former President Juan Velasco Alvarado of Peru was in serious condition at Georgetown University Hospital today after suffering a stroke last night, diplomatic sources said here. General Velasco, who had a leg amputated three years ago, arrived in, Washington in April for outpatient treatment at Walter Reed Army Hospital.

title: WINE TALK
description: Recenty 25 students at the Marick Cooking School in New York City conducted a comparison tasting of four California white wines and four French white burgundies all made from the chardonnay grape. The tasting was similar in some ways to one held a few weeks earlier in Paris and reported on here.

title: G. O. P. FEMINISTS ANGRY AT PARTY
description: WASHINGTON. July 27I Feminists in the Republican Party are nagry at the treatment they believe women are getting from their party and they fear that many of the best women workers will simply sit out the campaign if steps are not taken to improve things.

title: TARGET IS STEADY ON MONEY SUPPLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The Federal Reserve has decided on no change in its target for growth of the nation's narrowly defined money supply, known as MI. for the year ahead, it was disclosed today.

description: Budget cuts are threatening to impair the ability of the High School of Performing Arts to provide trained professionals in the New York cultural scene, according to Irving Orfuss, the school's deputy principal.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 27William and Emily Harrisangered over a series of rulings by their trial judge and knowing that Patricia Hearst could be called to testify against them suddenly rested their case today without calling a witness.

description: In professional investing circles, it is almost universally assumed that stocks are superior to bonds as an investment medium.

title: A Celebrity Chorus Line Sings a Love Song to New York
description: A chorus of 20 wellknown New Yorkers, including Bess Myerson, Rocky Graziano, Tammy Grimes, Robert Merrill and Ruby Dee, and led by Skitch Henderson, gathered yesterday to record a song called Mad About Manhattan. The proceeds will go to the Citizens Committee for New York City.

title: Spain Wins Doubles
description: MOSCOW, July 27 (Reuters) Manual Orantes and Juan Gisbert kept Spain's Davis Cup tennis hopes alive in Donetsk today with a 61, 61, 810, 63 doubles victory over the Soviet pair of Alex Metreveli and Teimuraz Kakulia.

title: About New York
description: For nine months of the year Joe Clinton teaches school history in Huntington, L. I., and for three months he is a lifeguard lieutenant at Jones Beach. He wishes it were the other way around.

title: The Whale Quotas
description: Some hope that the whale might yet be saved from extermination has at last been raised by action of the International Whaling Commission at its recent session. While the American proposal for a 10year moratorium on killing of whales was again turned down, the commission actually has succeeded in reducing the overall quota by about 40 percent from a year agonow down 26,000 for all species of whale in all oceans.

title: BEAME AND GOLDIN OFFER FISCAL PLAN
description: The Beame administration announced yesterday that tightened revenue productionincluding higher pistol permit fees and tougher enforcement of traffic summonses on rentalcar driverswould take care of nearly half of the $50 million in fresh budget cuts scheduled to be imposed next month.

title: Dentist Is Arrested as Molester In DecoyTrap Set Up by Police
description: A 51  year  old Manhattan dentist was arrested yesterday after detectives watched by means of a hidden camera as he allegedly molested an undercover woman investigator as she sat unconscious in the dental chair under an anesthetic.

title: Spain and Vatican Agree on Revision Of 1953 Concordat
description: MADRID, July 27 (AP)The Spanish Government and the Vatican have agreed on a revision of the 1953 Concordat governing relations between Spain. and the Roman Catholic Church, the Government announced today.

title: Clark, Campaigning, Proposes a New Tax On Holdings of Rich
description: Ramsey Clark, one of five candidates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate from New York, yesterday proposed a nett worth tax on properties held by the rich that he predicted would bring in more than $11 billion to the Federal treasury.

Schweiker of Pennsylvania as the Californian's running mate as a tough decision necessary to broaden Mr. Reagan's appeal to win both the Republican nomination and the November election.

title: Competing for Shares
description: Wall Streeters who have long rejoiced in the bullish performance of the computer industry are turning strangely skittish about the potential for computers their own business. As one segment of the securities industry, led by the more confident brokerage firms, draws up ambitious proposals for automated buying and selling of shares nationwide, other industry forces warn of the costs and dangers of black boxes which ultimately could run the leading stock exchanges out of business.

title: CASTRO SAYS ANGOLA NEEDS TECHNICAL AID
description: PINAR DEL RIO, Cuba, July 27 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Fidel Castro says Cuba will continue to provide Angola with military support but that the former Portuguese African colony needs technical help more than military assistance.

description: PARIS, July 27The econotnic watchdog of the Western industrialized nations says their recovery is proceeding too slowly to make much of a dent In unemployment, but it warns that any faster growth would accelerate inflation and start a new boomandbust cycle.

title: U.S. Regains Gold In Basketball, 9574
description: The United States regained the gold medal in Olympic basketball last night, defeating Yugoslavia, 9574. In 1972 the United States suffered its only defeat in 40 years of Olympic basketball when the Soviet Union won a controversial final, 5150. The Russians lost to Yugoslavia in Mondays semifinal.

title: New Haven Becomes Ranger Affiliate
description: The New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League will serve this season as the primary farm club for the New York Rangers of the National League, the Rangers announced yesterday. The Nighthawks replace the financially troubled Providence Reds, whose fiveyear agreement with the Rangers was completed last season.

title: People and Business
description: In the latest installment in the banks continuing attempt to block proposed changes in accounting rules, the head of New York City's largest bank said yesterday that the changes could block an effort by the Municipal Assistance Corporation to stretch out its debt repayments.

description: Henry A. Kelly 3d, who retired in 1954 as vice president and treasurer of Henry Kelly & Sons Inc., wholesale fruit and vegetable dealers in Manhattan, died Saturday in his home on Hack Green Road, Pound Ridge, N. Y. His age was 74.

July 27 (Reuters)  The earthquake in China today was the strongest recorded in 12 years and struck! at a point about 100 miles southeast of Peking in Hopehi Province, the United States, Geological Survey said here.: The Geological Survey said the quake measured 8.2 on the! title: Carey Takes Look and Listen Trip

The man, apparently an American, was, according to Mr. Theroux, one of an odd community of practically nameless fugitives from the war in Vietnam.

title: Daughters of Eve at the Oars
description: MONTREAL, July 26The ancient Greeks held the body beautiful in high esteem, yet a curious Puritan ethic prevailed at Olympia. Because athletes in the Olympic Games wore only the uniform they were born in, women were barred as spectators and if one of the sisterhood was caught peeking she was dropped off the nearest cliff. There was one notable exception in 404 B.C. A wealthy widow from Rhodes disguised herself as a trainer to watch her son box, and when the kid won she went into such transports of delight that somebody recognized her. Out of respect for her father, brothers and son, all Olympic winners, she was allowed to live, but thereafter trainers were required to work naked like the competitors. It is no news to Gloria Steinem or Elizabeth Ray that things have changed for the daughters of Eve. Not only do the likes of Nadia Comaneci, Princess Anne and Shirley Babashoff ornament the Olympics these days, but for the first time since Helen of Troy strayed from the fireside, women competed here in basketball and rowing. The rowers wound up their part of the program last Saturday and an overcrowded weekend deprived them of the attention they deserved.

A White House nurse said the wife of the Secretary of State felt lightheaded.

Public Analysis opinion does not very often play a vital role in the politics of Japan, where feuding factional leaders mobilize legislative followers like feudal lords gathering troops to mistshrouded castles. Personal alliances and personalities have been far more important than policies.

title: And a Quinn Buckner Shall Lead Them
description: MONTREAL, July 28When the United States Olympic basketball team filed out in its blue sweatsuits for the gold medal ceremony, Quinn Buckner led them. As the captain, he was entitled to lead them. But ever since the Olympic basketball players were assembled, Quinn Buckner has been their leader. His unselfish style is almost invisible, but when the 9574 victory over Yugoslavia was completed last night, Quinn Buckner was more visible as he smiled and danced a hugaloo near midcourt with the basketball his arms. In each of the six victories, his initials identified his role. He didn't score that many points but he directed the offense. And when the United States needed points, he often supplied them. He played tough defense. He did the small things that a leader doespatting a teammate on the rump, extending hand to help a teammate up from the floor. When not the game, unaccustomed as he is to heing on the bench, he preferred to stand and exhort his teammates. He was called an amazing player by Dean Smith, the American coach. But for all that Quinn Buckner did as a leader, perhaps his most important contribution was in leading Scott May, his Indiana University teammate, onto the Olympic team two months ago.

The communique said the attack took place yesterday and that the patrol returned the fire. It gave no other details.
