description: BOSTON, July 28 (UPI)The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, F.David Mathews, said today that the nation would have a very critical problem if an acceptable insurance plan for the swine flu vaccine was not developed by Friday.

title: Bridge: Grand National Play Reaches Quarterfinals Bracket Today
description: The Grand National Team Championship, which began at club level eight months ago, reaches its climax in Salt Lake City during the next three days. The champions of eight zones will battle in knockout matches to determine the national winners, who will qualify for playoff matches to select the 1977 international team.

title: Byrne Seeks Maximum U.S. Building Aid
description: TRENTON, July 28 Governor Byrne announced plans today to get as much as possible of the $309.5 million in Federal capital construction funds that New Jersey is entitled to under the $3.95 billion Public Works legislation approved by Congress last Thursday over President Ford's veto.

title: Fraud in Crime Insurance Case Is Laid to Two Men in Brooklyn
description: In the first indictment in volving abuse of the fiveyearold Federal Crime Insurance, Program, a Brooklyn bus driver and a publicinsurance adjuster were charged by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday with fraud and bribery.

title: Harrises Lose Fight for Mistrial on Possible Tampering With Jury
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28William and Emily Harris lost a fight today for a mistrial on possible jury tampering, even though the prosecution and defense agreed that one of the jurors might have smuggled a 1974 newspaper on Patricia Hearst's kidnapping into the heavily guarded jury room 10 days ago.

title: In First Execution Since 1973,France Guillotines Slayer
description: MARSEILLES, France, July 28 (Reuters)  A 22yearold man was executed by guillotine, today for the kidnapping and murder of an 8yearold girl.

title: Byrne Decries Plane Delays
description: TRENTON. July 28 (UPI)Governor Byrne has told the Federal Government that it should take a more vigorous role to prevent aircraft from wasting fuel while waiting to take off and land at the nat ion's airports. In a letter yesterday to Frank Zarb, head of the Federal Energy Administration, he called for better utilization of airports,

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, July 28 (UPI)The dollar fell on European money markets today, including Paris, where the franc rose without apparent intervention from the Bank France. The price of gold closed unchanged in Zurich $114.15 an ounce and dropped 25 cents an ounce in London to close at $113.875 against yesterday's $114.125.

title: STEIN ASSAILS FIX ON S.I. PARK DEAL
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said yesterday that he had deduced that a builder's campaign contribution had influenced Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin and other members of the Board of Estimates to conspire to defraud the public in approving a proposal for a Staten Island amusement park last week.

title: Boisset's Rape
description: In Yves Boisset's film, Rape of Innocence, justice, mercy, decency, fair play and a young woman are raped, but not innocence. Innocence is in very short supply in this wellintentioned melodrama, which is so clumsily schematic that you know everything that anyone is going to say or do at least two reels before it happens.

title: Family Planning
description: MANILA, July 28 (AP)A couple cannot get a marriage license in the Philippines until they show they have received instruction in family planning and responsible parenthood, the Government's Commission on Population has announced.

title: G.M. Net 2d Highest
description: The General Motors Corporation reported the second highest quarterly net income in American business history, $909 million, second only to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $939.7 million profit. Page 41.

title: PRESIDENT IS NAMED BY A CITYAID GROUP
description: Philip H. Hoff, a former Governor of Vertnont, yesterday was named president of the Coalition to Save New York, an organization of leading banking, insurance, real estate and labor leaders in the city.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: The New York Times Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents share on its Class A and Class B common stock, the same amount as in previous quarters. The dividend will be payable Sept. 24 to shareholders of record Sept. 10. The company also declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.37 a share on its 5 percent cumulative prior preference stock, payable Oct. I to stockholders of record Sept. 10.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Florida man, found guilty of having flown a plane carrying about a ton of marijuana to Teterboro Airport has been sentenced to five years in jail and fined $5,000. United States District Court Judge Frederick B. Lacey sen. tenced the defendant, Erroll Jay Mirmelli, a 34yearold. Miami travel agent who was arrested in March after he. landed a small plane at the Bergen County airport. Mr. Mirmelli was arrested by United States customs agents when they noticed several men unloading 53 cartons from the 10seater plane on the airport runway on March 22. The street value of the marijuana was estimated at $800,000 to $900,000 by Federal authorities.

title: House Votes Mine Safety Shift To Dept. of Labor From Interior
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The House of Representatives passed today a bill, strongly backed for several years by the United Mine Workers union, that would transfer the enforcement of Federal coal mine safety standards tothe Labor Department from the Interior Department, which has long been criticized for lax enforcement.

title: Compatibility
description: I compiled a list of persons . . . whose basic beliefs were compatible with my own. I have selected a man who believes in the same basic values in which I believe.

title: Today's Schedule
description: Times are Eastern Daylight

title: Daniel Gearhart Is Buried
description: KENSINGTON, Md., July 27 (UPI)Daniel Gearhart, a mercenary executed by an Angolan firing squad two weeks ago, was buried today after a simple Roman Catholic ceremony attended by about 200 people. Mr. Gearhart and three Britons were shot following their conviction by a revolutionary court for mercenary activities.

title: Argentina Opening Nine Oil Fields For Private Company Development
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 28Argentina is opening nine productive oil areas for development by private companies in the first stage of a new policy to increase oil output with the use of international capital and technology.

title: CHINA REPORTS HEAVY QUAKE LOSS IN TANGSHAN, CITY OF ONE MILLION
description: PEKING, Thursday, July 29A second powerful earthquake struck northeast China yesterday, 16 hours after a major tremor hit  the same area, smashing buildings and forcing millions of people to evacuate their homes.

title: Other Highlights
description: HANDBALLThe Soviet Union swept the gold medals in both the men's and women's events. The Soviet women defeated East Germany in the final of the first Olympic women's handball competition. The Russian men defeated Rumania in the final.

title: Portugal Completes Cabinet
description: LISBON, July 28 (Reuters)The formation of Prime Mini ster Mario Soares's Socialist Cabinet was completed tonight when 42 secretaries of state and under secretaries were sworn into office. President Antonio Ramalho Eanes presided over the ceremony. Mr. Soares was sworn into office last Friday to head the first democratic government in Portugal for half a century.

title: Independent Political Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 28In the Idaho primary campaign in May, the 13 women of the Ladies for Reagan Committee in Boise got together $152.82 to put an advertisement in the Idaho Statesman urging people to turn out for a rally with Ronald Reagan.

title: National Starch Lifts Price
description: The National Starch and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday a price increase for its Hi Loft resins of 1 cents a pound, effective Sept. 1, 1976. The new price in bulk quantities will be 21 cents a pound.

title: Weak News on Economy Sends Stocks Downward
description: Bearish economic news drove the stock market lower yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

title: FORD IS ENDORSED BY TOP DELEGATE FROM MISSISSIPPI
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Clarke Reed, the influential chairman of the Mississippi delegation to the Republican National Convention, endorsed President Ford's candidacy tonight.

title: Ford Would Keep Wiretap Records From House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) A Federal judge took uncle] advisement today President Ford's contention that it would be an unacceptable risk tc give a House subcommittee ac cess to records of national se. curity wiretaps.

title: G.M. Net 2d Highest
description: The General Motors Corporation reported the second highest quarterly net income in American business history, $909 million, second only to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $939.7 million profit. Page 41.

title: Mbre Big Banks Cut Prime
description: A quarterpoint reduction in the prime lending rate of commercial banks began spreading through the country yesterday. as several banks followed the cut announced Monday by the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: All Americans in China Reported to Be Safe
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)  The United States liaison office in Peking reported today that all Americans known to be in China survived the severe earthquake that rocked the PekingTientsin area, the White House announced.

title: Although It's 90 in Sun, It's Cooler Than on Inside
description: Outside 277 Park Avenue yesterday, a secretary named Judy Suzuki bit into her tuna sandwich and sighed. It feels good, she said, sitting on a concrete wall in the 90degree noonday sun, to be out here, where it's cooler.

title: Dorf man's Peace of Mind Wins Upstate Show Title
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 28  Peace of Mind, owned by Mark Dorfman of Mendham, N.J., scored 16.3 points to win the junior working hunter championship today at the Orange County Horse Show.

title: Smaller Dollar Coin Considered By Treasury for Vending Trade
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Treasury Department is considering issuing a new smaller Si coin primarily for use in vendine machines.

title: Dodgers at the Mercy of Niekro's Knuckler and Bat
description: Wild pitches and hit batsmen are not uncommon for knuckleballers. Atlanta's Phil Niekro has led the National League in both categories at one time or another.

title: Clouding the Air
description: Whatever the legal merits to his argument, Mayor Beame is not helping the city by challenging a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into New York's fiscal practices over years past.

title: Dance: Les Noces
description: Jerome Robbins's Les Noces is a kind of freak of art. The Stravinsky score was first staged by Broil:slava Nijinska in 1923, and she revived it for the Royal Ballet in London in 1966. It is a stunning and fantastic ballet, one of those few but pungent works that Nijinska has left to posterity.

title: Air Controllers Will Slow Traffic by Sticking to Rules,
description: In a move that could cause significant slowdowns in air travel, the air traffic controllers union, which is involved in a salary dispute, called on members yesterday to handle aircraft by the book.

title: Rail Signal Setup Is Cited In Fatal Connecticut Crash
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 28The first official report on the rushhour train crash at the New Canaan station two week! ago attributes at least part of the cause to the station's primi tive signal system and recom. mends that it be upgraded or an emergency basis.

title: Pirates Top Mets in 13th With Homer
description: It's a long, long time from April to October, but the starts are dwindling down to a precious few for Torn Seaver.

title: MONDALE ADJUSTS TO ROLE AS 2D MAN
description: PLAINS, Ga. July 28When Senator Walter F. Mondale arrived here late last Saturday) night, he was greeted at the old depot by Jimmy Carter, who told the crowd of tourists and townspeople that I've never had the slightest doubt that I made the right choice. That was only nine days after he had announced Mr. Mondale as his choice for running mate.

title: Film: French The Clockmaker,
description: Michel Descombes (Philippe Noiret) is a Lyons clockmaker by trade and by nature an observer of the rules. He waits for the walk sign before crossing the street, even when there are no cars and no policemen in sight. When he is asked if he is a widower he considers the question with care. His wife, he says, left him many years earlier, but she is now dead. Yes, he supposes, he is a widower at least technically. Michel is not a fussy or fearful man, but to the extent that he ponders the inner workings of his life, he values order and accuracy.

title: 3 Shot in a 2Block Area Of East Side in Half Hour
description: Three men were shot last night within two blocks of or.e another on the Lower East Side, reportedly by three different assailants brandishing pistols and yelling obscenities, the police said. The gunmen escaped by mingling in the crowds that had gathered outside to seek relief from the muggy summer night.

title: Agnew Heads Foundation Sympathetic to Palestinians
description: Former Vice President Spirt T. Agnew has taken over the presidency of a non profit educational foundation that ad. vacates a buildup of American nuclear arms, is critical of America's policy of detente with the Soviet Union and expresses sympathy for Palestinian refugees in the Middle East.

title: A Thirst for Justice Troubling Chowchilla
description: CHOWCHILLA, Calif.. July 25 The sign in front of the Madera Methodist Church in the county seat a few miles from here usually carries a verse of Scripture or a prayer. Today it carried a different plea:

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, July 28As a prelude to hearings on a bill to restore the death penalty in New Jersey, state prison officials today displayed the death house and the longidle electric chair at the state prison here to an entourage of reporters.

title: In Memoriam
description: BECKENSTEINFannie, July 29, 1971. In loving memory of a cherlshed mother. Forever In our hearts and lhoughls. Her Family.

title: CHINA PREDICTED BIG EARTHQUAKE
description: American specialists in earthquake prediction who returned last month from a visit to China were shown, while there, evidence of ominous magnetic changes in the Tientsin area and were told that a major quake was expected in northeast China before the 1980's.

title: Olympic Sidelights
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 28Nadia Comaneci, whose three gold medals and perfect gymnastic scores made the 14yearold the darling of the Olympics, came home yesterday to the cheers of an overwhelming crowd. But all was not joyous. Miss Comaneci, a collector of dolls from foreign countries, was upset because the head of one of her dolls fell off on the trip from Montreal.

title: U.S. Is Assured 7 Boxing Medals
description: MONTREAL, July 28If trading punches with Teofilo Stevenson of Cuba can be considered an opportunity, Johnny Tate of Knoxville, Tenn., gets that chance tomorrow in the semifinals of Olympic boxing.

title: Chess: Petrosian Applies Pressure, But the Bonitos Bacardiles
description: Spectal to The New York Times BIEL, Switzerland, July 27 Bent Larsen of Denmark increased his lead by achieving. 8 points after 11 rounds of the Interzonal Tournament for world championship aspirants here in the Konaresshaus.

title: EDWARD DEUSS, 79; STATE DEPT. AIDE
description: Edward Louis Deuss, a former journalist and retired State. Department employee, did Friday at the Jefferson Memorial Hospital in Charlestown, W. Va. He was 79 years old and lived in Great Falls. Va.

title: Landslide Kills 11 in Japan
description: UTSUNONIYA, Japan, July 28 (Reuters)A landslide killed 11 workers at a golf course construction site near here today. Rescue workers said one person was missing and three were injured. Most of the dead, including five women, were farm workers employed at the site temporarily.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 29, 1976

title: UWE INDEX OFF BY 0.46 ON AMEX
description: In another lowvolume day, stocks on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday, with the market value index closing at 103.73, off 0.46.

title: Beame Is Astonished
description: Mayor Beame declared yesterday that he was astonished at the suggestion that he and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin were not cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission and vowed that they would testily despite a concurrent action challenging the commission's right to investigate the New York City government.

title: Mobil and Socal Profits Up Moderately; General Foods Quarter Net Gains 60.4%
description: The Mobil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday; moderate earnings advances for the second quarter and the first half of 1976.

title: Youth Shot, 9 Persons Held In Outbreak in Chester, Pa.
description: CHESTER, Pa., July 28 (AP) Three persons were injured, including one youth who was shot, and nine persons were arrested today when violence with racial overtones broke out here.

title: Cuban to Run in 400 Today
description: MONTREAL, July 28The great debate between Alberto Juantorena and his wife, Yria, is not whether he can win Olympic gold medals in the 800and 400meter runs but whether their 18monthold daughter will become a gymnast or quartermiler.

title: U.S. Releases 200 Pages Of Pentagon Papers Data
description: WASHO:GTON. July 28 (AP) The Justice Department unsealed data about a fiveyearold secret but the substance, of the data was common knowledge all along.

title: New Prison Watchdog
description: In 1960, two years after he finished divinity school, the Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, who was appointed chairman of the State Commission of Correction yesterday, visited

title: Josephine M. Lazarus, 58, Director of Checker Cab
description: Josephine Markin Lazarus of Ossining, N.Y., a director of the Checker Taxi Company of Chicago and an interior decorator, died Tuesday of leukemia in Phelps Memorial Hospital. North Tarryton, N.Y. She. was 58 years old..

title: Russians Struggle to Begin Again in New York
description: Ciara and Abram David. vitch spent the first 50 years of their lives in Odessa, U.S.S.R. On June 25, bearing two oneway tickets and a piece of paper printed with the Brooklyn telephone number of a friend of a friend from Odessa, and not a great deal besides, the Davidovitches arrived at Kennedy International Airport in a planeload of Russian Jewish immigrants.

title: Books of The Times
description: One winter morning, in the middle of my fiveyear wait to determine if the operation for breast cancer had been successful, Doris Schwerin noticed a pair of pigeons nesting on a ledge across from her kitchen window. There were two eggs resting on dried grass and twigs, like large pearls laid on luxurious brown velvet cloth. Winter seemed an unpropitious time for birds to nest, but then, whatever their faults, which are several, New York pigeons are a temerarious lot.

title: Market Place
description: The National SeMiConauctor Corporation surprised Wall Street after the close of trading Tuesday with an announcement that manufacturing problems with semiconductor digital watch components would depress profits in the current quarter.

title: Incendiary Device Found In Korvettes at 34th Street
description: A incendiary device concealed in a cigarette pack was discovered yesterday in the men's clothing department at Korvettes Department store on 34th Street in Manhattan.

title: Yankees
description: BATTING

title: A 3County Olympics
description: RUTHERFORD, July 28The best of the Olympic spirit without the team competitions was colorfully evident all over Memorial Field today as 672 children from Bergen, Passaic and Hudson Counties took part in the third annual Playground Day.

title: Soviet Scoffs at Korchnoi's Bid For Asylum in the Netherlands
description: MOSCOW, July 28  The Soviet chess star. Viktor Korchnoi, was officially attacked today for his defection in Amsterdam as Tass, the Soviet press agency, called him ambitious, vain and unsporting.

title: Tank Truck Explodes
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 28 (UPI) At least one person was killed when a tank truck exploded early today on the Ohio Turnpike, temporarily closing a section of the eastwest toll road. The Ohio Highway Patrol said that the truck, loaded with an unidentified explosive liquid, burst into flames at 5:30 A.M. The accident occurred in heavy fog.

title: TEAMSTER IS SILENT AT INQUIRY ON HOFFA
description: DETROIT, July 28 (AP)One witness took the Fifa Amendment and two other: sought unsuccessfully to avoid testifying today before a Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of James R. Hoffa. Mr. Hoffa, the former teamsters union president, disappeared one year ago this Friday. He reportedly believed he. was on his way to meet Anthony Provenzano, a New Jer sey teamster figure, the day he vanished.

title: 20 More Evacuated From Area in Italy Hit by Poison
description: SEVESO, Italy, July 281 (AP)Authorities evacuated 20 more persons today and extended by several miles the zone regarded as dangerously polluted by a cloud of chemicals from a Swissowned plant.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A Revolutionary Saint Laurent Showing
description: PARIS, July 28Yves Saint Laurent presented a fall couture collection today that will change the course of fashion around the world. It is as stunning in its impact as the collection Christian Dior showed in 1947, the one that came to be known as the New Look and affected the way women dressed everywhere.

title: CRACKING JAll BY NAT ADDERLEY
description: Quartet, Now at Hopper's, Has Energetic Style

title: Total of Medicare Fraud Put at $300 Million a Year
description: WASHINGTON. July 28American doctors are stealing more than $300 million a year from Medicare by padding bills, falsifying claims and participating in kickback schemes, Senator Frank E. Moss, chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Long Term Care, charged today.

title: Use of National Guard At Convention Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)A government employee's union has formally protested to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld about assignment of Kansas National Guard units to duty during the Republican National Convention at Kansas City, Mo.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: LONDON, July 28 (UPI)A Parliamentary committee said today that the troubled British Chrysler automobile subsidiary might still collapse despite a $291.6million Government rescue operation last January.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
Last Round for U.S. World's Fair Pavilion?
description: The United States Pavilion of the 196465 World's Fair will soon be felled by the wrecker's ball unless its last defenders can save the plundered hull and refurbish it for a new life.

title: Patient Summerell Getting Chance to Take Giant Step
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 29The entry under Carl Summerell's name in the Giants yearbook reads: Personal: Carl Leight Summerell was born on Dec. 6, 1951 in Norfolk, Va., and starred in football and baseball at Kellam H.S. As a youngster, he was a top Little League player and competed in the Punt, Pass and Kick program....

title: When Movies Were Better Than Ever
description: THE BLACKGOWNED SOPRANO, perched atop glistening white piano, sang a 1920's torch song. Her audience sat in reverential silence. The singer was the late Helen Morgan, famed for her rendition My Bill in Show Boat, here doing a lesserknown lament. What Wouldn't I Do for That Man? in the 1929 film Glorifying the American Girl: The audience was composed of about 70 moviegoers ranging in age from the 20's to the 60's, many of them habitus of Theatre 80 St. Marks, dedicated showcase for old movies.

title: A Party in the Tuileries Leaves Parisians Divided
description: PARIS, July 29The Tuileries gardens, the splendidly pruned and sculptured scene of French elegance and violence over the centuries, are the center of a new controversy.

title: Miss Comaneci to Visit
description: CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI)Nadia Comaneci, the Rumanian gymnast, and her 1976 Olympics teammates will visit Chicago for a performance in October, it was announced today. Mayor Richard J. Daley's director of special events, Jack Reilly, said Miss Comaneci and her teammates would arrive in Chicago on Oct. S and would perform at Chicago Stadium either Oct. 9 or Oct, 10.

title: Where to Catch the Train
description: The Steam Passenger Service Directory lists the following details about steam and electric trolley operations Within or near the metropolitan region:

title: Gold CasterAccused Of Tapping the Mold To Enrich Himself
description: In addition to casting gold rings and other jewelry at the Wilber Casting Company in Buffalo, 26yearold Daniel T. Sanders has been pouring little bars of gold for himself over the last two years, the police charged yesterday.

title: A Ferry Museum Opens on S.I.
description: With the clang of an old bronze bell from the 1919 ferryboat Captain Clayton and a ceremonial cutting of ribbon, the city's Transportation Administration yesterday opened a maritime museum on Staten Island that is unusual in two respects. It is the only one devoted solely to ferryboat history, and it cost the city no money to establish.

title: Ford Gains in South And Asks Firmness By Pennsylvanians
description: WASHINGTON, July 29President Ford gained today fresh support in the Deep South for his candidacy, and he urged the big, friendly Pennsylvania delegation to stand fast with him at the Republican National Convention.

title: S. E. C. SETS DATE TO EAR BEAME
description: The Securities and Exchange) Commission said yesterday that Mayor Beame and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin had agreed to testify in September on the city's fiscal troubles, but had first sought to defer the testimony until after a legal challenge by the city to the S.E.C. was completed.

title: State Auditors Find New York City Lax About Dil Deliveries
description: The New York State Department of Audit and Control said yesterday that it had found that oil deliveries to City Housing Authority buildings were not being checked adequately.

title: Strong Quake Shakes Caucasian Oil Area
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI)An earthquake struck a major oilproducing region in the Caucasus last night, officials reported today.

title: 8 Holdout Tenants at Closed Shelton Towers Win 5Year Fight
description: Eight tenants who have been holed up in the old Shelton Towers hotel for the last five years, at average rents of $3 a day, now face the prospect of eviction from their lonely, musty premises because the hotel may soon become a Holiday Inn after renovation.

title: U.S. Says Russia Is Arming More Missiles With MIRV's
description: WASHINGTON. July 29 (AP) The Soviet Union has begun! installing multiple nuclear warheads on the intermediaterange missiles arrayed along its Western border, President Ford told Congress today in an annual arms control report.

title: Japanese Accused of Taking Lobster
description: PORT NEWARK, July 29The Japanese fishing vessel Ookuni Niaru was seized by the Coast Guard last night for allegedly taking lobster from the Continental Shelf in violation of United States law. The ship was brought here this morning to await a decision by Jonathan Goldstein, United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Amex Prices Drift Lower In Dull Day
description: Prices continued to drift lower on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, where the i market value index closed at 103.56, down 0.17 in quiet trading

title: Turkish Research Vessel in Aegean
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 29 (Reuters)  A Turkish oil exploration ship sailed into the Aegean Sea today, watched closely by Greece, which disputes Turkey's claims to seabed mineral rights in the area.

title: 50 Poles Jailed in Price Riots
description: WARSAW, July 29 (Reuters) More than 50 Poles have been sentenced in the aftermath of riots last month against food price increases and trials are continuing, a Government spokesman said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JULY 30, 1976

title: The Labor Scene
description: No matter which candidates win in November, it is a safe bet that a significant focus of White House and Congressional interest in the next four years will be on measures to turn workers into capitalists through governmental encouragement of employee stock ownershin.

title: Balm for the G.O.P.
description: KINGS POINT, N.Y.  Whether Ronald Reagan's selection of Senator Richard S. Schweiker as his running mate will prove to be a brilliant maneuver or a boomerang remains to be seen but it clearly has deepened the split in Republican ranks. For months a feeling of gloom has permeated the party and now there is a widespread notion that the nomination won't be worth a cent, that many voters will defect to. Jimmy Carter or just stay home.

title: Karen Quinlan Is Still Breathing Strongly on Her Own
description: TRENTON. July 29Karen Anne Quinlan is still breathing strongly on her own, free of the mechanical respirator once thought vital to sustain life.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Pro Football Braces for a Full Weekend
description: All 28 of the National Football League's teams will be in action this weekend with the first full schedule of preseason games on tap. There are 11 tomorrow, beginning About Pro Football in the afternoon with Cleveland against Baltimore at Lincoln, Neb., where the Browns drew 46.000 lest year against Atlanta. The only televised games this weekend will involve the local teams, the Jets at St. Louis tomorrow night (Channel 5, 8 o'clock) and the Giants against New England at Foxboro, Mass., on Sunday night (Channel 11 at 8).

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: My son doesn't need an allowance, said a New Jersey father of a 14yearold. Whenever he needs money. I give it to him.

title: Gold Caster Accused Of Tapping the Mold To Enrich Himself
description: In addition to casting gold rings and other jewelry at the Wilbar Casting Company in Buffalo, 26yearold Daniel T. Sanders has been pouring little bars of gold for himself over the last two years, the police charged yesterday.

title: Fidrych Bows to Orioles
description: DETROIT, July 29 (AP) Rudy May fired a sixhitter for his second shutout of the season  both against Detroit  and the Baltimore Orioles scored an unearned run that hint the Tigers and Mark Fidrych, the rookie star, 10, tonight.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, July 29, 1976 (In bushels. 000 omitted)

title: Drug Program Pressured To Oust Felon as Its Chief
description: A 52yearold Bronx cornmunity figure continues to direct a city and federally financed drugtreatment program in the South Bronx seven months after he was convicted on charges of conspiring to! bomb construction sites and tol extort money from building contractors.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDING'S

title: 15 of 16 Legislators Absent at DeathPenalty Hearing
description: TRENTON, July 29Only one of the 16 legislators on the Senate and Assembly Judiciary Committees showed up today to hear the public's views on restoring the death penalty in New Jersey.

title: How to Get Tickets
description: Tickets to the Brogue Opera Company's productions William Shield's Rosina and The Music Master (attributed to Pergolesi) are available at the, box office, ETC Theater, 182 Fifth Avenue (near 23d Street). Prices for Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M. are $3 for general admission and $2 for students and the elderly. or further information call 9249418 after noon.

title: Miss Rost Rides 3 Jumping Victors
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y.. July 29Robin Ann Rost, an 18yearold rider from Branchville, N.J., piloted the winners of three juniper classes today at the Orange County Horse Show.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Public Service Commission has granted the New York Telephone Company permission increase its rates by 8 cents a month for each residential telephone and 13 cents a month for each business telephone, effective this Sunday. The increase, technically tariff being added to a general rate increase granted last year, will permit the company to recover the cost of higher wages stipulated in union contracts.

title: Publishing: What the Rabbi Did on Wednesday
description: FOLLOWERS OF Harry Kemelman's Rabbi David Small, who solves cases of mayhem and murder with Talmudic astuteness, will be happy to learn that a new Rabbi book is due in the fall after a twoyear hiatus.

title: Energy Output Tripled In 25 Years, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29Global production of energy has tripled over a 25year period, according to a United Nations statistical study that also found that the per capita level of consumption of energy in industrialized countries was 16 times that of the world's developirrg countries.

title: Connally, in Nonpolitical Talk, Says He, Too, Farmed Peanuts
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 29 John B. Connally said today that he was a peanut farmer, too.

title: A SOVIET SWIMMER DEFECTS IN CANADA
description: MONTREAL, July 29  A Soviet diver has become the second Communist country athlete participating in the Olympic games to defect and there were unconfirmed reports of a third.

title: A's Tanner Decries Tainted
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 29 (AP)  On an ordinary night, 11 walks surrendered by a team during a single game would lift a manager's blood pressure, as well as his pitchers earnedrun averages.

title: 2 Airmen and Woman Held At Wyoming Missile Base
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  The Air Force said today that two airmen and a female companion have been apprehended after security officers discovered an open hatch lead ing to a Minuteman missile launching silo at Warren Air Force Base, Wyo.

title: Saint Laurent Impact Seems Certain but How Much and When?

There is, however, little consensus as to the degree.

title: Ford Gets Television Aide
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) William H. Carruthers, an independent Los Angeles television producer, has joined the White House temporarily as television consultant. Mr. carruthers will succeed Bob Mead, President Ford's radiotelevision consultant. He is expected to be on the staff of David Gergen, the new director of White House communications, with whom he worked on President Richard Nixon's campaign in 1972.

title: Mrs. Abzug Hails Carter View On Limited Nuclear War Idea
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, yesterday praised Jimmy Carter's warning about the military concept of limited nuclear warfare.

title: BONN VOTES CURB FOR TERRORISTS
description: BONN, July 29The upper house of the West German Parliament approved a controversial law against terrorism today, enabling judges to reaa letters between jailed terrorists and lawyers. The law also provides for jail terms of as many as 10 years for convicted terrorist ringleaders.

description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Zambian charges against South Africa.

description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the nation's money supply had moved up in the latest reporting week, while business loans at leading New York City banks declined again.

title: United Press International
description: FOREIGN POLICY BRIEFING for Jimmy Carter is conducted at Plains, Ga., by Dr. Zbigniew Brzezinski, left, of Columbia University. With them is Stuart Eisenstat, Mr. Carter's issues and policies director. Details on Page A6.

title: A Mass Walkout Held by Students In Soweto Schools
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 29 UPI)Thousands of black schoolchildren staged a walkout from their classes today and arsonists set four more schools ablaze as unrest spread in black townships.

title: Schlee and Wadkins, With 65's, Lead by Shot
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 29 (AP)John Schlee and Lanny Wadkins equaled the course record with sixunderpar 65's and withstood afternoon charges to share a onestroke lead today in the opening round of the $200,000 Pleasant Valley Golf Classic.

description: Where there is a will, as the philosopher says, there is a way. Thus, Rudolf Nureyev continues his remarkable season of daily appearances with the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House this weekend.

title: Business in Argentina
description: BALCARCE, ArgentinaRainfall sweeping across the farmlands of the pampas has revived Argentine hopes for quick deliverance from foreign debts and economic recession through a big wheat and corn harvest this year.

title: SYRIANS AND P. L. 0. REACH AGREEMENT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization signed an agreement tonight that might lead to another ceasefire in Lebanon, but it is not expected to solve the problems underlying the crisis in the country.

title: Weekend Gardening
description: This spring, we had a bumper crop of daffodil leaves. Lush reedlike islands of plants, measuring one to two feet across, dotted the beds along our stone walls, and every now and then two or three yellow trumpets might be caught sight of in the middle of all the greenery. The plants had not been divided for years and were developing a profusion of new bulbs, but next to no flowers. If, like mine, your daffodils were more plant than flower this spring, now is the time, to set things right for next year.

title: ArcsBates Move Put Off; Castle Reports Payments

title: Art: A Continuum
description: CONTINUUM is one of those words that critics tend to wince at, especially when it is used by artists to describe their work. (When critics use the word, as they sometimes do, they tend to wince a little less.) It is the kind of word that causes a certain blur in the mind. It seems to promise an artor at least an experience without limits or boundaries, an art of seamless continuities, yet it is often attached to an art whose limits are all too apparent. It induces an expectation of oceanic dimension, but it may only mean that the artist has covered a large canvas with a single color.

title: Restaurants
description: The other day in checking over a list of onestar to threestar restaurants, I discovered that one out of every 15 had folded since this time last year. The briefest life on the list was Le Colisee's, which suffered every form of bad luck known to restaurants plus one not frequently encountered, a holdup in which both the chef and the proprietor were shot. There was a hex on the place. Undeterred, a new restaurant called Pronto has opened the remodeled quarters. If there are any gremlins left around the place, they are limiting their pranks so far minor harassments, such as oversalting the fettucine and mixing up the orders between kitchen and table.

title: Books of The Times
description: PEOPLE HAVE BEEN pressing me lately to recommend some current books for them to take away on vacation. Naturally, my mind instantly goes blank. Then it wants to tell them about a woman I know who spends part of every summer rereading Remembrance of Things Past. But just in case my assailants are representative, here's a checklist, arranged alphabetically within category, of 11 nonfiction works and 10 novelspublished so far this yearthat have struck me as especially worthwhile, entertaining or both.

title: Antiques
description: SOME call it the Cinderella of the pressedglass world. Others describe it as the poor man's Tiffany. Whatever its designation, thousands collect carnival glass, which was made throughout the first three decades of this centurysome of it was given away amusement parks. And this interest has sparked the formaton of several collecting societies, the publication of a book on the subject, an increase in specialty auctions and the appearance at flea markets and in garage sales of this iridescent ware which, unlike blown Tiffany glass, was pressed and surfaced with a metallic acid solution. Although the carnival glassmakers sought to reproduce the look of Tiffany, what they achieved lacked the delicacy and grace In form and color of the originals.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 The Association of American Railroads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads for the week ended July 24 totaled an esti mated 14.8 billion ton miles, 7 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 453,634 cars, 5 percent above the 1975 figure for the same week. The AmericanTrucking Association of America Inc. said that intercity truck tonnage for the same week was up 6.4 percent from the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Up From Below
description: New York's Bicentennial celebration the thrill of the Tall Ships, the joy of the celebration In downtown Manhattan and the glorious fireworks displayhas passed into history, but the happy memories linger on. Millions of neonle from the metropolitan area converged on our city on Sunday, July 4, and most got home as easily as they had arrivedby public transportation. It was perhaps mass transit's finest hour.

title: Screen: Beached 'Swashbuckler"
description: THE time is 1718. The place is the island of Jamaica. It is a day of incredible, luminous clarity. In the courtyards of the British fort overlooking the sea an execution by hanging is being prepared. A junior officer sees an ominous spar on the horizon, but his commander won't hear of interruptions. The chaplain coughs. "I find no prayer for a pirate," he says mildly. "The closest I came is something by Peter for fishermen. . . ."Before the hanging can take place, the ominous spar on the horizon turns out to be the pirate ship Blarney Cock, under the command of Capt. Ned Lynch who has come to cheat the noose of the life of his associate, Nick Debrett. There is a pitched battle, Nick escapes, and the new pirate adventure, "Swashbuckler," should be off and running. It's not. It's off and sinking.The film, which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, has hardly anything to recommend it unless, like me, you'll put up with all sorts of gaffes for even the dimmest recollection of a kind of fiction that once made childhood tolerable."Swashbuckler," which was directed by James Goldstone and written by Jeffrey Bloom, was photographed largely around Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, on land and seascapes of storybook beauty. Doubling as the Blarney Cock is an exquisitely lovely reproduction of Sir Francis Drake's ship, the Golden Hind, and the cast includes Robert Shaw, James Earl Jones, Genevieve Bujold, Beau Bridges and Peter Boyle, all people of proven talents. Yet the movie is such a mess you might suspect it was tacked together by nearsighted seamstresses.The screenplay is full of lines that either are arch ("A pirate in love is like a fish out of water") or are failed anachronisms ("We're pirates, Ned, not revolutionaries." "Pirates  revolutionarieswe're all men"). Worse, though, is a plot that is skimpy on incident, acted by people who have been mostly miscast.As the pirate captain, Mr. Shaw, a good character actor, works extremely hard to create a figure of romantic dash but produces only sweat. He'd have been much better as the wicked governor, a role played by Peter Boyle, who might possibly have been more convincing as an eccentric deckhand than as an effete fellow who takes hot tubs with his lute player (male).Genevieve Bujold is charming as the swordswomandaughter of a man wrongly imprisoned by the governor, but it's a very, very silly role. Mr. Jones is also wasted as Captain Lynch's best pal. Mr. Jones is a star and looks foolish in what is essentially the Alan Hale part. But then Beau Bridges is also a star, and he's on screen for less time than the opening credits.A strong director might have imposed some order on the project, but Mr. Goldstone is not such a person. "Swashbuckler" seems to want to be high adventure, but it has no cohesive style, no exuberance. It looks like slogging, joyless hard work."Swashbuckler" has been rated PG, in recognition, I suppose, of a couple of scenes in a busy whorehouse and the dopey reference to the governor's homosexuality, which this mindless film equates with political corruption.

title: BURGLARY REPORT DELAYED BY F.B.I.
description: DENVER, July 29Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington delayed for eight days earlier this month the decision to report to the police here that one of the bureau's paid informer had burglarized the Denver office of the Socialist Workers Party, according to a Federal official familiar with the matter.

title: September Contracts Dip In Wheat and Soybeans
description: Grains and soybeans traded quietly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, lacking the incentive of important news to stimulate a sharp move either way. September wheat closed at $3.45, down 4 cents bushel, while September corn was unchanged at $2.81 bushel. September soybeans declined 3 cents a bushel ,to $6.27.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in The Times on May 25 incorrectly stated that Neil Albert Salonen. president of the . Unification Church, had been a member of the church since 1959. He ioined the church in 1967. The same article incorrectly stated that Mr. Salonen told the Internal Revenue Service in 1974 that there was no relation between the Freedom Leadership Foundation and the Unification Church other than the fact that they had some members and officers in common. The statement was made in 3973.

title: CAREY RECALLING THE LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Carey announced late yesterday that he was summoning the Legislature into a special session next Wednesday in an effort to gain anproval of a package of constitutional amendments on court reorganization, even though leaders of the Assembly and Senate remain in angry disagreement over which to enact.

title: U.S. Lends Egypt $93 Million
description: CAIRO, July 29 (UPI)Egypt will receive $93 million from the United States under three loan agreements signed today by Economy Minister Mohammed Zaki Shafei and the American Ambassador, Hermann F. Eilts.

title: OffDuty Woman Officer Is Stabbed in a Holdup
description: An offduty woman police officer was stabbed in the arm and stomach and robbed of her purse, gun and shield last night when she and a woman friend were accosted by a knifewielding man in an elevator in Harlem.

title: SUMMER JOBLESS PUSH TOTALS UP
description: A seasonal surge into the labor market of vacationing students and new graduates pushed up unemployment in New York City and New York State last month, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: The Games Spectators Play, Such as MatchtheLabel
description: PARIS, July 29In case you're wondering where anybody wears all those Paris couture creations, one place is the city of its origin, especially during the time when the new collections are being shown.

title: Pop Life
description: THE MARDI GRAS INDIANS, black carnival societies of New Orleans, are a bizarre amalgam of authentic folklore and Hollywood myth. They first appeared during the years immediately following the Civil War, when gangs of black youths would dress in costumes decorated wan beads, eggshells and bits of broken glass, and parade through their neighborhoods on Mardi Gras day, drinking, carousing and brandishing knives, guns and sharpened curtain rods. When one gang met another, warfare erupted. There were so many killings the very sight of Indians marching down a street was enough to terrorize residents.

title: Bronx Woman Is Shot to Death As Shooting Outbreak Spreads
description: An 18yearold woman was shot to death in front of her Bronx apartment building early yesterday when an unidentified gunman reportedly walked upi and opened fire as she sat in a doubleparked car chatting with a young woman friend who had just driven her home.

description: Guy Flatley

title: Carey Signs Bill to Curb Takeovers
description: Governor Carey signed a bill yesterday that would impose procedural restrictions on the growing number of unfriendly tender offersthe gambit employed by acquisitionminded companies to buy out shareholders of other corporations.

title: Soviet Newspaper Reports on Cruelty At Kazakhstan Zoo
description: MOSCOW, July 29A bizarre tale of cruelty and neglect in Soviet zoo was told today by a Moscow newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda.

title: A Woman Swimmer Returns With Medals, Bad Memories
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 29Wendy Lansbach Boglioli returned to her alma mater today with two heavy necklaces adorned by the bronze and gold Olympic medals she won swimming at Montreal.

title: REPORT SAYS GUARDS SAW VAN'S BURIAL

title: GIBBON REPORTS ON 50 PROJECTS

title: Red Smith
description: ILE D'ANTICOSTI, Quebec, July 29We hold these truths to be selfevident: that if God had intended man for racing, He would have given him four legs like a horse; and that the only sensible way to travel is in a yellow convertible with the Lop down. With Montreal heaving and panting with footracers in this second week of the Olympics, it was obviously the right time to put children's games aside and come off to Anticosti Island to kill salmon. Anticosti lies in the Gulf of St. Lawrence northeast

title: Study Assails Sponsors on TV Violence
description: The National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, Washingtonbased public interest organization released yesterday the results of a professional monitoring study that identified the television advertisers whose commercials were most prevalent in violent entertainment programs during the last six weeks.

title: Christians Besiege Lebanon City of Tripoli
description: BSHERRL Lebanon, July 26Seen from olive groves two miles to the south, the coastal city of Tripoli rises on the horizon like a child:s twodimensional drawing of a city on the moon. The high rise buildings have no aeptn and no shadows. Their color is a uniform watery gray. There are no signs of life or movement. No smoke is com ing from the stacks.

title: Viking to Try Organic Soil Test Again
description: PASADENA, Calif., July 29While Viking I analyzed Martian soil samples for signs of life, project engineers here) were devising plans today fori the spacecraft to make anotherl attempt next week io obtain soil for organic chemical, examination.

title: Mrs. Johnstone Leads Jersey Golf
description: PARAMUS, N.J., July 29 Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair increased her lead to four strokes today with a twoday total of 168 at Arcola Country Club in quest of her third straight Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54hole strokeplay championship.

title: Wife and Doctor Help Robinson Cap Long Climb in Long Jump
description: MONTREAL, July 29They call it Kelton Hill, the piece of unused real estate that sits next to a highway in San Diego and runs almost straight up.

title: Brezhnev Says U.S. Meddles In Italy to Bar the Communists
description: MOSCOW, Friday, July 30 (AP)Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has accused the United States and other Western nations of being ready to take Italy by the throat just to keep Communists out of its government.

title: Reagan and Credibility
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Ronald Reagan's strongest asset in his quest of the Republican Presidential nomination was his credibility among those in the party's dominant right wing But his designation of a liberal, Senator Richard S. Schweiker of Pennsylvania, as his prospectse running mate has seriously jeopardized that trustand Mr. Reagan's prospects for the nomination.

description: HOUSTON, July 26Just as Cervantes and Shakespeare said it would, the once trodupon worm has turned.

title: Witnessesin Quake Area Describe Rescue Efforts
description: CHINHUTANGTAO, China. July 29 (Agence FrancePresse)Large numbers of relief workers, many of them servicemen. were seen today on the regions devastated by yesterday's earthquake.

title: Phils Beat Cubs, 3 to 2, In the 11th
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (UPI)Tim McCarver singled home Ollie Brown with two out in the 11th inning today to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 32 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Design for Dining: Feasts for the Eye, Too
description: No serious eater will ever admit that anything takes precedence over food in a restaurant, and many restaurantgoers take a certain pride in recounting the ugly rooms and bad service they have suffered through for the supreme joy of the palate. But if food is first, it need not be all; New York is particularly rich in eating places that are as much a feast for the eye as for the stomach. (In a few cases, alas, they are far kinder to the eye.)

title: Neighbors Recall Two Suspects
description: CHOVICHILLA, Calif., July 29On the night of July 14, less than 24 hours before 26 Chowchilla school children and their bus driver were abducted at cunooint and forced into a sweltering nioving van buried underground. Rick and Jim Schoenfeld were laughing and playing cards, a genie of hearts, in a nextdoor neighbor's house in their comfortable suburb of Athertorr.

title: Banks Face Crash
description: WASHINGTON. July 29 (UPI)  Thomas Taylor, Deputy; Comptroller of the Currency, said today he had evidence that some banks were not complying with consumer protection laws and, as a result, his office would conduct a crash examination program to remedy the situation.

title: Bolivia Ends State of Siege
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia. July 29 (Reuter)The Bolivian Government tonight lifted a state of siege imposed on June 9 after labor unrest.

title: AIRLINERS SLOWED BY UNION ACTION
description: Air travel here was badly disrupted yesterday, apparently by a combination of bad weather and the slowdown ordered Wednesday by the traffic controllers union.

title: U.S. Suit Is Seeking $650,000 From Dun On Credit Reports
description: The United States Government filed a $550,000 civil suit against Dun & Bradstreet yesterday seeking to recover double the damages the Government says it sustained as a result of fraudulent credit reports issued by the credit rating concern.

title: Harris Tells Jury Politics Is Not Issue at Coast Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, July 29William Harris, pleading his own case today, asked the jury to judge him and his wife,1 Emily, not on their revolutionary politics but on the facts) that have emerged in their sixweek trial on assault, robbery and kidnapping charges.

Ford was me laSE or LIM domestic auto companies to report its April 1June 30 results. The General Motors Corporation reported record earnings yesterday as did the Chrysler Corporation Monday.

title: Art People
description: THE NEW YORK art scene may seem dead right now, but don't be fooled. It's simply shifted  to Provincetown, East Hampton, Maine and all of the other haunts where New York artists wind down from that OctobertoMay frenzy known as the season.

title: 8 Holdout Tenants at Closed Shelton Towers Win 5Year Fight
description: Eight tenants who have been holed up in the old Shelton Towers hotel for the last five years, at average rents of $3 a day, now face the prospect of eviction from their lonely, musty premises because the hotel may soon become a Holiday Inn after renovation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in The Times on May 25 incorrectly stated that Neil Albert Salonen. president of the Unification Church, had been a member of the church since 1959. He joined the church in 1967. The same article incorrectly stated that Mr. Salonen told the Internal Revenue Service in 1974 that there was no relation between the Freedom Leadership Foundation and the Unification Church other than the fact that they had some members and officers in common. The statement was made in 1973.

title: Critic Takes A Bad Seat And Tells All
description: ONE memorable occasion, Bernard Shaw went to review a play  or perhaps it was a concertand he was placed behind a pillar. He knew exactly what to do. He wrote about the pillar and nothing but the pillar. At length and in detail. The management got the message, and after that Shaw got better seats.

title: Lisbon Government Is Uneasy As Far Right Marshals Forces
description: LISBON, July 30A mass was held for the sixth anniVersary of the death of former dictator Antnio de Oliveira Salazar this weekand many neoule thought it was natural.

title: The Most Terrible Shock
description: PARISThere is particular sadness in the fact that China, which has devoted such special attention to the problem of predicting earthquakes and preparing threatened areas to minimize casualties, should just now have suffered the most terrible shock anywhere on earth during the past twelve years. This has evidently produced Very high loss of human life as well as incalculable physical damage.

title: Last of the Russians Are Leaving Egypt
description: CAIRO, July 30  The number of Soviet military technicians and advisers in Egypt, once well into the thousands, has shrunk to roughly 100 and may reach zero by the end of the year, wellplaced sources sympathetic to Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, reported this week.

title: Italian Leaders Take Up Poison Chemical Problem
description: ROME, July 30Members of the newly installed Italian cabinet met today to discuss the growing problem of an area near Milan that has been affected by a poisonous chemical that escaped into the air after a factory explosion three weeks ago.

description: WASHINGTON. July 30The Ford Administration lost an initial test in the House today on its proposal to let private corporations go into the business of enriching uranium for use as fuel by nuclear power reactors.

title: CURB ON EVIDENCE ON RAPES BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The Justice Department is willing to go along with a proposed new bill to bar in Federal rape cases most evidence concerning a woman's previous sexual conduct.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters)Chairmen of the Federal Reserve Board would be subject to Senate confirmation under a measure approved today by the Senate Banking Committee.

title: A Priest Grows in Brooklyn
description: The absolutely last thing I had in my mind while growing up in Crown Heights, in the shade of the Brooklyn Museum and the public library, was that I would return to the area as a priest.

title: Panel Favors Fewer Layoffs at Hospitals
description: The head of a mayoral task force on municipal hospitals, recommended yesterday that 1,350 employees be laid off770 fewer than had been plan, ned by hospital officials. And] a hospital workers union im; mediately announced plans to strike next Wednesday if the cuts were made.

description: ARCHERYDarrell Pace of Cincinnati and Luann Ryon of Riverside, Calif., captured the gold medals. They had both gone into the final day with substantial leads.

title: HOUSE LOSES MOVE FOR WIRETAP DATA
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) A Federal district judge today blocked a Congressional subcommittee from enforcing a subpoena requiring the American Telephone and Telegraph: Company to turn over its records of secret Government wiretaps installed without court warrants.

title: Jacqueline Onassis Goes to Snug Harbor
description: Jacqueline Onassis took the wheel of a Staten Island ferryboat yesterday on her way back from a visit to the future cultural center at Sailors Snug Harbor and helped pilot herself back to Manhattan.

description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest investorowned insurance enterprise, reported yesterday increases of 119.4 percent in secondquarter net income and 232.6 percent for the first half.

title: CRIME DATA DELAY TIED TO F.B.I. AIDE Denver Agent Said to Have Held Up Burglary Report Despite Bureau Orders
description: DENVER, July 30An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has testified that the bureau's office here delayed for six days earlier this month in notifying the police that one of its informers had been involved in a burglary, despite instructions from bureau headquarters in Washington that the informer's role be made known to the local authorities.

title: Tap on the Wrist
description: The overwhelming House of Representatives vote to reprimand Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, for financial misconduct is better than no censure at all; but it can by no stretch of the imagination be called an adequate response. It is a tap on the wrist for member of the House who has dishonored Congress, not to mention himself, by using his official position for purposes of selfenrichment. But Mr. Sikes colleagues had no stomach for any real action against him.

title: Ford, Seeking Votes, Is Phoning and Flying
description: WASHINGTON, July 30H. Davidson Osgood recalled that it was about 2:30 in the afternoon when the telephone jangled in his office in Portland, Me., and the operator said, Just a minute please, it's the President calling.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The Senate voted today to allow taxfree treatment of certain pensionplan contributions benefiting spouses who have no job outside the home. It applies to both men and women.

title: Eucharist Congress on TV
description: Parts of the 41st International Eucharist Congress, being held in Philadelphia, will he televised live on two stations in New York. Tomorrow WNEWTV will carry the opening ceremonies, from noon to 1:30 P.M. Next Sunday, WABCTV will present the closing ceremonies, from 4:30 to 6 P.M. The first telecast is being originated by Westinghouse Broadcasting and the second by Capital Cities Broadcasting.

title: 2 CITY U. COLLEGES DROP DISMISSALS
description: The threat of dismissal of tenured teachers from the City University's senior colleges)l apparently dissolved yesterday when Brooklyn and Queen Colleges, which had earlier warned that at least 40 teachers could be lost because of, budget cuts, said there would be no such dismissals this year.

description: The Baltimore Orioles seem to be a little too late in the race for the American League's Eastern Division pennant.

title: Pentagon Aide Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) M. Alan Woods, special assistant to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was nominated yesterday by President Ford to replace William I. Greener as assistant defense secretary for public affairs. Mr. Greener resigned to become communications director of Mr. Ford's election campaign.

title: EDWARD B. ROONEY, JESUIT EDUCATOR
description: The Rev. Edward B. Rooney, who for 30 years was president of the National Jesuit Education Association, died yesterday at Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 53 East 83d Street.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Amtel Inc. of Providence. R. I., announced yesterday that it had discovered inventory shortages and other evidence of irregularities in its specialty industries division.

description: Supporters of Roy Wilkins executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, are urging the association's board of directors to keep the 74yearold retiring official In the job until July 1977.

title: Economic Impact of the Quakes Viewed as Severe Only Locally
description: TOKYO, July 30The immediate economic impact of the powerful earthquakes in China's Hopeh Province is likely to be quite severe locally, in the opinion of people here who are informed on Chinese affairs.

title: Italian Pilots End Strike
description: ROME, July 30 (Reuters)Italy's airline pilots decided today to suspend daily strikes over a contract dispute that have been disputing air travel for months, causing Alitalia losses of $2 million a day, the Italian airline announced.

title: Jane White, Actress, Shifts to Cabaret With a Wide Range
description: Jane White, well established on Broadway as an actress, is venturing into cabaret for the first time this week at Alfredo's Sattebello, a new restaurant in the building at Seventh Avenue and 10th Street that previously housed Your Father's Moustache and, before that, was Greenwich Village jazz landmark. Nick's.

title: Japan's Women Top Russians in Volleyball
description: MONTREAL. July 30Before a crowd that waved multitudes of Japanese flags and booed loudly every time the Soviet Union served, the Japanese women's volleyball team routed the Russians, the defending Olympic champions, in three straight games today, 157, 158, 152, for the gold medal.

title: Puerto Rico Air Fare Rises
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed today to let American and Eastern Airlines raise fares between New York and San Juan, P.R., by 1.6 per cent, effective Sunday.

title: In Home of Olympics, Race Is to the Clever
description: OLYMPIA, Greece, July 29 In 776 B.C. the Greeks held the first Olympic Games here on the banks of the Alpheus River, starting it all: the competition and the commercialism, the beauty and the bravado, the grace and the grossness. As the 21st version of the modern Olympics was coming to a close in Montreal this week, Mayor Angelos Koutras sipped the evening air and a glass of beer and mused: We live with this glory. It is all we have. We do not even have a cinema, but we have the glory.

title: Red Cross Offers Help
description: GENEVA, July 30  The League of Red Cross Societies has sent a message of sympathy to Peking and an offer to help the Chinese Red Cross but has not received a reply, league sources said here today.

title: Paul Schreiber, Led Social Work School At Hunter, 195669
description: Prof. Paul Schreiber, dean of Hunter College's School of Social Work from 1956 to 1969, died Thursday evening of a heart attack while attending a concert in Central Park. He was 65 years old and a resident of Hempstead, L.I.

title: The Redwoods: Going, Going

title: Koosman Stops Phils, 32; Allen Put on Disabled List
description: Joe Frazier, the manager of the Mets, seemed as surprised as the 26,548 fans at Shea Stadium last night as his team stifled the firstplace Phillies, 32.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Queens chiropractor was convicted of taking part a scheme to defraud taxpayers out of thousands of dollars by submitting false Medicaid claims for services which were needlessly performed or never performed at all. Federal jury returned a guilty verdict against the chiropractor, Max Kavaler, of 342 Cedarhurst Avenue in Cedarhurst, Queens. He is part owner of Medicaid clinics Corona and Long Island City, Queens, and in Brooklyn, Dr. Kavaler is also a partner in a chiropractic office In Jamaica, Queens, which specialized in treating Medicaid patients.

description: MONTREAL, July 30 (AP) Stan Dziedzic of Slippery Rock (Pa.) College eliminated a twotime Soviet Union world champion and joined five United States teammates in prime medal contention after tonight's Olympic freestyle wrestling.

Hugel, one of the two sailors still living there. Mrs. Onassis was pleased that center will preserve the landmark buildings but, when told that the sailors may be evicted, she replied: Everyone seems so fond of them, referring to Mr. Bugel and Anthony O'Connor, who have refused to leave, I'm sure they'll stay.

title: New York Bight a Pollutant Pit

title: Guadalupe's Ban Stayed

Guadalupe, who is free to ride pending a hearing here Aug. 10 before the State Racing Commission, had been barred for failure to cooperate with authorities investigating the alleged fixing of trifecta races at the track last summer.

title: U.S. Says Army Sea Dump Off Jersey Perils Waters

description: The buttons for sale in the hallway at the convention of New York State's Young Americans for Freedom (YAF) say things like Support Isolationist Foreign Policy and In Gold We Trust.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Cuts Price On Stainless Plate About 6%
description: The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation said in Pittsburgh yesterday that ft was reducing the published prices of its 300series stainless steel plates by about 6 percent, effective with Price Changes shipments beginning on Monday. title: Movie:'Drum' Opens at Loew's State 1
description: There's more hot air than steam in the overwrought melodrama of "Drum," the sequel to the financially successful "Mandingo" that opened yesterday at the Loew's State 1 and Orpheum Theaters. Life at Falconhurst, the Louisiana slave-breeding plantation introduced in the first film, is just as riotously unpredictable as it was when "Mandingo" ended with the plantation master being shot and his best slave being boiled in oil.Some years have now passed and the late master's son, Hammond Maxwell (Warren Oates), is running the business as usual, sleeping with pretty slave girls, while his teenage daughter skips through the honeysuckle making indecent proposals to the male slaves, including Drum, played by Ken Norton, who appeared in "Mandingo" as a different character.Mr. Norton is a fine figure of a man, but no actor. He walks through the film with the gait of a football star coming off the field after a very long game. He can hear the roar of the crowd that we can't. This seeming lack of interest in anyone except himself doesn't help the melodrama, in which Drum is supposed to be a sort of black Joseph Andrews, a young man of such perfection that both men and women (including his white mom) can't keep their hands off him. Vanity is a far cry from innocence  a small point that isn't understood by people who make exploitation junk like this.Kyle Onstott's original novel was adapted for the screen by Norman Wexler and directed by Steve Carver, who may be a bad director or may simply be defeated by material that could only be contained in grand opera. Life on the old plantation was horrendous, I agree, but movies like this are less interested in information than titillation, which, in turn, reflects contemorary obsessions rather more than historical truths.Not since "Mandingo" have I seen a film so concerned with such methods of humiliation as beating, shooting and castration.Among the people in the film who don't look totally ridiculous are Mr. Oates; Fiona Lewis, who plays the fiancee he found in a whorehouse, and Pam Grier, who plays a stunningly beautiful slave woman.

title: The Screen:'Squirm' Shows Worms Turning on People
description: "Squirm," the best horror film that opened all day yesterday at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, seems principally to be about people not paying attention.The setting is the Georgia coast, where the local power company never thinks to turn off the juice when one of its high-tension towers collapses during a thunderstorm. The electricity pouring into the ground stirs up the local worms, who, shocked and angry, come forth by the millions to eat people. The question asked by "Squirm" is not who will survive, but will anyone?The film, written and directed by Jeff Lieberman, has two decent performances by John Scardino and Patricia Pearcy and some effectively revolting moments when it deals with real worms photographed in close-up. It sort of goes to pieces, though, in its spectacle scenes. The sight of a young man sinking slowly up to his eyeballs in worms looks no more terrifying than a busboy having an accident at Mama Leone's. It is spaghetti with meat sauce.

description: Manfried Comfort dozes. Visions of verbal rhumba rattle in his purblind, furlined, ginverved, purloined brain. D.T.s hover near again. A wrist roll, a flash of a brother trying to get his gun in a grave between his knees. Tired, tired of this, though I comfort taxes, and my blue shirtsleeves are storiedsteadied?up with pinching rubber bands. Prostitution that's acceptable. Who? title: Poverty Fund Theft Denied.

title: Carey Tries to Get Public To Back Court Changes
